column2: BRUSSELS The European Free Trade Association "is primarily a means to an end rather than an end in itself."

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 15 Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Stark have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Evelyn Stark, to Geoffrey Richard Woglom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Woglom. A wedding on June 17 here is planned.
The Commissioner of Hospitals conceded yesterday that some unauthorized experiments had been carried out on patients in city hospitals without his knowledge or that of the hospitals' medical boards.
VIENNA Austria, a nation still enjoying a prosperity untouched by unemployment, is facing a new economic fact of life.
A strike by 7,500 city welfare Department workers was scheduled to begin at 7 A.M. today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr's latest venture in his year-long drive to eradicate Chicago slums is encountering resistance at City Hall and apathy in the Negro ghettos.

The Super Bowl game yesterday was also a battle of two networks, the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company, both having televised it. To determine which network most viewers had watched depended on which rating service one read.
In the big plant that once was filled with the aroma of cinnamon buns, coffee rings and muffins with blueberries, the walk-in ovens were cold and the giant batter mixers stood still yesterday.
The city soon will name area administrators to direct urban renewal programs from field offices, rather than from the distant confines of City Hall.

New Yorkers, with their paralyzing transit strike just a year behind them, will hope that Philadelphians have-won swift deliverance from a similar tie-up at the start of a work week this morning. Rapid transit is the lifeline of any great metropolitan center. When the subway, bus and elevated lines stop, a big part of the city's normal activity stops with them.

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor yesterday strongly endorsed a proposal for a meeting between top officials of the Lindsay administration and Federal officials headed by Vice President Humphrey.

Unaccustomed as he was to losing, Coach Adolph Rupp of Kentucky may have come to the end of a long string of winning seasons. Rupp described Kentucky's loss to Florida Saturday night, as "our Waterloo."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 15 (Reuters) All overseas branches of Intra bank will remain frozen until the end of this month, pending talks with American concerns that are aimed at refinancing the bank, Intra Bank sources said here over the weekend.

The audience of 600 in the ballroom of the Commodore Hotel rose yesterday as if by prearranged signal and let loose a barrage of applause. The frail man standing behind the lectern smiled, waved his arms and, when the applause died down, remarked in Yiddish:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) Representative George H. Mahon, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, called today for less talk about peace and more about winning the Vietnam war.
VIENNA Austria, a nation still enjoying a prosperity untouched by unemployment, is facing a new economic fact of life.
A strike by 7,500 city welfare Department workers was scheduled to begin at 7 A.M. today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr's latest venture in his year-long drive to eradicate Chicago slums is encountering resistance at City Hall and apathy in the Negro ghettos.

PARIS, Jan. 15 Queen Juliana of the Netherlands and Baudoin I, King of the Belgians, may be used as diplomatic deterrents to keep President de Gaulle from dominating a proposed high-level meeting of the countries of the European Economic Community in Rome this spring.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark. Poul Petersen is through with farming. "I owe my children reasonable living conditions," he says.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 15 (AP) Ralph Boston posted two quick victories in the first Athens invitation indoor track meet tonight by capturing the 60-yard high hurdles and the long jump within minutes of each other at the new Coliseum Arena.
RYE, N.Y., Jan. 15 The engagement of Miss Shelby Hammitt to Olav Syse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Odd Syse of Oslo, Norway, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Craig Hammitt.

Lieut. Col. Donald Park of its armory at Park Avenue Sherman, past commander of and 33d Street. the Old Guard of the City of New York and of the Centennial Legion of Historic Military Commands, died of cancer Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital on Staten Island. He was 75 years old and lived at 117 Delafield Avenue, Randall Manor, S.I.
GENEVA The harassed Kennedy-round negotiators who are whittling away at the barriers to the free flow of goods overlooked the biggest single item in international trade the tourist.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 15 Syria, the Iraq Petroleum Company and possibly most of all the Iraqi Government are facing a hard winter and spring, as far as oil revenues are concerned. are concerned.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark Danes have entered the new year with a feeling of foreboding.

UNLIKE some of his swinging teammates, Bryan Bartlett Starr, the quarterback for the Green Bay Packers, goes to bed early. He says, "yes, sir" to almost everyone and most notably his coach, Vince Lombardi. He works with a Boy Scout troop and if he has ever tried
BERLIN The slowdown in West Germany's economy showed once again how West Berlin, because of its sensitive position, reacts with special intensity to any shift.
BUDAPEST Strange as it may sound, the Soviet Union has be- come in one basic sense an economic colony of Eastern Europe as a supplier of raw materials.
American and Canadian Jewish leaders yesterday voted a record goal of $115-million in the 1967 worldwide campaign for the sale of Israel bonds.
ROME, Jan. 15 Pope Paul VI warned today against those "who think that charity," without "adherence to the truth of a single faith," is enough for Christian unity.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 15 A Saudi Arabian patrol boat tried to intercept an Israel fishing craft, the Lamerchav in the Gulf of Aqaba today it was reported here. The vessel later reached the Israel port of Elath at the head of the gulf.

Perhaps without realizing it, President Johnson sharply underscored last week the fact that individuals and families could not develop and maintain sound personal financial programs unless they took pertinent news developments into account.
The Soviet Union has placed a two-page advertisement in today's New York Times in an effort to promote foreign trade.

WINNETKA, Ill., Jan. 15-- Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Hunt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Sally Hunt, to Peter Leadbetter Tripp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Tripp of Greenwich, Conn.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within 12 months amount to $108,125,066,055. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 15 Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Searing Hall 3d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Burrowes Hall, to Richard Jordan Warren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. Warren of Bangor, Me.

ENFIELD, N.C., Jan. 16 (UPI) Milton Freier, a former staff photographer with United Press International and a freelance photographer-writer was killed yesterday in a traffic accident four miles north of here. He was 46 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 A study of the economic potential of outdoor recreation and tourism in the economically depressed Appalachian Mountains region has found that a program to develop a vacation industry there would be a mistake.
The Police Department squads charged with removing illegally parked cars struck it rich yesterday as the forbidden area was extended.

The plan to relieve a substantial number of taxpayers from the burden of filling out the city's new income tax form will mean less paperwork for an estimated 500,000 commuters and a million city residents, including all wage-earners with incomes of $6,000 a year or less. And it will also mean savings estimated at $1.5 million for the city.
Nearly 1,000 paintings will be on view tomorrow at the Brooklyn Museum, most of them never seen by generations of the public.
ROME, Jan. 16 "Call me Bambi," said Dolores Francine Rhiney, an American Negro who models in Rome.

New conflicts among state, city and private agencies are continuing to stymie the city's attempts to begin planning the development of new land that will be filled in around the tip of lower Manhattan.

HONG KONG, Jan. 11 Nowhere are the tensions, conflicts and delicate sensibilities engendered by the clash of the Communist giants, China and the Soviet Union, more excruciatingly felt than in North Vietnam.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 16 (AP) Buford Ellington, expressing the belief that "the next four years will bring to Tennessee its greatest era," became its Governor today for the second time and asked citizens to join hands for a "new and better tomorrow."
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 16 Mortimer W. Loewi, an artist, who became a member of the New York Stock Exchange and a pioneer promoter of practical television, died today at the age of 82.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 16 (AP) The Cleveland Teachers Union authorized its leaders today to call a strike at 12:01 A.M. Thursday unless an agreement is reached with the city school board.

BOSTON, Jan. 16 (AP) Dr. Robert J. Van de Graaff, inventor of the Van de Graaff particle accelerator used in nuclear physics research and cancer therapy, died today at Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 65 years old.

Stephen D. James, president of the Citizens Exchange Corps, sent a message Sunday night to President Ho Chi Minh proposing an equal exchange of Americans and North Vietnamese for the purpose of expressing their points of view.
A $21-million libel suit against Seven Arts Productions, Ltd., of Toronto, and its president, Eliot Hyman, has been settled out of court for $265,000, the company announced yesterday.

BONN, Jan. 16 Henri Nannen, editor in chief of the West German magazine Stern, said today that any change in William Manchester's book "The Death of a President" would increase what he said was an impression that the truth was being manipulated.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 Alan Stephenson Boyd was sworn in today as the first Secretary of the new Department of Transportation in a brief ceremony at the White House.

A group of 30 Harlem constituents of Representative Adam Clayton Powell filed suit yesterday in Federal Court to enjoin President Johnson and the House of Representatives from proposing further taxes for their district.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Jan. 16 (Reuters)--The first all-Negro Cabinet in the 300-year history of the Bahamas as a British colony took office today.

ROME, Jan. 16 A common prayer for Christian unity is expected to be ready within a year, Msgr. Gianfrancesco Arrighi, the Under Secretary for the Western Section of the Vatican's Secretariat for Christian Unity, said today.
In a twist of irony, the McCormick Place fire destroyed one of the largest trade exhibits of the year on the very morning it was to open.
"We call this a wife-saver," the salesman said, flipping a switch in the Anchormatic booth at the National Boat Show yesterday.

LE PAVILLON restaurant, whose name has been synonymous with elegance and luxury cuisine since it opened in 1939, has been sold to a group headed by Claude Philippe, the well-known and flamboyant hotelman. The group includes Theodore W. Kheel, the lawyer and labor mediator; Mrs. Alfred Levitt, widow of the builder, and Carl H. Pforzheimer Jr., an investment banker.
ROME, Jan. 16 (Reuters) Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge left by air tonight for Saigon after a long audience with Pope Paul VI.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) --The Supreme Court left it to lower courts today to decide if the General Electric Company properly refused last year to bargain with a committee for the International Union of Electrical Workers that included representatives of seven other unions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 A Los Angeles savings and loan executive testified in Federal District Court here today that he had handed $33,300 to Robert G. Baker in 1962 for distribution to senatorial candidates.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia, who is expected to preside over the forthcoming State Constitutional Convention, said today that he favored the drafting of a "short, simpe, new" basic charter for the state.

Music for oboe and keyboard instruments was played in Carnegie Recital Hall last night by Ronald Roseman, one of the finest oboists around this or any other town, and Gilbert Kalish, a pianist and harpsichordist who is also a skilled and talented musician.
An attractive brown-haired housewife was handling telephoned air-pollution complaints in a city office last night to let New York's millions know that they have a friend with connections.
SKANEATELES, N.Y., Jan. 16--Miss Judith M. Smith and Lieut. Comdr. James G. Partlow, U.S.N., plan to marry April 22.

Danger of an immediate large-scale clash between Israel and Syria has diminished, but whether the two sides now can be persuaded to negotiate a more durable truce at the first meeting in eight years of the Israel-Syria Mixed Armistice Commission remains very doubtful.

MADRID, Jan. 16 The village of Palomares in southeastern Spain, an area where four unarmed American hydrogen bombs fell after a plane collision 2 year ago tomorrow, has been hit by a sudden frost that may have destroyed half of its tomato crop.
TRENTON, Jan. 16 A state commission today urged the construction of a $10.5-million building for the Legislature, which, under reapportionment, has outgrown its two chambers in the State House.

The heated proxy fight for control of Metro-GoldwynMayer, Inc., got hotter yesterday, when the company filed for an injunction against dissident director Philip J. Levin to prevent him from making use of its stockholder list.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 16 Albert DeSalvo, the man who insists he strangled 13 women, was described by a prosecution psychiatrist today as a rather common sociopathic type of criminal who was probably quite sane and in control of his impulses when he committed the sexual assaults charged to him in his trial.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 The Supreme Court ruled today that admissions made by public employes under a threat of dismissal may not be used against them in subsequent criminal trials.
Eli Lilly Co. set records in sales and earnings in 1966, Eugene N. Beesley, president of the pharmaceutical producer, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 Hundreds of community action agencies will have to reorganize their governing boards by March 1 to give one-third of the seats to representatives of the poor.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (UPI) A Federal judge dismissed a $1-million libel suit against Readers Digest magazine today on a defense motion that the United States courts lacked jurisdiction in the case.

The Nederlander family is planning to expand its circuit of legitimate theaters by adding 2,000-seat houses, suitable for dramas or musicals, in Phoenix, (Ariz.), San Francisco, Dallas, Houston and Atlanta. The business is supervised by David T. Nederlander and his five sons.

THE New Jersey Knockout Championships, which ended in West Orange on Sunday, resulted in a victory for the defending champions, Lawrence Rosler of East Orange, N.J., and Jeff Rubens, Roger Stern and Paul Trent, all of New York.
The new boldness of surgeons in entering the heart to correct life-threatening ailments of many types is one of the most striking features of contemporary medicine.

MIAMI, Jan. 16 Sigmund Sommer's El Bonito won the richest and final stakes race of the Tropical Park meeting today, the $61,300 Tropical Park, Handicap, over a muddy track and against a depleted field.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 A one-day strike of the Transport Workers Union against the Philadelphia. Transportation Company was settled early today, and the company moved within hours for fare increases to pay for the new labor contract.

Robert Moses, the president of the World's Fair Corporation, issued a statement yesterday that said "practically all major noteholders" of the fair's bonds had received enormous benefits "far outweighing" the losses they had sustained on the notes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 Allan Nevins, the Pulitzer Prize winning biographer and historian, said today that he believed a publisher's obligation to history is more important than a family's "right" to control a book about one of its members.
LONDON, Jan. 16 Ministers of Britain, the United States, France, West Germany and Italy will meet in England this weekend to explore the possibility of a coordinated reduction of interest rates.

Mrs. Vivian Straus Dixon who was active in charities here for many years, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital after a short illness. Mrs. Dixon, who was the last surviving child of Isidor and Ida Straus who died in the sinking of the Titanic in 1913, lived at 465 Park Avenue. She was 80 years old.
NEWARK, Jan. 16 Gasoline prices have been increased 1 cent a gallon by a large number of service stations in northern New Jersey.
MOSCOW, Jan. 16 (AP) The Soviet theater lacks "really gay, interesting, entertaining plays," a leading playwright said today in a sharp attack on both authors and critics.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 Homebuilding registered another good gain in December, for the second straight month.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 16 (AP) The General Motors Corporation and the White Motors Corporation of Cleveland issued "no comment" statements today on reports that they are negotiating for White's purchase of G.M.'s earthmoving equipment plant in suburban Euclid.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 16 Suspension of two student editors of a weekly campus paper at Johns Hopkins University was revoked today after they expressed "regret" to university officials for a bitter satire on President Johnson last week.

Welfare Department employes, mostly caseworkers, went on strike yesterday for higher pay and improved working conditions. The start of the strike was accompanied by reports of vandalism in 15 of the city's 32 welfare centers.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 16 This morning, on Hsin-yi (Integrity) Street, an eight-foot string of firecrackers exploded next to a huge ceremonial wreath and painted slogans. Passers-by gathered to watch. But it was not a celebration of Peking's troubles. It was the traditional Chinese ballyhoo for a new open-front store, in this case a bakery.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 The Supreme Court will decide whether last year's bank-merger legislation imposes stiff new burdens on the Government in its suits to block such mergers.
Interest rates dropped dramatically in the Eurodollar market yesterday, touching off rippling circles of repercussion throughout foreign exchange markets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) President Johnson announced today the resignation of Raymond Telles as Ambassador to Costa Rica and the selection of Clarence A. Boonstra, a career Foreign Service officer, to succeed him.
PANGIM, India, Jan. 16 More than 300,000 people voted today to determine the future of Goa, but a heated controversy developed this evening as to whether 500 of them should have voted at all.
A subsidiary of the American Express Company won a round in London yesterday in its battle to win insurance payments on losses resulting fom the food oil scandal of 1963.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16 The American Football League almost came of age in the Super Bowl yesterday. If it didn't quite attain full maturity, it made sufficient advances to start shaving. The Kansas City Chiefs demonstrated that they can't easily be cuffed aside by their elders in the National Football League.
Richard Darryl Zanuck, the 32-year-old production vice president of 20th Century-Fox, has been given a new sevenyear contract and the title of executive vice president in charge of production.
PARIS, Jan. 16 France and Britain agreed today to proceed with the joint development of a supersonic military jet with movable wings.
Robert E. Hughes, former night supervisor of The New York Times proofroom, died Sunday in his home at 1825 Riverside Drive. He was 88 years old.

HONG KONG, Jan. 16 There were conflicting signals from China today, some indicating that the "cultural revolution" might be conducted more conservatively, others suggesting that it would follow an uncompromising course.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 16 The Damascus radio broadcast a statement by the Syrian Foreign Ministry tonight reporting that the Syrian representative at the United Nations had been instructed to advise Secretary General Thant of "Israeli troop concentrations aimed at putting pressure on Syrina."
HARTFORD, Jan. 16 Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff told the automobile insurance industry today that he was "shocked at how backward" its leaders had been in the campaign for highway safety.

Price announcements in the aluminum and steel industries yesterday were terse generally without elaboration. But a few aluminum producers said they were pleased and satisfied with the prevailing increases in aluminum, although they were smaller than the rises originally scheduled.

HONOLULU, Jan. 14--Adm. U.S. Grant Sharpe, the commander in chief of United States forces in the Pacific area, has a beautiful view over Pearl Harbor from his headquarters at Camp H.M. Smith, perched high in the Hawaiian hills above the scene of the greatest American military disaster.
Consumers can expect to pay less for their frozen orange juice concentrate soon as a result of the record-breaking Florida orange crop this season.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 The Supreme Court declined today to hear the appeal of a group of New Yorkers who contended that fluoridation of the city's water supply was unconstitutional.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 16 (UPI) Arnold Palmer, rested and well again after a fiveweek vacation from golf, defeated Billy Casper by 2 strokes today in a benefit match at San Francisco's Presidio course.
ROME, Jan. 16 Premier Aldo Moro told Prime Minister Wilson today that Italy was willing to support a British application for entry into the European Economic Community.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Jan. 16 Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. VanDemark have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Elaine VanDemark to Leland Wilkinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kirk C. Wilkinson of North Tarrytown, N.Y., and Wellfleet, Mass. A June wedding is planned.
The election of Edward M.M. Warburg as president of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York was announced last night at the annual meeting of the appeal's directors at 220 West 58th Street.
THERE are two major sections of Nassau in the Bahamas, and Lynden Oscar Pindling came from the wrong one.
Three present and two former Building Department inspectors were arrested yesterday on charges of demanding money from building owners in return for overlooking violations.
THE HAGUE, Jan. 16 The Dutch are ahead of the flock in the drive launched by Pope John XXIII to revitalize the Roman Catholic Church and give the faith new meaning in the modern world.

Mrs. Grace Gerrish Andrews, mother of Nancy Andrews, stage and television actress, died Sunday in her home at 302 West 12th Street. She was 79 years old. Her husband, the late James C. Andrews, had owned the Andrews Hotel in Minneapolis.

WASHINGTON, Jan.16 (AP) Gen. John D. Ryan, Commander in Chief of the Strategic Air Command at Offutt Air Force Base, Nebraska, is being reassigned as Commander in Chief of Pacific Air Forces, Hickman Air Force Base, Hawaii, President Johnson announced today.
An escaped convict from the Rhode Island State Penitentiary held up a Broadway liquor store twice yesterday.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 16 Four-and-a-half year old blond, blue-eyed Beth has a new, legal last name today Liuni.
Last week thousands of department store retailers came to New York to discuss the results of 1966, compare mutual problems and project their business for the year ahead.

"THERE have been five John Winthrops of whom the world has taken special note," the first sentence of this biog- raphy says. It is the second, the son of the Governor of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, whose own life was bound up with the growth and stability of Connecticut, who is the subject of this study by Robert Black.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Jan. 16 Several hundred persons, including a brass band, braved subfreezing temperatures and gusting winds today to greet members of the pro football champion Green Bay Packers on their return to "Titletown, U.S.A."
WHATEVER happened to Elsie Smith? If one is a gun buff, he looks for her in murky junk shops, small town sporting goods stores and perhaps in a gas station in East Broken Knee, Vt.

TOKYO, Jan. 16 (AP) The Peking radio called today on "straying leaders" to repent and "join the burning force of the great cultural revolution." At the same time it conceded there were "a handful" of forces opposed to Chairman Mao Tsetung in Communist party and military circles.

The International Business Machines Corporation, the Green Bay Packers of the electronic data processing game, yesterday announced record sales and earnings for 1966. This was the company's 15th consecutive profit high and 20th straight year of record sales.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 16 (AP) Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller released today a confidential report of beatings, torture and extortion in the Tucker Prison Farm and he called for creation of a commission to make an intensive study of the state's prison system.
The Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday that about 45 million persons watched the telecasts of the Super Bowl on Sunday and that the majority had been tuned to its network.

DETROIT, Jan. 16. (UPI) The Detroit Pistons worked a three-way deal with the Los Angeles Lakers and Baltimore bulets today to get a 6-foot-8-inch onward, Rudy LaRusso, in exchange for a 6-9 forward, Ray Scott.

A group of 31 Protestant church and lay leaders called upon churchgoers yesterday to take action to block the renewal of a $40-million credit fund for South Africa by a consortium of 10 American banks.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 Leaders of the Legislature took exception today to some of Governor Rockefeller's reported proposals for operating a state lottery. They expressed concern that the Governor's ideas might induce schoolchildren to spend their lunch money on lottery tickets.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 16 The administration of Gov. Ronald Reagan appears to have in mind a somewhat more moderate approach than was first indicated on the question of charging tuition at the University of California.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 16 The engagement of Miss Catherine Clair Biggins to Archibald Bonsall Alexander, son of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald G. Alexander of Stamford, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John C. Biggins. An April 1 wedding is planned.
JERUSALEM (Israel), Jan. 16 Israel agreed today to a meeting with Syrian officials but warned that she had "reached a limit" over continuing border incidents.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 16 (AP) Four damage suits, totaling $2.4-million were filed today against the owners and operators of the Daniel J. Morrell by widows of seamen who lost their lives when the freighter sank Nov. 29.
PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 16 A Presbyterian minister has been a staff chaplain in a Roman Catholic hospital here for the last two months.
The fifth annual awards program of the City Club of New York will honor outstanding architecture in public buildings here.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 16 A crowd estimated by the police at 4,000 persons demonstrated in downtown Pittsburgh tonight to protest Federal cuts in war on poverty funds for this city.
The legal battle by Mrs. John F. Kennedy to prevent publication of the book "The Death of a President" ended yesterday when she withdrew her lawsuit in State Supreme Court.

MANHASSET, L.I., Jan. 16 George W. Bunce, a retired vice president of the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank, now the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, died Saturday in the Manhasset Medical Center of a heart attack. He was 79 years old and lived here.

The chairman of the State Mediation Board called yesterday for accelerated efforts to settle the two-week-old strike of the Cemetery Workers and Green Attendants that has forced some cemeteries to store coffins in tents.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 16 Barry Goldwater said here today that he thought that conditions in Vietnam were "going along in as good shape as they can."

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 16 (AP) Cliff Richey of Dallas defeated John Newcombe of Australia, 6-3, 6-2, today in the first round of the AustralianAmerican international tournament at the White City courts.
Senator Jacob K. Javits announced yesterday that he would try to enlist the nation's businesses in the attack on poverty through the establishment of an Economic Opportunity Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) The United States is withholding visas from Czechoslovaks in retaliation for the detention of Vladimir KazanKomarek, a Czech-born United States citizen held in Prague since Oct. 31 on spying charges, officials confirmed today.
ROSELLE, N.J., Jan. 16 Preston R. Smith of 221 West First Avenue, retired head of a chemical engineering concern bearing his name, died yesterday of a heart attack. His age was 68.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 16 The United States has resumed air strikes near Hanoi.
TOKYO, Jan. 16--"I was so surprised at Joan Baez's concert the other night," a folkmusic fan here remarked. "She sounded exactly like Maki Nishimura."
The following interview with a Red Guard was written for The Associated Press by Alessandro Casella, an Italian journalist who has just visited Communist China.

ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 16 (AP) --Nathaniel William James, great-grandson of William James, the philosopher, notified his Selective Service board in this ski resort today that he was refusing to be inducted for military service.
A $5.2-million negligence suit was filed in Federal Court yesterday in behalf of six persons who died and four who were injured in an Oklahoma plane crash last year that killed 82.
PARIS, Jan. 16 The French weekly news magazine L'Express announced today that it would accept as much as four pages of advertising by each of the major political parties campaigning for the Assembly.
The Detroit Edison Company and its subsidiaries reported gains in operating revenues and net income for 1966.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 16 (AP) A Federal judge ordered teletype and telephone operators of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad back to work today after a brief strike almost shut down operations of the nation's sixth largest railroad.

Following are the texts of three statements on the settlement yesterday of the dispute over "The Death of a President." One was made in behalf of Mrs. John F. Kennedy by John Seigenthaler, Edwin O. Guthman and Richard Goodwin; the second came from Harper Row, publishers of the book, and the third from William Manchester, the author.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 16 Mrs. George C. Wallace became Alabama's first woman Governor today and immediately pledged that she mould carry on her husband's fight against racial integration and "Federal bureaucracy" while he sought the Presidency.

Mr. and Mrs. Bartholomew Driscoll of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maureen Regina Driscoll, to John Arthur Donovan. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward J. Donovan of New York. A summer wedding is planned.
The wholesale commodity price index remained unchanged on Friday from its Thursday level of 102.8.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 Mrs. Jeanne Briscoe Taylor and Dr. Alexander Taylor, both of San Francisco, were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Frederick Brown Harris, chaplain to the United States Senate, performed the ceremony in the Simpson Memorial Chapel in the Methodist Building, adjacent to the Senate Office Building.

MACAO, Tuesday, Jan. 17 (AP) Macao authorities balked last night at Chinese Communist demands that this Portuguese colony's police be branded as assassins for their role in putting down rioting here in December.
BOWIE, Md., Jan. 16 (AP) Holly-O, a 4-year-old filly, scored her second straight victory at the Bowie meeting by taking the feature six-furlong race today in front-running fashion.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 16--Israel and Syria accepted today a proposal for a meeting of the Israeli-Syrian Mixed Armistice Commission to avert a threatened outbreak of large-scale fighting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. I6 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service said today that it was continuing this year to collect taxes on incidental expense money paid by an employer to an employe transferred to a new work location.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Jan. 16 Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kemelman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Kemelman, to Stanley Neustadter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Neustadter of New York.
Two men and a woman were found shot to death last night in a Bronx apartment.
The war between the state and some harness racing drivers abated yesterday while both sides replenished their legal ammunition.
BONN, Jan. 16 Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger emphasized today that close relations with France were of vital political-geographic importance for promoting West Germany's interests in Europe.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay announced today that they had "reluctantly" decided against saving the old Metropolitan Opera House from demolition.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 The Public Service Commission today ordered the Brooklyn Union Gas Company to inspect each of the 380 drip pots in its threeborough gas system.
Slipping interests have urged the Government to continue and to expand its present sea salvage services to hold down marine casualty losses.
David X. Clarin, retired divisional sales manager and a former director of Oakite Products, Inc., died Saturday. Mr. Clarin, who lived at 4715 Delafield Avenue, Bronxville, N.Y., was 76 years old.
Major issues in the dispute between the city and the striking Social Service Employes Union are as follows:

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 16 After years of debate about the need for a new Westchester County Courthouse, and its site, the Board of Supervisors voted unanimously today to buy a tract just west of the present county buildings here and to hire architects to design the structure.

MIAMI, Jan. 16 (AP) Hialeah Park, its 209 acres preened like a country estate, will open a 40-day racing meeting tomorrow with sprint stars matching strides in the $25,000 added Royal Poinciana Handicap, the inaugural feature.
Bill Robinson, the New York Yankees' replacement for Roger Maris in right field, entered Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday for an operation on his right arm.

RICHMOND, Jan. 16 (UPI) The Virginia Supreme Court struck down today Danville's parade ordinance and overturned the conviction in 1963 of 62 civil rights demonstrators accused of parading without a permit.

TORONTO, Jan. 16 The apparent easing in Canadian monetary policy was confirmed today when the Government priced a new long-term bond issue to yield 5.69 per cent, down from the 5.94 per cent yield in the last such financing in November.
Bernard A. Schmickrath was named yesterday to the new post of senior vice president of the Pratt Whitney Aircraft division of the United Aircraft Corporation.
Mayor Lindsay and Governor Rockefeller have agreed on a study for a tunnel along the route of the long-deadlocked Lower Manhattan Expressway.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 Stewart L. Udall, the Secretary of the Interior, told some Staten Island conservationists today that he was "disturbed" by a Federal agency's action that could imperil the development of a hiking path on the island.

LONDON, Jan. 16 (Reulers) Princess Margaret was not amused when she arrived at last year's ball to aid her favorite charity, the Dockland Settlements, and found "Bunnies" from London's Playboy Club forming a guard of honor, an organizer conceded today.
ARE STEEL stocks prised for an advance? That was the opinion yesterday in a special supplement issued by "The Outlook," a publication of the Standard Poor's Corporation.
Furniture retailing, an area of consumer goods sensitive to the "feast or famine" business cycle, appears uncertain for the rest of 1967 because of high inventories and a slow start in the new year.

DETROIT, Jan. 16 Photos purporting to show something looking like a big hamburger hovering over a Michigan lake did not "indicate an obvious hoax," an expert on unidentified flying objects said today.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 The Assembly passed legislation today that raised the salary of the Bronx County Public Administrator from $4,000 to $15,000 but took away his "windfall" of commissions, which were estimated at $75,000 or more annually.

Corporate reports in the future will have to include all extraordinary gains and losses, and earnings per share for common stock will be based on a weighted average of the number of shares outstanding during the period rather than on the number of shares outstanding at the end of the year, according to a formal opinion issued yesterday by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.

The New York Yankees, which for many years had no trouble in obtaining sponsorship for their baseball broadcasts on radio and television, have reduced the price to advertisers in the hope of stimulating sales.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 The Administration is seeking a further delay in Federal Power Commission proceedings on an application by the Arizona Power Authority to build a dam in the Grand Canyon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 The Treasury bill rate fell substantially at today's auction from last week's rates, with the drop particularly marked for six-month bills, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Senator Warren G. Magnuson called on the cigarette industry today to abandon television advertising "until such time as a safe cigarette is developed and proved."
"How do I get consumer reaction by tomorrow morning?" "It looks nice in the magazine ad, but where do I buy the product?"
Leading issues made slight gains yesterday in quiet trading on the London stock market.

The trustees of the New Haven Railroad have no possible hope of being able to lift it from reorganization except by selling it to the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads, an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing was told here yesterday.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 16 (UPI) Gov. Ronald Reagan made the first of a weekly series of televised "Reports to the People" tonight. He explained his order to cut the state budget 10 per cent and defended his proposal for a tuition fee at the University of California and state colleges.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) The Supreme Court let stand today lower court rulings that Federal district courts may not review refusals of the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board to issue unfair labor practice complaints.

ATHENS, Ga., Jan. 16 (AP) The University of Georgia's basketball team, trailing by 8-6 after employing a first-half slowdown, took off behind the 20-point shooting of Jim Youngblood tonight and defeated Kentucky, 49-40, for its first victory over the Wildcats in 17 years.

TRENTON, Jan. 16 A bill that would authorize Gov. Richard J. Hughes to shut down power plants and factories and clear the highways of all traffic during an air-pollution emergency was introduced today in the Assembly.
DETROIT, Jan. 16 (AP) Pontiac's sporty Firebird appeared in production reports for the first time this week as the General Motors division reported that more than a thousand had been built to date.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 16 (AP) A raging blizzard swept the Northern Plains today with winds as strong as 70 miles an hour whipping snow into blinding clouds, halting air and buy travel, ripping out power and communication lines, and glazing and blockading streets and highways in a half dozen states.

The massive steel and glass marquees are being removed from the Paramount Theater on Broadway at 43d Street preparatory to converting the theater to offices in a construction program that will take more than a year to complete.
Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover said last night that citizens in a democracy have a duty to become educated, especially so that they may support social action against harmful technologies.
For some who were driven out of their homes Friday in the fiery gas explosion in Queens, starting over again is not a new experience.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 16 (UPI) John Bennett of Australia set a world record in 800meter free-style swimming today as he covered the distance in 8 minutes 47.3 seconds to win the New South Wales state title.

HONG KONG, Jan. 16 The Chinese Communist party's apparatus for ruling and controlling the country appears to have remained reasonably effective, according to analysts here, despite persistent efforts of Mao Tse-tung and his chief collaborator, Lin Piao, to reorganize it and use it to impose

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 16 The engagement of Miss Barbara Ann Bywater, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Bywater, to Christopher DuFlon Creed, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Creed Jr. of Baltimore, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A June wedding is planned.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 The Supreme Court affirmed today a lower court ruling that declared unconstitutional Oregon's law requiring that imported meats be labeled with the name of the country of origin.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Jan. 16 A stocky former paratrooper was sworn in as sheriff today the first Negro to hold the office in a Southern county in this century.

The following dispatch was written by William C. Baggs, editor of The Miami News, after an interview with President Ho Chi Minh. Mr. Baggs obtained the interview on his capacity as a director of the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions at Santa Barbara, Calif. The dispatch appeared in The Miami News and was distributed by The Associated Press.

The city was able to staff all its welfare centers yesterday, despite the strike of unionized social workers. No needy person starved; no children went untended in custodial institutions; no emergency was ignored. But there were victims of the walkout: the 600,000 indigent New Yorkers who look to the Welfare Department for all the necessities of life. The longer the strike continues, the more severely hurt they will be.
The election of Lawrence A. Haggerty as president of Mark Rafalsky Co. has been announced by the real estate company.
HONG KONG, Jan. 16--As Secretary of State Dean Rusk has said, what is going on in Communist China is of great importance, but it is difficult to know what is going on.

The nation's foreign-aid program is in trouble. Even though President Johnson plans to request what amounts to a mini-budget for American economic and military assistance to the developing countries, Con- gress seems determined to reduce it further. If it is successful, there may soon be no foreign-aid program to cut back.
Steel production rose 2.9 per cent in the week ended Saturday, compared with the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The national director of the Congress of Racial Equality called yesterday for a new "political apparatus" for Negroes to give them increased national political power.

RIVER EDGE, N.J., Jan. 16 Russell Mahlon Moss, executive vice president of New York Local H-63 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, died here yesterday in his home. His age was 67.

The board of Varig Airlines, a Brazilian international carrier, has named Erik de Carvalho, as president to succeed the late Ruber Berta. Mr. de Carvalho has been with the line since 1955 and has been executive vice president since 1960.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 There was talk of a compromise on the filibuster rule today as Senators groped through parliamentary complexity toward a potentially explosive showdwon that some feared might shatter the rule altogether.
Aristocratic Embroidery of Guttenberg, N.J., has been awarded two prizes in Vogue magazine's annual contest for American fabrics.
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 16 John Ben Sheppherd, administrator of the Lyndon B. Johnson State Park Fund, has formed an advisory committee of 28 citizens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 Senator J.W. Fulbright set the stage today for another critical review of the Administration's foreign policy by announcing that the Senate Foreign Relations Committee would hold public hearings on "the responsibilities of the United States as a great power." Senator Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, is the committee chairman.
The credit markets seem so convinced that interest rates are headed down soon that sixmonth Treasury bills were sold yesterday at a lower rate than 3-month bills for the first time.
MRS. EDWARD M. PFLUEGER, a small, vivacious woman, lives surrounded by 18th-century porcelain and faience of museum quality. She describes collecting as "a part of my life."
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 16 Two mothers and five children died tonight in a three-alarm fire that swept through two fivestory brick tenements in downtown Jersey City.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 The turmoil in Communist China has delayed and possibly disrupted Peking's only direct diplomatic contacts with the United States those in Warsaw.
After a promising start, the American Stock Exchange closed yesterday with only modest gains.
Dr. Albert Sirmay, a composer and music editor, died on Sunday at Midtown Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 243 West End Avenue.

Dr. and Mrs. Nathan L. Levine of 9 East 96th Street and Neponsit, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Leslie Levine, to Martin Joel Levenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barney Levenson of Neponsit. A March wedding at the Waldorf-Astoria is planned.
Gulf Western Industries, Inc., reached an agreement yesterday to acquire the North Judd Manufacturing Company of New Britain, Conn., for stock valued at $10,080,000.

Kathy Whitworth of Jal. N.M., the 27-year-old queen of professional golf, was selected as the outstanding female athlete of the year for the second consecutive year, scoring a runaway victory in the 1966 Associated Press poll issued yesterday.

New contract proposals to the city's four major newspapers, calling for a 20 per cent general weekly wage increase, were made public yesterday by the Newspaper Guild of New York. The union also called for a reduction in the work week from five days to four.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, New York's biggest bank, reported yesterday record net operating earnings for 1966, an improvement in the rate of return on its stockholders' investment, but a lower profit margin. Significantly, however, Chase once again failed to match the earnings performance of its slightly smaller arch-rival, the First National City Bank.
Jacques Overdied and his wife, Shirley, yesterday went ahead with plans to repair their fire-damaged home in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, and to move in as soon as possible.
Antonio Maldonado, the 36year-old bodyguard and chauffeur of State Senator Eugene Rodriquez, was picked up in his home yesterday for questioning in the Bronx District Attorney's office.

AN all-court press and a musical gimmick, which the coach is willing to put up with, have helped Syracuse's basketball teams play better than most persons expected them to this season. After Dave Bing was graduated last June, it was felt the Orange would have little chance for a season good enough to get
At Lincoln Center: "Don Giovanni," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.
Stock prices advanced slightly yesterday in a session marked by heavy crosscurrents of buying and selling.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 16 (AP) United States District Judge Robert Hemphill refused today to dismiss a suit brought by the Lee County School District challenging the school desegregation guidelines of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
The Atlantic Richfield Company announced yesterday in Philadelphia the election to its board of Courtlandt S. Gross, chairman of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.
Contributions recorded yesterday by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund added $1,239.18 from 48 donors. The 55th annual appeal now stands at $748,087.79 from 14,779 benefactors.

More than 700 persons are expected at the annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Ramaz School on Jan. 29 in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton. Benjamin Bartel, Abe Newborn and Sidney Scheinberg are chairmen of the event, whose proceeds will help the school to grant tuition allowances to nearly 60 per cent of its students.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 16 (AP) Arthur Ashe of Richmond and Nancy Richey of Dallas were named today as the top-seeded players on the foreign list for the Australian tennis championships, which start Friday at the Memorial Drive courts.
WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Jan. 16 Woodbridge Township's 32 public schools closed at lunch time today as a result of a strike by about two-thirds of the school system's 900 teachers.

The contention of Alan S. Boyd, Secretary of Transportation, that the diversion of American shipbuilding contracts to foreign shipyards would stimulate this country's yards to become competitive "would seem to defy one of the basic laws of economics," a leading shipbuilder declared yesterday.
Some 1,500 drivers who own cabs voted last night to form a Taxi Owner-Driver Organizing Committee.

BUFFALO, Jan. 16--The engagement of Miss Ann Jehle Letchworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Letchworth Jr., to David Oliver Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Olives Smith Jr., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

Disappointment and perhaps a little chagrin were the best adjectives to describe the reaction of traders in potato futures to the Government stockson-hand report issued last Friday. A rash of selling took prices for the three nearby contracts down the day's limit of 35 cents a pound in heavy volume totaling 4,924 contracts.

For members of the Commodity Exchange, Inc., yesterday was a day to remember. Trading began for the first time in mercury futures contracts, and by the end of the session 205 contracts had changed hands.
Harcourt, Brace World, Inc., publisher of educational and general books, has acquired a teaching-film company, Guidance Associates of Pleasantville, N.Y.

Experimental drugs have been administered without written consent to 3,000 psychiatric patients in the last 10 years at the psychopharmacological clinic at Kings County Psychiatric Hospital, the director said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 "Good evening, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to another network minichat. Our guest tonight is Prof. Oakshott Humperdinck, the renowned old China hand. He will discuss recent significant events in China. And now, Professor Humperdinck."
CAIRO, Jan. 16 Jordan has decided to boycott Arab League conferences next month on military and financial policy, League officials said today.

EVERYBODY at George Grotz's party the other night was having fun but Mr. Grotz. He was so busy re- finishing a table, a wooden footstool and a Victorian mahogany mirror case, he hardly had time to take an occasional sip from a Mason jar filled with a clear liquid.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 McCormick Place, the huge exposition center that draws more than a million visitors a year to Chicago, was ravaged by fire today. Damage was estimated at $110million.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 A key Government witness in the trial of Robert G. Baker told a Federal jury today that he had lied four times to Government investigators about his financial relations with the former secretary to the Senate Democratic majority.
DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 17 Dr. John J. Gergen, professor of mathematics at Duke University, died yesterday at Duke Hospital. He was 63 years old.

Albert W. Selden and Hal James, producers of "Man of La Mancha," the musical hit, are involved in two impending Broadway presentations, "What Do You Really Know About Your Husband?" and "Hallelujah, Baby."

The first of the billion-dollar sales producers in the nation to report a decline in earnings for 1966 is the Caterpillar Tractor Company, which reported yesterday a drop of $8.4-million from its record profits of the year before.

LONDON, Jan. 17 The issue of American "domination" of British industry flared up again today as the Government reluctantly said it was letting the Chrysler Corporation buy control of financially ailing Rootes Motors, Ltd.
ALBANY, Jan. 17--Mrs. Ersa Hines Poston, a Negro, was named by Governor Rockefeller today as the president of the Civil Service Commission.

MONTREAL, Jan. 17 In this bilingual city, where a left wing is also a lance a gauche, there is little left this season for the fanatic followers of the Canadiens except a victory tomorrow night over the National Hockey League's All-Stars.

J. Raymond Jones, New York County Democratic leader, yesterday called for the "immediate" appointment of the special committee of the House of Representatives that is to examine charges against Representative Adam Clayton Powell.
Genesco, Inc., the footwear and apparel producer and retailer, announced here yesterday the election of Sheppard W. Zinovoy as president of its Majestic Specialities division.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) Five members of two maritime unions were accused today of waging a campaign of terror in a bitter labor dispute involving Great Lakes seamen.
Volume was up and so were prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
MONTE CARLO, Jan 17 (AP) A terrific battle among the major works teams developed tonight as survivors in the Monte Carlo auto rally struggled through the mountains north of here.
"A Man for All Seasons" at the Fine Arts Theater.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 The United States system of democracy has recently been praised by European newspapers as a result of a series of reports in North Vietnam by Harrison E. Salisbury, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times.
A Broadway ticket-taker, in what may be the only instance of its kind, regularly briefs latecomers on the show's plot to "ease up their possible frustration."
A silent demonstration to express concern over statements by Cardinal Spellman on the Vietman War was conducted today by 75 lay Catholics and four Jesuit priests.

The city's First Lady, Mrs. John V. Lindsay, and the Fire Department appealed last night to New Yorkers to stop bringing clothing and household goods to firehouses for the victims of last Friday's fire in Jamaica, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) President Johnson named today the two top officials of the Bureau of Public Roads, which is being absorbed into the new Department of Transportation.
The Marine Midland Grace Trust Company of New York reported yesterday that its net operating earnings for the three months ended Dec. 31, 1966, rose to $2,370,938 from $2,315,638 in the 1965 period.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) President Johnson denounced tonight the "venomous abuse that often attends public life."

At 4 P.M. yesterday, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, one of those rare men who can radiate dignity even in rolledup shirt sleeves, put on his jacket and greeted representatives of the Grand Jury Association in his office.

LUIGI BARZINI'S bestseller. "The Italians," was translated last night into a thoroughly amusing, sardonic and controversial documentary over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network. The author was his own narrator, and his incisive turn of phrase made the study of the Italian character a fascinating program.

MIAMI, Jan. 17 The Havana radio announced today that Josh Alberto Naranjo, First Secretary of the United Party of the Cuban Socialist Revolusion in Havana Province, had replaced Rolando Alvarez as Minister of the Food Industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Senate leaders of both parties agreed today to accept liberalization of the filibuster rule if necessary to avoid the "dangerous precedent" of permitting a simple majority to change it.
The 16-day-old gravediggers strike, which has created increasing strain on the families of the deceased, is beginning to worry city health officials.
Antonio Maldonado, the 36-, year-old bodyguard and chauffeur for Eugene Rodriguez, was ordered held yesterday as a material witness in $25,000 bail by Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Brust.

Mrs. Rebekah Harkness received yesterday the Shield Award of the American Indian and Eskimo Cultural Foundation. It was presented at the preview of "The Dance in Contemporary American Indian Art" exhibition at the Harkness Gallery of the Dance, 4 East 75th Street.
PARIS, Jan. 17 A leading French publishing house, partly owned by Time, Inc., is negotiating for rights to stage and publish "MacBird!" in France.

A membership tea and fashion show has been arranged by the New York County chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society for next Tuesday at the Persian Room of the Plaza. The guests of honor will be the members of the chapter's board of directors.

MOSCOW, Jan. 17 (UPI) United States and Soviet negotiators reached tentative agreement today on the number of weekly Moscow-to-New York airline flights and the roundtrip fare, informed aviation sources said.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 17 State officials gained a court order here today to force the city to put out the fire in the Point Breeze Dump and thus end a major source of air pollution.
The appointment of Thomas M. Lillard Jr. as a Vice president and general counsel was announced yesterday in Chicago by the Consolidated Foods Corporation.

CLOSTER, N.J., Jan. 17 Mrs. Carroll Drum Johnson, former head of the Johnson Soils Engineering Laboratory in Palisades Park, died yesterday at Pascack Valley Hospital, Westwood, of injuries she received in an automobile accident here on Saturday. She was 51 years old and lived at 107 Demarest Avenue.
Several shareholders of the Hygrade Food Products Corporation voiced dissatisfaction with the meat packer's management, at the company's annual meeting held yesterday in Detroit.

The Marschalk Company has lent a light touch to the new statewide ad campaign of the Ohio Bell Telephone Company. Newspapers, radio and TV will be used to carry the message that telephone calls are a bargain and that the company's workers are dedicated.
The election of John S. Mayer as president was announced yesterday by the Richmond County Savings Bank, Staten Island.

While insurance adjusters in Chicago were assessing fire damage at McCormick Place, an early advocate of that mammoth 6-year-old convention center continued to speak glowingly here yesterday of its value and reaffirmed "our determination to rebuild."

MISCHA ELMAN is something of a phenomenon. Last night he played a big recital at Carnegie Hall. The playing was warm-hearted, if technically cautious, but the control over bow-arm and fingers was never to be doubted. On Friday, the Russianborn violinist will celebrate his 76th birthday.
WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Jan. 17 Teachers ignored a court order to return to work this morning and continued a strike against the Woodbridge Township district's 32 public schools for a second day.
LONDON, Jan. 17 Jo Grimond, the leader of they Liberal party for the last 10 years, resigned today.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 17 (AP) Australia won two of three matches today to build a 4-2 lead over the United States in their international tennis series at White City Stadium.

THERE was a time when the New York Yankees were able to draw on an inexhaustible supply of talent from their farm clubs in the maintenance of their overpowering dynasty. They had the smartest and most energetic front-office bosses, the most perceptive scouts and the magic of the Yankee name.

William F. Wolff Jr., a senior partner in the law firm of Greenbaum, Wolff Ernst, 285 Madison Avenue, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 53 years old and lived at 29 Oxford Road, White Plains.

LONDON, Jan. 17 Sir Hugh Beaver, former managing director of the Guinness breweries and chairman of a Government-appointed committee whose recommendations resulted in the Clean Air Act in 1957, died last night at his home in Sussex. He was 76 years old.

LONDON, Jan. 17 (UPI) Howard Winstone of Wales gained a 10-round decision over Richie (Sweet) Suc of Portland, Ore. tonight. The victory of the British and European championship puts him in line for another chance at Vicente Saldivar's world featherweight title.
NEWS reports recently of a well-known liars club re- ported that the year's winner was a Westerner who claimed "the food in this town is so bad I'm living on salt and Pepper."
MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 17 (UPI)--A Federal judge ordered Wilcox County school officials today to admit 66 Negroes to "traditionally white schools" and to provide transportation for them.
The police units assigned to hunt down and haul away illegally parked cars in Midtown had another bountiful day yesterday.
"How's the stock market?" replaced "What time's my next train?" as the burning question yesterday in the grand concourse of Grand Central Terminal.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 17 Enemy soldiers used an apparently nonlethal gas against United States troops yesterday for the second time in the Vietnamese war.
Hospitals Commissioner Joseph V. Terenzio admitted yesterday that multiple biopsies had been performed in Bellevue Hospital on patients without their consent.
Thomas J. Watson Jr., chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, last night received Pace College's Advisory Council's Man in Management Award for 1966.

The Metropolitan Opera will present a Verdi Festival at Newport, R.I., from Aug. 17 through Aug. 26. The major festival offerings will be concert versions of seven Verdi operas performed by leading Metropolitan artists and the company's chorus and orchestra. The works to be given will be announced later.

ROME, Jan. 17 Premier Aldo Moro expressed the belief today that the way was open for British membership in the European Economic Community. But he warned of "political complications" that could delay successful negotiations.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 17 Art gifts and purchases acquired in 1966 by the Yale University Art Gallery will be shown here beginning Thursday, with particular emphasis on an important bequest of the late Edith Malvina K. Wetmore.
"I want to congratulate you," the principal speaker said to the award winner. "I agree with you that you don't deserve the award, but I do congratulate you."
ALBANY, Jan. 17 An Assemblyman who has sought for four years to improve the state's adoption laws introduced a new bill today "to prevent another Liuni case."
NEW BRUNSWICK, Jan. 17 (AP) Thieves broke into City Hall, forced open the doors of two safes with crowbars and escaped with about $4,000 cash last night or early today.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 17 The Department of Justice accused a white former deputy sheriff today of having beaten a Negro who was later taken dead from his jail cell last November in nearby Wetumpka.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) The Federal National Mortgage Association (Fanny May) has rescinded a decision to buy some special-assistance mortgages at less than par value in the wake of Congressional criticism of the move.

The spot rate on the British pound was a shade lower in moderate trading on foreignexchange markets here, yesterday. Currency for today was quoted at $2.7814, down 4 points from Monday. Sterling for delivery tomorrow closed around a level between $2.7912 and $2.7914.
WASHINGTON, Jan.17 (UPI) The State Department is revoking the passports of four women who recently made an unauthorized trip to Hanoi, a department official said today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 17 Edgar G. Hinrichs of 15 Litchfield Road, president from 1935 to 1959 of the Pitt Scott Corporation, 51 Broadway, New York, international freight forwarders, died yester-, day in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset. He was 71 years old.

SUMMIT, N.J., Jan. 17 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Duncan Brough have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dana Karol Brough, to David Milton Boyce, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Milton Boyce of Danbury, Conn.
The sledgehammers of destruction resounded through the old Metropolitan Opera House yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Industrial production stayed essentially level in December for the second consecutive month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Margaret E. Peters, administrator of the Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine of New York University Medical Center, died Monday of cancer in University Hospital. She was 57 years old and lived at 60 Beacon Hill Drive, Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.
LANSING, Mich., Jan. 17 Gov. George Romney replied today to critics who have accused him of ambiguity on the Vietnam issue.
DARWIN, Australia, Wednesday, Jan. 18 (Reuters) Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam arrived here early today at the beginning of a controversial 10-day visit to Australia, and New Zealand.
JERUSALEM (Israel), Jan. 17 Premier Levi Eshkol told Parliament today that "the next few days" should determine whether the United Nations and the major powers can restrain Syria.
HONG KONG, Jan. 17 More than 400 Portuguese arrived here from Macao today as the tiny Portuguese enclave faced a new crisis in its uneasy relatious with Communist China.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 17 The South Vietnamese Government offered today to meet with representatives of North Vietnam to arrange, "on a properly agreed and supervised basis," an extension of the truce proposed for the lunar New Year celebration next month.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 Republican and Democratic legislative leaders talked optimistically today of coming to agreement on two of the knottiest issues of the 1967 session setting up a state lottery and overhauling the Condon-Wadlin Law.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 17 Dartmouth broke a 19-game Ivy League losing streak with a 67-63 basketball victory over Harvard tonight.

The naming of Floyd D. Hall, president of Eastern Air Lines, as general chairman of the area's 1967 Cancer Crusade was announced yesterday. He held the same post in the fund-raising drive by the New York City division of the American Cancer Society last year.

FOR the three long stories that make up "Shepherds of the Night," Jorge Amado, Brazil's internationally known novelist, has gathered a raffish crew. They are footloose and fancy free and fluid in family relationships, shunning responsibility and hating all authority. They would lay down their lives and their money for each other. Anyone else is fair
ROME, Wednesday, Jan. 18 (Reuters) A century-old bridge on the Appian Way south of Rome collapsed early today, killing at least three persons as their cars were hurled into a ravine below.

THE delay in the common draft of college football players by the National and American Leagues is a blessing to the new N.F.L. franchise in New Orleans as well as to the old franchise in New York. The New Orleans Saints, who will come marching in next season, have a

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)--President Johnson left to Mrs. John F. Kennedy today the decision whether to permit publication of letters he wrote to her and her children after the assassination of her husband.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Jan. 17 A June wedding is planned by Miss Starr Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chandler Starr Miller, and John Robert Kirkwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Kinloch Kirkwood of Pittsfield, Mass.

A source close to Philip J. Levin, the dissident MetroGoldwyn-Mayer, Inc., director who is waging a proxy battle for control of the company, presented his side yesterday in the case of what he termed the misused list of stockholders.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 17 (UPI) Arson squad investigators tried to determine today if a basement trash fire that mushroomed into a three-alarm blaze that killed seven persons was deliberately set.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 17 Gov. Ronald Reagan accused the University of California administration today of putting a "precipitate and unwarranted freeze on applications" for student admissions. This, he said, had "unnecessarily disturbed and even frightened" parents and students.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation joined the growing list yesterday, of companies entering the education field. Donald C. Burnham, president, announced yesterday the appointment of Donald H. McGannon as chairman of a new subsidiary, the Westinghouse Learning Corporation. Mr. McGannon will retain his position as president and chairman of Westinghouse Broadcasting Company, but also will take on executive direction and administrative
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 The Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruled today that the use of public school buses to transport private and parochial school children was constitutional.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Jan. 17 David C. Powers, who retired last March as a vice president of the First National City Bank of New York, died today at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 603 Monterey Avenue here.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) Sections of the northern Midwest dug out today after a paralyzing blizzard that blocked passenger and freight trains, trapped two railroad ferries temporarily, halted bus and plane service in many cities, closed hundreds of schools and forced some business concerns to change their working schedules.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 A key Congressional adviser to the Kennedy round of trade negotiations said today he was "deeply concerned" about the outcome and that his previous optimism had "faded."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 17 A woman correspondent of the French magazine Nouvel Observateur, who set out last month to drive a small car the length of South Vietnam, was reported missing tonight by a United States military spokesman.
The American Bureau of Shipping, which certifies merchant vessels, has certified its first commercial submarine, it was announced last night.
Mrs. John V. Lindsay delivered a message from City Hall to City Center yesterday: Her husband, the Mayor, says $500,000 is on the way uptown to overhaul the theater on West 55th Street:

PARIS The hawk faction in U.S. politics which wishes to escalate the Vietnamese conflict regardless of consequences claims there is something unAmerican about a "no-win" strategy. This is scarcely correct.

The city has collected testimony from three housewives who said they reported smelling gas early this month before their homes were destroyed in the gas explosion and fire in Jamaica, Queens, last Friday.

POUND RIDGE, N.Y., Jan. 17 A campaign has been started to bring the sound of music to the picturesque suburban library here that previously had served the people of northern Westchester County and adjacent Connecticut only mutely with books and art.
RECREATIONAL possibilities for military personnel in war theaters are always limited, and the Vietnam war is no exception.

Paperboard production fell 2 per cent to 445,300 tons in the week ended Jan. 14 from 454,000 in the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

The legislative committees propose, and the Appropriations Committee disposes. The sum of money that the President requests or that the House or Senate finally authorizes for any particular program is not decisive.

Mrs. William Landram McFarland, who promoted social progress through music died at her home at the Hotel Salisbury on West 57th Street Monday. She was 93 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 A drive to coordinate heart, cancer and stroke programs for 90 per cent of the nation was described today as showing "truly phenomenal progress" to date.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan.17 Foreign Minister Adam Malik urged President Sukarno today to resign to save Indonesia from threats to her security and stability.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 17 (AP) Gene Vance, 43 years old, a former Illinois Whiz Kid of basketball fame in the 1940's, was named athletic director of the university today, effective April 1.

The Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation, publishing and marketing concern, has taken a short-term sublease on 17,000 square feet of space in the recently renovated building at 245 East 45th Street that once was occupied by The New York Daily Mirror, now defunct.
UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 17 Striking mechanics of Mohawk Airlines rejected today the company's latest back-to-work offers.

Every time a New Yorker flicks on a light switch, steps onto a commuter railroad, picks up a telephone, puts his child on a school bus, accepts the services of a moving van or does any number of other things, he is affected by the rulings of the State Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 The Federal Trade Commission, in the first such action by any Government agency, announced today that it would investigate and probably bring antitrust suits against any further mergers involving large retail-food chains.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 (AP) The Philadelphia 76ers, scoring on 19 of 24 shots from the field in the first quarter, went on to defeat the New York Knicks, 119-111, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

HONG KONG, Jan. 17 "Revolutionary rebel" organizations loyal to Mao Tse tung, Chinese Communist party chairman, and Defense Minister Lin Piao have gone a long way toward assuming control of Shanghai, China's largest city, according to reports reaching Hong Kong.

PARIS, Jan. 17 A French Government enterprise the nation's principal electric power company is planning to go to the international bond market for a major financing. The borrower will be Electricite de France, seeking $30-million.

AN American-driver-of-theyear championship, to be based on achievement and sportsmanship in all major races sponsored by the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing, the United States Auto Club and the Sports Car Club of America, was announced here yesterday...

With stories that dramatized everything from the joys of heterosexual love to the Passion of Jesus, foreign language films last year scored a comeback in the United States market, in terms of prestige and box-office receipts for individual films.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 17--T. Marion Will, author and public relations director of St. Vincent's Hospital here, died Saturday at St. Vincent's. She was 80 years old and lived at 75 Elm Street.
A brand-new futures contract, mercury, put on a brisk second-day performance yesterday, with 116 contracts traded. When trading began on Monday, volume totaled 205 contracts.

The stock market charged to higher ground yesterday in the third heaviest trading of the new year.

If Jean and Kenneth Wentworth are not the last of a dying breed, they may be prophets of a new wave. They like four-hand piano music, and they have taken to playing it in public as well as at home.

LIDICE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 17--The village consists of neat one-family houses neatly laid out in a gently rolling central Bohemian landscape. The main street is broad and perfectly straight up to the House of Culture, where it curves in a perfectly executed arch.

THE astonishing strength in the stock market thus far in 1967 is creating a new atmosphere of exuberance on Wall Street. Rapidly rising prices and tremendous volume help to create a bullish feeling among both traders and investors even though they're more than a bit mystified by the sudden turn in events.

The bold proposal by Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay for an engineering study of the feasibility of a vehicular tunnel instead of the Lower Manhattan Expressway is an imaginative new approach to an old and very difficult problem.

Buckley Jr., editor of the National Review.

Nobody figured how many thousands of words were devoted to boating and its problems at the National Boat Show in the New York Coliseum yesterday at meetings on service and safety, but most of them were devoted to a gathering of marine manufacturers attended by 102 persons.

The Cross Brown Company has elected Norman F. Levy president and Richard W. Seeler executive vice president.
Prices firmed a bit yesterday on the London Stock Exchange despite late profit taking.

A British Liberal at the party's 1963 assembly said that if Britain elected its Prime Minister, Jo Grimond would win "hands down." He could have been right. The tall, shambling man with the unruly forelock, who has now stepped out as party leader, is one of the most attractive of British politicians.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 The Johnson Administration is talking very cautiously about the convulsion in China. This unheaval is regarded here as the most significant political event of the last decade, but U.S. officials are saying far less about it in public than the top leaders of the Soviet Union.

The nation's freight forwarders are hoping that the recently established Department of Transportation will give them a fairer regulatory "deal," Frederic N. Melius, president of United States Freight Company, stated yesterday.

Mayor Lindsay accepted a direct challenge from a pair of 3-year-old twins yesterday and lost, gracefully.

New York is lucky, a Federal meteorologist told the recent interstate air pollution conference here. Its location next to the ocean and its relatively strong winds permit the city's atmosphere to cleanse itself with unusual ease and speed. Air pollution such as is normal here would make the atmosphere intolerable for human beings if it took place in many other parts of this country.

The French American Banking Corporation announced yesterday the election of Yves Pierre Truffert as chairman and Francois de Lajugie as president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Military sources said today that an air raid Sunday on a petroleum depot 14 miles northwest of downtown Hanoi did not mean that the United States had resumed bombing raids within the suburbs of the North Vietnamese capital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--A New Jersey Representative wrote to Secretary of the Army Stanley Resor today calling for an investigation into whether the Army had failed to provide proper medical attention for a draftee now ill with cancer.

THE VENETIAN AFFAIR, a Metro-GoldwynMayer suspense drama, with Robert Vanghn, Elke Sommer, Felieia Farr and Boris Karloff, directed by Jerry Thorpe, is the attraction at local theaters.

It was indeed miraculous that no one was killed or seriously injured in the fiery gas explosion in Jamaica, last friday. But the residents in the area could not dwell too long on their thankfulness, for the economic pain of property damage and loss soon was upon them.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 18 Gloomy forecasts of demand for Texas oil led the Texas Railroad Commission today to cut production during February by 23,304 barrels a day below January levels. Wells will be permitted to produce at 36.5 per cent of capacity in February, down from January's 37.5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) Republicans are getting a mixed reaction from networks to their request that the party's rebuttal to President Johnson's State of the Union Message be televised and broadcast live.

The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday defended a $32.4-million-a-year electric rate increase it was granted last November and sharply attacked a public utility expert who has contended that the company was overcharging its customers. The com pany said at a public hearing here that the expert's allegations of 35-million in overcharges in the last two and a half years were "wholly inaccurate."
