TORONTO, Jan. 18 A Quebec finance company, the Depositors Mortgage Corporation, is in financial difficulty, Finance Minister Mitchell Sharp confirmed today in replying to a question in the House of Commons in Ottawa.

FOUR years ago John Boyden, Canadian baritone, gave his first New York recital. Last night he returned for his second recital, in Town Hall, to demonstrate again that he is an impressive lieder singer. For an artist of his caliber to be absent so long from the local recital stage (he has appeared here with orchestra in the meantime) is to be deplored.

Mr. and Mrs. Fenwick C. Riley of Eureka, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Riley of Paris, to Anthony Reynolds Smith of Paris, an officer with the State Department. Jesse W. Tapp, retired chairman of the board of the Bank of America and one of the country's leading agricultural economists, was found dead yesterday in his hotel room in San Francisco, apparently the victim of a heart attack. He was 67 years old.
British Government bonds led a modest advance yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

The Rabbinical Alliance of America disassociated itself yesterday from the planned Mobilization of the Clergy, which will be held in Washington Jan. 31 and Feb. 1 to protest United States policy in Vietnam.

They were six volunteers scraping, brushing, hammering and sawing yesterday to transform a dilapidated corner store in Greenwich Village into a psychedelic shrine the first meditation center to be established by Dr. Timothy Leary and his followers in this city.

ROME, Jan. 18 (UPI) The Vatican's weekly magazine, L'Osservatore della Domenica, attacked President Johnson today for supporting birth control as one means of reducing hunger. It was one of the Vatican's most outspoken criticisms of a United States President in recent times.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 18 (Reuters) President Sukarno said today that he was angry at a suggestion by Foreign Minister Adam Malik that he step down as President.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 18 Fire, believed caused by a short circuit, destroyed at least a third of the interior of the Metropolitan Cathedral, Mexico's biggest Roman Catholic church, early this morning.

A conference of Negro leaders in all fields will be held in Washington next Wednesday to discuss ways to restore Representative Adam Clayton Powell to his seat and to his chairmanship of the powerful House Labor and Education Committee. The leaders will also reexamine Negro-white relations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The further Chairman Mao Tse-tung tries to push China along the road to militant socialism, the more he alienates expatriate Chinese elsewhere in Asia, academic and government specialists report.

The Johnson Administration is taking a "carefully calculated risk" in the development of a supersonic transport that will pay handsome dividends, Najeeb E. Halaby, senior vice president for Pan American World Airways, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 A move by liberals to weaken the Senate filibuster rule was defeated by a wide margin tonight despite a friendly parliamentary interpretation by Vice President Humphrey.

SUMMIT, N.J., Jan. 18 Mr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Wheaton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Loraine Ellen Wheaton, to James Gerwig Bradley, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Bradley of Ashtabula, Ohio.
PANAJI, Goa, Jan. 18 The people of Goa appeared tonight to have voted decisively against merger with neighboring Maharashtra State and to remain a self-governing "union territory" of India.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday the following changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 19 United States Air Force B-52 bombers dropped tons of incendiary bombs yesterday on War Zone D, a Vietcong sanctuary, in an attempt to burn away dense foliage hiding suspected enemy camps and infiltration routes.
A holdup man was killed yesterday during a gun battle with four detectives that had pedestrians darting for safety into doorways of the busy garment district. About a dozen shots were exchanged.

ROME, Jan. 18 The Italians have always liked moles and beauty spots, but today the models wearing the summer crepes of Princess Luciana Pignatelli were covered with brown spots in more places than anyone could possibly count. There were manmade freckles on their feet as well as on their faces.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 Barney Ross, the former lightweight and welterweight boxing champion, died today of throat cancer at the age of 57 in his apartment on Lake Shore Drive.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 18--In an effort to live up to its new slogan--"The City Alive"--New Rochelle disclosed plans today for a $25-million enclosed air-conditioned shopping mart on 11 acres of the decaying downtown core of the city.
The City's monthly auction of surplus properties yesterday was a little livelier than usual for an assemblage that consists mostly of business professionals.
BONN, Jan 18 Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger vowed today that West Germany would embark on a "great policy" of peacemaking with the Communist countries of Europe.
SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Jan. 18 (AP) Quick action by prison guards averted today a threatened race riot by 2,000 whites and Negroes in the walled yard of San Quentin Prison.

A former vice president of the Del E. Webb Corporation, Joseph H. Williams, has been elected a vice president of Kinney National Service, Inc., and general manager of its new subsidiary, National Realty Maintenance.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 18 The engagement of Miss Jeannette Kittredge Watson to Ralph Talbot McElvenny Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McElvenny of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Watson Jr. of Greenwich and North Haven, Me.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara revoked today a policy under which about 1,000 Army reserve officers, including 400 to 500 in Vietnam, have been held on active duty without their consent after completing their obligated periods of service.

The Riegel Textile Corporation has announced the election as a director of James H. Styers, senior vice president in charge of the loans and investments division of the Wachovia Bank and Trust Company, Winston-Salem, N.C.
HONG KONG, Jan. 18--The Peking radio reported today that two Deputy Mayors of Shanghai had been seized and "dragged" through the streets of the city by supporters of Mao Tse-tung.
The Rev. Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr called yesterday on the universities, the church and the "informed" communications media to seek an end to the Vietnam war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 School authorities at Furze Pip, Mass., responded predictably when Billy Thornton appeared for classes wearing a suit of finely tempered Milanese steel armor. Contending that Billy's unorthodox apparel created a "distraction in the classroom," they sent him home with orders not to return until he had slipped out of his armor and into something more conventional.
THE most awkward sound in current literature is the wail of British novelists trying to put down Americans.
City Controller Mario A. Procaccino yesterday described three hospital affiliation programs here as "a morass of mismanagement" that had shortchanged both patients and taxpayers.

"The Chelsea Girls," Andy Warhol's marathon (3 hours 28 minutes), twin-screen, underground spectacular, is being prepared for national theatrical release, with the first engagement outside New York expected to start in Los Angeles next month.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The White House announced today that John T. Connor had resigned as Secretary of Commerce. The resignation was indicated last week.

RICHMOND, Jan. 18 The Grand Dragon of the Virginia Ku Klux Klan complained officially to Gov. Mills E. Godwin Jr. today about alleged "harassment" of Klan members by the Virginia police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee said last night that "at the moment there is no economic case for the proposed tax increase" asked by President Johnson.
DETROIT, Jan. 18 (UPI) Bill Cunningham scored seven of the final nine Philadelphia points as the 76ers defeated the Detroit Pistons 113-105, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will be shook up but it won't swing. It will rely more on showmanship but will also concentrate more on scholarly work. Its exhibitions will have greater depth. It is considering cooperative ventures with other museums and public institutions in the city. What happens will absolutely not be a happening.
A moderate expansion in exports and imports and an improvement in the United States trade picture in 1967 was predicted yesterday by economists of the National Foreign Trade Council.
GREYMOUTH, New Zealand Thursday Jan. 19 (Reuters) An underground explosion killed 19 men in a coal mine near here today.

LONDON, Jan. 18 (AP) Lloyd Marshall of Newark, who is not ranked among the top 10 lightweights, scored an upset tonight by knocking out Maurice Cullen, the British champion, in the ninth round of a scheduled 10-rounder at the World Sporting Club.

State Supreme Court Justice Thomas A. Aurello heard argument yesterday on a suit by Robert A. Shuttleworth, a harness driver for 20 years, that seeks to compel the State Harness Racing Commission to issue a license to him.

The Senate of the United States has again demonstrated its curious fear of majority rule. A simple majority, which is good enough to pass even the most far-reaching legislation, is apparently not good enough to control the conduct of business in the Senate.

ROME, Jan. 18 Danilo Dolei, the Sicilian social reformer and anti-Mafia crusader, publicly boycotted his trial for criminal libel today, alleging that the court would not hear witnesses to prove links between the Mafia and prominent politicians.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 Governor Rockefeller and legislative leaders have reached tentative agreement on the mechanics of a state lottery. The only unresolved issues at

THE United States chess champion, Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, is a ruthless opponent. Victory is his goal, and even when he clinches first prize he does not ease up. While looking for victory he possesses an objective coolness that does not desert him. But though he does not rely on impetuous, violent tactics that run head-on against good strategy, he will, in a compromised position, speculate dangerously.

Robert V. Roosa, former under Secretary of the Treasury for monetary affairs who served in both the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, warned last night that unless the United States gave the "highest priority" to ending the deficit in its international payments, 1967 could be "a crucial year for the dollar, and even for the standing and leadership of the United States in world affairs."

GLENVIEW, Ill., Jan. 18 (AP) Rear Adm. Richard L. Fowler, an air hero of World War II, died today in a fire that swept through his quarters at the Glenview Naval Air Station. The 53-year-old officer was chief of Naval Air Reserve Training.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 California smog officials reported today that nearly half the 1966 cars they had tested after use by private owners had failed to meet the state's legal requirements for fume suppression.
Houston Zora Folley, 212 pounds, Phoenix, Ariz., knocked out Floyd Joyner, 214 , San Francisco, first round.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 18 Rhodesia's Secretary for Health, Dr. Mark Webster, accused the World Health Organization today of imposing "sanctions' against his country bywithholding vital medical information and abandoning health projects of direct benefit to the African population.
Fredric March and his wife Florence Eldridge, will star in a 90-minute original television drama for the Columbia Broadcasting System.
POMONA, Calif., Jan. 18 (AP) Delos W. Lovelace, novelist and one-time newsman and syndicated columnist, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 72 years old.

Alberta Cox of Raytown, Mo., has been named coach of the United States national women's basketball team, Laurine Mickelsen, the chairman of the Amateur Athletic Union and Olympic women's basketball committees, announced yesterday.

The spot rate on the British pound was steady in moderately active trading on foreignexchange markets here yesterday. Currency for today closed at $2,791, up 1 point. Friday sterling was quoted at $2,7917 to $2,7919.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 18 (AP) The rules committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association adopted a new rule today, which it hopes will put the foot back into football and open a whole new pattern of offensive play.
Time, Inc., estimates its revenues rose about 10 per cent last year to "around $500-million," according to James A. Linen, president.
The appointment of Andrew J. Phelan as a corporate vice president of Braniff International has been announced by the Dallas-based airline.
Prices seesawed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange ending slightly higher on average than the day before in increased trading.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 18 Dr. Stephen Henri Deschamps, a medical specialist and assistant clinical professor at the Yale School of Medicine, died today in Bridgeport Hospital. He was 42 years old and resided at 388 Brooklawn Avenue.
Mrs. Betty Welsh Hubbard, an artist and the wife of Richard L. Hubbard of 174 East 74th Street, died on Tuesday in Roosevelt Hospital after a short illness. She was 65 years old.

Trowbridge as Acting Secretary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--A handwriting expert testified in Federal Court here today that the late Carole Tyler, secretary of Robert G. Baker, had forged the name "Wayne L. Bromley" to seven checks made out to Mr. Bromley for a total of $5,000.
OMAHA, Jan. 18 (AP) Two Californians, Roger Bass and Julie Lynn Holmes, captured opening-day honors in the junior men's and women's divisions of the National figure-skating championships today.
HONG KONG, Jan. 18 The new crisis in Macao appeared to have eased today with reports from the tiny Portuguese territory of a compromise settlement of its dispute with Communist China.
A citation for distinguished service to horticulture was presented yesterday to Mrs. Albert D. Lasker a philanthropist and art collector who has brought plants and flowers to the city's streets.

LIKE Shaw's Jack Tanner and Osborne's Jimmy Porter, the hero of "Kicking the Castle Down" at the Gramerey Arts Theater is a young fellow in love with the sound of his voice. Unlike them, he has very little to say that you haven't heard before, and you are ready to leave his company long before his creator. Robert Kornfeld, is willing to let you go.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 18 Jack Meadow of 8 Orsini Drive, a lawyer specializing in bankruptcy proceedings, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 68 years old.
PEKING, Jan. 18 Red Guards from the Peking Law School occupied the capital's police headquarters today.

In reaching their tentative agreement on the mechanics of the new state lottery, Governor Rockefeller and the legislative leaders were well advised to discard the proposal to price tickets at 25 or 50 cents and to dispense them through vending machines. The lottery was designed to raise funds for education. It must not be used either to entice school children to gamble or to serve as a concealed tax on the poor.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 18 The possibility that the regents of the University of California will go along this week with Gov. Ronald Reagan's proposal for imposition of a tuition fee was discounted today by Jesse M. Unruh, Democratic Speaker of the Assembly.
MONTREAL, Jan. 18 The National Hockey League finally disclosed tonight what it planned to give the six new expansion clubs that will join the loop next season.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 18--Mr. and Mrs. Stephen R. Currier of New York, who are among the nation's leading philanthropists, were missing today on a flight from Puerto Rico to St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands.

DETROIT, Jan. 18 (UPI) The Detroit Pistons today shelved Ray Scott, the man in the middle of the three-team basketball trade that collapsed when Rudy LaRusso of Los Angeles refused to report to Detroit.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 18 (AP) Mrs. Marlene Streit of Toronto and Mrs. Scott Probasco of Chattanooga carded 76's today and tied for the medal in the 35th Doherty Cup women's golf tournament.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 18 (AP) Secretary General Thant has tentative plans to make two trips to Asia one in April and one in June, a spokesman said today.
THE audience of fashion merchants, reporters and fans like Dinah Shore and Lauren Bacall were too sophisticated to gasp, but they looked as if the sky had fallen.

PALISADES PARK, N.J., Jan. 18 Dr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Braun of Palisades Park and Avon-by-the-Sea have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Elaine Braun, to Douglas Edward Ix. He is the son of Mrs. Alexander Ix of Englewood and Spring Lake, and the late Mr. Ix.
Look magazine filed lawsuits yesterday against the owners of The Chicago Daily News and the West German magazine Stern over the serialization of William Manchester's book, "The Death of a President."

ROGER DION, a stronglegged New Englander who was jumping off hills in Lebanon, N.H., not too many years after he learned to walk, suddenly is dominating the Eastern ski jumping season. He has won three major trophies in three appearances at Bear Mountain.
SYDNEY, Australia (UPS) Brilliant playing by Arthur Ashe could not save the United States team from a 6-3 defeat by Australia at the close of their three-day tennis series today.
DETROIT, Jan. 18 Stokely Carmichael, the black power advocate, told a racially mixed middle class audience today that alliances with white liberals would harm Negroes in the long run.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 18 The first shipment of United States heavy arms for Jordan arrived in Amman today aboard two United States Air Force transport planes. They are part of the military equipment the United States Government promised last month to deliver to Jordan to strengthen her defenses.

No danger to operations in Chile of American copper producers seems likely because of a setback to President Eduardo Frei Montalva. He is regarded as generally friendly to United Statees economic interests.

Barry Goldwater's successor in the Senate calls President Johnson's order invoking sanctions against Rhodesia "dictatorial, deceitful and dangerous." In the House a California Republican introduces a resolution to end the sanctions.

St. James Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Miss Antoinette Graham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Graham Jr. of 165 East 73d Street and Fairfield, Conn., to the Rev. Ivan Weiser.
The Roosevelt Savings Bank, Brooklyn, announced yesterday the election of Frederick H. Schneider as president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) Two Democrats with liberal voting records were named today to the House Rules Committee. This apparently assured the majority leadership of control of the committee whose power over legislation has been strengthened.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 18 Leslie Davis, who retired in 1964 as special assistant to the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, died yesterday at Princeton Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at the Milestone River Apartments here.
Wreckers continued to pound away at the Old Metropolitan Opera House yesterday according to plan, but the demise of the house has brought up two as yet unanswered questions.
TOKYO, Jan. 18 (UPI) Red Guards closed down Peking's largest department store today to stop the sale of certain "luxury items, a Japanese correspondent stationed in the Chinese capital reported.
MOSCOW, Jan. 18 (Reuters) Moscow will have a 65story skyscraper 33 stories higher than the city's present tallest building official press agency Tass said tonight.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 18 Evelyn Nesbit, the last surviving principal in the sensational Harry K. Thaw-Stanford White murder case of 60 years ago, died in a convalescent home here yesterday, where she had been a patient, for more than a year. She was 82 years old.

MANILA, Jan. 18 (AP)--The Philippine Supreme Court rejected today a bid by Mayor Villegas to clamp down on American and other foreign companies engaging in retail trade.
TRENTON, Jan. 18 Future commutation on the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad was virtually assured today when an agreement was reached between the line and the State Commuter Operating Agency.
JERUSALEM (Israel), Jan. 18 Three Israeli soldiers were wounded by Jordanian gunfire today in a brief exchange across the border at the northern end of the Gulf of Aqaba.

The striking welfare workers voted last night to accept a proposal for fact-finding on the critical issue of salaries and to return to their jobs today. The proposal had been made by the mediator in the dispute, Benjamin H. Wolf.

The Sperry Rand Corporation registered a 96 per cent increase in earnings for the nine months ended Dec. 31 above the prior year's period and exceeded the record net for the full fiscal year ended last March by $7,474,000, according to the results issued yesterday.
"The Death of a President" has brought Look magazine its greatest newsstand demand in its 30 years of publication.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 18 The views of Protestant and Roman Catholic churchgoers on issues such as the war in Vietnam and the speed of integration are almost identical with those of nonchurchgoers, an official of the American Institute of Public Opinion stated today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP) The most intense and widespread cold wave of the winter swelled over a vast area from the Rockies to New England today.

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 18 (Reuters) Vie Elford and David Stone of Britain were officially declared leaders of the Monte Carlo rally tonight, after two of the rally's three stages. Elford and Stone, who drove a German Porsche, had 5,130 points.
James J. Colt, industrialist and owner of vast land holdings in northern New Jersey, died Tuesday night at his home, 4941 Arlington Street, in Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 68 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 John Anthony Arata, the father of a marine serving in Vietnam, wrote to President Johnson on Jan. 10 to offer "one vote of confidence" in the President's policy.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 18 Trailing by 2-1 midway through the second period, Harvard scored three goals in the second period and two in the third as it defeated the Dartmouth hockey team tonight, 6-2.

Max Herzfeld, a Brooklyn lawyer since 1906, died Tuesday in the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn after a short illness. He was 83 years old. Although he was semi-retired in the last few years, he had an office at 153 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn. He lived at 135 Eastern Parkway.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 18 (UPI) Ken Yount of Niagara Falls, N.Y., scored the major upset of the day in the opening round of the Professional Golfers' Association match-play championship today by eliminating the co-medalist, John Barnum.
The New York Mets passed another milestone in labor relations yesterday by signing Bob Shaw, the 33-year-old pitcher who has harassed batters and executives in both major leagues for 10 years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The Soviet Union's active merchant fleet is now larger than that of the United States, Edwin M. Hood, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, reported today.

Harrison E. Salisbury, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times, said last night that "if there might be a temporary gain for the enemy" as a result of his reports from North Vietnam, "in the end the value would come to us."
MIAMI, Jan. 18 (AP) J. Graham Brown's Woozem pulled away in the stretch to win the $32,250 Jasmine Stakes today by six lengths before 16,158 fans at Hialeah Park.
LONDON, Jan. 18 More documents were found today on Chislehurst Common in Kent, on the outskirts of London, near where badly charred papers about United States missiles were found yesterday.

Milton Lewin, a reporter for the New York City bureau of The Associated Press, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive as he was driving downtown to cover negotiations in the Welfare Department strike.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 18--South Vietnam could be cleared of Vietcong guerrillas in three years if infiltration of soldiers and supplies from North Vietnam were stopped, Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam said in Canberra today.

ONE vital thing you can be reasonably certain of when visiting the New York City Ballet is that, irrespective of the works being given, you will get an evening of first-rate dancing. So it proved at the New York State Theater last night, where a wide variety of ballets were to be seen at a happily sustained level of performance.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 18 The United States has 35,300 troops in Thailand, of whom 8,000 are engaged in construction projects, the American Ambassador, Graham A. Martin, disclosed Wednesday.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange in the month ended Jan. 13 dropped 2,088,028 shares, to 12,531,230 shares.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that outstanding bankers' dollar acceptances rose $147-million in December to a record total of $3,603,000,000. The earlier record was $3,467,000,000 in May, 1965.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 18 Albert Henry DeSalvo, the 35-year-old mental patient who says he murdered 13 women as the Boston strangler, was found guilty tonight of armed robbery, assault and sex offenses involving four women.

MONTREAL, Jan. 18 The Montreal Canadiens, confined to fourth place in the National Hockey League and suffering through their worst season in 19 years, made the grand gesture at the Forum tonight. They defeated the All-Stars, 3-0.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (UPI) Lynda Bird Johnson went about her first out-oftown assignment as a magazine writer today in style.
PEBBLE BEACH, Cal., Jan. 19 Joe Carr, a slim, 28-yearold Worcester, Mass., professional, scored a surprising 68 in the opening round of the Bing Crosby golf tournament today.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan., 19 (AP) Chicago's open occupancy ordinance was declared constitutional today by the Illinois Supreme Court.

The Shubert Theater Enterprises, which owns the rights to more than 500 musicals, plays, revues and sketches, will make the material available for a proposed series of one-hour weekly television shows titled "Shubert Alley."
Ogden Phipps, owner of famed Buckpasser, has been elected to his fourth term as chairman of The Jockey Club, it was announced yesterday.
BIEDENKOPF, Germany, Jan. 19 At 1 A.M. Company 3 of the 64th West German Panzer Battalion was still grinding noisily down the dark and narrow back roads of Hesse.
BOLOGNA, Italy, Jan. 19 (UPI) The European middleweight champion, Nino Benvenuti of Italy, knocked out Manfred Graus of Germany tonight in the second round of their 10-round nontitle fight.
JURONG, Singapore To compensate for a shrinkage of nearby markets, Singapore is sweetening the already considerable enticements offered to foreign manufacturers to set up shop on the island.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 19 (AP) The Cleveland Teachers Union voted by a margin of more than 2 to 1 today to accept a pay proposal from the Board of Education.
A leading New York pediatrician said yesterday that a bill introduced this week in the Legislature to severely limit medical research on children would, if passed, be "a disaster real disaster."

MOSCOW, Jan. 19 Soviet Jews in the Moldavian Republic have been cautioned that if they insist on emigrating to Israel, they should not return to the Soviet Union complaining that they had not been warned about harsh conditions of life in the "Promised Land."

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia The ending of "confrontation" Indonesia's drive to break up Malaysia coincided last year with the start of an ambitious five-year development program here. But the benefits of both peace and planning have been delayed.

KARACHI, Pakistan On tile northwest frontier-where a mother offers her young son a gun instead of a toy, where guns are a man's never-failing companion through life, and where a Pathan family's wealth is measured in terms of the rifles and ammunition its men possess it would be natural to expect gun manufacturing to develop almost as a cottage industry. And so it has.

The first-prize winners of the fifth Dimitri Mitropoulos International Music Competition are Paul Capolongo of France, Enrique Garcia-Asensio of Spain, Helen Quach of Nationalist China and Alois Springer of West Germany. The names were announced by Leonard Bernstein late yesterday afternoon from the stage of Carnegie Hall, after the eight judges had deliberated more than 50 minutes.

SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPI) Nearly all of San Quentin prison's 4,000 convicts were locked in their cells today while the warden and his staff investigated a murder that almost triggered a race riot.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand Whether New Zealand is in an economic mess was one of the central points argued in the general election campaign late in 1966.

TOKYO Despite the delays and expense involved in obtaining a private telephone here, Japan recently replaced Britain as the No. 2 country, behind the United States, in the number of telephones installed.
HONG KONG Communist China's economy is facing the threat of disruption by political experiments and political power struggles.
The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that it had accumulated $29-million in deposits, which are required by the company from some of its customers as protection against unpaid bills.

Mrs. Louise Kellam Smithies, widow of Dr. Frank Smithies, a Chicago surgeon, died yesterday afternnon at the Osborn Memorial Home in Rye, N.Y. where she lived. She was 83 years old and had lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 19 (Agence France-Press)--One of three Western religious leaders who was received on Tuesday by President Ho Chi Minh and Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam said today that the Premier had insisted on "the determination of the Vietnamese people to remain independent" regardless of the sacrifices.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Senate Leaders filed today a closure petition that, if successful, would lead to a vote on a move to change the antifilibuster rule.
LISBON, Jan. 19 Lisbon welcomed today as a victory for Portugal the opposition of three former Portuguese enclaves to a merger with neighboring Indian states.

COLOMBO, Ceylon Ceylon's economic growth in recent years has been one of the poorest in Asia. Between 1960 to 1965, the gross domestic product increased at an annual average rate of 3 per cent. With the population growing annually at a rate of around 2.5 per cent, the margin left for improvement in per capita incomes was meager.

John A. Finneran, president's, of John A. Finneran Associates, an advertising agency at 152 west 42d Street, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. He was 66 years old and lived at 1880 Palmer Avenue, Larchmont, N.Y.
IT IS brilliantly colored, up holstered in op art pat terns and has pop art mirrors, trays, wall hangings, ash trays and lighting.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP) The defending champion, Mrs. Nancy Roth Syms, and the co-medalists. Mrs. Marlene Streit and Mrs. Scott Probasco, posted easy victories today in the first round of the 35th annual Doherty Cup women's amateur golf tournament.
The opportunity to hear songs by some 20th-century Swiss composers was provided by Heinz Rehfuss, the distinguished Swiss baritone, in a program in Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
Volume slipped while prices advanced yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
LONDON, Jan. 19 Jan Smeterlin, a concert pianist known for his interpretation of Chopin, died in a hospital here yesterday. He way 74 years old and had made my concert tours throughout the world.

MASSILLON, Ohio, Jan. 19 (UPI) James G. Clark, former sheriff in Selma, Ala., has been denied access to the American Legion Hall here, the sponsor of a scheduled speech by Mr. Clark charged today.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 19 J. Carles McCormick, who organized thousands of MexicanAmericans in support of John F. Kennedy's Presidential campain in 1960, was convicted today on charges of appropriating more than $100,000 from a group that he headed in 1962 and 1963.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 United States officials said today that the new submarinelaunched Poseidon missile, now being developed, would carry multiple warheads.
TOKYO, Jan. 19 Japanese leftists have been upset and confused by the turmoil in Communist China.

SAIGON, South Vietnam Import licenses have been issued to dozens of newcomers in South Vietnam in a move to insure that the $398-million of United States-financed commercial imports from fertilizer to typewriters fulfill their purpose of sopping up inflationary currency.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) Harrison E. Salisbury, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times, who recently returned from a visit to North Vietnam, was described as a "Hanoi-picked correspondent" tonight by Arthur Sylvester, who resigned earlier this month as Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs.

ALVAH BESSIE'S latest novel is preceded by the antigue legalism of an author's note purporting that his book is fic- tion and that "neither its characters nor the situations in which they are involved are intended to represent any person now living or dead (or both)...."
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 19 (UPI)--The guided missile cruiser U.S.S. Boston and four submarines joined today a sea-air search of the Caribbean for Mr. and Mrs. Stephen R. Currier of New York City.

EAST HAMPTON L.I., Jan., 19 Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Meddaugh have announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of their daughter, Capt. Winifred Joan Meddaugh, U.S.A.F., to John Alden Jackson, son of Mrs. G. Alden Jackson and the late Dr. Jackson of Los Angeles.

SCHRUNS, Austria, Jan. 19 (AP) Marielle Goitschel of France, a nonwinner in a major meet this season until she came here, took the special slalom today for a sweep of the Golden Keys women's Alpine ski competition.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 19 The police confiscated a print of the New York underground film "Flaming Creatures" as it was being screened last night by the Cinema Guild, a student group of the University of Michigan. After the seizure, about 100 students demonstrated against the action in front of the police station.

"If I was going to run from the colored I would run and run and run till I dropped dead, and never get away," said the middle-aged woman in blue jeans and knitted cap. "They're nice people, and I want to live here."
DETROIT, Jan. 19 Romney Associates, a private group with 11 employer and offices four blocks from the State Capitol in Lansing, statrted a low key pre-Presidential campaign operation today.

ROME, Jan. 19 Mila Schon, the Milanese designer whose last name trips up most Americans until they learn to pronounce it Shern, walked off with top honors in Rome's week-long whirl of high-fashion collections for spring and summer.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 At the urging of the Administration, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is planning early action on the long-stalled consular convention with the Soviet Union.
PERTH, Australia, Jan 19 (Reuters) West Australia's women athletes have asked their male colleagues to spare their blushes in the future by wearing longer shorts.
ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 19 Cornell scored seven goals in the first period and went on to defeat Colgate's hockey team. 10-2, tonight. The victory gave Cornell a 14-1-1 won-lost-tied record.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 19 The sounds of Monte Carlo today were roaring automobiles studded tires on snowless streets and two young Finnish drivers in the Cafe de Paris trying to order sis glasses of mills in their native tongue.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 19 Gov. Ronald Reagan and his potentially most powerful Democratic rival, Assembly Speaker Jesse M. Unruh, worked smoothly together today to allay fears of Californians over state university admissions policy.
James J. Nance, who will be 67 years old on Feb. 19, is starting a new career in the retail business.

LONDON, Jan. 19 (AP) Development work on the Ford Motor Company's new electric auto is under way in Britain and the first prototype will be shipped to the United States in June, a Ford spokesman said today.
PRAGUE, Jan. 19 More than 1,000 people packed a large hall here last night to drink beer and put their questions on love, sex and the family to a dozen experts.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 19 Dr. A. Robert Schoyen, professor of history at Syracuse University, was found dead in a street near his home early today. The police said he had apparently slipped and fallen on a sidewalk. He was 49 years old and lived at 123 Westminster Avenue.
The nation's banking system showed mixed trends during the week ended Wednesday, statistics released yesterday by the Federal Reserve indicated.
THOSE long-time favorites at cocktail parties -Ritz crackers and pretzels are now hanging from women's necks and dangling from their ears.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--President Johnson presented the Medal of Honor today to Maj. Bernard F. Fisher for his rescue of a fellow pilot from a battletorn airstrip in South Vietnam last March.

Proxy statements from about 2,800 holders of 400,000 Crucible Steel Company shares were mistakenly destroyed last April by junior employes of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the night before an important court decision in a proxy fight.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 Mr. and Mrs. Harold F. Stassen have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Esther Stassen, to Martin M. Berger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold Berger of New York.

HONG KONG Although riots here and in the neighboring Portuguese territory of Macao, unsettled conditions in China and general misgivings about the economy had created gloom in Hong Kong business quarters, such feelings were largely dispelled at the end of the year when trade figures showed that exports, the lifeblood of this British crown colony, had soared to a record.
According to lobbyists who keep track of such things, 100 million pounds of fiber glassreinforced plastic went into the construction of pleasure boats last year.

MIAMI, Jan. 19 William C. Baggs, editor of The Miami News, who was recently in North Vietnam, said in a dispatch published here today that the complaint that many civilians areas had been bombed in the city of Namdinh "appears to be a valid complaint."
JAKARTA, Indonesia At the end of 1966 Indonesia was still caught in the grip of what her economics with rueful pride call "the worst inflationary situation in the world."

HONG KONG, Jan. 19 Work stoppages and political disturbances have taken place in the city of Nanning, in South China, from which war material is transshipped to North Vietnam, according to a radio broadcast from there.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Because President Johnson has not ordered an immediate start on construction of a supersonic transport, two dozen airlines are free of an imminent requirement that they deposit an additional $11.4-million on the aircraft they have ordered the Federal Aviation Agency said today.

New York City sold yesterday a bond issue of $114million at the most favorable rate of interest it has received in l6 months. And for the first time in more than a year there was competitive bidding for the issue, which was said to indicate a greater public interest in buying tax-free municipal bonds, including the city's large offering.
Striking welfare workers returned to their jobs yesterday as fact-finding bean in their wage dispute with the city.
GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 19 (AP) A 52-year-old Greenwich man awaiting trial on a charge of negligent homicide in the death of his wife was found dead today in front of his house.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Revenue freight traffic volume generated by carloadings on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Jan. 14 were both ahead of the corresponding week of 1966.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 19 "This is a political war," said Lieut. Col. William Corson, the intense commander of the Marines' Third Tank Battalion near Danang, "and we must learn to fight on the enemy's terms."
Interstate Department Stores, Inc., announced yesterday the acquisition for "several millions in cash" of the four-store Children's Supermart, Inc., Washington.
Charles A. (Rip) Engle joined the illustrious company of Amos Alonzo Stagg and Glenn (Pop) Warner last night as a recipient of the annual award of the Touchdown Club.
Criminal Court Judge Simon Silver dismissed yesterday and assault charge against LeRoi Jones, the Negro playwright who wrote antiwhite plays for the Black Arts Theatre.

The agreement just reached between the New Jersey State Commuter Agency and the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad is an important step toward improving commuter rail service in the metropolitan area. It guarantees continuance of service for the 30,000 daily riders of the line, and will provide badly needed new care and equipment through a long-term capital partnership with the state.

The clearest thing about the end of the three-day welfare strike is that it should never have begun. The unionized social workers have agreed to fact-finding on wages by an outside mediator. Other disputed issues will also go to fact-finding if further negotiations fail to resolve them.

HARTFORD, Jan. 19 Dr. Theodore David Lockwood, provost at Union College, Schenectady, N.Y., has been named president of Trinity College. A Trinity alumnus, he will succeed Dr. Albert C. Jacobs, who will retire on June 30, 1968.
TOKYO Japan appears to be entering a new period of vigorous growth after having weathered the most severe business recession in the postwar recovery era.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Jan. 19 (AP) A day-long search by ships and aircraft failed today to turn up a trace of five Navy airmen whose helicopter vanished at sea.
In a flagrant attempt to win the hearts of new passengers through their stomachs, the president of Braniff Airways yesterday banned green peas from his airline and promised gourmet goodies for all.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Dr. Lincoln Gordon, a professor of economics, diplomat and Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, has been named president of Johns Hopkins University.
JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 19 The chancellor of the University of Mississippi, John D. Williams, whose administration was shaken by the desegregation crisis in 1962, resigned today, effective next Dec. 24.

The Xerox Corporation in 1966 recorded the biggest annual revenues and net income in its 60-year history, according to a report yeterday by Joseph C. Wilson, chairman and chief executive and C. Peter McColough, president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The flow of new orders for durable goods rose in December, largely because of a jump in military contracts, but remained below the level of earlier in the year, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Nine lawyer-members of the House of Representatives, one of them a Negro, were chosen today for the special committee to investigate the qualifications of Representative Adam Clayton Powell.

BABYLON, L.I., Jan. 19 Charles P. Underwood, senior member of Fishel, Underwood Fishel, Lawyers Here, died today at the Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip. He was 63 years old and lived at 120 Baker Street in West Babylon.
SINGAPORE-Whatever its political and military consequences, the American build-up in South Vietnam last year spelled opportunity for alert Asian businessmen.

MANILA When historians get around to chronicling Asian efforts toward economic development in the mid-20th century, they may likely find that the programs that did not work outnumbered those that did. Among the case studies of failure almost certainly will be the story of Phlippine rice.
SYDNEY, Australia Economic development is gaining momentum in the island territories of the South and Southwest Pacific.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 19 Mrs. Constance Goldberg has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alice Goldberg, to Peter Michael Kreindler, son of Mr. and Mrs. David, Kreindler of Liberty, N.Y.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 19 Mr. and Mrs. John Paul Blakely have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol T. Blakely, to Jonathan W. Kaplan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Milton A. Kaplan of New York.
Newsprint production in North America during 1966 was a record 10,828,933 tons, 9.4 per cent more than in 1965, the Newsprint Service Bureau reported yesterday.
NEW DELHI Nepal came cut of the economic shadow of her giant neibhbor last year.
OTTAWA, Jan. 19 Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson today rejected new proposals that Canada stop shipping arms to the United States until the United States stops its air attacks on North Vietnam.
The nation's leading chain organizations achieved record sales in December and for 1966, according to a survey made yesterday by The New York Times.
THERE are circumstances in which bad musical com edy books don't matter so much. They sort of create airspaces around the songs, giving them a decent chance to sneak up on you.
Cocoa traders got a surprise package yesterday in the form of a report of substantially lower Ghana purchases of cocoa in the week ended Wednesday than had been generally expected.
MIAMI, Jan. 19 Cuba and Czechoslovakia signed a trade agreement yesterday for an exchange of $90-million worth of goods in 1967, the Havana radio announced today.

The special Dutchess County deer season scheduled for Jan. 30 and 31 to remove 400 animals and thereby reduce agricultural damage next year, is having problems. Would-be hunters are complaining they cannot obtain landowner permission.
The Washington National Symphony Will give three concerts for children at Philharmonic Hall this season, with Howard Mitchell, the orchestra's music director, conducting.

Lukas Foss, the composer who conducts the Buffalo Philharmonic, will make his debut as an opera conductor for the New York City Opera's production of "The Marriage of Figaro" on Feb. 11 at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center.

HONG KONG Asia's attempts to free itself from the bonds of want and economic backwardness made generally disappointing progress last year. There was a growing realization that the continent's 1.8billion people 54 per cent of mankind were unable to feed themselves.

The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, announced yesterday that a move was under way to give laymen a greater voice in governing the 124year-old Roman Catholic institution.

The Consolidated Edison Company said, yesterday it could get 12 million more cubic feet of natural gas daily starting next fall and 66 million more daily in the fall of 1968 if it could get Federal Power Commission approval.

A group of Benedictine scholars engaged in the first systematic microfilming and cataloguing of European monastic libraries has announced plans to make the project the basis of an unusual interfaith research center.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 19 The Premier of South Vietnam, Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky, said today that he did not believe that Hanoi would request Chinese troops for North Vietnam. If it did so, he said, all Vietnamese from North and South would unite to defend their land.
Twenty-two prominent New Yorkers banded together yesterday as a nonpartisan Committee on Constitutional Issues, committed to work for a tighter, yet flexible, State Constitution.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. As 1966 ebbed, concern mounted about the fact that the world's relatively static output of food was lagging increasingly behind the needs of an expanding global population.

John C. Doughty, who as traffic methods supervisor of the New York Telephone Company was responsible for the renaming of telephone exchanges died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 24-30 29th Street, Astoria, Queens.
MADRID, Jan. 19 The Spanish Government received unexpected criticism today from the heads of its own labor organization.
A blue-ribbon committee of savings bank and savings and loan executives recommended yesterday a sweeping overhaul of legislation in New York state governing their operations.
More than 300 businessmen and patent lawyers gathered yesterday at the Plaza Hotel for the first interindustry discussion of the recently proposed changes in the United States patent system.

The Bronx District Attorney's office announced yesterday that 18 persons had been indicted on charges of cheating the Welfare Department out of about $30,000. Thirteen of those indicted have been arrested.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The appointment of Dr. Robert H. Simpson, Associate Director of the United States Weather Bureau since 1964, as director of the bureau's National Hurricane Center in Miami, was announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, L.I., Jan. 19 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Jacobson of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Jacobson, to Robert Stephen Zeiger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Zeiger of Lake Success and Miami Beach

A citizens' committee yesterday accused the Department of Welfare of "gross negligence" in its administration of the eight-month-old Medicaid program. It charged that the city had "lost" more than $30-million in state and Federal funds by failing to apply for reimbursement of hospital expenses.

The Marine Midland Corporation, New York's largest bank holding company, reported yesterday that net operating earnings for the final quarter of 1966 amounted to $9,173,972 or 77 cents a common share. This compares with $7,976,762, or 65 cents, in the 1965 period.

PAUL BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 19 (UPI) Chandler Harper of Portsmouth. Va., a former Professional Golfers' Association national champion, put out the medalist, Butch Baird, in the P.G.A.'s national match-play championship today.

The spot rate on the British pound was steady in quiet trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. Currency for today closed 4 points higher at $2.7919. Monday's quotes, ranging from $2.7906 to $2.7908, reflected normal weekend factors.

WORKED way up from owner of small-town silk shop to head of concern that pioneered and leads South Korea's electric-appliance and plastics industries. ...Born 1907 to wealthy landlord family .... Learned business as director of farmers' cooperative at age of 21.

The long, slow but almost sure process of getting President Sukarno out of office as well as out of power has advanced another step. Foreign Minister Adam Malik has publicly asked the one time "President for Life" and "Great Guide of the Revolution" to step down. As expected, Sukarno angrily announced that he would do nothing of the sort. However, another damaging blow has been struck at Indonesia's one-time political and always charismatic leader.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPI) Dick Hutcherson of KeokuK, Iowa, captured the pole position today for Sunday's $85,000 Riverside 500-mile stock car race. He toured the Riverside Raceway course in 106,660 miles an hour to lead the day's qualifiers.

One of the nation's fastestgrowing airlines, Braniff International, yesterday completed its $30-million purchase of Panagra (Pan American Grace Airways) and assumed dominance of United States-flag traffic to the west coast of South America.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The board of trustees at George Washington University voted today to end the school's football program after 58 years of varsity competition.
The appointment of Raymond R. Hermann Jr., 46 years old, as general manager of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation, was announced yesterday.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 19 President Eduardo Frei Montalva called for the dissolution of Congress tonight so that national elections may be held.

The fastest, steepest climb in municipal bond prices since World War II, if not in history, lost some of its extraordinary strength yesterday. Government and corporate bonds also declined. Some money market rates, however, continued to drop.

Wall Street's first reaction yesterday to word that the Justice Department had intervened in the proposed merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., was to sell.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art has received a grant of $100,000 from the New York State Council on the Arts to develop a program for high school students in the museum and in classrooms.
The following reports were provided yesterday by operators of the ski areas (messages were filed at the times indicated in parentheses):

ABBEY SIMON did not duck the issue at his Carnegie Hall recital last night. There was not one piece on his program that did not pose musical or technical difficulties of the highest order. It was the program of a pianist confident of his ability; and also the program of a pianist who obviously conceives of the instrument as a romantic, 19th-century instrument.
Prices declined on the London Stock Exchange as the Bank of England maintained its 7 per cent discount rate.

LEWISTON, N.Y., Jan. 19 Frank B. Snedecor, manager of the Niagara Falls plant of the Titanium Alloy Manufacturing division of the National Leads Company, died of cancer today at Mount St. Mary's Hospital. He was 62 years old.

Philip J. Levin, head of the group seeking to gain control of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., charged yesterday that the motion picture company's management was squandering corporate funds to fight its proxy battle.
MADRID, Jan. 19--The establishment of diplomatic relations between Spain and Israel was urged today in an editorial in the influetial Roma Catholic Daily YA.

SINGAPORE A wary optimism over the economic outlook prevails in Singapore. People generally are encouraged by the recently passed budget, which does not call for tax increases and offers liberal investment incentives.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 Daniel Escobedo, who was the central figure in a landmark Supreme Court decision concerning defendams' rights, had another day in court today as a defendant and as an officer of the court.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 19 (UPI) The president of Outboard Marine Corporation today overrode a stockholder's challenge to the re-election of Senator-elect Charles H. Percy to the company's board of directors.

A mysterious disruption of cell growth, not an excess of acid, may be the primary cause of stomach and intestinal ulcers, a research team at Cornell University Medical College reported yesterday at a meeting here of the American College of Physicians.

With the final deadline for the Kennedy Round less than six months away, negotiations are still moving at a disappointing snail's pace. Representative Thomas B. Curtis of Missouri, who as a special Congressional member of the United States delegation in Geneva has kept close watch oa the bargaining, reports that he no longer is optimistic about the outcome because of "the lack of forward momentum."
SYDNEY, Australia Buoyed by mounting income from the development of mineral resources and the accelerating recovery from a severe drought. Australia's economy entered 1967 with bright expectations.

LOUISVILLE Ky., Jan. 19 (UPI)-The national director of Selective Service, Gen. Lewis B. Hershey today ordered Cassius Clay's local draft board to reopen his case for a draft deferment on grounds he is a Black Muslim minister.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 19 The marriage of Miss Nancy Ruth Earl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Zachary Harry Earl, to David Bernard Albro, son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Albro, of Dayton, Ohio, took place here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)--A wide range of public facilities would be required to have emergency electric power equipment, under a bill introduced today by Sen. Jacob K. Javits.
The appointment of George Champion as national chairman of the 1967 United Negro College fund campaign was announced yesterday by William T. Gossett, chairman of the fund's board of directors.

OMAHA, Jan. 19 (AP) Scott Allen, a 17-year-old from Smoke Rise, N.J., finished strong in the compulsory figures to take a slight lead in defense of his men's singles title in the National figure skating championships today.
The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc., announced here yesterday the election of Reed Clark as president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The Senate Majority Leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, criticized the Administration today for "marking time" on European policy as he renewed his campaign for a reduction of United States troops in Europe.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy suggested yesterday that young men might be exempted from the draft in return for serving a specified number of years on a police force.

McConaughy, said this because the Chinese government "believes in free and private enterprise, welcomes foreign industrialists, businessmen and entrepreneurs, and encourages the inflow of foreign capital."
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 102.7 on Wednesday from 102.9 on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19-- New Jersey and New York dairy farmers would get more money for their milk under a proposal made today by the Agriculture Department.
The stock market kept its winning streak intact yesterday, but it was a close call.

BONN, Jan. 19 Look magazine's suit for an injunction to prevent publication of further installments of William ManChester's book, "The Death of a President," by the West German magazine Stern will be heard tomorrow by a panel of three judges of a Hamburg Distract Civil Court.

SPOKANE, Wash., Jan. 19 (AP)--An Air Force KC-135 tanker plane, flying from Hawaii with nine persons aboard, presumably crashed tonight on or near a mountain northeast of here, officials at the Fairchild Air Force Base said.

KENWORTH, N.J., Jan. 19 John W. Shallcross of 609 Springfield Road, founder in 1914 of the Shallcross Express Company here, died last night at the Alexian Brothers Hospital in Elizabeth. His age was 64.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco. Jan. 19 (UPI) The last leg of the Monte Carlo rally began tonight boiling down to a grudge match involving men, machine and tires over 360-miles of of snow-packed and ice-slick mountain passes behind this Rivera resort town.
Jay A. Pritzker and W.H. Gonyea, chairman and president, respectively, of the E.L. Bruce Company, are interested in selling their 26 per cent stock interest in the company.
Teacher (speaking to a Department of Parks employs at the Central Parks Zoo while a class of 6-year-olds shiver in the cold): "Is there a giraffe here?"
At Lincoln Center tonight: "Peter Grimes," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Festival Orchestra of New York, Thomas Dunn, conductor, with John Atlkins, pianist, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.
A patient at a state mental hospital was arrested yesterday in the subway shooting of a 33year-old Queens draftsman last Dec. 22.

Two city department heads said yesterday that they were "very' dissatisfied" with the length of time it took the Brooklyn Union Gas Company to respond to notice of the gas leak that caused a fire and an explosion in South Jamaica, Queens on Jan. 13.

The world's largest collier, the new 869-foot French bulk carrier Cetra Columba, now on her maiden voyage, is expected to start loading Monday the largest coal cargo ever shipped from the Hampton Roads area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--The President's National Crime Commission, under pressure from supporters of President Johnson, has backed away from a recommendation for new legislation to permit wiretapping and electronic eavesdropping by the police.

MANILA The old bromides about carrying coals to Newcastle and selling refrigerators to Eskimos neatly fit the case of Felix Lirag, whose Consolidated Mills, Inc., is doing a thriving business exporting textiles to Japan. What Mr. Lirag actually sells the Japanese are denim, khaki and industrial textiles such as curtain material.

Hard-working free Chinese on Taiwan, a province of the Republic of China again have demonstrated their pioneering spirit this time by establishing the bonded factory zone, officially tailed Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone, which has opened new door's to the world of international trade.
Mayor Lindsay ordered the City Investigation Commissioner yesterday to initate a "top priority" inquiry into alleged misconduct in the hospital affiliation program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Following are excerpts from addresses on the State of the Union as prepared for delivery tonight by the Republican leaders of the House and Senate Representative Gerald R. Ford and Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen:

MANILA The Philippine economy in the last two months has been eagerly awaiting a financial bonanza represented in the hopes of President Ferdinand E. Marcos at least by massive infusions of American aid, as well as a flood of loans and investment capital from both the United States and Japan.

CAPETOWN, Jan. 19 The governing Nationalist party caucus today elected the Minister of iFnance, Dr. Theophilus Ebenhaezer Donges, as the party's nominee for the office of State President of South Africa.

The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals will hold its 17th Animal Kingdom Ball in the Colonnades Ballroom at Essex House next Thursday. The theme will be "Carnival 101," denoting the organization's 101st year. fl cocktail reception with carnival games will be held in the Colonnades North, adjoining the ballroom.
LA ROCHELLE, France, Jan. 19 The Chrysler Corporation's next move in Europe will be to acquire majority control of Barreiros Diesel, a Spanish company, an authoritative source said here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., In Norway it is Fredskorps in the Philippines, Operation Brotherhood and in West Germany Deutscher Entwicklungsdienst. In these and 15 other nations Victor Hugo's contention, that "no army can withstand the strength of an idea whose time has come," has been borne out.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19 More American servicemen were killed or wounded in action during the week that ended Saturday than in any week since the Vietnamese war began.
KARACHI, Pakistan Continued export gains and a more favorable balance-of-payments position have brightened Pakistan's economic picture.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 19--Former Ambassador Quintanilla said tonight that President Ho Chi Minh was giving careful consideration to an invitation to attend the unofficial conference in Geneva next May.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Republican Congressional leaders put the country on notice tonight that they would work to defeat or drastically alter a large portion of President Johnson's foreign and domestic programs.

THE PRESIDENT Made presentation of the Medal of Honor to Air Force Maj. Bernard Fisher; received credentials from Bui Diem, new Ambassador from South Vietnam; received courtesy call from former Postmaster General James A. Farley.

ROME, Jan. 19 A bill to establish civil divorce in Italy cleared a major parliamentary obstacle today, but still faces powerful opposition of the Roman Catholic Church, the Christian Democratic party and the Government "establishment."
A group of wealthy New Yorkers have saved a well-loved Gramercsy Park landmark from demolition. They bought it.

MANILA, Jan. 19 Fifteen American-owned companies here, which suspended operations Jan. 1 when the city's Mayor, Antonio Villegas, refused to renew their annual retail trade permits, have been given permission to resume operation as a result of a Supreme Court decision. However, Mr. Villegas, despite the ruling, refused to grant renewal of the permits.

Metre-Goldwyn-Mayer, whose management is in a prosy fight to retain control of the company is planning to shoot 14 feature films in Hollywood between now and September, it was announced here yesterday by Robert H. O'Brien, the company's president.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 19 (UPI) The Roman Catholic Archbishop of San Antonio approved a proposed community Planned Parenthood program yesterday on the condition that no teachings that are opposed by the church be forced on Catholics.
It was just like old times yesterday in the financial district when the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company broke ground for its 22-story operations center.

The skeleton in the old trunk that patrons of the HarveyGautier Bar and Grill brought out occasionllly as a joke may have been theatrical, but it was no prop, the police said yesterday. They said that it was a man's skeleton and that they were trying to find out who he was and how he died.
KARACHI, Pakistan Two devastating cyclones and widespread floods in the last few months have had an adverse effect on the two major crops of East Pakistan raw jute and rice.

JAKARTA, Indonesia "Some economics student doing his Ph.D. dissertation ought to come here," an international financial expert visiting Indonesia recently remarked. "He could write the definitive thesis on a vanishing phenomenon: galloping, uncontrolled inflation."

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 19 (Reuters) The preliminary trials to select the Australian challenger for the America's Cup have been postponed to allow modifications to be made to Gretel's hull, the Royal Sydney Yacht Squadron said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 With the exception of the press itself, no American institution is better at handing out criticism or worse at taking criticism than the Congress of the United States.

The Port of New York Authority, which has been negotiating for more than a year in lease Teterboro Airport to Pan American World Airways, announced a $3.7-million runway improvement program for the field yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Doug Mohns, continued to torment his former Boston teammates by scoring three goals tonight in sparking the Chicago Black Hawks to a 4-2 National Hockey League victory over the Bruins.
A NEW service for brokerage customers known as creditor life insurance received the go-ahead signal yesterday from the New York Stock Exchange's board of governors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 A fourth unidentified satellite has been discovered. It fell from orbit on Dec. 30.

TAIPEI, Taiwan The economy of Taiwan, prospering but still an upstart, showed last year that it could get along nicely without United States aid. It has still to demonstrate that its fast-rising exports can hold their own in world markets and that enough jobs can be created for the generation now entering the job market.
The supplies in New York City's upstate reservoirs remained constant in the 24hour period that ended at 8 A.M. yesterday. Gains and losses balanced out exactly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)--The House voted today to give President Johnson 10 more day to submit his annual Economic Report to Congress.

A strong interstate agency, with a vote for the Federal Government equal to the vote of either New York State or New Jersey, was recommended yesterday to control air pollution in the metropolitan area.
LONDON, Jan. 19 A few more charred British military documents were found today at Chislehurst on the outskirts of London as security experts sought to determine why and how they had got there.
LONDON, Jan. 19 A few more charred British military documents were found today at Chislehurst on the outskirts of London as security experts sought to determine why and how they had got there.
The Museum of Modern Art announced yesterday the formation of a Television Archive of the Arts to preserve for posterity documentary film portraits of contemporary artists.
A redesigned British-built line of 1967 Ford Cortina cars was announced yesterday by Donald N. Frey, general manager of the Ford Division.

SAIGON, South Vietnam South Vietnamese and American economists are expressing the same kind of we-have-stoppedlosing relief that their military counterparts voiced a year before about the shooting war.
Wililam Alfred, author of "Hogan's Goat," is making a gift of time--watches, some almost a century old--to cast members tonight.

Frank D. Chutter, a leading utilities specialist, filed suit here yesterday against the United Shareowners of America, Inc., and the Telephone Shareowners Committee, Inc., for alleged nonpayment of fees for his testimony as an expert in the Federal Communications Commission's full-scale investigation into the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
VIENTIANE, Laos The war in Laos was recently described by military men as a "successful mess" from the United States point of view.
NEW DELHI India's humanity, increasing at the rate of one million a month, rose above 500 million last year.

CERVINIA, Italy, Jan. 19 The international set has taken over this colorful Alpine village nestling in the shadows of the shaggy Matterhorn. Skiers are now shuttling between Switzerland and Italy with about as little fuss as commuters exhibit in rattling between New Jersey
SEOUL, South Korea Low wage scales and the ability to learn new skills quickly are attracting an increasing number of foreign investors to Korea, once called the "Hermit Kingdom."

PARIS "The stronger Russia is in Central Asia, the weaker England is in India and the more conciliatory she will be in Europe." This observation by the famous Czarist General M.D. Skobelev expressed an underlying thesis of Russia's nineteenth-century policy.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 19--Nazareth's Municipal Council elected an Orthodox Christian Arab associated with the Israeli Government as Mayor of the city today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 19 Udell Charles Ypung, who retired in 1958 as the General Foods Corporation's executive vice president for engineering and manufacturing, died today at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 7 Beresford Lane.
Dr. George Washington Van Vleck, until 1956 head of the history department of the Brooklyn Polytechnic Preparatory Country Day School, died Wednesday in a hospital at Sodus, N.Y. His age was 83.

Phil Feldman, the producer who last year made the Seven Arts film "You're A Big Boy Now" entirely in New York, announced here yesterday that he has bought five more film prop-, erties for production here.

The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia reversed yesterday a Federal Maritime Commission decision disapproving two rules of the Trans-Atlantic Passenger Steamship Conference and the Atlantic Passenger Steamship Conference.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 19 A gas transmission company won the right today to build a 1.8-mile-long section of pipeline through Troy Meadows on a route it had proposed over the protests of a conservation group that owns most of the unspoiled area.
Leo Greenebaum, a prominent paper merchant here for more than 40 years, died yesterday morning at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 72 years old.
RANGOON, Burma The Burmese economy went through the year in a state of shock.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 19 Ethiopia's chief representative. EndalKachew Makonnen, proposed today that a small committee of conciliation drawn from the nonaligned members of the United Nations try to bring the combatants in Vietnam to the conference table.
DETROIT, Jan. 19 (AP) United States automobile production totaled 165,082 units this week as some plants continued to operate on shortened schedules.
BONN, Jan. 19 West Germany's recently formed coalition Government faced its first stiff test today when Cabinet unity was disrupted by a disagreement over federal budget plans for 1967.
The Police Department yesterday extended its program aimed at clearing the streets of illegally parked cars by adding a drive-away program to its tow-away campaign.

New York City does the poorest job of enforcing its parking regulations of any large city in this country. Traffic in Manhattan is at the crisis level, at least in part because an average of 75,000 illegally parked cars daily clog its streets. The result is the world's worst continuous traffic jam.
HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 19 (Agence France-Presse) North Vietnam said today that many civilians were killed or wounded in a new escalation of the air war by the United States.
David M. Baldwin, president of the Charles F. Noyes Company last night received the annual award of the Real Estate Board of New York for the most ingenious deal of 1966.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The International Telephone and Telegraph Company agreed today to postpone its planned merger with American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., for two weeks. I.T.T. also announced it would "vigorously oppose" the Justice Department's attempt to force a complete reconsideration of the merger by the Federal Communications Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today he still had to "squeeze the last water" out of his program to consolidate or phase out superfluous military bases and other activities as an economy measure.
PARIS, Jan. 19--France and West Germany are going into partnership to build a powerful research reactor at Grenoble, under the terms of agreements signed today in that city.

PORT TOWNSEND, Wash., Jan. 19 Harry Forwoud, a theatrical press agent in New York and on the road for almost 40 years, died at the St. John's Hospital here Monday. He had suffered a stroke three days before at his home in nearby Nordland. He was 62 years old.
SEATTLE, Jan. 19 (AP) American mountaineers cilmbed six peaks in Antarctica during a 45-day expedition, members reported today.

The preliminary audit by Controller Mario A. Procaccino of three contracts linking New York City's municipal and voluntary hospitals confirms the belief that serious abuses have crept into the administration of the affiliation program. Energetic correctives are plainly required to eradicate the waste and mismanagement that is the four-year heritage of hastily drawn and inadequately policed agreements.

ATHENS, Jan. 19 Greece decided tonight to take stern action against Greek ships trading with Cuba in defiance of a three-year-old Government prohibition against ships as well as sanctions on violating trading with Rhodesia.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 19 (AP) Edward Mallinckrodt Jr., retired board chairman of Mallinckrodt Chemical Works, an international concern, died today at his home here. He was 88 years old.

WHEN Joe DiMaggio first reported to the Yankees, he brought with him a glowing reputation as a minor leaguer plus the he-can't-miss label. It made for a somewhat uneasy confrontation. DiMadge was a trifle awed by the Yankees and the Bombers felt obliged to greet him with slightly more respect than is normally bestowed on a rookie.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 19 (UPI) The body of a 73-yearold California professor who died of cancer has arrived here for storage in a capsule at 220 degrees below zero centigrade for an experiment in bringing versons back from the dead.

ATHENS, Jan. 19 Greece decided tonight to take stern action against Greek ships trading with Cuba in defiance of a three-year-old Government prohibition against ships as well as sanctions on violating trading with Rhodesia.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 19 A handyman who had been summoned to court here to testify whether a mentally ill woman, for whom he worked, had any assets, has astonished lawyers and judges by calmly surrendering $365,000 worth of them.

Max Bartholet, who retired two years ago as secretary. treasurer and director of the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., at 980 Madison Avenue, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital, He was 66 years old and lived at 423 West 120th Street.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 19 Eugene V. Restow, United States Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, conferred today with Indian leaders on President Johnson's effort to internationalize the attack on India's food crisis.
Don Petersen, a 39-year-old teacher of schizophrenic children, has been named the first winner of the $2,000 ANTABishop playwriting award for his drama, "Does a Tiger Wear a Necktie?"
TOKYO Japan, the world's third-ranking steel producing country, behind the United States and the Soviet Union, looks for a continued high rate of expansion in 1967.
PARIS, Jan. 20 Half the manuscript of Mozart's "Don Giovanni" has vanished from a closely guarded vault of the Bibliotheque Nationale, France's national library.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 Since last month checks and electronic data processing records of the Philadelphia National Bank have been flown daily by helicopter between the city's International Airport and the bank's new heliport atop the 13-story Gimbel Building.
ROME, Jan. 20 Roman Catholics of the Rome Diocese have been forbidden by the Vatican to participate in three proposed Christian-unity prayer services to be held in non-Catholicchurches here.
BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 20 An astronomer-physicist said today he believed that chlorophyll, a key compound of life on earth, exists in outer space.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 20 (AP) Cliff Richey of Dallas led an American advance into the second round of the Australian tennis championships today.
The Winter Antiques Show like New York itself, has undergone considerable changes over the years, sometimes with clamor and controversy, but has managed to thrive.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 20 The highest legislative body in Indonesia will meet in March or April to discuss President Sukarno's tenure in office, leaders of the Provisional People's Consultative Congress announced after a six-hour meeting here today.
LONDON, Jan. 20 (Reuters) A privately owned bank, with 8-million ($22.4-million) in deposits, announced tonight that it was unable to meet payments.
Texas Instruments, Inc., set new highs in sales and profits in the fourth quarter of 1966 and for the year, the company's report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan.19 (AP) An intensive recruiting drive by the United States Office of Education has overcome a critical manpower shortage that hobbled Federal school aid programs in their early months.
The New York City Council on Port Development and Promotion has adopted a resolution supporting a plan to turn over the New York State Barge Canal to the Federal Government.

MIAMI, Jan. 20 A British freighter that ran aground last May off the northeastern coast of Cuba was refloated yesterday, the Havana radio said today. The broadcast said the ship would be added to the Cuban merchant fleet.

A forum on "The Crisis of Immorality: Values, Ethics and Attitudes in the Jet Age" will be held Monday at 1:30 P.M. by the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women. The 18th annual event will be held in the Leon Lowenstein Auditorium of Temple Emanu-El, 10 East 66th Street.
CERTAIN artists at certain points in their careers offer themselves as representative cases.
As a family might buy a washing machine, the Boston Museum of Fine Arts has bought a rare statue on the installment plan.
The array of alphabetical agencies in the city is getting three additions all of them volunteer groups associated with the fight against narcotics addiction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Communist China has assured the United States that its ambassador will attend the scheduled meeting between American and Chinese ambassadors in Warsaw Wednesday, officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman served notice today that the Administration would fight to preserve present farm programs to keep agriculture from plunging into "chaos."
