Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton expressed doubts yesterday about the advisability of moving Manhattan's wholesale food markets to the Bronx, as proposed by the city administration. BUFFALO, Jan. 29 Senator Robert F. Kennedy, took part today in a Seneca Indian pow-wow, but there were no headdresses or feathers.

Isabelle C. Austin, the last publicity manager of the old Roxy Theatre, died yesterday in St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases, the Bronx. Miss Austin, whose age was 63, lived at 350 West 57th Street.
Changes in the positions of several senior executives of the Society National Bank of Cleveland were announced yesterday.

MADRID, Jan. 20 Jose Luis Lopez Aranguren, one of Spain's best known intellectuals, has been arrested for holding an "unauthorized meeting" with several hundred university students at the northern city of Santiago de Compostela.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) The defending champion, Mrs. Nancy Roth Syms, and two other former winners were eliminated today in the second and third rounds of the Doherty Cup women's amateur golf tournament.

THIS Alaska king crab souffle is one of the favorite recipes at the University of Alaska. It would make a delectable luncheon or supper dish served with a tossed salad and a side dish of leaf spinach seasoned with lemon juice and nutmeg.

The Printing Pressmen's Union No. 2 presented contract demands yesterday to the Publishers Association of New York City, calling for increases in wages of $35 a week for those on the day shift and $42 a week for those on the night shift.
HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I. Jan. 20--The seventh annual Red Feather Ball will be held here Jan. 28 at the Seawane Club to benefit the endowment fund of the Five Towns United Fund.
DETROIT, Jan. 20 Leaders of American industry today hailed current economic and political reforms in Eastern European-Communist countries.
Price increases were announced yesterday by a South African platinum producer and a Canadian copper company.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 20 An angry crowd of 1,000 Cornell University students, demonstrating against the censorship of a campus literary magazine, today prevented the arrest of five youths by the Ithaca police.

History, like a badly constructed concert hall, has occasional dead spots where the music can't be heard. Everything in the United States today the boredom of the young, the numbness of the arts and the ineptitude of the politicians indicates that we are caught in one of them.
YONKERS, Jan. 20 Lindsay Scott, an Australian import now leased to Rainbow International of Canada, sped to a length victory tonight at Yonkers Raceway in winning the featured $6,000 mile pace.

BRISBANE, Australia, Jan. 20 (AP) Street fights broke out in Brisbane tonight as proKy and anti-Ky demonstrators greeted Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam on his return from a day of meeting the Australian people won a handshaking basis.
The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., proxy fight took another turn yesterday as Federal Judge David N. Edelstein dismissed here a motion by M-G-M for an injunction.

William J. Kappel of Pittsburgh, founder and chairman of the board of the Busch Jewelry Company of New York and other cities, died yesterday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. He was 81 years old.
The New Haven Railroad's net loss for 1966 has been estimated at about $11.5-million, an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner was told here yesterday.
WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 20 Miss Mary Joanne Coakley and William Walter Galvin 3d of New York will be married Feb. 5 in Worcester.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 20--Belgium warned the Congo today that she risked "a serious political crisis" if she kept Belgian technicians at work in the Katanga copper mines against their will.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI) Billy Foster, 29 years old, was killed instantly today at the Riverside International Raceway when his 1967 Dodge crashed into a retaining wall while he was making a practice run for Sunday's $85,000 Riverside 500-mile Grand National stock car race.

MACAO, Saturday, Jan. 21 (AP) Three Red Chinese gunboats moved out of Macao's Inner Harbor last night after a show of power apparently designed to impress on the tiny Portuguese colony the consequences of opposing its huge Communist neighbor.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 John T. Deegan was named today as the new warden of Sing Sing Prison. He will succeed Wilfred L. Denno, who retired Jan. 11 after 16 years as warden of the storied prison on the Hudson River.
An official of the Consolidated Edison Company confirmed in sworn testimony yesterday that the company's loss of $907,500 on World's Fair bonds had been passed along to its customers.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI) Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown, one of Dr. Clark Kerr's stanchest defenders, viewed the ouster of the president of the University of California today with "utter contempt."
Meyer Magid was named yesterday as president of the London Character Shoes division of the Commonwealth Shoe and Leather Company, Whitman, Mass.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 20 (AP) A series of meetings were held this week between three unions and management but little progress was made in ending the nearly three-month-old Toledo newspaper strike, it was reported today.

Jean Fenn will sing her first Mimi with the Metropolitan Opera in Puccini's "La Boheme" during the season's 22d week, which begins Feb. 20, Felicia Weathers, another soprano, will return that week as Lisa in Tchaikovsky's "The Queen of Spades."

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 20 (UPI) The Coast Guard expanded today the search for a chartered plane that disappeared Tuesday while carrying Mr. and Mrs. Stephen R. Currier of New York City on a vacation flight to the Virgin Islands.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 20 (UPI) President Eduardo Frei Montalva sent Congress a constitutional reform bill today that would allow him to dissolve Congress and call new elections.

Twenty-two dogs, ears flopping and tails wagging, turned up on the stage of Philharmonic Hall late yesterday afternoon to prepare for their first concert appearance. They ran around, sniffing eagerly to get the feel of the stage, eyes gleaming.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara released today $564-million for the construction of military housing, barracks and other projects.

The director of the agency that accredits colleges in the Western states said yesterday that his group was planning no action as a result of the dismissal of Dr. Clark Kerr as president of the University of California.
DALLAS, Jan. 20 John W. Runyon, publisher of The Dallas Times Herald, died of cancer today at the Baylor University Medical Center here. He was 79 years old.
Assemblyman Stanley Steingut called yesterday for legislation to help children whose lives have been disrupted by family emergencies.

With few exceptions, last night's Beethoven Sonata recital by Janos Starker, cellist, and Gunter Ludwig, pianist, at Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art was a pale, out-of-focus affair.
Sgt. Ralph Salerno, who has gained the reputation of knowing more about the Mafia than any other non-member, has put in his retirement papers.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 (UPI) Rudy LaRusso emerged from his five-day retirement today to rejoin the Los Angeles Lakers after Jack Kent Cooke, the owner of the National Basketball Association club, rescinded the star forward's trade in a three-way deal with Detroit and Baltimore.
DURBAN, South Africa, Jan 20 (Reuters) Denis Lindsay rescued South Africa with a century on the first day of the third cricket test against Australia today.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 20 "We have to make the breakthrough in pacification this year," the weary marine officer said the other day, "because there isn't enough time left for us to carry it any further."
A Harlem Head Start center closed its doors yesterday to protest the city's failure to provide it with funds to operate the preschool program for poor children.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 (UPI) The San Francisco Warriors came home today with their scoring star, Rick Barry, minus a tooth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--One of the most influential members of the Senate Armed Services Committee has called for an intensification of American air war on North Vietnam and a "substantial increase" in American forces in South Vietnam "even if this should require mobilization."

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor will ask the Board of Estimate next Thursday to order work on the $575-million World Trade Center halted until the board reviews a formal contract between the city and the Port of New York Authority.

OMAHA, Jan. 20 (AP) Gary Visconti of Detroit in a masterly free-skating finish tonight, wrested the men's singles title from Scott Allen, a two-time winner in the National figure skating championships.
CANNES, France, Jan. 20 Sixty bankers and businessmen from the world's major industrial countries met here today to discuss one of their fundamental problems: raising capital.
New American Library will begin in September publication of a mass-market paperbound periodical called New American Review. Theodore Solotaroff,...

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Jan. 20 Max D. Howell, who as executive director, executive vice president and president of the American Iron and Steel Institute was one of the chief spokesmen for the country's steel industry from 1952 to 1963, died today in Brunswick Memorial Hospital after a short illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Sea Island, Ga.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission ordered the Lone Star Cement Corporation of New York City tonight to sell the ready-mixed concrete plants and related equipment it acquired from W.D. Haden Company of Houston.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 20 A confidential report alleging the closing of churches in the Soviet Union, discrimination against Jews in Iraq and abuses elsewhere was ordered suppressed today by a United Nations subcommission.
I am writing with reference to the consular convention with the U.S.S.R. now pending before the Senate. On Aug. 3, 1965, the Committee on Foreign Relations reported favorably on this convention.

CAPETOWN, Jan. 20 President Charles R. Swart of South Africa emphasized his nation's willingness to cooperate with and aid newly independent African states as he opened the 1967 parliamentary session here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 The engagement of Miss Jeannine H. Rohrbach to Alden T. Leavenworth, son of Dana T. Leavenworth of West Hartford, Conn., and the late Mrs. Marie S. Leavenworth, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Maurice J. Rohrbach of Mount Airy.

Leo T. Mahoney Jr. of Huntington, L.I., was re-elected the national commodore of the Midget Ocean Racing Club last night at the organization's annual meeting at Stouffer's Restaurant on East 42d Street last night. He was also named commodore of the New York station.

Mayor Lindsay urged the Legislature yesterday not to approve any new judgeships until the Constitutional Convention could consider his proposal for the appointment, instead of the election of all judges.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 10 per cent in production for the week ended Jan. 14, compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week.

Prof. and Mrs. William A. Hance of New York and Nantucket have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Bronwen Hance, to Aviation Specialist Elliott Reed McLaughlin U.S.N. He is the son of Prof. and Mrs. Everett R. McLaughlin of State College, Pa.

VILLEFRANCE-SUR-MER, France, Jan. 20 With the ship's band playing the theme from a sentimental Franch film, "The Umbrellas of Cherbourg," the guided missile cruiser Springfield, flagship of the United States Sixth Fleet, sailed from her home port on the French Riviera this morning for the last time.

The Manhattan Democratic organization yesterday asked the special House committee investigating the qualifications of Representative Adam Clayton Powell to explore the facts of the "bag woman" charges Mr. Powell made seven years ago.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 20 (AP) Ray C. Bliss, Republican national chairman, said today that republicans could not sit around and count on the low estimate of President Johnson's popularity to give them a victory in the 1968 race.
A Democrat and a Republican, each prominent in his party, suggested yesterday that the best way to get a short and simple state constitution would be to divide the charter into two parts.
BONN, Jan. 20 The West German Government announced today that it had balanced its 1967 draft budget by wholesale slashing of federal spending plans.
Prices advanced again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Thursday the level it reached on Wednesday, which was 102.7.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 A vehement protest against three major reforms sought by the Securities and Exchange Commission two of them directly involving the commissions that securities buyers are charged has been made by James W. Devant, president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 10 John M. Palmer, a retired advertising executive, died this morning in New Rochelle Hospital after a long illness. He was 73 years old and lived at 105 North Chatsworth Avenue in Larchmont.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Consumer prices recorded their largest rise in a decade in 1966, but the Government's leading expert on prices said today that the rise would not be so great this year.

WAYNE, Pa., Jan. 20 Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Warren Marshall Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pauline Foraker Marshall, to Jose Luis San Roman y Cos-Gayon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jose Palmerino San Roman of Madrid.

MANILA, Jan. 20 (A.P) The future of American retail traders in Manila remained in doubt today in the wake of Mayor Antonio Villegas's defiance of a Supreme Court ruling that retailing by American companies be allowed to continue for the time being.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York announced yesterday that effective next Monday it would reduce its posted rate for loans to security dealers the socalled brokers loan rate from 6 per cent to 6 per cent.
MIAMI, Jan. 21 (UPI) Fifteen 3-year-olds headed by George D. Widener's Bold Hour, have been entered in the $34,700 Hibiscus Stakes at Hialeah Park tomorrow.

ROME, Jan. 20 Eugene Rostow, United States Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, today discussed the food crisis in India and other problems during an informal luncheon with Foreign Minister Amintore Fanfani.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (UPI) Political and boxing notables, fans and friends paid final tribute to Barney Ross today.

Under the Lindsay administration the Department of Parks has at long last been attacking the problem of playground design with creative imagination. The three new designs unveiled at City Hall the other day fully deserve the Mayor's encomium: "Little gems in our total recreation complex."
WALL STREET completed yesterday one of its busiest trading weeks in history. And it took it in stride.
Prices for frozen pork bellies weakened yesterday after traders learned the latest Government estimates of stocks in cold storage.

The Communications Workers of America defeated the Technical, Electronic and Communications Union in a representation election among 27,000 plant employes of the New York Telephone Company, according to vote totals announced yesterday.
THOUSAND OAKS, Calif., Jan. 20 (AP) An actress and a cameraman were killed yesterday during the filming of an automobile commercial on California Highway 23.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 20 On a day more suitable for old salts than golfers, gale winds swept the Crosby ProAmateur tournament today.

CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Jan. 20 (UPI) Jim Clark of Scotland, the former world champion driver, and his countryman, Jackie Stewart, both set lap records on the 2.3-mile race circuit today during practice runs for the Lady Wigram Trophy race tomorrow.

Isidore M. Konowitz, former supervisor of English in the Israeli high schools of Jerusalem and more recently an English teacher in the district school at Tiberias, Israel, died near there Monday at the age of 71.
The New York Rangers, continuing their longest trip of the season, face the last-place Bruins in Boston this afternoon. Tomorrow night the five-game road series will end at Detroit.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 20 Donald M. Russell, the football coach of Wesleyan University, is registering a formal protest with the National Collegiate Football Rules Committee concerning its passage this week of a new punting rule.
MIAMI, Jan. 20 (AP) Farmers in North Vietnams's rice bowl accuse American bomber pilots of trying to destroy their dikes, says an American editor who visited the area.
DETROIT, Jan. 20 (UPI) Roman Catholic traditionalists held a loud demonstration at an interfaith prayer service at a Detroit cathedral last night and stalked out when a rabbi began speaking.

TUSKEGEE, ALA., Jan. 20 (AP) Alabama's first Negro sheriff in this century issued a stern warning yesterday that constables who refuse to show proper identification will be arrested and charged with impersonating an officer.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Jan. 20 (AP) Herbert W. Walker, who had been president and general manager of the Newspaper Enterprise Association, died here today in a hospital where he had been confined for the last six months. He had gone into a coma after suffering a stroke in Kansas City in 1964. He was 71 years old.
The Carborundum Company announced plans yesterday to acquire the Commercial Filters Corporation for about $9.6-million.

A "Salute to American Musical Theater" will be given in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel on April 5 under the sponsorship of the Manhattan School of Music. Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson will be honorary chairman of the event, which will be a combination of a dinner dance and a special musical production.
Two trustees of the Old Met Opera Corporation called on the City Council yesterday to investigate action taken by Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay in an effort to save the opera house.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight that one of the greatest failures of United States foreign policy was the fact that European nations such as France and Britain are trading with North Vietnam and Cuba.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 (UPI) Gov. Ronald Reagan expressed surprise today at the dismissal of Dr. Clark Kerr as president of the university, but added: "I think the Board of Regents acted in a responsible manner."
The pace of construction of nonfarm residential housing will not be so slow this year as was thought just last month, retail lumbermen were told yesterday.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 20 South Korean naval vessels in the Sea of Japan were ordered into combat status today following the sinking of a South Korean patrol ship yesterday by North Korean shore batteries near the demarcation line.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 20--Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Thomas D'Aloise have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Kathleen D'Aloise, to Charles Holloway Goubeaud, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Goubeaud of Jackson Heights, Queens, New York.
BOSTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) John Havlicek scored 6 straight points early in the final period tonight to break a close game open and lead the Boston Celtics to a 129-117 victory over the Baltimore Bullets.
HONG KONG, Jan. 20 An article published in Jenmin Jih Pao has asserted that enemies of Chairman Mao and Defense Minister Lin will be given "no quarter."
ROME There is a wild race on in Italian fashion among men who dress women. Now they want to dress men, too.
OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 20 (AP) Rain and the forecast of more threatened to wash some of the remaining glitter from the American Football League all-star game tomorrow at the Oakland Coliseum.

The spot rate on the British pound was basically firm in moderate trading on foreignexchange markets here yesterday. Currency for Monday was quoted at $2.7910, down 9 points from Thursday. The drop reflected normal weekend considerations.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 20 (AP) The Very Rev. Hugh E. Dunn, president of John Carroll University here, said today that laymen, and not necessarily Catholic laymen, would be named to the school's board of trustees within six months.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 The dismissal of Dr. Clark Kerr as president of the University of California today came as a stunning surprise even to observers who had considered the development an almost inevitability in the near future.
TRENTON, Jan. 20 (AP) A group of state A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders has scrapped plans to invite Michigan Gov. George Romney to speak at a testimonial dinner for Senator Clifford P. Case.
The Central Research library on Fifth Avenue may be forced to cut back in fulfilling the needs of its 5,000 daily users.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 (UPI) Lew Alcindor scored 27 points in 30 minutes of action tonight as University California, Los Angeles, the No. 1 team in the basketball polls, established a school scoring record with a 122-57 victory over Portland (Ore.) University.
Presiding Bishop John E. Hines of the Episcopal Church named a special committee yesterday to "help rethink, restructure and renew" the 3.5million member denomination.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 21 American infantrymen uncovered and explored yesterday a massive tunnel complex that was believed to have served as a headquarters for guerrilla raids and terrorist attacks on Saigon.
TOKYO, Jan. 21 Defense Minister Lin was reported today to have described Communist China as being "in a state of civil war."
A PINT-SIZED new movie may cause a minor revo- lution in the classroom.
The city's doctors and diplomats took the news of Mayor Lindsay's expanded towaway program yesterday with a mixture of dismay and righteous indignation.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 20 The development of a big university center here to help persuade Vassar College to remain and other colleges to expand was advocated today by 32 leaders of industry, government and education.
THERE are many ways to enjoy the handsome spec tacle of this year's Winter Antiques Show, which opened yesterday.
Governor Rockefeller has urged the Federal Power Commission to grant an application of the Consolidated Edison Company for more natural gas as a means of reducing air pollution here.
Franz Allers, the conductor for such Broadway musicals as "My Fair Lady" and "Camelot" is planning to devote his time exclusively to opera and concerts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Military spending soared to $61billion in the calendar year 1966, up $12-billion from the year before, final Treasury figures disclosed today.
BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 20 Dr. Clark Kerr was dismissed today as president of the University of California by the Board of Regents without advance notice.
The Wrecking Corporation of America held a mournful rummage sale at the old Metropolitan Opera House in probably the last public event the building will witness.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 21 (Reuters) Ten British authors denounced critics of United States conduct of the Vietnamese war today and warned them against deceiving themselves that they had silenced the voices of reason.
Contract talks between representatives of 4,000 harbor craft workers and their employers are entering the final week on Monday.

Mrs. L. Hadden Merriman and A. Brewster Lawrence Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Valerie F. Lawrence, to Paul Donham, Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Donham of Orleans, Mass.
Munsingwear, Inc., a producer of men's and women's apparel, announced yesterday in Minneapolis the appointment of A. Byron Reed as president and chief executive officer.

Some of the flowers that bloom in the spring came up pink in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom last night, where the Yorkville Ball was held. The traditional decor of the ball, a benefit for the Yorkville Community Association, is pink.
Claude (Bud) Alexander gave his impressions of the boat-building business yesterday at the New York Coliseum and they were not altogether favorable.
ROME, Jan. 20 Pope Paul VI is suffering from a mild case of influenza and has canceled his appointments for today and tomorrow, according to Vatican sources.
The Valley Mould and Iron Corporation, a large manufacturer of conventional steelmaking equipment, is confident it will be around for a long time, despite attention given to new technology.

A "Guys and Dolls Gala Gambol" will be held in the New Gotham Motor Mansion Garage on Feb. 2 as a benefit for the Demon Runyon Memorial Fund for Cancer Research. Games of skill with prizes awarded will be played on a mezzanine of the garage, at 25 West 55th Street, and guests will dance to music by Bobby Hackett, who has donated his services, and his quintet playing in the garage elevator.
MOSCOW, Jan. 20 Western sources, said here tonight that it was premature to assume that the Soviet Government might be seriously interested in an agreement not to display missile defense systems.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 An objection to the Government's projected sale of Fort Slocum Island to New Rochelle, N.Y., for $485,000 was withdrawn yesterday.

A convicted rapist who admitted stabbing two women to death won dismissal of two murder charges against him yesterday because he had not been informed of his right to counsel before making his confession.

Mrs. Adriana Carranza McDonald, wife of William J. McDonald, a senior vice president of the Wendell P. Colton division of Wesley Advertising, Inc., died Thursday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She lived at 1045 Park Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Reports that military and political leaders have committed suicide in China were greeted with skepticism today by specialists here.

The BT New York Corporation, the large bank holding company, which began operations last June 1, reported net operating earnings of $46,501,000 for 1966, up 12.2 per cent from $41,415,000 in 1965. Earnings a share rose to $4.86 from $4.33.
Bond prices declined slightly yesterday as trading activity diminished considerably from its pace of earlier in the week. Many bond dealers viewed this as the pause that refreshes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 President Johnson sent his first message to the new Congress today, requesting an extension of the expiring portions of the Appalachian Regional Development Act.

"The Shop on Main Street," the Czechoslovak drama, was named last night the winner of the 1967 Joseph Burstyn award, given to what is judged the best foreign-language film by the Independent Film Importers and Distributors of America.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) Edward V. Rickenbacker, airline pioneer who was an ace in World War I, received the Tony Jannus Award tonight.

Robert L. Callan Jr., a radio broadcaster, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at The Lambs Club, 128 West 44th Street.

DALLAS, Jan. 20 (AP) The Rev. Billy Graham the evangelist, said today that his organization was, too big and needed some trimming.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Manufacturers operated their plants at 90 per cent of capacity on the average in the last quarter of 1966, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
THE Men's Pair championship, which opened the Tristate Regional Championship at Grossinger's, in upstate New York, Thursday was won by two cousins, Nat and Hubert Gerstman of Buffalo.

The city has finally given its official backing to the Lower Manhattan Plan released by the Planning Commission last June. An Office of Lower Manhattan Development has also been created to carry, out the plan and to coordinate the city departments and agencies and public and private interests involved.

Abraham I. Stern, executive vice president of Gold Seal Linen Supply Company of Brooklyn, died Thursday of a heart attack in Booth Memorial Hospital, Flushing, Queens. He was 68 years old and lived at 138-10 Franklin Avenue, Flushing.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 20 (AP) Adelphi's basketball team, sparked by Steve Sherman and Mark Schissler, downed New Paitz State, 90-69, tonight for its eighth victory in 10 games.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) Radioactive iodine-131 has been detected in milk from 28 of the 63 sampling stations in the nation since the fifth Chinese Communist nuclear weapons test Dec. 27, the Public Health Service reported today.
WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Jan. 20 Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, a New York union, invited the striking teachers of Woodbridge Township today to apply for jobs in New York.

MOSCOW, Jan. 20--The Soviet Union's campaign against the leadership of Communist China gained momentum today with a new denunciation of Peking and the "serious harm" it has caused to the world Communist movement.
A fireman was arrested at his Queens home yesterday in the hit-and-run death of Joseph P. O'Haire, a reporter for The Daily News.

PORTLAND, Conn., Jan. 20 Mr. and Mrs. John W. Sease have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Sease, to Stephen H. Skiles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Skiles of Sherman, Tex. A summer wedding is planned.

PANAJI, India, Jan. 19 On the veranda of the Mandovi Hotel, the North Indian tourists listen to a laconic radio commentary on the cricket match between India and the West Indies, while a few miles away on the white sands of Dona Paula Beach, Goan boys shout in Portuguese as they play soc cer with a battered old tennis ball.

Mayor Lindsay has given explicit orders to the police to tow all illegally parked automobiles out of the midtown Manhattan towaway zone, including those of diplomats, doctors and others who traditionally are not held to strict adherence to traffic regulations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) President Johnson approved today the appointment of Alan L. Dean, a career civil servant, to be Assistant Secretary of Transportation for Administration.
JERUSALEM (Israel), Jan. 20 A land mine apparently planted within the last 24 hours was found early today by an Israeli patrol outside a border kibbutz in the Galilee area.

MADISON, N.J., Jan. 20 Leonard G. Abraham of 61 Green Avenue, who retired in October as director of the transmission engineering planning center of the Bell Telephone Laboratories in Holmdel, died yesterday of a heart attack at a hospital in Ottawa, Ont. He was 65 years old.

Jacques Sarlie, the Dutch-born financier and art collector, was ordered yesterday to pay more than $400,000 to the E.L. Bruce Company for having sold overpriced shares to the company in a deal worked out between Mr. Sarlie and the company's former president, Edward M. Gilbert.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--Robert G. Baker said at his trial today that he went to Lyndon B. Johnson, "the best friend that I ever had around the Capitol," when he became involved in financial difficulties in 1962.
BACTIEN, South, Vietnam, Jan. 20 (Reuters) Miss Michele Ray, a French journalist who has been missing for three days, was reported alive today and being held captive by Vietcong guerrilas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The State Department made public today correspondence between Secretary of State Dean Rusk and J. Edgar Hoover with the objective of showing that the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation does not oppose the consular treaty with the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The head of a Columbia University laboratory was awarded a patent this week for the probe that has made possible delicate brain surgery by freezing.
The merger of the United States Plywood Corporation and Champion Papers, Inc., was overwhelmingly approved by stockholders yesterday at separate special meetings in New York and Hamilton, Ohio.
Victor Muscat, the New York financier, gained control yesterday of the Mercantile National Bank in Chicago after the management agreed to accept his proposal for an enlarged board of directors.

A cab driver was found shot to death in his cab last night in the East Bronx. He was tentatively identified as Carlos Quilly, about 40 years old. His address was not known.

STORRS, Conn., Jan. 21-- Connecticut and Fordham played their usual hard game of basketball tonight with the Huskies edging the Rams, 67-66.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--Having cut the cloth of his program to suit the shape of the new Congress, President Johnson went to work this week to make it fit and to make a sale. He trimmed and patched, at his budget, but offered still to adjust his design. He defended his own recommendations but promised nonetheless to heed the taste of his customers on Capitol Hill.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Jan. 21 (AP)--A big cruise ship's passengers watched tugboats struggle today in a futile effort to free the ship from a sandbar about 700 yards offshore.

WASHINGTON. HAPPINESS for freshmen members of Con gress finding out via the capitol grapevine that the drabness of their closet-sized offices alloted under the pitiless congressional seniority system might be partially relieved with free plants and cut flowers from the United States Botanic Garden.

NOT so very long ago, the National Foundation on the Arts and Humanities had a symposium for an invited audience of newspaper, critics. LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 21-- Nebraska's Secretary of State, Frank Marsh, announced today he had picked Feb. 14, 1968, as the day he would disclose the names of individuals he would certify for the Nebraska Presidential primary election of 1968.

VENICE, Fla.--A 150mile stretch of the Gulf Coast Intracoastal Waterway is now open in its entirety. A missing link, a five-and-one-half-mile section between Roberts Bay and Lemon Bay, was completed on Jan. 9 and will be dedicated on Feb. 25.

PENSACOLA, Fla.--This northwest Florida resort city has begun a program to preserve its historic sites. Among other things, it will soon offer walking tours of the Seville Square area, where most of the earliest buildings are situated.

A group of college professors, mainly from the Boston area, who organized the Ad Hoc Faculty Committee on Vietnam early this month, reported yesterday that they have collected more than 6,000 signatures of faculty members at 200 colleges and universities in 37 states to the plea: "Mr. President, stop the bombing!"
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--In the last 15 years the United States has created a new industrial machine equal in size to all that was built from the earliest factories until 1951.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--Next week will see the submission by President. Johnson to Congress of the Government's two key annual economic policy documents--the budget and the economic report. But this week the President has already disclosed the most important single fact governing policy --the size of the defense budget.
LeRoy A. MacColl, until 1961 a mathematician with Bell Laboratories, died of a heart ailment Friday night. He was 70 years old and lived at 43 Fifth Avenue.

Under Secretary of State Eugene Rostow's sevennation tour to seek international food aid for India is the third urgent mission sent abroad by President Johnson as a preliminary to putting his 1967 Food for Peace program before Congress.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21-- Mr. and Mrs. Calvert Hall of Chestnut Hill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Jeanne Hall to Martin Hopkins Potter of Darien, Conn. He is the son of Mrs. John Febiger Spahr of Gladwynne and John R. Potter of Darien and Miami Beach.

MONTICELLO, N.Y.-- Tobogganing and sleigh-riding are now gaining a wider fol lowing in the southern Catskills. Almost every major resort hotel in this SullivanUlster County area seems to be dedicated to preserving these two downhill sports, and new facilities have been cropping up recently in surprising numbers.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 21 --In the Waterman Chapel of the Second Congregational Church here this afternoon, Miss Barbara Anne Puritz, daughter of Raymond Marshall Peritz Jr. of Riverside and the late Mrs. Elinor Bell Peritz. was married to Licut. Thomas Eugene Hitchcock Jr., U.S.A.F He is the son of Mrs. Jane Weinheimer Hitchcock of Syracuse, N.Y.
The Friday 13th gas explosion and fire in Jamaica, Queens, may yet have farreaching effect on the entire natural gas industry.

ONCE again, America is in the midst of the ski industry's annual push to put more people on skis, a promotion campaign known as National Ski Week. The 10-day week began last Friday and, by the time it ends next Sunday, the observance's sponsors hope they will have reached millions of Americans who never have been on skis, as well as those two or three million who can and do call themselves skiers.

DEPENDING on your point of view, the New York Philharmonic's Young People's Con certs may--or may not--be suffering from schizophrenia. Has the 43-year-old series, founded by "Papa" Ernest Schelling, undergone a personality split in which it can't make up its mind whether it is a series of real concerts or a television package?

Mrs. Kristin Norstad, daughter of Gen. Lauris Norstad, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Norstad of New York, was married yesterday to Andrew Mark Jaffe, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry L. Jaffe of Los Angeles and Palm Springs, Calif.

VIENNA--For many Austrians and foreign visitors, the Vienna Woods mean Strauss waltzes, birds twittering in the trees and horse-driven carriages crunching through the leafy forest in spring, summer and fall. But the Vienna Woods, only a few miles from the heart of the city, is also a romantic place in winter.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Jan. 21 --The Board of Education and representatives of the township's striking teachers resumed contract negotiations tonight at the board's headquarters here after a month's interruption.
The immediate establishment of a task force in the Police Department to protect cab drivers was announced late yesterday afternoon by Chief Inspector Sanford D. Garelik.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Jan. 21--A quiet revolution has been achieved in these resort islands as a Negro Government has taken office this week to end three centuries of white rule. The impact has been nil on the tourists who have packed Nassau's hotels, but the changeover seems to have touched the heart of every Negro citizen.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 21--"Next year," said Mrs. Thomas A. Work Jr. in her house on the 14th fairway of the Pebble Beach Golf Course, "my husband says he is going to send me away during the Crosby. I have accepted too many invitations to parties, and he doesn't think it's good for his golf."

A BEACH cottage rising on stilts from a sandspit and overlooking a canal of the Inland Waterway will be given the top award this week in the annual house-design competition sponsored by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.
MANHASSHT, L.I., Jan. 21 --What does a community do with a school building that is no longer usable because of de facto segregation?
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 21 (UPI)--The explosion of a Saturn rocket will probably cause further delay in the United States moon program, but how much was not known, officials said today.
The Military Airlift Command, which evolved last Jan. 1 from the Military Air Transport Service, set new records in all airlift categories last year.

ATLANTA, Jan. 21--Military orders for textiles, which, pushed the industry's production past all previous national records during 1966, have had a major impact on the econ omies of the Southeastern states.
Project Rescu, a plan to establish 10 community centers to provide quick emergency repairs in slum buildings, was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

MIAMI BEACH--This resort city's glittering Gold Coast, a hoteland motel-studded strip of real estate stretching for several miles along the Atlantic Ocean, soon will be shining a bit brighter. Two new hotels, the first to be built along the oceanfront since early 1963, are scheduled to be opened this year.

Shuttling back and forth across the Paris-California border, the 29-year-old actress has managed to maintain two entirely different public images simultaneously. Over here.

SUMMIT, N.J., Jan. 21-- Raymond D. Stickney of 38 Waldron Avenue, a State Department adviser until 1957, died Thursday at Overlook Hospital here. His age was 73.

Just to the right of C. Stuart Mitchell as he sits behind his modern desk are his trophy shelves, and on them are the trophies--a box of Duncan Hines cake mix, a bottle of Crisco oil and others, and don't forget Tide, it's intensified.

Frank Froehling 3d of New York succeeds Chuck McKinley of Port Washington, L.I., as the top-ranking player of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association and Mrs. Donna Fales of New York again heads the women's list.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 21 (AP)--Liza Chapman, an actress who appeared in television melodramas, was killed today and her husband was injured in an accident on the Connecticut Turnpike.
A call for the creation of a Soviet capital market operated through that nation's banking system has been sounded in Pravda.

AN urbane, even casual man, Senabor Fulbright mould readily prefer to be a regular guest at the White House foreign-policy luncheon every Tuesday so that he could quietly nudge at the views of the Secretaries of State and Defense, gain the occasional satisfaction of influencing a Presidential decision, and then return to Capitol Hill to be the thoughtful spokesman and dignified legislative lieutenant of his party's Administration.
A new program was begun last week in Criminal Court in Manhattan to determine more quickly what defendants are eligible for free legal assistance.
Shares of the Studebaker Corporation swirled back into the center of the stock market's attention last week.

CAMPECHE, Mexico -- The ancient insignia of this seashore city on the western end of the Yucatan Peninsula has good reason to bear two vessels and two towers, for Campeche has endured many a pirate siege from the Gulf of Mexico since its founding in 1540. And many of the towers used in its defense still stand as picturesque monuments.

BONN, Jan. 21--The German eagle flying tandem with the French rooster was the image that West Germany's new Chancellor, Kurt Georg Kiesinger, brought home with him this week. Mr. Kiesinger indicated that his eagle would be flapping behind the Gaullist rooster on a mission of peaceful conciliation across divided Europe, and he vowed that cooperation with Paris would develop "over a long period and in the grand style."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) --"Keep the Faith, Baby," the record being billed as Representative Adam Clayton Powell's message to the world, was made in a pool hall in the Bahama Islands, an aide said today.
YONKERS, Jan. 21--Lucien Fontaine--that is a name that conjures up a picture of the Canadian north woods.

The Netherlands Chamber Choir of Amsterdam, a professional chorus of 18 directed by Felix De Nobel, appeared at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon to perform unaccompanied works by composers of the 16th and 20th centuries.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 21 --Miss Sandra Patterson Mallory was married here this afternoon to Thomas Robert Constabile Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Constabile of New Rochelle, N.Y. The bride's parents are Henry Rogers Mallory of Greenwich and Mrs. Patterson Mallory of Meriden.

A new plan to help bulk rail shippers meet their seasonal peak transportation needs and yet not be saddled with a fleet of freight cars during the slack season was announced last week by the Transport Leasing division of Pullman, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--The Government, at Mrs. John F. Kennedy's request, will discontinue July 1 the allowance she has been receiving to maintain an office to handle official business.

SAN PEDRO DE ATACAMA, Chile--Visitors say that the desert around this village in northern Chile looks like a lunar landscape, what with the lava ash, dried-up geysers and sandy plains. Scientists say it looks more like Mars, and they are studying the surface and subsoil to determine how close the resemblance is.

CAMBRIDGE, Md. Jan. 21-- The Cambridge deep-water port, closed for three months because of a labor-management wage dispute, will be in business again this Monday. The Icelandic freighter Brurafoss is scheduled to dock here then with a partial cargo of frozen fish consigned to Coldwater Seafoods, Inc., at their Nanticoke, Md., plant, according to shipping agents in Baltimore.

MIAMI--The Sheraton Hotel Corporation announced here last week that it has undertaken a management contract for the operation of The Four Ambassadors, the new $25-million complex of four 20-story apartment and hotel buildings in downtown Miami. Two of the towers will house 350 apartments, and the two others will be filled with 350 hotel suites. The two hotel towers will be opened in July, and the two apartment towers early next autumn.

One of the oldest cliches of the Kremlinological fraternity is the notion that a fat Communist is likely to be a peaceful one, especially if he has a television set to watch at night and an automobile to drive on weekends.
A sophisticated tanker terminal system on Staten Island involving docks, a pipeline and a distant storage area was proposed last week as part of a master port development plan.
Sanitation Commissioner Samuel J. Kearing has ordered a mass transfer of 450 officers and men effective tomorrow morning as a result of investigations into alleged corruption.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 21 (AP) --Ann Sheridan, the actress, who was once billed as "the oomph girl," died today after a long illness in her San Fernando Valley home. She would have been 52 years old Feb. 21. The cause of her death was not divulged.
The 470-acre estate and horse farm of the late Amory L. Haskell in Middletown, near Rumson, in Monmouth County, N.J., is for sale for $2-million.

HAVANA, Jan. 21 (Reuters) --An alleged Central Intelligence Agency agent, held responsible for the deaths of 44 Cubans drowned last October while trying to flee the country, was executed by a firing squad last night.

During the lull in apartment house construction here, a real estate man has taken the time to count the number of cooperative apartments built on the East Side since the end of World War II.
BUDAPEST, Jan. 20--Nearly 23 years after the event, Hungary is trying a group of men on charges of war crimes against several hundred Budapest citizens.

LAIE, Hawaii--About 40 miles from the ultramodern hotels and airconditioned bistros of Waikiki, visitors to Hawaii can sample the less-sophisticated Polynesian life that has enchanted Pacific travelers since the time of Capt. James Cook.

PEKING, Jan. 21 (Agence France-Presse)--The daily newspaper Peking Jih Pao, which stopped publication in June, appeared in a new form last night with a big front-page picture of Mao Tse-tung, Communist party chairman.
Mayor Lindsay discovered to his dismay yesterday afternoon that his own waiting car was illegally parked in an area, where he has ordered all illegally parked cars to be towed away.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 21-- A Girl Scout council in Westchester has decided to fight the secession of a rebel unit.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (UPI)-- The pastor of a large Roman Catholic church told his parishioners in the weekly church bulletin that he opposed integration in his all-white neighborhood on Chicago's Northwest Side.

TWO items bearing a rare printing flaw, which was found on the 1965, United States corn memorative stamp marking the 400th anniversary of the first permanent European settlement in America (St. Augustine, Fla.), will be offered for sale by Jacques C. Schiff Jr. of 536 West 11lth Street at an auction scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday.
MIAMI BEACH--When a motorist travels along Florida's coastal highway, State Route A1A, he is, in effect, islandhopping on wheels.

The Defense Department proposal to build a $2-billion, 40-unit fleet of fast deployment logistic vessels represents an about-face in Government support of the maritime industry, a shipping executive said last week.
SCHRUNS, Austria, Jan. 21 --Nancy Greene, a pert, blueeyed brunette, returns to Montreal tomorirow, having concluded the most sensational international skiing stand in Canada's history.

PARIS--For Mao Tse-tung, 1966 was the year of the horse and 1967 is the year of the sheep. Were Charles de Gaulle to use a French equivalent of the Chinese calendar, 1966 was the year of the goose (NATO's, cooked in sauce Gauloise) and this will be the year of the dollar (Uncle Sam's). If the general's plans work out, the dollar should start looking like one of Salvador Dali's melted watches.
Hugh Hutchings, a sailboat owner from California, was re-elected chief commander of the United States Power Squadrons yesterday at the organization's 53d annual meeting here.

BOSTON, Jan. 21--Harry Howell's 1,000th game as a New York Ranger must have seemed as long as the previous 999.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Jan. 21--The United Nations Command and North Korea accused each other today of aggression in connection with Thursday's sinking of a South Korean Navy patrol craft by North Korean shore guns near the demarcation line in the Sea of Japan.
TORONTO, Jan. 21--Reports of United States efforts to prevent Toronto Quakers from shipping drugs to North Vietnam have touched off a political uproar in Canada.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 (UPI)--Four American oil companies will participate in a project to lay an oil pipeline across the floor of the Persian Gulf at a depth of 300 feet.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 21--Miss Anne Whittelsey Walden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Whittelsey Walden of Guilford, was married this afternoon to Edward H. Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram E. Weiss of Brooklyn, New York.

A two-story circular office building sheathed in deeply crinkled bands of aluminum was recently completed in Richmond at a cost estimated at one-fifth of what it would have been if conventional prefabricated paneling had been used on the facade.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 21 (UPI) --The Cincinnati Royals scored a 122-108 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight. A 35point performance by Oscar Robertson sparked the winners of the National Basketball Association game.

A supper dance entitled "A Night in St. Moritz" for its Swiss chalet decor will be held on Friday at the Tavern-on-theGreen in Central Park. LA SERENA, Chile--This ancient city, undoubtedly one of the most beautiful in all of Chile, is now becoming an important tourist center.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas, V.I.--Fifty years ago next March 31, Denmark sold the Virgin Islands of St. Thomas, St. Croix and St. John to the United States for $25-million. Although the United States regarded the purchase primarily as a military stratagem, an unexpected side effect was the transformation of these islands into one of the busiest tourist centers in. the Western Hemisphere.

Mrs. Yetta Blau Fox, wife of Harry Fox, agent and trustee here of the National Music Publishers Association, died of a heart attack on Friday night in her home at 799 Park Avenue. She was 63 years old.

LAS CROABAS, P.R.-- This once sleepy fishing village near Fajardo, on the east coast of Puerto Rico, is becoming one of the island's busiest tourist centers. Land values have soared, and modern eating places have bloomed.
The percentage of mortgage loants undergoing Yoreclosure in September was below that of September, 1965, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.

ST. JOHN'S, Antigua -- When this tiny island receives its new constitution next month, it will have all the independence it wants, or, in other words, all that its spindly economy can afford. Antigua will be selfgoverning, but not completely self-supporting. Britain will continue paying some of the bills.

HONEOYE, N.Y.--This tiny Finger Lakes vil lage (pronunciation, hunny-oy; population 1,500) will welcome more than 40,000 visitors next weekend, when it joins two neighboring townships in staging the sixth annual Honeoye Lake Winter Carnival.

An international organization for small cruising yachts comparable to those that compete in this country under the banner of the Midget Ocean Racing Club is in the process of being formed, sparked in Australia and supported by several European countries.

QUICK-frozen flowers have solved the problem of providing botany students at Columbia University with accurate laboratory specimens the year round. In season and out, violets, gentians and other flowers are readily available in freezer files.

Ground for the latest office building in the Financial District was broken last week with, a horse-drawn scoop, an implement that has been missing from construction ceremonials here for at least 50 years.
PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 21-- A concrete office tower 20 stories tall will begin to rise here next summer on the site of a new superblock.

THE public's preoccupation with the problems of security in the atomic age in general, and with U.S. defense in particular is reflected in the continuing probings of many writers into the most esoteric and least understood of institutions--the Pentagon.

It seemed a singular remark, coming from one of the principals in an episode that had just cost some ten million lives. But Ludendorff was a singular man, and not a very attractive one at that.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 21 --Miss Patricia Marie Roche, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Roche of Greenwich and Ligonier, Pa., was married today to William H. Hoffman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoffman of Baltimore.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21 (AP)--The worst storm of the winter slashed across northern California and Nevada today, interrupting rail and highway traffic across the Sierra flooding scores of homes and knocking out power to several communities.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 21--Mr. and Mrs. Earl W. Sweeney of Stonewell, Tex., who are fighting condemnation of their land for the Lyndon B. Johnson State Park, have enlisted the Texas Legislature to further their campaign.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21-- Airline executives are nervously filling the vacuum of silence left by the Administration on the fate of the supersonic airliner.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 21--The Rev. Dr. John H. Gardner Jr., pastor emeritus of the First Presbyterian Church here and for more than 20 years, before his retirement in 1962, chairman of the Presbyterian Church Committee on Military, Chaplains, died Thursday at the age of 74.

THE New York area's first outdoor flowers have brought mid winter color to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The hardy bloomer is King George heather, a member of the heath family. A densely branched shrub about a foot high and two feet across, it bears hundreds of small magenta-rose flowers. King George is growing in the Rock Garden along the West Walk. It will continue to bloom until late February or early March.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 21--With his reddishbrown Beatle-cut hair flattened by his self-created breeze, 19year-old Michael Mickeriz of Rumford, Me., soared to victory today in the first Dwight D. Eisenhower Trophy ski-jumping competition.

Should New York hitch its new state lottery to race horses, a proposal now under consideration in Albany, the nation's oldest organized sport might be able to take a major step toward solving a significant problem--improving the breed of bettor.

THE news from Spain reveals deep unrest, active dissent and pressures for change. During most of the last 25 years, Spain has seemed almost immune to the vast changes that are transforming the countries of the Western World. But recently we have grown almost accustomed to hearing of students, workers and priests rebelling openly against the rigid patterns of Spanish life.

Moscow, Jan. 21 (UPI)-- Col. Gherman Titov, who became Russia's second man in space in 1961, said today that Soviet astronauts are finding a manned moon landing a "very difficult" task despite development of "new and more perfect rockets."

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 21 --Penn State handed Army its first wrestling defeat tonight, winning 7 of 10 bouts en route to a 23-9 decision. The undefeated Nittany Lions won their second meet of the season, whle Army's record dipped to 4-1-1.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Jan. 21 (Reuters)--Delegates from developing nations criticized the final recommendations of a conference of the development committee of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) when it ended here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) --The Federal Power Commission has announced approval of a $9.2-million annual reduction in wholesale natural gas rates by the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation and a refund of about $11.5-million to customers.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 21-- Mrs. William Edward Cain has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Deborah Staples Cain, to Herbert Franklin Decker of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton F. Decker of Mamaroneck, N.Y.A wedding in March is planned.

ARECORD 614 chess players gathered at the Broadway Central Hotel last month for the Greater New York Scholastic Championship. PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21--Mrs. Dale P. Schroedel has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ann Barbara Schroedel of New York, to Raymond Brewster Strong Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Strong of Strong's Neck in Setauket, L. I., and Brattleboro, Vt.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 21-- Mr. and Mrs. Christian H. Aall of Princeton and Blue Mountain Lake, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cecilia Aall, to Michael Stone Mathews. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Robert Green Mathews of Columbus, Ohio.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 21 Miss Ines Hinckeldeyn, daughter of Mrs. Arnold D. Frese of Greenwich and New York, and the late Peter Hinckeldeyn, was married this afternoon to John McCall Kingsley Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kingsley of New York and Greenwich.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 21 (UPI)--Dave Davis, a slim 24year-old left-hander from Phoenix, Ariz., won the $10,000 first prize in the eighth annual Las Vegas open bowling tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21-- Senator J.W. Fulbright, detailing an "alternative to Vietnam," has proposed an eight-point plan to end the war and to shape a general accommodation with Communist China to neutralize Southeast Asia.
Edmonton, Alberta--Amos (Big Train) Lincoln, 202 pounds, Los Angeles, outpointed Archie Ray, Phoenix, 10 rounds. Billy McCrandle, Edmonton, outpointed Tony hotter, Phoenix, 10. Featherweights.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 21-- Miss Marcy Michelle Curry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Curry Jr., was married this morning to Thomas Edward Minogue Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Minogue of Trumbull.

SMACK in the first month of a year when even pop magazines are beginning to wonder whether love is dead, comes a delightful novel that makes one wonder whether Charlotte Bronte is alive, and in Great Britain. Mary Elgin's THE WOOD AND THE TREES (Mill-Morrow, $4.50) simmers a fine kettle of pre-Freudian ingredients, with just the right amount of sophistication to attract present-day readers.

In 1610 Galileo turned that wonderful, newly invented instrument, the telescope, on Saturn, most distant of the planets then known to man, and saw two strange objects on either side of it. The planet actually was a triple body, he said. But within a few years this effect disappeared and Galileo, dejected, felt he had been deceived.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21-- The mutual fund indutsry and the Securities and Exchange Commission have completed a series of private conferences that have failed to uncover any basis for compromise on the commission's proposals for reform of fund industry practices and reduction of mutual-fund charges to customers.

The Crossroads Building on 42d Street below Times Square, an ornate but shabby relic a year ago, now gleams with white paint, in hopeful association with the tall and stately Allied Chemical Tower across the sereet.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 21 (UPI)-- Arthur Ashe of Richmond and Cliff Richey of Dallas moved into the second round of the Australian doubles tennis championship today. They defeated Peter McPherson and Geoff Sara of Australia, 7-5, 6-4, 6-3.
THE Romans idolized chariot drivers. We have the movie stars. A pity. Why not philosophers, or politicians, or businessmen--or writers, for heaven's sake?
"Thirty-five cents for a shine!" exclaimed the man as he stepped down from a chair in Grand Central Terminal. "What are they using--gold polish?"
Japan Air Lines has announced that the Japanese Government has approved reductiuns in trans-Pacific fares requested by that airline and several competing lines.

SAN FRANCISCO. ONTO a blood-red screen gal lops a black-silhouetted rider bound for the deadliest of adventures. This mys erious stranger surveys the uneasy stillness of a Mexican border town, ringed by mountains. He wears a ragged brown poncho, sports a moustache and 10-day growth of beard. Steely blue eyes. Cigar butt clenched in teeth. Laconic. Brooks no insult to his "mule." Miraculously chop, chop, chop on the draw. Four already dead. More to come.

IN her new book on Sarah Bernhardt, Cornelia Otis Skinner bewails the fact that the French actress's name has no meaning for today's younger generation. Incredible as it may seem, there have been reports that Arturo Toscanini's name similarly goes unrecognized among the young.
PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 21-- A Superior Court judge ruled today that the West Milford school board could not have its buses go off their established routes to accommodate parochial school children.
CINCINNATI, Jan., 21--Lieut. (jg.) Mary Jane Calder of the Navy Nurse Corps plans to be married in the spring to Lieut. John Thomas Freie of the Navy Medical Corps.
Rabbi Israel Margolies proposed yesterday that Israel be permanently neutralized as a "spiritual Switzerland" in the Middle East.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y.-- This is winter carnival time in the Adirondack Mountains, and Sara nac Lake will have a short one but a good one. This, in a way, distinguishes it from the Lake Placid carnival, which is a long one and a good one.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 21--South Vietnamese paratroopers discovered today that they had scored a major victory against the Vietcong as they conducted mop-up operations in fighting that began yesterday afternoon near Saigon.

PANAJI, Goa, Jan. 21--Down by the waterfront, firecrackers flashed to celebrate Goa's decision to remain a union territory. But in Panaji's Municipal Garden, the only noise was the pigeons coming in to land on the statue of the Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama.

OTTAWA, Jan, 21--The Canadian Government has prepared a note rejecting United States protests last month against proposed legislation limiting the assets of the American-owned Mercantile Bank of Canada.
BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 21 (AP)--Mario Savio and four other nonstudents were convicted today of creating a public nuisance during a sit-in protest at the University of California's Berkeley campus.
HONG KONG, Jan, 21--The possibility that Communist China's "cultural revolution," with its attendant turmoil, may begin to involve the nation's peasants was raised tonight by the official press.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 21--An orthopedic surgeon, associated with boxing for more than 30 years, has called for such radical changes in the sport as an eight-sided ring, a referee-doctor, a medical ratings committee, pneumatic gloves, mandatory use of headgear and face grease.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP)--Lieut. Gen. John F. Uncles, former chief of staff of the Army in Europe and commander of the Seventh Corps, died at Walter Reed Army Hospital yesterday after a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

A NATIONAL newsmagazine, reporting last year on the Reagan campaign, mentioned "mushroomburgers" as one of the bizarre features of the southern California scene. During a number of years' residence in Los Angeles, I have conscientiously investigated the area's gastronomic esoterica. I have never laid eyes on a mushroomburger or seen one offered for sale, let alone eaten one. Nor have I ever heard of anyone who ever ate one.

Waistlines are moving back into the fashion picture--and up. Belts are warn high, wide and handsome. Coats are trig, dashingly cut. Dresses are curvier, wrappier, show more of a small waist, a rounder, prettier bosom. It would seem that, at long last, real women are back in fashion.
The Port of New York Authority has awarded its distinguished service medal to Matthias E. Lukens, deputy executive director of the bistate agency.

Miss Cynthia Lee Jenner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Ernest Jenner Jr. of Kenilworth, Ill., was married yesterday to John William King of New York, son of Mrs. William Daniel King of San Antonio, Tex., and the late Mr. King. The Rev. Chase S. Hunt performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan.21 --Miss Ellen W. Kuhn of Cedar Grove, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Kuhn of Ridgewood, was married today to Frederick E. Foth, also of Cedar Grove, in the Central Presbyterian Church.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 21--St. Peter's College defeated Manhattan College, 75-73, tonight to take first place in the Metropolitan Conference. The loss was the Jaspers' first in four league games. The victory was St. Peter's 10th in 11 games and Manhattan now has an over-all record of 7 and 4.

BENJAMIN BRITTEN'S "Peter Grimes" returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday evening after an absence of 18 years. It received a new production, staged by Tyrone Guthrie, with sets and costumes by Tania Moiseiwitsch. The occasion also served as the Metropolitan debut of Colin Davis, the British conductor.

Richard B. Marsh, an account executive with Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., advertising agency, died on Friday at Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 54 years old and lived at 18 Grace Court Alley, Brooklyn Heights, and in Siasconset on Nantucket.
A subsonic plane with "eyes" that can pick out targets in any weather day or night is proving to be one of the most effective aircraft used against North Vietnam.

AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 21--Mr. and Mrs. Sam DuPree have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Herron DuPree, to Frank Breckenridge Bell 2d of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Davitt Stranahan Bell of Pittsburgh.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 21--Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Kennedy Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Joyce Kennedy, to Robert E. Heeter Jr., son of Mr, and Mrs. Heeter of Minneapolis.
Colgate University has completed the first phase of a massive fund-raising campaign designed to help keep it what it has been for 147 years--a small, independent college.

CASTRIES, St. Lucia, B.W.I. -- Nobody, any where, watches the clock When a party is going good. This year, in the eastern Caribbean, they won't even be watching the calendar. From now through March, anyone visiting the islands will see how West Indians celebrate when they really decide to let go.

FREDRIC MARCH and his wife Florence Eld ridge will co-star in an original television play for the Columbia Broadcast ing System. The 90-minute drama will be taped in April, although the date when it will go on the air has not been determined.

BOOTHBAY, Me., Jan. 21-- The engagement of Miss Sara Merrell Walbridge, to John McKenzie Witten, son of Mrs. John D. Witten of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Mr. Witten, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth M. Walbridge, the future bride's parents.
The American merchant marine in 1965 fell further behind in its struggle to carry a substantial portion of United States foreign trade, a role decreed by Congressional mandate.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21-- The Senate has been asked to help resolve the controversy over construction of a fourth jetport in the New York area.
Robert Moses yesterday described as "absurd" and "grotesque" any plans to consolidate all of the various state and city transportation departments into one agency.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- Something new is being added to the Poconos skiing scene. A mara thon ski competition is scheduled to start next Saturday morning at the Poco-North area in Hawley, about 40 miles northwest of here. Estimates are that it will continue nonstop, day and night for at least two days.

FORT MYERS, Fla. -- February is the biggest month of the year in this resort city of 25, 000 and also in Fort Myers Beach, which is on the Gulf of Mexico at a point 15 miles west of here. In both places, it is the peak month of the winter season, and it will be celebrated with a variety of displays, contests, parades, dances and other festive events.

IN some respects the most intriguing broadcaster of the current season is Stimson Bullitt, who operates major TV stations in Seattle, Spokane and Portland. As far as available records show, he is the first video station owner to go on the air with an editorial challenging President Johnson's conduct of the Vietnamese war and urging a cessation of the bombing of North Vietnam.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 21 --Harvard's Institute of Politics, though barely three months old, has already whipped up discussions about how far--if at all--scholars can become entangled in Government work before their integrity is challenged, jeopardized or tainted.
Rudy LaRusso, the Los Angeles Laker star who retired when he was traded, was suspended yesterday pending the outcome of a, special National Basketball Association meeting next Thursday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21-- The American Friends Service Committee plans to institute a medical aid program in Quangngai provincial hospital in South Vietnam in the next few months, it was announced today.

MICHIEL F. BRAIVE's "The Photograph: A Social History" (New York: McGraw-Hill Book Co. 367 pp. $16.95) may be the first book to attempt to deal exclusively with the history of photography from the viewpoint of its impact on social mores.

THE rebellious teen-ager may not be a rebel. He may simply be trying to live up to the picture adults have of him. Every society produces the type of adolescent it expects-and deserves. Americans once saw their teen-agers as simple-minded characters living in an Eden of preresponsibility, and that is what they often got. Today we have created a new set of stereotypes. And, obligingly, our adolescents have shaped their behavior to conform to them.

Frederick Chomowicz, an architect with a remodeling assignment, recently walked into the lobby of a longneglected five-story building in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn and came face to face with a nine--foot--tall grandfather clock.
LOS ANGELES, Jan.21 (AP) --Jim Ryun of Kansas won the mile run pretty much as he pleased tonight, easily defeating Tom von Ruden and Dyrol Burleson in the los Angeles invitation indoor track meet.

OTIS, Mass.--In an era when family skiing is being emphasized across the country, parents are showing a surprising amount of interest in junior ski-camp programs. AMERICAN readers are being treated to a number of new books which deal with sociological subjects non-socdologically. When we are introduced to the complex workings of a whole community, as in Laurence Wylie's "Village in the Vaucluse" or Robert Dahl's "Who Governs," the result can be superb.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 21--Rain, wind and blowing sand created such dangerous conditions that the third round of the Crosby pro-amateur golf tournament was postponed today. The interruption after 40-mile-an-hour gales swept three courses forced the round to be scheduled for tomorrow. The final 18 holes will now go over until Monday.
LONDON, Jan. 21--The British Government has given its formal approval to the construction of a 14-million ($39.2million) fertilizer plant in Cuba by a British concern.

Gerhart H. Seger, a militant anti-Nazi editor and lecturer, a former deputy of the German Reichstag and since 1961 head of the lecture bureau of West Germany's information bureau here, died of cancer yesterday in his home at 111-53 113th Street, Ozone Park, Queens. He was 70 years old and was one of Hitler's first political prisoners.

PARIS, Jan. 21--The French viewed it as a triumph over the Anglo-Saxons, the almighty dollar, and the bloodied pound. Washington and London viewed it as a resounding setback to the mischievous French and their antedeluvian ideas about gold.

SANUR, Bali--After years of housing travelers in palm-leaf huts or modest wooden bungalows, this languid Indonesian Island has plunged into bigtime tourism by erecting a hotel that would do justice to any seaside resort.

MIAMI, Jan. 21--Mrs. Frances A. Genter's In Reality won the $34,450 Hibiscus Stakes for 3-year-olds at Hialeah today and thus became a major contender for the $100,000 Flamingo on March 3. ALBANY, Jan, 21--For $2 in New York State you can place a bet on a horse, see a neighborhood movie, or get your car inspected. And in the not too distant future, you may be able to plunk down $2 at a bank teller's window and buy yourself a lottery ticket.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 22 A climate appears to be developing here in which an elected South Vietnamese Government might ultimately become a vehicle for negotiations to end the war.
ATLANTA, Jan. 22 One of the South's largest department stores observed today its first 100 years in business by projecting itself into the future.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana When the Chase Manhattan Frank opened for business here in a tiny store on Columbus Day, 1965, few thought of the branch as a revolutionizing instrument in the tradition-bound banking system least of all its young manager, William C. Keen.

Even after publication of the curious correspondence between Secretary of State Rusk and J. Edgar Hoover, it is far from certain that the Administration will be able to override the veto Mr. Hoover has hitherto exercised against the long-stalled SovietAmerican consular treaty.

FALUN, Sweden, Jan. 22 (UPI) Lars Grini took the lead after the first jump and was never seriously threatened thereafter as he paced a Norwegian sweep in today's ski-jumping competition at the 1967 international Swedish games.

CONCORD, Mass., Jan. 22 Mr. and Mrs. Morgan K. Smith have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances deForest Smith, to Lieut. (jg.) Page Lawrence Edwards Jr., U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwards of Durango, Colo.

Negro leaders yesterday postponed a conference in support of Representative Adam Clayton Powell because, they said, too many persons wanted to attend. The conference had been scheduled for Wednesday in Washington.
RIO DE JANEIRO Brazil is still chasing the elusive goal of a decisive victory over inflation, the chronic ailment of this huge nation's developing economy.
The city was reported yesterday to be thinking of a fourlane tunnel for the Lower Manhattan Expressway along with changes in downtown street patterns.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Jan. 22 Mrs. Mary Mercer Carter Stewart Vivian, widow of Leslie Langdon Vivian, vice president of Fenner Beane, now part of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., stockbrokers, died yesterday in her summer home here. She was 70 years old and lived at 789 Belvedere Avenue, Plainfield, N.J.
An unusual pooling of engineering skills of four countries in the Western Hemisphere, Europe and Asia is helping a construction project in the Middle East to proceed on schedule.

In hundreds of towns, the old market places have given way as centers of trade and gossip to commercial streets with shops displaying packaged goods, bright synthetic fabrics, musical records, bicycles and television sets.

Mr. and Mrs. David Bendel Hertz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Bendel Hertz, to Winthrop Ames Burr, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Thayer Burr of St. Croix, Virgin Islands.

NHATRANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 22 "The Ballad of the Green Berets" is still on the jukebox of the officers club at the headquarters of the Fifth Special Forces Group here, but it isn't played much nowadays.

Morris J. (Moish) Solomon, Brooklyn civic and welfare leader, who in 1944 was named the borough's No. 1 Citizen by the Men's League of Brooklyn, died yesterday in Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. He was 75 years old, and lived at 65 Montague Street.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras The most backward of the Central American countries, Honduras, ended 1966 in a rather flourishing financial condition. In many ways, it was too flourishing.

The Florentine Relief Fund will receive the proceeds of a champagne preview of paintings by Enrico Cervelli and drawings by Mario Sironi on the evening of Feb. 1 at the Grosvenor Gallery, 25 East 77th Street.
Charles A. Cleveland has joined the Bankers Trust Company as a vice president in its international division, William H. Moore, chairman of Bankers Trust, announced over the weekend.
The Real Estate Square Club of New York has chosen William Goldfine as its realty man of the year for 1967. Mr. Goldfine is chairman and president of the Royal National Bank of New York.
The City Hospitals Commissioner said last night that he was trying to draw guidelines that would prevent research on patients without their written consent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today that there was at least an even chance the Senate would relax its rules to provide for shutting off filibusters by a three-fifths vote of members.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 22 Authorities will begin an intensive inquiry tomorrow into the death of a 26-year-old graduate student at Vanderbilt University who was killed by the police Wednesday night as they struggled to subdue him in his apartment.

NUIDAT, South Vietnam, Jan. 22 (Reuters) Captured Vietcong guerrillas cheer for the Indians during Western movies shown to theim at an Australian hospital at Vungtau, an Australian intelligence officer said here today.

Twenty-three peace demonstrators unfurled posters portraying a maimed Vietnamese child in the center aisle of St. Patrick's Cathedral during the 10 o'clock high mass yesterday morning, causing the celebrant to interrupt the liturgy.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22 (AP) A heavy rainstorm moved south through California today, dropping 1.91 inches of rain on this city and causing hundreds of traffic accidents. The police said the accident rate was about five times normal.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 22 Mrs. Carol Walsh Potts was married here this afternoon to Robert A. Gartland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Z. Gartland of White Plains.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today that there was at least an even chance the Senate would relax its rules to provide for shutting off filibusters by a three-fifths vote of members.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday. Jan. 23 (AP) The most recent attempt to use nonlethal gas on a major objective in the Vietnam war is reported to have failed like most of the others.

Joseph M. Rose, who retired seven years ago as head of J. M. Rose Co., a woolen mill sales agency he founded in 1938, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 201 East 66th Street. His age was 77.
Robert T. Foscato of V. Foscato, Inc., a Long Island City mosaic contracting firm, has been elected president of the Terrazzo and Mosaic Contractors Association of Greater New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--American officials said last week that the flow of men and materiel down the Ho Chi Minh Trail, a complex of highways and mountain paths that runs from North Vietnam through eastern Laos into South Vietnam, had slowed markedly recently.
Columbia University announced yesterday that it had received $2-million from Percy Uris, the realtor and builder.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 22 Bloody rioting broke out after an anti-Government demonstration tonight.
