LAKE PLACID, N.Y. Jan. 22 (UPI) Bjoern Wirkola of Norway, the world ski jumping champion, set a hill record with a 255-foot jump and won the 43d International Masters' championship today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (UPI) The Chicago Black Hawks beat the Montreal Canadiens, 4-1, tonight, for the fourth time this season to widen their first-place lead in the National Hockey League to 5 points.

The Community Committee of the Brooklyn Museum has planned a tea and a tour of three landmark homes in Brooklyn Heights for the afternoon of Feb. 3. The homes to be visited are Dr. and Mrs. Joseph T. TOKYO, Jan. 22--"When I played for Benny Goodman I was with the King of Swing, and now I'm playing with the swingin' King," said Lionel Hampton, the orchestra leader.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 A spokesman for the Kennedy family, Richard N. Goodwin, said tonight that every incident described by Mr. Manchester in the Newsweek interview was "fictional."
Since she came to New York in 1960 to study at the Juilliard School of Music, Paula Sylvester has followed a steady course toward success in her field, which is playing the flute.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 22 The 101-day tugboat strike that has crimped shipping operations here shows no sign of an immediate settlement.

Colorful is the word for the concert played by the American Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. Paul Kletzki, the man who has been chosen to succeed Ernest Ansermet as conductor of the Orchestra de la Suisse Romande, was on the podium as guest of the American Symphony, and his program consisted of works by three composers known for their skill as orchestrators.

LONDON, Jan. 22 Dr. Ambrose Reeves, former Anglican Bishop of Johannesburg, said here today after a nine-day visit to Hanoi that there was very little sign there of a solution of the Vietnamese war at the moment.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 22 (AP) A cold, blustery rainstorm halted the $85,000 Motor Trend 500-mile race for stock cars today after 135 miles of fast, rugged competition. The stewards said the race would be finished next Sunday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 22 A new Brazilian Constitution was adopted early today, and a debate began immediately about how to change it.
The Metropolitan Opera reinstated its 14-year-old production of "La Boheme" this month. The second performance, Saturday night, was well-routined and adequate but rarely moving.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) Senator J.W. Fulbright said today that the United States should replace Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam if he refused to negotiate with the Vietcong.

THE National Broadcasting Company presented the fourth of its highly successful "World Premiere" movies Saturday night, but Late Show watchers must have been terribly aware that they had seen the same picture many, many times before.

KINGSTON, Jamaica Just outside the headquarters of the Aluminum Company of Canada's giant bauxite and alumina plant near Mandeville, an Alcan official pointed to the parking lot where dozens of cars were lined up.

Paul Badura-Skoda played a Mozart program in August in Philharmonic Hall's Mozart Festival. Yesterday afternoon, he did the same, this time as the third pianist in the Vienna Festival series, also at Philharmonic Hall.

All Chinese radio stations and newspapers these days are preoccupied with a campaign against the most awful heresy of the moment, "economism." The villainous backers of this doctrine, it turns out, have been successfully using "sugar-coated bullets" to induce honest Chinese workers to behave selfishly.

DENVER, Jan. 22 (AP) The 10th United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver has refused to rule on a rate issue involved in a complex natural gas case because of insufficient evidence. The case has been sent back to the Federal Power Commission.
The election of Rabbi Israel Miller as chairman of the American Zionist Council, the coordinating and representative body of all Zionist groups in this country, was announced yesterday.
CROSSINGER, N.Y., Jan. 22 The Open Pair title in the Tristate Regional Championship being held here was captured on Saturday by Nat Gerstman of Buffalo and Judy Slater of Utica, N.Y.
GRENOBLE, France, Jan. 22 (AP) Song Soon Kim of North Korea and Stien Kaiser of the Netherlands broke the Soviet Union's monopoly on the women's title today in a pre-Olympic speed skating meet.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao A record number of tourists brightened the economic scene for Curacao and nearby Aruba last year and softened the islands' chronic unemployment problems.
ALL that glitters is not gold in the five room settings that go on view today on the seventh floor at Abraham Straus.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 22 (UPI) Robert L. Howsam was named general manager of the Cincinnati Reds today, succeeding Bill DeWitt, the former owner of the National League baseball team.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 22--Three United States warplanes were shot down during air operations over North Vietnam yesterday, the American military command announced today.

FREEPORT, Grand Bahamas, Jan. 22 (UPI) George Lewis of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y, captured the second Grand Gahama open golf tournament today with a 284 total. He edged Paul Kelly of Scarborough, N.Y., by a single stroke.
RIO DE JANEIRO Brazil rediscovered the economic potential of its fabled Amazon basin the "Green Inferno" again last year.

TORONTO Two years ago, Paul E. Roberts, president of the Abitibi Paper Company of Toronto, Canada's largest newsprint producer, agonized all night over whether to match a surprise West Coast price cut of $10 a ton.

HO-HO-KUS, N.J., Jan. 22 Henry E. Schmults, president of the Citizens First National Bank of Ridgewood and from 1944 to 1947 Mayor of the borough of Ho-Ho-Kus, died yesterday in his home, 216 Elmwood Avenue. His age was 69.

BOSTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) Johnny Bucyk's third-period goal gave the last-place Boston Bruins a 3-1 National Hockey League victory, over Toronto tonight and extended the Leafs' victoryless streak to four games.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 22 (UPI) Jobyna Ralston, who appeared in "Wings" in 1927, the first movie to receive an Academy Award, died today at the Motion Picture Country Home in Woodland Hills. She was 66 years old.
The construction of two cities devoted entirely to scientific research is under way near Moscow, according to recent Soviet newspapers received here.

Why should a giant discount store chain elect to start a division of "free-standing" children's toy stores when toy merchandising is one of retailings low profit-makers and is subject to very sharp competition?

OTTAWA Population, the world's most formidable problem, is Canada's challenge, too but there is a difference. The world is growing rapidly. Canada, whose first settlers landed more than 300 years ago, is vastly underpopulated. For the unforseeable future, the world's growing numbers of people promise mass markets for Canada's goods and raw materials, if she can find ...

JERUSALEM (Israel), Jan. 22--Israel agreed today to a request by Syria to delay the start of their talks over border tension. The meeting, originally scheduled to begin tomorrow, is now set for Wednesday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 22 (AP) Iran has obtained $220million in credit from British, French and West German financiers to build a 750-mile, $450-million pipeline across Iran to supply gas to the Soviet Union, the English-language newspaper, Kayhan International, said today.
DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 22 Teri Ardleigh of Greenwich, Conn., won two firsts and a championship today at the Ox Ridge indoor horse show.
EDMONTON, Alberta The Petroleum Club of Edmonton was a gloomy spot last August. But six weeks later, smiling faces reappeared.

Miss Kaliope Michel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony P. Michel of Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Alexander Demetrios Xenakis of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., son of Demetrios Xenakis of Philadelphia and the late Mrs. Xenakis.

Simon and Garfunkel, the young vocal duo, arrived at Philharmonic Hall last night to face and captivate a capacity audience. In fact, the pair have arrived nationally as important voices on the pop-folk scene.

PARAMARIBO, Surinam Oil and water or rather the lack of both in this tidy corner of the Netherlands in South America were the major drawbacks to Surinam's efforts last year to continue its economic progress.

WINNIPEG, Man. Eight of nine Canadian chartered banks maintain their head offices either in Montreal or in Toronto. But the ninth the brandnew Bank of Western Canada has chosen the midcontinent city of Winnipeg.
On a balmy afternoon when spring seemed close enough to touch, 35,000 feverish boating fans climbed aboard at the Coliseum yesterday for a lastchance look at the National Boat Show.

BUENOS AIRES The coup that put President Juan Carlos Ongania's military-backed regime into office last June 29 was hatched mostly by businessmen who had decided that Argentina was heading toward economic ruin under the constitutional Government of President Arturo U. Illia.

June Havoc, the actress, who buys and refurbishes houses in the city and in the country as a hobby, has sold the fourstory brownstone house on East 95th Street that she had used for 11 years as her principal New York home.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Jan. 22 William M. Blake Jr., formerly chief assistant district attorney of Queens County and deputy superintendent of the State Insurance Department, died yesterday at Brunswick Hospital in Amitvville. He was 66 years old and lived at 89 Beach Road.
Tom Paxton, the folk and topical singer, gave an excellent display of his writing and performing growth at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night.
PANAMA Money is pouring into a properous Panama.

Mrs. Anna M. Skivens Pond, grand secretary of the Order of the Eastern Star of the State of New York for the last 52 years, died on Saturday at the Sands Point Nursing Home in Port Washington, L.I. The widow of Frank N. Pond, she was 89 years old and lived at 210 Hollywood Avenue, Douglaston Manor, Queens.

FOX, Okla., Jan. 22 (UPI) School officials plan to meet tomorrow night with Negro parents in the Tatums community who have refused since last September to let their children attend classes with white students in the Fox school system.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 A House subcommittee will shortly give its approval to participation by the Export-Import Bank in the financing of the exportation of up to $50-million in American machinery for a big new automobile plant to be built in the Soviet Union by Fiat of Italy.
GUATEMALA Despite uncertainty caused by rebel terrorist attacks, Guatemalans have never been so well off economically.

The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said yesterday that its sales for 1966 rose to $659-million from $575-million and that earnings increased to $50.3-million, or $2.63 a share, from $46-million, or $2.44 a share. Both the sales and earnings figures are new highs.
Mrs. Nina King Colgate of 201 East 62d Street, widow of Gilbert Colgate, was married yesterday afternoon to R. Graham Heiner of New York, a retired lawyer.
ROME, Jan. 22--Pope Paul VI said today he was sorry that a fairly mild flu prevented him from distributing prizes to children who won a contest for the best Christmas cribs.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 22 (AP) The Oakland Raiders have traded a tackle, Rex Mirich, and a high draft choice to the Denver Broncos for Willie Brown and Mickey Slaughter, quarterbacks. The American Football League clubs announced the trade last night after the league All-Star game.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 22 (AP) More rain and snow fell in the Northeast last year than in any of the three preceding years, but the total still was 18 per cent below normal, the Weather Bureau reported tonight.

Jimmy Archer had 350 street fights as a kid in the South Bronx, he says, and can't remember losing any of them. His younger brother, Joey, had 8. Jimmy was mouthy, a leader, an extroverted party-goer, a schemer. Joey was quiet, introverted, a deep, dark thinker.
Mayor Lindsay had a oneword answer yesterday when asked if his official car should be towed away if it was parked illegally.

SAN SALVADOR This capital and the tiny, densely populated country around it were colorfully decorated at Christmas. There were substantial reasons for gaiety: Salvador had recorded another good economic year, although she continued to wrestle with a number of tough problems.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 22 (AP) Mrs. Alice Dye sank a five-foot putt on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff and defeated Sandra Post, 1 up, today in the final of the 35th annual Doherty Cup women's amateur golf tournament at the Coral Ridge County Club.

LA PAZ, Bolivia When a rural Bolivian or Peru vian pauses to refresh himself, he takes a "coca break.' By chewing the leaves of the coca plant mixed with a little lime ash, he can draw a mild form of cocaine.

Samuel Spielman a cellist and former member of Columbia Broadcasting System's radio orchestras for 21 years, died of cancer yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 536 West 113th Street.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 22 Mr. and Mrs. Lester Metzger have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dail Eileen Metzger, to Henry S. Goldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris L. Goldman of Rye. A wedding on June 11 is planned.
MOSCOW, Jan. 22 An attempt by a dozen avant-garde Soviet artists to display their forbidden modern paintings was broken up tonight after the show had been open about an hour.

ATHENS, Jan. 22 An alleged plot to kill former Premier George Papandreou in an air crash was described this week by defendants at a treason trial of 28 Greek military officers. A court-martial in Athens has just completed 10 weeks of hearings on the charges.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (UPI) Arthur Sylvester, retiring Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs, acknowledged today that bombing errors had been made and that civilians had been killed in Vietnam.
MOSCOW, Jan. 22 (UPI) A Soviet poet has accused John Steinbeck, the American novelist, of betraying his principles by accompanying United States troops to South Vietnam.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 22 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that India had accepted new restrictions on trade with North Vietnam and Cuba in order to get badly needed American grain.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 22 The Saudi Government has given Yemeni royalists permission to resume their war against the United Arab Republic in Yemen, according to reports from an informed observer in Saudi Arabia who is close to the royalists.

MACAO, Jan. 22 (Reuters) Six Chinese gunboats appeared outside Macao Harbor today, keeping up psychological pressure on Portuguese authorities from whom the Chinese are demanding a statement on riots here last month.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 22 (AP) The liner Atlantic steamed back into port tonight wtih 645 people who had spent the weekend aboard the cruise ship on a sand bar 800 yards offshore.
LONDON (Religious News Service) The Church of England will face a shortage of about 3,000 clergymen by the end of 1968, according to the Church of England Year Book for 1967.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) Failure to read the "fine print" trapped eight of the Justice Department's best legal minds in an elevator yesterday for about two hours.
LONDON, Jan. 22 Prime Minister Wilson began the second leg of a European tour today, in which he hopes to assess the possibilities of Britain's joining the Common Market.

Archbishop Stepinac of White Plains and Archbishop Molloy of Queens captured the team titles yesterday as 10 meet records were set in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association division indoor track and field championships at the 102d Engineers Armory.

HONG KONG, Jan. 22 (Reuters) The North Vietnamese Foreign Ministry said today that American troops clearing the Iron Triangle area north of Saigon had killed or wounded hundreds of civilians.

MILAN, Italy, Jan. 22 (Reuters) Ron Clarke of Australia, the holder of five world records in distance running; canceled plans today to run in the United States later this month.

ASUNCION, Paraguay The 1,000-mile-river system between this landlocked nation and the Atlantic was down most of 1966, and so were Paraguay's traditional exports of cattle products, lumber, cotton, tobacco and coffee.
ROCHESTER, Jan. 22 (AP) Frank Robinson was named the winner tonight of the S. Rae Hickok professional athlete of the year award, a $10,000 diamondstudded, gold-buckled belt.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 22 Thomas C. Parker, a real estate man who was prominent in national art circles, died at his home here last night. He was 62 years old.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 22 (UPI) Joe Caldwell and Lou Hudson scored on easy lay-ups in the final minute today and led the St. Louis Hawks to a 104-101 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Knickerbockers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) Vice President Humphrey indicated today that the Administration would withdraw a request for a tax increase it believed, if the economy would be impaired.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 22 Billy Casper became the 54-hole pace-setter as both the lead and weather changed in the Bing Crosby pro-amateur golf tourney today.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 22 (AP) Tony Benson of Australia, who won the two-mile run with a time of 8 minutes 57.2 seconds, and James Hines of Texas Southern, who twice equaled the world indoor 60-yard dash record of 5.9 seconds, were chosen last night as the most outstanding athletes of the second annual National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics track meet.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 22 The pattern of conservative Republican strategy to retain control of the party's Presidential nominating convention in 1968 is beginning to take shape.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--A major group of truck companies today asserted that the contract demands of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters were "far in excess" of the 5 to 7 per cent a year that the union had estimated earlier.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22 (UPI) The world mile champion, Jim Ryun of Kansas, expressed satisfaction today about his performance in the Los Angeles invitation indoor track meet. He said it indicated that his training was on schedule.

Six days a week, Hilda Harris cavorts in the chorus of the Broadway hit "Mame," but yesterday, the young mezzo-soprano foresook the Winter Garden for the more intimate stage of Carnegie Recital Hall, and made a triumphant New York recital debut.

MONTREAL The fourstory building on Beaver Hall Hill is almost anonymous in the corporate grandeur of Montreal. But the plaque reads: "The Mercantile Bank of Canada, Affiliated With First National City Bank."

President Johnson has promised to send Congress proposals for revising the military draft to make it "as fair and as effective as possible." His recommendations will undoubtedly be based on the report he is about to receive from his National Advisory Commission on Selective Service.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 The Soviet Union and the United States expect to resume private negotiations next month to iron out the final details of a treaty to prevent the spread of atomic weapons.
A stalemate in contract negotiations between the national networks and a union representing news reporters and correspondents may be nearing its end.
Ted Bates Co., Inc., and Corporate Expansion Services, Inc., an Interpublic unit, have announced major executive appointments.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22-- The American Society of International Law has appointed Stephen M. Schwebel as its executive director effective March 1.

SANTA ANA, Calif., Jan. 22 Two Marine Corps Reserve attack bombers collided and crashed today. One smashed into a retirement community, killing four persons, including the pilot, and injuring five, authorities said.
Miss Lisa Beth Volow and Dr. Harvey Golombek of Toronto were married here yesterday at the Park Royal by Rabbi Emanuel Gettinger.
HONG KONG, Jan. 22 (Reuters)--The North Vietnamese Foreign Ministry said today that American troops clearing the Iron Triangle area north of Saigon had killed or wounded hundreds of civilians.
BONN, Jan. 22 (Reuters) Former Premier David BenGurion of Israel said in an interview here today that the Germans of today were not the same as they were under Hitler.

CALGARY, Alberta A restrictive monetary policy by the Bank of Canada carried a large part of the burden in the fight aaginst inflation, although supplemented by a small personal income tax increase, a novel refundable tax on corporate cash profits and a cut in depreciation allowances.

MIAMI, Jan. 22 Dick Steams, a sailmaker from Wilmette Harbor, Ill., led a parade of former world champions across the finish line today as the 1967 Bacardi Cup Star Class sailing series began on Biscayne Bay.

OMAHA, Jan. 22 (AP) Gary Visconti, a 21-year-old skater from Detroit, and Peggy Fleming, 18, of Colorado Springs, head the 18 skaters and two alternates selected last night to represent the United States in the North American figure skating meet at Montreal Feb. 10 through 12 and the world meet Feb. 28 through March 5.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 22 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky repeated his pledge today that South Vietnam would have a constitution soon and free general elections.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 After six years of resistance, the Food and Drug Administration appears on the verge of accepting as fit for human consumption a fish protein concentrate processed from whole fish.

After a solid decade of piling up annual deficits in its transactions with the rest of the world, the United States appears to be no nearer a solution for eliminating them than it was when they began.

Mayor Lindsay is seeking greater guidance from the Puerto Rican community here on problems of urban development, education and housing rather than relying on political leaders in Puerto Rico for advice.

The DWG Corporation has obtained a 21 per cent interest in Wilson Brothers, manufacturers, of a line of underwear and apparel, through its recent tender offer. That was the word yesterday from Victor Posner, chairman and president of DWG, which manufactures cigars.
Putting a 4-minute-12-second miler into the Millrose Games would be like entering a plow horse in the Kentucky Derby. You should see the plow horse the Millrose Games landed yesterday.

Bonds were buoyed early yesterday by the pledge of five nations to work together for lower interest rates and also by increased talk of peace in Vietnam. Later, however, most bond prices drifted downward and closed little changed from Friday's levels.
BERLIN, Jan. 23 The Western Allies disclosed today that they had eased travel regulations for East Germans seeking to visit Western countries for nonpolitical reasons.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 23 President Sukarno maintained "a direct relationship" with the plotters who headed an unsuccessful Communist-sponsored attempt to take over the Government in the fall of 1965, an article published by the official Armed Forces Information Center charged today.
Mrs. Lillian Diebold Poling, wife of the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, chairman of the board of the Protestant monthly. The Christian Herald, died at her home yesterday.

In a $1-million leasing transaction, a group headed by Jerry Ossip, a restaurateur, has leased 14,000 square feet of space in the Edison Hotel, including the Green Room, a well-known entertainment and dining spot until it closed three years ago.

ROME, Jan. 23 Charges by an American writer that the late Pope Pius XII had failed to do anything to save 335 Italian hostages executed by the Germans on March 24, 1944, were being studied by the Vatican today.

The engagement of Miss Rosalind Valoise Townsend of New York, daughter of Mrs. Philip L.B. Iglehart of Lantana, Fla., and Edward Townsend of New York, to C.J. Stuart Allan, also of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents. Mr. Allan is the son of Mrs. Charles John Stuart Allan of Winnipeg, Man., and New York and the late Mr. Allan.
YORK, Pa., Jan. 23 (AP) The cartons were filled to overflowing with garbage. Some of the debris had fallen to the pavement, littering the sidewalk and spilling over into the gutter.

Layoffs in color-television picture-tube production are not anticipated by the Radio Corporation of America and the General Electric Company, two major producers.
PHULY, North Vietnam, Jan. 17 This is a little city which has been pretty much bombed off the map.

The Bank of New York, which merged last month with the Empire Trust Company to form the city's ninth billiondollar bank, reported yesterday that earnings of the enlarged institution increased 12.6 per cent in 1966.
ALBANY, Jan 23 (AP) The Republican majority in the Senate today blocked a Democratic attempt to obtain a vote on a bill designed to save the old Metropolitan Opera House, now being torn down.

Three renowned Negro athletes Gale Sayers of the Chicago Bears, Bill Russell of the Boston Celtics and Bill White of the Philadelphia Phillies will head a sports committee to raise $100,000 for the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc.
The United Nations asked the city for a cease-fire yesterday to stop a police action too close to home the towing away of illegally parked diplomatic vehicles.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 23 The 10month-old center-right coalition of Premier Paul Vanden Boeynants is in trouble because of Belgium's economic woes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The Supreme Court today denied the appeal of Mark A. Fein, 34-year-old former New York industrialist, who was convicted in 1964 of killing a bookmaker to whom he had lost large sums of money.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The eleven labor unions that coordinated their 1966 contract negotiations with the General Electric Company and Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced plans today to continue cooperating between bargaining periods.

GUERNSEY, Channel Islands, Jan. 23 (AP) The Greekborn captain of an oil tanker, caught in a gale saw his 30 crewmen safely into lifeboats in the English Channel today, then scrambled on to a rock and waited until he was rescued by a helicopter.
The Rangers' lost weekend, a study in complete failure, was not taken philosophically yesterday by Coach Emile Francis.

YONKERS, Jan. 23 The fourth race at Yonkers Raceway tonight had a tragic ending. Dilman, a 9-year-old gelded B-1 pacer and the 11-10 favorite, dropped dead of a ruptured blood vessel after staggering across the finish line in last place and continuing on to the clubhouse turn.
After two postponements and an emergency haircut, Joey Archer got his return match with Emile Griffith for the middleweight championship of the world at Madison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to hear a challenge to the constitutionality of a New York law that prohibits loitering near public schools.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 23 Robert L. Barrows, a retired advertising executive, died today at his home, 92 Park Avenue, of a heart attack. He was 87 years old.

PARIS, Jan. 23 The first Paris couture collections today showed that very tangled Shirley Temple curls are here. So are snug-fitting little shorts under above-theknee summer dresses and sleeveless coats over longsleeved summer dresses. Orange is the chosen color, but black is creeping back, too.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan, 23 A United States field commander reported today that Operation Cedar Falls had resulted in the loss of 1,219 Vietcong soldiers.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 University of California students formed a statewide organization today to block threatened budget cuts and to obtain regular student participation in the university's government.

Tape watchers received some good news from the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The exchange announced plans to introduce a 900-character-perminute ticker system by next Oct. 1, that will almost double the present speed of the ticker service.
VALHALLA, N.Y., Jan. 23 Vandals caused such extensive damage inside Valhalla High School during the night that classes for the 1,006 students were canceled for today.

Martha Graham will offer two new works during her Broadway season, which opens at the Mark Hellinger Theater Feb. 21 and runs through March 12. Both of the new works have been underwritten by a grant from the National Council on the Arts.

THE public will be the winner if Congress authorizes a system of national scenic trails across the nation. Congress is expected to take up an Administration bill to this end during the current session.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The legal division of the Office of Economic Opportunity raised last week the possibility of criminal charges of "willful misrepresentation" against the leaders of a controversial Head Start program in Mississippi.

MANILA, Tuesday, Jan. 24 (AP) President Ferdinand E. Marcos underwent a 90-minute operation for an inflamed gall bladder this morning. He entered the hospital last night shortly after he had delivered the annual State of the Nation address at the opening session of Congress.
The Dressmakers Joint Council of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union warned yesterday of possible strike unless its demand for a 20 per cent increase in wages was met.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 Loyola University announced today that laymen would be added to its governing board for the first time in its 97-year history.

Raymond E. Jones, in charge of radio and television station relations for Young Rubicam, Inc., died of a heart ailment Sunday afternoon at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. He was 51 years old and lived at 30 East 37th Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 23 (AP) Grace Cunard, a silent screen star more than 50 years ago, died Thursday in the Motion Picture Country Home in the San Fernando Valley. She was 73 years old. In private life she was Mrs. Grace Shannon.

The biggest transfer of employes in the history of the Department of Sanitation was effected yesterday. Four hundred fifty men reported for work at new locations in bureaus different from those to which they had been attached until Saturday.

The Chase Manhatan Bank announced here yesterday the appointment of Irwin W. Bodner, Robert V. Higdon and Robert R. Smith as vice presidents.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 23 (AP) Arthur Ashe of Richmond and Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., won second-round matches without difficulty today in the Australian tennis championships, the first of the year's major world tournaments.

Chief Inspector Sanford D. Garelik said yesterday that there would be a "substantial" increase in the number of detectives assigned to ride taxis and unmarked cars in the stepped-up campaign to protect cabbies.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 Proposals for amendments to the state's divorce and adoption laws will be heard at a public hearing in New York City next month.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 23 (AP) Alex Antonio, a pro from Chicago, was inadvertently written out of any chance of sharing in the purse today in the Bing Crosby golf tournament.

Consultants to the city have recommended that the 20-cent fare on buses operated by the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority be continued through 1967 without the issuance of transfers.
FIVE New Jersey players outdistanced the field of 110 teams in the Open Team Championship, which concluded the Tristate Regional Championship at Grossinger, N.Y., on Sunday.
"An A minus except for two who say B." "B plus." "B except for one C." "D.'
Last September, Solomon Green, a 42-year-old luncheonette counterman, of 110 West 183d Street, the Bronx, held a $1,112 winning twin double ticket at Yonkers Raceway.

Six men, including a former Queens County assistant district attorney, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on wire and mail fraud charges.
Stock prices continued to move upward yesterday as the market posted its 15th consecutive advance.

Three aerospace companies issued financial reports yesterday, showing mixed results.

Three movie programs of note are being presented free of charge this week by the New York Public Library.

IT must be said that "The Wicked Cooks" generates its own kind of suspense. Will all of the actors succeed in killing themselves before the evening is out? Or will they merely be maimed for life?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara told Congress during December that U.S. pilots bombed Vietnamese targets twice as heavily as Communist targets had been bombed during the Korean War.
John (Sonny) Franzese went on trim with live others yesterday the United States District court in Brooklyn, charged with masterminding a series of bank robberies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) The Supreme Court left standing today a Taft-Hartley Law injunction that had forced 2,100 striking workers to return to their jobs at an Indiana defense plant.
The first in a series of factfinding hearings was held yesterday in the contract dispute between the city and the Uniformed Firemen's Association and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

McGraw-Hill, Inc., has named Hugh J. Kelly, formerly executive vice president for manufacturing and services, to be president of a new real estate and general services division.

British Government bonds were again the strongest feature on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The Catholic University of America issued today a qualified denial of a young professor's charge that the university's clerical administration had discriminated against a non-Catholic in considering a faculty appointment.

The Board of Higher Education last night approved the opening next Sept. 21 of York College, the city system's newest senior college, in temporary quarters in Bayside, Queens.

Justice Joseph A. Brust signed an order in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday granting a Bar Association application for permission to examine the minutes of the grand jury that indicted State Senator Eugene Rodriguez on perjury charges.

Two large bronze plaques honoring the memory of New bold Morris, former president of the City Council and Commissioner of Parks, who died last year, were unveiled yesterday in the inner lobby of the City Center, 131 West 55th Street.

Dawdling world sugar futures prices, which have been edging up a little recently after a long stay in the doldrums, managed to show a healthy spurt yesterday.

Charles A. Buckley's right-hand man, Henry G. McDonough, was viewed yesterday as an almost unbeatable favorite to succeed the Bronx Democratic leader, who died Sunday.

BONN, Jan. 23 A District Civil Court in Hamburg refused today a request by Look magazine for an injunction against publication by a West German magazine of further uncut installments of "The Death of a President."
Directors of Johnson Johnson, Inc., proposed yesterday in New Brunswick, N.J., a threefor-one stock split of the company's common shares.

More than 150 striking Woodbridge, N.J., teachers were transtransported here by bus yesterday to get applications for city teaching jobs next month, several hours after their union rejected the latest offer from the Board of Education in the New Jersey town.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23 Republicans made a strong show of intersectional unity today as they opened the first meeting their National Committee has held in the South in modern political history.

Former Senator Barry Goldwater described yesterday Senator J.W. Fulbright's eight-point plan to end the war in Vietnam as "foolishness" that ought to be stopped "before people start taking it seriously."

Astronomers in California have observed what seems to have been the most fearsome explosion ever recorded by man, apart from the one in which, many believe, the universe was born. However no one knows when it occurred.

Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, voiced "deep concern" yesterday over the United States deficit in its payments balance, and called on the nation to devote "urgent attention" to its elimination."

REPORTS of a surprise peace overture in Viet nam and the reality of easing interest rates provided the heady news on which the stock market thrived yesterday morning. The initial impetus proved sufficient to keen prices ahead at the close.

Mrs. Lenore Lafount Romney, the wife of Gov. George Romney of Michigan, has expressed anger at critics of the Mormon attitude on Negroes. The Governor is a leader of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
The city's Board of Ethics proposed yesterday that a nonprofit corporation be formed to receive private funds given to the city for entertaining official guests.

WHETHER it's work or play or losing a para keet, almost anything the Hubleys do is liable to involve the entire family.
NORTH HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 23 Miss Isabel Elliott Collins and David Edward Rossman plan to marry here June 17.

Jack Reilly, a pianist and composer whose work is lightly colored by jazz, gave a program of his compositions last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

A basic and on the whole valid complaint of Latin Americans against North Americans is that no attention is paid to them unless or until they have revolutions, assassinations or earthquakes. Honduras is rarely heard from these days because it is quiet but that is no reason to forget its existence.
Prices advanced for the 15th consecutive trading session on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 23 (Reuters) Iraqi President Abdel Rahman Arif announced today that the Iraq Petroleum Company must resume pumping oil from the Kirkuk oilfields by Saturday.

NORBORNE, Mo., Jan. 23 (UPI) Robert Bolivar DePugh announced today that he was resigning as national coordinator of the right-wing Minutemen. Henceforth, he indicated, it will operate in complete secrecy and completely underground.

MADRID, Jan. 23 The police charged today that "all the subversive propaganda" circulated recently in the Catalonian region of Spain flowed from a religious center maintained in Barcelona by the Benedictine monks from the Montserrat Abbey.

A still-confidential report to the Lindsay administration suggests a study not only of a tunnel for the Lower Manhattan Expressway but also of "the feasibility of extending the tunnel to Brooklyn to relieve traffic on the East River bridges."

The curing of bodily ills with such ancient Chinese techniques as acupuncture and herb medicine is the subject of a two-part television series produced by French television that will begin here tonight at 8 o'clock on WNDT, Channel 13.

In the blue-walled room where the body of former Representative Charles A. Buckley lay, his daughter, Mrs. John Forshay moved quietly among the visitors yesterday, while his widow, Marie, sat in a straightbacked chair and chatted in muted tones with several friends.

Britain's Hayley Mills was once the essence of dewy-eyed girlhood in such films as "Pollyanna" and "The Parent Trap." Now she is almost 21 years old, and starred in a British movie that has been barred from Cunard Line cruise ships because children might see it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The Supreme Court moved today for the first time to involve the Federal courts in the question of the imposition of the death penalty against Negroes convicted of raping white women.
Chester C. Canning, chairman of the board of American Gas Chemicals, Inc., died yesterday at University Hospital. He was 66 years old.
PARIS, Jan. 23 Chinese students burned papers here today as they prepared for a mass return to their homeland.

A meeting between two lawyers, said to have been an attempt to settle the legal problems of Representative Adam Clayton Powell, broke up within minutes yesterday with each lawyer blaming the other for failing to come to terms.

"Dutchman," a film version of LeRoi Jones's Off-Broadway play, has been acquired for release in the United States and Canada by the Walter Reade Organization.
OTTAWA, Jan. 23 (AP) The Mercantile Bank of Canada said today the Federal Government of Canada has aimed "discriminatory" legislation at it because it is American-owned.
MANHASSET, L.I., Jan. 23 Casper J. Azzara, head of the real estate department of Lord, Day Lord, New York law firm, died today in his home at 198 Sussex Drive. His age was 66.
LEW ALCINDOR, the giant of the unbeaten Univer sity of California, Los Angeles, basketball team, will leave college before completing his four years, according to Al McGuire, the Marquette coach.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 President Johnson asked Congress today to authorize the biggest single increase in Social Security benefits, starting July 1, to be financed in part by higher payroll taxes, starting in mid-1968.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., reported yesterday a 5 per cent drop in earnings last year despite record sales.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 23 A Cornell University faculty committee voted today not to prohibit the sale of The Trojan Horse, the campus literary magazine that has caused a storm of protest here in the last few days.
The Port of New York Authority awarded the first contracts yesterday for the super-structure of the World Trade Center, whose twin, 110-story towers will be the tallest buildings in the world.

THE concert was over, everybody sat back, and eventually Leonard Bernstein appeared. SAIGON, SouthVietnam, Jan. 23 South Vietnamese military authorities placed Saigon's sprawling Tansonnhut Airport on alert briefly this afternoon and searched at least one incoming airliner for Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Huu Co, the Defense Minister and Deputy Premier.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) The Supreme Court agreed today to hear a Justice Department challenge to the proposed merger of two Philadelphia banks.

The First Western Financial Corporation, parent company of the First Western Savings and Loan Association in Las Vegas, Nev., announced yesterday a "complete reorganization" of its top management, including an entire new board of directors and a new operating management.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 23 The New Jersey Superior Court took possession of this city's Point Breeze dump today and immediately banned its further use except for disposal of burned-out wastes from the city incinerator.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia was designated unanimously today at a Democratic caucus to be president of the State Constitutional Convention.

The City Investing Company plans to acquire American Electric, Inc., a privately held aerospace company in California, for stock worth about $40-million, according to proposed terms announced yesterday.

Two statements by Premier Chou En-lai only a few days apart vividly illustrate the deteriorating situation of the Maoist forces in China. Less than two weeks ago the Premier was assuring some Albanian visitors that the opposition to Mao was showing signs of collapse. But now, in the last day or two, he talks about loosing China's army against the dissidents. The clear implication is that the latter are growing stronger rather than weaker.

A new department of physical fitness, to operate the year round, has been established by the New York Giants. Johnny Dziegiel, for many years a trainer of the Giant teams and also those at Fordham, will direct the department. Wellington T. Mara, the president of the club, announced the new plan yesterday.

BOTH of these books, both set on the West Coast, are voyages of discovery and return. In each a man has to learn about himself, what he is and what he needs. Both novels are modest and compact. Their reach and grasp are well within their abilities; their situations are convincing. The difference lies in the handling.

MIAMI, Jan. 23 (AP) Braulio Baeza, the nation's leading money winning rider last year, fell from his mount at the start of the first race at Hialeah today and suffered a deep cut in his right elbow. The injury is expected to keep him out of action for about two days.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Following is the text of the message on older Americans that President Johnson sent to Congress today:

MEMPHIS, Jan. 23 (AP) The Philadelphia 76ers, trailing part of the way, scored the last 8 points and held off a rally by the St. Louis Hawks tonight for a 112-105 National Basketball Association victory.
The United States Freight Company, a holding company that controls the world's largest freight forwarding system, announced the acquisition of another steamship operation yesterday.

Network news reporters and correspondents have unanimously approved terms of a threeyear contract drawn up by negotiators for the national networks and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.

Evasive action by Secret Service agents, who seemed immobilized during "five terrible seconds," might have saved President Kennedy from the second and fatal shot fired by Lee Harvey Oswald, according to William Manchester.

Kilimanjaro in East Africa is one of the scenic wonders of the world. It consists of three extinct volcanic peaks, of which one Kibo Peak, towering more than 19,000 feet is the highest mountain in Africa. It is also the center of an area important for its wild game.
Lee C. Dowling, former executive director of the state's Committee on Mental Retardation and Physical Handicap, died Sunday night in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 64 years old.

Helen Rex Kelley, retired librarian and author, died Saturday in the New Paltz (N.Y.) Nursing Home. Her age was 90.

The New York Foundling Hospital will receive the proceeds of the annual luncheon, bridge and children's fashion show Thursday at the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria. The ladies auxiliary of the hospital, at 1175 Third Avenue, is the sponsor.
Sanderson Vanderbilt, a writer and editor at The New Yorker magazine for nearly 30 years, died in his sleep Sunday at his home in Palisades, N.Y. He was 57 years old.

Laurance S. Rockefeller described as "deliberately misleading" yesterday an advertisment that contained his name and urged State Senators to vote in favor of saving the old Metropolitan Opera house, which is being torn down. The advertisement appeared in The New York Times and other newspapers.

Art and city government got together yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art for the start of the museum's new exhibition, "The New City: Architecture and Urban Renewal."

The spot rate on the British pound was steady in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. Currency for delivery today was quoted at $2.7912, up 2 points from Friday. Sterling for tomorrow closed between $2.7907 and $2.7909.

Steel production in the week ended Saturday dipped 0.3 per cent to 2,443,000 tons from 2,450,000 tons the preceding week, The American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

"You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown," a revue based on Charles M. Schulz's comic strip, "Peanuts," will arrive March 7 at Theater 80 St. Marks on St. Marks Place.

Lee Simonson, the Broadway scenic designer and a founding director of the Theater Guild, died early yesterday at the Saw Mill River Nursing Home in Yonkers. He was 78 years old and had lived at 411 East 50th Street.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 23--Fifteen thousand Chinese Nationalists celebrated "Freedom Day" today in a colorful rally that was half spontaneous and half timeworn drill.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 House Democratic leaders skirted the issue today of committee seniority for Adam Clayton Powell if he is permitted to take his seat in the House.

MIAMI, Jan. 23 (UPI) A 40-year-old policeman crouched in the corner of a coin shop and shot it out with three bandits today, killing one as he peeked over a hostage's shoulder and wounding another as he fled down the street.

BONN, Jan. 23 Wilhelm Harster, Nazi police chief in the Netherlands in World War II, went on trial in Munich today on charges of complicity in the murder of more than 80,000 Dutch Jews.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 23 Academic leaders of the University of California's nine campuses met in executive session today to discuss their search for a new president to succeed Dr. Clark Kerr, who was removed by the Board of Regents on Friday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today he was concerned over recent declines in farm prices, and promised to try to strengthen them.

JERUSALEM (Israel) Jan. 23 The Bank of Israel announced tonight that it had taken over two smaller Israeli banks, Feuchtwanger and Ellern's because of their mismanagement.

TRENTON, Jan. 23 (AP) Gulf Western Industries won a major court test today growing out of its merger with the New Jersey Zinc Company. The New Jersey Supreme Court upheld the merger, consummated in February.
The P. O. Group has added 108 new ships to its fleet at a cost of $576-million over the last 10 years, according to F.I. Geddes, managing director of the British-flag company.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 23 Gideon I. Davenport, who headed several New York cotton textile concerns, died of a heart attack yesterday, at his home, 94 Overlook Road. His age was 77.

The Securities and Exchange Commission's sharply critical report on mutual funds, published early last month, had little effect on sales and redemptions of shares, according to figures for December released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) The Supreme Court refused today to upset "recidivist" laws of various states that permit a jury to be told of prior offenses of a defendant before it has decided his guilt.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 23 (AP) Two brothers, who had not seen each other since they worked together in an aircraft company 28 years ago, were reunited today working together in the same restaurant.

LONDON, Jan. 23 An "invitation" from President Ho Chi Minh to President Johnson to come to Hanoi for peace talks was reported here today by three clergymen who have just returned from North Vietnam.

Stock prices fell into a hole in the first hour of trading yesterday and spent the rest of the session climbing out of it.

Hogan.

ROME, Jan. 24 President Nikolai V. Podgorny arrived today for a week-long official visit to Italy, the first by a Russian chief of state since that by Czar Nicholas II in 1909. Mr. Podgorny will pay a call on Pope Paul VI.
