Nino Benvenuti, the Italian who is the middleweight champion of Europe, predicted yesterday that his "spectacular" style would enable him to dethrone the world champion, Emile Griffith, in their anticipated title bout blueprinted for Madison Square Garden on March 22.
Bond prices registered substantial declines and big new issues of corporate and municipal bonds offered to investors yesterday sold slowly.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 24 One of the Ford Mark II's entered in next week's (Feb. 4 and 5) 24-hour Continental was being tested on the 3.81-mile road course here today. Bruce McLaren of New Zealand and Lloyd Ruby of Wichita Falls, Tex., were the drivers. It was one of those "hushhush" type of operations. The drivers were permitted to talk about themselves and the forthcoming race, but could say nothing about the car.
Demand continued for British Government bonds yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
WILMINGTON, Ohio, Jan. 24 (AP) Wilmington College announced today that it would offer a program combining college education and Peace Corps service.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 24 A law requiring emergency lighting equipment in almost all buildings in the Town of Hempstead except one-and two-family houses was adopted today by the Town Board.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 24 (AP) West Germany, last year's winner of the European Zone Davis Cup, will meet the Soviet Union in the first round this year.

The Norfolk Western Railway, with earnings of $97.8million, or $10.61 a share, made more money last year than any transportation company ever did before in a single year, but fell short of its own management's goal to net $100-million. Meanwhile, the Pennsylvania Railroad, the biggest transportation company in the nation (both assets and revenues) increased its consolidated system net income last year by almost 29 per cent to $90,293,000, or 6.49 a share.

A former official of the Port Authority of New York, Paul L. Thomas, has joined Parsons, Brinckerhoff, Quade Douglas, engineering and architectural concern, as vice president and deputy to the administrative partner.
Robert P. Newton, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, died Friday in Sarasota, Fla., where he lived He was 74 years old.

Philip Greene, a vice president of Bankers Trust Company, was elected president of the East Side Chamber of Commerce yesterday at its annual meeting in Ratner's Restaurant at 138 Delancey Street. He will succeed Andrew Ziegeler, executive vice president of the Merchants Bank of New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) President Johnson wants Congress to charge the costs of highway safety and beautification to the nation's motorists.
The 41st Valentine's Day dinner dance of the Physicians Wives League of Greater New York will be held on Feb. 11 in the Sert and Terrace Rooms of the Waldorf-Astoria.

There was a rather nice birthday party at Town Hall last night as Clarion Concerts celebrated the 400th anniversary of the birth of Claudio Monteverdi, the Italian composer who did so much for opera in the days of its infancy. Since Monteverdi was actually born on May 15, 1567, the party was a bit premature, but that did not dull its pleasures.

Stillman Hanna views the world through the driver's window of a 50th Street crosstown bus. He greets his passengers with an air of resignation born of endless explanations of the mysteries of his route.

Commodity traders who have been awaiting the Government's report on grain and soybean stocks read some bearish news and some that was bullish yesterday, but it was too late for trading action. The long-awaited report was issued after the close of trading.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan, 24 The number of dead in floods in Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo states rose above 150 today as torrential rains continued.
Frank Robinson received another honor yesterday when New York's baseball writers elected him the outstanding player in the 1966 World Series.
ARGUS RESEARCH Corporation is a major supplier of economic and investment research to Wall Street and yesterday its chairman, Harold B. Dorsey, expressed his thoughts in forthright fashion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 President Johnson's Budget Message to Congress today highlighted more than ever before the fact that there are three ways of measuring the Government's activities the administrative budget, the cash budget and the national income accounts budget.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 24 (UPI) The Kentucky Human Rights Commission was asked today to investigate the phraseology in the state song "My Old Kentucky Home" for racial overtones.

A State Supreme Court Justice ruled yesterday that the refusal of the Police Department to issue a gun permit to a 22-year-old man because his father had a bookmaking record was "not in accordance with the American way of life."

The Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center, in a major innovation, turned to Broadway yesterday, Mike Nichols, of the comedy team of Nichols and May and a successful Broadway and film director, will stage Lillian Hellman's "The Little Foxes" at the Vivan Beaumont Theater next season.
Paramount Pictures has announced 27 new projects, marking one of the company's most ambitious programs in recent years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Administration turned down today a request by Alabama to postpone the cutoff on Feb. 28 of $95.8-million in Federal welfare funds because of the state's failure to comply with civil rights regulations.
Nobody not even Robert Moses ever will know just how great a goalie Thomas P.F. Hoving might have been for the Princeton hockey team.

An official With the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity said yesterday that New York City was in danger of losing millions of dollars in poverty funds unless it could spend funds currently allocated.
The Radio Corporation of America has decided to move into the magnetic tape industry in a big way.
The International Dog Show of Chicago, the country's largest all-breed event, has yielded its April dates in the International Amphitheater to some industrial exhibitions.

Consolidated earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) in 1966 were estimated yesterday at a record of $1.09billion, or $5.06 a share, by M.L. Haider, chairman. Gross sales and other income last year also established a record, $13.55-billion. The per-share figure is based on the average at 215,476,000 shares outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Maritime Administration announced today that the controversial and experimental nuclear ship Savannah would be taken out of service and laid up when the subsidy contract under which she currently operated expired Aug. 20.

BANMETHUOT, South Vietnam, Jan. 23 In the seven provinces and 27,700 square miles of the 23d South Vietnamese Division's sector in the Central Highlands, a good beginning has been made on a major new American and South Vietnamese objective opening roads to military travel.

CHESTER, Pa., Jan. 24 The launching of a new $13.6-million United States Lines freighter of revolutionary design today served as the backdrop for a warning that the vessel's commercial success depended on a new era in labor-management relations.

LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP) Tommie Smith of the United States and Ron Clarke of Australia dominate the list of athletes whose world track and field records were officially recognized today by the International Amateur Athletic Federation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 A further speed-up in corporate tax collections that would, for the first time, affect small and middle-sized companies with taxes of less than $100,000 a year, was proposed by President Johnson in his budget today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) The Federal Government now has more than 6 million persons on its payroll. And the payroll is still growing.
HOIAN, South Vietnam, Jan. 23 The chief of Quangnam Province has run into a maze of contradictions in his efforts to make pacification projects work.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 24 The men who are trying to make George Romney the next Republican candidate for President left their first major party conference today encouraged over the progress of their cause.
When Helen Quach waves her wand, as many as 12,000 people fall silent and as many as 100 start to make music.

The St. George's Society of New York elected Alex Faulkner president last night in the Williams Club, 24 East 39th Street. Mr. Faulkner is chief American correspondent of The Daily Telegraph of London and a former president of the Foreign Press Association.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 A State Senator said today that he would form a study group aimed at drafting legislation to replace the New York State teacher loyalty laws stricken down yesterday by the United States Supreme Court.
PEKING, Jan 24 Troops in the center of Peking were sharply increased today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 (AP) The Boston Celtics used 38 points by Sam Jones and a tenacious defense to beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 118-106, tonight. The setback ended Philadelphia's string of 36 National Basketball Association victories on its own floor.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee deferred action today on a United States-Soviet consular treaty.
Three men have picked up important titles at Leber Katz Paccione, Inc., a growth-conscious agency that went from $7-million to $10-million in billings last year.

Countess Anthony Karolyi of New York and Sao Paulo, Brazil, and Warren Frederick Lutz of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., formerly of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Bermuda, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maria Theresa de Guevara Lutz, to Harry Fanjul Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fanjul of Larchmont, N.Y., formerly of Havana.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Government plans to extend a helping hand to a million more children in elementary and secondary schools in the next fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 A bipartisan drive to weaken the Senate filibuster rule was aban- doned for two more years today after proponents were unable to summon the two-thirds major- ity needed to bring their pro- posal to a vote.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 24 The Indian Government has finally approved the film "Doctor Zhivago" for showing here after its director, David Lean, reluctantly accepted several cuts designed to mollify the Soviet Union.
The appointment of Sverre Marcussen as executive vice president of Icelandic Airlines, Inc., has been announced by Sigurdur Helgason, president of the airline.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) It will cost you $9.35 if you want to buy the complete set of budget documents outlining the Government's spending plans for the next fiscal year.
A dispute between the Congo and the giant Belgian mining company, Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga, will not necessarily lead to an international lawsuit, Theodore C. Sorensen said yesterday.
Mrs. Marguerite Oswald said yesterday that she would sue William Manchester, author of "The Death of a President," for referring to her son as the "assassin" of President Kennedy.

When The Reporter magazine people prepared the book entitled, "Vietnam: Why," last fall it Was intended only as a promotion item for advertisers, potential advertisers and ad agencies. Now it is in its third printing at $1 a copy, and the magazine can't keep up with the demand.
Emile Francis strutted up to the microphone at Leone's restaurant yesterday and asked:

The vote on the filibuster rule yesterday, when taken in conjunction with a similar vote last week, suggests that the members of the Senate are in basic disagreement over its proper institutional role in the functioning of the Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Federal payments in aid of the poor will rise to $25.6-billion, according to Administration calculations of its proposed new budget. That would mean an increase of $3.6billion, or 16 per cent above the figure for the present fiscal year.

The bill for Congressional reorganization which Senator Monroney of Oklahoma presented to the Senate yesterday provides for only a minor refurbishing and updating of existing procedures. Most of its provisions are excellent as far as they go, but they do not go very far.

LONDON, Jan. 25 The world premiere of "Shadowplay," given by the Royal Ballet at Covent Garden tonight, marks a triumphant return for its choreograpper, Antony Tudor. One of British ballet's founders, he has spent nearly 30 years away in America, Sweden and Japan.
MOSCOW, Jan. 25 Fighting broke out today in Red Square between visiting Chinese students and Soviet policemen and other Russians waiting in line to visit the Lenin Mausoleum.
ONE of the most interesting tables in all of Manhattan is that of the Peter Hyuns, who live in an apartment on the Upper East Side.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 George C. Wallace appealed today to a friendly Senate Finance Committee to help Alabama stop the Administration from cutting off $95-million a year in welfare funds for failure to comply with the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 25 (UPI) The Cincinnati Royals lost a 17-point half-time lead, but rallied in the fourth quarter to beat the New York Knickerbockers, 132-125, in a National Basketball Association game tonight. Oscar Robertson scored a game-high 37 points for the second straight night against the Knicks.
Trans World Airlines has leased the 14th floor in the building at 425 Park Avenue in an expansion move that will affect two of the company's sales offices.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) Adam Clayton Powell will hold a news conference on the island of Bimini Saturday at which, a spokesman said, he will make "several important announcements."

A Supreme Court justice who has remained silent under repeated insults for weeks by a defendant acting as his own lawyer in an extortion case lost his temper yesterday and called the defendant a sneak and a liar.

DETROIT, Jan. 25 The hardpressed American Motors Corporation, smallest of the nation's four principal automobile manufacturers, announced today it had obtained a $20-million supplemental credit from the group of banks that granted $70-million in credits less than 14 months ago.
Two major steel manufacturers and the nation's largest copper producer reported mixed financial results for 1966 yesterday.

DARMSTADT, West Germany, Jan. 25 (UPI) Staff members of the Stars and Stripes newspapers in Europe have demanded a Congressional investigation of Defense Department plans to centralize the flow of news through the Pentagon to military personnel.

PEKING, Jan. 25 (Agence France-Presse) A number of posters calling for the reinstatement of Hsiao Hua, dismissed head of the army's General Political Department, ap peared in the streets of Peking today.

"LIZZIE BORDEN," presented last night in its television premiere on Channel 13, may not be The Great American Opera. It is, however a compelling piece of musical theater, and one that adapts brilliantly to the restrictions and potentials of the small screen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Congressional investigators have begun a study of the methods by which the Department of Defense distributes news to members of the armed forces.

Louis Stulberg, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, expressed confidence yesterday that the union's contract dispute with the dress industry would be settled without a strike.
ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 25 (Reuters) Former Chief Justice Sir Arku Korsah died today at the age of 73.

TORONTO, Jan. 25 (AP) Goals by Yvan Cournoyer, Gilles Tremblay and Claude Larose enabled the Montreal Canadiens to defeat Toronto, 3-1, tonight for the Leafs' fourth straight National Hockey League setback.

SEATTLE, Jan. 25 (AP) Officials of the University of Washington confirmed today that the Reserve Officers Training Corps at the school gave secret instruction last October so that cadets could spy on fellow students and campus "left wing" organizations.
The city's drive on illegally parked cars drew praise yesterday from theater owners, criticism from storekeepers and shrugs of indifference from men at parking lots and garages.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 A small group of legislators is planning a new attempt to overthrow a program of the State Commissioner of Education designed to end racial imbalance in the public schools.
The proposed merger of the McDonnell Company and the Douglas Aircraft Corporation took a giant step forward yesterday.
ANYONE who thinks he can make a raccoon do something it doesn't want to do is likely to have his illusion shattered rather quickly upon confronting one.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 25 (UPI) Governors George Romney of Michigan and James A. Rhodes of Ohio, bath Republicans, met for an hour here today to discuss interstate problems, relations with the Federal Government and "a little politics."

LONG desirous of improving its image, baseball moved up considerably in class the other day when Stan Musial was named general manager of the St. Louis Cardinals. This advances into the showcase one of the best liked and most admired men to grace the sport with his presence. It also returns to a more active role a man who had been lurking in the background in the somewhat anomalous post of vice president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) Dr. William Haddon Jr., director of the National Traffic Safety Agency, told car manufacturers today that the Administration was extending the time period for appealing its final safety standards.
LONDON, Jan. 25 Colin Jordan, leader of Britain's National Socialist Movement, a neo-Nazi group, was sentenced today to 18 months imprisonment for stirring racial hatred.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 The United States has quietly made several informal but direct contacts with political representatives of the Vietcong, diplomatic sources disclosed today. So far, it is said, they have not proved fruitful.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia disagreed with Governor Rockefeller today on the system to be used to determine winners of the state lottery.

WASHINGTON, Jan.25 (AP) The Army General Counsel, Albert B. Fitt, denied today that the Hughes Tool Company, in winning a helicopter contract, had benefited from alleged leaks and disclosures of a competitor's cost data.
SUMMIT, N.J., Jan. 25 Emory Hammond Westlake, who retired last year as chairman and president of the Tennessee Copper Company, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital here after a short illness.
Consolidated net profits of the Chicago North Western Railway for 1966 climbed to $26,074,648, or $16.85 a common share, from $16,063,760, or $13.14 a share, the year before.
WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Jan. 25 The parents are worried, some of the students are concerned and the teachers' strike was in its eighth day today, although mediation was in sight tonight.

THE main problem in teaching obedience is not the dog, but the handler, said Philip Jacobs of Southboro, Mass., who is instructor for the classes conducted by the New England Dog Training Club, one of the country's first organizations in the field of dog training.

Investigators at Tulane University have presented new evidence that schizophrenia may be a disorder of the body's defense system, resulting in the production of antibodies against the patient's brain tissue.

Rafael Kubelik led the Boston Symphony Orchestra in a commanding performance of Mahler's Ninth Symphony last night at Philharmonic Hall. Fortunately, in this instance "commanding" did not imply "overawing." It was a Ninth warmed from within and utterly secure in concept.
LINDEN, N.J., Jan. 25 Public school teachers were back in their classrooms today, despite the school board's approval last night of a 1967-'68 budget that fell short of their demands.
Fifteen young women descended from men who fought in the American Revolution will make their debuts at the annual Colonial Ball, to be held at the Plaza on Feb. 17.
The Carnegie Commission on Educational Television proposed yesterday the imposition of a Federal tax on all new sets to provide the major source of financing for noncommercial television in the home.

MIAMI, Jan. 25 (UPI) Bold and Brave of the Wheatley Stable, trained by Eddie Neloy and ridden by Braulio Baeza, thundered down the stretch today to win the 22d running of the $31,200 Royal Palm Handicap at Hialeah Park by a neck.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 25 A lack of faith in the integrity of the British Government was the main reason for the Rhodesian Government's rejection of the constitutional changes proposed by Britain last month, according to a Government white paper published here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Gov. Ronald Reagan of California was urged today to withdraw his request for a delay of three months in Congressional consideration of plans for a redwood national park.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 The Johnson Administration has barred American planes from venturing within five miles of Hanoi's center, Washington sources disclosed today.

State Supreme Court Justice Thomas A. Aurelio ruled yesterday that the State Harness Racing Commission had acted "in the sound exercise of discretion" in not immediately issuing an owner-trainer-driver license to Robert Shuttleworth.
PORTMADOC, Wales, Jan. 25 (Reuters) Dr. William Lloyd George, younger brother of David Lloyd George, the late Prime Minister, died today at this North Wales resort.
The almighty computer was helpless for 11 minutes yesterday at the New York Stock Exchange.

The white phone was on the wall in the panelled kitchen of Roy Campanella's big brick home in Hartsdale, N.Y. When it rang shortly before 11 A.M. yesterday his wife, Roxie, put down a pot of coffee and walked over to answer it.
The roofs leaks. The schoolyard is closed. The street is never cleaned. The traffic light on Queens Boulevard blinks erratically.

PARIS, Jan. 25 Prime Minister Wilson left Paris tonight displaying a mood of confidence and determination but offering no evidence that the French had withdrawn their objections to British entry into the Common, Market.
GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 25 Harold J. Gane, a retired advertising executive for the Socony-Mobil Oil Company, died here yesterday at his home in the Putnam Hill Apartments. His age was 66.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Jan. 25 John F. Mylod, president of the Mortgage Corporation of New Jersey, Newark, died yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived on Ballantine Road in Bernardsville.
Joe Shaw, a New York mid dleweight, scored a unanimous decision over Junius Hinton of Brooklyn last night in the eight round main event at Sunnyside Garden, Queens.

ROME, Jan. 25 Pope Paul VI has quietly reversed a decision by his staff prohibiting participation by Roman Catholics of the Rome Diocese in prayer services for Christian unity held in Protestant and Anglican churches.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) The Senate securities subcommittee, a unit of the Banking Committee, put at the bottom of its legislative schedule today proposed reforms in the mutual fund industry.

In the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon, Miss Phyllis Slick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Frates Slick of Winston-Salem, N.C., became the bride of John Franklin Cowell 3d. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Cowell of Summit, N.J.
The philanthropic activities of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen R. Currier, which amounted to almost $3-million last year, will be continued posthumously under provisions in their wills.

When a rumor makes the rounds among commodity men, there's often plenty of action. So yesterday world sugar futures gave the New York Coffee Sugar Exchange its busiest trading day for sugar since 1926.

SAKS FIFTH AVENUE customers shopping in the Pucci boutique sometimes shy away from the salesclerk with blond, schoolgirl hair, apparently believing. She is too young to understand the fine points of the printed jersey dresses that have become a status symbol in fashionable circles.

PARIS, Jan. 25 The couture house of Lanvin, which is the oldest in France and always used to act its age, kicked up its heels this morning and showed the youngest, gayest, most lovable collection of its long, respectable life.

PAUL SANASARDO does not so much defeat criti cism as elude it. He is a difficult man to pin down. With his company, he proved as difficult and as elusive as ever last night at Kaufmann Hall of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association on 92d Street.
Transportation Administrator Arthur E. Palmer Jr. has claimed compensation for a 10day vacation in the Bahamas last month. He did so on the advice of a staff administrator, Mr. Palmer said yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 (AP) A prominent Roman Catholic educator said today that Government-operated birth control programs increased rather than lessened individual freedom.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Mrs. Arline Denzer Hays, chairman emeritus of the Citizens Council for a Clean Potomac, died yesterday of a heart ailment at the Washington Hospital Center. Her age was 88. She was the widow of Hiram J. Hays.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has revoked the investment-adviser registrations of Marketlines, Inc., of 50 Broad Street, and Elizabeth Schreiber, doing business as the Commodity Trading Advisory Service, 65 Stuart Street, Lynbrook. L.I.
The New York Philharmonic has elected Mrs. Richard J. Bernhard and Miss Alice Tully to the board of directors.
WARSAW, Jan. 25 Communist China rejected today a request by the United States that they step up the pace of their ambassadorial meetings here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Senator Joseph S. Clark accused the Administration and Congress today of "shortsighted" and "inconsistent" action in cutting off food aid to Eastern European nations trading with Cuba or North Vietnam.
JELLICO, Tenn., Jan. 25 (AP) For two weeks Mrs. Glenna Perkins, a hospital nurses' aid, helped care for an old woman who had cancer.

ALTHOUGH Grand Master Bent Larsen of Denmark is not the top player in the world or even the best in the West, he is certainly the most confident in the international arena. And this ebullient manner, this ever-optimistic opinion of his chances in even positions, explains his setbacks at the height of many a winning streak.

By WALTER SULLIVAN The discovery of a second starlike source of intense X-rays in the sky, reported here yesterday, has persuaded a number of astronomers that such visible objects represents a new type of celestial phenomenon.
A Federal judge has upheld the authority of the Federal Maritime Commission to seek documents from the Zim Israel Navigation Company in an investigation of alleged spurious identification of cargo.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 25 (UPI)--Rival student groups, one of them led by Stokely Carmichael, clashed today in a rock-throwing battle in the streets of Santuree. United States involvement in the war in Vietnam was among the issues.
he spot rate on the Canadian dollar fell seven points to 92.71 in foreign exchange dealings here yesterday. The currency for delivery in three months declined by the same amount, to 92.63.

"HE'S the least anecdotal man I know," a friend said recently of Dr. James Rhyne Killian Jr., adviser to Presidents, chairman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Corporation and head of the Carnegie Commission on Educational Television, whose report was re leased yesterday.

DUBLIN, Jan. 25 Irish societies in the United States have raised $100,000 toward a memorial park for John F. Kennedy, which is nearing completion on a hillside in County Wexford close to the home of the late President's ancestors.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 25--King Hussein of Jordan told a "public rally" at the luxury Jerusalem Intercontinental Hotel today that Jordan had enough military forces to meet her defense requirements and therefore had no need of Arab troops from outside.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 President Johnson asked Congress today to permit the disfranchised citizens of the District of Columbia to spend a record $527-million most of it their own tax money for municipal services in the Federal city.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Two of the principal points on which Robert G. Baker has based his defense were challenged at his trial today by rebuttal witnesses called by the Government.
As the credit markets yesterday tried to assess the Treasury's plans for refunding $7.5billion of Government notes maturing in mid-February, prices first fell sharply and then recovered.
Prices slipped yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, ending an advance that extended through 16 sessions.
President Johnson's proposed record increase in Social Security benefits could have monumental impact on the financial plans of individuals and families.

BONN, Jan. 25 Stern magazine, which has been publishing the uncut serialization of William Manchester's "The Death of a President" for the last three issues, announced today that it would delete future passages as "a personal gesture to Mrs. John F. Kennedy."

Members of Congress, civic leaders, judges and recipients of clubhouse favors turned out in great numbers yesterday for funeral services for Charles A. Buckley, one of the last of the old-line county bosses.

The Angry Arts, an organization of about 200 painters, sculptors, writers, actors, musicians, filmmakers and dancers announced yesterday that its members would present works symbolizing their protest against the war in Vietnam in a week-long series of demonstrations, starting Sunday.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 25 Rabbi and Mrs. Murray Grauer have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sheri Lea Grauer, to Stanley Raskas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Raskas of St. Louis.
LONDON, Jan. 25 (AP) Customs officers relented tonight and released an impounded football, victim of Rhodesian sanctions.

HAWTHORNE, N.Y., Jan. 25 A motorist, annoyed by state troopers' use of radar to apprehend speeders on the Taconic State Parkway, must answer a charge of putting up a glaring "radar one-half mile ahead" sign beside the parkway.
Some 900 women were told here yesterday that even though they had been out of the labor market for a long time, there was a crying need for their services in business, industry and government.
ROME, Jan. 25 A former American Episcopal minister and news correspondent was among 16 priests ordained today by Pope Paul VI at a special ceremony in the Sistine Chapel.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 25 Three clergymen and a city official were among six civil rights leaders arrested here today for blocking contractors' trucks to protest what they called discrimination against Negro workmen.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 25 Rutgers University's basketball team had not stepped on the court in intercollegiate competition for 28 days because of the Christmas vacation and the examination break. It made absolutely no difference judging by the performance the Scarlet Knights put on tonight in beating Fordham, 82-66, in Rutgers Gymnasium.
Industrial issues were firm yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
HONG KONG, Jan. 25 Portuguese residents of Macao did not appear to be greatly inconvenienced today by a boycott launched against them by Communist-led Chinese in the territory.
The New York Rangers have made their best All-Star showing in 34 years by placing three players on the National Hockey League's first team.

WEST CORNWALL, Conn., Jan. 25 Joseph W. Gannon, manager of the advertising acceptability department of The New York Times from 1932 to his retirement in 1956, died today in Tranquil House, a nursing home in Warren, after a short illness. He was 93 years old and lived here.

ROME, Jan. 25 President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union met polite but firm Italian resistance today to his attacks on United States policy on Vietnam, his defense of German partition and the proposed exclusion of Washington from European security affairs.

The Lincoln Center Repertory Company has engaged two British stars: Sir Anthony Quayle for "Galileo" and Margaret Leighton for "The Little Foxes." "Galileo" is due at the Vivian Beaumont Theater on April 13 and "The Little Foxes," on Oct. 23.
Three key aides to former Mayor Robert F. Wagner took sharp issue yesterday with his criticism of the Lindsay administration's plans for reorganization of city government.

Albany, Jan. 25 Legislative leaders completed their sweep of the top posts at the Constitutional Convention today with the designation of Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges to head the Republican delegation.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 25 Last March, when Prime Minister Indira Gandhi returned from a trip to Washington, New Delhi basked in the warm glow of the rapport she was reported to have established with President Johnson.
HONG KONG, Thursday, Jan. 20 (Reuters) North Vietnam said today reports that China had hijacked Soviet missiles destined for North Vietnam were false.
Some judges and Legal Aid Society lawyers were accused yesterday of cooperating to provide free counsel to solvent defendants so that Criminal Court calendars could be cleared quickly.

Nino Benvenuti, an Italian middleweight, said yesterday that he would have to get permission from the Italian Boxing Federation to delay a defense of his European title so he could oppose the world champion, Emile Griffith, at Madison Square Garden March 22.

"Sperry Rand hasn't done a very good communications job," said Bert T. Oakley, vice president for corporate relations of that very same corporation, who dropped by yesterday to announce that all that was changing.
President Johnson has taken a courageous and constructive stand on foreign aid.

The Consolidated Foods Corporation, Chicago, and BigelowSanford, Inc., New York, announced early yesterday that they were considering a merger and then, in the late afternoon, said they had terminated their talks without reaching an agreement.

The Building Industry Employers of New York State has named Franklyn L. Snyder managing director effective Feb. 1.
A radar failure and heavy fog gave La Guardia Airport a day of delays, diversions and cancellations yesterday.
Under intense, nail-chewing circumstances, the New York Rangers broke their slump and edged the Boston Bruins, 2-1, at Madison Square Garden last night.
BONN, Jan. 25 West German diplomatic initiatives in Communist Europe brought positive results from Hungary and Rumania today plus a panicky reaction from East Germany.
Proposals for changes in the traffic pattern that has been designed for the downtown civic center were submitted to Mayor Lindsay yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton.
The three-week boom in the stock market ended with a bang yesterday.
An anonymous contribution of $1,000 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund headed the list of 35 gifts recorded yesterday by the 55th annual appeal.
Mayor Lindsay moved yesterday to exempt 258,000 more residents from filing city income tax returns.
DETROIT, Jan. 25 (UPI) The University of Detroit, controlled by Jesuit Roman Catholic priests for 90 years, announced today it plans to turn over half the seats on its Board of Trustees to laymen.

LONDON, Jan. 25 Philips, the big Dutch electronics company, offered today an explanation of how it acquired 9.6 million shares of Pye, Ltd., a Cambridge, England, electronics manufacturer, after steadfastly denying that it was the "mystery buyer" in the stock market.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)--Major electrical systems of the Eastern and Western United States and Canada will be interconnected for test purposes on Feb. 7 to form a huge power grid, Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall announced tonight.
Indoor track returns to Madison Square Garden tonight with the 60th annual Millrose Games, the showcase of the sport.
The Johnson Administration proposed yesterday that the interest equalization tax on American purchases of foreign securities be doubled from 15 per cent to 30 per cent effective today.
Verdi's "II Trovatore" has had its ups and downs in recent Metropolitan Opera history. Last night the seven-year old production was revived in what was at best an adequate performance.

Directors of McGraw-Hill, Inc., proposed yesterday a twofor-one split of the company's common stock, subject to shareholders' approval at their annual meeting April 25. It would then become effective June 30.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) With imports climbing twice as fast as exports, the favorable United States trade surplus dropped last year to its lowest level since 1959, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The hands of the courtroom clock stand at 3:30 P.M. and it is time for Judge Oliver Gasch to deliver his daily homily in the trial of Robert G. Baker.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the nation's second largest electrical manufacturer, had the best year in its 81-year history in terms of sales, earnings new business and backlog, the report of D. C. Burnham, president, disclosed yesterday.
Paced by Bob Chlupsa's 25 points, the Manhattan College basketball team defeated St. Francis, 76-64, last night at the 69th Regiment Armory.
Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc. has named two staff members of long standing as senior vice presidents.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 A severe shortage of freight cars appears to be imminent, according to William H. Tucker, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Ever since Pope John urged the Roman Catholic Church to involve itself more directly in the social needs of the secular world, Catholic higher education in the United States has been in ferment behind-the-scenes. In the last two weeks, new patterns have burst into public view.
Directors of the Lone Star Cement Corporation elected yesterday Harry E. Green to the position of president and chief executive officer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 The Treasury offered today a 15-month note and a five-year note for cash, each bearing an interest rate of about 4.85 per cent to replace $3.8-billion of securities maturing Feb. 15.

PEKING, Jan. 25 (Agence France-Presse) A Peking "revolutionary rebel" newspaper said today that Yang Chengwu, interim Chief of Staff of the Chinese armed forces, had been the source of a recent report that China would launch a "spaceship" this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) The new Lani Bird satellite has transmitted its first television tests between the United States and Japan with good results, the Communications Satellite Corporation reported.

SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, Jan. 25 Mr. and Mrs. Rutherford Harris have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Ainslie Harris, to Ian Alexander Todd. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Todd of Sandgate, Folkstone, England.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 25 Spiro T. Agnew, a liberal Republican who defeated a segregationist Democrat for Governor of this strongly Democratic border state, pledged at his inauguration today to throw over "old alliances and outmoded convention" in government.
MOSCOW, Jan. 25 (AP)--A Soviet magazine published excerpts from the uncut version of William Manchester's book "The Death of a President" today.
The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday it would present a live television broadcast of a London news conference in which Soviet Premier Aleksai N. Kosygin will respond to written questions.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25 Make believe, for a moment, that the four conductors of the major symphony orchestras that give concert series in New York each had a night off and each was in town.
DENVER, Jan. 25 (AP) A storm left nearly two feet of snow on Utah mountain slopes and headed eastward through the Rockies tonight on the heels of destructieve Midwestern winds yesterday.
FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 25 (UPI) Pete Gogolak, the kicking specialist for the New York Giants, was declared fit for military duty today and was inducted into the Army for two years.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 25 (Reuters)--The army announced today the arrest of the chief of President Sukarno's palace guard.

Rudolf Serkin, the pianist, was unable to get to all of the meetings during the deliberations of the Carnegie Commission on Educational Television, of which he was a member, but he more than made up for it.

DETROIT, Jan. 25 (UPI) The Chrysler Corporation and the General Motors Corporation, caught in an auto-industry sales slump, announced today they would lay off nearly 16,000 workers in a seven-plant production cutback.

THE world's biggest individual tournament was played earlier this month in Boston. Kenneth Edmunds of Andover, Mass., headed the field of more than 600 players in the New England Regional Individual, and Sholom Waletzky, one of a small contingent of competitors from New York, placed third.
A plate-number block of four stamps with a printing flaw a missing yellow color was auctioned last night for $5,500.
OTTAWA, Jan. 25 The Canadian Government plans to announce shortly whether it would permit United States and other foreign banks to open bank agencies in Canada.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 25 Rescue work by the army and civilian groups progressed today in the flood-stricken areas of Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo states.
The Liberal party declared yesterday this state should become the first in the nation "to guarantee a job to every man and woman willing and able to work as a matter of right and public policy."
Gravediggers who went on strike Jan. 2 voted yesterday to accept a new contract, and some returned to work immediately.
The Crucible Steel Company appointed yesterday Walter E. Gregg, 53, as executive vice president.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 The University of California's Los Angeles faculty joined Berkeley college today in denouncing the dismissal of Dr. Kerr and asking a greatly enlarged role for...
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 (UPI) Roberto Clemente, the National League's most valuable player last year, signed his 1967 contract today and became the highest paid player in Pittsburgh Pirate history.
WILL Donald C. Cook, president of the Ameri can Electric Power Company, become the next president of the New York Stock Exchange?

Herbert A. Koehler Sr., Queens County Democratic leader from 1959 to 1962 and city Deputy License Commissioner from 1950 through 1961, died Sunday in Physicians Hospital, Jackson Heights, Queens. No announcement of his death was made at the time. He was 80 years old on Nov. 6.
In a dream-like sequence of events, Harry Howell of the Rangers was showered with a glittering assortment of gifts as he was honored last night at Madison Square Garden.
DETROIT, Jan. 25 (UPI) The police today held 56 persons, most of them Wayne State University students, who were trapped in a series of quick raids on an alleged LSD and marijuana ring.

WASHINGTON, Jan.25 (AP) James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, asked the Supreme Court today to review his conviction and five-year prison sentence on charges of fraud and conspiracy involving a union pension fund.
The members of the Carnegie Commission on Educational Television follow:

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 25 (AP) Arthur Ashe reached peak form and Cliff Richey staged a fighting comeback today in pacing four Americans into the fourth round of the Australian national lawn tennis championships.

The opposition to the Somoza dynasty in Nicaragua made a futile as well as tragic gesture. The Conservative party candidate, Fernando Aguero, and his followers must have been desperate to face such hopeless odds and to hold foreign guests in a hotel as hostages.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation reported yesterday for its 50th anniversary year 1966 a record profit of $93.8-million, or $6.16 a share. This was exclusive of additional extraordinary net income of $475,000.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25 A painting valued at $350,000, stolen from a library at St. Joseph's College in Rensselaer, Ind., 15 months ago, was recovered here today by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents.

A scientist at Massachusetts Institute of Technology said here yesterday that spacecraft could survive the menacing radiation of the earth-encircling Van Allen belts 10 to 100 times longer than had originally been estimated.

SACRAMENTO, Jan. 25 The move among Regents of the University of California, to get rid of Dr. Clark Kerr as president of the nine-campus, 87,000student institution originated years before the Berkeley disorders of 1964.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 A Democratic legislator asked the State Controller's office today to withhold the salaries of four men assigned to a committee of which he is a member on the ground that they are "nonqualified persons."

LONDON, Jan. 25--Kwesi Armah, former Ghanaian Ambassador to Britain, was freed from jail tonight after Home Secretary Roy Jenkins ordered that he should not be deported to Ghana to face criminal charges.

A prominent Roman Catholic theologian disclosed yesterday that a quiet campaign had been initiated to keep recent ecumenical gains from being damaged by debate on state aid to parochial schools at the Constitutional Convention in April.
The bank-robbery trial of John (Sonny) Franzese and four others will be held in Albany, beginning Monday, Federal Judge Jacob Mishler announced yesterday.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 25 The United States Steel Corporation was found guilty of negligence tonight in the collapse of a bridge in Costa Rica in which 12 workmen were killed and seven injured.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 102.6 on Tuesday from 102.7 on Monday.
Mrs. Kennedy has sent the following telegram to the editor of Stern:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to request J. Edgar Hoover, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to clarify his views on the consular treaty with the Soviet Union.

The Carnegie Commission on Educational Television has reached the conclusion that a well-financed and well-directed educational television system, substantially larger and far more pervasive and effective than that which now exists in the United States, must be brought into being if the full needs of the American public are to be served. This is the central conclusion of the commission and all of its recommendations are designed accordingly.

"ROMANTIC REBELS," by Emily Hahn, Is bulged as the pouch of a pelican With bright life from wild waters Splashed by Bohemia's sons and daughters. I enjoyed it. Although it's knockable, Who in thunder today is shockable?

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 25 Mr. and Mrs. John Liebermann have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Jane Liebermann, to Mark Nolan Busch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Busch of New Brunswick, N.J.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 25 Fighting broke out again tonight in the center of Managua. First reports said one person had been killed and two had been wounded in shooting between the National Guard and partisans of the opposition.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 25 (AP) The American effort to end the Vietcong's domination of the Mekong delta mounted today with the commitment of a permanent combat team expected to grow soon to at least 30,000 men.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 House Republicans named today Barber B. Conable Jr. of Upstate New York and George Bush of Texas to the House Ways and Means Committee.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 25 (AP) Buckpasser, the nation's leading candidate to win horse of the year honors for the second straight year, has hoof trouble and may not run in the $100,000-added Charles H. Strub Stakes Saturday at Santa Anita.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 25--Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Huu Co, the Deputy Premier and Defense and War Minister, has been ousted from the military junta that rules South Vietnam, Government sources said today.

A businessmen's group set up by Mayor Lindsay called yesterday for apartment houses to comply with a May 20 deadline for upgrading incinerators to decrease air pollution even though one of its experts estimated half might be forced to shut down.
The Federal Trade Commission is conducting a continuing investigation of paper dresses and has found in tests of a dozen dresses that they do not violate the provisions of the Flammable Fabrics Act.

David Ben-Gurion, the first prime minister of Israel, has accepted an invitation to come to the United States to participate in several meetings of the United Jewish Appeal during March, it was announced yesterday by Max M. Fisher of Detroit, general chairman of the U.J.A.
The city agreed late yesterday to delay towing away illegally parked cars of diplomats and physicians for a "reasonable" period of time in cases of emergency parking.

Dr. Francis J. Putman, a professor of law at the New York University Law School since 1945, was found dead yesterday in the garage of his home at 36 Ridgeview Avenue in Greenwich, Conn. The cause of death was accidental carbon monoxide poisoning, according to Dr. Coleman Kelly, a medical examiner. He was 63 years old.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 25 The Yale Daily News today called for the repeal of the Connecticut law that bans the use or possession of marijuana.

LANDING ZONE MARSHMAN, South Vietnam This raw scar of earth gouged out of the top of a jungle ridge in the "panhandle" of Kontum Province, near the Cambodian border, is probably the most exposed outpost of a major American fighting unit in Vietnam.

LONDON, Jan. 25 (AP) Jim Ryun's world record halfmile run of 1 minute 44.9 seconds remains unratified because an application form submitted by American track and field officials was not in order, the International Amateur Athletic Federation said today.
The Rev. Bonaventure McIntyre, a Franciscan father in the Province of the Most Holy Name, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 73 years old.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 25 The Carnegie Commission's report on the future of public television is one of those quiet events that, in the perspective of a generation or even more, may be recognized as one of the transforming occasions in American life.
Wolverhampton, England Jack Bodell, 198 pounds, England, outpointed Ray Patterson, New York, 194, 10 rounds.

Diamonds were a benefit's best friend last night. They sparkled on many of the women attending the eighth annual Diamond Ball, sending transient flashes through the candlelit ballroom of the Plaza Hotel, and they were responsible for a major portion of the $70,000 raised for the treasury of the Institute of International Education.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)--The space agency disclosed plans today to develop a jet engine only about one-tenth as noisy as the engines now in use.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 25 Jack Walsh converted a pass from Jack Morrison at 6 minutes 3 seconds of the third period tonight to give Yale a 4-3 hockey victory over Army.

RECREATIONAL skiing is being sold to thousands of Americans who really would rather not be sold. They find themselves being pushed to the top of the hill by such pressures as the sport's image of youth, the thing-to-do motivation, their skiing children, or the chance to wear goodlooking ski clothes and to drink the gluhwein around the fire afterwards.

LONDON (UPI) Jan. 25 --The British Broadcasting Corporation announced today that it would devote an entire evening of prime broadcast time to a television inquiry into the doubts surrounding the assassination of President Kennedy.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 25 The No. 1 rink of the host Westchester Wicks, skipped by Mrs. Archibald W. Smith, led the way into the semi-final round of the 13th annual Empire State women's bonspiel today with a 9-6 victory over the Toronto Curling Club rink, skipped by Mrs. Geoffrey Boone, at St. Andrew's Golf Club.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 26 The Chinese army has intervened in support of Maoist factions in Manchuria and Anhwei Province, but in Inner Mongolia it appears to be backing the other side, according to Japanese reports from Peking based on wall posters.
JERUSALEM (Israel), Jan. 25 Israel and Syria reaffirmed today their 17-year-old armistice pledge to refrain from hostile and aggressive acts.

The election of Frederick J. Lind as chairman of Licensed Beverage Industries, Inc., the public relations arm of the liquor industry, was announced yesterday at the group's annual luncheon at the Plaza Hotel here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said in Congressional testimony made public today that ground operations in South Vietnam, coastal surveillance and bombing raids against North Vietnam appear to have imposed limits on the build-up of enemy forces in South Vietnam.

The last legal vestiges in New York State of the unedifying era of witch hunts, guilt by association and loyalty oaths for teachers and other public employes have been swept away by this week's 5-to-4 decision of the Supreme Court. Some of the provisions of law now held unconstitutional as violations of individual liberties go back to 1917, but most are from the McCarthy period of the 1950's.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas introduced crime-fighting legislation today to case the use of confession, and wiretapping.
An authority on processed foods suggested last night that Congress should prepare the groundwork for an international group to combat world hunger.
The Cassius Clay-Ernie Terrell heavyweight title fight in Houston on Feb. 6 will be televised live to Europe and Asia, using both communication satellites simultaneously.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Unreasonable though it seems, it is irritating to sit down to breakfast and find an unfamiliar character on the front page. This is because the front page is not, as myth has it, a daily testament to life's chaos, but a tranquil, clubby institution which enables us all to meet each morning with old familiar acquaintances and reflect upon the stability of the world.

St. Francis Clinic, which was created by the city early this month from a small portion of the closed St. Francis Hospital, began an ambitious expansion program yesterday as it became the only clinic in the city to remain open until midnight.
Those parts of the 1968 Federal budget dealing with the merchant marine provoked sharp criticism yesterday in the maritime industry.
United States involvement in the war in Vietnam was defended yesterday as "lawful" by the Executive Committee of the New York State Bar Association.
TRANAAS, Sweden, Jan. 25 (UPI) Odd Martinsen of Norway covered 7 miles in 37.38 minutes today to win the international cross-country ski race here.
The agreement between the city and the Port of New York Authority on the controversial World Trade Center was signed last night by Mayor Lindsay.
A special election for baseball's Hall of Name ended unexpectedly in a shutout yesterday when none of the 68 candidates was elected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) In view of Communist China's nuclear capability, members of the Senate-House Atomic Energy Committee decided today to make a "very exhaustive" study of the world's nuclear balance of power.

PRAGUE, Jan. 25 CzechoSlovakia is ready to establish diplomatic relations with West Germany provided neither side puts conditions on such an agreement, according to authoritative Czechoslovak sources.

After years of permissive strangulation, midtown traffic is moving at last. The Lindsay administration's courageous decision to tow away all illegally parked cars has opened up thoroughfares usually snarled from morning to night.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that the volume of outstanding commercial paper declined $890million, or 6 per cent, during December to $13,279,000,000.
LOME, Togo Togo's first development plan a five-year, $114.4-million program to improve transportation, communications, light industry and agriculture was begun in 1966.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia Africa seemed last year to be like a new planet that was still cooling off. Fresh political upheavals, together with tensions of the unresolved issue of Rhodesia, continued to obscure Africa's future. But on the firmer ground of economic development, most African countries managed to maintain some progress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) President Johnson today assured Arthur Costa e Silva, the visiting Presidentelect of Brazil, that the United States felt it had much at stake in Brazil and would do all it could to help his Government achieve its goals.
"COME LIVE WITH ME" has no doubt been pro duced on Broadway in order to introduce us to Soupy Sales. Now that we've met, it would be nice to see him in a play.
The Lindsay adminstration raised its estimate of net savings from reorganization of city government to $5.9-million yesterday at the opening of City Council hearings on the plan.

RABAT, Morocco Drought, which destroyed half of her cereal crop, caused Morocco to suffer a serious economic setback last year. Making up the losses, and taking steps to prevent similar disasters, will consume the major part of the country's energies in 1967.

Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri sentenced yesterday eight individual defendants for either conspiring to sell, or actually selling, the stock of the Bankers Intercontinental Investment Company, Ltd., and the Florida Patsand Corporation in violation of the antifraud provisions of the Securities Act of 1933.
A nattily dressed gunman walked into a branch of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company bank in the Bronx yesterday, disarmed a guard and walked out with $50,000 in cash.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 26 (UPI) Frank Sinatra testified for about 45 minutes today before a Federal grand jury investigating possible tax evasion by Nevada gambling casinos.
NYACK, N.Y., Jan. 26. Clarence M. Travis of 58 South Midland Avenue, former president of Nyack and founder of Travis Monument, Inc., died in Nyack Hospital today. He was 89 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, asked the Supreme Court today to look into alleged new evidence that the Government eavesdropped on him and the jurors during his jury-tampering trial in 1964.

ARMONK, N.Y., Jan. 26 A private plane from St. Louis with three men aboard crashed yesterday in pine woods of New York City's watershed property here at the north end of Kensico Reservoir. The wreckage was found this morning after an all-night search.

LONDON, Jan. 26 John French, chairman of Dollar Land Holdings, Ltd., plans to call a special stockholder meeting within six weeks to consider a request by dissident shareholders to oust the managers of the company's North American properties.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 (AP) The Soviet Youth newspaper Kosomolskaya Pravda said today that Lawrence Shepp, a 30year-old American mathematician, had been expelled from the Soviet Union for distributing anti-Soviet literature and other offenses.

The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation announced yesterday "a major realignment of its organizational structure." Three new corporate divisions were created and several executive changes were involved.
DOVER, Del., Jan. 26 President Johnson's political pacification squad made its first sally today in the White House campaign to subdue rebellious Governors.

THE HOLDINGS of various mutual funds in the stock of Metro-GoldwynMayer, Inc., may play a critical role in the proxy fight drama over the film producer. The final act unfolds at the Feb. 23 annual meeting in the Loew's State Theater on Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Congestion at the nation's major airports is "just a plain mess," complicated by a host of social, economic and technological problems, Secretary of Transportation Alan S. Boyd told Congress today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. When a Harvard man has a deep sense of failure or a Radcliffe girl is too depressed to study, the chances are, sooner or later, they will find their way to a 10-story building here called Holyoke Center, which houses, among other things, Harvard Health Services.

Two city commissioners charged yesterday that the failure of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company to replace a defective cut-off valve had played a key role in the disastrous Queens gas main fire on Jan. 13.

MILAN, Italy, Jan. 26 (UPI) President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union arrived in Milan tonight apparently unruffled by a wave of terrorist attacks against Communist party offices here and elsewhere in Italy.
BLANTYRE, Malawi Malawi, a poor, landlocked nation deep in the African continent, is hoping to shake her economy out of its lethargy by moving the capital of the country.
The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, one of the leading department-store chains in the country, moved yesterday to strengthen its management team by naming a new ...
Charlette Cooke, a 19-yearold Texas Southern coed, had five all-comer records officially recognized yesterday by the Amateur Athletic Union.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 26 (UPI) The Australian America's Cup challenger Daine Pattie has had a new 92-foot mast fitted at a cost of 10,000 Australian dollars ($11,200), it was announced today.

NAIROBI, Kenya, With a hectic sort of boomtown vitality, Nairobi is asserting itself again as the commercial capital of an East African region that goes far beyond its borders and the Americans are in the thick of it.

Back in 1934 the Department of Parks, in a move to nurture pride and improve upkeep, established its Annual Award for Efficiency. It was to go each year to the borough whose park facilities were judged to be the best kept.

HONG KONG, Jan. 26 Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Huu Co, who seems about to join the long list of South Vietnamese generals in absentia, said today that he was awaiting orders from his fellow junta members in Saigon.
MOSCOW, Jan. 26 Sixty-one Chinese students, many bandaged after a clash in Red Square yesterday, left by train today on a six-day trip to Peking.

The credit markets expected the Bank of England to cut its bank rate yesterday, but they had no idea that a major New York bank would cut its prime rate. As a re sult, bond prices rose only modestly early in the day after the Bank of England ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Government has just published a report that pictures the State Department as dominated by a "social system" that makes its officers shy away from active policy debates and teaches them "not to make waves."
One survivor of yesterday's building collapse said he "heard a crack" and another recalled that he "felt the floor sliding" as the walls fell upon them.

BOWIE, Md., Jan. 26 (AP) Solar Bomb finished 1 lengths behind Stu Agogo today at Bowie Race Course, but was declared the winner of the $5,500 White Cockade Purse after the apparent winner was disqualified.
KHARTOUM, Sudan An agreement for a $3,325000 loan by the United States Agency for International Development for a modern durra processing plant was recently completed here.

Several persons prominent in the arts have sent a telegram to the Lincoln Center Repertory Company urging the appointment of Harold Clurman as artistic director. Mr. Clurman, drama critic of The Nation, was formerly executive consultant of the troupe.
LONDON, Jan. 26 Britain took a first cautious step today toward relaxing the economic squeeze adopted last July to rescue the pound.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 26 Eleven leaders of the Woodbridge teachers' strike were found guilty of contempt of court here today, but sentencing was postponed indefinitely by Superior Court Judge Leon Gerofsky.
The Board of Estimate overrode Mayor Lindsay yesterday and mapped its own court battle to compel the Transit Authority to accept a city subsidy of $84.3-million.

IN the rather conventional program that William Stein berg conducted with the New York Philharmonic last night in Philharmonic Hall, the nearest thing to a novelty was Leos Janacek's Sinfonietta. It was presented as an example of the season's program theme, "Symphonic Forms in the Twentieth Century."

Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller gave birth to a son before daybreak yesterday, less than an hour after her husband, the Governor, had persuaded a weary, homebound cab driver to ignore his "off duty" sign and rush them to a hospital.
Seven operas, four from the 20th century, will be presented by the Hamburg State Opera in its first United States visit, for the Lincoln Center Festival '67 in the summer.
A PROFESSIONAL fishing observer in Miami said yesterday, "why don't you escape that sweltering heat up there and come down here to fish in reasonable temperatures?"

Age, citizenship and residence are the only conditions Congress can legally consider in determining Representative Adam Clayton Powell's eligibility to resume his Congressional seat, the leaders of the American and New York Civil Liberties Unions declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, said today that William McC. Martin, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is a spokesman for the "big vested interests" and should be replaced as board chairman.

PEKING, Jan. 26 Demobilized soldiers have been employed to resist Chairman Mao Tse-tung's militant revolutionary line and are posing a delicate problem for troops and commanders of the People's Liberation Army. The army itself has been directed to give full support to the Maoist forces whenever asked.

OUAGADOUGOU, Upper Volta The military regime that took power in this landlocked republic a year ago is concentrating development efforts on modernizing and diversifying the country's traditional agricultural base.

Ghana, the world's largest cocoa producer, announced yesterday that its central purchasing agency had bought 8,512 tons of cocoa from growers in the latest week, compared with 11,226 last week and 18,259 the week before.
TAO YUAN, Taiwan Tsai Yi-ly, an enterprising young farmer, has decided he needs a power tiller to raise production on his 10 acres of land here. He plans to go to Africa to get it.

IF 57.7 per cent of the new pleasure boats sold in the United States are made of aluminum, how come aluminum accounted for only 12.8 per cent of the fleet in the recent National Boat Show? Salt water and Swiss cheese," ...
JERUSALEM (Israel) Jan. 28 Two weeks ago an 18-yearold Israeli was killed when he stepped on a land mine planted by Arab inflitrators on a soccer field of the border settlement of Dishon.

Since one or two parked cars can shut off a lane of traffic as effectively as a whole block of parkers, exceptions to the city's vigorous and vital new towaway drive must be relatively few and highly selective as for the handicapped, for emergency medical calls, etc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 A. Philip Randolph, international president of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters (A.F.L.-C.I.O.) called on the United States business community here tonight to sever its ties with South Africa.
LONDON British trade with Commonwealth nations in Africa prospered last year in spite of, and in some cases because of, tensions generated by the Rhodesian dispute.
LIBREVILLE, Gabon About 150 miles south of the major port town of Port Gentil lies an area of lagoons, grasslands and forests, almost uninhabited except for roaming herds of elephants and buffaloes.
The annual luncheon of the Gotham Chapter of Brandeis University's National Women's Committee will be held Tuesday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
LAGOS, Nigeria Nigeria's booming oil industry has passed through a year studded with many lucky breaks in the field of exploration as well as anxious moments as to its future stability.
PLEIDJERENG, South Vietnam, Jan. 25 The Fourth United States Infantry Division is bracing for another struggle with the North Vietnamese in the rugged country along the Cambodian border.
SPOKANE, Wash., Jan. 26 (AP) Dr. W. Glenn Terrell Jr., dean of faculties at the University of Illinois at its Chicago campus, was named today the seventh president of Washington State University.
Government bonds responded to the cut to 6 per cent in the British bank rate yesterday and moved ahead on the London Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Chairman Mao's decision to call on the active support of the army is regarded by United States analysts as a reluctant gamble that reflects desperation among the Maoist forces.

Israel and Syria had gone to the brink of war. Now they have paused and even may be in process of turning back. Their representatives met under United Nations auspices for the first time in eight years and they will meet again on Sunday.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 Governor Rockefeller sent a special message to the Legislature today asking for the strengthening of the Eelction Law.

The overriding questions raised by the report of the Carnegie Commission on Educational Television are these: What would the proposed Corporation for Public Television mean to the viewer and, more especially, how would it affect the choice of material that he might tune in?
One-fourth of the space in the 27-story office building at 111 John Street, in the financial district, has been leased by Parsons, Brinckerhoff, Quade Douglas, Inc., 82-year-old engineering company.

BONN, Jan. 26 Observers of Communist countries' affairs think that the Soviet Union may have declined to support East Germany's efforts to block the West German drive for establishing diplomatic ties in East Europe.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 26 (AP) An overpowering performance by Arthur Ashe of Richmond and easy triumphs in the women's division by Nancy Richey and Rosemary Casals today gave the United States three semi-finalists in the Australian national lawn tennis championships.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa There is little about South-West Africa that marks it as a controversial territory, now under United Nations surveillance because of charges of imposed apartheid.

A limit of 200 yachts was set last night for the Storm Trysail Club's biennial Block Island week at the organization's annual meeting in the New York Yacht Club. The number was considered the limit of the island's anchorage and shoreside facilities. The event will be held June 24 through July 1.
HONG KONG, Jan. 26-- Chairman Mao's "great proletarian cultural revolution" produced new violence and sharpened political struggle in Communist China today as the purge of his opponents continued.
ACCRA, Ghana The faces of most Ghanaians still light up with recollection of the joy and relief felt at the overthrow of the oppressive regime of Kwame Nkrumah here last Feb. 24.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa Through a year of world hostility and bitterness against south Africa, the republic has continued its economic surge, stimulated once again by the very pressures that are being brought to bear.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. For Somalians, 1966 was a year in which long-term economic prospects built up consistently, while most shortterm developments marked time.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) The House of Commons voted tonight 306 to 220 to renationalize Britain's steel industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 President Johnson and his Council of Economic Advisers tacitly abandoned today the Government's fixed standard of 3.2 per cent for noninflationary wage increases, approving settlements somewhat higher.

MINEOLA, Jan. 26 The Nassau County Commission on Human Rights condemned today the requirements for admission of new members into volunteer fire departments. It warned that the requirements were "creating racial tension."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The deficit in the United States international payments worsoned somewhat in the fourth quarter of last year, President Johnson's Economic Report to Congress disclosed today.

Seventeen alleged members of a stolen credit card ring whose victims included diplomats from Russia and Saudi Arabia were arrested and arraigned in the Bronx yesterday. Seven others were being sought.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Pigeonholed somewhere in the executive offices at the White House is a document that attests to United States concern with the advancement of African countries as a whole.
Ralph Boston, the world's best long jumper, said last night that he was under consideration as a punting specialist for the Kansas City Chiefs of the American Football League.

LONDON, Jan. 26 A businessman of dual French and British nationality was sentenced to four years in prison today for having fraudulently obtained a British passport for use by a former member of a Soviet trade delegation here.

Sandy Koufax, boy broadcaster and retired pitcher, appeared in New York yesterday for a busy social weekend. Carl Lindemann, vice president in charge of sports for the National Broadcasting Company, introduced his newest star employe to the press at a luncheon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Senate Republican leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen, complained today that he was being "lobbied" by both the State Department and the Soviet Embassy to support a proposed consular treaty with the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) The National Advisory Cancer Council has urged Dr. William H. Stewart, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, to increase his efforts to warn the public about what the council calls "the fatal consequences of cigarette smoking."
DETROIT, Jan. 26 (AP) United States automobile production picked up a bit this week as an estimated 170,192 cars were built. A rise of 3 per cent over last week's output of 164,792 cars.
Major league soccer drew a step nearer the United States yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Secret military discussion of bomb shortages in Vietnam and of Administration security policies has led to the summary relief of a senior Air Force officer as commandant of the service's top school the Air War College.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (UPI) An unidentified American purchased Anglo, the winner of last year's Grand National steeplechase, for $42,000 today.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 26 (UPI) Bob Howsam, who is leaving the St. Louis Cardinals to become general manager of the Cincinnati Reds, confirmed today that one of his last tasks as Cardinal general manager was to offer Roger Maris a $75,000 contract.
Prices seesawed again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. At the close gains nudged out losses.
PORT GIBSON, Miss., Jan. 26 Negroes will lift a 10-month boycott of white businesses here tomorrow after winning a list of concessions from the white leadership of the town.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Judge Oliver Herman Gasch has long been worried about the little man face-to face with big government. Several years ago, before ascending to the Federal bench, he expressed this concern in public in an essay about the plight of the government ...
Meyer Levy, a lawyer who served as a State Senator in 1923-24, died yesterday morning at the Park East Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 520 East 90th Street.
If Rudy LaRusso retires from competition in the National Basketball Association, it will be from the roster of the Detroit Pistons.
LONDON, Jan. 26 Following are excerpts from a letter from American Rhodes Scholars to President Johnson asking questions about Vietnam, made public here today:
ALBANY, Jan. 26 Governor Rockefeller announced today, a $7.2-million increase in payments to nursing homes throughout the state for the care of patients who are on welfare.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the week ended Jan. 21 registered a gain over the corresponding 1966 week. Intercity truck tonnage in the corresponding period declined slightly.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, the second-largest commercial bank in the nation, announced yesterday a reduction to 5 per cent from 6 per cent in its prime interest rate, or the rate that it charges business borrowers "of the highest credit standing."

A bronze plaque commemorating the fact that the late General Douglas A. MacArthur had lived in the Waldorf Towers from 1951, until his death in April, 1964, was unveiled be side the entrance to the Towers on 50th Street, just east of Park Avenue yesterday.
Bob Seagren and Dave Patrick, young collegians with almost limitless futures, took the major honors last night as indoor track returned to Madison Square Garden.
Bernhard Henninger, a trim looking dark-haired baritone with operatic experience in Europe, sang at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 26 The United States Steel Corporation was assessed an additional $244,000 in damages today as the result of its being found responsible for a fatal bridge collapse four years ago in Costa Rica.
Business and labor reacted with satisfaction yesterday to President Johnson's blurring of his 3.2 per cent guidelines on wage and price increases.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 26 (UPI) John Barnum and Marty Furgol posted two-under-par 70's today to take a one-shot lead in the opening round of the Professional Golf Association's national seniors championship.
HOUSTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) Nearly a week of the worst fog in years has cost Houston's shipping industry nearly $1-million.

Rafael Kubelik and the Boston Symphony Orchestra traveled to the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night. Their major work was a rare performance of Bohuslav Martinu's Double Concerto for Two String Orchestras, Piano and Timpani. It was bracketed by Haydn's Symphony in B flat (No. 102) and the Franck D minor.

The Dowager Countess of Gosford, widow of Britain's fifth Earl of Gosford, died Tuesday of a heart attack in the home of her daughter, Miss Beatrice L. Breese, in Tiburon, Calif. She was 75 years old and lived at 212 East 48th Street here. She had a summer home in South Shaftsbury, Vt.
DETROIT, Jan. 26 The General Motors Corporation recalled today 321 trucks from their owners for repairs to prevent possible steering trouble or tire failure.
Merger discussions involving the Amerada Petroleum Corporation and the Ashland Refining Company have reached an advanced stage and an official announcement is expected in the near future.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sonenblick of 923 Fifth Avenue of the engagement of Mrs. Sonenblick's daughter, Miss Amy Louise Osler, to Alexander Edward Sharp 2d, son of Dr. and Mrs. A.E. Sharp of San Antonio, Tex., formerly of Stamford, Conn.
KAMPALA, Uganda Realism and self-reliance are being applied as the stimulants for a revival of development by this East African country.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) President and Mrs. Johnson joined 30 Mayors today in a salute at the White House to the beautification of cities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) President Johnson announced today that he would nominate John L. Sweeney to be an Assistant Secretary of Transportation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 27 The number of American servicemen in South Vietnam reached the 400,000 mark last week, military authorities reported yesterday. The total was up 2,000 from the week before.
An unoccupied four-story apartment house collapsed in a shower of bricks and beams on 54th Street just east of Broadway yesterday, killing two demolition workers and entombing three others.

The American Tobacco Company announced yesterday that it was negotiating to acquire Royal Crown Cola Company in a $100-million transaction. American Tobacco is the nation's second largest cigarette manufacturer, ranking after the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company. It had sales of $1,231,628,000 in 1965.
ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast This thriving nation could be compared to a high-flying West African crane that has paused on a plateau before taking off for the mountaintop.

Rabbi Edward T. Sandrow, re-elected yesterday as president of the New York Board of Rabbis, proposed that a world conference of religious leaders of all faiths be convened to press for a peaceful solution to the Vietnam war.
TUNIS You are a tourist in a Tunisian hotel. You go to wash your hands and find the handles on the water taps are missing. You complain to the hotel. What are you told?

Two sharply divergent views of the 172-ship emergency fleet serving the Vietnam sealift were made public here yesterday one by the seamen who man the vessels and one by a United States official who said he "bristled" at persistent references to the "rust bucket" refugees from the national reserve fleets.

IT is a beautiful dream that Mayor Lindsay has in trying to bring the 1976 Olympic Games to New York, but it is only a dream with virtually no basis in reality.
