Perhaps it's churlish to sprinkle ice water on Hizoner's pet plan for Fun City even before that plan becomes vaguely outlined in the minds of befuddled experts. But facts are facts. As such they are inescapable.

President Johnson's Economic Report provides more than an outline of his policies and expectations for 1967. In a rather Messianic view of the future, he offers a bold and sweeping array of the prospects and the problems that face the nation once current uncertainties are resolved and peace is won.

NAIROBI, Kenya In the words of Prime Minister Jomo Kenyatta, 1966 was a challenging period of consolidation, in which the Government of Kenya attempted to create a climate of security, welfare and opportunity.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 26 (AP) Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that his department is not embarrassed because it does not understand everything that is going on in Red China now. Mao Tse-tung does not either, Mr. Rusk said.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky returned tonight from a 10-day visit to Australia and New Zealand and declined comment on the ouster of Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Huu Co, Deputy Premier and War and Defense Minister.
MADISON, Wis., Jan. 26 Gov. Warren P. Knowles proposed today Wisconsin's first billion-dollar budget but said the state would not have to raise taxes.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 26 If, as the saying goes, a messy dress rehearsal means a successful opening night, tomorrow's inaugural ball for Maryland's Gov. Spiro T. Agnew will be a smash.
NAIROBI, Kenya Massive international investment in East African tourism may well make it the biggest revenue-earner in Kenya and Tanzania in the next three or four years.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 26 (AP) Luther Lassiter has clinched the title in the Long Beach international pocket billiards championships, qualifying for the playoffs to determine the all-round winner.

LONDON, Jan. 26 Significant progress toward international agreement on a plan to create a new "reserve asset" for governments was reported tonight at the end of a threeday meeting of financial experts.
DURANGO, Colo., Jan. 26 (AP) Two Italian skiers set the pace today in the national 30-kilometer cross-country race at the Hesperus Ski Center, although neither was eligible for the championship.
BOSTON, Jan. 26 Cornelia Otis Skinner walked into suite 213 of the Vendome Hotel today and found herself transported back to 1880, when Sarah Bernhardt was a guest there.

KHARTOUM, Sudan A threat that hung over the Sudanese economy through most of 1966 that it would be smothered under thousands of bales of unsold cotton has been averted by a combination of good sense and good luck.
LISBON, Jan. 26 The Portuguese authorities uncovered today a ring dealing in donkey meat.
A hush fell over a small part of Broadway yesterday as thousands of persons gathered to watch the desperate efforts to rescue nine demolition workers trapped under 50 feet of rubble.
MIAMI, Jan. 26 (UPI) Crafty Look drew off in the stretch at Hialeah Park today to win the $5,000 feature race by two lengths.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) Six foreign airlines and Pan American World Airways were accused today of charging less than their published rates for cargo shipments between the United States and Europe for certain air freight cargo forwarders.
The Southern Pacific Company crossed the $100-million mark in earnings and the $1billion level in gross revenues in 1966.
KAMPALA, Uganda An area of Western Uganda that until recently was uninhabited and infested by tsetse flies is being transformed into prosperous ranching country.
DAKAR, Senegal With poor rains causing a shortage in crops, Senegal's economy struck a bad patch in 1966 and the outlook until at least well into 1967 was not too bright.
NAIROBI, Kenya Changes of emphasis in economic relationships between the countries of East and Central Africa in 1966 brought new hopes for the creation of a new and powerful black economic bloc.

Tug McGraw and two other young left-handed pitchers were added yesterday to the list of New York Mets signed for 1967, and McGraw promptly revealed that he would miss part of spring training because of military duty.
LAGOS, Nigeria Tribal and political strife buffeted Nigeria's economy last year, leaving it bruised but not critically damaged.

NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania The desert nomads of this flat, almost waterless and backward country are being slowly but firmly propelled into the 20th century by a planned series of ultramodern industrial projects.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Federal Trade Commission warned tire manufacturers today that any future mergers either between tire producers or between producers and their suppliers or major customers would be subject to investigation by the commission and probable prosecution.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 President Johnson has chosen Lucius D. Battle, the United States Ambassador to Cairo, as Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs.

A continued increase in the study of religion in secular universities could seriously influence American church life by creating a sophisticated laity who would "not be content" with traditional church teaching, a professor said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The United States is trying hard to persuade 19 sister nations in the Western Hemisphere toward a summit conference table without becoming the sole financial "angel" in the solution of their problems.

PARIS, Jan. 26 President de Gaulle has decided to make an official visit to Poland later this year to pursue his campaign for a d tente between Eastern and Western Europe, informed sources said today. No date has been set.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The United States has been telling other donor nations that future aid to famine-threatened India must be counted as part of the American contribution under the 11-member consortium headed by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

A possible new threat developed yesterday to the publication of "The Death of a President" when William Manchester, the author, reportedly indicated that he did not accept some changes in his manuscript that had been made to satisfy the Kennedy family.
SIRMIONE, Italy, Jan. 26 (AP) Ettore Bastianini, a leading operatic baritone, died last night at a clinic in this Lake Garda resort. He was 43 years old.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) The worst snow and ice storm in 18 years drove through the Midwest with 43-miles-an-hour winds today, virtually knocked out Chicago with one blow and then headed eastward.
LONDON, Jan. 26 Following is the list of signers of a letter on the Vietnam problem sent to President Johnson by Rhodes Scholars:
BOSTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) Suffolk Downs race track in East Boston owes $219,885 in unpaid property taxes for last year, according to the Boston collector, Treasurer Edmund W. Holmes.
LONDON, Jan. 26 Fifty American Rhodes Scholars sent President Johnson a letter today questioning United States policy in Vietnam.
KINSHASA, the Congo This capital of the Republic of the Congo seemed a prosperous city as its population looked back on a successful year from the economic view.

CAIRO Mysterious caravans of Army trucks moved through Cairo in dark of night last year. Unheralded, but under heavy guard, they bore onethird of Egypt's gold reserves from the Central Bank to the Cairo Airport. From there the precious cargo was flown to Switzerland and sold.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara told Congress today that the Soviet Union was strengthening its defenses because of "serious border problems" with Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Breaking a century and a half of tradition, Senators voted today to sacrifice, if necessary, their ink wells, quill-pen holders and blotting sand for hidden microphones that would amplify their voices in the Senate chamber.

An air-pollution alert was put into effect for the metropolitan area starting at 11 A.M. yesterday, touching off, for the second time in two months, a series of official moves to cut down fuel use and automobile-driving.
TOKYO, Jan. 26 (AP) Japan, the world champion, defeated Peru, 3-0, and the United States beat South Korea, 3-1, as the women's world volleyball championships opened today.

The Landau-Unger Company is editing "The Face of War," a 102-minute study of a Marine rifle squat at the Vietnamese front, as the first project in a program of documentary films for movie houses and television. Eugene S. Jones produced and directed the war documentary on location during 97 days in Vietnam. It will be shown first in theaters.
Lew Alcindor of the University of California, Los Angeles, has increased his lead in the major college scoring derby, taking advantage of the idleness of his rivals.
In a roller-coaster session, stock prices fell yesterday morning, recovered their losses in the early afternoon and then coasted to a mixed finish.
President Johnson's call in yesterday's economic message for Congressional support for a large-scale program of research in transportation was viewed as a project with two distinct purposes.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 26 The engagement of Miss Victoria Millicent Koo to Ronald K.H. Choy of Honolulu has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Anthony Y.C. Koo. Dr. Koo is professor of economics at the University of Michigan.
New officers were elected yesterday by the International Newspaper Advertising Executives at their 98th sales conference in the Sheraton Park Hotel, Washington.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26 (UPI) The president of the United States Steel Corporation said tonight exports of Americanmade steel have been on a downward trend for nine years, while foreign steel exports have shot up like "an Agena rocket heading into outer space."
Employes of Time, Inc., represented by the Newspaper Guild of New York authorized a strike last night unless the unit is able to negotiate a satisfactory contract.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) The Government proposed today new regulations to clarify the insurance coverage of deposits in commercial, mutual savings banks and savings and loan associations.

ATHENS, Jan. 26 An inquiry board on the loss of the 8,922-ton Greek car-ferry boat Heraklion says in its report that when the vessel sailed from Crete for Piraeus Dec. 7, she carried with her the makings of a disaster.

LONDON, Jan. 27 The center of Portuguese military activity in Angola has shifted from the northern hills bordering the Congo to the eastern plains near Zambia, according to a military communique today.

LISBON Rhodesia's defiance of Britain appears to have eased the nationalist threat to the neighboring Portuguese possessions of Angola and Mozambique. But it has also cost Portugal millions in revenues from her African investments.

Sperry Hutchinson, Inc. the largest company in the trading-stamp industry, was identified yesterday as the concern that has proposed to make a tender offer to acquire the majority stock of Bigelow-Sanford Inc., a leading manufacturer of carpets.
BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 26 It is a maxim of democratic politics that strong men eventually and almost inevitably inspire the opposition forces that bring them down.
MONROVIA, Liberia The main economic progress by this West African country last year was a start on the development of land resources.
KIGALI, Rwanda Modernization is moving steadily ahead in Rwanda, the small state of 1,000 hills in north central Africa.

The 17th annual Animal Kingdom Ball drew 400 persons to the Essex House last night. The event was entitled "Carnival 101," to mark the beginning of the 101st year of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, sponsor of the ball.

YONKERS, Jan. 26 Another pacer, the third in less than a week, died tonight at Yonkers Raceway. The latest standardbred to perish was Captain Defender, a 9-year-old bay gelding owned by Philip Sorgento of Freehold, N.J., and driven in the second race by Carmine Abbatiello.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 United States officials said today that "authorized contact" with the South Vietnamese National Liberation Front had been concerned only with matters involving Americans held prisoner by Communist forces.
FREETOWN, Sierra Leone West Africa's first diamond-cutting and polishing industry has been adding an extra sparkle to the rough diamonds that are this country's chief export.
The state's 103 Family Court judges urged yesterday that the court be merged with the State Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Communist China may be in a position to test an intercontinental ballistic missile this year, according to Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara.

A NOVELIST'S second book, the old saw goes, is never as good as his first. Like most old saws, this one is bent and rusty; it never was much use. Cecelia Holland's first novel, "The Firedrake," was an ambitious but enervating account of the Norman Conquest ambitious because she attempted to convey its events as they might ...

The Tanzania Committee of Community Development Foundation and the World Wildlife Fund will benefit from a dinner to be held in the Pierre's Grand Ballroom next Thursday in honor of Dr. Louis S.B. Leakey, the anthropologist.
John Diebold, Inc., an investment and management company, announced here yesterday the election of Ralph E. Weindling as president.
The United Church of Christ formed yesterday a panel of consultants to help bring about public school integration in Northern cities.

E.R. Squibb Sons was accused by the Government yesterday of prescribing the dosage of milk of magnesia for infants as "1 tablespoon, which may be added to the morning feeding." The correct dose is one teaspoon, the Government said.

ST. GERVAIS, France, Jan. 26 (UPI) Annie Famose put together runs of 47.42 and 44.08 seconds for an aggregate of 1 minute 31.25 seconds today to lead France to a clean sweep of the women's special slalom in the Emile Allais Cup ski races.
Corporate image-building is definitely in vogue.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia A huge question mark looms over Rhodesia, raised by the imposition by the United Nations of mandatory economic sanctions against the rebellious former British colony.
Two taxicab drivers were held up in the Bronx yesterday by lone gunmen who realized a total of $22. The police said neither of the drivers was injured.

MOSCOW, Friday, Jan. 27 (UPI) The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union signed a treaty this morning banning the use of space and the moon for military purposes. It was the first major East-West agreement in four years.
PLEITOUNBRENG, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 This is a village of Djerai tribesmen just this side of the Stone Age.

TUNIS This country's Lower Medjerda development project is expected to benefit at least a million acres, to push annual crop production to $75million and even to give birth to a new middle class of independent farmers by providing each with sufficient land to enable him to make a net of $500 a year.
Water supplies in New York City's upstate reservoirs showed an increase of 3.5 billion gallons during the 24hour period that ended at 8 A.M. yesterday.

The Yale School of Drama appears ready to jump into the professional theater with both feet. The Yale Corporation, essentially the university's board of trustees, is expected to discuss the feasibility of the school's taking over the Long Wharf Theater of New Haven.
TRIPOLI, Libya The old saying that "money isn't everything" is being proved here in a new context.

As the 5:41 New York Central train sped out of Grand Central Terminal last evening for Chappaqua, Bud Pomeranz looked forward to his first early night home in two months. L.S. Abernathy hoped for a good night's sleep. James Calvin had thoughts of steak, medium rare.
The consolidated net income of Texaco, Inc., last year was $692, 066,000, or $5.11 a share, J. Howard Rambin Jr., chairman, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) Exports from non-Communist countries to North Vietnam climbed during 1965 but in 1966 the number of Western ships calling at North Vietnamese ports dropped sharply, the State Department reported tonight.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 26 The Committee to Rescue Italian Art has made a grant of $60,000 to help restore the 15thcentury Pazzi Chapel designed by Brunelleschi and the adjoining cloister in the Church of Santa Croce in Florence.

LOS ANGELES, Jan 26 The chancellors of all the University of California's nine campuses formally took a position tonight in opposition to Gov. Ronald Reagan's proposal that a tuition system be instituted as a state economy measure.

THE PRESIDENT Sent economic message to Congress; saw President-elect of Brazil, Costa E. Silva; gave lunch in honor of Brazilian President and wife; saw Ernest McFarland, Arizona Supreme Court judge and furmer Senate majority leader.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 26 (AP) Donald Lee Bert, 18-year-old summer boot black and busboy, entered Harvard last fall worried about fitting in with the pol ished products of Ivy League prep schools.

MANY of the leading American experts will be com- peting fiercely in Las Vegas next week in a knockout team tournament. It is the Riviera Masters event and what is at stake is neither prestige nor master points but hard cash.

WASHINGTON Jan. 26 Officials of Washington's 13 major banks appealed today to President Johnson to assign agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to assist the city police in a sweeping campaign against crime.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 26 Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, publisher of La Prensa, the principal Opposition newspaper, was taken into custody today by forces of the National Guard. According to witnesses, the Guard had no warrant nor any explanation for its action.

The economy's momentum was described last night as at a low ebb, with little rise expected in the first nine months of 1967. In the final quarter, it was predicted, the economy will turn upward at a substantial rate.

More than 20,000 commuters were delayed up to four hours last night when an electrical fire broke out on a New York Central train on tracks over 108th Street and Park Avenue. All trains in and approaching Grand Central Terminal were halted.

STORRS, Conn., Jan. 26 Dr. Jaime Homero Arjona, head of the University of Connecticut's department of foreign languages from 1946 to 1964, collapsed and died while walking near his home last night. He was 60 years old.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 26 A "protocol of cooperation" between Negro advocates of black power in the United States and a Puerto Rican group agitating for independence against "Yankee colonialism" was signed at International Airport here tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 With good Wagnerian singers in short supply, the fact that two artists were appearing in their American debuts in the title roles made "Tristan und Isolde" in Philadelphia last night of more than normal interest.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania For a country that started 1966 with critical losses in exports and foreign aid, Tanzania has rallied impressively.
DETROIT, Jan. 26 Stockholders of the insolvent Pioneer Finance Company overwhelmingly approved today a takeover by the General Acceptance Corporation of Allentown, Pa.
LONDON, Ont., Jan. 26 (AP) George Mooney Gibson, the only Canadian to manage a major league baseball team, died here yesterday. He was 87 years old.
FREETOWN, Sierra Leone It is still comparatively easier to get diamonds out of the ground than rice in this tropical land.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Jan. 26 (UPI) Several hundred beatniks from different parts of the Western world who have been roaming Katmandu's streets for the last two months were rounded up and deported from Nepal during the last week, it was disclosed today.

With straight face, Ronald Reagan says no "politics or partisanship" entered into the dismissal of Dr. Clark Kerr as president of the University of California. Indeed, he says, the university "is not in the political ring at all" and "won't be sullied by partisan politics" while he is Governor.

PARIS, Friday, Jan. 27 (Reuters) Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin, France's only marshal, died of a heart attack today, at the age of 78. He had been admitted to the Val de Grace Military Hospital on Tuseday after a respiratory attack.

TANANARIVE, Malagasy Republic State farms, irrigation societies, cooperatives and commune associations were among measures taken by the Malagasy Republic last year in a new attempt to exploit this island's rich potential of natural resources.
Nearly 6,000 employes of the City Housing Authority began a strike last night that could leave 500,000 tenants without heat and hot water and with accumulated garbage.
Record earnings in 1966 were reported yesterday by two major steel producers, but a third steel maker disclosed its profits fell last year.
NASHVILLE, Jan. 26 A state grand jury was ordered today to be convened Feb. 6 for a two-day investigation of the fatal shooting of a Vanderbilt University graduate student by a policeman a week ago.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., called on the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to deny a petition by the Department of Justice to stay the merger of the two concerns.

ACCRA, Ghana The first Ghana International Trade Fair, to run from Feb. 1 to 19, will provide a major opportunity for Ghana to promote investment and exports and start to rebuild an economy badly weakened by the ousted Nkrumah regime.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia In this mountainous land, the surest way upward is by a wind ing path. It was by a similar course that Ethiopia's economy continued to advance last year.

The marriage of Miss Susan Elizabeth Colley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford C. Colley of Swampscott, Mass., to Creighton Churchill of New York and Clayton, N.Y., took place here yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed by Supreme Court Justice Abraham N. Geller in his chambers.
The emphasis of the City's midtown traffic program was switched yesterday from "no exception" towaways to mapping special parking aid for handicapped drivers and physicians.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Vietnam war will add more than $1-billion to the United States balance-ofpayments problem this fiscal year, Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said in Congressional testimony made public today.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 26 (AP) Heavily favored Buckpasser topped a field of 14 entered today in the $100,000 added Charles H. Strub Stakes and his trainer said the colt was likely to start in the feature Saturday at Santa Anita.

CONAKRY, Guinea The people are being called on by their Government this year to rediscover the virtues of cultivating their own gardens after a period of forced industrialization and diplomatic adventure since Guinea became independent of France in 1958.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa In Botswana, formerly the British protectorate of Bechuanaland, they call it "ipelegeng." Literally, it means "pick yourselves up" or "stand on your own feet."
DETROIT, Jan. 26 (UPI) Bobby Hull's second goal of the game with less than four minutes remaining gave the Chicago Black Hawks a 4-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight.
No one will overstep President Johnson's guidelines at Carnegie Hall on Feb. 15, when Maria Clodes, pianist, gives her New York debut recital. All tickets will cost 50 cents.
PARIS, Jan. 26 Marc Bohan, the designer at Chris tian Dior, showed an African collection this morning with lots of clothes in it for wouldbe White Hunters.
The Continental Can Com-, pany recorded the highest sales and earnings of its 62-year history in 1968, the preliminary report of Thomas C. Fogarty, chairman, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Administration forces fortified their control of the House Rules Committee today as the panel agreed to hold regular weekly meetings to assure timely action on Administration bills.

GEORGE BALANCHINE'S "Don Quixote" is the work in which Mr. Balanchine himself, as man and artist, probably stands most clearly revealed. The theme of a man single-heartedly pursuing a dream-ideal not only seems to ...
ALGIERS Political stability and an increase in Saharan oil production combined to offset a severe drought that threatened, to make 1966 a bleak year for the Algerian economy.
Foreign-exchange markets were caught short by the cut in the British bank rate. The spot rate on the British pound was pushed up in yesterday's trading by 13 points, to $2.7927.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The jury in the trial of Robert G. Baker went sightseeing today while Judge Oliver Gasch heard the suggestions of opposing counsel on the instructions they would like the court to give the jury.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Anholt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sherry Lou Anholt, to Alan David Shephard of London. He is the son of Richard David Shephard of Burwash, Sussex, England, and Mrs. Charles John Maples of Tunbridge Wells, Kent, England.

James E. Reardon, associate in Harry Gross's $20 million-ayear bookmaking combine in the nineteen-fifties, was named yesterday as the head of a multimillion-dollar-a-year bookmaking ring that employed women on welfare in Yonkers.
Dr. John Russell Randolph, a radiologist at 209 West 135th Street, died yesterday at University Hospital, 560 First Avenue. He was 66 years old and lived at 634 West 147th Street.
The trend toward easier money was intensifying even before yesterday's move to lower bank interest rates, figures released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated.
LONDON, Jan. 26 British and American dance took a step nearer tonight when Ballet Rambert danced Glen Tetley's "Pierrot Lunaire" for the first time at the Richmond Theater on the outskirts of London.
Advance orders for William Manchester's "The Death of a President," indicate it will probably become one of the great best-sellers in book publishing history.

Miss Lonnie Beth Prince, daughter of Mrs. Irving Prince of New York and the late Mr. Prince, was married last evening to Michael Ivan Selzer at the Regency Hotel. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Herman Selzer of Lahore, West Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Changes in the public assistance laws designed to give people on welfare an incentive to do whatever paid work they can were proposed by President Johnson today in his Economic Report.
State Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht refused yesterday to direct the State Harness Racing Commission to issue a license to William D. Gilmour.
LUSAKA, Zambia This twoyear-old Republic appears to be heading for a significant trade surplus despite the severe problems caused by the Rhodesian crisis.
A rebuttal to critics of the Warren Commission report on the assassination of President Kennedy will be presented by WNEW-TV from 8 to 10 P.M. on Sunday, Feb. 12.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 The pro golf tour moved from the hazards of the Pacific Ocean today and sub-par scores bloomed again. The Rancho Park Municipal Course became the urban setting for the opening round of the $100,000 Los Angeles open.
John T. Connor, who will step down Feb. 1 as Secretary of Commerce, has been elected president of the Allied Chemical Corporation.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 26 Mrs. E. Harris Harbison has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helen Mary Harbison, to Ervand Abrahamian of New York, son of Mrs. Vahan Abrahamian of Teheran, Iran, and London, and the late Mr. Abrahamian. Miss Harbison is the daughter also of the late Professor Harbison of the department of history of Princeton University.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company expressed general approval yesterday of the recommendations on the Carnegie Commission on Educational Television but voiced opposition to giving educational TV preferential relay rates at the expense of other users of communications facilities.

SOARING temperatures and sunny skies have predicta bly thrown Eastern skiers and area operators into a profound state of gloom. While balmy breezes and snowless sidewalks produce feelings of delight in most urban dwellers, the recent temperate weather means nothing but ...

A welcome monetary thaw is setting in at home and abroad. In New York, the Chase Manhattan Bank reduced the prime rate the cost of loans to the biggest and most creditworthy corporate clients from 6 per cent to 5 per cent, the first reduction since 1960. In London, the Bank of England lowered its lending rate from the crisis level of 7 per cent to 6 per cent.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 26 Dr. A. LeRoy Johnson, dean of the Harvard University School of Dental Medicine from 1942 to 1947, died today at the Hudson River State Hospital. His age was 85. Until recently he had lived with a daughter, Miss Jane Johnson, director of the vocational bureau at Vassar College.

TULSA, Okla., Jan. 26 Dr. and Mrs. Simon Pollack have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosalind Pollack, to Harry J. Petchesky, son of Mrs. Joseph Petchesky of New York and the late Mr. Petchesky.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 Sixth Army headquarters said today it was warning students in the Reserve Officers Training Corps that membership in some political organizations could jeopardize their chances of obtaining commissions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 Sixth Army headquarters said today it was warning students in the Reserve Officers Training Corps that membership in some political organizations could jeopardize their chances of obtaining commissions.
FELTON, Del., Jan. 27 (AP) A tornado struck this farming community of 1,000 today, slightly injuring seven persons, destroying a service station and damaging more than a dozen homes.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 27 Reinhard Kreutzer, a scared and confused 10-year-old boy from the Austrian town of Villach, sits in his hotel room here not knowing of the controversy in which he is involved.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP) Sam Sncad, sinking a 120-yard wedge shot on the eighth hole for an eagle 2, took the lead in the Professional Golfers' Association seniors teachers trophy tournament today with a threeunder-par 69 that brought his 36-hole total to 140.
Four major lumber associations reported an increase of four-tenths of 1 per cent in production for the week ended Jan. 21, compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan. 26 George Temple Bowdoin, philanthropist and retired banker, died today at the Huntington Hospital. He was 68 years old and was a resident of this community, Hobe Sound Fla., and Northeast Harbor, Me.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 27 The three-man crew of astronauts for the Apollo 1 mission were killed tonight in a flash fire aboard the huge spacecraft designed to take man to the moon.
OTTAWA, Jan. 27 (Canadian Press) The Bank of Canada will reduce its interest rate to 5 per cent from 5 per cent, effective Monday, signaling a general easing of credit.
WASHINGTON (AP) The Government says American workers are switching jobs fast- er than ever.
A Brooklyn man accused of disturbing passengers on a BMT subway train was shot and critically wounded last evening by a Transit Authority patrolman.
HOUSTON, Jan. 27 The flash fire that killed three astronauts in a spacecraft at Cape Kennedy tonight was filmed, an official of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) President Johnson, in a statement here tonight, expressed sorrow at the loss of three Apollo astronauts in an accident tonight at Cape Kennedy.
Woodward Lothrop, a department-store chain in Washington, D.C., and the Dayton Cbmpany of Minneapolis announced yesterday that they had terminated their merger talks by mutual agreement.

TOKYO, Jan. 27 (AP) Color television pictures, newspaper reports, telephone calls and press photographs flashed through the Pacific sky today as the United States and Japan began commercial satellite communications service, through Lani Bird 2.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Liberal Republicans backing Gov. George Romney for the Presidential nomination have decided to try to force Richard M. Nixon, his political associates and their plans into the open.

The Securities and Exchange Commission extended yesterday its trading ban on the stock of the Rand Development Corporation for a second 10-day period and postponed until Feb. 20 a hearing into the alleged failure of the Crescent Corporation to comply with disclosure and reporting requirements. The hearing had been scheduled to begin on Monday is Washington.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 27 After hiding for 24 hours, Dr. Fernando Aguero Rocha, the opposition presidential candidate who seeks to break the power of the Somoza family in Nicaragua, returned home today and said he would never accept the results of the coming election on Feb. 5.

WARSAW, Jan. 27 Rumania's readiness to establish diplomatic relations with west Germany and the likelihood that other East European countries will do the same are causing dismay and anxiety in Poland.

The heaviest recorded snowfall in New York City accumulated during a storm that began on Dec. 26, 1947, and continued into the next afternoon. In that blizzard 26.4 inches of snow were measured by the Weather Bureau.
Net income of Eastern Airlines, Inc., fell sharply last year and reflected the impact of the 43-day strike by airline machinists last July and August, the carrier announced yesterday.
A leading physicist reported yesterday an observation that, if true and correctly interpreted, would invalidate Albert Einstein's theory of relativity.
ROME, Jan. 27 Marzio Ciano, 29-year-old grandson of Mussolini, was arrested today as he sought to protest the visit to Italy by President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union.
PARIS, Jan. 27 Foreign Minister Adam Rapacki affirmed tonight Poland's resistance to the bid of West Germany for improved relations with Eastern Europe.
SPACE CENTER, Houston, Jan. 27 (AP) The families of the three Apollo astronauts killed at Cape Kennedy went into seclusion tonight, consoled by scores of colleagues in the Texas space community.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) Professional football is neither an art nor a science, but just a sport, the United States Tax Court ruled today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The big-city mayors have apparently decided to suspend their campaign for new "national priorities" in Federal spending and to concentrate instead on protecting existing programs from Congressional cutbacks.

Frank Robinson added one of the more coveted baseball awards to his burgeoning collection yesterday when he accepted the sixth annual Outstanding Achievement Award presented by the Phillips Van Heusen Shirt Company at the Americana Hotel.

PEKING, Jan. 27 (Agence France-Presse) Shanghai, the first "revolutionized" city in China, remains in the grip of considerable political and economic difficulties, which reflect what is happening in most provinces.
MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 27 (UPI) Eugen Dollmann, a former Nazi SS colonel, said today that Pope Plus XII would have intervened had he known beforehand of the 1944 Ardeatine Caves massacre near Rome.

BARTLESVILLE, Okla., Jan. 27 (UPI) The Phillips Petroleum Company said to- day that it would increase its wholesale price for gasoline Feb. 1 and would recommend that retailers raise their prices one cent a gallon.
Commuter trains ran almost on schedule at Grand Central Terminal yesterday, despite a derailed locomotive that blocked two of the four tracks serving the station.
VICTORIA, B.C. Whitehaired women and straight- backed older men sipped tea and broke crumpets at tables before the hearth in the grand foyer of the Empress Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 A New York policeman sees a car that arouses his suspicion. He notes the license number and sends a radio message to his dispatcher.

SWIRLS of color and oriental patterns are the two leading trends in patterned rugs for 1967. They are repeated through carpet collections that are now, or soon will be, in stores and wholesale showrooms.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 27 (AP) Tom Fears, the National Football League's most valuable player in 1950, was named today the first head coach of the New Orleans Saints, the newest National Football League team.

HOUSTON, Jan. 27 Following are excerpts from a transcript of a news conference held at the Manned Spacecraft Center here by Paul P. Haney, public affairs director of the center:

Alexander I. Rorke, a former assistant district attorney in New York County and a popular orator on patriotic topics for Tammany Hall, died yesterday at French Hospital, 324 West 30th Street. He was 90 years old and lived at 321 West 78th Street.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 (UPI) The Soviet Union granted Scandinavian Airlines permission today to make flights across Siberia to Japan.
Reform Democrats in the Legislature suggested yesterday wide changes in the election laws to minimize the possibility of partisan political adminstration of them.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (AP) Wilt Chamberlain, who took only four shots in the first three quarters, led a rally in the final 12 minutes that carried the Philadelphia 76ers to a 110-107 National Basketball Association victory tonight over the Cincinnati Royals.
Harper Row Publishers sent last night final corrected copy on William Manchester's "The Death of a President" to Haddon Craftsmen of Scranton, Pa., with orders to begin printing the book.
TOKYO, Jan, 27 (AP) Linda Murphy of Northridge, Calif., led the United States to its second straight victory with a four-game triumph over Peru today in the world women's volleyball championship.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 27 (UPI) The Southeastern Conference adopted today a freshman eligibility rule that was disapproved recently by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, and let the controversial "140" athletic scholarship rule stand.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The Church League of America has asked the State Department for assurances that Prime Minister Ian D. Smith, head of the breakaway Rhodesian Government, will receive "unconditional freedom to enter and leave" the United States to fulfill a speaking engagement at a League rally in Chicago in mid-March.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) The Senate Interior Committee approved today a bill to establish a National Water Commission to advise the President on water problems.
Mayor Lindsay dismissed Paul O'Dwyer yesterday as a special corporation counsel.
YONKERS, Jan. 27 (UPI) Lindsay Scott, an Australian horse, won the $7,500 Stamford Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 27 (AP) Joseph Cardinal Ritter said today he had named a layman and a lay brother to posts formerly held by Roman Catholic priests in the St. Louis archdiocese school system.

HORST ANTES, the German artist who won the UNESCO Prize in last summers Venice Biennale, is having his first New York one-man show at the Lefebre Gallery, 47 East 77th Street. Bright and vigorous, the paintings are more than anything else fantasies, not so much because their principal character is an odd personage ...
A SILVER exhibition at the New Haven Colony His torical Society should help disprove the popular misconception that Paul Revere was America's only pre-Revolutionary silversmith.
LONDON, Jan. 27-The Labor Government hopes to take over the steel industry by late summer or early autumn.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 27 Dr. Ulysses M. Frank, a physician for the Newark Health Department, died today at Newark City Hospital after suffering a heart attack at the Health Department clinic at Plane and William Streets. He was 70 years old and lived at 12 Undercliff Road, Millburn.

ROME, Jan. 27 Future participation of Roman Catholics in prayer services in unity of their church and other churches in Rome remeins an open question despite a favorable ruling by Pope Paul VI in a single case.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 For five hours and 20 minutes today in a crowded courtroom, the Justice Department's star prosecutor and one of the nation's leading criminal lawyers presented their final arguments in the case of the United States V. Robert G. Baker.
Business borrowing costs dropped yesterday as banks across the country reduced their prime interest rate to 5 per cent from 6 per cent.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan, 27 Carlton F. Diskin of 240 East Palisades Avenue, a vice president of Gottesman Company, Inc., and the Central National Corporation, pulp and paper marketing companies at 100 Park Avenue, New York, died today in Coral Gables, Fla., where he was vacationing. His age was 53.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Chapin Alsop of 1020 Park Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzette Alsop, to Peter Durant Coburn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph G. Coburn of Katonah, N.Y.
THE margin-account front is popping with activity on Wall Street. Interest costs are going down. A new insurance plan is coming up.
LONDON, Jan. 26 Dr. Alick Isaacs, one of the world's leading virologists, died yesterday at University College Hospital. He was 46 years old.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) The snowstorm that paralyzed Chicago today forced the postponement of a scheduled college basketball double-header tonight at the Stadium featuring top-ranked University of California, Los Angeles.

The tragic accident last night that resulted in the death of three of America's astronauts has shocked the nation. Lieut. Col. Virgil I. Grissom, Lieut. Comdr. Roger B. Chaffee and Lieut. Col. Edward H. White 2d are the first Americans to have lost their lives in a spacecraft, and their deaths will be mourned throughout this country and the world.
On July 21, 1961, Virgil I. Grissom, then a 35-year-old Air Force captain, became the third human being and the second American to enter space.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Arthur J. Goldberg, the Permanent United States Representative at the United Nations, told an audience of American Negro leaders today that some African delegates to the world organization were disregarding rules of procedure and the rights of others in their impatience to "redress wrongs."

Leon Kirchner, one of our ablest composers, has not produced works with great frequency, but the quality of his work has been so high that he has sometimes seemed incapable of miscalculation. At Town Hall last night, the Beaux-Arts String Quartet demonstrated that Mr. Kirchner is as human as the rest of us.

PANAMA, Jan, 27 In a session that lasted into the early hours today, the National Assembly approved in second reading a measure extending Panama's territorial waters 200 miles into the Atlantic and Pacific.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Jan. 27 The staff of the Gaylord Hospital and Rehabilitation Center gave a farewell party today for a young African patient who is going home with the congratulations of the whole town.
Mrs. Tessie Dryfoos Herman, widow of Sidney W. Herman, a banker, died Thursday in her apartment in Delmonico's Hotel, 502 Park Avenue. Her age was 81.
In a demonstration of the ecumenical spirit, a Protestant minister and a Roman Catholic priest participated last night in the installation of a new spiritual leader for a Jewish congregation.

Ira Parnes of 2040 Bronxdale Avenue, the Bronx, who retired in 1959 as metropolitan sales manager of Refined Syrups and Sugars, Inc., of Yonkers, a Corn Products Company subsidiary died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 72 year old.
Nearly all of the 500,000 residents in public housing developments here were left without heat or hot water yesterday by a strike of 6,000 employes of the City Housing Authority.
The blizzard that crippled the Middle West yesterday snowed under the major Chicago commodity exchanges, too.
The city has settled for $350000 its $916,700 claim arising out of two parking-meter purchase contracts signed in 1961 and 1962, the Corporation Counsel's office announced yesterday.
Net earnings of the Union Oil Company of California last year rose 19 per cent to a record $142.3-million from $119.2million in 1965, Fred L. Hartley, president, reported yesterday.

The Metropolitan Opera will present Verdi's "Otello" for the first time this season Feb. 27, Ermanno Lorenzi will make his Met debut as Cassio. The first "Madama Butterfly" of the season will be March 3.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Jan. 27 Judge Harry H. Umberger, who served on New Jersey's Compensation Court for 35 years, died last night at his home at 136 Berkeley Avenue in Bloomfield. His age was 73.
The Brooklyn Academy of Music announced yesterday that it had named Mrs. Robert P. McQueen and Donald F. Benjamin to its governing committee. Both live in Brooklyn.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP) Walter T. Varney, founder of Varney Air Lines, a predecessor of United Air Lines, died Wednesday. He was 79 years old.

Harper Row, the publishers, marked 150 years in the book business with a formal reception at the Museum of the City of New York on Thursday night, and champagne flowed as the gathering of authors, editors and journalists were given a view of life in the New York of 1817.
LONDON, Jan. 27 The Government of Malta denounced today the defense agreement under which Britain stations troops, ships and aircraft on the strategic Mediterranean island.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 27 The engagement of Miss Susan Gail Kobren to Dr. Murray A. Morrison has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Kobren, parents of the bride-to-be. Dr. Morrison is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin G. Morrison of Northampton, Mass.

HONG KONG, Jan. 27 Disunity and confusion in the Chinese Army seemed apparent to some political analysts here today in the wake of an order to the army to stamp out resistance to Mao Tse-tung's political purge.
MEGEVE, France, Jan. 27 (AP) Jean-Claude Killy of France, the world champion, scored another major victory today when he won the Grand Prix of Megeve downhill ski race by two full seconds.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 A city accustomed to snowstorms succumbed to one today.

AMHERST, Mass., Jan. 27 For the first time in 35 years Amherst College's squash racquets team defeated a Princeton University squad today. The Little Three school turned back the Big Three team, 5-4, the final match deciding the competition.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 A Presidential study group has recommended that the Bureau of Indian Affairs be transferred from the Department of the Interior to the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
The lack of a single strong voice on housing matters has cost New York City hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal urban renewal aid, Edward J. Logue declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Scientists will launch 18 rockets from northern Canada and northern Alaska to altitudes up to 124 miles during a 14-hour period starting Monday evening.
ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 27 A State Supreme Court Justice said today that a Cornell University student magazine contained "much that is vile and evil" but that its sale could not be forbidden.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) A consumer conference called today for the retirement of William McChesney Martin as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 27 Prime Minister Ian D. Smith announced today that "an impartial, independent commission" would be set up to study the question of a new constitution.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 27 William Aldrich Greene, a vice president of Infoplan, an international public-relations company, died today in the Greenwich Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived on Dewart Road.

Ring Magazine, for the first time since 1933, has refused to designate a fighter of the year. It pointed out that "most emphatically is Cassius Clay of Louisville, Ky., not to be held up as an example to the youngsters of the United States."
MONTREAL, Jan. 27 (Canadian Press) Dosco Steel, Ltd., has increased the price of certain rolling mill products by an average of $5 a ton, the company announced today.
The Rev. James Bevel, a close associate of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., has been named national director of a new organization protesting the war in Vietnam.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 27 (UPI) The Coast Guard said today that no lifeboats were launched when the ore carrier Daniel J. Morrell broke up and sank in Lake Huron last November with the loss of 28 lives.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 President Johnson presided today over a White House ceremony at which the United States, the Soviet Union and 60 other countries signed a treaty to limit military activities in outer space.
After most major banks lowered their prime rate yesterday, most bond prices continued to advance, although the rise was not as pronounced as on Thursday.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 27 The Campus Crusade for Christ, addressed by The Rev. Billy Graham, the evangelist, today hailed its drive for Christian converts at the turbulent University of California as an exciting success.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 27 Syria demanded today that Israel be evicted from the demilitarized zones along their border.
The Board of Education will issue report cards in Spanish to Spanish-speaking parents of pupils next fall.
The program schedules of the national television networks were interrupted last night for bulletins and then special reports on the deaths of the three astronauts in a flash fire at Cape Kennedy.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 27 (AP) A United States freighter and a Liberian ore carrier collided about dawn today during heavy fog in Chesapeake Bay, 60 miles north of here.
A board of inquiry was appointed yesterday to investigate the collapse of a fourstory apartment house that trapped and killed five demolition workers here Thursday.
RYE, N.Y., Jan. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Gene Reichert have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jill Derryl Reichert, to Damon Lawrence Kroh, son of Dr. and Mrs. Damon K. Kroh of Panama.
PORT GIBSON, Miss., Jan. 27 (UPI) Civil rights forces claimed victory in a 10-month boycott of this small south Mississippi town today, but Mayor Edwin D. Davis said that nothing had really changed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 A conversation machine,in vented in a converted mansion at Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., can answer questions over the telephone.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) The Job Corps is going to let some of its young enrollees live at home during training.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 27 Secretary General Thant sent a message of condolences to President Johnson tonight on the death of the three American astronauts.

LONDON, Jan. 26 Champions of the "Desert Rats," the men of the British Eighth Army who fought Rommel's Afrikakorps in the Western Desert, won a battle today against a television series of American origin called "The Rat Patrol."
Court of Appeals Judge Charles D. Breitel said yesterday that the forthcoming Constitutional Convention should not write a "short, snappy, literary constitution."
There was an air of tension at the start of rehearsals yesterday for "The Hemingway Hero," a play by A.E. Hotchner at the New Amsterdam Roof, atop a seven-story building at 214 West 42d Street.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 17 Kuwait, one of smallest but richest Arab states, has voted for conservatism by electing a a new Parliament in which a large majority of the members are loyal supporters of the royal family.

Miss Barbara Claire Dunbar, daughter of Dr. and Mrs Charles Dunbar of Pittsburgh, was married here yesterday afternoon to William Goldfarb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Goldfarb of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by Judge Louis B. Heller of the Kings County Branch of the Civil Court in his chambers in Brooklyn.
LONDON, Jan. 27 The Earl of Kilmuir, one of Britain's leading legal experts, died today at his country cottage at Withyham, Sussex. He was 66 years old.
TOKYO, Jan, 27--Premier Eisaku Sato will submit his conservative, pro-Western policies to the Japanese electorate Sunday for the first time since he took office in November, 1964.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 27 (AP) President Liu Shaochi was present when his wife was seized by Red Guards at a hospital Jan. 6 and forced to confess her "errors," Tanyug reported today.
A federal judge, acting on a higher court's ruling, ordered the Directors Guild of America yesterday to drop a non-Communist oath from its constitution and membership applications.
SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 27 (AP) Five persons aboard an Army helicopter were killed today when it crashed after take-off at Dugway Proving Grounds, 70 miles southwest of here.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 27 (AP) Ten Egyptian Ilyushin jet bombers raided the town of Najran, Saudi Arabia, near the Yemen border, this morning, killing four people and injuring three, a Saudi Defense Ministry communique said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The United States, in an attempt to mend frayed relations with Yugoslavia, has quietly informed the Belgrade Government that the Yugoslavs may purchase nearly $10-million worth of edible oils under they Food-for-Peace Program.
HONG KONG, Jan. 27 Peking said today that the Soviet leadership was in the same category as the last Czar, Hitler and the Ku Klux Klan.
BONN, Jan. 27 The West German Government has empowered Foreign Minister Willy Brandt to establish diplomatic relations with Rumania, it was announced today.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (UPI) Ten years ago Miss Rita Boyd was unable to speak, had difficulty walking and her left hand was useless. She was a victim of cerebral palsy.
Robert Lothar Kendell said yesterday that if Congress had mice it needed a cat.

Otto Preminger, the film producer and director who lives here but shoots elsewhere, has told Mayor Lindsay that he will make his next film within the jurisdiction of New York's production unions, if the unions approve the wage contract experiment proposed last week by the Mayor.
PARIS, Jan. 27 (Reuters) France is preparing a state funeral for Marshal AlphonsePierre Juin, her only marshal, who died of a heart attack during the night at the age of 78.

TOKYO, Jan. 28 More than 100 people have been killed and scores wounded in an outbreak of armed opposition to Chairman Mao in Sinkiang Province, according to wall posters quoted by Japanese reports from Peking.

Gerald Driscoll and Gene Trepte, San Diego yachtsmen who were key figures in the rejuvenation program of the 12Meter yacht Columbia for next summer's America's Cup dense campaign, resigned on Thursday because of a dispute over management with the owner, Pat Dougan of Corona del Mar, Calif.
The stock market rebounded yesterday, with gains ranging up to 4 points. The best advances were made by the steel, motor and electronics issues.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 (AP) United States marines pressed ahead today with a new drive in the Kylam River valley 15 miles below Danang. It had accounted for 74 enemy dead in brisk fighting with a Vietcong battalion through its opening hours yesterday.

PORT HUENEME, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP) After seven restless years on the beach, 80year-old Leon W. Blachutta has returned to the sea as third mate of the freighter Albion Victory a 6,000-ton World War II Victory ship.

THE steady expansion in the number of bridge players is matched by a steady expansion in the number of bridge clubs. The first new bridge club of 1967 in the metropolitan area is the Sleepy Hollow at the Hilton Inn, Tarrytown, N.Y., which holds its first regular evening game at 9 P.M. tonight.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 27 (AP) Nancy Richey of San Angelo, Tex., defeated Kerry Melville of Australia, 6-4, 6-1, today and qualified to meet Australia's top-seeded player, Lesley Turner, for the women's singles title in the Australian lawn tennis championships.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 (Reuters) Some South Vietnamese peasants who refused to leave their homes may have been killed when villages in the Iron Triangle were razed, a United States official said today.

ALAMOGORDO, N.M., Jan 27 (AP) The reader of a religious sect was sentenced today to six months in jail and fined $100 on common law charges resulting from failure to bury the body of a woman he said he would return to life. She was dead a month.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (AP) Dr. Raymond A. Dart, anthropologist of Johannesburg, South Africa, has accepted a post with the Institute for the Achievement of the Human Potential here, it was announced today.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 27 Princeton scored five times in the opening period and coasted to a 7-0 victory over the University of Pennsylvania in a hockey game at Baker Rink tonight.
MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 27 Dr. Berton F. Sweeney, who practiced dentistry in Essex County for 48 years, died yesterday at Orange Memorial Hospital on his 80th birthday. He lived at 56 Yale Street here.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 (UPI) Rudy LaRusso, the suspended Los Angeles Lakers forward, said today his attorney would file suit against the National Basketball Association for its action in affirming his trade to the Detroit Pistons.
A partial break-up of the Caltex group of companies was announced yesterday by Texaco, Inc., and the Standard Oil Company of California, joint owners of the California Texas Oil Company, Ltd.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The telephone rang last night in a home in Little Falls, N.J. The caller was Representative Charles S. Joelson and he wanted to tell Mrs. Floyd W. Waucheck that Army physicians at Walter Reed Hospital had decided not to amputate her 20year-old son's right leg.
This is a short story about how the Legislature of New York conducts its affairs. It is not the kind of story found in civics textbooks for children learning about state government.
LONDON, Jan. 27 Queen Elizabeth II honored two intrepid Britons today, one posthumously.

ROME, Jan. 27 The resignations of about 40 Roman Catholic bishops around the world, including 17 in Italy and 10 in the United States, have been accepted since Oct. 11, when Pope Paul called for the retirement of prelates more than 75 years old.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 Don Massengale, who has been out of the money in two tournaments so far this year, hit his golfing stride today with a 65. The six-under-par round at the Rancho Park Municipal Course was not the day's best, but it put the 195-pound Texan into the 36-hole lead by two strokes with an aggregate of 132.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The second proposed design for a memorial here to Franklin D. Roosevelt was rejected today by the Fine Arts Commission. The decision against the design by Marcel Breuer and Herbert Beckhard was unanimous.
BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Richard Cardinal Cushing was joined by three Roman Catholic priests and a layman today in his defense of North American motives for aiding church missions in Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 27 (AP) Although the Soviet Union has not put any of its astronauts into space recently, it still plans to beat the United States in landing a man on the moon, a Senate committee said today.
British Government bonds were again in demand yesterday in an otherwise featureless session on the London Stock Exchange.
Two of the astronauts killed yesterday were matterof-fact recently when asked about the possibility of an Apollo mishap.
GENEVA, Jan. 27-The United States and the European Economic Community, or Common Market, are standing eyeball to eyeball in a confrontation over tariff reduction offers in the Kennedy round.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia rescinded today a bus fare increase here that had been approved two weeks ago over the protest of civil rights groups.

BOSTON, Jan. 27 Something old, something new, something borrowed, something blue, the time-honored bridal prescription, by chance characterized the program given by the Boston Ballet tonight at the opening of its third season at the Back Bay Theater here.

The Medicaid program in this city is reaching only a tiny percentage of those for whom it is designed. The slow rate of enrollment has given rise to worries exactly opposite to those expressed by many critics when the enabling legislation was rushed through the State Legislature last year as a companion to Title XIX of the Federal Social Security Act.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The head of the nation's largest trucking company said today that it might be less costly to take a strike than to meet the "shocking" contract demands of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
MOSCOW, Jan. 27 Pravda directed withering criticism today at literary journals of both the liberal and conservative wings of Soviet literature.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (UPI) Roving bands of marauding youths prowled snowbound Chicago's West Side tonight, looting and pillaging almost at will.

LONDON For the third time in six months, a cut-price insurance company has failed, sending tens of thousands of Britain's 9.5 million car owners scurrying elsewhere for new protection, at additional cost.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 The military junta confirmed the ouster of Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Huu Co. today and named Lieut. Gen. Cao Van Vien to replace him as Defense Minister. General Vien retains his post as Chief of the Joint General Staff.

SPACE CENTER, Houston, Jan. 27 (AP) The tragedy at Cape Kennedy tonight that killed the men scheduled to make America's first Apollo flight propelled a backup crew of one space veteran and two rookies into the spotlight.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 27 Dr. John Sturdivant Read, a retired Brooklyn urologist who was president of the Kings County Medical Society in 1935, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital here after a short illness.

The National Maritime Union truck a passenger liner and half a dozen freighters last night in scattered ports along the Atlantic Coast, apparently in a demonstration of strength during wage negotiations.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 27 (AP) The trial of a $2.5-million negligence suit against United States Stell International resulting from the collapse of a bridge in Costa Rica in 1962 ended in Superior court today with the jury voting 10 more awards to heirs of the 12 victims of the disaster.
Gordie Howe of the Detroit Red Wings was named yesterday the second winner of the Lester Patrick Trophy for outstanding contribution to hockey in the United States.

Another specialty car was announced yesterday, this one by the Pontiac Motor Division of the General Motors Corporation. Called the Firebird, it brought to seven the number of specialty cars offered by American car manufacturers.
Nino Benvenuti, freed of a commitment to defend his European middleweight title, signed yesterday to fight Emile Griffith, the world champion, at Madison Square Garden in late March.

Cocaine and heroin valued at $1,870,000 were seized yesterday after a post-midnight chase that twice encircled the Bronx County Courthouse.

Marc Cassuto's phone rang just after he got home from work one evening last week. The caller wanted to know how he could get an apartment just like the one he was visiting at 11 East 87th Street. The time was 6:10 P.M.

Last week, as in so many weeks in Vietnam, American patrols slipped through the jungles, the paddies and the mountains, seeking but in general not finding, the enemy. Neither the Vietcong nor the North Vietnamese are believed by intelligence sources to be willing to risk major engagements that will inevitably expose their forces to the murderous firepower of American artillery and aircraft.
The general reduction in bank rates cast a shadow late last week over what had been one of the brightest spots of the nascent 1967 bull market.
The pieces of a long-standing oil industry puzzle began to fall into place last week. But there were signs that the picture was still far from complete.

The Faculty Woodwind Quartet from the Crane Department of Music of the State University College at Potsdam brought a bright program to Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon. The repertory was basically light in content and texture with few really serious moments. Such is usually the case with woodwind literature. But if trifles were the main course, they were quite acceptable musically.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Americans love to be classified. They talk a good game about individualism, but they practice groupism with a passion that makes American life a trial to the occasional wayfarer who still hates badges and uniforms.
A sealed combustion furnace that draws air for burning from outside instead of inside the house has been placed on the market.
LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) A delegation from the House of Commons flew to Malta for urgent talks today only hours after Britain had been ordered to quit the Mediterranean island.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 28 "Is the Roman Republic on the Way Out?" asks the sober-sided headline over a picture of Julius Caesar, gloomy in plaster.

The automobile insurance industry was a leader in the drive against highway accidents long before traffic safety was widely recognized as a major problem, Guy E. Mann, chairman of the American Insurance Association, said last week.

HE should have been convinced the day he set the record. But he wasn't. It took a dinky little home run off his best curve ball a year later to bring the message to Lefty O'Doul. That's when he decided that he had no future as a pitcher. When he walked off the mound, he went directly to his manager, Duffy Lewis.

THE Italian Postal Ministry is expected to destroy a huge stamp stock valued at hun dreds of thousands of dollars. These are the remainders of issues dating from the 19th and early 20th centuries issues now selling at high prices.

THE exhibition of paintings by the late Hans Hofmann, currently on view at the Andr Em merich Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, is the first posthumous view of the artist's work we have been offered since his death nearly a year ago.

The growing popularity of houseboats will be strikingly reflected by the queen of the fleet at the 13th annual Chesapeake Bay Boat Show, which opens next Saturday.
HARTFORD, Jan. 28 Connecticut's Republican leaders wearily broke up a meeting on unity early this morning as divided as ever.
MANHASSET, L.I., Jan. 28 Miss Marcia Elizabeth Haines and Daniel J. Slattery Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Slattery of Washington, plan to be married in June.

WOLFSBURG, Germany, Jan. 12--Although this city was built from scratch to house employes of the mammoth Volkswagen factory, residents insist that neither city nor workers owe their souls to the company.

President Johnson laid out in two large documents totaling almost 1,000 pages the budget and the Economic Report before Congress and the public last week his economic policy for the year ahead. He found the economy in pretty good shape, with the worst of inflationary pressure behind us, and he projected "healthy forward motion" for 1967.

TORONTO. MARSHALL McLUHAN, one of the most acclaimed, most controversial and certainly most talked-about of contemporary intellectuals, displays little of the stuff of which prophets are made. Tall, thin, middle-aged and graying, he has a face of such meager individual character that it is difficult to remember exactly what he looks like; different photographs of him rarely seem to capture the same man.

DESPITE the similarity of language, origin and religion, Bolivia is more different from Chile than Sweden is from Italy. Paraguay is more different from Venezuela than France from Greece. It is one of the many merits of "Inside South America" that John Gunther realizes this fact full well and approaches his difficult and complex subject on a country-by-country basis.

ONE of the interesting re cent developments in Spanish American literature has been a burgeoning of fantastic, imaginative prose a fact all the more striking because Spanish American literature has always, almost by definition, been regarded as realistic. The great change is most prominently observed today in Argentina birthplace of the widely known Jorge Luis Borges, of Adolfo Bloy Casares, Julio Cortazar, Marco Denevi, and half-a-dozen other superb fiction writers.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 28 Providence College defeated Seton Hall University, 91-87, in overtime before an overflow crowd of 3,300 at Alumni Hall today. The basketball game was televised regionally.

SOMETHING deja vu is evoked by John Peter's fine novel about Canada, TAKE HANDS AT WINTER (Doubleday, $4.95): the provincialism of the American 1920's, as anatomized by Sinclair Lewis. Like the author of "Main Street," Mr. Peter is both critical of and sympathetic to a cast of characters who function in a nostalgic climate where puritanism lingers on, tycoons are prehistorically ruthless, and adultery is more than a Happening.

The marriage of Miss Rosemary Alexandra Karran McGowan to Anthony Francis Phillips took place in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour here yesterday afternoon. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. William O'Neill, was followed by a reception at the Union League Club.

THE handsome evergreen Cryptomeria is so unlike other evergreens, it is not likely to be forgotten once seen. Yet, since the tree's introduction to this country from Japan more than 100 years ago, it is still somewhat a rarity.

Three men will receive awards as "Great Contemporary Americans" on March 18 at the second annual awards dinner sponsored by Marist College, Poughkeepsie, at the Commodore Hotel. A commemorative bust of each recipient will be installed at the College.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 28 A cartoon circulating here this week shows a man with a black briefcase and bowler hat waiting outside a circus manager's office. "That's the substitute for the tightrope walker," a receptionist is explaining to the manager. "He has never worked in a circus, but for the last three years he was an opposition politician in Brazil."
The National Association of Daytime Dress Manufacturers has asked the Federal Trade Commission to decide whether apparel made of paper fabrics violates the Flammable Fabrics Act.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Jan. 28 (Canadian Press) A 10 per cent surcharge on freight rates between European ports and Vancouver is expected to be imposed almost immediately, a waterfront executive said yesterday.

OUT of the depths occasionally emerges a voice not completely strangled by despair, a voice that can pitch itself both above and below a sustained, wordless scream. In this century such voices, though not common, have been heard: Gorki, Wright, Dahlberg, Genet. Now, at least in terms of expressing the inexpressible, of giving dramatic shape to a writhing mass of underground raw material, Shane Stevens swells the furious chorus.
Columbia University announced yesterday that Hugh J. Kelly, a publishing executive, had been appointed to a key administrative post in the school's capital funds drive.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 28 A seven-man board of inquiry began today to investigate how and why the nation's first three Apollo astronauts met death while testing their spacecraft on the launching pad.

CHACO CANYON, N.M. Remodeling houses is a 1,000-year-old tradition at Chaco Canyon National Monument. Back in the 10th century, Pueblo Indians living in Chaco created enduring architecture, often because they simply enjoyed changing things a bit. And now it is the National Park Service that is making the changes changes that will enlarge the present 13-site campground to one with accommodations for 50 camping families.

Business in the Fifth Federal Reserve District continued to expand for the sixth consecutive year in 1966, with the year generally marked by high and rising employment in all major industries and of continued growth in manufacturing.

The Left Bank, formerly one of the most populer discotheques on Long Island, has gone out of business. But its former operator, Peter Petersen, is fighting a license revocation proceeding, which he says has cast an unjustified blot on his reputation.

SAN DIEGO, Calif. Not too many years ago, San Diego was known chiefly for its Naval installa tions and its balmy climate. The Navy and the sunshine are still here, but a visitor of 20 years ago would find it difficult to recognize this city, which is now the 15th largest in the United States.

TOKYO, Jan. 28 (AP) Japan's defending champions ran into a surprisingly strong United States team today, but defeated the Americans, 15-12, 15-0, 15-8 and won the fifth world women's volleyball championship.

Pennsylvania's commercial banks, now restricted on where they may open new branches, would be permitted to branch through mergers on a statewide basis under tentative recommendations of the Pennsylvania Banking Law Commission that were announced yesterday.

The "world's largest newsprint machine," being built at the Catawba, S.C., mill of the Bowaters Southern Paper Corporation will produce nearly as much newsprint as two machines of the type built a dozen years ago. This is reported in a 1966 review and look ahead by V.J. Sutton, president of the Bowaters U.S. Corporation, Calhoun.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 It was a perfect day for golf, especially if you were a member of Arnie's Army. With a huge gallery trailing him, Arnold Palmer moved to the front in the Los Angeles open today with a fourstroke lead on a 54-hole total of 201.
Aluminum companies set their sixth record in succession for production of primary metal last year, the Aluminum Association reports.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 Princeton owed its continued basketball success tonight to a 9 -minute segment of the first half, during which the Tigers outscored Penn, 18-3. The 15point margin enabled Princeton to go on to a 70-66 victory over the Quakers at the Palestra before a sellout crowd of 9,200.

President Johnson's economic objectives, as outlined in his new budget and his economic report, are audacious and far-reaching. MIAMI, Jan. 28 Mrs. Magruder Dent's Point du Jour scored a victory in the Palm Beach Handicap for the second year in a row today, winning by 3 lengths in the first division of the 1 1/16-mile turf race. Hobeau Farm's Third Martini led all the way in winning the second division by a neck.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Jan. 28 Miss Susanne Gates Johnson of Washington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Saltonstall Johnson of Fairfield, was married today to Charles Kellogg Mann of Arlington, Va. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Nelson Mann of Derby, N.Y.
TORONTO, Jan. 28 Canadian stock brokers are grumbling about the continuing heavy outflow of Canadian investment dollars into United States securities.

The report that observations of the sun had brought into question Albert Einstein's general theory of relativity has awakened intense interest in experiments that might verify the challenge. Several such tests are in preparation.
