TARANTO, Italy, Jan. 28 President Nikolai V. Podgorny continued today to develop for Italians his picture of a Europe that would arrange its affairs without United States participation and without a German "menace."
DURANGO, Colo., Jan. 28 (AP) Mike Gallagher of Killington, Vt., retained his national cross-country ski championship today with a victory in the 15-kilometer race at the Hesperus Ski Center.
An increasing shortage of physicists is threatening the nation's scientific progress, the American Institute of Physics warned yesterday.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 28 Eight teen-agers, all from the same private school, were arrested is a narcotics raid on a 10-room home in Roslyn Heights, L.I., last night.

MADRID, Jan. 28 Liberal leaders of the influential lay organization Catholic Action in Spain are pressing for the support of progressive-minded bishops in a forthcoming showdown over the lay leaders' future.

BERKELEY, Calif. Jan. 28 The balance of political power in California has now moved sharply to the right. The moderate establishment of Earl Warren's days is in disarray, and has been replaced by a conservative coalition under Governor Reagan. Dr. Clark Kerr believes this was the decisive factor in his dismissal as president of the University of California.

The dispute between the Syrian Government and the Iraq Petroleum Company over transit fees for a pipeline transporting oil from neighboring Iraq highlights the difficulty that is encountered in present international oil operations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Millions of workers will receive pay increases next week as the Federal minimum wage goes up amid court challenges from states that contend it cannot be applied to their public employes.

AT 19, Peter Serkin is very much like any other teen-ager. He is a tall, nice-looking boy with a gentle face still in search of its first character lines. He generally needs a haircut, and he prefers sweaters and odd pants to suits and ties. His West End Avenue apartment is a shambles, or was recently.
LONDON, Jan. 28 This week's decision by The Times of London to sign reporters' names on articles is part of the new look that has been emerging in the venerable newspaper since May 3 of last year.

ONE of the bigger surprises to horsemen attending the recent annual convention of the American Horse Shows Association came when the rank and file of the professionals failed to rise in protest against a projected change in the open jumper rules.

The developer of a diversified community at Middletown, N.J., is taking the calculated risk that a little knowledge on the part of home buyers may not be a dangerous thing. The company warns visitors on possible pitfalls in buying a house.
The American Institute of Architects has chosen Wallace K. Harrison to receive its 1967 Gold Medal, the highest honor accorded by the professional group.

WARREN, Vt., Jan. 28 Although his blond, blue-eyed good looks belie the years, Stein Eriksen is now 40 years old. That may come as a shock to a number of middle-aged skiers with memories who look to Stein to remind them forever of their youth. People like Eriksen should be permanently 29.

CHRISTOPH WILLIBALD GLUCK, the great opera reformer, might be pleased to know that someone has been reforming him, or at least his music. Charles Mackerras is the reformer, and his new recording of Orfeo ed Euridice for Vanguard is an effort to be taken seriously by scholars as well as enjoyed by musicians and opera lovers.

The ninth annual International House Ball will be held Friday at International House, 500 Riverside Drive as the main fund-raising event of the year for the center's Fellowship fund. More than 1,000 graduate students here from nearly 100 countries, including the United States, receive scholarships or living allowances from the fund.

Miss Ginger Rogers and I used to perform this kindergarten jingle (with appropriate gestures and steps). The place was RKO; the time, about 9:00 A.M.; the occasion, the beginning of every shooting-day of the two films in which I directed her: "Bachelor Mother" (1939) and "Tom, Dick and Harry" (1941).
A donation of $9,434.80 from the Sophia Louise Miller Trust yesterday was among 77 gifts that added $11,004.70 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 28 The engagement of Miss Mary Hall to William Hendrik Johan Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willem Adams of Como, Italy, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Curtis Hall Jr.

THE poodle was America's No. 1 breed for the sev- enth year in a row and 1966 was the greatest for almost all breeds, according to the registration figures for the year issued last week by the American Kennel Club. Of the 115 breeds that the A.K.C. accepts into its stud ...
Dr. Jane Lesley Norman was married yesterday evening to Dr. Andrew Joseph Werner by Rabbi Dr. Joseph Gelberman at the St. Moritz Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 With all the enthusiasm of a college freshman forced to attend an early-morning lecture, the Administration finds itself confronting another round of Congressional advice and criticism on foreign policy from the dean of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 28 (AP) Mike Passarella of Chicago Shattered the United States record for the three-quarter mile and stormed into the senior men's lead in the 68th National outdoor speed skating championship today on Lake Como.

Last Wednesday Dr. Albert H. Bowker, chancellor of the City University of New York, left on a visit to California. The trip had been scheduled some time ago but recent events gave it additional purpose.
PARIS, Jan. 28 Louis Kahn, France's former chief of naval engineering, died here on Fri- day at the age of 71.
Ironically, the deaths occurred on the ground.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 Lew Alcindor scored 35 points tonight to lead the University of California, Los Angeles, Bruins to their 15th straight basketball victory without a defeat, 82-67, over Loyola in the second game of a Chicago Stadium tripleheader.

FAIR HAVEN, N.J., Jan. 28 Mr. and Mrs. Walter Seymour Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Morgan Seymour, to Frederic J. Mock. He is the son of Mrs. Kenneth S. Kassler of Princeton, N.J., and Rudolf J. Mock of London.
The marriage of Miss Andrea Helen Tietjen to Norvon Stephen Clark took place yesterday afternoon at Trinity Episcopal Church.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 28 A Nationalist Chinese court today convicted nine senior members of Parliament and five businessmen of corruption growing out of Taiwan's $5-million soybean scandal.
Elmhurst Hospital in Queens and Coney Island Hospital in Brooklyn will be struck Tuesday morning, a union representing hospital employes warned last night.
An Indiana group has been named Outboard Boating Club of the Year in the annual competition conducted by the Outboard Boating Club of America.

SIX major balls took place in New York last week. They were attended by members of society, the profes sions, the arts and fashion, all of whom had at least one thing in common considerable money or personality, in some cases both.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sunday Jan. 29 (UPI) The newly knighted British yachtsman Sir Francis Chichester set sail from Sydney today aboard his yacht Gipsy Moth IV for Plymouth, England, a 15,000 miles and, he hopes, 110 days away.
TORONTO, Jan. 28 More than 1,000 pamphlets telling Americans how to escape the draft by immigrating to Canada have been mailed to the United States by two Canadian groups in the last few months.

JANE BOWLES is a writer's writer's writer. Few surface literary reputations are as glamorous as the underground one she has enjoyed since her novel "Two Serious Ladies" was published in 1943. The extreme rarity of the book, once it went out of print, has augmented its legend.
THE great hope surrounding Vietnam is that the end of the hot war there may begin to finish off the cold war everywhere.

GATHER round, children, and you shall hear an other tale of how it was way back yonder in the days when innocence could walk inviolate abroad and evil could not survive when a man could share his roof and board with the birds of the air and the beasts of the field, practicing the while a bit of light-handed sorcery, with no intolerance to pester him.

THIS postwar German novel, which has had great success in Europe, now comes to us in a fine translation by Richard and Clara Winston. Its dreariness must not be ascribed to them, but to the turn of mind of its author, Henry Jaeger who, though now at 40 a well-established writer living in Switzerland, had an unusually troubled start.

THE story of H loise and Abelard has been told and retold down the centuries: with learned questioning of source material, of chronology, of philosophical debate; in biography, in novel, in drama and in verse; through editions of Latin texts, through translations into modern languages.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Moderate Republicans in Congress are quietly planning their own legislative alternatives for use in the event the party leadership fails to develop what the moderates consider to be a responsible minority position.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) The snowstorm that dumped most of its load on the Middle West 23 inches in Chacago and 28 in Kalamazoo, Mich. moved into northern New England and eastern Canada yesterday at reduced intensity.

DELAND, Fla., Jan. 28 Dr. J. Ollie Edmunds, president of Stetson University, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Jane Lee Edmunds, to Wayne Alien Novak. He is the son of Mrs. Marguerite T. Novak and Max L. Novak. A summer wedding is planned.
The United States Combined Training Association took a head count yesterday of the horses competing in its events and decided a tightening of the rules was in order.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (UPI) The National Liberation Front, the political arm of the Vietcong, rejected today a South Vietnamese Government proposal for negotiations on an extension of next month's lunar New Year ceasefire.

HARRISON, N.Y., Jan. 28 Mr. and Mrs. Mandel Kramer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Lesley Kramer, to Fredric Warren Altschul, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Altschul of Paterson, N.J. The wedding is planned for April 23.
Muhammad Ali, who won the heavyweight championship as Cassius Clay, is considering a defense of his title in Tokyo against Floyd Patterson.
JOE FOSS has survived wars, politics and the in- fighting of a football league, but a typical outdoors habit took him down a notch or two recently.
Libel, much discussed and little understood, is now elucidated by Robert H. Phelps, news editor of The Times's Washington Bureau, and E. Douglas Hamilton, a New York liberal lawyer.

PARIS. HENRYK SZERYNG, the violinist who is to play at Hunter Col lege on Saturday, is a man of many enthusiasms. The violin is the one for which he is best known, but it was his enthusiasm for a pianist that launched him on his career as a concert violinist.
A cockroach slowly crossed the kitchen floor of the threeroom flat above an East Harlem grocery that is the new home of the 23-year-old nephew of Governor Rockefeller.
The India Pavilion of the 1964-65 World's Fair will rise again. The pavilion, now lying in heaps in a lot in Lyndhurst, N.J., will become an office building in nearby Clifton.

CARLISLE H. HUMELSINE, president of Col onial Williamsburg, is not going to have to move out of his house after all. Two weeks ago, it was reported in this section that, in 1968, Williamsburg would open five new exhibit buildings and begin a two-ticket tour plan.
New York State's historic position of leadership has been based in large part upon the quality and quantity of the transportation facilities serving the state.
VIENNA, Jan. 22 Ernst Fischer, one of Austria's prominent intellectuals, has the distinction of being barked at simultaneously by the cultural watchdogs of the Communist East and the capitalist West.
LONDON, Jan. 28 Two men were arrested yesterday in connection with a burglary a month ago at Chequers, official country home of Prime Ministers, now occupied by Harold Wilson.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP)--Pope Paul VI, heads of state and the world's men of science joined today in offering their condolences on the death of the three American astronauts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Caught between a possible fallout hazard to dairy cows in Nevada and the sensitivities of delegates to the Geneva disarmament conference, the Adminstration decided this week in favor of the cows and sheduled a "peaceful" atomic explosion for next month.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 A week of turmoil at the University of California following the dismissal of Dr. Clark Kerr as president has produced numerous indications of more problems ahead.
In a practice more than faintly reminiscent of Dickens's "Oliver Twist," a ring of youthful shoplifters, led by adults, has been operating recently in the metropolitan New York area.
FORT CAMPBELL, Ky. Jan. 28 (UPI) Two children and a Fort Campbell soldier were killed today when a live hand grenade exploded on the porch of a home.
HARTFORD, Conn. The nearby Talcott Mountain ridgetop, which offers a vista that awed Whittier and Mark Twain, has become public domain after 156 years as the private preserve of rich men.

RED HOOK, N.Y., Jan. 28 The engagement of Miss Virginia Smithers to Kenneth John Nyman has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Francis Sydney Smithers 3d, parents of the future bride. Mr. Nyman is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walfred M. Nyman of Cumberland, R.I.
JESSUP, Md., Jan. 28 (AP) More than 100 prisoners rioted for two and a half hours at the Maryland House of Correction tonight, then were put back in their cells by state policemen using dogs.
MOFFETT FIELD, Calif., Jan. 28 (AP) Scientists at NASA'S Ames Research Center have analyzed a new mineral that is found only in certain stony meteorites. They have named it niningerite.

Now, in the interim between the January thaw and Groundhog Day, one can somewhat understand the reasoning back of most of our weather traditions. The countrymen who established them lived with the weather, saw what happened year after year, and were philosophical realists. They were also inclined to be skeptics.

MIAMI, Jan. 28 (UPI) Cookie Gilchrist, a 250-pound fullback for the Miami Dolphins of the American Football League, said yesterday he would sue the Dolphins because he wasn't getting $200 a week as required by his contract.

A two-mile relay team from Boys High, running in an unseeded section of the event and lapping the field before the second leg was over, set a national flat-floor record of 7 minutes 53.4 seconds yesterday.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28 Another battle for the world championship of automobile endurance will be waged here next Saturday and Sunday over the 3.81mile combination of road and high banked oval of the Daytona International Speedway.

LAHTI, Finland, Jan. 28 (AP) Kees Verkerk of the Netherlands, the world champion, led a field of 33 skaters from 12 nations today at the end of the first day of the European speedskating championships.
A half-million tenants thawed out yesterday as heat was restored to their apartments at the end of a two-day strike by caretakers and other City Housing Authority workers.

PRAGUE, Jan. 28 (AP) A prominent Czechoslovak writer has strongly criticized the American author John Steinbeck for his writings on the Vietnamese war and has asked the International P.E.N. Club to condemn him, the Czech press agency reported today.

Richard S. Tufts, who put Pinehurst, N.C., on the golf map, was announced yesterday as the 1966 winner of the Bob Jones Award for sportsmanship at the annual meeting of the United States Golf Association.
Many housewives now know that beef prices will be heading up this year.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 28 Behor Shitreet died of a heart attack today, four weeks after he stepped down as Minister of Police in the Government of Levi Eshkol.

I DON'T know that any lawgiver ever said that all por tions of a novel should move at the same tempo, or that violence should be carefully apportioned in equal parts per chapter. But most contemporary spy novels seem to obey these rules.

Airlines must develop volume and frequency-of-shipment incentives for shippers if they are to make serious inroads into the traffic carried by ocean carriers and over-the-road transport, according to Harold L. Graham, vice president of cargo sales for Pan American World Airways.

PRAGUE, Jan. 22 After two decades of neglect, the beautiful city of Prague has begun to remember what it owes to its past and future, and is renewing itself. It makes the present somewhat uncomfortable for its million residents, but the effect is magical.

Wednesday will be the 80th birthday for the man who has sold more books than anyone else in this country, probably in the world. He is Harry Scherman, dreamer-upper, cofounder and now chairman of the board of the Book-of-the-Month Club. Most people, advancing toward 80, say as a matter of course they will spend that day at the office.

One can argue that the two most epochal steps in the civilizing of man were the invention of the wheel and the birth of agriculture. The first initiated technology. The other was the start of man's reshaping of the environment to his own ends.

Clement J. Gaertner, who retired Sept. 30 as a general partner in the investment banking firm of Salomon Brothers Hutzler, died of a heart attack yesterday in St. Francis Hospital, Miami Beach. He was 72 years old and had homes at Bal Harbour near Miami Beach and at 75 Central Park West here.

TORONTO, Jan. 28 (AP) First-period goals by Eric Nesterenko, Doug Mohns and Doug Jarrett sparked the Chicago Black Hawks to a 5-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight. It was the Leafts' sixth defeat in a row.

Communities in the upper Illinois River Valley are making plans to take advantage of the economic benefits that will come from the building of the giant Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation complex next to this tiny hamlet of 400 persons.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 28 The Metropolitan soprano Regine Crespin sang "La Vie en Rose" last night for the 500 guests at the Opera Ball, and Mrs. Arturo di Filippi, wife of the Opera Guild's founder and general manager, declared that it probably the closet thing to opera manay of the organization's lifetime members have experienced this season.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 Air Force B-52 Stratofortresses dropped hundreds of tons of incendiary bombs today on a dense forest known as War Zone C, a traditional sanctuary believed to house the Vietcong's supreme headquarters.
Nearly half the city residents who went to the polls last Nov. 8 failed to vote for judges. Of those who did, only a small percentage could remember a week or so later whom they had backed.

A COLORFUL, oversize, offset-printed stamp will grace a commem orative 6-cent airmail postal card that the United States will release on March 31. It commemorates the 50th anniversary of the purchase of the Virgin Islands from Denmark for $25-million.
A small Jesuit seminary in Kansas placed its bet last week on what it expects to be the model for theological education in the future. In a word, it's what Clark Kerr called a "multiversity."

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 28 (Reuters) The economic position of New Zealand is "considerably more serious" than at the first of the year, Prime Minister Keith Holyoake said at a press conference this week.

William Cahn, the newly elected president of the New York State District Attorneys Association, said yesterday that organized crime had reached "warlike proportions" and that the only effective weapon against it was wiretapping.

PEKING, Sunday, Jan. 29 (Reuters)--The massive demonstration outside the Soviet Embassy here continued today for the fourth consecutive day, and the Peking press published reports of similar protest rallies involving millions of people all over China.

On the living room wall of Senator George Aiken's Vermont home is a framed copy of Frost's "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening." But a visitor gets the impression that the Senator does not often stop to contemplate the miles to go before he sleeps. He enjoys the journey too much. Along the way he leaves Aikenisms that express his own turn of mind. Here are some samples:

THIS is a daydream of a novel, brimming with the memo ries, observations and private play of the nameless 20-yearold narrator, and as a novel deliberately indifferent to the formalities of conventionally structured fiction.

FOR the first time, the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx will offer "Prehistoric Botany Plant Fossils," a three-session course which begins Tuesday, Feb. 7. The instructor, Dr. Herman F. Becker, is the botanical garden's curator of paleobotany. Two sections are scheduled: 10 to 11:30 A.M. and 8 to 9:30 P.M. Fee is $10 ($7.50 for botanical garden members).

RICHMOND, Jan. 28 Mr. and Mrs William Edgar Byrd Jr. have announced the engagement of Mrs. Byrd's daughter, Miss Pamela Howell Parsons, to Charles Ashford Greathouse 3d of San Francisco. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Greathouse Jr. of Indianapolis and Northport Point, Mich.

James J. Heffernan, a Democratic Representative from Brooklyn from 1941 to 1952, died Friday after a long illness. His age was 78 and he lived at 65 Prospect Park West in Brooklyn.

MAPLE HEIGHTS, Ohio, Jan. 28 The engagement of Miss Gail Marie Bisjack to Edward Robert Salzer, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Salzer of Merrick, L.I., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Bisjack.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 28 Arthur Ashe of Richmond, closed in on a final berth in the Australian tennis championships today by building a 12-10, 9-9 lead over John Newcombe of Australia before darkness forced suspension of their match.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 28 The fulfilled dreams and frustrated hopes of the West's rural poor were reflected here as President Johnson's National Commission on Rural Poverty heard recommendations for streamlining economic opportunity programs.

The James Chapel of Union Theological Seminary was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Miss Penelope Barnes, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. F. Duncan Barnes of New Rochelle, N.Y., to Kenneth Robert Thompson. He is the son of Mrs. John Vincent Ward of Lansdale, Pa., and Joseph Thompson of Hopewell, N.J.

SEATTLE, Jan. 28 In St. Paul's Episcopal Church here today Miss Kathleen Irene Kirkpatrick and Paul Gerry Maurer, graduates of Stanford University, were married by the Rev. Warren Fenn. Miss Betty Kay Aberlin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward H. Aberlin of Grymes Hill, S.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Penn Lupovich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Lupovich of Pittsburgh.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Jan. 28 Miss Ingrid Ellen Winther and Prof. James R. Scobie plan to marry here in June.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Preesident Johnson named a three-man emergency board today to investigate a labor dispute between the nation's railroads and six shop unions.

A seven-race schedule that was slightly shorter than usual was made public last week for the New York Yacht Club's power yacht predicted log competition, a relatively new activity for the ancient stronghold of sail.
RICHARD VERBER of Chicago, scoring 6-1 in a seven-round Swiss system, topped 162 players to win the 1966 North Central Chess Championship. The event was played at the Plankinton House, Milwaukee.
ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 28 (Reuters) A British Commonwealth featherweight title fight scheduled for tonight was postponed until Feb. 3 after a dispute at the weighin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) Special high-altitude balloons have been circling the globe for record periods up to more than six months in warmup tests for a proposed new long-range, worldwide weather forecasting effort.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) The proportion of public school teachers with substandard certification has increased for the first time in five years, according to a United States Office of Education survey made public tonight.
Republicans across the nation were urgde yesterday by two of their leaders to unify their party and to fight increasing Federal takeover of governmental action.
The trading stamp industry posted its largest total sales record in 1966, according to Irving M. Axelrod, president of the Trading Stamp Institute of America, industry trade group.

DALLAS, Jan. 28 (AP) Mrs. Marie Tippit, widow of the Dallas police officer slain in 1963 by Lee Harvey Oswald, and Police Lieut. Harry Dean Thomas confirmed yesterday that they were married a-week ago at the Beckley Baptist Church.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 29 Mrs. Marion Hamilton Diller, former president and general manager of the Norwalk Symphony, died yesterday at a local convalescent home. Her age was 86. She lived on Perry Avenue and was the widow of Alfred Welles Diller, a former advertising man.

SAN ANTONIO Tex., Jan. 29 A pill may some day be capable of eliminating the need for operations to remove tumors of the uterus, a leading expert in the field of birth control pills said here recently.

Leonard Rose, a cellist of distinction, gave a recital at Hunter College Assembly Hall on Saturday night. It was notably satisfying, and suggested that he should consider making more frequent appearances.

One of the three adjoining East Side mansions purchased by the Marquesa de Cuevas about two years ago to save them from demolition has been sold by the marquesa to the American Foundation on Automation and Employment, Inc.

Brother A. Benedict Ayers, an assistant professor of biology at Manhattan College and former supervisor of schools for the New York Roman Catholic Province of the Christian Brothers, died yesterday at the college in Riverdale. He was 56 years old.

The marriage of Miss Jill Kneerim, daughter of Arthur Kneerim of Brooklyn Heights and the late Mrs. Margaret Whittlesey Kneerim, to Richard L. Grossman took place here last evening. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Samuel Grossman of New York and the late Mr. Grossman.
In a long procession, 555 tenants carrying valises, baby carriages and bags of groceries, streamed from their heatless Queens housing development yesterday to take refuge offered to them by the city.

Loren Driscoll, a newcomer this year, was a bright-faced Alfred; and Joy Clements a pretty if somewhat artificially vivacious Adele.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 Most of the nation's car dealers agree with the Detroit manufacturers that "safety doesn't sell," and predict substantially higher prices for 1968 models.

New Haven's Long Wharf Theater has withdrawn its request that the Yale School of Drama take it over.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 29 Maj. Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle wound up his campaign for the presidency today with a noisy, colorful rally of about 50,000 people in Managua's main square. The election will be held Sunday and General Somoza is heavily favored to win it.

Miss Estelle Irene Pollack of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Flying Officer Maurice Reymes King of the Canadian Air Force, were married yesterday in the State Suite of the Plaza by Rabbi David J. Seligson of the Central Synagogue.

Dr. Josephine Diaz Martin, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Diaz of New York and Tampa, Fla., was married here yesterday to Robert J. Schwartz, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Schwartz of New York. Family Court Judge Florence M. Kelley performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Schroeder Boulton.

At Lincoln Center tonight: "Queen of Spades," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 7:30; chamber music flute and strings with Sue Ann Kahn, flutist, Library and Museum of the Performing Arts, 6.
Miss Jo Ann Black and Howard Edwin Chase were married here yesterday afternoon at the Essex, House by Rabbi Max Schenk.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 30 Thirty-one Vietnamese civilians were killed and 38 wounded during an attack by American helicopters and patrol boats in the Mekong River delta, a military spokesman announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The Defense Department was accused today of contravening, United States foreign policy objectives, particularly in the disarmament field, by an "aggressive" promotion of arms sales abroad.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (UPI) More snow fell today in the Middle West, which was still digging out from under the greatest snowfall ever in northern Illinois, northern Indiana and Southern Michigan.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (UPI) Lew Alcindor set one Chicago Stadium scoring record and tied another today in leading No. 1-ranked and unbeaten University of California, Los Angeles, to a 120-82 basketball triumph over Illinois. It was the Bruins' 16th victory.

The Senate of the United States was not on trial with Bobby Baker, but it must share the disgrace of his conviction. The twisted version of the Horatio Alger story that carried Baker from page boy to illicit wealth as a peddler of Congressional influence grew out of a moral atmosphere on Capitol Hill that neither house has yet shown any conspicuous zeal to decontaminate.

The 32d awards presentations of the New York Film Critics took place last night at Sardi's Restaurant on West 44th Street, where the plaques were handed out by Mayor Lindsay and Judith Crist, chairman of the critics group, herself the critic for The World Journal Tribune.

Mrs. Lilia Jeffries Howry, the wife of Kenneth A. Howry, editor of Department Store Economist, a monthly trade magazine, died of cancer on Saturday at Memorial Hospital. She was 56 years old and lived at 15 Chelsea Drive, Merrick, L.I.

Arthur W. Bingham, president of the International Grenfell Association and a past president of the Grenfell Association of America, died of a heart attack Saturday in San Juan, P.R. He was 66 years old and lived at 520 East 86th Street.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 29 The Seamen's Church Institute was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Mrs. Rita Norrie Wells Rilliet to Norrie Sherman Sellar of New York and Newport.

HAVANA, Jan. 29 (Reuters) Premier Fidel Castro formally inaugurated last night a new comprehensive rural development plan designed to serve as a pilot project for Cuba's version of Communism.

The late Branch Rickey, who broke baseball's color line, and Lloyd (Little Poison) Waner, half of one of the sport's greatest brother acts with the Pitts burgh Pirates, were elected yesterday to the Hall of Fame.

The municipal broadcasting station, WNYC, will present its annual American Music Festival between Lincoln's and Washington's birthdays. Fifteen free concerts will be among the more than 100 events to be broadcast between Feb. 12 and 22. About 50 works will be given premiere performances.

JAMES SHERWIN, a New York lawyer, is an inter national chess master with a deceptively eclectic style. His forte is the counterstroke. Every Saturday and Sunday, 8-year-old Amy Salzman earns a dollar or two by riding ponies in a vacant lot in Greenwich Village, a few blocks from her home. So do her 12-year-old sister, Bly, and two boys from the neighborhood, Jerry DeGrazio, 11, and Angel Perez, 15.
JERUSALEM (Israel), Jan. 29 Israel and Syria failed again today to find any common ground for their talks over border tension, but will meet again Thursday.

Former Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of Freedom House. He succeeds Roscoe Drummond, the newspaper columnist, who becomes vice chairman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29?In the spring of 1964, five days after the fraud trial of James R. Hoffa began in Chicago, a tough young lawyer named William Omar Bittman walked upon the scene cold. The chief prosecutor, Abe Poretz, was seriously ill and forced to withdraw.

Mayor Lindsay, Senator Jacob K. Javits and Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving trudged through the snow-covered woods of Staten Island yesterday to protest a planned highway that could destroy one of the last natural areas of the city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara is unhappy with the performance of the heavily subsidized American-flag merchant marine and has expressed his irritation in closed Senate hearings.

One day in 1955, a Cleveland advertising executive on one of his frequent trips to New York impulsively walked into a bank here and opened a savings account with the profits from a deal he had just completed.

The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor will continue its investigation of the right of a major New York stevedoring company to hold a license in this port and has instructed counsel in the inquiry to file briefs by Feb. 14.

PARIS, Jan. 29 (AP) Senator Robert F. Kennedy arrived from London today and said that "the next few weeks will be crucial and critical" for the war in Vietnam because of several developments already taking place and contacts being made.
ROME, Jan. 29 Nikolai V. Podgorny, the Soviet President, will probably meet Pope Paul VI tomorrow afteroon, Vatican sources said today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 28 A policeman masquerading as a woman in an attempt to halt a series of assaults and rapes was dragged into an alley and beaten severely last night.
Louis L. Allen was named over the weekend as president of the Chase Manhattan Capital Corporation, the wholly owned small business investment company of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

Neal Steinhauer said he was putting the shot too high and Bob Seagren, considering his injured back, probably was polevaulting too high, but neither has a complaint. PARIS, Jan. 29 Fifty white cardboard chairs, which look like deep milk buckets, gave people something cozy to slump in and something new to talk about before the Emanuel Ungaro show yesterday. His collection came on the seventh day of the Paris spring-summer shows after a torrent of more than 1,800 dresses, suits, coats, Bermuda shorts and bloomers designed by other people.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 29 Lawrence G. Larsen, chief probation officer of Essex County, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home at 18 Undercliff Terrace. He was 39 years old.
SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 29 Robert T. Whelan, assistant vice president of the Nopco Chemical Company in Newark, died Friday in Presbyterian Hospital, New York. His age was 52.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Monday, Jan. 30 (UPI) Heavily armed army units and armored cars loyal to General Suharto, Indonesia's strongman, encircled President Sukarno's palace in downtown Jakarta today. There were unconfirmed reports that Mr. Sukarno was under virtual house arrest.
MEGEVE, France, Jan. 29 (AP) Guy Perillat of France broke Jean Claude Killy's streak of eight victories today in winning the special slalom by less than one-half of a second at the Megeve Grand Prix.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29 Demand for steel seemed to be rising last week. New orders tabulated at one mill in the last few days were more than 100 per cent of capacity for the first time in months. The order surge lifted cumulative bookings decisively above the December average.
The Week of the Angry Arts or, more accurately, of angry artists Against the War in Vietnam started yesterday in Greenwich Village.
United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau is investigating a complaint by some members of a New York teamster local that they were intimidated by members of another local.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 House Republicans are preparing to press charges of "fiscal gimmickry" and deception against the Johnson Administration this week in hearings on the national debt limit.
Net new orders for machine tools rose in December after two successive declines.

LONDON, Jan. 29 (UPI) A leading British legal authority said tonight he could see no need to reopen the inquiry into the death of President Kennedy. A Yale University professor disagreed and called for the creation of a small, full-time commission to re-examine the evidence.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Monday, Jan. 30 (Reuters) Nancy Richey won the Australian national women's tennis championship here today by beating Lesley Turner, 6-1, 6-4, in the final. It was the Texas girl's first major world singles title.

Martina Arroyo sang Wagner's "Wesendonk Songs" and Richard Strauss's Four Last Songs with the Musica Aeterna Orchestra last night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Edgar G. Crossman, a senior partner in Davis Polk Wardwell Sunderland Kiendl, lawyers at 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza, died Saturday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 1088 Park Avenue.

The 15th annual Piarist Ball will be given Friday at the Plaza's Grand Ballroom and the Terrace and the Crystal and Baroque Rooms. Nearly 1,000 guests are expected at the gala where the Hungarian csardas and the waltz are the stars.
TORONTO, Jan. 29 (Canadian Press) Valerie Jones of Toronto and Donald Knight of Dundas, Ont., won the Canadian national free-skating titles today.

Mrs. Anne Eisner Putnam, who for 10 years devoted her writing and painting talents to capturing the life of pygmies in the Belgian Congo, died of cancer Saturday at Memorial Hospital. She was 55 years old and lived at 5 Minetta Street in Greenwich Village.

The opening today of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's hearings on the global responsibilities of the United States will offer another opportunity to air the most crucial of all American foreign policies, that on the war in Vietnam. Senator Fulbright, who will be in charge, will undoubtedly use the occasion to emphasize his special concern with what he has labeled "the arrogance of power" on the part of the United States in Southeast Asia.

The merger terms of the Amerada Petroleum Corporation and the Ashland Oil and Refining Company were announced jointly over the weekend by the two companies. A number of the major issues remain to be resolved, however.

A CUSTOMER walked into Tiffany's the other day, stopped in front of a table setting that had just been put into place on the second floor, and cried: "I'll take it!" The store declined to say how much the customer would have to pay for the whole table setting, but a quick addition

LYNBROOK, L.I., Jan. 29 Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Francis Coogan Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Monica Coogan, to Michael Francis Horan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Vincent Horan of Pawtucket, R.I.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) President Johnson underestimated the cost of the Vietnam war in his new budget, Representative Melvin R. Laird, Republican-Wisconsin, said today.

Operations in the Port of New York, which directly or indirectly provide employment for one out of four of the city's workers, were sharply curtailed yesterday when 2,000 tugboat workers went on strike.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 29 (AP) James J. Corbett, athletic director at Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge since 1955, died of a heart attack here today. He was 47 years old.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 30 (AP) The last major units of the United States Ninth Infantry Division arrived today, raising to about 404,000 men the total United States strength in Vietnam.

The American Electric Power System reported over the weekend record earnings of $87.7million for 1966. Donald C. Cook, president, said the new high resulted from records in sales and revenues and represented a gain of 9.4 per cent above the 1965 net of $80.2million. Share earnings rose by a like percentage to $1.94 from $1.78 a year ago.

An Administration spokesman made a strong plea last night for President Johnson's Great Society budget, which would be increased 16 per cent in the next fiscal year if Congressional opposition could be overcome.
MADISON, Wis., Jan. 29 (UPI) Bjorn Wirkola, the world ski jumping champion from Norway, set a hill jump record of 206 feet today in winning the Blackhawk Ski Club tournament.
GLEN ROCK, N.J., Jan. 29 Dr. Francis W. Ash, a retired surgeon, died Friday in his home at 36 Rutland Road. His age was 75.
Governor Rockefeller and Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia were described yesterday as seriously considering a law requiring all workers in the state to be covered by hospitalization insurance.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 29 While investigators continued to seek the cause of the fatal Apollo 1 blast, an inspection of the fire-blackened spacecraft showed today that the greatest damage seemed to have occurred where the electrical lifeline from the launching pad entered the cabin. A reporter who examined the coneshaped space craft, still perched 218 feet atop its rocket, found the cockpit a shell.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) Sharply conflicting assessments of the relative popularity of President Johnson and Senator Robert F. Kennedy, appeared today in two nationally distributed polls.

The 50-year-old American Association of Advertising Agencies caled a news conference in its Pan Am Building headquarters the other day to announce its biggest undertaking the establishment of an educational foundation.
The Arvida Corporation, one of Florida's largest real estate development companies, has purchased about 1,800 acres in the area of Boca Raton in the southern part of Palm Beach County.
ATLANTA, Jan. 29 (AP) The wife of a Negro minister was mysteriously shot to death at her home early today, only hours after an attempt had been made to set fire to her husband's church.

Two Manhattan clergymen told their congregations yesterday that the success of the integration movement now depends largely on the willingness of whites to accept the emergence of "black power" as a positive step.

MACAO, Jan. 29 (AP) Under a portrait of Mao Tsetung and two red flags, the Governor of Macao signed an agreement today with proCommunist Chinese to end a seven-week crisis that had threatened Portugal's rule of this tiny enclave on the South China coast.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Robert G. Baker was found guilty today of income tax evasion, theft and conspiracy to defraud the United States Government.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 An attempt to persuade prominent Roman Catholic laymen to support publicly a liberalization of New York's abortion law, in opposition to their church's official doctrine, has met with failure.

NEW BERN, N.C., Jan. 29 Former Representative Graham Arthur Barden, the conservative North Carolina Democrat who preceded Representative Adam Clayton Powell as chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, died of cancer this morning at his home. He was 70 years old.

A Queens police lieutenant devoted time and effort to help a youth in trouble two years ago, but one of his detectives found it necessary to shoot the youth fatally Saturday night in a motel robbery, the police said yesterday.
A group of economists and financial analysts dissected the economy Saturday but concluded after five hours of debate only that 1967 would be a year of "transition."
A brief memorial service at Cape Kennedy, Fla., for the three Apollo 1 astronauts killed there last Friday will be televised this morning by the three networks.
Derrel (Bud) Harrelson and Jerry Grote, two of the younger regulars for the New York Mets, signed 1967 contracts yesterday. This brought the club's list of in-the-fold players to 24.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) Bui Diem, South Vietnam's Ambassador to the United States, said today that within two years his country "will be stable enough to deal with the problem of the Vietcong and Communists in general."

ROCHESTER, Jan. 29 (AP) There have been several spacecraft fires similar to the one that took the lives of the three astronauts at Cape Kennedy on Friday, a specialist on gaseous environments said last night.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 29 Dr. Walter Phillips, for many years chief of surgery and president of the medical staff of Englewood Hospital, died today in this home at 109 East Palisade Avenue. He was 87 years old.
BOSTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) Richard Cardinal Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, plans to retire in 1970 and go to South America.

HONG KONG, Jan 29. The republication in Communist China over the weekend of a 37-year-old essay of Mao Tsetung, the party's Chairman, is interpreted by observers here as an appeal for moderation in the Cultural Revolution.
PEKING, Jan. 29 (Reuters) Crowds of Chinese demonstrated today outside the Yugoslav Embassy here, shouting "crush the dog's head of Tito" and burning an effigy of President Tito on the gates.
One of the political and social realities emerging with increasing clarity in New York is the quest for self-expression by the city's large Puerto Rican community.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Jan. 29 Mr. and Mrs. Renzo Olivieri of Locust Valley and Florence, Italy, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maria Olivieri, to Martin Quinn. He is the son of Mrs. Edward James Goldie of San Francisco and Thomas Henry Quinn of West Warwick, R.I.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 29 Mrs. Louis Cannizzaro, who rides for the Fairfield County Hunt Club in Fairfield, Conn., guided her mount, Caesar's Ghost, today to two blue ribbons in the Secor Farm horse show.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 29 The 2-million-member United Church of Christ is trying to establish its identity.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--The United States may have "an embryonic space station" orbiting the earth before an astronaut walks on the moon.

Najeeb E. Halaby, a senior vice president of Pan American World Airways, has stated that he believes the Soviet Union plans to flight test their supersonic transport design next winter, and put it into commercial service three years later.

Joseph L. Eckhouse, who trained for an executive post at Macy's but instead became a vice president of Gimbels, died of a cerebral hemorrhage last night at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at the Mayflower Hotel, 15 Central Park West.
ST. PAUL, Jan. 29 (AP) Mike Passarella and Jean Ashford, runners-up a year ago, took the titles away from the defenders in the national outdoor speed skating championships today.
President Johnson has been urged to ask Congress in his air pollution message this week for "substantial increases of natural gas" for the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 29 In the second and last production of its repertory season at the Walker Art Center, the Center Opera Company played to strings. The bill was a series of oneact operas on Greek themes, hence the over-all title "To Hellas." Chief among the divertisements were the three so-called "minute operas" of Darius Milhaud.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 29 (UPI) Vincente Saldivar of Mexico retained his world featherweight title with a seventh-round technical knockout over Mitsunori Seki of Japan tonight. The bout was halted at 1:53 of the round.
PONCE, P.R., Jan. 29 The plebiscite on the political status of Puerto Rico, scheduled for July 23 by the commonwealth Government, will probably be postponed until fall.

MOSCOW, Jan. 27 (UPI) An official Soviet newspaper said today the deaths of the three American astronauts were caused by the "haste" of United States space officials in the race to beat the Russians to the moon. It said there were "flaws" in the Apollo spaceship.

Having got all wound up to begin a campaign for a July plebiscite on the future status of the island, Puerto Ricans are now unwinding themselves. If reports from San Juan prove true, the plebiscite will be put off until November and may not be held at all.
There are a couple of men with new titles in the Interpublic complex today and a new vice president at Ted Bates.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 Arnold Palmer, who has won more money playing golf than anyone else, added the Los Angeles open to his conquests today. With a score of 269 for 72 holes he captured the first prize of $20,000 by five strokes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) The magazine U.S. News World Report said today that the Soviet Union had developed a missile defense that, if as effective as some reports say, could neutralize the United States arsenal of long-range nuclear weapons.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 29 Miss Carey Panet Chittenden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Hastings Chittenden, was married this afternoon to Michael Gray Curtis, son of Prof. and Mrs. W. Edgar Curtis of Berlin, N.Y.

FLORHAM PARK, N.J., Jan. 29 The wedding of Miss Barbara Ellen Skowronek, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin Skowronek of Somerville, to Robert Aaron Levenstien took place to day at the Florham Park Country Club. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Levenstien of Bayside, Queens, New York.

DeWitt Clinton, the undefeated Division I Public Schools Athletic League basketball champion last season, lost its first game of the 1966-67 season yesterday. Clinton's 33game winning streak was broken by William H. Taft, 84-67, before a capacity crowd of 600 at Taft gymnasium in the Bronx.
Recovering from the snowstorm that crippled operations last Friday, the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange were back in business yesterday.

PARIS, San. 30 The Government has authorized the free importation and exportation of gold to and from France, with the stated aim of making the small Paris gold market more important.

The engagement of Miss Jane Goldstone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Goldstone of New York and Redding, Conn., to Ralph M. Feaver, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Feaver of Devon, Pa., has been announced by the future bride's parents. A spring wedding is planned.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 30--Mr. and Mrs. James J. O'Neal have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Tierney O'Neal, to Edward Francis Maloney Jr. of the Army Officer Candidate School at Fort Lee, Va. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maloney of Bronxville.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) Farm product prices declined 1 per cent between midDecember and mid-January. Increases in prices for cattle, broilers and potatoes were offsetting factors.

Jimmy Durante will receive the Club of Champions gold medal from the Catholic Youth Organization of New York at its annual dinner, tomorrow in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom. He will be honored for "his faithful devotion and outstanding example to youth as a man of principle and achievement."

LONDON, Jan. 30 The Government began today a sweeping investigation of restrictive practices in the professions. It will consider the fixing of fees, requirements for entering a profession, limitations on services and other practices.

A large, friendly crowd greeted Ludwig Olshansky last night at Carnegie Hall, as the young New York pianist gave his third local recital since his successful debut in 1963. It was an all-Romantic program, listing the Four Schubert Impromptus, Opus 90, Chopin's "Funeral March" Sonata, and two Intermezzi and the F sharp minor Sonata of Brahms.

SAIGON, Jan. 30 After six days of scrambling by aircraft, jeep, truck and shank's mare from Saigon north to the demilitarized zone, the impression of peace amid war emerges as sharply as the black silhouette of a helicopter against the red evening sky of the central highlands. The beauty and stillness of this land with its misthung mountains, its fertile green fields, its beautiful beaches and latticework streams, everywhere surrounds the terrible scenes of war.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 30 An international financial group led by associates of the, Rothschild banking family, met here tonight to consider ways of resuming copper production in the Congo.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 31 (AP) The United States Army rounded out its Mekong Delta fighting force yesterday with the landing of the final unit of the 15,000-man Ninth Infantry Division. The $35,000 Grarnd National Steeplechase will be raced at Aqueduct this year on June 2, the day before the Belmont Stakes The three-mile race has been a fall fixture.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30 (AP) The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia said tonight that absolute safety had been given up in the United States space program in an effort to get quick results.
Proofs of the magazine ads for the American Cancer Society's 1967 crusade have been mailed to the publications and, according to the society, the reaction has been "tromendous."

Two men who confessed to a murder won dismissal on the charges in State Supreme Court yesterday on the ground that they had not been informed of their right to counsel before they confessed. Both defendants have long criminal records.
DAVID KOSSOFF, the British actor who came here late last year to do a Broadway show but was washed out in Boston, finally got his New York debut last night, downtown at the Theater de Lys.
The Canadian Pacific Railway Company announced yesterday that its earnings in 1966 climbed to $50,219,767, from $40,239,707 the year before.
Directors of the Transamer- ica Corporation named two vice presidents to newly created posts, John R. Beckett, the company president, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) The Pentagon called today for the drafting of 2,229 doctors, including a first-time induction of osteopaths, beginning in July.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 30 (AP) The future of Buckpasser, the nation's leading thoroughbred in 1966, remained problematical today, but his trainer, Eddie Neloy, was optimistic that the millionaire 4year-old would be back racing this year.

The New York Stock Exchange has appointed Lloyd W. McChesney as chief examiner of the department of member firms, effective tomorrow, it has been announced by Keith Funston, president of the exchange.
PRAGUE, Jan. 30--An American of Czechoslovak birth went on trial today on charges of having carried out "antistate activities" in the pay of an unspecified foreign power's intelligence service.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 30 Princeton's nationally ranked basketball team poured it on in race-horse style tonight for a 97-74 victory over Rutgers.
ALBANY, Jan, 30 A jury was picked in less than six hours in Federal Court here today in the bank-robbery trail of John (Sonny) Franzese and four other defendants.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 Charles C. Renshaw, an investment banker here and a former governor of the New York Stock Exchange died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was found slumped over the wheel of his car in a downtown parking lot. He was 78 years old.
Twenty-three employes of The New York Times who were fined by, the Newspaper Guild for crossing a guild picket line during a strike will not pay the fines, their lawyer said yesterday.

Following are the issues in the tugboat strike involving 3,500 men who normally operate 450 harbor craft, ranging from tugs to tankers and self-propelled and non-propelled barges. The men are members of Local 333, United Marine Division, National Maritime Union. The 60 employers are represented by the Marine Towing and Transportation Employers Association.
Picking up where it left off last Friday, the stock market made another broad advance in heavy trading yesterday.
The new board of trustees of the Central Aguirre Sugar Company met, in Aguirre, Puerto Rico, yesterday and elected Bernard P. Faure, a French citizen, as chairman and chief executive officer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- What many persons here felt was really on trial during the last three weeks in Courtroom 21 of the Federal Court Building was not simply the conduct of Robert G. Baker, the former secretary to the Senate Democratic majority.

City officials decided yesterday to ease some parking, restrictions for handicapped drivers and to crack down on illegally double-parked trucks that impede cross-town traffic between 34th and 66th Streets.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has elected Bernard D. Broeker as a director and as chairman of the finance committee, it was announced yesterday by Edmund F. Martin, chairman and chief executive officer of the nation's second largest steel producer.

The National Maritime Union said yesterday that it would halt all American-flag shipping in New York harbor if tugboat workers set up picket lines at piers where United States-flag vessels are berthed.

PLANDOME, L.L, Jan. 30 E. Frank Liebrecht, a senior vice president of the M.W. Kellogg Company, died yesterday in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset. He was 63 years old and had suffered a heart attack Saturday at his home, 51 Broosside Drive here. His office was at 711 Third Avenue, Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) --The first community treatment centers for Federal prison system inmates will open this spring in Houston and Atlanta, the Bureau of Prisons announced today.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 30 Unlike soccer, horse racing, baseball or bullfighting, automobile racing seems to demand Courage and coolheadedness on the part of organizers and spectators as well as those who actually take part.
GREENSBORO, N.C., Jan. 30 (UPI) The Boston Celtics raced to their 10th straight National Basketball Association victory tonight by trouncing the San Francisco Warriors, 121108.
The Lindsay administration plans to end the 24-hour-a-day ferry service to Hart Island, which costs the city $16.60 a person for each round-trip.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 30 (AR) The St. Louis Hawks scored 8 straight points early in the fourth quarter and went on to a 106-99 National Basketball Association victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight. The loss halted the Lakers' four-game winning streak.

LONDON, Jan. 30 Minister of Health Kenneth Robinson announced in the House of Commons today that the Government planned to withdraw from individual British physicians the right to prescribe narcotics for addicts. He said the right to issue such prescriptions would be limited to psychiatrists in hospitals.
A request for immediate Congressional hearings to examine the needs of the maritime industry in the next fiscal year was made yesterday by the president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.
Raven, Novie, a 21-year-old secretary, convicted of squirting a tear-gas gun into the face of a bar, patron last May, received a suspended sentence yesterday in Criminal Court.

John V. Irwin, a lawyer who specialized in estates and trusts, died of a heart attack in his home at 925 Park Avenue at 80th Street yesterday morning, He was 92 years old and had an office at 67 Wall Street, and another residence on Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan, Conn.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 30 Westchester County was told today that it must return to its pre-Depression practice of issuing long-term bonds so that essential capital improvements costing substantially more than $125-million can be started now

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30 The number of neuropsychiatric cases admitted to hospitals here from the American and South Vietnamese Armies is "remarkably low for the number of troops involved," according to a study by a United States-South Vietnamese team.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 30 (AP) Roy Emerson, Australia's Davis Cup star, overwhelmed Arthur Ashe of Richmond, 6-4, 6-1, 6-4, today in winning the men's singles title of the Australian tennis championships for the fifth straight time.

DETROTT, Jan. 30 (UPI) The undefeated Belfast Glentorans of the Northern Ireland Soccer League will represent Detroit this summer in the newly formed North American Soccer League, John W. Anderson, the president of the recently organized Detroit club, said today.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 30 Some men collect coins, some collect stamps. Others collect sea shells or Inca artifacts. Hymen Nathan Glickstein collects race tracks. He is head of El Comandante race track here, and is also head of Shenandoah Downs in Charles Town, W. Va.

MADRID, Jan. 30 Stonethrowing students fought a two-hour battle with the police today. The police repeatedly charged them with clubs and powerful water jets. Some students limped away from the battlefield at the University of Madrid with blood. streaming down their faces. Three foreign correspondents watching the fighting were attacked and beaten by the police.
MIAMI, Jan. 30 The United States Weather Bureau is seeking permission for hurricane hunter planes to fly over Cuba, a bureau spokesman said today.

Several members of the National Association of Motor Bus Owners are understood to be supporting Charles E. Webb, a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, for the $55,- 000-a-year presidency of the trade organization.

Two Parisians, who said they did not know each other and who entered this country separately in the last week, were held in bail of $75,000 each in Federal Court yesterday after Customs officials said they had found 11 pounds of illicit heroin on one. The heroin was said to be worth $1.5-million on the retail black market.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--A high official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has charged that William Loeb, the right-wing newspaper publisher offered to give J. Edgar Hoover $100,000 if he would disclose illegal wiretapping by the Government against James R. Hoffa,

Moscow, Jan. 30 Workmen hastily erected a high wall in front of the Lenin Mausoleum in Red Square tonight as another group of Chinese students arrived in Moscow on their way home from schools in Western Europe.
TRENTON, Jan. 30 The State Air Pollution Control Commission declared today that it had accepted Federal clean-air standards set by a conference in Manhattan earlier this month.
NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Jan. 30 (AP) Frank Remley, the butt of Jack Benny's jokes for nearly 30 years while performing as a left-handed guitar player on the comedian's radio show, died Saturday.
ALBANY, Jan. 80 Legislative leaders, reporting progress in their effort to draft a state lottery plan, tonight discussed a combination based on horse races and "fishbowl" drawings.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union ant employers in the dress industry reached agreement yestetday on a new three-year contract that will give 80,000 workers in the eight-state metropolitan dress market wage increases totaling 15 per cent.
THE private hunting and fishing club in Quebec may be on its way to becoming a thing of the past as the provincial government pushes ahead with plans to force many of the clubs out of business.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 30 Joseph L. Mailly, who had been removed as acting postmaster of Jersey City after an investigation into alleged loansharking, theft and improper use of Government equipment, resumed his career as a policeman today.
GRAPEFRUIT is one fruit that is widely available in winter, and it needn't be restricted to serving on the halfshell. Here is a recipe for a molded grapefruit dessert.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 Support for the liberalization of the state's abortion law was voiced today by the Episcopal Diocese of Albany.
LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP) King Charles I, executed 318 years ago by Oliver Cromwell, was remembered today by a group that laid wreaths on his statue in bustling Trafalgar Square.

MIAMI, Jan. 80 (AP) Wheatley Stable's highly regarded Bold Monarch raced to an impressive victory in the seventh race at Hialeah today, winning by two lengths in the excellent time of 1:09 4-5 for six furlongs over a fast track.
Prices didn't change much in the bond market yesterday, but the calm was deceptive.
The Edison Savings and Loan Association announced yesterday the election of Lawrence O. Langerfeld as president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- Former Ambassador George F. Kennan told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the growing independence of nations within the Communist world had opened up encouraging possibilities for improved East-West relations.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Jan. 30 Striking teachers will return to their classrooms tomorrow as a result of an agreement reached at 3 A.M. today after 20 hours of negotiations between their representatives and the Board of Education.
ROME, Jan. 30 Pope Paul VI raised today with President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union the issue of the almost complete elimination of organized Roman Catholic presence on Soviet territory.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 30 (UPI) Briggs Cunningham, the man who guided Columbia to victory in the first America's Cup challenge involving 12meter sloops, was named yesterday to try to duplicate the feat this Year.
The American Symphony Orchestra played two-a-day at Carnegie Hall yesterday to audiences that were as happy as schoolchildren; in fact, they were schoolchildren.
British Overseas Airways Corporation announced yesterday that it would ask the British Airports Authority for permission to buiid a $17-million passenger terminal at London Airport.

UNDER the tutelage of Theodore H. White, an old China hand before he became preoccupied with the making of Presidents of the United States, a program last night entitled "China: Roots of Madness," offered a valuable and instructive lesson in the background of the constant turmoil and bloodshed that have plagued the Chinese mainland for over a century.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) President Johnson said Today the bombing of six Yugoslav diplomatic missions in the United States and Canada was "reprehensible." He ordered Government agencies to give every assistance in finding those responsible for the attacks.
EDMONTON, Alberta, Jan. 30 (Canadian Press) An Arctic blizzard apparently has taken the lives of the three beluga whales that remained alive in a hole in the ice 1,200 miles north of here.
ALGIERS, Jan. 30 (Reuters) Algeria tonight bought the British Petroleum Company's distribution network in Algeria as a first step toward creating its own domestic marketing company.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 30 Word was received here today of the death Wednesday in Poona, India, of Dr. Briton Martin Jr., assistant professor of South Asian history at Syracuse University. He was 37 years old.
GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 30 Henry Norman Eyre, president of Bear Travel, Inc., which he bonded is New York after World War II, died today at his home. He was 72 years old.

Despite the development of Dave Bing of the Detroit Pistons into the prime candidate for rookie of the year honors in the National Basketball Association, the New York Knickerbeckers stand stanchly, behind their selection of Cazzie Russell over Bang in last year's college draft.
Dr. Harold Taylor, former president of Sarah Lawrence College, has resigned as president of the American Ballet Theater Foundation, it was announced yesterday. He remains a trustee of the company.
FOUR unbeaten teams survive in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Double Knockout Championship, which began last October.
Dr. Clark Kerr has alleged that early in December a "close supporter" of Gov. Ronald Reagan strongly suggested that he resign before Jan. 1 as president of the University of California.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30 A hundred and fifty students at the University of Saigon medical school staged a brief sit-in today to protest the Government's dismissal of the dean of the school.

Hill, Samuel Co., Ltd., a London merchant banking house, announced yesterday that Richard S. Perkins, chairman of the executive committee of the First National City Bank of New York, had resigned as one of its directors, effective Jan. 31.
LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP) The heads of the central banks of the United States and Britain took issue tonight with President do Gaulle's proposals for reforming the international monetary system.
Three-hundred artists eager to exhibit their work are being sought by the First Annual Jamaica Art Festival, exhibition and competition in Queens.
BOSTON, Jan. 30 (AP) The Yankee Network, one of the oldest regional radio networks in the United States, will cease operations Feb. 26, it was announced today.

WICHITA FALLS, Tex., Jan. 30 (AP) A district court judge dismissed murder charges against Jack Ruby today and expressed regret that the killer of Lee Harvey Oswald had not lived to have "a legal trial in Wichita County."
Remember the old days, when the Rangers foundered and the fans hooted and nothing went right?
A major real estate association proposed yesterday that the city eliminate rent control gradually over the next five years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 President Johnson urged Congress today to authorize a vigorous attack on air pollution through Federal and regional regulatory procedures.
Big-ticket merchandise, such as furniture and applianaces, is taking on a greater importance in door-to-door selling, according to buyers interviewed here yesterday.
Henry G. McDonough, who was the late Charles A. Buckley's closest associate but who advocates a limited reform of Buckley policies, was elected the new Bronx Democratic chairman yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) A space agency study three years ago pointed out the dangers of using pure oxygen in spacecraft but concluded that the relative simplicity of such a system made it acceptable.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 30 (AP) Webster College's president, Miss Jacqueline Grennan, asked the courts today to officially change her name from Jean Marie to Jacqueline.

GIOLINH OUTPOST, South Vietnam, Jan. 29 This lonely border station, a mile from the demilitarized zone astride the border between North Vietnam and South Vietnam, has become the South Vietnamese Army's last bastion in Quangtri Province.
The General Building Contractors of New York State, Inc., has elected Bruno A. Scrufari as president.
WASHINGTON, Jan, 30 English is the kind of language where grown people don't think it's funny to tell a child, "Sit down and sit up."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) Broadcasting stations, not the buyers of TV sets, should finance educational television, Representative Charles S. Joelson, Democrat of New Jersey, said today.

TOKYO, Jan. 30--The triumph of Premier Eisaku Sato's party in the national elections for the House of Representatives was interpreted today as a solid gain for the pro-American element and a severe setback for the pro-Peking leftists in Japan.
Mrs. Hilda Altschul Master, wife of Dr. Arthur M. Master, a cardiologist, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a month's illness. She was 74 years old and lived at 885 Park Avenue.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 30 Dr. Aloysius P. Rictman, a physician active in civil defense work for two decades, died Jast night at his home, 3566 Kennedy Boulevard here. He was 65 years old.
Jacques Nevard, a former New York Times reporter, was sworn in yesterday as the deputy commissioner in charge of press relations for the Police Department.

The opinion of the United States Court of Appeals in the case of two University of Michigan students reclassified after participation in an antiwar rally bars use of the draft to stifle dissent. The decision makes it plain that draft potentials cannot be stripped of the protections of the Bill of Rights a principle that should never have been in question.
BONN, Jan. 31 A reward was paid to the betrayer of Anne Frank and her family, one of the defendants in a trial in Munich said today.
The Metropolitan Opera said yesterday that it would continue its post-performance bus service to the East Side at least until the end of its current season, April 15.

Paramount Pictures Corporation announced here yesterday that it had acquired a 50 per cent interest in E.C.P.P.-Athos Films, an exhibition-productiondistribution organization in France. The purchase was made by Paramount's subsidiary, Paramount Films of France.
BONN, Jan. 31 West Germany and Rumania agreed today to establish full diplomatic relations. The step was hailed here as the beginning of a new political era in Europe.
Andrew L. Bruno, a well- known restaurateur, died Monday in Princeton (N.J.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 121 East 82d Street.
Is there a scale of distances and events so small that time loses its meaning? A leading physicist proposed yesterday that there may be.

Rabbi Mare H. Tanenbaum, director of interreligious affairs of the American Jewish Committee, said in New York that "Rabbi Segal and those who hold his view have an obligation to demonstrate that discussion of religious subjects between Christians and Jews has, in fact, weakened the faith and religious commitment of Jews who have participated in such conversations."
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 31 A bettor who cashed a $14.906 twin-double ticket at Roosevelt Raceway in 1965 was held as a material witness today in Nassau County's investigation of harness racing.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 1 (AP). Bad weather held American air attacks against North Vietnam yesterday to only 31 missions, the United States Command reported today.

Snow or flurries are forecast today for portions of New England, the Central Plains States and in the central and southeastern plateaus. Rain mixed with snow is expected in the mid-Mississippi Valley, showers in portions of the Southern Plains States, and rain along the northern Pacific Coast. It will be clear to partly cloudy elsewhere, with colder weather

For the first time in their existence, the National Catholic Office for Motion Pictures and the National Council of Churches are expected to join shortly in designating a motion picture as the best of the year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Following are excerpts from a statement today by former Ambassador Edwin O. Reischauer before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee:

IN their study for the 20th Fund, "Performing Arts: The Economic Dilemma," William J. Baumol and William G. Bowen say of dance: "Here is a performing art in which there really seems to be a substantial rate of expansion."

A start is at last being made at tackling the immense problem of misery and backwardness in Brazil's vast northeast region, where over 27 million people live in what has rightly been called "a disaster area."

PEMBROKE, Mass., Jan. 31 Mr. and Mrs. C. Bertram Currier of Pembroke and Wellfleet have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catharine Blake Currier, to David O'Neil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horton O'Neil of Cos Cob, Conn.
WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 31 (AP) J. Allen Frear Jr., former Democratic Senator from Delaware, said today that he had never authorized Robert G. Baker or anyone else to purchase any stock for him.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 A statistical survey in hospitals in South Vietnam during De- cember indicates that the war caused more civilian than military casualties among the South Vietnamese.

Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. criticized yesterday the belief that the Vietcong were "the spearhead of a coordinated and disciplined Chinese system of expansion" and that the issue in Vietnam was "the restraint of Chinese aggression."
Mayor Lindsay is scheduled to name four judges today to fill vacancies on three city courts.

At 10 A.M. yesterday, Dr. Vincent Manson climbed out of a battered green car in front of Tiffany Co., dug into his overcoat pocket and pulled out a small, white cardboard box held together by two brown rubberbands.
On Sept. 10, Renault, Inc., began a print ad campaign to rewin the hearts of those Americans who had heard bad things about its automobiles.
BRISBANE, Australia, Jan. 31 (AP) Fred Stolle of Australia defeated Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., 6 3, 10 8, in the professional tennis debut of both players tonight.

A Queens apartment house owner has introduced a goodwill program, including a monthly raffle, superintendents bearing gifts and the publication of his annual report, to keep tenants in five nonrentcontrolled buildings.
Mickey Mantle signed his fifth straight $100,000 contract with the New York Yankees yesterday.
BANKING analysts are betting that they'll soon be grappling with the largest issue of capital notes ever offered by a bank.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 31 A Protestant minister proposed here today that a "theology of fun" be developed to help the churches break out of what he described as their "religious ghetto."

Harrison E. Salisbury told the Overseas Press Club yesterday that the "shock value" of his dispatches recounting civilian bombing casualties in North Vietnam would have been diminished had the American press not ignored articles by "respected" French correspondents who had preceded him there.
Antitrust, a specter that has presumably haunted executives of the International Business Machines Corporation through the years, became a reality yesterday.
Eight major airlines are preparing answers to Civil Aeronautics Board charges that they are conferring "special favor and advantage to selected passengers."
John Mikula, a first classman (senior) from Dayton, Ohio, was confronted with the ultimate test in a basketball game last night in the Fordham University gymnasium.
The New York Commandery and the New York State Society of the Dames of the Loyal Legion of the United States will hold their annual dinner dance on Feb. 13 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom.

THE biggest-ever assembly of student bridge players is expected to gather at Massachusetts Institute of Technology later this month for the annual Eastern Intercollegiate Tournament. Thirty colleges were represented in the 1966 event, including players from as far away as Texas, and Richard Zeckhauser, the tournament director, expects a substantial increase this year.
Herder and Herder, a major American publisher of Roman Catholic books, announced yesterday it had purchased Burns Oates, Ltd., England's oldest and largest Catholic publishing house.

Miss Sabine Cailliau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Cailliau of Sainte-Adresse, France, was married on Saturday to Thomas Madison Haythe of New York. He is the son of Mrs. Barbra Belt Haythe of Greenwich, Conn., and Madison H. Haythe of Greenwich and New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The Patent Office will move across the Potomac River to a building in Arlington, Va., which may be its permanent home.
HUE, South Vietnam, Jan. 31 The grave young educator knit and unknit his long fingers as he spoke.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) The new Federal minimum wage of $l.40 an hour that goes into effect tomorrow will mean only a, "minuscule" increase in national labor costs, a Government official said today.

SYOSSET, L.I., Jan. 31--The engagement of Miss Nancy Lynne Cantwell to Clifton Aynesworth Mann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Mann of Washington, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Albert T. Cantwell.

Louis H. Morin, an inventor and mechanical engineer, who held hundreds of patents, particularly on diecasting and molding machines and separable fasteners, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 888 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.
The Borden Company has realigned its senior management to 'strengthen the company for its future growth and expansion," it was announced yesterday.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended with slight declines yesterday as late profit talking wiped out most of the early gains.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31 (Reuters)--President Tito of Yugoslavia headed tonight for talks with Hungarian leaders in Budapest after four days of discussions with Soviet leaders.
Wheat futures tumbled yesterday, touching new lows in all contracts.

Federal Judge Irving Ben Cooper reserved decision yesterday on a series of motions to dismiss an indictment charging Louis E. Wolfson and three associates with conspiring to breach the securities laws and other irregularities in connection with the purchase and sale of Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation stock.
The city will begin an experimental program March 15 to enable welfare applicants in two districts to obtain relief quickly without being investigated beforehand.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 31 In an effort to "guarantee the integrity" of a sport buffeted by scandal and investigation, harness racing set up today a protective bureau similar to the one that polices thoroughbred tracks.
Walter N. Rothschild Jr., president of Abraham Straus department stores, was named yesterday as the new chairman of the Citizens Committee to Keep New York City Clean.

Gerald E. Rosenberger, chairman of the board of Coro, Inc., leading manufacturer of fashion jewelry, died apparently of a heart attack yesterday at the threshold of his office at 47 West 34th Street. He was 63 years old and lived at 480 Park Avenue.
