By unanimous vote, the City Council set up a six-man committee on the Constitutional Convention yesterday to advance and protect New York City's interests when the state's basic charter is rewritten for the first time in 30 years.

WHITINSVILLE, Mass., Jan. 31 Mr. and Mrs. Oscar E. Erickson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss V. Gail Erickson to Donald H. Cadwell, son of George M. Cadwell of Hastingson-Hudson and New Lebanon, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Cadwell.
DETROIT, Jan. 31 The United States auto industry appeared disappointed tonight that it had not received the time it thought necessary to comply with the new Federal motor vehicle safety standards.

GENEVA, Jan. 31 William M. Roth, President Johnson's newly appoined special representative for trade negotiations, will arrive here tomorrow to discuss ways of speeding up the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting talks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The United States lost $27-million of gold in December and $571-million for 1966, the Federal Reserve Board disclosed today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 31 The retail price of rice in Saigon has jumped 30 per cent in the last month, arousing fears of further, serious inflation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) A Pennsylvania Railroad official said today a plan for reduced rates on container shipments to and from Port Newark, N.J., would be profitable to the railroad even if regular traffic were diverted to it.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 31 Sir Francis Chichester is riding out a gale tonight, having survived the near capsizing of his yacht Gipsy Moth IV which was struck on the starboard side by a freak wave just after midnight last night.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 31 (Reuters) Prime Minister Wilson arrived from London tonight to examine the Belgian attitude toward the possibility of Britain's joining the Common Market.

The capital budget that Mayor Lindsay submits today is the first for which his administration has had undivided responsibility and is the largest in history. Its size is a measure of the city's needs; its character reflects Mr. Lindsay's innovating spirit in municipal government.
Mayor Lindsay will recommend today a 50 per cent increase in the capital budget for the city's health services, which are under investigation by six agencies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) The Government announced today plans for a nonmilitary nuclear explosion equivalent to the Hiroshima bomb, deep underground in New Mexico, in perhaps 7 to 9 months.

The General Tire and Rubber Company exceeded the billiondollar sales mark and the $50million level in earnings last year for the first time in its history, the company's annual report disclosed yesterday.

Thomas E. Jennings of 92-05 Whitney Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens, who retired last year as a sales and public relations representative of Merck Co., Inc., pharmaceuticals manufacturers, died on Friday at Gracie Square Hospital. His age was 67.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 31 (UPI) F.E. Kilroe, the racing secretary, said today that Eddie Neloy had asked that Buckpasser, the horse of the year in 1966, be assigned an impost tomorrow for the Santa Anita Handicap at Santa Anita race track Feb. 25.

OTTAWA, Jan. 31 The Canadian Government is about to issue a limited declaration of economic independence from the United States. It will continue to welcome foreign mainly American investment in Canadian industry but it is determined to erect barriers to restrict American influence on Canadian banking.
"Yes, we do some dirty things in the roller derby," said Larry Smith, a 22-year-old skater, yesterday.

Above are schematic diagrams of the three hatch covers that would have to have been removed for Lieut. Col. Virgil I. Grissom, Lieut. Col. Edward H. White 2d and Lieut. Comdr. Roger B. Chaffee to have got out of the Apollo capsule in which they died last Friday.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 31 The striking United Farm Workers Organizing Committee has singled out La Casita Farms of Rio Grande City, for a "nationwide consumer boycott" to push the strikers' minimum-wage demands.
Dr. Edward Liss, a specialist in child psychiatry and a former pediatrician, died Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 321 East 43d Street and in Westport, Conn.
LOUISVILLE, Ky, Jan. 31 (AP) Cassius Clay, the world heavyweight champion, asked his draft board again today to exempt him from the Army because he was a Black Muslim minister.
BERLIN, Jan. 31 Bishop Otto Dibelius, the Evangelical (Lutheran) Church leader, died at his home in West Berlin tonight. He was 86 years old.
PARIS, Jan. 31 France's wooing of the Soviet Union won her substantial economic and technological gains today, with a promise of more to come.

A report that disputes the recent criticism of mutual funds by the Securities and Exchange Commission has been made by Vance, Sanders Co., Inc., a Boston mutual fund management and distribution company.
An announced crackdown on truck parking violators in the garment district led yesterday to a special meeting, renewed talk of cooperation, and no towing of trucks.
Demand for Government bonds was heavy yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
BUFFALO, Jan. 31 (AP) The Hotel Buffalo, whose guests included four Presidents and such sports notables as Babe Ruth and Jack Dempsey, will be closed tomorrow after nearly 60 years' operation.

SAIGON, Jan. 31 A million people may have slipped from Vietcong control since early 1965. This possibility was based on American intelligence appraisal of an enemy document captured earlier this month.
A mansion in French Renaissance style, at 26 East 72d Street, will house exhibition galleries of Christie's, the London auction concern.
PARIS, Jan. 31 President de Gaulle's political forces opened their campaign tonight for the National Assembly election in March.

Gregory Peck will be the narrator at two concert performances of Aaron Copland's "A Lincoln Portrait" by the Pro Arte Symphony at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I. Lawrence L. Smith will conduct the concerts, which will be held on Saturday evening, Feb. 11, and the next afternoon.

HENRY JAEGER is the newest alumnus of that workshop of writing the jail. He joins Frank Elli, Silvano Ceccherini and Jean Gen t all of whom have books being published in a period of two or three months.

CORINTH, N.Y., Jan. 31 The Rev. and Mrs. Delbert B. Smith of Corinth and Syracuse have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gretchen Joy Smith of New York, to Joel Alan Plotkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Plotkin of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) President Johnson has accepted the resignation of Warren Wiggins as Deputy Director of the Peace Corps and has chosen Brent K. Ashabranner to fill the post on an acting basis.

Three months after she was hit by Japanese planes in Macassar Strait, off Borneo, holed, set afire and left rudderless, the light cruiser Marblehead, still taking water, steamed slowly into an East Coast port, 13,000 miles from the scene of the attack.
The General Motors Corporation, the first of the big three auto producers to announce 1966 results, reported yesterday a drop of 15.7 per cent in earnings on a sales decline of 2.4 per cent.
The Treasury's two new note issues quickly rose above their original prices as they began to trade yesterday but most Government and corporate bonds declined.

Politicians are closely watching the Bronx to see how the Democrats' new county chairman, Henry G. McDonough, will adapt to the vast changes that have been taking place in the business of influencing voters.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 "New and significant manned space flights" by the Soviet Union are indicated" in the near future," the President said in a report to Congress today.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 31 The midyear college examination break that worries all basketball coaches had no visible effect on Boston College tonight.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 31--The former chairman of Yale University's architecture department ended a bitter public controversy here today by resigning the contract to design a high school for New Canaan.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The use of fish protein concentrate made from whole fish was approved today for use in human diets by the Food and Drug Administration.

The Japanese Communist party has disclosed that Mao Tsetung overruled a committee of the Chinese Communist party headed by Premier Chou En-lai and prevented an agreement between the two parties last spring.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) The Federal Home Loan Bank Board relaxed tonight some of the restrictions it placed on advances to savings and loan associations during last year's tight-money squeeze.

After all due allowance for improvements that the Constitutional Convention can make in the lawmaking process at Albany, the big job of self-improvement resides with the New York Legislature itself. And even there, merely changing forms and rules will not suffice to work a revolution for the better. The final product, in lawmaking, will always depend on the political wisdom and courage of the membership.
Lill Kraus, now two-thirds of the way through her Mozart piano concerto marathon at Town Hall, seems to be holding up well.
Two nationwide polls show that Mrs. John F. Kennedy's popularity has declined following the controversy over William Manchester's book about her husband, "The Death of a President."
French astronomers, making observations through American and French telescopes have confirmed their earlier discovery of a new moon in orbit around Saturn.

URGING Americans to "make a significant contribution to conservation," the Secretary of the Interior, Stewart L. Udall, has kicked off the season for the purchasing of the $7 Golden Eagle Passport to federally controlled recreation areas.
When Keith Funston becomes a "private citizen," his primary business affiliation will be as chairman of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation.
The formation of Knight Gladieux as a general management consulting concern was announced here yesterday.

The American Natural Gas Company announced yesterday that its preliminary consolidated net income for 1966 had reached $46.9-million, equal to $3.03 a share on 15,477,455 shares outstanding. This compared with the $43.7-million or $2.83 a share on 15,472,879 shares outstanding at the end of 1965.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31 Fred Van Beuren 4th of Mexico City has arrived at the age of 23 at the threshold of the big time in automobile racing.

TOKYO, Jan. 31--The Buddhist sect called Soka Gakkai (Value-Creating Society) has grown as a political force in Japan. This became clearer in the national elections to the House of Representatives last Sunday.
WASHINGTON. Jan. 31 (AP) Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine was named today to succeed Senator Warren G. Magnuson of Washington as chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Secretary of The Treasury Henry H. Fowler sought today to ward off amendments to an Administration bill to raise the national debt limit from $330billion to $337-billion.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--About 2,000 clergymen and laymen demonstrated in front of the White House today to urge a reappraisal of American policy in Vietnam.
The subways are getting safer all the time; according to John J. Gilhooley, a member of the Transit Authority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) A group of student leaders met for nearly two hours today with Secretary of State Dean Rusk and afterwards a spokesman said "our questions [about Vietnam war policy] weren't answered satisfactorily."

WHATEVER one thinks of Nietzsche's "Also sprach Zarathustra," it does contain rapturous paeans to nature and to life. In its orchestral setting by Richard Strauss, it is a superbly colored, thoroughly Germanic exposition of the nature-painting aspects of the poem. In its choral setting by Frederick Delius, it is a rich, sensuous, gorgeous work that strikes far deeper than the Strauss. It has a kind of rapture that matches the rapture of the original.

The Surrogate's Court here was asked yesterday to officially declare that Mr. and Mrs. Stephen R. Currier, two of the nation's leading philanthropists, died two weeks ago on a flight from Puerto Rico to St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands.
MONTEREY, Calif., Jan. 31 Vice Adm. Arthur G. Robinson, who brought home the Marblehead, the ship that was "bombed to hell" in World War II, died today at Fort Ord Hospital. His age was 74.

Harold J. Grossman, one of the nation's leading authorities on wines and spirits, died yesterday of a heart attack at the Trafalgar Hospital, 161 East 90th Street. He was 64 years old and lived at 460 East 79th Street.

ATLANTA, (AP) Because of early detection and treatment, infectious syphillis in America showed an annual decrease in the fiscal year 1966 for the first time since 1957, the Communicable Disease Center reported today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The State Department sees no change of position in two weekend statements by Hanoi concerning possible peace talks.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 31 A leader of the largest Orthodox Rabbinical Association in the United States assailed Jewish secular organizations today for engaging in "religious doctrinal dialogues" with Christians.

A two-week test of night and weekend check-ups on complaints of air pollution showed it was "very difficult to catch violators at nighttime hours, although the public does seem to want somebody to complain to."
A series of "clubs" will begin opening in two weeks at department and men's specialty stores throughout the country, which will feature a new type of high-quality, and high-price appeal.

Net income of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway rose last year to a record $93,448,219, or $3.54 a share, from $90,952,024, or $3.45 a share, in 1965, the railroad reported yesterday. Operating revenues climbed to $728,781,947 from $667,402,313.

DETROIT, Jan. 31 (AP) Little Eddie Tolan, the midnight express of University of Michigan track, and the first Negro to be called the fastest man alive for his successive dash victories in the 1932 Olympics, died today. He was 57 years old.
A new three-year agreement between the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and five employer associations will provide $12 a week is wage increases for 10,000 embroidery workers.
PARIS, Jan. 31 The trick to seeing a collection de- signed by Madame Gres is not to psychoanalyze it or her.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 31 Dr. Sobhi Kahhala resigned today as chief of the Arab Jordan River Exploitation Authority. The resignation, which took place in Cairo, appears to complete the eclipse of the three anti-Israel, Pan-Arab organizations organized in 1964 at the first meeting of Arab heads of state.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Senator Thruston B. Morton, accusing the Administration of "timidity," called on President Johnson today to press more forcefully for Senate ratification of the consular treaty with the Soviet Union.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31 (AP) Chinese anti-Soviet demonstrations were reported today to have spread from Peking and other world capitals to Hanoi in North Vietnam, and to Sana, in Yemen.

GENEVA, Jan. 31 The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that it was extremely concerned over recent air raids against the civilian population in Yemen and neighboring regions by the United Arab Republic.
The stock market started off on another advance yesterday but stalled in a barrage of profit taking that gained momentum toward the close.
The Home Insurance Company of New York reported yesterday an adjusted gain of $6,072,377 from insurance operations last year, contrasted to a loss of $23,626,379 in 1965.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 31 (UPI) A Negro woman who said she was "too scared" to continue her case dropped a $20million lawsuit today against a group of law enforcement officers whom she had accused of killing her husband. The case was dismissed by United States District Judge Harold Cox.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell gave $32,460 yesterday to the lawyer for a 70-year-old widow as payment on a defamation-of-character judgment he owed her.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 31 Published descriptions of the last moments of three doomed astronauts aboard the Apollo 1 spacecraft were said today to have prompted James E. Webb, Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, to ask the special board of inquiry to release preliminary accounts of what happened.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 1 (AP) A United States Marine A-6 Intruder accidentally dropped two 250-pound bombs on a Marine company's position today, killing one marine and wounding 11 others, a spokesman said.
The Citizens Budget Commission announced yesterday the election of seven new trustees.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 31 Technicians here are preparing the nation's third Lunar Orbiter photographic laboratory spacecraft for a launching Friday night.
The chief executives of the El Paso Natural Gas Company and the Beaunit Corporation confirmed yesterday that they were exploring the possibility of merging Beaunit into a new El Paso subsidiary.
Litton Industries has acquired Wilson Transit Company's Great Lakes water transportation business, Roy L. Ash president of Litton, and E.T. Binger, president of Wilson Marine, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The man who was the second American in space and the eager beginner who would have been the 20th were buried today, side by side, on the crown of a high hill in Arlington National Cemetery.
The American Can Company announced here yesterday that it achieved record sales and earnings last year for the second consecutive year.
The Manhattan Shirt Company announced yesterday a low-level blend durable-press dress shirt for fall, 1967, to retail for $5.

Sales and income of the United States Steel Corporation recovered so sharply in the fourth quarter of 1966 that its profits for the year, at $4.60 a share, just missed the 1965 level of $4.62 a share.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) Senator Clinton P. Anderson, chairman of the Senate space committee, said today that the use of 100 per cent oxygen as atmosphere in space capsules "should be questioned again" in the light of two fatal fires.

LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP) Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin has decided not to bring Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko along on his week's visit to Britain starting Monday, British officials said today. Keen disappointment was reported in Government circles.

Silvercup Bakers, Inc., sued, nine competitors and two officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters for $22,472,000 yesterday, charging that they had conspired to ruin Silvercup's business in the area.
BURSA, Turkey, Jan. 31 (AP) Police officials reported tonight that a ski patrol had found an American couple who were Peace Corps volunteers and who had been missing for three days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) An eye doctor told a Senate subcommittee today he and his colleagues prescribed 83 per cent fewer glasses in 1965 than did another group of ophthalmologists who own an optical company.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 31 The United States presented $1-million to the United Nations Children's Fund today to mark the fund's 20th anniversary and the award of the 1965 Nobel Peace Prize to the fund.

AS a benefit exhibition, "Treasures from the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute," opening to the public tomorrow at Wildenstein, 19 East 64th Street, is a reminder that, although the excitement about the floods has died down, Italian art has not made a correspondingly quick recovery.
The American Bankers Association held a post-mortem yesterday on the collapse of the Pioneer Finance Company and heard some conclusions that were not very reassuring.
The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation announced yesterday in Owensboro, Ky., the election of Franklin K. Rader as executive vice president.

William Jovanovich, president of Harcourt, Brace World and also an author, has accepted the invitation of the University of California at Berkeley to serve as Regents' Lecturer, During February and March he will go to Berkeley to deliver two public lectures and to conduct six seminars in the department of education. Regents' lecturers at the university have included C.P. Snow, James B. Conant and Jean Renoir.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 31 (UPI) William Loeb, newspaper publisher challenged Cartha D. DeLoach, assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, today to a joint lie detector examination to determine the truth about statements Mr. DeLoach is reported to have made to Mr. Loeb about the James F. Hoffa case.
A flashy fourth quarter enabled the New York Knickerbockers to snap a five-game losing streak by defeating the St. Louis Hawks, 139-120, before 15,078 spectators at Madison Square Garden last night.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 31 The Belgian Government protested today against restraints placed on the freedom of European employes of the Belgian-controlled Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga.
Virginia Morris Pollak, a sculptor and art adviser, died of a heart attack yesterday at her apartment in the Ritz Tower, Park Avenue and 58th Street. She was the wife of Leo Pollak.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 City Controller Alexander Hemphill resigned today to seek the Democratic nomination for Mayor of Philadelphia.

"THE DEER PARK" is like a child you're rather fond of who's behaving quite foolishly in the living room and before company, too but who isn't going to be sent out of the living room because, by God, he's kind of cute.

American Ballet Theater will give the premiere of the first domestic professional production of the complete Petipa and Ivanov version of Tchaikovsky's "Swan Lake," on Feb. 16 in the Chicago Opera House. It is a little more than 62 years since the ballet's premiere in St. Petersburg. Although American ballet has bided its time in the matter, the production, successful or not, cannot fail to be a landmark in American dance.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 31 Manhattan College trounced Dartmouth, 72-37, in a dual track meet today.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 The legislative leaders of both parties agreed today on a compromise measure to control lobbying on constitutional amendments before the opening of the State Constitutional Convention, April 4.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) The United States has developed a "hardened" nuclear warhead capable of penetrating sophisticated Soviet defenses, the Atomic Energy Commission told Congress today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Challenging Administration views, former Ambassador Edwin O. Reischauer told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the United States had overestimated the military and political menace posed by Communist China.

Actors Equity has reversed its stand on the casting of Margaret Leighton for the fall revival of "The Little Foxes." The union had protested the hiring by the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center of a British actress.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Behind the seasonal commotion at the White House these days there is an unmistakable sense of motion--up from the doldrums.
ELEOCHARIS tuberosa was one of five appetizers and oryza sativa one of six main dishes served at a dinner in Brooklyn one night this week.
VIENNA, Jan. 31 Bruno Pittermann Austrian Socialist leader, announced his intention to resign to a tense party congress today.
Giovanni Martinelli sings again!

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) Secretary of the Navy Paul H. Nitze posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor today to a Marine first lieutenant killed in a third attempt to rescue a wounded comrade in Vietnam.
The port's 3,400 striking tugboatmen got the unqualified backing of 10 maritime unions representing more than 100,000 members yesterday in their three-day old dispute with tugboat operators.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 31 The Jagadguru Shankaracharya of Puri, one of India's most revered holy men, ended his fast against cow slaughter today on the 73d day.

MAMARONECK, N.Y. Jan. 31 Mr. and Mrs. Hans Lowey have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Lowey, to Andrew Michael Edelman, son of Mrs. Harold E. Edelman of New York and the late Mr. Edelman.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Today's reception was proof enough that the presentation of White House portraits can be pleasant.

David L. Yunich, president of Macy's New York, will be host at a luncheon today at the Savoy in London to present plans for Macy's Festival of Britain. The import promotion will be staged by 14 stores in the Macy New York group in fall 1968.

It would be presumptuous nay, downright foolish for nonspecialists to intervene in the dispute between the shade of Albert Einstein and so formidable a contemporary physicist as Princeton's Prof. Robert H. Dicke.

DONMATIAS, Colombia, Jan. 27 A priest who has been in this village 7,000 feet in the Andes for less than two years is embroiled in a bitter fight to break the area's centuries-old feudal submissiveness.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 31 Harry Laurie scored on four free throws and Ken Grant connected on two in the closing seconds tonight to assure a 91-87 victory for St. Peter's over Hofstra in a Metropolitan Basketball Conference game.
A campaign by the maritime trades unions to keep the nuclear merchant ship Savannah in operation gathered momentum yesterday.
The appointment of Glenn W. Johnston as president of the Lehn Fink Products division of Sterling Drug, Inc., was announced here yesterday.
HONG KONG, Jan. 31 Western political analysts said today that Communist China seemed to be preparing to provoke the Soviet Union into breaking diplomatic relations.

American business can help underdeveloped nations in North Africa through profit-making investments, a group of executives was told yesterday by members of a trade mission that recently visited Libya, Tunisia and Morocco.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Following is the text of a layman's version of the motor vehicle safety standards issued today by the National Traffic Safety Agency. The official text, much of it highly technical, is expected to be published later this week in the Federal Register.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Hornblower have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Hornblower, to John Frederick Cosgrove, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Cosgrove of Los Angeles.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 31 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Adam Malik urged today that General Suharto, the effective head of Indonesia's Government, use any means, including force, to topple President Sukarno.

LJUBLANA, Yugoslavia, Jan. 31 (UPI) The Soviet Union's star ice-skating duo of Ljudmilla Byelousova and Oleg Propopopov scored 104.1 points tonight to lead the opening pairs competition in the European figure-skating championships.
Active demand for the pound's sterling pushed up the spot rate another eight points to $2.7948 in strong trading on foreignexchange markets here yesterday.

Following are the issues in the tugboat strike involving 3,500 men who normally operate 450 harbor craft, ranging from tugs to tankers and self-propelled and non-propelled barges. The men are members of Local 333, United Marine Division, National Maritime Union. The 60 employers are represented by the Marine Towing and Transportation Employers Association.
Marshall McLuhan, whose exploratory journeys toward a philosophy of communications have raised some communications problems of their own, is getting an assist from the National Broadcasting Company.
LONDON, Jan. 31 The British-American Tobacco Company improved its bid today for shares of Yardley Co., Ltd., the perfume and cosmetics manufacturer.
The will of Charles A. Buckley, the Bronx Democratic leader who died Jan. 22 at the age of 76, was filed yesterday in Bronx Surrogate's Court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 "America must come to accept the human and practical reality that the masses of nonwhites in the ghettos are not expendable," the executive director of the New York Urban League told a delegation of New York Congress members today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Two young Governors with progressive records asked Congress today to give the states more authority and more money under the Federal system.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 103 on Monday from 102.9 on Friday.

MIAMI, Jan. 31(AP) M. R. Guerrini's Farmer's Son, the favorite, took the lead at the start of the last sixteenth of a mile and then held on to win by a nose from Glassell B. today in the seventh race at Hialeah before a crowd of 14,746.
Steinway Sons opened the doors of its Astoria factory yesterday to show about 135 members of the music profession and press how a mahogany beam goes round and round and comes out a piano.
TORONTO, Jan. 31 The Governor of the Bank of Canada, Louis Rasminsky, has joined the battle against efforts by the First National City Bank of New York to expand its operations in Canada.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 31 (AP) An Air Force scientist said today that prolonged exposure to a pure oxygen atmosphere might cause a change in the body's balance of red blood cells.

BONN, Jan. 31 European motor vehicle production set records in 1966. The West German automotive industry association reported today that 9.1 million vehicles were produced last year, up from 8.6 million in 1965.

Mrs. Minna Ysaeva Tulchin, a former concert singer and the wife of Dr. Simon H. Tulchin, a noted clinical psychologist, died Monday in her home, 47-13 39th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens. She was 69 years old.

A GROUP of left-wing Japanese scholars in 1965 held a roundtable discussion at which they vigorously attacked United States policy. But when it was suggested that their opinions be published in a magazine, they balked. "If these are printed," one of them protested.

A financial organization, a beverage company and an advertising agency have named new executives. They are Robert S. Eisenhauer, vice president of customer and public relations at Investors Diversified Services; David Alan Kirsch, executive vice president and marketing di rector, and Lee Kirsch, vice president, both at the No-Cal Corporation, and Robert McIntyre, senior vice president at Lennen Newell, Inc.
A credit-card holder whose card is stolen without his knowledge is not responsible for debts incurred against it by the thief, according to a ruling by Civil Court Judge Harold Birns.

JERUSALEM (Israel), Jan. 31 Three officials of the Feuchtwanger Bank, taken over last week by the Bank of Israel, were jailed today for 10 days on suspicion of using bank funds improperly for their private companies.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 31 (AP) Four ethnic Chinese carrying pistols and hand grenades held about 400 teachers and Chinese students at bay in the Chinese section of Saigon today while they made an appeal for the National Liberation Front, police sources reported.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 President Johnson sent to Congress today proposals to give servicemen, veterans and civilians in war zones a total of $250-million a year in added benefits.
Schenley Industries, Inc., announced here yesterday the election of C. Orville Schupp as president of its production division, Schenley Distillers, Inc. The post is a new one.

JOPLIN, Mo., Jan. 31 (AP) Robert Bolivar DePugh, former leader of the Minutemen organization, pleaded nolo contendere today to a charge of violating the National Firearms Act and was sentenced to one year in prison.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 A government witness who says he was a member of a bank robbery ring allegedly masterminded by John (Sonny) Franzese caused a furor in Federal Court here today when he testtified about plans to rob Yonkers Raceway in 1965.
ALBANY, Jan. 31--A bill designed to remove the stigma of accepting welfare aid was passed in the Assembly today.
PARIS Despite differences on other issues, Moscow, Peking and Hanoi fully agree that there shall be no negotiations on Vietnam unless there is first an unconditional end to U.S. bombing of the North.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 A national civil rights organization urged Congress today to withhold approval of Weston, Ill., as the site for the world's largest atom smasher pending "broad, specific action" by the state of Illinois and the city of Chicago to "open wide the doors of equal opportunity" for Negroes.
LINTRIGUE, 35 West 56th Street, Bob Carroll, singer: Joe Beck, instrumental combo.

WHEN Brooklyn was in the National League and when Ebbets Field was populated by slews of quaint charac- ters, the quaintest of them all at one time unquestionably was Uncle Wilbert Robinson, the Falstaffian manager of the Dodgers. He rode herd on the Daffiness Boys and he was well qualified for the assignment. Here was a guy who really belonged.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 31 Mr. and Mrs. Harold Heiser have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Heiser, to Lawrence Mitchell, son of Mrs. Andrew Mitchell and the late Mr. Mitchell.

SOME of the most Scandinavian-looking stoneware being made today comes from Laurel Bloomery, Tenn. Its international character stems from seven years of travel by a California woman to improve her potting skills.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) A coalition of dissident Democrats and Republicans on the House Banking Committee won a preliminary victory today in a drive to curb the powers of the committee chairman, Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The National Traffic Safety Agency issued today the nation's first set of Federal standards for vehicle safety.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 31 Two airmen were killed today when an oxygen-filled spacecraft simulator caught fire during an experiment at the Brooks Air Force Base School of Aerospace Medicine.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 31 Gov. Ronald Reagan presented to the Legislature today a "strict economy budget" of $4.6-billion and expressed alarm over an "upward spiral" in state government costs.
MADRID, Jan. 31 (Reuters) A Spanish student fell to his death from a sixth-floor window during a police raid on his home here today, heightening tension over clashes between the police and students.

LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP) Lord Harewood, cousin of Queen Elizabeth and former director of the Edinburgh Festival, is being considered as a possible successor to Rudolf Bing as general manager of New York's Metropolitan Opera, The Evening Standard reported today.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 1 The Peking radio said today that Mao Tse-tung's forces had gained control of a fifth major city, Kweiyang, the capital of Kweichow Province.

Within the next decade, Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., plans to open at least one store a year, to acquire other successful stores or chains and to expand to other major cities across the country.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 Legislation that would permit flat tracks in New York to keep a bigger share of the money bet daily was proposed today by Governor Rockefeller.
The "Chrysler Theater," a series of one-hour weekly television dramas on which Bob Hope appears as host, will be discontinued at the end of this season.
The New York Racing Association regards Governor Rockefeller's pari-mutuel tax proposal as only the first half of what it hopes will be a winning daily double.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Feb 1 (AP) Karl Mildenberger survived a first-round knockdown and outpointed Piero Tomasoni of Italy in 15 round, to retain his European heavyweight championship tonight.
Ernest Westmore, Hollywood makeup artist, a member of a family prominent in the movie industry for more than four decades, died yesterday at the Park Sheraton Hotel. He was 63 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--President Johnson asked Congress today to set aside nearly 143,000 acres of wild coastal range north of Los Angeles as perpetual wilderness.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 1 (AP) Some 800 northern Kentuckians debarked from 21 buses today and peppered Gov. Edward T. Breathitt with complaints and questions for a memorable "citizens' day."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) A Peace Corps volunteer on her way home after a two-year tour in India was found dead today in her hotel room in Teheran, the Peace Corps reported.

RAHWAY, N. J., Feb. 1 Arthur J. Murphy of 617 Bryant Street, a former member of the local Board of Health and long a civic leader, died yesterday at the Alexian Brothers Hospital in Elizabeth. His age was 72.

A new exhibition, "Musicals of the 1930s," will open at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, on Feb. 14. The display will feature custumes, photographs, scenery, costume designs,...
JERUSALEM (Israel), Feb. 1 The Foreign Ministry announced tonight that Michael Comay, the Israeli representative at the United Nations, would be coming home in a few months.

LONDON, Feb. 1 The House of Commons yawned through its first experimental morning session today. Morning sessions, approved in December, are the first cautious step toward modernizing Commons procedure.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Raynham Townshend have announced the engagement of Mrs. Townshend's daughter, Miss Suzanne Ridgway Robertson, to Second Lieut. William Emerson, U.S.M.C.R. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Emerson of Concord, Mass.
Sugar futures took off on a price-rising spree yesterday sustaining a recent uptrend Trading volume set a record for 41 years at 3,870 contracts.

HOUSTON, Feb. 1 Miss Orisa Echhardt, daughter of Representative Robert C. Eckhardt of Houston and Washington and of the late Mrs. Orissa S. Eckhardt, was married to night to Lawrence Warren Arend. He is the son of Mrs. Eiwin S. Barrow of Austin and the late H. O. Arend.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) The Federal Power Commission announced today its intention to appeal to the Supreme Court a decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit that sent back to the commission for futher proceedings the complex Permian Basin natural gas rate case.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The Treasury announced tonight an allotment of 10 net cent on its new notes of 1968, and 7 per cent on the notes of 1972.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 1 (UPI) Six passengers were killed and 12 others were injured today when an interstate bus rolling through the night with most of its occupants asleep, struck a parked tractortrailer and was sheared almost in half.
The assessed value of taxable real estate in New York City has risen to a record high of $32,970,642,511, according to a tentative estimate of property assessments for the fiscal year 1865-66.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 Following is the text or the annual budget message sent to the Legislature today by Governor Rockefeller:

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 1 (AP) Marquette's high-pitched Warriors held St. John's without a field goal for 11 minutes 27 seconds and rolled to a 7154 surprise basketball victory tonight. Fordham Defeats N.Y.U. In Swimming by 63 to 41 Fordham led by Charles Gulotta, defeated the New York University swimming team for the first time in 19 years today. 63-41, at the winners Rose Hill pool.
MADRID, Feb. 1 Manuel Benitez, Spain's most celebrated bullfighter, who had started as a briklayer, announced in Cordoba today his retirement at the age of 29.

SESTRIERE, Italy, Jan. 30 High in the Piedmont Alps, just a short distance from the old mule trail used by Napolean and his troops more than 1 centuries ago, this famous ski retreat finds itself with surprisingly little snow.

Paperboard production rose 3.4 percent with 167,100 tons in the week ended Jan 28. from 136,800 tons in the corresponding 1966 week the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Mike Mansfield, Senate majority leader, appealed to the Senate today not to let "the tragedy of Vietnam" prevent "rational consideration" of legislative steps to improve East-West relations.
Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands and Gen. Lauris Norstad, U.S.A.F., retired, are honorary co-chairmen of the National Air Force Salute to be held on Feb. 21 at the New York Hilton.
BOLOGNA, Italy, Feb. 1 (UPI) It was not a bird. It was not a plane. It was the opera "Carmen." And the audience last night went bam, pow, zowee with rage.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) Cutting through usual routines, the Senate confirmed today the appointment of Gen. Joseph H. Nazzaro as commander of the Strategic Air Command.

Attended only by gulls, the Queen Elizabeth undertook the risky task of docking without tugboats yesterday as the tugboat strike made the harbor look emptier than city streets in the towaway campaign.
Sale in the city's department store, rose sharply in January over the level in the 1966 month, primarily because the 13-day transit strike held down volume last year.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 1 Tennis leaders from all parts of the United States gathered here today with a single, rankling question looming large in the background: How to regain international supremacy in the sport.
PEKING, Feb. 1--Chinese demonstrators pulled a French Embassy official from his car outside the mission today and forced him to stand below-freezing cold for nearly seven hours.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) --Senator Jacob K. Javits, New York Republican, introduced today his own version of legislation designed to prevent discrimination by emlployers against "washed-up" workers 45 and older.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 A member of the Federal Reserve Board rejected today the widely held view that interest rates might have to be kept fairlyhigh in the United States this year to hold money at home and thus protect the balance of international payment.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 Governor Rockefeller proposed today a record state budget of nearly $4.7-billion, balanced by lottery proceeds, accelerated incometax collections and heavy sale of bonds.
The arts will an airing at Washington's John F. Kenned Center for the Performing Art even before the first building is up.

A speed-up of "a year and possibly more" in creating a strong regional air pollution commission and enforcement in the New York metropolitan area was envisioned yesterday by Federal officials under the Johnson Administration program.

PARIS, Feb. 1 (AP) A slight touch of influenza caused Senator Robert F. Kennedy to curtail some of his appointments today as he wound up a three-day fact-finding visit to Paris. The New York Democrat goes to West Germany tomorrow.

Publishers generally approach the publication of a first novel with the view that it represents an investment in the future of the author. Coward-McCann has a happily different outlook on Norman Bogner's "Seventh Avenue,"...
Jimmy Durante and Casey Stenbel were honored by the New York Catholic Youth Organization's Club of Champions last night at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Mrs. Helen Ufford Butler, a retired newspaper columnist and magazine, editor, died Tuesday in her home at 200 East 66th Street. Her age was 84 and she was the wife of Dudley Butler.

SAIGON, Feb. 1 The Year of the Goat begins next week in Asia and Vietnamese astrologers predict on the basis of past performance that it ought to be a good year for peace. That is the clearest forecast available here as to what the next twelve months may bring.

WOLFVILLE, N.S. Feb. 1 (Canadian Press) Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court said today that one of the most serious threat to individual privacy in the United States was a proposal to create a Federal data centre.

About two and a half years ago, the sportsmen at Abercrombie Fitch changed their advertising style getting away from sketches of hunters and skiers and introducing brightly written copy with the personal approach.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The Federal Communications Commission agreed today to let the Justice Department present to it whatever evidence it has that that the acquisition of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation could seriously hurt competition in broadcasting.
Declines outnumbered advances yesterday in a downand-up day on the American Stock Exchange.

The Hupp Corporation, a diversified manufacturer, announced yesterday the election of John F. Reed as president to succeed Don H. Gearheart. Mr. Gearheart continues as chairman and chief executive officer.
ROME, Feb. 1 (UPI)--Pope Paul VI has launched a new campaign for peace in Vietnam and has asked President Nikolai V. Podgorny for help, high Vatican sources said today.
NOW that the tight money screws have been loos- ened, some mutual funds are beginning to take note of high quality finance company stocks.
The appointment of Donald H. Kallnum to the new post of financial vice presidend and corporate counsel of the Manhattan shirt Company was announced here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) The Senate Rules Committee cut some $430,000 from the more than $5-million requested by Senate committees for spending outside their regular budgets.

Thirty families were left homeless last night after a multi-alarm fire that broke out in one Harlem tenement house spread to two others. There were no serious injuries, but two patrolmen rescued eight small children from a fire escape as flames swept through one of the buildings.
PARIS, Feb. 1 A nationwide 24-hour strike called by two of Frances three powerful labor-union federations was only partly effective today.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 1 (AP) Jndge Roy L. Stephenson of United States District Court issued a temporary restraining order today barring the Department of Labor from enforcing the new minimum wage law of $l.40 an hour in Iowa's state and local governments.
MIAMI, Feb. 1 (UPI) Ethel Jacobs's Reflected Glory rallied from next to last place in a 16-horse field today to take the $34,850 Bahamas Stakes at Hialeah by a neck over the favored Bold Hour.
The stock market retreated yesterday as profit takers again chipped away at the gains recorded in January.
The criminal trial that has come to be known as "the poor, man's circus" reaches the summing-up stage today in a court that has been called "the Barnum and Bailey Room" at 100 Centre Street.
A delude of corporate offerings and plans for new financing hit Wall Street yesterday, with $100-million of Morgan Guaranty Trust Company notes making the biggest splash.

NEWROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 1 Twelve demonstrators, including three ministers, were arrested this morning in a second protest against alleged antiNegro discrimination on construction jobs at an urban renewal site here. The ministers also had been arrested last week.

DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Palmer Taylor have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara, Anne Taylor, to Philip Flint Metcalf of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Rich Metcalf of Auburn, N.Y., and Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

PARIS, Feb. 1 France's last marshal, Alphonse-Pierre Juin, was given a hero's burial today under the gold dome of the Hotel des Invalides, resting place of Napoleon and most of France's most famous generals and marshals.

A nationwide forcast of housing starts in 1967 foresees an increase for New York City that will add 48,300 dwelling units to the housing supply. The figure would be an increase of 1.7 per cent compared with the number of housing starts in the 12-month period that ended last October.
The New York Stock Exchanges, which threatened to leave New York State last year because of an increase in the stock transfer tax, may solve its housing problem temporarily by expanding next door.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 A House Select Committee invited Adam Clayton Powell Jr. today in defend himself in person next Wednesday against challenges of his qualification to be a member of the House.
Two voluntary hospitals reported yesterday that the death rate had declined by as much as 35 per cent in municipal hospitals with which they were affiliated.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 2 (AP) A platoon of the United States First Infantry Division suffered heavy casualties today when it was attacked in predawn darkness by an enemy force in the so-called Iron Triangle area northwest of Saigon.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (UPI) The third winter storm in six days pummeled Chicago tonight as the city still reeled under last week's 26-inch snowfall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The Administration will go ahead with development of a supersonic airliner. But a 39-word announcement by the Federal Aviation Agency disclosed today that the airlines would be asked to help carry the financial burden of building test planes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 If President Johnson gets the funds he has requested for the year beginning next July 1, the Government will spend twice as much for the poor as it did in 1963 and two and one-half times what it spent in 1960.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) Five civil rights workers staged a sit-in at the Pentagon today near the office of Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara. They said they were protesting alleged discrimination in off-base housing for Negro servicemen.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb, 1 (AP) Geoffrey O'Hara, whose rollicking song "K-K-KKaty" pepped up many a marching column in World War I, died last night. He was 84 years old.
THE deluge of children's books continues unabated, with a diversity that ranges from da Vinci to diving suits.
Even the person who likes to think income-tax-return time is a long way off (April 17 is the deadline) usually cannot resist the urge to add up his 1956 income from the...
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 1 Army's hockey team defeated Hamilton, 6-2, today.

MADRID, Feb 1 Fifteen thousand students at the University of Barcelona began a 48-hour strike today in sympathy with the demands of fellow students at universities in San Sebastian, Valencia and Madrid for an independent student union.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The two-day Washing- ton engagement of the Harkness Ballet, which ended tonight at the Lisner Auditorium, was ostensibly most remarkable, if not in the event most notable, for...
Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., is adding sugar to its widely diversified interest.

New York Mailers Union No. 6 presented new contract proposals yesterday to the Publishers Association of New York City that called for a $30-aweek pay increase for members on the day shift and a $50-aweek increase for those on the night shift.
WASHINTON, Feb. 1 (AP) Maj. Gen. Carl A.Hardigg, former chief of the subsistence section in the office of the Army quartermaster general, died Sunday at Fort Bragg. N.C.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 1 (AP) Pfc, Thomas Clark is 18S years old and is headed for Vietnam. He says he is going so his married bother will not have to take the risk.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Manufactures inventories, which had been rising at the very large rate of $1-billion a month ever since the end of June, increased by a little less than $800-million in December, the Commerce Department reported today.
ALBANY, Feb, 1 Governor Rockefeller's proposed budget disclosed today that the bootlegging of cigarettes has cost New York State and New York City about $40-mil lion a year in lost tax revenue.
Firth Sterling, Inc., a producer of specialty steels, announced yesterday in Pittsburgh the election of Ralph W. Rawson as chairman and chief executive officer.
TRENTON, Feb. 1 A bipartisan legislative reapportionment commission was deadlocked here tonight over the drawing of boundaries for the state's 80 new Assembly districts.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company announced here yesterday the election to its board of Olcott D. Smith, chairman of the Aetna Life and Casualty Insurance Companies.
Our world, our galaxy and the entire universe may be immersed in a sea of tiny particles, known as neutrinos, whose presence to date had eluded observations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The air is full of hints of cultural fatigue. Nobody talks about Batman any more or jokes about Andy Warhol paintings. Nobody gets really excited any longer about Bogart film festivals. The Beatles may dis-band, and nobody cares.

Maurice Sanders, deputy chief probation officer of the United States District Court, Southern District of New York, died at Midtown Hospital Tuesday after a short illness. He was 65 years old and lived in Paterson, N. J.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board blamed pilot inexperience today for the crash of a private plane that took three lives last April 10 near North Collins, N.Y., south of Buffalo.
Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 A young woman rushed up to Stewart Lee Udall at a party in Washington recently and said: "I should be introduced to you because I'm a bird-watcher."

CAIRO, Feb. 1 (AP) The Egyptian Government has again denied charges that its forces in Yemen have used poison gas. It called for an investigation of the allegations by a United Nations fact-finding commission.

CRESSKILL, N. J., Feb. 1 Dr. and Mrs. William James Follette have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sharon Lee Follette, to William Lee Tift, con of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Handing Tift of Macon, Ga.

Earnings of the Phelps Dodge Corporation increased sharply last year to $82,883,000, or $8.17 a share, from $67,747,000, or $6.68 a share, the year before, the preliminary report of the copper-producing concern disclosed yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 1 (AP) Superior Court Judge Cornelius J. Moynihan denied today a new trial for Albert DeSalvo, the self-proclaimed Boston strangler, who was ... victed on Jan. 13 of assaults on women, burglary and robbery.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 1 President Johnson appealed to Israel and the Arab states today to "go that extra mile with us" in the search for peace in the Middle East.
President Johnson's news conference, scheduled for 3 P.M. today from the White House, will be carried live on television and radio.

DETROIT, Feb. 1 The new management of the troubled American Motors Corporation told a lively but good-natured stockholders meeting today it plans to reintroduce the oncesuccessful Rambler compact car.

Miss Alfreda L. Madison is a licenccd teacher who has not taught a day in a city school in two and a half years. For the last 11 months, she has not been inside a public school building, here except on brief occasions.
Newsweek magazine may drop its coverage of television as a separate department because it feels that the medium has declined in quality and variety.
SHERMAN OAKS, Calif., Feb. 1 Richard L. Breen, a screenwriter who in 1954 won an Oscar for his work on the film "Titanic," died today at St. Joseph's Hospital in Burbank, Calif. His age was 47.
TERESA BERGANZA, the popular Spanish mezzo- soprano or mezzo-coloratura, as she is billed gave a recital last night before a good-sized audience in Philharmonic Hall.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced plans yesterday to cut rates on calls between the mainland and Hawaii.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 1 (AP) A Federal judge ruled today that Alabama should continue to receive Federal welfare funds until the courts could review the situation.

The huge sum of almost $4.7 billion that Governor Rockefeller seeks in his new budget accurately reflects the state's growing responsibilities. His plans for acquiring the necessary revenues without resort to increased taxes are much more precarious and problematical.
THE open-air exhibition of eight large sculptures by Tony Smith currently on view in Bryant Park at Sixth Avenue and 42d Street is the sort of event that invites discussion on more than one level.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The United States has proposed to the Latin-American countries that a Latin common market start in 1970 and achieve complete free trade among the member countries by 1980.

TALKEETNA, Alaska, Feb. 1 (AP) An eight-man international team has begun the first attempted winter ascent of 20,320-foot Mount McKinley, a bush pilot, Don Sheldon, said today after a radio message from the climbers.

"MY body still hasn't adapted itself to the difference in the time" said Kerry O'Brien of Australia. his hazel eyes clouding over wearily. "I still have trouble in sleeping, even on the night after a race when I should be exhausted."
HUE, South Vietnam, Feb. 1 A smile has returned to the face of Hue, but it is hard to tell whether it reflects an inner calm or masks a carefully concealed discontent.

SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Feb. 1 (UPI) The son of the United States Ambassador to Germany was under observation by Santa Cruz County psychiatrists today after the police said he nearly ran his car into a crowded school bus while under the influence of LSD.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 1 (Reuters) The Belgian central bank reduced its lending rate today to 5 per cent from 5 per cent, effective tomorrow.
It is not every week in wintertime that New York becomes the site of an indoor tennis tournament. Two tournaments a season would be the most in the past.

The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen yesterday called a strike against the Long Island Rail Road for 4 A.M. Saturday. But within two hours of the threat, the wlkout was averted for at least 30 days by Federal intervention.
Despite the publicity by newspapers, radio and television since the city "no exceptions" towaway program went into effect on Jan. 23, an average of about 200 cars are impounded daily.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 About $2-million in fellowships were announced today by the National Endowment for the Humanities.
Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Dorn of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Thesrese Adelaide Dorn, to Paul Anthony Bernbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Bernbach of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) The nation's major railroads and six shopcraft labor unions threatening a strike late next month have agreed to a 15-day extension of a moratorium in their contract dispute, it was announced today.

Ignoring Moscow's latest charges of a Nazi resurgence in West Germany, Rumania's Foreign Minister has agreed in Bonn to establish full diplomatic relations with the Federal Republic. The Soviet propaganda blast, in fact, is a grudging tribute to the success of Bonn's diplomatic offensive in Eastern Europe.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 Governor Rockefeller's proposed state budget includes a record $1-billion for New York City, but not a penny of the $300-million in new money that Mayor Lindsay requested last December.

Bookmakers in the metropolitan area handle more than a $100-million a year in bets on horse races and sporting events, United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday. The bookmakers' profits about 40 per cent, he added.
Negro leaders have urged President Johnson and the State Department to cancel plans for a Navy aircraft carrier to make a four-day stop at Capetown this weekend.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L. I., Feb. 1 Australis, the national open jumper champion the last two years, has been sold to J. L. Simpson of Calgary, Alberta. Danny Lopez, Australis's owner-rider since the 8-year-old bay mare came off the racetrack as a failure four years ago, made the announcement tonight.
BREBACH, Germany, Jan. 6, Listening to the songs of Franz Josef Debenhardt for the first time, one is tempted to draw parallels with other well-known lyric writers.
Emmett I. Poons, a former economics professor at Cty College, was accused in Supreme Court yesterday of scheming to defraud New York doctors, dentists and taxicab drivers of nearly $2-million.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The Administration abandoned today bitterly contested plans for two power-producing dams in the the Grand Canyon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered hearings today on its charges that Pakco Companies, Inc., had failed to disclose material facts about its operation in its public reports.

The revised version of the Central Arizona Project as set forth yesterday by Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall is a substantial victory for all those who have fought to protect the Grand Canyon from desecration. We congratulate President Johnson and Secretary Udall for having the wisdom to take a fresh look at a complicated problem and the courage to change their minds.
The Internal Revenue Service, apparently unswerving in its intention to be kind to taxpayers, has promised prompt payment of refunds to taxpayers entitled to them.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 1 Dr. and Mrs. Allan Fromme of Bronxville and Westhampton Beach, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Pamela Jane Fromme, to Lee Stephen Formato, son of Mr. and Mrs. Austin P. Formato of Eastchester.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Governor Rockefeller declared today that attempts to call him a Presidential candidate for 1968 were deliberately designed to split the Republican party and weaken the chances of Gov. George Romney of Michigan.

Leonard Shure, the pianist, returned to Carnegie Hall last night for his first local recital since 1963. Mr. Shure made his debut in 1934 and was acclaimed. He played frequently over the years, but has been devoting his time more to teaching. Currently, he is teaching in Austin, Tex.

Picasso's "Femme Couch e Lisant" ("Reclining Nude Reading"), the artist's gift to raise funds for the salvage of flood-ravaged art hi Florence, will have its first public exhibition here tomorrow and Saturday.

Harry Scherman, who was 80 years old yesterday, received among his batch of felicitations a note of thanks from Columbia University for the gift of several thousand papers dealing with his life's work.
A 31-year-old Brooklyn housewife gave birth to quintuplets last night.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 1 Richard A. Hoover, general manager of the Pittsburgh Playhouse for 21 years. resigned today, effective June 30. He said he has decided for personal reasons to "consider other areas of activity."
SAN FRANCISCO "We just gave up our little beach house in Aptos." Mrs. Louie Benoist said. "Thank goodness. We only had a cleaning woman and not enough time to cover all those bases."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The deaths of three astronauts in a spacecraft fire at Cape Kennedy last week has made oxygen the heart of a controversy that could delay the Apollo lunar landing program for months or years. At the least, the National Aeronautics and space Administration is certain...
British Government bonds closed steady but industrial issues eased yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Feb. 1 (UPI) Top-seeded Roy Emerson andd Kerry Melville led an Australian delegation into the quarter-finals of the Auckland invitation lawn tennis tournament today. Rosemary Canals of San Francisco posted the lone American triumph.
ROME, Feb. 1 (UPI)--The trial of 32 Italians, Americans and Frenchmen on charges of smuggling nearly half a ton of heroin began today.

TORONTO, Feb, 1 The Dutch will buy 105 CF-5 jet fighters from Canada in a major defense transaction valued at as much as $180-million in Canadian funds, or about $165 million in United States money, Canada and the Netherlands announced today.
DETROIT, Feb. 1 (UPI) The Detroit Pistons broke an eight-game home-court losing streak by defeating the New York Knickerbockers, 104-101, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 Alan S. Boyd, secretary of the new Department of Transportation, today urged formulation of a new transportation plan for the country providing for increased Government participation, more coordination among all parties involved and restoration of fair profits.

BONN, Feb. 1 Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger said today that the forthcoming exchange of ambassadors between West Germany and Rumania would not alter the West German Government's position that it "alont has the right and duty to speak for all of the German people."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 1 (AP)--The Chamber of Deputies approved today President Eduardo Frei's constitutional amendment permitting him to dissolve Congress, but the measure is expected to run into stiff opposition in the Senate.

A capital budget of $1,081,982,771 for the fiscal year 196768, the largest construction program in the city's history, was submitted by Mayor Lindsay to the Board of Estimate and the City Council yesterday.

The board of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., has named an executive management committee, a finance committee and appointed three new executive vice presidents, J. W. Schwab, chairman, announced yesterday.
The Fairchild Hiller Corporation has decided to build a new short-range jetliner even though it does not expect to sell any for about a year.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 1 (AP) Honeywell, Inc., an electronics concern specializing in automatic controls, was shut down today by a strike of some 10,500 workers, a spokemen said.
The spot rate on the British pound continued steady in busy trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.
TOKYO, Feb. 2 About 20,000 troops have retreated from Shihotze, an anti-Maoist center of resistance in Sinkiang, according to reports from Peking.

The engagement of Miss Marian Kuehns, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ernest Kuehns of Manhattan, to Dr. Melvyn S Goldenberg. son of Mrs. Sidney J. Hersh and David Goldenberg has been announced by the future bride's parents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) The New York Central Rail road entered an objection today to a Pennyslvania Railroad plan to offer a special rate on trainload shipments of container units between Port Newark, N.J., and the Midwest.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Feb. 1 With the persistence of inchworms, teams of Federal technicians are alowly moving across the face of Long Island and disturbing the status quo.
An 78-year-old youth shot and killed himself yesterday, while demonstrating the game of Russian Roulette to a younger sister and three neighborhood teenagers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) --The White House said today that President Johnson would probably not send Congress a promised special report on the Vietnam war--at least not soon.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Feb. 1 (AP) The Congo rejected today any participation of the outsted Union Miniere duHaut-Katanga mining company in its Congolese successor, the Generate Congolaise des Minerais.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) Professional antipoverty workers criticized the Agriculture Department today and said that the responsibility for developing programs for the rural poor should be vested solely with the Office of Economic Opportunity.

Percy Van Gelder Mitchell, who retired in 1941 as vice presidend for passenger traffic of the United States Lines, died yesterday in Phoenix, Ariz. He was 90 years old and lived in Scottsdale, Ariz. He previously had been a resident of Summit, N.J.
A drifter was arraigned yesterday in the fatal stabbing of a 58-year-old man who tried to act as a peacemaker in an argument over two cents in a Lower East Side grocery store.
HONG KONG, Feb. 1--Efforts by Mao Tse-tung's partisans to smash established authorities and establish a rigorous type of Communism in China have brought them some, gains in recent weeks.
BOSTON, Feb. 1 The future of the successful air shuttle operating between Boston, New York and Washinton may depend on how well a challenger does with its coffee and other in-flight amenities.
LISBON, Feb. 1--Portugal said tonight she had promised Communist China she would not allow Macao to be used against China's security.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1, North Vietnam, through diplomatic intermediaries, has drawn the attention of the United States to its latest official statement on the possibility of peace talks, usually informed sources said today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 1 A "serious conflict" in the Syrian leftist regime between Maj. Gen. Salah Jadid, the country's strongman, and Maj. Gen. Hafez Assad, the Defense Minister and Air Force commander, has been reported in the pro-Cairo newspaper Al Anwar.
Samuel Crowther 3d, a rewrite man for The World Journal Tribune, died Monday at Columbus Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived at 72 West Hudson Avenue, Englewood, N. J.
Goodbody Co., a partnership and one of the few brokerage houses to publish detailed earnings data reported record income from operations for 1966 yesterday.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 1 A duplicate Apollo spacecraft was shipped here today for examination by investigators in their effort, to trace the cause of the explosive cockpit fire that killed the three astronauts here last Friday.
Padraic Colum, the 85-yearold dramatist who is better known as a poet, children's story writer and folklorist, has written "The Road Round Ireland," a folk play with music.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 1 (UPI) Buckpasser was assigned top weight of 130 pounds today for the 30th running of the $145,000 Santa Anita Handicap Feb. 25 at Santa Anita race track.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 The meeting of President Nikolai V. Podgorny, chief of state of an officially atheistic country, with Pope Paul VI has been reported on the front page of Pravda, the Soviet Communist party paper and produced hardly a ripple of comment from Russian readers.

The first joint meeting in two days between tugboat operators and Local 333, United Marine Division, ended in a deadlock yesterday and sent the strike by 3,400 of the port's tugboatmen into its fifth day.
LONDON, Feb. 1 Britain has agreed to give Zambia 13.8-million (about $38-million for projects intended to tighten the United Nations Security Council's sanctions against Rhodesia.
Alexander Levene, a retired Manhattan lawyer, died Sunday in Harlkness Pavilion, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 82 years old and lived at 22 East 88th Street.

Mrs Monique von Mudra McKellar, daughter of Alfred von Mudra of Einbeck, Germany, and Mrs. Charlotte von Mudra of Palo Alto, Calif., was married to Ricard R. Ohrstrom of New York on Jan. 3 in a civil ceremony in Mexico. The couple were remarried on Jan. 27 in a civil ceremony at Garrison, N. Y.
The New York Mets signed Tommy Davis for $47,000 yesterday and said that he would be the team's regular left fielder, would play every day and bat clean-up.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) Christians and Jews throughout the United States were urged today to join in a threeday "Fast for Peace" beginning next Wednesday.
DETROIT, Feb. 1 Two auto manufacturers called back some 2,100 trucks today for inspection and possibly repairs.

HAWTHORNE, N. Y., Feb. 1. If you are caught in a police radar trap and accused of speeding, don't tell the officer whom you know in City Hall but talk to him about the fine points of the Doppler shift in radar.
COPACABANA, 10 East 60th Street. Tony Bennett, singer; Gene Baylos, comedian.

WASHINGTON, Feb.1 (AP) Ralph Nader, author of the book "Unsafe at Any Speed." said today that officials of the National Traffic Safety Agency had exhibited "poor performance" in issuing auto safety standards yesterday.
PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Feb. 1 (UPI) Byron Nelson won the Professional Golfers Association quarter-century championship today by two strokes.

The New York State Banking Board approved yesterday the proposed acquisition of the Liberty National Bank and Trust Company in Buffalo by the BT New York Corporation, the big bank holding company that controls the Bankers Trust Company here.

SACRAMENTO, Calif, Feb. 1 --The $4.6-billion budget given to the California Legislature yesterday by Gov. Ronald Reagan was attacked today by the Senate Finance Committee's chairman as a "Regan coupon budget."

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 1 The engagement of Miss Emily Hamilton Agnew to John Evon Nelson 2d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Rea Agnew Jr., parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Nelson is the son of Wenley Dodds Nelson of Kolding, Denmark, and Mrs. Richard Coast Murphy of Greenwich.
Investors Diversified Services, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday that combined net income last year rose to $24982,235, or $3.66 a Class A share and 92 cents a Class B share.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The Federal Government awarded today the second largest grant in the history of its buiidingdemolition program to New York City.
Leopold La Fosse, who made his local debut at Town Hall last night, is a violinist of solid training. His tone glistens, his bow arm is stanch and his fingerwork agile.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Federal Government began today an inquiry that may provide relief for pedestrians, uncomfortable passengers and intimidated motorists in the nation's cities.
A group of letters, written by King Edward VII of Britain when he was Prince of Wales, to the actress Lillian Langtry were bought tonight by a Boston book dealer.

A RECENT social evening among members of the Marshall and Manhattan chess clubs, at the latter's quarters ended with an informal 16-board team match. The Marshall club fielded three women on its team, the Manhattans, one.
PARIS, Feb. 1 The Roman Catholic Bishops of France made public today a statement, of regret at the tone of a warning from Rome on the doctrinal ferment in the church.
PRAGUE, Feb. 1--An American of Czechoslovak birth was sentenced today to eight years' imprisonment on charges of subversive activities against Czechoslovakia on behalf of France.
Lord Taylor and B. Altman Co. will be the first stores to open branches in the new Fashion Center in Paramus. N. J., the two Manhattan-based stores announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Governor Rockefeller appealed to Congress today to make the preservation of state governments one of its major objectives. Otherwise, he said, the states may "go under."
Deputy Administrator Jacob Levine of the Health Services Admistration, a 30-year career man in city government, will leave municipal service Feb. 28 to become a vice president of Yeshiva University.

VIENNA, Feb. 1 Dr. Bruno Kreisky, former Foreign Minister, was elected the leader of Austria's Socialist party today. He succeeds Dr. Bruno Pittermann, the former Vice Chancellor, who resigned the party chairmanship last night.

CHICAGO, Febv. 1 (UPI) Kenny Wharram's two goals led the Chicago Black Hawks to a 6-1 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight, increasing Chicago's National Hockey League lead to 11 points over the idle New York Rangers.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 1 Sometimes the unexpected can happen when golf is played in the desert. Jay Dolan 3d, a 27-year-old New England professional from Leicester, Mass., led the opening round of the Bob Hope Desert Classic today with a six-under-par 66.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 A key witness for the Government in the bank-robbery trial of John Sonny) Franzese was confronted today with letters he wrote in prison demanding that the Government live up to a "deal" It had allegedly made with him.

Roller-derby skaters usually have recuperative powers matched only by professional wrestlers. But Joan Kazmerski, a girl with hair the color of a ripe banana, received such a hard jumping hip-block from Joan Weston last night that she was hospitalized.
