The New York Marine Corps Scholarship Foundation will hold its annual Leatherneck Ball on Feb. 17 in the WaldorfAstoria's Grand Ballroom.
EL CENTRO, Calif., Feb. 1 (UPI) A member of the Navys Blue Angels precision flying team was killed today when his Grumman F-11A Tiger jet crashed in the desert on a training flight.
NORTH BELLIMORE, L.I., Feb. 1 A 62-year-old Episcopal Church here went into court today in an effort to remain open.

The women's division of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York opened its 1967 campaign yesterday at a luncheon at the Voisin Restaurant. 30 East 65th Street. A record first-day total of about $1,100,000...

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 1 Federal District Judge W. Harold Cox, who held up a grand jury reinvestigation of the Phil- adelphia and Vernon Dahmer civil rights murders earlier this month, has decided to call a Federal grand jury here Feb. 20.
WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 1 (AP) Three civil suits filed in Delaware's Superior Court seek a built $9-million in damages from Pierre S. du Pont in connection with not-too-sucessful motion pictures.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 1 Twenty-one nations in the Western Hemisphere today began working sessions that are expected to lead to a treaty barring nuclear weapons from Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 House Democrats refused today to restore committee seniority to Representative John Bell Williams of Mississippi, who was disciplined two years ago for openly supporting Barry Goldwater for President. The vote, by secret ballot, was 134 to 100.
Ellen Stewart's Cafe La Mama is probably the bestknown of the off Off Broadway showeases, but Joe Cino's Caffe Cine at 31 Cornelia Street in Greenwich Village is the oldest.

PARIS, Feb.1 Many Americans arrived in Paris last week, but George Hamilton, the actor and beau of Lynda Bird Johnson, is one of the very few whose reason for coming was not that the French haute couture springsummer collections were in full swimg.
Keeve M. Siegel resigned yesterday as chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Conduction Corporation, following a policy dispute with the McDonnell Company.

SUNTHERIZATION, as it must to all continents, has come again to South America, in another marvelous plum pudding of a book. John Gunther is the main marvel. As McLuhanites and aficionados of spiritual seances might say, he is the medium and the message. He is unable to write a lifeless sentence.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 2--Despite gusty desert winds, Gene Littler and Don Massengale broke par today and shared the lead at the 36-hole mark in the $110,000 Bob Hope Desert Classic golf tournament.

ELIZABETH, N.J. Feb. 2 William J. Murphy of 741 Magie Avenue, a department supervisor in the Newark office of the Prudential Insurance Co., died last night at his home after a short illness. His age was 60.
RICHMOND, Feb. 2 (AP) Chuck McKinley opens the defense of his championship in the second Fidelity Bankers invitation tennis tournament tomorrow against a field that outranks him.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) Business is good but would be even better if a special trainload rate was permitted on the shipment of containers by rail to and from the Middle West an official of a shipping company said today.
ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP) Walt Disney Productions to- day announced it would build the world's first glass-domed city in central Florida amid Disneyworld, a $100-million entertainment center.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 2 The Right Rev. Richard Beamon Martin was consecrated Suffragan Bishop of Long Island in the Cathedral of the Incarnation here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) Arizona's former governor Sam Goddard, said today he had nothing to do with any complaints that led to the transfer of a top Air Force general reportedly critical of administration policy.

LONDON, Feb. 2 The Government reported today a skimpy-looking rise of 11 million ($30.8-million) in ,January in Britain's reserves of gold and dollars, but official sources encouraged' the belief that the "true gain" was several times greater.
Fannie Rose, an actress in the Yiddish theater, died Wednesday in Miami Beach. She was 77 years old and lived at 25 East Third Street.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 2 A newspaper editor who quit his job because he disagreed with a polilical editorial his employers insisted he publish has been ruled eligible for unemployment pay.

MIAMI, Feb. 2 (AP) Topweighted Bold Bidder, the 1966, handicap champion, will passup the $50,000 added Seminole at Hialeah Park Saturday because of leg trouble. But his trainer expects him to run in the $100,000 added Widener Handicap Feb. 18.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 One of the National Traffic Safety Agency's top engineering consultants, William I. Stieglitz, resigned today in protest against the Federal standards for vehicular safety that were issued Tuesday.

THERE was nothing quite so disturbing about last night's angry (contra Vietnam war) arts protest at the Hunter College Playhouse or at least let honesty amend to admit pure self-interest there was nothing so disturbing for the daily reviewer as the time the protest took to protest. It was long. Yet much of it was also interesting.

ATLANTA, Feb. 2 Hardly anyone paid any attention one morning recently when the Georgia House of Representatives passed a resolution taking note of National Negro History Week, but the action was of more than passing interest to State Representative Julian Bond.
RICHMOND, Feb. 2 (UPI) The Federal Housing Authority has urged Negroes here to move into all-white suburban residential Sections.

A record $2.6-billion was collected last year by the Bureau of Customs in duties and excise taxes and turned over to the Treasury Department, it was reported yesterday by Lester D. Johnson, the United States Cummissioner of Customs.

American Eagle, the 12-Meter yacht whose wings were clipped by Constellation for the defense berth in the final selection trials of 1964, will be back in the America's Cup defense picture next summer.
The proposed merger between two major American ship-officer union, representing deck and engine-room personnel, has cleared another hurdle.

SAN FRANCISCO There is no place in America where residents dine with more grace and style than in this golden city by the Bay. There is a commendable choice of good restaurants, but equally important is the attitude of San Franciscans and of restaurant staffs toward dining out.

PLEASANTON, Calif., Feb.2 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Russell P. Studebaker of the engagement of Mr. Studebaker's daughter. Miss Phyllis Studebaker, to Richard J. Larschan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Larschan of New York.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 2 The engagement of Miss Susan Elizabeth Wright to Henry Moore Kennedy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy of South Orange, N.J., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James B. Wright Jr.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 2 South Africa has agreed to assume greater responsibility for the defense of the southern sea route around Africa.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 2 (UPI) --Oscar Robertson, who had left the game early in the third quarter with a slightly pulled left hamstring muscle, returned to spark Cincinnati to a 131-125 victory over Baltimore tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
HOFGASTEIN, Austria, Feb. 2 (AP) Gerhild Schiffkorn of Austria won the first title today in the World Skibob championships.

The four surviving infants of the first quintuplets in the city's history were squirming healthily yesterday in their incubators at the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, where they were born Wednesday night. Physicians there said "there is every indication that they will survive."
LANSING, Mich., Feb. 2 Gov. George Romney, in a televised budget message tonight, called for Michigan's first income tax.

The refusal of the House Democrats to restore Representative John Bell Williams of Mississippi to a senior place on the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee is as much a victory for the status quo as for the principle of party responsibility. If Mr. Williams were given back most of the seniority he lost two years ago as punishment for bolting the party to support the Goldwater candidacy, he would gain at
CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) A new snowstorm moved into northeastern New York and northern New England today, dumping heavy snow, sleet and freezing rain.

Edward R.L. Corballis, a retired British wing commander who was made an officer of the Order of the British Empire for his World War I service in the Royal Flying Corps, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital, Winter Park, Fla. He was 76 years old and had moved from New York to Winter Park in 1963.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Feb. 2 John R. Brady, a former member of the public relations staff of the F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company. Brooklyn, died Tuesday at his home here. Mr. Brady, who was 71 years old, lived at 85 Tamagues Way.

A revolutionary plan for the development of a master container port on Staten Island is being presented to industrialists, railroad officials and port experts in a series of meetings called by an unusual maritime entrepreneur.

RAE BARELI, India, Feb. 2 As Prime Minister Indira Gandhi left one of her campaign meetings here yesterday, a wizened old farmer in a white skull cap approached her and said, "I've lost my calf; please help me find him."
Argentina will move strongly against inflation within her borders in 1967, Adalbert Krieger Vasena, Minister of Economics, said at a news conference here yesterday.
The Brandenburg Players at Carnegie Hall last night devoted only half their program to the specialty their name implies: two of Bach's "Brandenburg" Concertos (Nos. 3 and 6).
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) The Treasury Department an- nounced today that it would transfer to the Coast Guard on Feb. 21 the technical marine functions now performed by the Customs Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) Harrison E. Salisbury, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times, testified today that he believed the Hanoi Government "is ready to begin to, talk business" about peace in Vietnam but that any negotiations must begin in total secrecy.
ROME, Feb. 2 A Socialist Deputy, Loris Fortuna, sponsor of a bill to introduce civil divorce, expressed the hope today that his bill would be passed "during this legislature."
Mayor Lindsay's appointment of Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, an aide who dispenses patronage, as the city's new Highways Commissioner is expected soon.
The New York Yankees, who have signed only two regular players for 1967, signed five irregular ones yesterday.

DETROIT, Feb. 2 (UPI) Third-period goals by Alex Delveechio and ray Culle, only 11 seconds apart, helped the Detroit red Wings gain a 4-3 victory over the Boston Bruins in a National Hocky League game tonight.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 2 Gov. Ronald Reagan threatened today free use of his veto powers to see that Californians get an economy budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb, 2 (UPI) A Federal judge issued today a temporary restraining order barring a state judge from enforcing a contempt of court citation against an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 The painter of the "Pink Lady of Malibu Canyon," as the work is known locally, has filed a $1-million damage claim against the County of Los Angels for leaving obliterated the painting.

MICKEY MANTLE took the news like a little man. There wasn't the slightest whimper or trace of a tear. Yes, he would be willing to give it a try as the Yankee first baseman and would start this noble--or is it ignoble--experiment in the early weeks of spring training at Fort Lauderdale in Florida this month.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) Harrison E. Salisbury said today that he opposed a unilateral halt in United States bombing raids on North Vietnam.

During the last decade, Cecil Taylor, a jazz pianist, has been one of the most exciting performers in the field for periods of 5 or 10 minutes at a time. And he has tested the endurance of his audiences by surrounding these brief forays with long, long sessions of intense, mind-numbing cacophony.

By STEVE CADY "METACENTRIC height," the teacher said, point- ing to a beat diagram on the blackboard, "is the distance from the center of gravity to the intersection of the center of buoyancy line. Is that clear."

WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., Feb. 2 Mrs. Carolyn Nason Maher's engagement to Peter Nicholson Payne has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Nason. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. May DeForest McAll of New York and Coral Gables, Fla., and the late Oliver H. Payne of New York.
With just a trace of a smile, the Fordham professor picked up a piece of chalk and scrawled the question for the day on the blackboard:
The United States Court of Appeals has dismissed eight antitrust charges against the American Federation of Musicians and its New York branch. Local 802, but found one union practice to be illegal.

Look magazine sued The World Journal Tribune yesterday for more than $700,000 for having allegedly used "unfairly excessive portions" of material printed in the magazine's second installment of "The Death of a President."

SCRANTON, Pa., Feb. 2 O.E. McGregor, former president of the Scranton Chamber of Commerce and a leading figure in the baking industry for three decades, died today at Moses Taylor Convalescent Home. He was 77 years old.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 2 (UPI) The state of Maryland has filed suit in Federal court challenging the constitutionality of an amendment to the Fair Labor Standards Act.
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 2 Sweden's central bank reduced its discount rate today from a record 6 per cent to 5 per cent, effective tomorrow.

HONG KONG, Feb. 2 Communist China violently denounced today reports, which it attributed to the Soviet Union, that it had a tacit understanding with the United States about nonintervention in the Vietnamese war.

Both the National Catholic Office for Motion Pictures and the Protestant National Council of Churches announced their choices of the best pictures of 1966 yesterday, agreeing in only one case. "A Man for All Seasons." The two organizations also made it official that later this month they will for the first time make one joint award for the best film of the year.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 2 (AP) Some 20 to 30 proCommunist Pathet Lao guerrillas raided the airport of Luang Prabang, the royal capital, today and destroyed six T-28 fighters and two helicopters, a Royal Army spokesman announced.
Louis Freiman, a playwright and actor in the Yiddish Theater for many years, died Monday at the Pilgrim State Hospital in Brentwood, L.I., He was 75 years and lived at 310 East 12th Street.
New York City's water supplies contained 343.5 billion gallons, or 72.1 per cent of capacity, at 8 A.M. yesterday, an increase of 1.7 million gallons during the last 24 hours.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Republican leaders said today that President Johnson's budget was so "shabby and phony" that Congress should send it back to the White House for drastic revision.

THE American Broadcasting Company's weekly series titled "Stage 67" paid a taped visit to London last night for a highly uneven hour of variety. The program was described as David Frost's "Night Out in London" and the British humorist indeed produced the show; unfortunately, he was too much the tourist at home.

HARLINGEN, Tex., Feb. 2 (AP) The defending champion, Curtis Person of Memphis, defeated Ell Ruben of Hallettsville, Tex., 4 and 3, today to reach the semi-finals of the life begins-at-40 golf tournament.
Raymond H. Weill, a New Orleans stamp dealer, paid $35,000 last night for an 1869 stamp with an inverted center.
Four new judges of city courts were sworn at City Hall yesterday afternoon by Mayor Lindsay.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 2 The engagement of Miss Patricia Anne Whitfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, G. Bryan Whitfield, to Neil Lutley SclaterBooth, son of George Lutley Sclater-Booth of Pebble Beach, Calif., and the late Mrs. Jeanette Mackelvie Sclater-Booth of New York and London, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

Maralin Niska, who turned out to be one of the Metropolitan Opera National Company's most valuable sopranos in its appearances here last season, suffered a back injury last fall. Not until last night was she able to rejoin the ensemble, when slasang the Countess in "The Marriage of Figaro" at the City Center.

Harold Konigsberg, the 38year-old defendant in an extortion case who is acting as his own lawyer, delivered a fourhour summation yesterday, during which he recited the Preamble to the Constitution and blessed the jurors and their families.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 2 (AP) --The Senate rejected today an effort to tightly restrict outside business activities by its employes. The proposal was an outgrowth of the Robert G. Baker case. The vote was 49 to 28.
MOSCOW, Feb. 2 Izvestia, the Government newspaper, charged tonight that Communist China had hampered and endangered Soviet air transports refueling at Peking for
Mayor Lindsay and his top fiscal aides expressed determination yesterday to fight for more state aid in an all-out effort to avoid new taxes or make deep cuts in services.

Wheat futures have been setting so many lifetime lows recently that traders have been searching for bullish news. Yesterday they found it, apparently word from Washington that the Government plans to send additional wheat to food-short India.

Maurice Cantor, a founder and honorary board chairman of the New York Auction Company, Inc., a leading fur auction concern at 226 West 26th Street, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and lived at 175 West 12th Street.

Wagner College retained its unbeaten record in the Middle Atlantic Conference with a 9375 triumph over Washington College last night at Grimes Hill. Wagner led most of the way, with the half-time score being 42-34.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 2 Talks aimed at settling the Congolese copper dispute have resumed. Theodore C. Sorensen, former United States Presidential adviser, is playing a key role in the negotiations.

THE PRESIDENT Participated in Presidential prayer breakfast with members of Congress, the Cabinet and leaders of the armed forces; saw Gov. Maddox of Georgia; held televised news conference; sent special food for India message to Congress.

"We are pleased to announce that ROSSER REEVES has been admitted to our firm as a Limited Partner effective February 1, 1967," said the little ad in the financial pages the other day. It was signed "Oppenheimer Co."
The election of C. Douglas Dillon, former Secretary of the Treasury, as president and a director of the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation, a closed-end investment company, was an-

A Negro businessman said yesterday that his inability to negotiate a business loan might force the cancellation of plans for both Columbia University and the Department of Hospitals to locate research center, on 125th Street.

ROME, Feb. 2 Senator Robert F. Kennedy said tonight that changes in relations among European states and between Europe and the United States required adjustments and modifications of trans-Atlantic policies.
SMITHTOWN, L. I., Feb. 2-- The Suffolk Republican considered most likely to challenge the re-election of County Executive F. Lee Dennison today withdrew from the race.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Both the State Department and French Foreign Ministry have denied reports that Peking relayed to Washington through Paris its "conditions" for staying out of the war in Vietnam.
LONDON, Feb. 2 Britain offered Malta a "high-powered team of industrialists" today to help meet problems arising from British plans to cut British forces there two-thirds over the next four years.
SAGINAW, Mich., Feb. 2 (AP) A prominent physician and his wife were found shot to death today in their suburban home.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Gov. Lester G. Maddox of Georgia spent an hour today at the White House with President Johnson.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 2 The Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination is investigating reports that Jewish students of the Harvard Law School may have faced discrimination in job placement.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 A holdup man testfying for the Government in the bank-robbery trial of John (Sonny) Franzese and four others admitted here today that he would not hesitate in lie on the witness stand to stay out of prison.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 2 (AP) The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has been given until March to include a higher percentage of Negroes in hiring at its plant at suburban Sparrows Point.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Harley H. Kight have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Jeannette Kight, to Henry Joseph Rode 2d, Son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rode of Scarborough and Davenport.

PRAGUE, Feb. 2 The defense lawyer for Vladimir Kazan-Komarek asked the court today to revoke the eight-year prison sentence it imposed yesterday on the Czechoslovakborn American and expel him from the country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Navy officials said today that there were no plans to cancel the planned visit of the aircraft carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt to the South African port of Capetown despite protests by congressional and civil rights leaders.
YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Feb. 2--While a guard stood watch tonight, the folk singer Pete Seeger gave a concert at Yorktown High School of songs he described as "American as apple pie."
The Federal Communications Commission has taken a first step toward gradually outlawing millions of walkie-talkie radios, which in recent years have become popular with children and grown-ups.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Following is the text of the message President Johnson sent to Congress today on food for India:

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Michael Meehan of 800 Park Avenue and East Hampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maureen Meehan, to Michael Anthony Sennott, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Sennott of Winnetka, Ill.

President Johnson has broken exciting new ground with his proposals to Congress for American participation in a worldwide "war on hunger." His program is both short-run, dealing specifically and immediately with the famine threat in India, and long-term, geared to help willing nations help themselves along the road to self-sufficiency in food.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 A $6-billion increase in the limit on the national debt from $330-billion to $336-billion was approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 2 An Indian Air Force plane shot down a Pakistani military aircraft today when it crossed into India, the Defense Ministry said tonight.

Augusta Ciolli, the actress who portrayed the aunt in the prize-winning television and movie productions of "Marty," died yesterday at Maimonide Hospital in Brooklyn at the age of 65. She was the widow of Joseph de Laurentis and lived at 778 East Second Street, Brooklyn.

After the close of trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, Mary Pratesi, a secretary in the informationservices division, slipped into the exchange's well-equipped broadcast booth, sat down in front of a microphone and delivered a three-minute report, in Spanish, on the day's market performance. Her re-
Mayor Lindsay's appointment of August Heckscher as the new Administrator of Recreation and Cultural Affairs is a felicitous choice.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 3 (AP) American B-52 bombers staged three raids before dawn today on War Zone C, where the Vietcong are said to have their national headquarters.

PARIS The war of the Chinese succession is in effect a struggle between the factions of Liu Shao-chi and of Lin Piao to inherit Mao Tse-tung's massive power. Liu is backed by the regular Communist party apparatus and Lin is backed by Mao with his godlike reputation. Moscow favors Liu, but almost certainly prefers to avoid open intervention.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 President Johnson advised Congress today that he was making an immediate consignment of two million tons of food grains to India. He asked for Congressional approval to send three million tons more, "provided it is appropriately matched by other countries."
SYDNEY, Australia, Friday, Feb. 3 About 1,200 people prayed outtside Pentridge Jail in Melbourne this morning as Ronald Ryan was hanged for the murder of a prison guard.

The Mineola (L.I.) Theater will change its status on March 26 from an unsuccessful commercial stage to a community-oriented nonprofit venture under the auspices of the new Long Island Theater Society.

An eight-point program for new state legislation against air pollution--including tax relief to offset the cost of upgrading apartment-house incinerators here--was proposed yesterday by the city's Air Pollution Control Commissioner.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (UPI)-- Braniff International Airways and the British Aircraft Corporation (BAC) were named yesterday in suits asking $6-million in damages for survivors of persons killed in a crash near Falls City, Neb., last Aug. 6.

TULSA, Okla., Feb. 2 (AP) Four oil companies raised wholesale prices on gasoline yesterday, and two more planned to join today with the increase to be passed along to motorists in Oklahoma and much of the nation at a rate of one cent a gallon.

PARIS, Feb. 2--Pass the message to Marlene Dietrich: Yves Saint Laurent is a fan. The spring-summer collection Saint Laurent showed to the press this morning was drenched with a Dietrich-of-the-nineteen-thirties look. The show went wildly African toward the end, but his...
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 A native New Yorker was appointed today to the $28,000a-year position of Chief of Police of Los Angeles,

Hundreds of angry patrons left the Metropolitan Opera last night after it was announced that the scheduled performance of Benjamin Britten's "Peter Grimes" had been canceled and Verdi's "II Trovatore" substituted.
WAYNE, Neb., Feb. 2 (UPI) A bearded English instructor kept up his rebellion against Wayne State College today even though a court injunction forbade him from stepping onto the campus.

The peaceful conclusion of a new three-year labor contract covering 80,000 New York dressmakers indicates that the recent change in top leadership of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union has not altered the constructive pattern of labor-management relations in the city's biggest industry.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 2 (UPI) Capt. William Carpenter yesterday rescued a major from a plane that had crash-landed.

MADRID, Feb. 2 Students at the University of Valencia called a 24-hour strike today in protest over the entry of policemen last night into the university. About 8,000 of the 8,500 students did not attend classes.
Sidney L. Gardner, an assistant to the Mayor, has left his City Hall post to go to Vietnam as a civilian official with the Agency for International Development.
GROSSE POINTE, Mich., Feb. 2 Miss Mary Leslie Renchard and Henry C. Cashen 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Cashen have made plans to be married here, in July.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 2--Four specialists in international affairs were sworn in at the United States mission today to fill posts immediately below that of Arthur J. Goldberg, the chief delegate.
Paul P. Kennedy, a, reporter for The New York Times for 22 years who specialized in covering Latin America, died of cancer last night at the University Hospital. He was 62 years old.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 (AP) The president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations said today President Johnson had refused to meet with religious leaders who oppose the war in Vietnam.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 2 James J. Davis, a member of the City Council here from 1934 to 1944 and long a Democratic leader in Union County, died today at the Alexian Brother Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 117 Murray Street.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 2 A top space agency official received today the first preliminary but secret report on results of the investigation into the fatal Apollo 1 spacecraft fire.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 President Johnson sought today to overcome Senate opposition to the consular treaty with the Soviet Union by emphasizing that the treaty would raise "no problem" of national security.

Former Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois will conduct a television series here over Channel 4 in which prominent guests will discuss topical issues relating to the national economy. The programs will be presented from 2:30 to 3 P.M. each Sunday, beginning Feb. 26.
IT WAS like taking candy from a baby during Mon day's sale of Treasury securities, as a sudden change in the interest-rate structure brought a splendid kill at Uncle Sam's expense.
Bub Lloyd put on a one-man show last night, scoring 33 points, as he led Rutgers to a 68-57 victory over New York University in the feature game at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) Pilot needs caused by the Vietnam War have compelled the Air Force to transfer older officers from desk duties to flying status, Dr. Harold Brown, Secretary of the Air Force, said today.
BONN, Feb. 2 An American rabbi today accused Josef Cardinal Frings, the Archbishop of Cologne, of having made provocative statements about German Jews.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 The death rate from Hodgkin's disease could probably be cut sharply if more doctors and their patient knew what they should about this form of cancer, specialists believe.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 3 A large-scale, organized revolt in Canton, involving large numbers of Government troops, was reported today from Peking.

LONDON, Feb. 2 Two weeks ago, the Moscow Narodny Bank joined the dozen or so other London banks that are offering to sell certificates of deposits for dollars. A spokesman for the Soviet-owned bank said yesterday that none had been sold so far, and "at the present time, we're not worried."
AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 2 (AP) About 150 persons, including Protestants as well as Catholics, came to the Statehouse in a snowstorm today to support a proposed addition to a Catholic school.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 2 (UPI) --Equador II, an Irish filly owned by Emanuel Mittman, staged a strong stretch rally in the 5,500 features race at Bowie today to win by a length.

WARSAW, Feb. 2 (AP) Diplomatic sources said today that the Soviet Union had informed its Warsaw Pact allies of plans to withdraw about 50,000 troops from Eastern Europe to bolster defenses along the Chinese border.

A decade-long, $1.1-million research program into the effects on fish of the Tocks Island Dam across the Delaware River has been initiated by the Delaware River Basin Commission. The study will also cover lower river fish and shellfish problems.

WASHTNGTON, Feb. 2 President Johnson's chief economic adviser assured Congress today that the President "would be the first" to discard his proposal for a tax increase this year if changing economic conditions made the increase unwise.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 President Johnson said today at a news conference that he was "not aware of any serious effort" by North Vietnam to stop the fighting and move toward peace negotiations. [Question 1, Page 14.]

A special committee of the New York Stock Exchange has recommended that members "not oppose" the Securities and Exchange Commission's request for curtailment of the "give-up." The committee's recommendation was included in a letter from Keith Funston, president of the exchange, that was mailed to members Wednesday night and made available to the press yesterday.

SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Feb. 3 (UPI)--North Korean troops attacked a South Korean outpost near the central part of the demilitarized zone between the two countries early today, the South Korean Defense Ministry said. One North Korean was reported killed in a 20-minute gun battle.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 President Johnson used two well-publicized forums here today to reassure the public that he was reasonable and candid.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 2 Lunar Orbiter 3 is set to be launched tomorrow night on its photographic mission to select landing sites for Apollo astronauts.
LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, Feb. 2 (AP)--Emmerich Danzer of Austria won his third straight European men's figure skating championship today with a dazzling free-skating performance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) President Johnson announced today two new appointments to his staff Irvine H. Sprague as an aide for Congressional relations and William M. Blackburn Jr. as a legal staff assistant.
The bond market, which has left behind the easy sailing of January, continued to move cautiously toward lower interest rates yesterday.
The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday a $50,110,679 profit, equal to $7.27 a share, for 1966, a 20.7 per cent gain above 1965, when earnings amounted to $41,518,728, or $6.02 a share.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) The Navy created a new central authority today to command its "growing strategic forces," including submarinebased Polaris and Poseidon missiles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 President Johnson reaffirmed today his intention to Press ahead with his East-West "bridge building" despite 'some difficulties' that may arise, such as the sentencing yesterday in Czechoslovakia of Vladimir Kazan-Komarek to eight years in prison.

The General Electric Company, whose researches invented synthetic silicone rubber during World War II, has developed a liquid silicone roofcoating material that is now available in commercial quantities.
The Conservative party urged yesterday the defeat of proposed legislation that would relax the state's abortion laws.
Dr. Leon Felde, a Belgian economist who served the United Nations as an adviser, died Wednesday in FlowerFifth Avenue Hospitals. His age was 87.
ST. PAUL, Feb. 2 (UPI) Carmen Salvino, a 33-year-old bowler from Chicago, moved into the lead today after three rounds of the Professional Bowlers Association $50,000 St. Paul open.

YONKERS, Feb. 2 Tonight's harness racing program at Yonkers Raceway was the 27th of the meeting, which began the night of Jan. 3. It marked the start of the second half of the first of three home stands to be offered at the Hillton track this season and the track's management is more than satisfied with the turnouts and the wagering so far.
Mayor Lindsay's plans to increase feature film production in New York moved a step closer to reality last night.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 1 The talk in Europe these days is all about the technological gap between the two sides of the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 The Federal National Mortgage Association, in an action reflecting easing conditions in the money markets, announced today that it would increase the price it pays for mortgages and liberalize other rules of its secondary market operations program.
Stocks turned mixed in late trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
LONDON, Feb. 2 A sizable minority of the Labor Government voted disapproval at a party meeting of the Government's policy on Vietnam.
The first "little borough hall" in Manhattan was opened in a refurbished storefront that once was a grocery at 85 MacDougal Street in Greenvich Village.

Harry Alexander Leach, a stockbroker here who formerly owned and managed the LeachParamount chain of moving picture theaters in Florida, died yesterday at the Wickersham Hospital, 133 East 58th Street. He was 78 years old and lived at 135 East 54th Street.

SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP) The second murder trial of Dr. Carl Coppolino today was ordered moved from Sarasota. The defense and prosecution agreed that pretrial publicity had hurt Dr. Coppolino's chances for an impartial jury.

The Allegheny Power System, Inc., reported yesterday a gain of 7.8 per cent in net income for 1966. Revenues rose by 5.3 per cent, according to J. Lee Rice Jr., president. He placed 1966 net income at $31.7million, equal to $1.64 a share. This compared with 1965 share earnings of $1.52.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, who is chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, introduced a bill today to repeal the law enacted last year to let each taxpayer earmark $1 of his tax return to finance Presidential campaigns.
Beginning Sunday, the New York Central Railroad will provide additional service on both its Hudson and Harlem divisions.
Mayor Lindsay proposed state legislation yesterday that would sharply reduce rents and carrying charges in future middleincome housing projects sponsored by the city.
Sales of new cars for the last 10 days of January and for the entire month were off sharply from last year's levels, according to reports received yesterday from Detroit.

Expansion of United States exports is imperative to reverse the balance of payments deficit. Carl A. Geerstacker told numbers of the New York State Chamber of Commerce at their monthly meeting yesterday.

A 15-story apartment building on the northeast corner of Second Avenue and 62d Street has been sold by Gould Properties, Inc., real estate Investment company, to the Princess Holding Corporation for a price of more than $2.6-million, including cash and mortgages.
HOUSTON, Feb. 2 Poetry and Bernie Glickman reappeared on the boxing scene today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 17 The building of embassies is booming, adding some variety to the saw-toothed skyline of Indonesia's architecturally nondescript capital.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) A White House panel reported today that the individual's "inalienable" right to privacy had been undermined in recent years by electronic and other kinds of snooping.

Allen Klein, business manager for various rock'n' roll stars, has filed suit in United States District Court here against Puritan Fund. Inc. in an attempt to keep the fund from selling its stock in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., to Philip J. Levin or his associates.
Following is a transcript of Presi- dent Johnson's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

THE novice programs in New York tournaments have proved highly successful in attracting players who have played relatively little competitive bridge. But there is an obvious need on a lower level to provide for the needs of those who are inexperienced not merely at duplicate but at bridge itself.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the week ended Jan. 28 was above the comparable week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage during the same period declined.
Mark Fitler Rockefeller held his first news conference yesterday. He slept through most of it.
SEOUL, Feb. 2 President Chung Hee Park today accepted the nomination of his ruling Democratic Republican party to run for a second four-year term in the April presidential election.
Prices of industrial shares on the London Stock Exchange fell back from an earlier advance yesterday.
A trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board found yesterday that the Second Regional Office of the board here had not discriminated against three Negro employes, as they had charged.

BELMAR, N.J., Jan. 30 The engagement of Miss Virginia Kondakjian to Myron Stephen Kavalgian of Belmar, son of Mrs. Araxy C. Kavalgian of Summit and Dr. Aram Kavalgian of Arlington, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Kondakjian, also of Belmar.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 2-- The Cairo radio broadcast declarations today by a Jordanian officer, Major Rashid Mohammed Youssef al-Hamarsha, who accused Jordanian military au authorities of planning to arrange the assassinationof Syrian leaders.

Wilhelm H.F. Schluter, who served in the Navy in the Spanish-American War and both World Wars and retired in 1946 with the rank of commander, died Wednesday in his home at 3715 Avenue I in Brooklyn. He was 92 years old.
LONDON, Feb. 2 (UPI) About 1,000 angry soccer fans, locked outside a packed stadium here last night, battled the police and smashed down two 12-foot high fences during a brawl.
The Ford Motor Company, the nation's second largest auto producer, reported yesterday a 12 per cent drop in 1966 earnings, the first profit decline since 1961.
John Coakley, who claims to have organized the first floating crap game back in 1918, said that times have changed.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 2 (AP) Kel Nagle of Australia, the 1960 British open champion, fired a six-under-par 67 today and grabbed the second-round lead in the $5,600 Victorian open golf tournament.

August Heckscher, cultural adviser to Presidents Dwight D. Eisenhower and John F. Kennedy, was named yesterday by Mayor Lindsay to succeed Thomas P.F. Hoving as Administrator of Recreation and Cultural Affairs and Commissioner of Parks.

The nonpartisan Committee on Constitutional Issues called yesterday for an "all new" state constitution limited to "those fundamental propositions that control the basic relatioship between the state and its citizens."
THE narrowing of the gap between fashions in cloth- ing and in furnishings is immediately apparent in the model rooms opening today on Gimbels' ninth floor.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 2 President Chiang Kai-shek has established a National Security Council with sweeping powers and himself as chairman.

The only previous time Kerry O'Brien and Ergas Leps met in a race, they became a footnote in track and field history. But times have changed. Their clash tonight in the Colombian Mile is the prospective highlight of the 48th annual Knights of Columbus meet at Madison Square Garden.

LAST night's New York Philharmonic concert at Philharmonic Hall brought back that splendid violinist Edith Peinemann as soloist in Dvorak's A minor Violin concerto. The program opened with a briskly paced, if not always well articulated, performance of Mozart's overture to "Cosi fan tutte." The last half was firmly weighed down by Bruckner's Symphony No. 4 in E flat, the "Romantic."

TRENTON, Feb. 2 Governor Richard .J. Hughes Announced today that the state's largest power generating company had agreed to begin switching to low-sulpher fuel oil, thus subatantially dropping the level of sulpher dioxide air pollution in the Northern New Jersey area.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 Dan Gurney of Costa Mesa, Calif., drove a bid 7-liter Ford Mark II to top position today as a field of 60 qualified for thc 24-hour Daytona Continental scheduled to start at 3 o'clock Saturday afternoon. Gurney act a one-lap record of 1 minute 55.10 seconds or 119.165 miles an hour over the 3.81-mile course.

An atmosphere of "hopelessness," testifying to a "dying or dead institution," besets Bellevue Hospital. Kings County Hospital's prenatal patients receive "obvious inadequate medical care." Fordham Hospital's operating room faces "contamination hazards." Harlem Hospital has acute supply shortages.

"To the little birds who migrate and to the little children who fortunately do not, this park is affectionately dedicated," are inspirational words for August Heckscher, whose grandfather wrote them for a plaque at the entrance to Heckscher Park, Huntington, L.I.

OTTAWA, Feb. 2 Finance Minister Mitchell Sharp told a Parliamentary committee hearing today that the Government was favorably disposed toward the idea of permitting foreign-bank agencies in Canada. But he said the idea needed further study and he foresaw no legislation now to permit such a move.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb.2 (AP) Ailing Buckpasser, sidelined with a hoof infection, may stick around Santa Anita for a go in the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap Feb. 25.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 Four bi-mittee, recently critizied Senapartisan bills were introduced for Kennedy's proposals. The today in the Legislature to curb bills must clear through his "abuses" in the Surrogates' committee before being put to

Brandishing something of an olive branch in one hand and the tallest commissioner in sports, the American Basketball Association formally set up shop as a second major league yesterday by hiring George Mikan as commissioner.

A Bronx accounting office allegedly used for a bookmaking ring that had done nearly $500,000 in business in a little more than a week was raided yesterday morning in the basement of an apartment building. Two men were arrested.

LONDON, Feb. 3 (Reuters) France's attitude toward gold, the pound and the dollar were clarified today by French Finance Minister Michael Debre in an interview published by the financial publication, The Banker.
FRESH snow in upper New England and in the Adirondacks yesterday had ski operators in those precints grooming their slopes, stocking their cafeterias and oiling their cash registers.
An upward push in afternoon trading carried a somewhat skittish stock market into higher ground yesterday.
BERLIN, Feb. 2 The foreign ministers of the Warsaw Pact countries are scheduled to meet in East Berlin Monday in what was described by diplomats today as a "show of solidarity" with East Germany.

Weekend considerations lifted the spot rate on the British pound 10 points, to $2.7963, in quiet trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. Publication of Britain's gold and foreign exchange figures for January had little effect on dealings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 High Administration officials are reported to be leaning toward a two-phase Nike-X missile defense for the United States should talks with the Soviet Union fail to produce a freeze on antimissile deployments.

"Mr. Cocoa" had a birthday yesterday, and on these quotation marks hangs the tale about the beginning of the New York Cocoa Exchange. Isaac Witkin, founder of the exchange, marked his 75th birthday and his 53 years in the commodity business.
HONG KONG, Feb. 2 Reports from Communist China hinted today that Mao Tse-tung's political purge might have brought about private accommodations with some high Communist party leaders in some areas.

The County Dollar Corporation, a subsidiary of the Dollar Land Corporation, Ltd., owners of the Cross County Shopping Center, Yonkers, N.Y., filed an action yesterday in the New York State Supreme Court in Westchester County seeking a declaratory judgment to convey to County Dollar certain streets and lots in the Yonkers shopping center.

A new offer was made carly today to the city's 3,400 striking tugboatmen. They will vote on it, at 11 A.M. Sunday at National Maritime Union headquarters, 13th Street and Seventh Avenue. Details of the offer were not disclosed.
LANDSHUT, Germany, Feb.2 (AP) A Bavarian court today cleared the name of a wartime German major who was executed for failure to blow up the Remagen Bridge across the Rhine 22 years ago.
PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 2 The Portland General Electric Company announced here tonight that it would build a $130million nuclear power plant on the Columbia River.

Net income of Pan American World Airways last year climbed to $83,734,000, or $5.37 a share, from $52,075,000, or $3.61 a share in 1965, Juan T. Trippe, chairman and chief executive, announced yesterday.

For a party that has borne the burdens of government for eighteen years, Japan's Liberal-Democrats have won a surprisingly easy election victory. Premier Sato's party suffered some erosion its popular vote fell below 50 per cent but it will command a robust majority of perhaps 286 in a House of Representatives of 486.

"Mr. Cocoa" had a birthday yesterday, and on these quotation marks hangs the tale about the beginning of the New York Cocoa Exchange. Isaac Witkin, founder of the exchange, marked his 75th birthday and his 53 years in the commodity business.

SEASONED ground beef shaped into an oval cake, pan-fried or broiled and then covered with, or simmered in, a brown gravy is called Salisbury steak on menus around town and in some cookbooks, but the origin of this name is obscure.
ROME, Feb. 3 (AP) A Vatican body is investigating a Mexican monastery where women psychoanalysts have analyzed the monks, a Vatican Spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara today presented the Pentagon's Distinguished Public Service Medal to his retiring information chief, Arthur Sylvester.
Subject: Report on Apollo 204 Review Board discussions.
The masters of two luxury liners battled wind, time and tide yesterday to bring their ships safely into their berths without the aid of tugs.
Leave it to Eadie Van Nostrand to offer sea horses at a boat show that previously had been held in competition with a show that occupied a raceway.

CLINTON, N. Y., Feb. 3-- Mr. and Mrs. George L. Nesbitt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Elizabeth Nesbitt, to John William Oppel, son of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore W. Oppel of Pelham.

HONG KONG, Feb. 3 A number of vignettes of the conflict in Communist China, as pictured in the Chinese press, reflect some of the difficulties faced by Mao Tse-tung in his attempts to "remold" national thinking and the party.

Now that President Johnson has thrown his prestige into the fight to win Senate ratification of the Soviet-American consular convention, the treaty's prospects have improved; but the battle is not over.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Feb. 3 (UPI) A 20-year-old skipper, Scott Allan, defeated the former America's Cup skipper, Bob Bavier, of the New York Yacht Club today in the Congressional Cup yachting series.

A philosophy reference work that started out to be one book by 25 authors appeared this week as an eight-volume, 5million-word encyclopedia with 500 contributors. The Macmillan Company and The Free Press published the work, "The Encyclopedia of Philosophy."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 3 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky, apprehensive that peace negotiations might start before South Vietnam could elect a new government, called today for a speed-up in the election process.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 3 Miss Rence Braun, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Werner Braun, was married at noon today to James Augins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Augins of Syracuse. Rabbi Everett Gendler performed the ceremony in the Princeton Jewish Community Center.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 3 A corps of 50 determined housewives enlisted today in a community effort to save the Long Wharf Theater from what they see as the threat of absorption into Yale University.
Legal abortions today are "magnificently safe" and the mortality rate is virtually zero. Dr. Alan F. Guttmacher said yesterday.

The 26 debutantes presented last night at the Piarist Ball at the Plaza curtsied against a background of blue and white, the colors of the Hungarian Piarist Alumni Association, sponsor of the benefit, Garlands of blue and white flowers hung between the columns in the ballroom, which were entwined with smilax.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) New York Airways asked permission today to provide scheduled helicopter service between the Pan Am Building in Manhattan and the Teterboro, N.J., airport and also between Teterboro and Kennedy International Airport.

RICHMOND, Feb. 3 With a closing vitality hardly expected of a businessman who plays tennis only occasionally, Chuck McKinley of Port Washington, L.I., put on a stampede that snatched victory from Cliff Drysdale of South Africa tonight in the opening round of the Fidelity Bankers invitation tournament.

ROME, Feb. 3 (AP) Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, spent 90 minutes with Foreign Minister Amintore Fanfani today, during which he discussed the Vietnam war and his own ideas on now nations not involved in the war, such as Italy, might help bring about peace negotiations.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Feb. 3 (UPI) Rosemary Casals of San Francisco teamed with Francoise Durr of France to post a first-round doubles victory over New Zealand's Mrs. Fay Lob and Beverly Vercoe, 6-2, 5-7, 6-2 in the Will invitation tennis tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 A former officer in the South Vietnamese air force who has been teaching the Vietnamese language at Fort Bragg, N.C., was jailed here today on orders of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 3 Julius Klein, a former convict who has been mentioned prominently in recent hearings of the State Liquor Authority, was indicted on perjury today by a Suffolk County grand jury.
Carl Levin Associates, Inc., a Government and industry relations company based in Washington, announced yesterday the appointment of Ed Edstrom as an associate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Democratic and Republican members of the Joint Economic Committee joined today in suggesting that Congress should get revised estimates of Government spending plans every quarter instead of every year.
Government bonds were in strong demand yesterday in moderate trading on the London Stock Exchange.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) Several Chicago artists have turned out works to show President Johnson that, by comparison, Peter Hurd's portrait of him was flattering.

DETROIT, Feb. 3 (AP) Bad weather across major sections of the country took much of the blame for a sharp drop in auto production this week. Output was estimated at 134,487 cars against 151,993 last week and 172,157 in the week a year ago, according to the trade publication Automotive News.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 3 (UPI) Natashka heads a field of 14 in tomorrow's $62,300 Santa Margarita Handicap, which decides the filly and marc championship of the Santa Anita meeting.

A strike of longshoremen along the Hudson River from West 24th Street to West 57th Street yesterday halted pier operations and forced many of some 1,100 returning cruise passengers to carry their own baggage.

GENEVA, Feb. 3 Willy Spuehler, the Swiss Foreign Minister, said at a press conference in Bern today that the Swiss and Swedish Governments were "skeptical" about Britain's chances of being admitted to the Common Market.
MIAMI, Feb. 3 (AP) Wheatley Stable's entry of Stupendous and Bold and Brave heads a field of 12 handicap horses entered for tomorrow's $64,700 Seminole at Hialeah Park.
CENTRALIA, Ill., Feb. 3 Judge Fred L. Wham, who had served on the Federal District Court bench in Eastern Illinois for 29 years, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital. He was 82 years old.
Lewis W. Dymond, president of Frontier Airlines, has been elected chairman of the Association of Local Transport Airlines for the coming year.

ARAISE of an overcall differs in two important re- spects from a raise of an opening bid. As the overcaller can be assumed to have at least five cards in his suit, the raise can be made with any three cards and a doubleton honor will suffice at a pinch. And the jump raise is encouraging but not forcing.

DETROIT, Feb. 3--Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, resigned today from the Executive Council and most other posts in the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) A Navy jet trainer crashed today on Washington's busy beltway at the height of the late afternoon rush hour. Two automobiles were struck and burst into flames, seriously injuring two of five occupants.
It is not often that someone gives up a $30,000-a-year job to write a play.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 3 Tom Weiskopf proved him self an expert golfer and a dip lomat today. Attributing his improved health to his wife's cooking, Weiskopf assumed the 54-hole lead in the Bob Hope Desert Classic on a 68 that gave him a total of 210.
The present student and worker unrest in Spain, which has spread all over the country, is the most serious challenge that Generalissimo Franco and his Government have yet faced.
HONG KONG, Feb. 3 Developments in Communist China pointed today to an increased reliance on military force by partisans of Mao Tse-tung in their campaign to gain control of the country.

An unpublished book left by R.P. Blackmur, the literary critic, when he died in February, 1965, will be issued by Harcourt, Brace World next Thursday, Called "A Primer of Ignorance," it has been edited by Joseph Frank, Mr. Blackmur's literary executor, who ...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) The Pentagon disclosed today that three Navy men listed as killed in action in Vietnam were now known to be prisoners.

VIENNA, Feb. 3 The charm of Vienna was at its best last night when 200 debutantes and their partners danced to a Johann Strauss waltz at the opening of the Vienna Opera Ball, traditionally the top social event of the carnival season.

AS a bright, red-haired 16year-old apprentice toolmaker, he was dismissed from his 40-cent-an-hour job back in 1923 for leading a protest against a seven-day work week. The aggressive redhead was Walter Philip Reuther, son of a German-born labor organizer, and the reasons ...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) The Treasury Department said today that Series E bond sales of $452 million during January were the highest of any month in 19 years and more than 4 per cent above the January, 1966, level.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 The Justice Department denied today that Federal agents spied on James R. Hoffa with wiretapping and electronic eavesdropping devices during his jurytampering trial in Chattanooga, Tenn.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 3 Mr. and Mrs. Henry C.L. Johnson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynne Lalor Johnson, to Walter Woodhull Merriam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Merriam of Chester, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 The space agency will go ahead with three unmanned Apollo flights this year despite the asphyxiation deaths of three Apollo astronauts last week in their capsule at Cape Kennedy, Fla.

SINCE the Soviet Union undoubtedly has a goodly supply of expert violinists active in its concert and conservatory life, it is not surprising that we should be introduced to new ones at fairly frequent intervals. Last night, at Carnegie Hall, the most recent representative made his New York debut.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 An emergency meeting of the University of California's Board of Regents, called to discuss finances, turned today into a jousting match over the selection of a new president.
The General Cigar Company announced here yesterday the election of William L. Rudkin and Howard S. Tierney Jr. as directors.
Bruce R. Tuttle, a partner in the law firm of Royall, Koegel, Rogers and Wells, 200 Park Avenue, died Thursday at City Hospital of Elmhurst, Queens. He was 66 years old and lived at Cove Neck, L.I.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board approved in general today the international air fare agreements that are to go into effect next April 1, most of them for two years.

Senator Jacob K. Javits promised yesterday to seek a larger share of Federal antipoverty funds for New York and disclosed that a Senate subcommittee would make an inquiry into "loss of money and political abuse" in the Administration's operation of the program.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 3 Even though the cause of the fatal Apollo spacecraft fire remains unknown, studies were initiated today to abandon a pure oxygen environment during the launching of American space missions.
The Loral Corporation announced yesterday in Scarsdale, N.Y., the resignation of Bernard Zisman as president and the election of Lawrence S. Munson as his successor.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 7.1 per cent in production for the week ended Jan. 28, compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week.

MADRID, Feb. 3 (UPI) The police broke up a demonstration today by about 300 marching students in Barcelona. Students at the University of Saragossa staged a strike protesting a ban on student congresses.

The fate of Mayor Lindsay's campaign to bring increased feature film production to New York apparently rests now with two unions whose members do most of their work in television and the legitimate theater. They are the United Scenic Artists, Local 829, and the Theatrical Teamsters, Local 817.

WALTHAM, Mass., Feb. 3-- One of the things the National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities has done for the theater this season is subsidizing the production of three new plays at three university theaters, those of Brandeis, Michigan and Yale.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Liquor salesmen who have been frustrated by busy signals when they try to telephone in their orders at the end of the day are being res- ...

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 Bob Tullius of Falls Church, Va., won the season's first Trans-American race for sedans today. He covered 300 miles over Daytona International Speedway's 3.81-mile course in a Dodge Dart at an average speed of 99.361 miles an hour.
BERLIN, Feb. 3 (AP) Four Americans, one a young woman, were released from prison in Communist East Germany tonight and crossed into West Berlin with shouts of "Freiheit!" ["freedom"].

Forty thousand seamen of the National Maritime Union are expected to get higher wages and overtime pay and improvements in benefit plans as a result of an arbitration award handed down yesterday by Theodore W. Kheel, industry arbitrator for the union's contract.

Abraham Kaplan, conductor of the Collegiate Chorale, generally leads his ensemble in the repertory of great choral works. But every now and then he comes up with a novel, provocative program, and this he did last night in Philharmonic Hall.

ALEXANDRIA, La., Feb. 3 Miss Mollie Dunnam Lamkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Roberts Lamkin, was married here this afternoon to Peter van B. Heide, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Henry Heide of Martinsville, N.J.

John Cooper Wiley's long and distinguished career in diplomacy spanned both World Wars and the Korean war. It plunged him into negotiations in times of peace and war, and it had moments of high drama.
TORONTO, Feb. 3 Abraham L. Feinberg, rabbi emeritus of Toronto's Holy Blossom Temple, says he found Ho Chi Minh to be a warm, almost puckish man.
The disclosure that the Federal Communications Commission is considering action against unlicensed walkie-talkie radios rocked the market for the popular consumer device yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 3 (AP) The world champion Baltimore Orioles signed today Brooks Robinson, their fancy fielding third baseman, for a salary reported to be $75,000. Last season Robinson received about $55,000.
PONTIAC, Mich., Feb. 3 (UPI) The General Motors Corporation advised a number of bus lines today to check for a possible defect that might cause loss of steering control in 1967 G.M. coaches.
Welfare Commissioner Mitchell I. Ginsberg charged yesterday that city and state housing officials discriminate against welfare recipients in renting apartments.

SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 3 The United Nations Command protested to North Korea today over an attack on a South Korean guard post inside the demilitarized zone that took place just after midnight in the central sector of the truce line.

Lodge 886 of the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen of America filed suit in Federal Court yesterday in a move to compel the Long Island Rail Road Company and the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority to enter into "continual negotiations" for a new contract.
Opponents of plans to build Interstate Highway Route 87 through Bedford Township in Westchester County applied in Federal Court yesterday for an injunction against Federal approval of the route.
The Tenth Decade Dinner, the first in a series of annual special events leading to the 100th anniversary of the Art Students League, will be held Friday at the Plaza.
STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 25 Few French politicians are so confident of re-election in March as the two Gaullists who represent Strasbourg in the National Assembly.
DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 3 (Reuters) Demba Diop, president of the parliamentary group of the governing party in the National Assembly, was stabbed to death today at Thies, about 50 miles from here.
Practical nurses employed by the city voted 352 to 341 last night to accept its contract proposal.

The Board of Estimate filed suit against Mayor Lindsay yesterday to force him to turn over $84.3-million to the Transit Authority. The Democraticcontrolled board said it was taking the action to keep the transit fare at 20 cents.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 3 About 100 persons, all with diagnosed terminal cancer cases, are being given weekly injections of the Rand Development Corporation's controversial cancer vaccine at a clinic here.
Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Herscher of 175 Riverside Drive have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Miriam Herscher, to Stephen L. Milstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Milstein of Newark.

Met with Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board; met with three U.S. Ambassadors departing shortly for their posts; saw Chairman Ackley of the President's Council of Economic Advisers; named three Air Force generals for promotion in new command assignments; met with Office of Economic Opportunity officials.

The American Federation of Musicians may request a review of a Court of Appeals ruling that the union violated the Sherman antitrust act by forcing orchestra leaders acting as employers to fix minimum engagement prices.

ROME, Feb. 3 The historic meeting between Pope Paul VI and President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union this week was brief and without substantive agreement except on the desirability of maintaining some future contact between the Vatican and the Kremlin, it was reported today.

NEWARK, Feb. 3--A gambling operation estimated to handle $10-million to $20-million a year in bets in Bergen and Essex Counties led to the arrests today of three men and the surrender of a fourth. A fifth suspect is being sought.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 3 Six persons were injured, one seriously, when the police opened fire today on striking railway workers in Lahore, the capital of West Pakistan.
HIEN LUONG BRIDGE, Demilitarized Zone, Feb. 3 Twenty-eight shivering young men crossed a bridge today, stopped midway and tossed their new clothes into a river despite the near-freezing rain.

PARIS, Feb. 3 Andre Courreges, who has been playing hide-and-seek with the public for the last two years, made a marvelous comeback today with a new spring-summer collection. It is haute couture and may be ordered only by private clients.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Administration prospects for preventing sharp cutbacks in antipoverty funds grew bleaker today with the naming of members to a House Appropriations Subcommittee that handles key domestic money bills.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 4 (AP) United States Air Force jets streaked through intense antiaircraft fire yesterday to bomb a major railroad yard and a railroad bridge north of Hanoi, United States military headquarters reported today.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 3 (AP) The United States submarine Clamagore and a twin-hulled tourist boat collided outside San Juan harbor today.
The General Instrument Corporation made a tender offer yesterday for 1.5 million shares of Universal Controls, Inc., common stock at $6.25 a share.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 3 (UPI) Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said last night he still favored an exchange of consulates with the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Consumer installment credit recorded its smallest rise in more than four years in December, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 The termination of a suit filed in Federal Court here against The Chicago Daily News by Look magazine and William Manchester, author of "The Death of a President," was announced today.

The United Automobile Worker' withdrawal yesterday from key leadership posts in the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations has placed the federation on the brink of its greatest internal crisis. The development, which included the surprise resignation of the union
Until yesterday, New York City had never meant much to Bart Starr.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 4 (AP) The Maoist camp conceded today that its claims of victory in the cities of Shanghai and Taiy an might have been premature, and there were reports of fresh opposition thrown up by anti-Maoists.

THIRTY-SEVEN years after his art was first shown at the Museum of Modern Art, the American sculptor Alexander Calder has made a gift of 19 examples of his work to that now-venerable institution. The museum placed these gifts on exhibition this week, and they will remain on view through April 5. Included are several major works.
The bond and strangled body of a 40-year-old children's book designer was found yesterday afternoon in his $250-a-month apartment at 315 East 68th Street.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 3 Members of the Jersey City Federation of Teachers picketed the four city high schools and four elementary schools for 20 minutes before classes began today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) President Johnson announced plans today to fill two top-level jobs in the Office of Economical Opportunity.

Federal Government aid is vitally needed to reverse the process of deterioration in New York City, Lawrence Lachman, president of Bloomingdale Bros., told a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel.
LAKE CHARLES, La., Feb. 3 (AP) An explosion and fire rocked an offshore drilling platform in the Gulf of Mexico late today. Five men were reported missing and presumed dead.

MILAN, Italy, Feb. 3 (UPI) Sandro Mazzinghi of Italy floored Jean Baptiste Rolland twice in the 10th round and retained the European light-middleweight championship tonight when the Frenchman's handlers threw in the sponge.

Mrs. Helen Livingston Weinberg, wife of Sidney J. Weinberg Sr., a partner in Goldman, Sachs Co., a leading Wall Street investment banking firm, died of a heart ailment Thursday in Phoenix, Ariz., where she had been visiting. Mrs. Weinberg, whose age was 69, lived at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel.
The United Presbyterian Church and the Catholic Foreign Mission Society (Maryknoll Fathers) will begin joint publication later this month of a combination magazine-record album.

MINNEAPOLIS these days is a thing of sheer, fairytale beauty. About three weeks ago, the city was hit by a freak thunderstorm, followed by normal sub-zero winter temperatures. It probably will last until spring, for nobody anticipates a thaw until then.
