WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) President Johnson's offer at his news conference Thursday to stop the bombing of North Vietnam if Hanoi takes "just almost any step" has provoked new anxiety among some military officers. They fear the President may end the raids in return for something less significant.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 5--Theaters that are off Broadway by more than a thousand miles are booming.

HOUSTON, Feb. 5--Ernie Terrell talks with methodical and cautious deliberation and has none of the animation or sparkle of Cassius Clay. They fight pretty much the same way as they talk and they will bring their contrasting styles into the ring at the Astrodome tomorrow night in a battle for the heavyweight championship of the world.
MOST visitors to New York arrive armed with lists of places to go, people to see and gifts to purchase, but Dwight Godwin of Gainesville, Fla., always brings a grocery shopping list.
Can diners at sidewalk cafes in New York City blend right into the street life--or must they be somehow fenced off from passers-by?
A week-long strike of 3,400 tugboat men here ended yesterday with an agreement giving them a 30-hour week.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary said yesterday that he was creating a committee called PACT, Police and Citizens Together, to create closer ties between the police and the community.

What a pleasure to welcome a bright, marvelously gifted young performer! Ellen Hassman is just such an artist, and the 18-year-old cellist was magnificent in her recital debut last night at Town Hall. A scholarship student of Leonard Rose at the Juilliard School. Miss Hassman appeared as a Concert Artists Guild Award winner.
Prosperity has dealt the heavy electrical equipment makers a low blow.

BINHMINH, South Vietnam Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky. wearing his black air force jumpsuit, his long-billed, silverbraided baseball cap and his purple silk scarf, sat patiently through a series of long-winded speeches in this village in the Mekong River delta last week.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Feb. 5--The copper crisis in the Congo appears to have reached a decisive turn over the weekend.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 5 --William Pardoe of the Fox Meadow Tennis Club and George Lowman of the Wee Burn Country Club successfully defended their American Platform Tennis Association senior doubles championship today at the Englewood Field Club.
AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 5-- Peace marchers demonstrated today for the ninth consecutive Sunday, circling the Amherst Town Commons in an hour-long silent vigil.

The gathering debate on what should be included in a new Constitution for New York is more than a matter of length--short versus long. The question is whether this state shall have a government free to respond swiftly to changing times or one cramped and corseted by needless constitutional restrictions.
HONG KONG, Feb. 5 Supporters of Mao Tse-tung appeared today to be meeting mounting problems and making little progress in their campaign against opposition forces
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5 (AP)--One camp for North Vietnamese prisoners sits on the rounded crest of a hill near Pleiku in the Central Highlands.

ROCKVILLE, Conn., Feb. 5 (UPI) Four young children three of them members of the same family, were killed today in a predawn fire that virtually destroyed their tenement home. A fifth child was injured.
A well-dressed robber leisurely ransacked the home of a Brooklyn executive for six -- hours Saturday night while the executive's 14-year-old son repeatedly tried to escape.

Martin Saxe, a former president of the New York State Tax Commission, a former State Senator and a lawyer specializing in tax matters, died yesterday in his home, 101 Central Park West. He was 92 years old.
SAGINAW, Mich., Feb. 5 (AP)--A Saginaw educator and his wife were found murdered in their home today, about a mile from the scene of a similar double slaying last week.

Awards for their "contribution to Jewish culture in the United States" were given yesterday to Richard Tucker. Metropolitan Opera tenor; Irving Howe, editor of Dissent magazine, and Jacob Glatstein, Yiddish poet.
PEKING, Feb. 5--Hundreds of slogan-chanting Chinese demonstrators delayed for hours today the departure of a Soviet airliner carrying 30 women and 50 children home.
What are the most seriouspressures placed upon a securities salesman? What values do bankers employ in their decision-making? What are the meanings and long-range goals of business life?
A message from North Vietnam indicating willingness to negotiate on ending the Vietnam war was reported to have been given to Senator Robert F. Kennedy in Paris last week.

TORONTO, Feb. 5--Rabbi Abraham L. Feinberg, who was permitted to visit two captured United States pilots during his trip to North Vietnam last month, quotes both men as having questioned the war in Vietnam.
CONCARNEAU, France, Feb. 5--This ancient Breton port was choked today with 125 trawlers, tied three and four abreast along the quais fronting the old fortified town.

As he had done many times before, Henry La Casse went into the apartment of his 68year old, semi-invalid neighbor, Mrs. Elizabeth Selvin, on Saturday night to see if she needed any help. He found her stabbed and beaten to death.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5-- California's disordered Democratic party forces, official and unofficial, have begun planning a comeback. The party was badly damaged by the victory of Republican Ronald Reagan in the November fight for the governorship and by significant Republican gains in the Legislature.
HOUSTON, Feb. 5--When people ask Ernie Terrell if he thinks he can beat Cassius Clay, he rubs a thumb slowly against his chin and replies softly, "I don't just think I can beat him. "I know I can."
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 5--Investigators of the Apollo 1's fatal fire are now concentrating their search for clues in the cabin's life-support system.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 5 --Mr. and Mrs. Chester Elmer Whittle have announced the engagement of Mrs. Whittle's daughter, Miss Lynda Marion Spence, to Gary Leroy Bridge. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Eugene Bridge of Salt Lake City.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 5 (AP)--Ding Schoonmaker of Miami won the Caribbean Midwinter Regatta Don Q trophy today for the second year in a row, even though he did not start in the final race.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb.5-- The romanticized fraternity of white hunters surrendered and admitted its first black hunter this week. He plans to go on being part of a white hunter's team, at least for a while.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 5 (Ap)--Ambassador J. Graham Persons of the United States spoke his mind today in the face of recurrent demonstrations against Washington's policy on Vietnam.
SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 5 Former President Posun Yun was designated today as the candidate of opposition groups to run against President Chung Hee Park in the April presidential election.
DURBAN, South Africa, Feb. 5 (AP)--Maurice Chevalier said here yesterday he planned to retire Sept. 12, 1968--"the day I turn 80."

New York--the city where it couldn't be done--has protected 160 notable buildings and four historic districts since the Landmarks Preservation Law went into effect in April 1965. Ten new designations have just been made. Some in the long list were routine designations. Others were contested originally and then accepted. Still others have provided effective demonstrations of how the landmarks law works.
LONDON, Feb. 5 (AP)-- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union arrives tomorrow for talks with British leaders certain to be dominatcd by the quest for a peace in Vietnam.
The fourth concert in the sixpart Bach Festival at Philharmonic Hall last night brought together Szymon Goldberg, violinist, and Jorg Demus, pianist, Each offered two big solo Partitas.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 5 Robert Penn Warren, whose fiction and poetry have won several major literary awards, has received the Bollingen Prize in Poetry, which many consider the most prestigious in its field.

American consumers support a $13.5-billion industry that probably receives less attention for its size than any other. Its products are designed to be tossed into the garbage can without a second look.
BERLIN, Feb. 5 (AP)--Peter Feinauer, a 27-year-old American from Providence, R.I., is being held by Communist authorities in East Berlin, his mother, Mrs. Victoria Feinauer, said tonight.
The penitential season of Lent will begin the day after tomorrow, Ash Wednesday. It will continue for 40 days, not including Sundays, and will end with the joyful Easter festival on March 26.
The Youth Symphony Orchestra of New York gave its second free concert of the season yesterday afternoon, greatly pleasing the near-capacity audience at Carnegie Hall. The conductor. Leonard Slatkin,

A slackening of economic activity and not governmental pronouncements are responsible for recent declines in interest rates around the world, the First National City Bank of New York asserted over the weekend.
Victory Memorial Hospital in Brooklyn will hold its annual dinner dance on Saturday at Andre's 8609 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that if the United States could not solve the problems of its major urban centers, "then we're not going to do any better across the globe either."

The Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday designated the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street as a landmark. The building was cited as "one of the masterpieces of beaux-arts style of architecture."

Vie Niederhoffer of Chicago, ranked No. 1 nationally, defeated Samuel Howe of Philadelphia, the second-ranked player. 15-9, 15-11, 15-9, yesterday in the finals of the Harry Cowles invitation squash racquets tournament at the Harvard Club.

Max Adrian will be the only actor in "An Evening With G.B.S.," which unfolds most of George Bernard Shaw's career. Mr. Adrian has performed it at the Edinburgh Festival and in London. It will arrive here the week of Oct. 2. The sponsors are Arthur Cantor and Nicholas Vanoff, who are presenting "Of Love Remembered" on Feb. 14 at the ANTA Theater.

ALBANY, Feb. 5--Legislation requested by Mayor Lindsay to exempt nearly two million New York City residents and commuters from filing city income tax returns is expected to be approved this week by the Legislature.

It will arrive here the week of Oct. 2. The sponsors are Arthur Cantor and Nicholas Vanoff, who are presenting "Of Love Remembered" on Feb. 14 at the ANTA Theater.

ALBANY, Feb. 5--Legislation requested by Mayor Lindsay to exempt nearly two million New York City residents and commuters from filing city income tax returns is expected to be approved this week by the Legislature.
WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 5 --Miss Mary Joanne Coakley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Coakley, was married this afternoon to William W. Galvin 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Galvin of Suffield, Conn.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5(UPI) --Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Nugent are dropping out of the University of Texas.

Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff said yesterday that he had asked the Justice Department to determine whether perjury had been committed at a Senate hearing last March during discussion of alleged harassment of Ralph Nader by General Motors.

Henryk Szeryng was in a giving mood Saturday night at Hunter College. He played a big program covering a wide range of styles with a rare degree of violinistic virtuosity and an equally high level of mature, full-blooded musicianship.
Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Cohen of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Gamora Cohen, to Richard John Defouw, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Dufouw of Port Washington, L.I.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP)--The Boston Celtics broke away fast today and breezed to a 137-121 National Basketball Association victory over the Cincinnati Royals, who lost their star, Oscar Robertson, in the first period.

Some shipping operators believe that the nagging "me too" problem in maritime labor management relations may be solved in the next few months on the basis of a pattern set last week by Theodore W. Kheel, the labor arbitrator.
WALDWICK, N.J., Feb. 5-- Harry Hoffman won the Eastern senior indoor tennis championship today with a 6-1, 6-3 victory over Alan Fleming of Chatham.

The influential Public Education Association proposed yesterday that the city's local school boards be given the power to choose district school superintendents and principals and some authority over budgets and curriculums.

VILLARD DE LANS, France, Feb. 5 (AP)--Klaus Bonsack and Thomas Kohler captured the two-man luge championship today, giving East Germany a sweep of the honors in the Olympic preview races that had to be severely curtailed because of warm weather.

WASHINGTON, Feb.5 Leaders of 15 student organizations representing both political extremes as well as the center called today for the abolition of the draft and the encouragement of voluntary service in humanitarian pursuits.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)--A State Department official said tonight that what he called a "campaign of terror" by Arabs against Israel was "morally reprehensible, politically irresponsible and a primary cause for the recently increased tensions on Israel's borders."

In Nicaragua, unlike most of the rest of Latin America, the unexpected has been happening for some thirty-five years. The Somoza family goes on and on. A defeat for Gen. Anastasio (Tachito) Somoza Jr. in the Presidential elections yesterday would not only have been unexpected; it would have been a miracle. Early reports seem to confirm the miracle did not happen.
LEAVENWORTH, Wash., Feb. 5 (AP)--Bjorn Wirkola of Norway, the world champion, soared 335 feet today, breaking the North American ski-jumping record by 10 feet.
Miss Charlene Ann Yap of New York and Honolulu and Peter Thomas Simpson of New York and Niagara Falls, N.Y., teachers in city schools, plan to marry in August in Honolulu.

A Harlem businessman who said he was unable to borrow $300,000 to prepare a building for rental to Columbia University and the city paid yesterday that he had received "eight or nine" offers as a result of newspaper publicity.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 5 (AP)--An American company has won 200,000 kroner (about $29,000) in a contest of ideas for an 11-mile connector, bridge or tunnel between Denmark's two largest islands, Zealand and Fyn.

RICHMOND, Feb. 5--The posture of Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico as an indoor tennis player approached invincibility today as he defeated Arthur Ashe of Richmond in the final of the Fidelity Bankers invitation tournament.
VIENNA, Feb. 5 (UPI) Willie Brenter sped over a 3,685yard course in 2 minutes 44.9 seconds to lead an Austrian sweep of the first world skibob championship today.

John Holley Clark Jr., an assistant United States attorney in the Southern District from 1921 to 1925, died Saturday night at Whitestone General Hospital from complications that resulted from a fall 10 days ago. He was 79 years old and lived on 26th Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 5 --Dal Joon Lee, a Korean living in Columbus, Ohio, defeated Martin Reisman of New York, 21-17, 21-16, 21-14, tonight to win the men's final in the Eastern table tennis tournament.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 5--Leif Bringslimark, a mason contractor from Congers, N.Y., who was born in Norway, captured the Telemark Ski Club jumping tournament and the B.B. Hanssen Memorial Trophy today with flights of 138, 159 and 159 feet as a crowd of 23,556 watched.

WINNETKA, Ill., Feb. 5-- Perry Dunlap Smith, a leader in the progressive education movement and headmaster of the North Shore Country Day School from 1919 until his retirement in 1954, died at his home here yesterday after a heart attack. He was 78 years old.

ST. JAMES, L.I., Feb. 5 Leslie Maguire, a 17-year-old high school senior, rode Dutch Shy to the regular working hunter championship and reserve for the junior hunter crown today at the Hollandia Farms Horse Show.
PARIS, Feb. 5--Wear black stockings and flat-heeled shoes. Don't forget the puffy organdy bloomers under the dress with the pussycat bow. Buy a fall and wear a cartwheel hat. Lisp a little.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The Federal Government and the University of Minnesota are about to embark on an experimental project that could lead to the construction--in the Minnesota farmlands--of a new city with a population of a quarter of a million persons.
Directors of the Hammond Organ Company and the Wells Lamont Corporation have approved their merger, it was announced over the weekend.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 (UPI)-- Denis DeJordy registered his second shutout of the season tonight as the first-place Chicago Black Hawks beat the Boston Bruins, 5-0, in a National Hockey League game. DeJordy blocked 36 shots on the goal.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 5-- Steel men were groping for a market trend last week.
Two concerns, one of them in the United States, have joined forces to develop a $30-million motion picture exhibition circuit in Canada. It will be called N.G.C. Cinemas, Ltd.
A Northwestern University chemistry professor said yesterday that thousands of good high school students were being driven to their "academic deaths" because of excessive workloads.

Aides of President Kennedy made clear their animosity toward president Johnson in incident after incident aboard the plane that returned them to Washington after the assassination in Dallas, according to William Manchester.
A Supreme Court jury began deliberations yesterday in the trial of Harold Konigsberg, a 38-year-old former convict accused of conspiracy, extortion attempted extortion and felonious assault.
MOSCOW, Feb. 6 (AP) Moscow television broadcast a half hour program in English tonight, featuring what it called the leading song of the American protest movement, "We Shall Overcome."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 The industry that creates images was told to work on its own by one of its own here today.

MIAMI, Feb. 6 The Fleet Crest Stable's Fleet Admiral spoiled Moccasin's 1967 debut by scoring a front-running victory at Hialeah Park today. Ridden by Angel Cordero, Fleet Admiral held on to win by threequarters of a length from Golden Buttons, with Moccasin third, a length farther back.
Several of the nation's large chain-store organizations began 1967 much as they ended 1966 with record sales.
The International Brotherhood of Teamsters signed up some new members last night 50 former bunnies from the Playboy Club.
GREAT NECK, L.I., Feb. 6 Dr. Milton I. Strahl, a retired radiolgist, who had practiced in Brooklyn, died yesterday in his home, 20 Chapel Place. He was 77 years old.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 "I don't want young people making general entertainment centers out of cars," a Rochester Senator declared today in arguing for his bill to make it illegal to drink alcoholic beverages in a car on any road in the state.
Pan American World Airways announced yesterday the retirement of William J. McEvoy as assistant vice president for public relations, governmental affairs and special projects.

MEMPHIS, Feb. 6 (AP) Gus Johnson helped Baltimore build a 20-point lead in the first half that carried the Bullets to a 107-98 triumph over the St. Louis Hawks in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
ATHENS, Feb. 6 Greece and Cyprus reached an agreement today on how to handle their long-standing dispute with Turkey over the political destiny of Cyprus.
Bond market trading was a mixed affair yesterday as what one dealer described as "an air of expectancy" hung over Wall Street.
Ownership by a syndicate of investors is proposed for a major building in the jewelry trade center on West 47th Street.
The vice president of they Board of Education urged his fellow members yesterday to "reject emphatically" a recent proposal calling for the abolition of the school system's Board of Examiners.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 6 (AP) Gov. Ronald Reagan today asked California's state employes to work voluntarily without extra pay on two of their holidays.

Leaders of the Uniformed Firemen's Association and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association charged yesterday that Herbert L. Haber, director of the city's labor relations, had misled them in their negotiations for new contracts.
A bomb blew up in a car driven by a bricklayers' union official yesterday less than a block from the home of a former bricklayer official who has accused the union of racketeering.
In the great investment banking sweepstakes held annually among corporate securities underwriters, the First Boston Coropration last year took first place for the fourth consecutive year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Senator Robert F. Kennedy reported to President Johnson today that he had brought home no Vietnam peace feelers from his recent trip to Europe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Within a decade, Senator Jacob K. Javits said today, Republicans could be "regularly elected in statewide contests in all but one or two states in the Deep South."
Prices were mixed at the close of moderately active trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
SONGBE, South Vietnam, Feb. 6 Phuoclong province, to the Americans who are here, is "the end of the line."
WARSAW, Feb. 6 Poland protested to China today over an attack by Red Guards in Peking yesterday on the Polish ambassador and members of his staff.
An individual has the right to resell unwanted opera tickets even at a profit despite objections by the state, the city and the Metropolitan Opera, a Criminal Court judge ruled yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 6 The Soviet Union sought today a year's postponement of an international conference scheduled to convene in September, on the peaceful uses of space.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 6 (AP) The Air Force announced today that, in a change of plans, Maj. Gen. Robert A. Breitweiser, now vice commander of the Military Airlift Command, will take over command of the service's top school in March.
Trading was very light and prices eased yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
ALTHOUGH Bernard Kops, the English writer, first came to the notice of Americans as a writer of plays, he has made a greater impression in other works.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 (AP) Earle T. Mack, son of Connie Mack and a former executive of the Philadelphia Athletics, died yesterday after suffering a stroke last week in suburban Delaware County Memorial hospital. Mr. Mack, whose original family name was McGillicudy, was 77 years old. Survivors include a son, Earle Jr., and a daughter, Charlotte; a, grandson, his stepmother, a half-brother and four half-sisters.
LONDON, Feb. 6 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union arrived in Britain today for a week's visit designed mainly for political discussion.

TALKEETNA, Alaska, Feb. 6 (AP) Jacques Batkin, 36 years old of Anchorage, was killed Jan. 31 when he fell in a crevasse on Mount McKinley. He was one of eight men making the first winter ascent of the 20,320-foot peak.

"Lakes" have been discovered tucked among the mountains of the moon. Presumably they were once great pools of molten lava that, in some cases, overflowed and swept down nearby valleys, forming glacier-like highways.

THE alarming effects of airand-water pollution on hu- man beings is currently receiving a great deal of attention from health authorities. However, a great deal less consideration is given to the dangerous impact pollution has on wildlife.
Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor said in a book published yesterday that the United States had acted "more from instinct than from sound judgment" in coming to the defense of Vietnam.

The proposed transfer of certain functions of the Bureau of Customs to the Coast Guard, which will become part of the new Department of Transportation, was protected yesterday by the American Waterways Operators, Inc.

Through more than three decades of large-scale public relief in this city a sizable part of the effort that might have been focused on helping families work their way out of dependency has gone into investigations intended to uncover chiselers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Living cheek-by-transistor, as we all do nowadays, with machines of staggering competence, we are naturally bound to develop neuroses different from those that afflicted grandfather. It is not surprising, then, that psychiatrists report a rapidly rising incidence of machine envy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Representative L. Mendel Rivers, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, strongly criticized today the decision to cancel shore leave for the crew of the Roosevelt when she entered Capetown.

BONN, Feb. 6 Carnival time, which comes to a climax with today's Rose Monday celebrations, is for most West Germans a time to drop their reserve, act foolishly, have fun, eat and drink immoderately, dance, sing and spend lots of money.
DETROIT, Feb. 6 Michigan's Attorney General, Frank J. Kelley, ruled today that Gov. George Romney had overstepped his powers by ordering cuts in Medicaid.
TRENTON, Feb. 6--The State Supreme Court today affirmed the power of the State Board of Education to regulate the awarding of degrees by Shelton College, a small, fundamentalist school in Cape May.
Paul H. Douglas of Illinois became a part-time New Yorker yesterday.

Frank Wille, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday that the State Banking Department would recommend legislation designed to broaden the investment powers of savings banks and savings-and-loan associations.

KINSHASA, Feb. 6 President Joseph D. Mobutu met this morning with Andre de Spirelet, one of the negotiators sent here by Societe Generale de Belgique, to seek a joint solution of the copper dispute that exploded in the Congo with the nationalization of Union Miniere on Jan. 1.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 6 Miss Patricia Ann McNulty and Jamey Austin Mitchell Jr., son of Mrs. Mitchell of Springfield, N.J., and the late Mr. Mitchell, plan to marry Aug. 12 in Maplewood, N.J.
The Administration is asking commercial airlines that will be buying supersonic transport planes to put up more money as a deposit for financing the SST development.
ATHENS, Ga., Feb. 6 (UPI) Vanderbilt scored three quick field goals in an overtime period and beat Georgia, 51-41, tonight at the Athens Coliseum.
The Seven-Up Company plans to make its first public offering of stock.

Joel E. Saltzman, a book publisher, died Sunday in his home at 195-60 A Peck Avenue, Fresh Meadows, Queens, at the age of 51. He was vice president and a director of Twayne Publishers, Inc., and president and a director of its subsidiary, Bookman Associates, Inc., both at 31 Union Square West.

Michelangelo Antonioni's "Blow-Up," which has attracted considerable notice as the first film to be denied a seal of approval by the recently liberalized Production Code, may eventually win that approval after all.
The appointment of Robert E. Powers as a vice president was announced yesterday by the United States Trust Company of New York.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Feb. 6 (AP) Two smiling Roman Catholic priests arrived in New Mexico today for five days of disciplinary retreat, saying it was a matter of church protocol and not punishment for taking part in a farm workers' strike.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today appointed Maj. Gen. John D. Stevcnson director of mission operations in the Office of Manned Space Flight today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 6 Less than 48 hours before the lunar New year cease-fire, which begins Wednesday, allied spokesmen announced today the start of a major offensive, record air strikes in South Vietnam and the beginning of defoliation runs in the demilitarized zone along the border between the two Vietnams.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 6 Civil rights demonstrators blocked truck traffic at an urban-renewal site for the third time today and announced plans for a boycott of New Rochelle's stores, beginning Saturday.
The Federal Communications Commission has approved the $14-million sale of a chain of television and radio stations in the Southwest and West to Doubleday Co., a major book publisher.

Roy L. Reierson, senior vice president and chief economist of the Bankers Trust Company, predicted yesterday there would be "considerably greater availability of credit in 1967 than in the latter half of 1966."
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Feb. 6 (Reuters) Martine Carol, the movie actress, was found dead of a heart attack today. She was 16 years old.

A reccommendation that a Southeast Asian Institute for Development be set up to work out "a comprehensive approach" to solving the problems of Vietnam and nearby countries is being made by the World Institute Councii.
The city's newest firehouse at 148-150 West 19th street was opened yesterday with some modern features that would gladden the eye of a Smokey Stover.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) chairman John E. Horne of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today the board should continue its control over dividends paid by member savings institutions and bring savings and loan holding companies under its authority.
G.T. Etheridge was appointed yesterday as president and general manager of the Kelvinator International Corporation, the appliance subsidiary of the American Motors Corporation.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 6 Jersey City and the State Department of Health presented Superior Court Judge Robert A. Matthews their plans for extinguishing smoldering fires on the Point Breeze dump and converting it to a legal sanitary land fill. He gave the city 30 days to operate its plan and will then review it.

New York City's air, like that of most other metropolitan areas across the country, is so badly polluted that it sometimes actually constitutes a threat to health. In Manhattan alone, forty million pounds of contaminants large enough to be visible are ejected into the atmosphere each year.
Directors of the General Motors Corporation decided yesterday to continue the company's quarterly dividend of 85 cents a share on its common stock, despite a decline in earnings for 1966.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 6--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Stevens Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Gould Stevens, to Lieut. Stan Lee Webb, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Webb of Peabody, Mass.

Last night's world heavyweight championship fight between Cassius Clay and the World Boxing Association champion. Ernie Terrell, will be shown on the American Broadcasting Company's Wide World of Sports television show Saturday at 5 P.M.
AN exceptionally imaginative and well-acted production of Moliere's "Les Femmes Savantes". ("The Learned Ladies") opened last night at the Barbizon-Plaza Theater on Central Park South.
LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP) Ernest Marples, a former Transport Minister, whose job was to help reorganize Britain's conservative party, left the post today.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 6 Clifford A. Rand Sr., former chief engineer for the Food Fair stores in Linden, died Saturday at Orange Memorial Hospital. He retired in 1966 after 10 years with the food store chain. He was 68 years old and lived at 69 North Arlington Avenue here.
YONKERS, Feb. 6 Mrs. W. Dale Sutton of Frogmore, S.C., the first woman appointed to the Yonkers City Planning Board, died Saturday in Beaufort, S.C. She was 76 years old.
PRAGUE, Feb. 7 (AP) Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, took up China and problems of Eastern Europe at a three-day visit with party leaders in Czechoslovakia, a communique said today.
A priest who accompanied Cardinal Spellman of New York to South Vietnam said last night that the Cardinal had never used the phrase "Christ's war" to describe United States participation in the war.
LONDON, Feb. 6 Britain's decision to withdraw most of her troops from Malta has caused an emotional trauma for some Britons.

Disenchanted by what it calls "inaction" by the State Commission for Human Rights, the state N.A.A.C.P., has decided to support legislation in Albany to revise drastically the commission's structure and procedures.
LONDON, Feb. 6. After weeks of stalemate, negotiations over the price of North Sea gas seem to be making some progress.
PRAGUE, Feb. 6 (Reuters) The Czechoslovak Supreme Court has cleared five writers given long prison terms for antistate activity, the press agency reported here today.
LANCASTER, Pa., Feb. 6 (UPI) Nine racing horses and nine show horses were killed today when fire destroyed a big barn at the Lancaster Riding and Tennis Club, four miles west of here.
Mortimer Steindler, former chief investigator of the Queens District Attorney's office, was shot to death yesterday in the Sunnyside apartment of a businessman whose son he once investigated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) The Federal Aviation Agency said today that the United States airlines interested in buying supersonic transports had agreed in general to help finance the development program.

A dramatic cleanup in the city's air pollution by this time next year with a 40 to 50 per cent reduction in sulphur dioxide and a 25 to 30 per cent cutdown in smoke and soot was envisioned yesterday by the city's. Air Pollution Control Commissioner.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Representative Adam Clayton Powell agreed today to appear Wednesday before a special House committee investigating his fitness to serve in Congress.
HARDLY a man who had money in the stock mar ket last year emerged unscathed and this went for the professionals as well as the amateurs.
American Airlines plans to shift this year to an in-flight entertainment system that can show motion pictures in color. It is called Astrocolor.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 6 The board of review investigating the Apollo accident met again today without any indication that it was close to finding the cause of the spacecraft fire that killed Lieut. Cols. Virgil I. Grissom and Edward H. White 2d and Lieut. Comdr. Roger B. Chaffee. Not even a brief formal announcement was made of its activities.
MODERN women are making their own rules when it comes to a matter of personal identification, regardless of tradition and etiquette books.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 6 President Julius K. Nyerere proclaimed today that the Government was immediately taking over all banks in Tanzania, dispatches from Dar es Salaam reported.
The Chicago North Western Railway said yesterday it had offered to acquire "on a reasonable basis" any of the lines in its territory that might wish to be included in an expanded system.
The electronic computer scored another "first" on Wall Street yesterday by helping to safeguard the movement of $2.2-billion in securities for Bache Co., Inc.

Council President Frank D. O'Connor, the defeated Democratic candidate for Governor last fall, urged yesterday that contributions of $1 be authorized as part of state income-tax payments to help defer the cost of statewide elections.
JERUSALEM (Israel), Feb. 6--A bundle of explosives was found this morning against the schoolyard gate of an elementary school for Arab children near the Sea of Galilee. There was no explosion.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 6 The economic experts of Western Europe are becoming increasingly concerned over the slowdown in economic growth in West Germany and the effects this could have on general European and world trade.
HOUSTON, Feb. 6 Cassius Clay turned Ernie Terrell's best and only weapon, the left jab, against his foe in the Astrodome tonight.
The application of William D. (Bud) Gilmour for a license to own, train and drive standardbreds in this state was denied yesterday by the New York State Harness Racing Commission.
TRENTON, Feb. 6 (AP) The National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing lost a court test today of its claim that it cannot be sued for damages suffered by drivers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Treasury bill yields rebounded this week from the low levels to which they fell a week ago.
Tugboat operators said yesterday that they expected their ranks to "diminish appreciately" during the life of a new three year contract that will increase labor costs some 25 per cent.
LOS ANGELES What must be the most talked- about feature of California dining is the serving of salad as a separate course before the main dish of a meal.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 6 Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury under President Franklin D. Roosevelt for 11 years, died here tonight at Vassar Brothers Hospital after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) The Senate defeated today, 58 to 27, an attempt to permit its Select Committee on Small Business to send legislation to the floor for action, as do regular and standing committees.

General Motors charged yesterday in court papers that a private detective it had hired to investigate Ralph Nader was "cooperating" with him in his $26-million invasion of privacy suit against the company even though the detective was also a defendant in the suit.

A docile party executive committee has chosen Henry McDonough to be Democratic leader of the Bronx, but the voters will have the last word on this selection. The new leader was a longtime associate of the late Charles Buckley, under whose direction the "regulars" in recent years encountered successive defeats.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 6 (UPI) David H. Mitchell 3d began serving a five-year sentence today for refusing to be drafted for service in Vietnam.
A court-appointed referee upheld yesterday the American Express Company's right to make a $60-million settlement with creditors of its American Express Warehousing, Ltd., subsidiary.
HOUSTON, Feb. 6 Ernie Terrell had talked, of controlling the bout, not fighting the way Cassius Clay had wanted.

If he had sung nothing but Canteloube's "Chants d'Auvergne" in his program at Town Hall last night, Julian Patrick would have made a very good impression as a recitalist. In five of the folk-song arrangements at the end of the evening, he revealed liveliness, vocal flexibility and interpretive skills that had not been much in evidence during the remainder of the program.

The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company maintained yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission's "present equation of 'materiality' with 'hopes' and 'speculation'" conflicts with the Government agency's "own regulations."

W orld sugar futures broke a trading record yesterday, giving members of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchanges a busy day. Volume in the No. 8 contract totaled 5,148, outdistancing the prior record day of 4,515 on Nov. 19, 1926. There were also 151 trades in the domestic No. 10 contract.

The Tet, or lunar new year, truce in Vietnam begins tomorrow in the midst of a confusion of vague reports and denials of negotiations with Hanoi. Is it the fog of peace or the fog of war that hangs over the Vietnamese battlefield?
The spot rate on the British pound eased in quiet trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.
HONG KONG, Feb. 6 Communist China put into question today the continuation of diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union in the light of what it described as an attack on its embassy staff in Moscow.
BERLIN, Feb. 6 The meeting of Warsaw Pact nations scheduled for East Berlin tomorrow has apparently been transferred to Warsaw because of a threatened boycott by Rumania.
ROYAL BOX, Americana Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 52d Street. June Valli, singer.

In a realignment of its top officers, Douglas GibbonsHollyday Ives, Inc., has elected Brewster Ives chairman of the board and Donald S. Macdonald president. Richard C. Hollyday, formerly chairman, will become honorary chairman and consultant.

HOUSTON, Feb. 6 The privilege against self incrimination in the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution should be eased to require suspects to answer questions posed by judges, a noted criminal lawyer told a Congressional subcommittee today.
Ron Clarke, the Australian distance-running star, will run in two West Coast indoor track meets this month, the Amateur Athletic Union announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 A group of Mayors told Congress today they were unalterably opposed to the idea of the Federal Government's sharing its tax revenue with the states.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Proclaiming public order to be "the first business of government." President Johnson asked Congress today to authorize an extensive and costly program of Federal assistance to stimulate state and local crime control efforts.

HOUSTON, Feb. 6 Cassius Clay cruelly battered and cut the eyes of Ernie Terrell, the awkward and thoughtful challenger, for 15 rounds tonight to gain a unanimous decision and retain his world heavyweight boxing championship. A crowd of 37,321, an indoor record for a fight, saw Clay win.
The election of Robert H. Morris as president and chief executive officer of the Ohio Injector Company, a subsidiary of Kearney-National, Inc., was announced yesterday.

The United States Court of Appeals upheld yesterday a lower court decision denying motions by Gerardo A. Re and his son, Gerard F. Re. to set wide their convictions for stock fraud and to vacate sentences previously imposed.

"The no-duct, range hood has fully proved itself," Stanley Silber, general manager of Nautilus Industries in Freeland, Pa., was saying. "It has all the advantages of the ducted kitchen hood, plus the fact that it is a do-it-yourself item, its aircleaning machine dispels the odors ..."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) Representatives of the United States and the Soviet Union approved today the texts of two agreements to regulate Soviet fishing off the Pacific Coast of the United States.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6 The victors in the 24-hour sports car Continental race gathered their spoils at a champagne-and-filet mignon brunch attended by 300 persons today in the Hotel Daytona Plaza.
YONKERS, Feb. 6 A fourinch morning-afternoon snowfall and 16-degree temperature at night held down the crowd to 10,039 and the wagering to $1,079,971 at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) President Johnson has upgraded the rank of two United Nations delegates and will nominate an official of the Agency for International Development to the Inter-American Development Bank, the White House announced today.
Rehabilitated tenements will get improved maintenance and youngsters will net steady jobs under a program being drafted by city housing and antipoverty officials.
Howard Boyd, chairman of the El Paso Natural Gas Company, has been elected a director of the Greyhound Corporation.

ALPE D'HUEZ, France, Feb. 6 (AP) Eugenio Monti of Italy, seeking his 10th title, took the lead today after the first run in the world two-man bobsled championships. The best American placing was eighth.
The Canadian Department of Transport is seeking bids for the construction of a new icebreaking vessel for Canadian Coast Guard service on the Great Lakes.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 6 The Arizona Daily Star and the Tueson Daily Citizen were back on the streets today after cancellation of both papers' weekend editions in the face of disorders caused by mass picketing and scattered violence outside The Star Citizen plant.
CORNER BROOK, Nfld., Feb. 6 (Reuters) Bowater Newfoundland, Ltd., has suspended production of sulphite pulp for export because of a critical power shortage.

TOKYO, Feb. 6 Diplomatic sources in Peking say President Liu Shao-chi and the Communist party's secretary general, Teng Hsiao-ping, have been dismissed from their jobs, two Japanese correspondents reported from the Chinese capital today.

TORONTO, Feb. 6 The shares of companies involved in the family row over the Bank of Western Canada declined today in active trading as Finance Minister Mitchell Sharp called on both sides in the dispute to appear before the Parliamentary finance committee.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 6--With a sizable victory in yesterday's election, President-elect Anastasio Somoza Debayle called today for a reconciliation in Nicaragua.
WARSAW, Feb. 6 East German and Polish sources indicated today that the conference of Warsaw Pact foreign ministers will be held later this week in Warsaw.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 6 Billy Rothwell scored after 5 minutes 10 seconds of the overtime period today to give New Hampshire a 5-4 victory over Army in an Eastern College Athletic Conference hockey game.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 6 (UPI) The personnel of the North American Air Defense Command moved under a 1,400foot protective mountain of granite today.

The Continental Oil Company last year had a record consolidated net income of $115.6million, or $5.08 a common share, Andrew W. Tarkington, the company's president and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.

Walt Bellamy is expected to be back in action tonight as the New York Knickerbockers meet the Los Angeles Lakers at Madison Square Garden. In a preliminary game at 6:45 P.M., two top National Amateur Athletic Union League teams, the Akron Goodyears and Phillips 66ers, will make a rare New York appearance.
More than 1,600 suntanned ship passengers returned from winter cruises in the sunny Caribbean yesterday, stepped onto chilly piers and became baggage handlers.

HONG KONG, Feb. 6 The use of the word "commune" in Peking in the last few days to describe emerging new organs of control in Peking, Taiyuan and Shanghai appears to represent groping moves by the Maoist revolutionary movement toward new forms of government.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 The State Board of Examiners announced today the names of 379 persons who passed the examination for admission to the bar. Of the 210 candidates who took the examination for the first time, 130 passed. A total of 625 applicants took the examination on Nov. 30 and Dec. 1, 1968.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6 Snow swirled off Lake Michigan again today, coating old, blackened drifts with a scarf of white and hindering anew Chicago's efforts to did out from its record storm of 11 days ago.
OCEANSIDE, L.I., Feb. 6 Their spirit was willing, but 80 mothers found today that their flesh was too weak for them to compete successfully against their children in physical fitness tests.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) A 19-year-old marine who was mortally wounded while shielding the evacuation of injured companions in South Vietnam was named a Medal of Honor winner today.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 6 Two heads from an 11-headed Buddhist idol, allegedly destroyed by Chinese Red Guards in Tibet were displayed here today by the Dalai Lama.
The Lindsay administration has reversed a previous plan and given assurance that Gouverneur Hospital will provide services for the acutely ill in its new building.
Vivid close-ups of Ernie Terrell's grimacing face, betweenrounds replays of the damaging blows and an excellent blackand-white picture kept 5,500 fans at Madison Square Garden quite happy last night.
The Lytton Savings and Loan Association, Los Angeles, announced yesterday the election of William E. Weigel as executive vice president.
MILAN, Italy, Feb. 6 (Reuters) Ferene Budaj, a Hungarian trade official, was jailed today for five years and Domenico Villa, an Italian, for four years on charges of espionage.

A cruise to southern waters will set sail on March 3, and every passenger aboard will be a substantial contributor to Project Hope. This is believed the first time fund-raising and winter-cruising have been joined.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 The Senate approved today the establishment of a National Water Commission to make a "comprehensive review of national water resource problems and programs."
The Comomnwealth Oil Refining Company and the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company announced jointly yesterday plans for the construction of a $45million to $50-million ethylene plant in Puerto Rico.
DETROIT, Feb. 6 (AP) The nation's auto industry strove to get its car building lines back to normal operation this week after bad weather cut deeply into last week's output.
NUIDAT, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 7 (Reuters) New Zealand artillerymen accidentally shelled Australian troops near here yesterday, killing 4 men and wounding 13.

MADRID, Feb. 6 Professors at Valencia University's School of Philosophy protested today against measures imposed on students at the University of Barcelona and called for a nationwide student strike tomorrow.

PRESUMABLY it was George Szell's idea to present Beethoven's great "Missa Solemnis" without an intermission. He conducted it last night in Carnegie Hall as the first of the season's offerings by the Cleveland Symphony in New York, and it was a wonderful idea. This way one gets the consecutive sweep of the big score (1 hour, 18 minutes, last night), and there is no intermission to shatter the mood.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the nation's largest sales finance company, disclosed yesterday that it had reduced the interest rate it charges automobile dealers to finance inventories of unsold cars to 6 per cent from 6 per cent retroactive to last Wednesday.
LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 7 (AP) Britain's Labor Government won support in Parliament early today for the imposition of mandatory sanctions against Rhodesia as voted by the United Nations.
Clifton I. Frank, a partner in the Frank Travel Service died Sunday in his home, 215 East 73d Street. He was 77 years old.
Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times, was elected a life trustee of Columbia University yesterday.
THE energetic career soldier who has been elected President of Nicaragua must be reckoned a modern kind of major general.

MOSCOW, Feb. 6 A tense mood developed outside the Chinese Embassy this evening as Moscow factory workers converged on the modern sevenstory, glass and concrete structure to submit resolutions of protest against alleged Chinese terrorizing of Russians in Peking.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler said today that he did not have "any confidence" Congress could or would cut $4-billion to $6-billion from President Johnson's budget and that therefore he believed a tax increase this year would be necessary.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, Feb. 7 (Reuters) The Peking radio reported this morning that Chinese troops had arrested a number of leading party officials after a clash between Maoists and their opponents in the Manchurian industrial city of Changehun.
HOUSTON, Feb. 6--In his own cruel time, Cassius Clay battered and dimmed the eyes of Ernie Terrell tonight and added the awkward giant's heavy weight title to his own.
By WILLIAM N. WALLACE Forty-two players in the Na- tional Football League will belong to a new team, the New Orleans Saints, as of Friday.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 6 The civil rights movement has collapsed in broad areas of the South, and is fighting what seems to be a last-ditch battle for survival in its few remaining spheres of influence.

MARLBORO, N.Y., Feb. 6 In his youth, Floyd Patterson enjoyed hiding in a small room where subway work- men kept their tools at the end of the High Street station in Brooklyn. The total blackness, he said once, was "my hideaway ... from the bitterness of the world. I'd spread papers on the floor and I'd go to sleep and I'd find peace."

The board of trustees of Columbia University voted approval in principle last night of an experimental broadcast laboratory that will offer a Sunday night series of live coast-to-coast programs next fall over noncommercial stations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 President Johnson presented the National Medal of Science to 11 men today and urged the American scientific community to greater efforts.

PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 6 Mr. and Mrs. William Dexter Bramhall have announced they engagement of Mr. Bramhall's daughter, Miss Susan Alice Bramhall, to Thomas James Babe Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Babe of Rochester. A spring wedding is planned.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 6 Michele Ray, a French correspondent, told today how she had crouched for four hours in a shallow tunnel as rocket and mortar shells burst a few feet over her head one day during her three-week captivity by the Vietcong.

As parties have gone this season, the one held last evening for Elia Kazan, the stage and film director, could hardly be called pretentious. No one wore masks, and evening dress was absolutely de trop. But the guest list wasn't a dull one--Tennessee Williams flew in from the Virgin Islands and Budd Schulberg from Hollywood, and Andy Warhol turned up with some of the cast of "The Chelsea Girls"
Employers and union members in the commercial printing industry went back to school last night tn study the economics of the printing business in New York.

The smallest of the four surviving Brooklyn quintuplets Talitha Harris was gravely ill with pneumonia last night. She was reported in "poor" condition, as a team of doctors at the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn tried to save her life.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 6 (UPI) Buckpasser, the 1966 horse of the year, made his first visit to the training track at Santa Anita today since having been sidelined by a hoof infection just before the $100,000 Charles H. Strub Stakes.
BOWIE, Md., Tuesday, Feb. 7 (AP) Today's racing program at Bowie Race Course has been canceled because of snow, General Manager Jack Loome announced early today.

IT would be difficult to define precisely what I find so engaging about the Manhattan Festival Ballet, which is permanently installed on Monday nights at the excellent Theater 80. St. Marks Place. But I think in one word it would be its enthusiasm, which is two words but one should never underestimate anything.
Senator Jacob K. Javits renewed yesterday his call for Presidential primary elections in New York State. He asked:

POWNAL, Vt., Feb. 6 The engagement of Miss Sally Dodge to Michael William Mole, son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Mole of Salt Lake City, has been annnounced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge Jr. of Quarry Hill Farm here. A June wedding is planned.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 The nation's clinical laboratories were accused today of serious deficiencies that have a sometimes aggravated illness and even caused deaths.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Feb. 6 The engagement of Miss Mary Esther Dunn to Robert Brevoort Medina, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold R. Medina Jr. of New York and Westhampton, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. R. Robert Dunn Jr. Plans have been made for a wedding July 8.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)--Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen said today that some of his objections to the United States-Soviet consular treaty were being removed by intensive study of its terms.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 6 (UPI) Two Xavier University basketball players, John Macel, a 5-foot-10-inch senior guard and captain from Huntington, W. Va., and Jack Radich, a 6-4 freshman forward from Columbus, Ohio, were declared today academically ineligible for further play this season.
The walls came tumbling down yesterday on the United States Track and Field Federation's invitation meet Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

WESTON, Conn., Feb. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Herbel Howe have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adeline Honour Howe, to Miller Parker Longbotham Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lonabotham of Rye, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.
FREEPORT, Me., Feb. 6 (AP) L.L. Bean, mail order super salesman of outdoors goods, died yesterday in Pompano, Beach, Fla. He was 94 years old and lived here.

BUFFALO, Feb. 6 A fourmonth study requested by Governor Rockefeller has concluded that the new campus for the State University center here should be in suburban Amherst, not in a downtown waterfront area favored by a committee of prominent residents.
WASHINGTON, Feb.6 (AP) Three women members of Congress, in a move for equal rights, tried to crash the House men's gym today. They were politely, but hastily, ushered out.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Feb. 6 Rosemary Casals, San Francisco's sensational 18-yearold tennis queen, beat Francoise Durr of France today to win the women's singles crown in the Wills invitational tennis tournament.

Miss Mary Katherine Smyth, daughter of Mrs. Gibbs Smyth of 166 East 63d Street and Joseph P. Smyth, was married Saturday in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, to Maurice Hanson Basquin, son of Mrs. Harold Lee Harmeson of Frankfort, Ind., and the late Maurice Hanson Basquin. The Rev. Graham Dowell performed the ceremony in the Anglican Church of St. Matthew, following a civil ceremony in the Municipality Building.

Eric Bentley, Brander Matthews Professor of Dramatic Literature at Columbia University, has been selected as the winner of the George Jean Nathan Award in dramatic criticism for the 1965-66 season. The $4,000 prize is the biggest in the American theater.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 6 This island city, capital of the old British colonial empire whose indelible traces remain in the snappy policemen, the efficient civil service, the left-hand traffic and the cricket club, is perhaps as good a place as any from which to look at an evolving and enigmatic Asia.
CARE, a nonprofit overseas aid agency, has prepared a new emergency plan to increase its famine relief program in India.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) Forty-seven Senators proposed today a special Federal income tax credit of up to $325 a year to lighten the expenses of higher education.
Directors of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation elected a new chairman and president yesterday and authorized plans for a $125-million sale of convertible subordinated debentures.
"I'M making a Donegal tweed skirt and I don't want the seams to unravel. Some- one told me to use glue. But I'm hoping Mr. Bach can show me a better way."
Steel production in the week ended Saturday was almost unchanged from that of the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
UCHINOURA, Japan, Feb. 6 (AP) A Japanese Lambda3H space research rocket was lifted today to a height of 1,337 miles, a new record for Japanese rockets, the space research center announced.

ATLANTA, Feb. 6 (UPI) Bobby Dodd stepped down today as football coach at Georgia Tech because of illness, but he will remain as the school's athletic director. He said his successor as coach would be named within the week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) President Johnson announced today that he would nominate Brig. Gen. Walter P. Leber as Governor of the Panama Canal Zone.

Bitter cold and snow rolled into the city yesterday from the Midwest and Canada, disrupting airplane travel, delaying buses and trains and causing hazardous driving conditions. The icy weather was part of a cold front that spread arctic air from Texas
CHEYNEY STATE defeated East Stroudsburg State Saturday night, regaining its winning ways and starting what any loyal Cheyney fan hopes will lead to another long winning streak.

SEVENTH AVENUE was a street for three seasons yesterday. In the air was the snow of winter; crowding the streets were hand-trucks laden with the clothes of spring; in the showrooms were the first presentations of the styles of summer.

YESTERDAY (Feb. 6, 1967) THE PRESIDENT Sent crime message to Congress; participated in presentation of the National Medal of Science awards; saw chairman Ackley of the Council of Economic Advisers; announced his selection of Army Brig. Gen. Walter P. Leber as new Governor of the Panama Canal Zone.

Dr. Sydney Selesnick, director of the New York Veterans Administration Hospital, First Avenue and 24th Street, died Sunday at the hospital. He was 58 years old. Since his appointment to the post here six months ago he had lived at 408 First Avenue.

CAPETOWN, Feb. 6 The aircraft carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt left today for the United States 14 hours before her scheduled departure but not before 60 of her 3,800 crewmen had answered a South African appeal for blood donations that will be administered on a segregated basis.

State Supreme Court Justice Thomas A. Aurelio yesterday refused to either quash or modify a subpoena calling on former Criminal Court Judge Benjamin H. Schor to testify before the State Investigation Commission.

A grant from the United States National Council on the Arts has made possible the revival of Alwin Nikolais's fullevening, dance, theater production, "Imago." It will have a four-week season at the Henry Street Playhouse.
Grace Bumbry sang her first Amneris in Verdi's "Aida" with the Metropolitan Opera last night. She made a handsome, imperious princess, both in singing and in acting.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 Leaders of the National Cotton Council claimed today for the cotton products industry its brightest outlook "in modern history."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 6 Dr. Albert Schaafsma of the Hague died today of a heart attack while addressing a group of experts on a five-year survey program, sponsored by the Secretary General. U Thant on the development of nonagricultural resources. He was 61 years old.
About 75 retired union musicians braved the bad weather yesterday and demonstrated that old musicians don't die they just blow away or fiddle and drum away.

A major reorganization of United Air Lines' East Coast operations is being completed to meet expanded traffic in the next few years, according to A.J. Schoepf, who has been named regional vice president for sales and services.

HOWARD SCHENKEN and Peter Leventritt of New York showed that their longestablished partnership is as good as ever by winning the Riviera Masters Knockout Team Championship in Las Vegas last week. Teamed with Lew Mathe and Robert Hamman of Los Angeles they won seven straight matches to capture the first prize of $7,500.
Queens College defeated Brooklyn Poly, 93-61, last night at Fitzgerald Gym. Queens. Queen's won-lost record is 3-10 and Brooklyn Poly has yet to win in 10 games.
Stock prices closed mixed yesterday after having meandered upward and downward in another active session.
Three major cast changes, two necessitated by illness and one by the weather, made last night's repetition of "Queen of Spades" at the Metropolitan Opera, of more than normal interest.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 7 (UPI) Fleet Host won the $29,300 Arcadia Handicap by a nose today in a four-horse blanket finish at Santa Anita race track.
The Right Rev. Edward T. O'Meara took office yesterday as national director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, succeeding Bishop Fulton J. Sheen.
Herbert L. Haber, director of labor relations for the city, denied yesterday that he misled negotiators for firemen and policemen in bargaining talks last December.
MONTREAL, Feb. 7 FranzPaul Decker has been appointed music director of the Montreal Symphony, effective immediately.

WATERTOWN, S.D., Feb. 7 (AP) United States and Canadian power were tied together successfully today in a huge grid test.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The President's commission on the draft will recommend drafting the youngest men first instead of the oldest and will propose that the gradual abolition of student deferments be given serious consideration, informed sources said today.
Stocks closed lower with savings-and-loan and glamour issues weakest in an abbreviated trading session; volume, 6.4 million shares.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Almost $1-million in grants for scholarly research projects were announced today by the National Endowment for the Humanities.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 7 The arms aid that Iran is expected to receive from the Soviet Union will be a dramatic further Step in the developing rapprochement between the Soviet Union and its southern neigbor.
MIAMI, Feb. 7 (AP) Bobby Ussery scored at Hialcah today by winning the sixth race on Irongate, by six lengths, and the seventh on Secret Promise, by four lengths.
Levitt Sons, Inc., the nations largest home-building company. yesterday opened the first unit of a contemplated chain of 10 home-furnishings stores.

Mrs. Elizabeth Tonkonogy Osserman, widow of Stanley Osserman, former chairman of the board of Dictograph Products, Inc., died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 62 years old and lived at 28 East 73d Street.
John W. Mazzola has been appointed senior vice president of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

The 1:04 P.M. Public Service bus from Teaneck, N.J., was 10 minutes late leaving for New York yesterday afternoon. It arrived at the Port Authority Terminal at 41st Street and Eighth Avenue 5 hours and 58 minutes late.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 7 Repeating criticism that haste has made for waste in the nation's Apollo moon project, two engineers said today that the pressure of meeting schedules had tempted workmen to take shortcuts.
The New York State Society of Newspaper Editors went "firmly on record" against "socalled amnesty measures" at the final session of its winter meeting yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 7 H. Edmund Machold, a director of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation and once a major figure in Republican state politics, died last night at the Upstate Medical Center. He was 86 years old.
A sense of isolation spread over the city's suburbs yesterday as the snowstorm closed schools, shops and offices, and an icy base from Monday's storm made roads hazardous and generally impassable.

AMERICAN women may soon wish they had followed the Italian cus tom of throwing their old crockery out the window on New Year's Eve. For new designs in porcelain, china, pottery and plastic dinnerware are very tempting. The designs for the most part are bolder, more colorful and imaginative than those seen since the early nineteen-fifties, when dinnerware in modern patterns began appearing on the market.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 7(AP) The formation of a company that will operate a national chain of Negro-owned supermarkets was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) Vice President Humphrey defied a heavy snowstorm today to hear the Council of Lake Erie and Great Lakes Ports bemoan their financial losses.
The Beatrice Foods Company plans to acquire James H. Rhodes Co. for an undisclosed amount of stock, it was announced yesterday. The merger would become effective March 20.
Nurses are being trained to read electrocardiograms of patients in acute coronary distress and perform other complex life-saving tasks formerly done only by physicians.
Weakened by pneumonia, the smallest of the four surviving quintuplets born last Wednesday in Brooklyn died early yesterday morning.
The Bristol-Myers Company, a pharmaceutical producer, announced here yesterday the election of William F. Moss 3d as a vice president.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he agreed that funds for urban purposes under any Federal tax sharing program should go directly to major cities rather than be channeled to them through the states.

WHEN the telephone rang at 4:02 A.M. yesterday in his six-room apartment on Staten Island, jarring Patrick Michael Torre from sleep, he realized that for the next few days he was going to be one of the most important men in New York City one of the 9,910 regular "San men" on.

Earnings of the Weyerhaeuser Company last year dropped 4.4 per cent from the record set in 1965 despite a 15 per cent rise in sales to a new high, the Tacoma, Wash., forest-products company reported yesterday.
Part of a $105-million expansion program announced yesterday by the McLouth Steel Corporation will consist of four curved-mold continuous casting machines, the company said yesterday in Detroit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) The Senate defeated today an attempt by Senator Russell B. Long to sheive the Congressional reorganization bill by sending it back to the special committee that drafted it. The vote was 70 to 18.

SECTIONAL tournaments seldom attract players from substantial distances, but exceptions may occur when the site of the tournament is worth a visit in its own right. The Bermuda sectional last week was one of the exceptions: there were large contingents from St. Louis, New England, New York, and other parts of the eastern seaboard.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 7 United States Air Force helicopters have been replaced by Thai aircraft in supporting operations against guerrillas in the northeast, informed sources said today.

IT would be too clearly facile to suggest that the dance avant-garde is made up of two elements, the dance and the avant-garde, but such facility does perhaps produce a tiny grain of truth. Elizabeth Keen and Rudy Perez, for whom a surprisingly large audience braved the aftermath of the blizzard at the Judson Memorial Church last night, perhaps illustrate my point.

The snow emergency declared yesterday morning by Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes meant that motorists were barred from parking or standing on more than 1,000 miles of thoroughfare marked "snow streets" and "snow emergency routes."
Stock prices declined slightly yesterday in a session cut short by the blizzard.

Martin M. Berger, a 39-yearold lawyer who has been an active worker in legal cases involving civil rights here and in the South, was elected unanimously last night by Democratic County committeemen for Greenwich Village to succeed City Councilman Edward I. Koch as district leader for the area.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 7 (AP)--India's 1966-67 jute crop is one of the best in years, but exports of jute goods have fallen sharply, seriously damaging one of the country's major industries.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today that he did not think the Government should ever again try to establish a specific guidepost for wage increases.
Loses outnumbered gains yesterday in an abbreviated trading session on the American Stock Exchange.
The first live global telecast linking five of the seven continents will be carried on the National Educational Television network Sunday, June 25, at 3 P.M.
A committce of prominent New Yorkers suggested drastic changes yesterday in the approach and organization of departments that shape the physical contours of the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)--House Republicans plan to oppose the Administration's request for a $6-billion increase in the national debt limit unless two Republican amendments are included, Representative Melvin R. Laird, Wisconsin Republican, said today.

The strike by Local 824 of the International Longshoremen's Association at three Hudson River piers enters its sixth day today as two actions, scheduled for yesterday, that could have halted the walkout, were postponed for 24 hours.

Heights Casino defeated The Yale Club, 3-2, yesterday and advanced to the final of the Class C Metropolitan squash racquets playoffs at the Racquets Tennis Club.

Limited resources have always been a major obstacle to noncommercial television in demonstrating its capacity for spreading public enlightenment and enjoyment. Since mid-November the Criminal Courthouse at 100 Centre Street has been open 24 hours a day, seven days a week, to permit the prompt arraignment of persons arrested anywhere in Manhattan. The effect of the new hours on the administration of justice has been so beneficial that the system should be extended to the four other boroughs as soon as possible.

PARK HILLS, N.Y., Feb. 7 Miss Judith Benner Allen and Gallion Adrian Thompson plan to be married on April 1. Their engagement has been announced by Miss Allen's parents. Mr. and Mrs. Buford Layton Allen. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gallion Thompson of Virginia Beach, Va.

Two thousand snow plows and salt spreaders rumbled again and again through the streets of the city yesterday as snowflake after snowflake, pushed by icy winds, quickly covered their tracks and frustrated the efforts of 7,000 sanitation workers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) The Department of Commerce fixed today at 1,366,845 tons the amount of steel mill products I that must be reserved for de fense orders in the second quarter of 1967.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 A special House investigating committee agreed today to prohibit Representative Adam Clayton Powell from charging other House members with misconduct when he testifies tomorrow.
