Almost $4.5-million in grants to develop and expand education facilities throughout the world were announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.
The petroleum industry has raised questions about the supply and need for low-sulphur fuels, growing out of air pollution control recommendations here and elsewhere.

LONDON, Feb. 8 Sir Victor Gollanez, an idealist of the left whose vastly successful publishing enterprise and ardent writings did much to prepare Britain intellectually for the welfare state, died early this morning at his home. He was 73 years old.
TOKYO, Feb. 8 Tsutomo Seki, an amateur astronomer, sighted a new comet four days ago and, as he always does on such occasions, "quivered with joy and excitement."
The Emerson Electric Company has announced the election to its board of James S. Anderson, a retired president of the Babcock Wilcox Company.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Feb. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Louis Holland have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beverly Holland, to Dr. Fredric Reichel. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Reichel of New York and Stockbridge, Mass.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 Following is the text of President Johnson's reply to Pope Paul:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 Democratic members of the House Banking and Currency Committee agreed today to curb the powers of their chairman, Wright Patman of Texas.
Despite freezing temperatures that encrusted and hardened the thick blanket of snow, those in the suburbs began yesterday to dig themselves out from under the heaviest snowfall of the year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 The West German Foreign Minister, Willy Brandt, expressed concern today that a treaty to bar the spread of nuclear weapons might impose a technological handicap on Germany in developing the peaceful uses of atomic energy.

Daniel P. Moynihan, author of a controversial report on the Negro family, said in an article published yesterday that an opportunity to make a "total commitment to the cause of Negro equality" was lost 20 months ago because of the short-sightedness of civil rights leaders, Negro and white.

JAMES GABRIEL GALANOS came out of the West with a 200-piece fashion collection that kept 300 store executives and reporters in their seats for two hours and solidified his position as one of the top-ranking designers at work anywhere.
Directors of the American Zinc Company voted yesterday to reduce the quarterly dividend to 10 cents a common share from 35 cents, payable March 20 to holders of record Feb. 24.

BONN, Feb. 8 Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger summoned the Soviet Ambassador, Semyon K. Tsarapkin, to his residence today to reiterate West Germany's contention that it alone legally represents all the German people.

LONDON, Feb. 8 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union said today that unconditional cessation of American bombing was "necessary in order to enable talks to take place" between the United States and North Vietnam.

Prof. Jotham Johnson, chairman of the classics department at New York University, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at a meeting of department heads in the Main Building on Washington Square. He was 61 years old.

Last season Montserrat Caballe, the much-admired Spanish soprano, made a single appearance with the Metropolitan Opera, as Marguerite in "Faust." It turned out to be a role not ideally suited to her. Last night she sang with the company again, this time as Leonora in "II Trovatore." The Verdi opera showed off much better the special virtues of her artistry. For lovers of beautiful singing, her performance gave unusual satisfaction.

RAYY, Iran Abbas Farajollah pointed sadly with a hand roughened by 20 years of professional carpet scrubbing at a peasant girl who was using an American detergent to do her laundering at the Chasmeh Ali spring.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 8 Capt. Dennis Macks scored four goals to lead Brown to a 10-5 upset victory over Yale tonight in an Ivy League hockey game in Ingalls Rink.
BERLIN, Feb. 8 An East German mother sacrificed her own rights to allow her young daughter to return to West Berlin to live with her grandparents.
Welfare Department caseworkers marched along a snowbanked sidewalk at a midtown center yesterday in a demonstration aimed at getting the city to hire more employes so that caseloads can be reduced.

PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 8 (UPI) A radio signal sent nearly a quarter-million miles through space today ignited a retro-rocket engine aboard America's moon-bound Lunar Orbiter 3. The rocket was slightly slowed to place it into the proper eliptical orbit around the moon for photographing possible manned landing sites.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--President Johnson gave Congress a vivid picture today of the neglect suffered by millions of American children and recommended a variety of measures, largely experimental, to alleviate their condition and to seek long-term solutions.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 8 (Reuters) Australia gained a draw with South Africa today when their fourth cricket test was abandoned because of rain.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 (AP) Russell Johnson, a Quaker peace committee official who visited Hanoi from Jan. 20 to Feb. 3, said today he believed that the Vietnam war could be ended only if the Americans left.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 8 The reapportionment plan that the Westchester County Board of Supervisors proposed last November after months of controversey was declared unconstitutional today by Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan because of a minor provision.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Monday the level it reached on Friday, which was 102.5.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 8 Mr. and Mrs. John Henderson Crichton have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kimberly Crichton, to John William Roper Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Roper of Twin Falls, Idaho.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday that efforts last year to combat inflation had succeeded in slowing down the economy.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 8 Frank Louis Esposito, controller and a vice president of Schenley Industries, died today in his home at 300 Martine Avenue. His age was 57.
Lent, the penitential season for Christians, began yesterday, Ash Wednesday. It will continue for 40 days, exclusive of Sundays, ending at Easter, the joyful festival of the Resurrection.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 Wilbur J. Cohen, the Under Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, expressed opposition today to various proposals to give the poor some kind of guaranteed cash income.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 President Johnson expressed hope today that the current four-day cease-fire in Vietnam might be extended and open the way to negotiations for "a just and stable peace."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 Somewhere in transit between London and Dulles Airport, an air traveler, obviously doodling with his identity crisis, wrote the following self-description on the back of a paper napkin and left it in the seat pocket where it was later found by the cleaning crew:
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 8--The United Hospital in Port Chester will benefit from a matinee and an evening performance of "Festival of Ballet" on March 4 at the Highlands School.

Childville, a residential treatment center for emotionally disturbed children, will benefit from a dinner dance to be held at the Pierre on March 4. Six Childville chapters are sponsoring the event to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the agency's service.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 8 The nationwide Fast for Peace, timed to coincide with the lunar New Year cease-fire in Vietnam and the beginning of Lent, received scattered support on its first day today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 8 The 13-nation panel of experts on the proposed United Nations conference on exploration and peaceful uses of outer space elected Vikram A. Sarabhai of India as chairman today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 8 (AP) Chaerul Saleh, once one of President Sukarno's closest advisers, died early today in his prison cell, military sources reported.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 8 A Negro will take over the hiring and assigning of teachers next month in the public school system here, one of the South's first battlegrounds on school desegregation 10 years ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 Following is the text of President Johnson's special message to Congress on America's children and youth:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) The Johnson Administration sent Congress today an antibugging bill that would ban virtually all electronic eavesdropping or wiretapping.

Higher copper prices outside the United States, increased copper production and a better return on investment in fabricating operations swelled earnings of the Anaconda Company last year to $132,408,000 from $79,467,000 in 1965.

A PLAYER in a contract that seems too easy should consider the possibility of a bad break. This was the situation on the diagramed deal, which was played recently at the Gotham Bridge Club, in the Olcott Hotel at 27 West 72d Street.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 9--An American military spokesman listed today only 17 "significant incidents," assertedly caused by enemy forces, during the first 24 hours of the current four-day holiday cease-fire.

That the American movie public is not particularly homogenized, nor quite as sophisticated as might be indicated by the success of "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" is illustrated by the success of "The Ghost and Mr. Chicken," a film that is probably unknown to most New Yorkers.
The marriage of Mrs. Fritzi Cosden Ritter, widow of Dr. Henry Housman Ritter, to John Hendricks Young of New York and Whitehouse Station, N.J., took place yesterday evening.
NORTH STRATFORD, N.H., Feb. 8 (UPI) Fire raced through a nursing home in this islated northern New Hampshire community tonight, killing four elderly persons and injur

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 Hernan Echavarria, Colombia's Ambassador to the United States, said tonight that he had been advised by his Government that an agreement had been reached with the International Monetary Fund.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 8 The state's investigation into charges of anti-Negro discrimination in construction unions opened today at City Hall with a hearing that was boycotted by the civil rights leaders whose grievances led to the inquiry.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 8 (UPI) The University of Pittsburgh announced today that in the interests of academic freedom it had broken with Helen Clay Frick, one of its most generous benefactors.

Ralph Morgan Pitcher, vice president of personnel of the Business Supplies Corporation of America, 475 Fifth Avenue, and president of American Business Executives, Inc., died yesterday at New York Hospital. He would have been 77 years old today.
ALPE d' HUEZ, France, Feb. 8 (UPI)--Two Austrians and a Norwegian captured major honors today as the Olympic winter rehearsals finally moved into top gear.
THE sport of shooting live pigeons is little known in this country, where it is banned in many places. But in Europe and Mexico it is pursued with much enthusiasm and money.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 The steel industry began a major drive today to have Congress enact a new "temporary levy" on imports of foreign steel and pig iron.
The stock market roared back into high gear yesterday with prices rising sharply in heavy trading.

TOKYO, Feb. 8 The Tokyo police arrested today a multimillionaire industrialist and six associates allegedly involved in the corruption enveloping the Japanese election campaign last month. The arrests dominated the news here today.

The United States needs a foreign policy decision in order to avoid the multiple embarrassments that accompanied the curtailed refueling stop of the carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt at Capetown, and it is clear what that decision should be. But it is doubtful whether the decision will be forthcoming.
The New York waterfront was humming again yesterday as 15,681 longshoremen went to work on 95 piers and 92 ships.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) More than 400 former Peace Corps members and other persons who have served abroad on private and governmental projects asked President Johnson today to end the bombing of North Vietnam beginning with the current lunar New Year truce.

Charles Reed and Eugene Williams, having survived several Harlem snowball fights during the morning, threw themselves upon flattened cartons, coasted down a 10-foot-high hillock of snow running across the sidewalk on Lexington Avenue near 111th Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 The Administration is considering a mailing surcharge on American mass-circulation magazines that could cost them $5.5-million a year.
ALBANY, Feb. 8 A bipartisan majority of the Senate and Assembly rallied behind a direct primary bill today, but there was still no guarantee that it would pass both houses at this session.

LIKE a moth into a flame, Peter Serkin flew right into Beethoven's "Diabelli" Variations last night in Philharmonic Hall. He did not emerge entirely unscathed. The long "Diabelli" Variations, Beethoven's 33 exegeses
The J.C. Penney Company announced here yesterday the appointment of Thomas J. Spenker as executive vice president and a director of its wholly owned insurance subsidiaries.

Trans World Airlines' Flight 97, a Boeing 707 bound for St. Louis, took off from Kennedy Airport at 11:15 yesterday morning with 97 passengers, the first plane to leave the city since the storm struck 25 hours earlier.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 The Inter-American Development Bank announced today five loans totaling $67.8-million, bringing the banks lending activity past the $2-billion mark.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 8 Chances of making food aid to poorer countries part of any Kennedy round tariff-cutting agreement are rapidly diminishing, despite strong American promotion efforts.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 8 Arthur Calwell, the 70-year-old leader of the Australian Labor party, which suffered defeat in the last three federal elections, resigned today. He was succeeded by his deputy, Gough Whitlam.
The Yale University swimming team defeated Columbia yesterday, 60-33, in the Columbia pool.

VINCENT LOMBARDI, the boss of the Green Bay Packers who was here yesterday addressing a luncheon of the American Management Association at the Americana Hotel, delivered his opinion about the status of Mike Ditka, the star tight end of the Chicaeo Bears.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Adam Clayton Powell, risking the loss of his seat in the House, refused today on Constitutional grounds to answer a select committee's questions about his New York court troubles and his conduct as a committee chairman for six years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 American industry was accused today of having done "only what public pressure required it to do" about air pollution.

LONDON, Feb. 8 The House of Commons strongly reinforced today the "consensus" that the Government should stay out of the financially troubled British newspaper industry and let the papers work out their own salvation.
A maritime labor award dealing with "me-too" clauses in labor agreements was hailed yesterday as offering a solution to the whipsaw bargaining that has plagued the shipping industry for decades.

The United Nations diplomatic community, which has complained at times about living conditions in the city, will be assisted by a new high-level committee including Mayor Lindsay and civic representatives.
CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP) The Peoria trial of Richard Speck, charged with murdering eight Chicago student nurses, was postponed a second time today, to Feb. 20.

BANGKOK, Feb. 8 Despite the sudden spectacle of the Chinese giant thrashing and gasping in a violent wrestling match with itself, no one in this part of the world expects to see a more tractable Chinese regime soon emerging from the smoke and dust. As one experienced Asian leader described the struggle, "It seems to be the hard line against the harder line."

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, Feb. 8 (Reuters) The Prime Minister, Sir Albert Margai, announced today the discovery of an army officers' plot against him and thanked President S kou Tour of Guinea for having helped to forestall it.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Feb. 8 (UPI) Cazzie Russell broke a 103 103 tie with a free throw in the final minute of play tonight and the New York Knickerbockers went on to gain a 106103 National Basketball Association victory over the Chicago Bulls.

Sanitation Commissioner Samuel J. Kearing Jr. tramped and rode through the city's snow-laden streets yesterday, made an aerial inspection from a police helicopter and then promised a passable lane for traffic on every street by this morning.
ASHLAND, Ohio, Feb. 8 (UPI) Rex Wolfe, a firstgrade pupil, walked to school today while it was three degrees below zero.
The Rev. Milton A. Galamison, leader of the 1964 school boycott here, will head a new antipoverty program he has proposed to the city. It is expected to be set up in all five boroughs.

A seven-story apartment house at 153d Street and 89th Avenue in Jamaica, Queens, has been purchased by Mary Immaculate Hospital, a Roman Catholic institution directly across the street, for a price reported "in excess of $100,000."

BOSTON, Feb. 8 (AP) The American Academy of Arts and Sciences tonight awarded its Rumford Premium, established in 1796, to Robert H. Dicke of Princeton University and Cornelis B. van Niel of Stanford University.

In the continuing northward movement of the textile industry in Manhattan, Burlington Industries, Inc., the world's largest textile producer, disclosed yesterday that it would occupy quarters between 54th and 55th Street on the Avenue of the Americas.
A worried motorist, who was forced to leave his car on the road in Tuesday's blizzard, wondered yesterday whether his insurance policy would pay off if another vehicle struck

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 8 (UPI) Gov. Dewey Bartlett announced today that an agreement had been reached in the Fox-Tatums School dispute to clear the way for 75 Negro children who have been out of school since last September to return to class.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 The Senate rejected today two proposals to require annual financial statements from each Senator and every Senate employe earning more than $10,000 a year.

PASADENA, Calif. "When we entertain," Lois Brown declared, "we're fairly typical of others who live in Southern California. We either have a very few guests, six or eight perhaps, or a really large bash. We cat lots of salads, very few starches and emphasize fruits for dessert. We have a long cocktail hour and dine at 8 or 9."
MIAMI, Feb. 8 J. Graham Brown's Woozem won the $35,600 Mimosa Stakes at Hialeah today, appearing much the best of a field of nine fillies.
MOSCOW, Feb. 8 Soviet loudspeakers blared complaints at the curtained windows of the Chinese Embassy today while the Soviet Foreign Ministry accused the diplomats inside of rudeness.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 8 The engagement of Miss Gloria Diane Spitalny to Howard Gary Smith has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William L. Spitalny.
MIAMI, Feb. 8 (UPI) A three-judge Federal Court ordered today a 48-Senator, 119Representative reapportionment plan for Florida, with a special election to fill all the seats.

Harris B. Steinberg, a criminal defense lawyer, last night told a forum of the Federal Bar Association that defendants should be guaranteed the right to "discover" or review the prosecution's evidence before a trial began.
"I was a little disappointed in other years when I didn't make it," Ken Strong said, "but as long as it happens before you're dead."

Ken Strong and Emlen Tunnell, heroes of separate eras when the New York Giants won championships in the National Football League, were among eight men who have been named to the National Pro Football Hall of Fame, officials announced yesterday.
The Interstate Engineering Corporation of Anaheim, Calif., is being wooed by a second admirer.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 8 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was struck in the face by a stone today while addressing a heckling, hooting crowd during an election campaign rally in Bhubaneswar, capital of Orissa state.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday the receipt of orders for two nuclear-power plants with a total capacity of 1,077,000 kilowatts.
The appointment of Philip Click as the city's Chief Assessor was announced yesterday by Michael Freyberg, president of the City Tax Commission and head of the Real Property Assessment Department.
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 8 Disastrous bush fires in the southern part of Tasmania, the island state 150 miles south of Australia, were brought under control today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 In the session's first major legislative action, the House approved tonight a $6-billion increase in the limit on the national debt.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) The Air Force announced today a 20 per cent expansion of its women's corps and the assignment of the first Wafs to Vietnam.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 8 (AP) An Air Force scientist says spacemen could survive exposure to the vacuum of space if they were rescued quickly.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 A major test of willpower in national trucking negotiations took shape today as James R. Hoffa and a major employer group clashed over the format for bargaining.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Feb. 8 Two of 200 graduates of the United States Merchant Marine Academy here today received their diplomas two days ahead of official graduation day to allow them to join Vietnambound vessels that needed them to complete their crews.

SAIGON, Feb. 8 Unnerving firecracker explosions rattled through Saigon tonight as the Vietnamese bade farewell to the Year of the Horse and ushered in the Year of the Goat. It was the beginning of Tet, the three-day lunar new year holiday.
Boom Boom Geoffrion and his followers acted out their aggressions last night in a violent form of group therapy.

SUMMIT, N.J., Feb. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Lawson Langenheim have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Agnes Langenheim, to Gary Lee Gastineau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Amos W. Gastineau of Kettering, Ohio.

New counterfeit $20 Federal Reserve notes that are supposed to be issues of Federal Reserve banks in Boston. New York, Cleveland and Minneapolis are appearing in volume in this area, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday.

IT would have taken the flood to prevent New York dance aficionados from packing the Kaufmann Hall at the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association last night, and even then the audience would probably have arrived by ark. The occasion was the debut of Donald McKayle's re-formed Dance Company, which will soon take off on a European tour. And it proved one of those occasions that is an occasion.
A prominent Jewish leader urged "liberal groups" in the United States last night to send representatives, to West Germany to sponsor "a kind of Point Four program for democracy."

BOSTON, Feb. 8 Southern New England made a fast recovery today from the season's worst snow storm. Eighteen deaths many due to heart attacks were attributed to the storm, which piled up 10 to 14 inches of snow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 A national civil rights group charged today that the Federal Government had helped to build the nation's Negro ghettos and that its new programs, specifically the model cities program, may serve only to perpetuate those ghettos.

Nine tall lance bearers of the Royal Guards, in flaming orange capes, stood stiffly at attention. King Hassan II of Morocco came softly down the powder-blue broadloom of a stairway in the liner Raffaello. The King strode through the lobby under their lances, then out onto the pier, where 200 feet of carpeting had been rolled before him.

ROME, Feb. 8 Pope Paul VI made public today appeals to President Johnson and the leaders of North and South Vietnam for action to transform the lunar new year truce into negotiations for "a just and stable peace."
In a rare display of harmony, Reform and regular organization Democratic leaders in the Bronx agreed yesterday on a joint effort to get more and better public improvements for their county.

YONKERS, Feb. 8 True to the tradition of show biz, even though only 8,758 customers, the smallest crowd of the meeting, turned out, tonight's harness racing program at Yonkers Raceway was presented as scheduled. But to make certain that the show would go on, three crews totaling 50 men operated in three shifts, some around the clock, to make it possible.
Dare Smith of DKE won the national seniors singles squash tennis championships at the Yale Club courts yesterday by defeating Norman Forster, 1513, 15-11, 15-8.
Mayor Lindsay proposed a new housing code yesterday that would impose considerably more severe penalties on tenants as well as landlords found responsible for unsafe living conditions.
Ed Kranepool signed with the New York Mets yesterday and became the only licensed stockbroker who will be playing first base in Shea Stadium this summer.
MIAMI, Feb. 8 (AP) Bill Sirois of Miami won the fourth annual Sam Griffith Ocean Powerboat race today in the record time of 3 hours 30 minutes 30 seconds.
ALBANY, Feb. 8--A bill that would require the dating of packaged bread sold in New York City was passed in the Assembly today.
SHARP-EYED traders were reminded of one of the stock market's apparent anomalies again yesterday as the shares of Calgon and Pittsburgh Coke and Chemical closed at practically the same price.

It was 19 degrees and gusty, the curbs were mounded high with snow, and only about 500 tourists were in Chinatown as the Year of the Horse cantered out and the year of the Sheep trotted in at midnight last night.
A State Supreme Court jury found Harold Konigsberg guilty of four more counts of extortion here last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8(AP) President Johnson announced today that he would nominate Assistant Secretary of State Douglas MacArthur 2d to be Ambassador to Austria.
Mayor Lindsay appointed as members of the Municipal Art Commission yesterday Adolph Gottlieb, a painter; Seymour Lipton, a sculptor, and Mrs. Mary St. John Villard, lay member.
"HASTEN forward quickly there!" Theodore Roosevelt told a cowpoke in the heat of a Dakota roundup. Local translation: Get going and head off them cows!

The American Broadcasting Company's "Stage 67," usually an hour, will televise its first 90-minute show on Thursday, April 20, starting at 9:30 P.M. instead of 10. Honor Blackman and Tony Randall will star in a comedy drama, "The Wide Open Door." The T.E.B. Clarke story about a bank robbery carried through with the unwitting aid of Scotland Yard has been adapted for TV by Tom and Frank Waldron.

LONDON, Feb. 8 The retirement of Frederick J. Stephens as chairman of the Shell Transport and Trading Company, Ltd., and the appointment of David H. Barran, deputy chairman, to succeed him, were announced today. Both moves are effective June 30.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 8 (UPI An alleged prisoner syndicate dealing in cigarettes and drugs inside the Ohio Penitentiary came to light today during testimony in the trial of a convict accused of stabbing to death a fellow inmate.

HONG KONG, Feb. 8 The followers of Mao Tse-tung were warned today to be alert for possible "palace" coups as well as for direct attempts at "armed coups" from people in open opposition to the Chinese Communist party leader.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Feb. 8 (AP) The wife of a Cornell University professor and a senior at the university were killed and two students injured today in a two-car collision on Route 90, just south of here.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 8 A group of 81 business executives, most of whom have served in the armed forces, have sent a letter to President Johnson to "protest against the escalation of the war in Vietnam."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 8 Dr. and Mrs. Albert Wiley have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carole Judith Wiley, to Dr. Daniel Lawrence Schweitzer, son of State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer and Mrs. Schweitzer of New York and Scarsdale.

Almost every problem concerning children and youth is touched on in large or small degree in the President's wide-ranging special message to Congress yesterday. Virtually nothing seems to have been left out in offering new answers to the challenges of an ever-younger population, or in building on the more successful of already established programs.

HAROLD M. PHILLIPS, a lawyer who died Jan. 6, was an active player, patron, organizer, judge and promoter of, commentator on and just plain kibitzer in chess, giving much time, energy and ready counsel to his favorite avocation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) A $20-million research program aimed at developing a power cell supplying all the electrical energy needed in a home at less than present rates was disclosed today by spokesmen for the natural gas industry.

Pan American World Airways reported here yesterday that it had completed a formal agreement with Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, on the start of New York-Moscow air service by the two lines. Flights are expected to begin in May.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) The Administration asked Congress today to establish a unified United States corrections service to take over functions of the present Bureau of Prisons and assume major responsibility for probation and parole of offenders.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (UPI) The first-place Chicago Black Hawks trounced the Montreal Canadiens tonight, 5-0, and extended their unbeaten string in the National Hockey League to 12 games. The Hawks, who have won 10 and tied two in that span, raised their league lead to 12 points over the New York Rangers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 The Board of Immigration Appeals today reduced to $500 the bail bond of Huynh Ngoc Tuyen, being held for deportation. A hearing Friday is to determine his status as an alien.
Columbia University students, demonstrating against Central Intelligence Agency recruiting on campus for the second time since last November, refused yesterday to let an agent out for lunch.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8(AP) A bill to set Federal controls over clinical laboratories was introduced today by Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York and George Murphy of California, both Republican.

An abundance of potatoes in Canada apparently pushed potato future prices down sharply in the United States yesterday. During the early part of the trading session, futures prices declined as much as 22 cents a hundred pounds before a recovery set in later in the day.

HOUSTON, Feb. 8 The New York Yankees had just served as the distinguished guests at the formal open- ing of the Astrodome to baseball a couple of years ago, the first full-dress exhibition game in that Texas showplace, before an overflow crowd that included the President. It was a gala occasion, embellished by a home run by Mickey Mantle.
LONDON, Feb. 8 The following are excerpts from a speech by Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union at the Guildhall today dealing with the subjects of Vietnam and Germany.

Mrs. DeWitt Wallace, who with her husband is co-chairman of the Reader's Digest, has offered $1-million to the Metropolitan Opera's National Company. Last December, the Met announced the cancellation of the touring troupe's 1967-68 season for financial reasons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 "I do not urge, and indeed do not believe in, any broad-scale program of imposing direct limitations on advertising or other promotional expenditures," Donald F. Turner, the Justice Department's antitrust chief, told members of the American Advertising Federation here today.
British Government bonds were again in demand yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 A Government witness in the bank-robbery trial of John (Sonny) Franzese and four others said today that the reason he asked the United States attorney to wipe out a state parole violation was that he feared that after testifying against Franzese he "couldn't go back to the prison population."

Emile Griffith has been guaranteed $80,000, the largest purse of his career, for his world middleweight title defense against Nino Benvenuti of Italy on April 17, Harry Markson, the director of boxing at Madison Square Garden announced yesterday.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 8 (UPI) Robert Croft, a Connecticut sailor, made a 212.7-foot descent into the Gulf Stream today, breaking a 54-year-old record for a free dive.
Shaking off the effects of Tuesday's blizzard and the early close of trading, prices on the American Stock Exchange snapped back smartly yesterday.

GREAT FALLS, Va., Feb. 8 Kenneth Dean, vice president and a director of SherryLehmann, Inc. a wine and liquor store at 679 Madison Avenue in New York, died here yesterday in the home of his son, Jonathan, after a long illness. Mr. Dean, who was 78 years old, resided at 235 East 51st Street in New York.

Pan American World Airways has promoted two of its executives to vice presidents. They are William Binnian formerly manager-scheduling and Carl M. Kneisel formerly manager-property and facilities. Both are veteran engineers.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 8--St. Peter's College strengthened its hold on first place in the Metropolitan Basketball Conference by defeating New York University tonight, 69-68, on a last-second lay-up by Ken Grant.
More than 1,000 corporate executives listened almost spellbound yesterday at the Americana Hotel as a football coach told them how to run their businesses.

A wide-ranging three-year experimental theater program, aided by a $233,000-grant from the Rockefeller Foundation, will be undertaken by Wesleyan University of Middletown, Conn., in collaboration with the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Foundation.
ALBANY, Feb. 8 A public hearing on a bill to liberalize the state's abortion law turned into an arguing match today with legislators cross-examining witnesses in the style of a criminal trial.
The City Planning Commission gave general approval yesterday to Mayor Lindsay's $1 billion executive capital budget, but noted areas requiring "further discussion or review."
Over the years, Claudio Arrau and Beethoven have become names that all but belong in the same breath.
IN an age when big donations drop into the nation's collection plates from corporate or impersonal foundation sources, Mrs. DeWitt Wallace is a do-it-yourselfer.
HOUSTON, Feb. 9--The American Bar Association took the first step today in a drive to tighten the discipline of the nation's lawyers.

Thirty-nine Vassar College alumnae and former faculty members have written the college's student newspaper expressing concern that Vassar students have not participated in student protests against the war in Vietnam.
Wheat traders have been hoping for some bullish news, such as dry weather in the Southwest or large allotments of grain for India.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP)--Three hooded gunmen invaded a resort hotel early today, bound and gagged three employes and escaped with cash and gems estimated by the management to be valued at $1-million.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Following is the text of the message President Johnson sent to Congress today on foreign aid:
The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, the nation's leading cigarette manufacturer, is planning to acquire its fifth nontobacco company since its initial diversificatin four years ago.
TRENTON, Feb. 9--A public defender charged today that "a mistake of major proportions" by the New Jersey Blue Shield made it necessary for the medical insurance plan to seek an increase in its rates.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (AP)--Ernie Terrell was operated on today for an injury of the left eyeball. His surgeon said the injury had caused dou ble vision from the time it was incurred in Monday night's heavyweight title fight against Cassius Clay.
IT'S not that there are no skirts in Seventh Avenue summer collections. It's just that the pants look more interesting.

JERUSALEM, (Israel), Feb. 9--A meeting between Syria and Israel on discussion of land cultivation rights in the demilitarized zone, has been postponed until Thursday, the United Nations reported this morning.

AUTRANS, France, Feb. 9 (UPI)--Jan Halvarsson of Sweden, stopping to change skis at a midcourse control, captured the opening of the pre-Olympic cross-country ski race today, beating Odd Martinsen of Norway, the favorite, by 19.6 seconds.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 9 (UPI)--The standing committee of the Provisional People's Consultative Congress unanimously demanded today the ouster of President Sukarno and establishment of a court to try him on charges of complicity in the unsuccessful Communist coup of October, 1965. The action marked the legal beginning of what could be the end for him.
The city's first rehabilitation project under the Mitchell-Lama housing program was approved yesterday the Board of Estimate for development in Harlem.
SAIGON, Feb. 9 (UPI)--The United States has suffered 50,529 casualties in the Vietnam war, military spokesmen said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 Winner and runner-up here a year ago and also at Richmond Sunday, Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico and Arthur Ashe of Richmond head the field that will begin play tomorrow in the sixth annual Philadelphia international indoor tennis tournament.
LOS ANGELES--One of the remarkable things about restaurants in California, at least in those establishments that one Easterner has visited recently, is the table service.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 9--Miss Barbara J. Steuerwald's engagement to Stanley R. Sloan has been announced by her mother. Mrs. Phyllis C. Steuerwald. Her fiance is the son of Stanley Sloan of Montpelier, Vt., and the late Mrs. Virginia Sloan.

A nun who has used the new Paulist catechism, "Come to the Father," said yesterday that her students had responded "beautifully," but that their parents found it "a bit confusing." She said that some adjustments were necessary for children from broken homes.
IT can be deduced from "The East Wind" that a good cup of tea, even a good British cup of tea, is not enough.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk ruled out today any cessation of American bombing of North Vietnam until the other side shows a willingness to reduce its military effort in South Vietnam.
RIO DE JANERIO, Feb. 9-- President Humberto Castelo Branco's sudden devaluation of the cruzeiro and institution of monetary reform prompted criticism and speculation today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--An unarmed United States Navy plane accidently flew over part of Communist China's Hainan Island today, the Defense Department announced.
The New Orleans Saints scanned a list of available players yesterday who may comprise their 42-man roster when they make their National Football League debut this season.
The spot rate on the British pound closed 9 points up at $2.7960 after moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Those who like to receive erotic literature in the mail can get it and those who do not can have it stopped under a legislative approach disclosed today by the general counsel to the Post Office Department.
Jacques Brel is in town for the last time as a singer, he says.

Burton B. Turkus, the port arbitrator for the longshore industry, yesterday ordered a formal arbitration hearing in a final move to end the sevenday longshoremen's strike against Upper West Side piers.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 9 (AP)-- Roger Maris, who hit 61 home runs for the New York Yankees in 1961, signed his 1967 contract with the St. Louis Cardinals for a salary reported at $72,000, General Manager Stan Musial said today.

Government and philanthropic associates of Henry Morgenthau Jr. joined his family and friends yesterday in paying tribute to the former Secretary of the Treasury at a funeral service in Temple Emanu-El.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Feb. 9 (AP)--Bob Lewis scored 6 points in an overtime period tonight to pace second-ranked North Carolina to a 75-73 victory over Wake Forest in an Atlantic-Coast Conference basketball game.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 9--At least 63 persons were reported killed in an earthquake that rocked Colombia this morning. About 100 were said to have been injured.
An airline has established a procedure to help set up reunions in Hawaii between military personnel enjoying rest and rehabilitation leave from Vietnam and their friends and relatives back home.

The Supreme Court jury deliberating in the case of Harold Konigsberg, the 38-year-old exconvict who acted as his own lawyer, was discharged yesterday after reporting it could not reach a verdict on the four remaining counts in the indictment against the defendant.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 9-- A leading Roman Catholic educator said today that the proliferation of new but poorly supported Catholic colleges and universities "has tremendously slowed down, if not halted."

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 9-- Alfred John Mosher, international representative for the Sheetmetal Workers International Association, died yesterday at his home at 53 Boxwood Drive here.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 9-- O.M. Mosier, a retired executive vice president of American Airlines who contributed to the growth of the aviation industry, died here today at Mercy Hospital. His age was 69.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The A.F.L-C.I.O. said today that it had no comment on the auto union's letter to its locals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) --The Senate confirmed today the appointment of Lowell K. Bridwell as administrator of the Federal highway system.
VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, Feb. 5--A complex and contradictory set of tensions is hindering the allied effort to speed the pacification of the Vietnamese countryside.

American Airlines expects within a year to capture 35 per cent of the $30-million-a-year Boston-New York air market with hourly all-jet service it will begin Monday, according to Marion Sadler, president.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 10 (AP)--China's power struggle spread today to its nuclear bomb program with a report of two men being arrested on charges of having stolen atomic secrets.

Woolworth Company declined to $67,700,573 last year from the revised net of $70,050,121 in 1967, primarily as a result of declining earnings of the British Woolworth company, the preliminary report disclosed yesterday. Clayton T. Allen, a communications expert, orchardist and former insurance man, died Wednesday in Roosevelt Hospital. He had been ill briefly with meningitis. He was 74 years old and lived at 67 Riverside Drive.

Miss Marion S. Chait, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph M. Chait of 47 East 88th Street, was married here yesterday evening to George T. Howe, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Raymond R. Howe of Jordan, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman, rabbi of Temple EmanuEl, performed the ceremony in his study.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 9 (AP) Dean Refram, Ken Still and Jack Rule tied for the firstround lead in the $70,000 Phoenix open golf tournament today with 5-under-par 66's.

A paradox in the financing of the great New York Public Library lies in the fact that its 82 circulating branches receive full support from taxes while the internationally respected research facilities at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street have to depend largely on private contributions and are in continuing financial difficulties.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 9 (AP)--The Cornell hockey team ranked second in the East, strengthened its Ivy League lead today with a 3-1 victory over Princeton.
BAD GENSTEIN, Austria, Feb. 9 (AP)--Marielle Goitschel of France won the women's giant slalom in the 1967 Ski Cup of Alpine countries today, scoring her second victory in the six-nation competition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The varied but firm peace terms that Secretary of State Dean Rusk set out in diplomatic language today are being expressed much more pungently around the White House, to the Congress and to foreign embassies here.
LOGAN, Utah, Feb. 9 (UPI) --Chuck Mills, an assistant coach with the Kansas City Chiefs of the American Football League, last season, was appointed head coach today at Utah State University.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The House Committee on Un-American Activities has decided after a preliminary investigation that the American Nazi party constitutes no threat to the security of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) --Patrick and Luci Johnson Nugent are hunting for bigger quarters in Austin, Tex., to make room for the child the President's daughter is expecting in May.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8 (AP) --Lajos Egri, a playwright and poet who became a well-known teacher of creative writing, died of a heart attack on Tuesday in Cedars of Lebanon Hospital. He was 79 years old.

Last night's Carnegie Hall concert by the visiting Minneapolis Symphony was a brief, invigorating survey of important, though seldom-heard contemporary works. The composers were Poland's Witold Lutoslawski, the Soviet Union's Shostakovich and the world's Igor Stravinsky.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9-- Officials of two of the nation's largest mutual-fund organizations held out the hope today that competition would continue to reduce the management fees levied on fund shareholders. These have been termed "excessive" by the Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9-- President Johnson proposed today the smallest foreign aid appropriation in the 20-year history of that program. He asked that $3.1-billion be authorized for each of the next two fiscal years.
LONDON, Feb. 9 (Reuters)-- Jewish leaders in Britain sent to Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin tonight a plea to provide adequate educational and religious facilities for Jews in the Soviet Union.

The Federal Reserve's push toward a progressively easier credit policy, which started last November, appears to have slowed perceptibly. This was the interpretation that informed bankers put last night on the latest crop of banking statistics released yesterday by the Reserve System.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Intercity truck tonnage and revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the week ended Feb. 4 were both ahead of the level of the corresponding week in 1966 when traffic was affected by severe weather conditions.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Feb. 9 --Miss Janice Golda Copen's engagement to Edward Frederick Redish has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ira Y. Copen. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Jules Redish of Lynbrook, L.I., and the late Dr. Redish.
BERLIN, Feb. 9--The Soviet Union was reported today to be planning to withdraw several army divisions from East Germany.
THE silvery look in decorating is moving into high gear, with everything from metal curtains to furniture bathed in glittering finishes.
Net income of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad amounted to $1,898,000, or 65 cents a share, last year contrasted with a net loss of $1,451,000 in 1965, the road said yesterday.

RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 9-- "Everything in Morocco depends on the King, except the weather." This remark by an aide of King Hassan II underscores the monarch's importance in the affairs of this African Arab country of nearly 14 million people.
The show will go on in Madison Square Garden tonight, but whether some of the leading actors will perform remains a mystery.

A proposal to reduce crime on the streets by assigning plainclothes policemen to trap unwary offenders will be put into operation soon in several of the, city's precincts.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 9 (AP) --The favored Tumble Wind rallied in the stretch today to win the $28,200 San Vicente Stakes at Santa Anita. The Florida-bred colt once again stamped himself as a strong threat to win the rich Santa Anita Derby March 4.
RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 9-- North Carolina's "brownbaggers" found a friend today in Gov. Dan K. Moore. The Ku Klux Klan found an enemy.

The modernizing effect of the new building code proposed by Mayor Lindsay is perhaps best indicated by the fact that it would forbid the use of gas for illumination, thus officially ending the gaslight era. Much more importantly, it would bring together for the first time all the legal requirements affecting the maintenance of dwellings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI)--The House Armed Services Committee has approved a new bill to block Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara's long-standing plan to merge the Army National Guard and organized Army Reserve.

"AN exercise in brutality," "a study in cruelty," "disgusting," "almost bestial"--so went the morning-after judgments of Cassius Clay's eighth successful defense of the heavyweight boxing championship, this time against Ernie Terrell in Houston Monday night.

BOSTON, Feb. 9--The Boston Globe published a four-column photograph today showing Kenneth P. O'Donnell, an aide to President Kennedy standing at the left shoulder of Mrs. Kennedy when President Johnson took his oath of office.

ROME, Feb. 9--Giacomo Luigi Cardinal Copello, Chancellor of the Roman Catholic Church and former Archbishop of Buenos Aires, died this morning after suffering a heart attack last night. He was 87 years old.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 (AP)--The State Bar Association's Committee on Public Health urged the Legislature today to "revise and liberalize" the state's 84year-old law on abortions.

ONE of the happier byproducts of the blizzard that grounded all planes to the north was that it enabled a reluctant stayer-on in Houston to visit with Don Klosterman, the dynamic executive vice president and general manager of the Houston Oilers of the American Football League. He is a fascinating man personally and his record as a talent-assembler indicates that he also is able to exert that same fascination professionally.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago announced plans yesterday to build its sixth nuclear generating plant. The contract for the turbine generator, reactor and nuclear fuel for the 1.1-million-kilowatt plant was awarded to Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9-- Tax-sharing will not bring any extra Federal money to local governments, Senator Edmund S. Muskie asserted today. Tax-sharing envisions turning back some Federal funds to state of local governments without carmarking them for specific programs.

ALBERTO GINASTERA'S "Don Rodrigo" was one of the New York City Opera's big successes when the company moved to the New York State Theater. Thus, Julius Rudel selected the Argentine composer's opera to open the spring season--spring?--of the company last night. It gave New York a chance to see once again one of the more talked-about operas of recent years, to renew acquaintance, to reassess if necessary.

Dr. Frank Stanton received a new five-year contract yesterday as president of the Columbia Broadcasting System. Inc., parent corporation of the C.B.S. television and radio networks, Columbia Records, the New York Yankees and many other subsidiaries.
A 112-room motor inn that was built on the side of a cliff overlooking the New York Thruway and the Tappan Zee Bridge at Nyack, N.Y., has been bought by Irving Maidman, New York real estate investor.
Eugene Rodriguez, awaiting sentence for an attempted $100,000 shakedown and for perjury, was formally charged yesterday with conspiring to commit firstdegree murder.

BIENHOA, South Vietnam, Feb. 9--After waiting through the night to ambush an enemy who never came, Capt. John H. Wilson ordered the men of his Company to withdraw to their base camp just before dawn yesterday.
MADRAS, India, Feb. 7--A touch of California has entered the election campaign in Madras, with the major parties vying to associate themselves with movie stars.

PONTIAC, Mich., Feb. 9 (AP)--The list price for the Firebird, Pontiac's new sports model, will be $2,495 for the two-door hardtop coupe and $2,720 for the convertible, the General Motors Corporation said today.

A new concept in teaching religion to Roman Catholic children, departing radically from the traditional rote of the Baltimore Catechism, was made "available for immediate adoption" yesterday by the Paulist Fathers.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 9--Rhodesia revised its tariff system tonight by ending preferences for British Commonwealth countries. The measure was announced in Parliament by Finance Minister John Wrathall.

PARIS, Feb. 9--France's exports to Communist China rose steeply last year, according to figures made public today. The figures, covering the first 11 months of 1966, indicate that these exports totaled $86.6 million in that period, compared with an average of about $50million yearly since 1963.
WARSAW, Feb. 9 (Reuters) --Six East European foreign ministers and the deputy foreign minister of Rumania discussed their difference over dealings with West Germany here today.

TEANECK, N.J., Feb. 9-- Dr. and Mrs. Raymond. A Weiss have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss Lynn Cheryl Weiss, to Kenneth Richard Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Cohen of New York.

The widespread speculation that the United States and the Soviet Union have reached virtual agreement on a treaty banning nuclear proliferation is strengthened by Premier Kosygin's optimistic remarks yesterday. DETROIT, Feb. 9--With an all-out effort the United States auto industry should be able to comply with the initial Federal safety standards in all its 1968 models, the president of the Chrysler Corporation stated today.

Hart Schaffner Marx, the men's clothing manufacturer and retailer with headquarters in Chicago, and Gleneagles, Inc., a Baltimore maker of quality rainwear for men and women, announced yesterday they had agreed in principle to a poolingof-interests merger.

DETROIT, Feb. 9--The United Automobile Workers accused the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations today of being "the comfortable complacent custodian of the status quo."

Eastern Airlines announced yesterday a major expansion of its all-cargo services that will utilize a fleet of 16 new convertible cargo planes and new ground terminals.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York is considering the introduction of sex education as part of the school curriculum of the archdiocese, or as a community project involving Catholic parents.

The appointment of Edward L. Maynard as Eastern regional sales manager for the Matson Navigation Company's Far East freight division has been announced by George F. Collins, director of the San Francisco-based carrier.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--John M. Stevens will leave his post as British Economic Minister in Washington to join Morgan Grenfell Co., Ltd., in London in June or July, it was announced today.
Charles A. Kearns of 22 Beverly Road, Yonkers, who retired a month ago as an official of the International Paper Company here, died on Monday at Sun City Center, Fla. His age was 65.

The Living Theater will resume its local stage activities in October after a three-year absence. Roger Euster, who operates the Village Theater on Second Avenue at Sixth Street, will sponsor the troupe's return from Europe.

Handy Harman, the fabricator and refiner of precious metals, filed yesterday a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commisson for a proposed sale of 200,000 common shares, 84,312 to be sold by the company and 115,688 by selling holders.
