Reger's Variations and Fugue on a Theme by Mozart and Tchaikovsky's "Manfred" Symphony, which made up last night's program by the New York Philharmonic in Philharmonic Hall, have one thing in common: Although they are fine works by respected composers, nonproblematic for the average audience, they turn up rarely on concert programs today.
OSLO, Norway Feb. 9--(AP) A Norwegian shipbuilder is studying a plan for building hydrofoil boats with a carrying capacity of 350 tons with room for 400 passengers and 50 automobiles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The Federal Reserve Board unanimously rejected requests from various Federal Reserve banks to raise the discount rate to 5 per cent on eight separate occasions between July 15 and Sept. 2 of last year, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The nation's unemployment rate held steady last month because of surprising strength in the nonfarm job market, the Government reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI)--The White House interrupted worldwide distribution of President Johnson's foreign aid message for about 10 minutes today to add two words.

WAYNE, N.J., Feb. 9--The Wayne Township Board of Education voted 8 to 1 tonight to censure its vice president. Newton Miller, and asked him to resign because he publicly urged the defeat of two Jewish candidates for the board.

Walter P. Reuther and his fellow-leaders of the United Automobile Workers have chosen the high ground of social idealism as the battle area in their war with the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations high command.
The election of Robert E. Benson as a vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was announced yesterday by Harold S. Geneen, chairman and president.
ALBANY, Feb. 9--Governor Rockefeller, describing the state's traffic death toll as "shocking," asked the Legislature today to enact a sevenpoint highway safety program.

ARNOLD, Md., Feb. 9--The engagement of Miss Nancy Sterrett Niedringhaus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Munhall Niedringhaus of Rugby Hall here, to Charles Waterman Bennett has been announced by the future bride's parents. The prospective bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Konvalinka Bennett of Washington.

The 70-year-old woman who has been suing Representative Adam Clayton Powell for six and a half years became a recording star yesterday in an album called "No Man Is Above the Law--I Have Kept the Faith."

MINEOLA, L.I., Friday, Feb. 10--Nassau County Dictrict Attorney William Cahn early today announced the arrest of nine men accused of being involved in a "layoff" bookmaking operation that has been doing a $100-million-a-year business in the metropolitan area.

MAGNAVOX and Admiral helped put some stiffen ing in a ragged stock market yesterday. The two color-television producers had been lagging behind other color set stocks, and traders evidently decided it was time for the two to assume more prominent roles is the general market recovery.
St. John's University broke open a close basketball game with a 16-1 spurt in the last four minutes of play tonight and defeated West Virginia, 83-71.
LONDON, Feb. 9--Premier Kosygin urged today that the United States end the bombing of North Vietnam unconditionally in return for peace talks with Hanoi.
THE things science does to fish and animals goes on unabated; the animals find it hard to argue back.

The Walter Reade Organization, co-producer of the screen version of James Joyce's "Ulysses," has added six theaters to the original six booked to show the film in the metropolitan area. The movie will have only three evening performances, on March 14, 15 and 16, and one matinee, March 15.
LONDON, Feb. 9--The current strife in China may reflect an attempt to distract attention from policy failures Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin suggested today.
Mozart is beautiful, Schubert is charming, but for laughs, listen to Lanner.
An afternoon round of profit taking knocked the stock market into the loss column yesterday.
The city school system, which has been plagued by broken windows (200,000 last year), has decided to meet vandalism with a "new weapon"--hardened glass.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 9 (AP) --The roof of a Roman Catholic church plagued by a his tory of mishaps collapsed onto about 100 worshipers today burying them beneath tons of debris.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9-- King Hassan II of Morocco received a royal greeting at the White House today from President Johnson. It was reliably reported to have included the promise of approximately $15million in arms to help bolster Morocco's defenses.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9--A conference of academic specialists on China closed today with several participants asserting that it was more in American interest in the short run to see the militant faction of Chairman Mao Tse-tung win Communist China's power struggle than his opposition.

TOKYO, Feb. 9--The Japanese Communist party denounced the "thoughts of Mao Tse-tung" today as an unacceptable interpretation of Marxist-Leninist principles, and warned Peking to keep out of Japanese political affairs.
The results of an apprentice test in the sheet-metal industry, in which Negro applicants scored "phenomenally" high, were upheld here yesterday in State Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) --The Senate rejected today, 37 to 22, a proposal to put a $100 limit on the value of any gift accepted by a member.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 9--The six Common Market countries agreed today to adopt a procedure of indirect taxation in a far-reaching move that will accelerate their economic integration.

A 65-year-old retired interior decorator and his 25-year-old son were among eight civilians honored yesterday by Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary for assisting the police in the performance of duty.

MIAMI, Feb. 9--The figures at Hialeah for the first half of the current meeting are way off from those of last year, but Eugene Mori, president of the famous race track, refused to take a pessimistic view of the picture.
MIAMI, Feb. 9 (AP)--Winds gusting up to 47 miles an hour whipped the serene beaches of South Florida into a Sahara-like sandstorm today.

LONDON, Feb. 9--In olden days "people expected their princes to fight" for markets and national Survival. Today's markets are just as important to national survival, but princes are expected to use methods that are "a little more subtle," said Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, today.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 9--Gov. Ronald Reagan listened grimly today as a professor accused him publicly of showing "hostility and suspicion" toward higher education in California.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust, the largest common-stock mutual fund, reported yesterday that during the fourth quarter of 1966 the fund had made a new investment in Johns-Manville and increased its holdings in 12 other companies.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 10 Albert C. Cornish, a New York City petroleum executive, died early yesterday in Princeton Hospital after a lengthy illness. He was 77 years old.

Philip J. Levin, a dissident stockholder of Metro-GoldwynMayer, Inc., lost yesterday in his attempt to prevent the film concern from using the company's employes or funds to defend itself against attacks by Mr. Levin and his group.
VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Feb. 10--Charles N. Smith a choral director, died yesterday at Meadowbrook Hospital after a long illness. He was 49 years old and lived at 15 High Street.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 10 Dr. Magdalena Berger Wechesler, senior research scientist in the department of experimental psychiatry of the New York State Psychiatric Institute, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, died today at her home at 27 Seacord Road, after an illness of two months. Her age was 42.

HOUSTON, Feb. 10 Thousands of Americans may soon obtain low cost legal help through their unions, churches, employers and even social clubs if a movement now under way in the American Bar Association catches on.

IT is a very good week when a partial tour of the new shows in the gallieries yields half a dozen that it would be a shame to miss, especially when they range all the way from first one-man shows to an exhibition by Lee Gatch, whose first New York exhibition took place exactly 40 years ago.
American manufacturers of men's sports outerwear are protesting what they believe are tariff inequities permitting a flood of imported garments into this country.

CARLSBAD, Calif., Feb. 10 Some ingenious promoters have put together a sporting event that they guarantee will appeal to fans of golf, major league baseball and professional football. However, it may leave the fans a little confused.

Emergency Measures Here to Be Lifted Today The metropolitan area narrowly missed a repeat performance of Tuesday's blizzard yesterday morning when a fresh storm veered out to sea after dusting the city with only 2 inches of snow.

MARY LOU WILLIAMS, the pianist who is sometimes called the Queen of Jazz, celebrated the opening of her Votre Boutique in Harlem last week by sitting down at a mahogany Wurlitzer and jamming with a fellow pianist, Hazel Scott.

Last night's conceit by the Municipal Concerts Orchestra at Town Hall was well-rounded. Julius Grossman could doubtless have used more rehearsal in the works, but his small orchestra held up well in what is demanding literature.
Lloyd J. Derrickson, 39 years old, was named yesterday as general counsel of the National Association of Securities Dealers, the selfpolicing body of the over-thecounter market.
Terry Carpenter, a University of Massachusetts senior, won the mile yesterday in the United States Track and Field Federation's college development track meet at Madison Square Garden.

PARIS, Feb. 10 The visit of Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union to Britain was being watched with some misgivings today by French observers who had hoped that Paris rather than London would emerge as the focal point of an East-West d tente.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 10 (AP) Lagoon Girl, the runner-up to Recall in the recent Patricia Stakes, prepped for the $25,000 added Barbara Fritchie Stakes, to be run at Bowie Feb. 25, by winning the six-furlong feature race today under Phil Grimm.

Burton Roberts, Chief Assistant District Attorney of the Bronx, said yesterday that a grand jury investigation into the alleged misconduct of 21 Bronx policemen had been ended because of a Jan. 16 decision by the United States Supreme Court.

The Burroughs Corporation was picked yesterday by the Department of Defense tn build the Illiac IV, an experimental computer that is considered to be the precursor of the fourth generation of electronic dataprocessing equipment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Six American girls came to the rescue tonight of Huyhn Ngoc Tuyen, a weary and bewildered South Vietnamese caught in the seemingly inscrutable toils of United States immigration laws.

THE word got around Wall Street yesterday that Aerojet-General was about to introduce a cancer-detection device and the predictable happened. The stock spurted 7, to 41 5/8, in vigorous trading on the American Stock Exchange.
BADGASTEIN, Austria, Feb. 10 (UPI) Marielle Goitschel, French ski ace, suffered a brain concussion in a spill during training today.
Twenty-five years ago yesterday the world's most beautiful ocean liner capsized at her Hudson River pier after a fire that started the day before.

TORONTO, Feb. 10 Canada's first deposit insurance law was put into effect by Ontario today amid political charges that the legislation had been rushed to prevent the failure of the York Trust and Savings Corporation.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10 Dr. Margaret Mead said today that future American society might require two forms of marriage, either to give greater protection to children or to reduce the birth rate.

THE six essays in this book each author contributes two deal with a handful of representative English and Ameri can novelists of the 19th century. Some are well known: Charles Dickens, Henry James, James Fenimore Cooper, Nathaniel Hawthorne, Some are known better in the classroom than outside of it: Elizabeth Gaskell, Walter Besant, Disraeli (the novelist; not the politician). The novels are seen as products of great periods of change.
The Monsanto Company announced yesterday it would shed its interest in Mobay Chemical Company of Pittsburgh, a joint venture with Farbenfabriken Bayer A.G. of West Germany.
CAIRO, Feb. 10 (Reuters) The Government placed today a confiscation order on all the property and cash in the United Arab Republic of King Faisal of Saudi Arabia and most of his family.
Grosvenor Neighborhood House will benefit from the Blue Hill Troupe's seventh annual dance in the Grand Ballroom at the Roosevelt Hotel next Friday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The Army announced today that almost all veterans would be barred from burial in Arlington National Cemetery. The order becomes effective next Friday.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 10 The oldest and best-known collegiate winter sports jamboree the Dartmouth Carnival got off to an auspicious start today as first-rate skiing conditions helped officials conduct the meet's first two events in rapid order.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 (AP) Two New York City men were booked early today on suspicion of making false bomb reports to an airline stewardess.

The City Opera's production of "La Boh me," new last fall, has been so tastefully staged by Carmen Savoca and is conducted with such musical discipline and sensitive pacing by Franco Patan that it almost wouldn't matter if the singers squeaked.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) A new summation of 20 years of research among survivors of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki atomic bombings indicates that the long-range effects on health have been grim but not nearly so extensive as at first feared.

THE Festival Orchestra of New York thought it had found a beautiful work to introduce here when it decided to perform Honegger's 'Le Dit des jeux du monde" in the concert given at Philharmonic Hall last night.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 10 Iranian and foreign observers believe that Iran's agreement to accept Soviet military aid was merely further, though dramatic, evidence that the eight-yearold Central Treaty Organization of the Middle East had long since outlived its military role of providing defense against Soviet attack.
The question of whether abortion is a legal or theological issue was debated yesterday at a hearing on proposals to permit legalized abortion in New York in certain cases.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Saturday, Feb. 11 (UPI) Pamela Brewer, who posed nude for a magazine foldout, was found guilty early today of violating rules of the University of Florida.
ASPEN, Colo., Feb, 10 (AP) Sandy Shellworth of Boise, Idaho, zipped through a heavy snowstorm today to win the women's downhill race in the Roch Cup ski competition in 1 minute 3.4 seconds.
Stock prices moved aimlessly yesterday before a minor rally in late trading carried the list into slightly higher ground.
DETROIT, Feb. 10 A new state unit to fight racketeers and gangsters started work today as citizens telephoned offering leads.
Byron Jay, president, estimated yesterday that the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company would earn about $2.25 a share on a sales gain of around 7 per cent in fiscal 1966.
CHARLESTON, W.Va., Feb. 10 The West Virginia Legislature enacted a bill yesterday to allow the sale of liquor by the drink in the hundreds of private clubs that operate throughout the state.

Mrs. Martha Hewton Knoud, who with her late husband, Michael J. Knoud, operated an English saddlery shop at 716 Madison Avenue, died Thursday at her home, at 33-01 149th Place in Flushing, Queens. Her age was 87.

MARACAIBO, Venezuela, Feb. 10 (AP) Ramon Sota of Spain fired a hole in one en route to a second-round 68 and tied DeWitt Weaver of Atlanta for the halfway lead today in the Maracaibo Open golf tournament.
SUMMIT, N.J., Feb. 10 Miss Rowena L. Brentano of 45 Woodland Avenue, daughter of the late Arthur Brentano Sr., founder of the Brentano's book stores, died yesterday at her home.
The New School for Social Research has purchased the former Lane department store at Fifth Avenue and 14th Street for classroom use.

In a 2 to 1 decision yesterday the United States Court of Appeals upheld the conviction of Saul I. Birnbaum, a millionaire accountant, on charges of bribing an Internal Revenue Service agent in a tax case.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 10 Agreement appears imminent for the resumption of Congolese copper exports, sources close to Societe G n rale de Belgique said today.

A plastic nude by Frank Gallo, a lens-box construction by Mary Bauermeister and an op painting by Richard Anuszkiewiez are among 51 works by American artists to be auctioned Monday evening at the Parke-Bernet Galleries for the benefit of the Artists Technical Research Institute.
Just three weeks after the end of the last Welfare Department strike its unionized social workers are preparing to strike again.

Paul Hornung is now a Saint, and so is Gary Wood. Hornung, a bridegroom of three weeks, and Wood, a father of four months, and 40 other athletes from 14 teams of the National Football League were among the seasoned men named here yesterday to play for the New Orleans Saints, the team that begins competition next season.
The New York Mets announced yesterday that their Jacksonville farm club had purchased Ron Taylor, one of the reliefpitching stars of the St. Louis Cardinals in the 1964 World Series.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 10 The Rev. and Mrs. Gabor Brachna have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ethel Vilma Brachna, to Robert Lewis Bonn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. Bonn of Lynbrook, L.I.
WYNCOTE, Pa., Feb. 10 An 18-year-old youth from Barcelona, Spain, hit shots worthy of a master, and challenged Arthur Ashe to produce some of the finest tennis of his career tonight.
The city was given a 60-day deadline yesterday to prove in court that a housing emergency exists here or have rent control revoked.
ATLANTA, Feb. 10 (UPI) Bud Carson was named tonight as the successor to Bobby Dodd as Georgia Tech head football coach.
Greasepaint and stage talk will soon supplement the sound of music on West 141st Street, where Dorothy Maynor has been heading an ambitious, successful and small-but-growing cultural center.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 10 (UPI) The serialization of William Manchester's "The Death of a President" is creating a stir in Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Bulgaria.

An erroneous statement that Dr. Robert A. Wilson, author of "Feminine Forever," had been ruled "unsuitable to test drugs in humans" was reported from Washington by The Asso ciated Press and published last Nov. 17 by The New York Times.
The Emhart Corporation announced yesterday that its earnings last year rose to $13.9million, equal to $3.17 a share, from $12,988,461, or $2.97 a share, the year before.

For potatoes it was a day of sagging prices, one of many recently. Traders tended to even out positions pending the issuance of the Department of Agriculture's report of stocks on hand, after the close of trading.
ALBANY, Feb. 10 The Lind say administration asked the Legislature today to give New York City a larger share of the proceeds from a $200-million park-bond issue approved by the voters last November.
Marshall McClintock, an author and editor, died on Thursday at Lebanon Hospital, the Bronx. He was 60 years old and lived at Washingtonville, N.Y., and 283 Bleecker Street in Manhattan.

"Mourning Becomes Electra," an opera by Marvin David Levy, derived from Eugene O'Neill's dramatic trilogy, will have its world premiere at the Metropolitan Opera on Friday, March 17. Making Met debuts in the production will be Evelyn Lear and Marie Collier, sopranos.
BAIRAGARH, India, Feb. 10--A forest of saffron flags snapped in the breeze over this town's main street today in what could be a storm warning for the governing Congress party.

WASHINGTON, Feb.10 TheFederal Maritime Commission, charged with administering certain features of a new cruise control law, appears inclined to drop any requirements for cruise ship advertising, a commission spokesman said here today.

Cartographically speaking, the British won the Revolutionary War. It wasn't even close. Evidence of their clear triumph hangs at the moment on a wall at the New-York Historical Society in a new showing of rare old maps, atlases and globes.
OBERSTDORF, Germany, Feb. 10 (UPI) Kjell Sjoeberg of Sweden broke the world ski-jumping record today, set only 90 minutes prior to his leap, with a distance of 485 feet.

The Mayor's Taxi Study Panel has come up with many recommendations which the cabriding public will not contest. More taxis will mean less waiting in rain and snow unless all the new cabs are to be equipped with permanent "off-duty" signs, as the majority of old ones appear to be.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) President Johnson announced today that the United States and Mexico had concluded an agreement on a $1.38-million canal to keep salt water from draining into the Rio Grande.
Bank Leumi le-Israel announced yesterday the appointment of Shimon BarTslil as a vice president. He will be in the bank's New York branch at 60 Wall Street.

The extreme bitterness of current Sino-Soviet relations has been startlingly evidenced by Premier Kosygin's remarks on China in his London television broadcast. His open avowal of Soviet sympathy for the Chinese opponents of "the dictatorial regime of Mao Tse-tung" removes any pretense of Russian neutrality in China's inner struggle.

EVEN a beginner knows enough to hold up an ace in the opponents' long suit at no-trump, but there are holdup plays that are less obvious. It may be right to hold up one sure trick when the opponents still have the ace.

MIAMI, Feb. 10 It was like old times for Bill Hartack today at Hialeah. He paid a visit to the winner's circle, after a hardearned triumph aboard Bargain Counter of the Carolyn Stable in a 6-furlong sprint.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The 25th Amendment, designed to assure clear lines of Presidential succession and continuity of power in case of disability, became part of the Constitution today when it was ratified by the 38th state.
Negotiations continued last night in an effort to avert a strike against Time, Inc., threatened for today by the Newspaper Guild of New York.
Spiked-shoe power politics made a big dent in last night's United States Track and Field Federation indoor meet at Madison Square Garden.

MONTREAL, Feb. 10 (Canathan Press) Peggy Fleming of Colorado Springs, the world champion, combined precision and concentration today to dominate the women's compulsory figures at the opening of the North American figure skating championships.

Sumner Putnam, president and executive editor of Ives Washburn, Inc., book publishers at 750 Third Avenue, died Thursday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 57 years old and lived on Guard Hill Road in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

THREE floors above the streets of midtown Man hattan, 100 persons enjoyed an old-fashioned clambake cooked in the snow this week. The feast took place on the terrace of the Henry Hudson Hotel on 57th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. It was prepared by Leighton's Catering Service of South Weymouth, Mass., and baked by Leighton's three proprietors.
At 12:05 P.M. yesterday Albert B. Kelly, a 60-year-old changemaker in the IRT subway at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue, saw a pistol at the window in his booth.

SEATTLE, Feb. 10 (UPI) More than 245,000 cans of salmon are being removed from retail food stores because of defective seams and the presence of bacteria, the Marine Foods Packing Company of Seattle, the distributor, announced today.
LONDON, Feb. 10 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin declared Soviet sympathy tonight for those in Communist China "struggling against the dictatorial regime of Mao Tse-tung."

AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 10 (UPI)--John Ben Shepperd, former Texas Attorney General, announced today that all disputes over land acquisition for the LBJ State Park near President Johnson's LBJ Ranch had been settled.

LAST night's presentation of "Uncle Vanya" was a taped testament to the overriding strength of the British theater. Every part was filled by a star, yet the total effect was that of an integrated ensemble accomplishment in which Chekhov's relentless account of a purposeless and dark environment was always dominant.
SUMMIT, N.J., Feb. 10 Walter F. Meister of 27 Dogwood Drive, until 1956 a chemical engineer with the National Lead Company, died yesterday at a nursing home in New Providence. His age was 75.

THE exhibition of sculpture and drawings by Elie Nadelman (1882-1946) currently installed at the Zabriskie Gallery, 699 Madison Avenue at 62d, is the first one-man show of the artist's work New York has seen in six years.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 7.9 per cent in production for the week ended Feb. 4, compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week.

KOTTAYAM, India, Feb. 10 On a billboard at the edge of a public park in this bustling town in Kerala State, a tall man with glasses is shown straining under a pole weighted at each end with a bulging sack.
At Lincoln Center today: "Peter Grimes," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P.M.; "The Abduction From the Seraglio," New York City Opera, New York State Theater, 2:15; Gene and Fran- ...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Experts here saw new indications today that the Soviet Union may try to launch a manned space station this year.

HARRINGTON PARK, N. J., Feb. 10--Mr. and Mrs. James R. Sutphen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Sutphen, to John Harold Runyon, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Runyon of Morgantown, Pa.
WASHINGTON, Feb.10 The Johnson Administration is seeking to roll back a penny-a-gallon increase in gasoline prices that has spread through the oil industry in the last 10 days.

Two Chicago stock brokers placed before the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington yesterday a reorganization plan for the bankrupt New Haven Railroad. It would transfer all the carrier's operating assets to a new corporation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 In August, 1963, the chair man's seat of the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on constitutional amendments was suddenly emptied by the death of Estes Kefauver. The post was comparatively insignificant, and James O. Eastland, the full committee's...

ROME, Feb. 10 (AP) Unpublished documents in the Vatican archives show that the British Government rejected in 1942 papal appeals to relax its naval blockade to allow the shipment of food into Greece, a Jesuit historian said in an article published today.
Stocks rebounded in Tokyo yesterday, recovering almost two-thirds of their losses on Thursday when rumors of a new peace move in Vietnam engulfed the list.

LONDON, Feb. 10 (Reuters) The Earl of Harewood, cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, said here tonight that he had been "sounded out" on the possibility of succeeding Rudolf Bing as general manager of New York's Metropolitan Opera company.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Feb. 10 C. Douglas Dillon, former Secretary of the Treasury and Ambassador to France, and Mrs. Dillon have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Joan Douglas Dillon of Paris, to Prince Charles of Luxembourg, brother of Grand Duke Jean of Luxembourg.
A white civil-rights worker who advises an interracial farmers' cooperative in rural Louisiana has won draft deferment at his New York City board over the objections of some Louisiana whites.
HAMMAGUIR, Algeria, Feb. 8 It is a far cry from Cape Kennedy. There are no neon signs, no drive-ins and no night clubs.

Our aims are strictly limited and we sincerely believe they contain nothing inconsistent with the interests of any party. Our public pronouncements of them both in Washington and at the United Nations are solemn commitments by the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 A mutual fund executive charged today that the Securities and Exchange Commission was attempting, indirectly, to put mutual funds out of business by proposing that the sales commissions charged fund purchasers be cut almost in half.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 10 The Suffolk Board of Supervisors recommended today that the county's antipoverty director, Alan Gartner, be suspended and that the District Attorney investigate an antipoverty staff worker who has been accused of misconduct.

PHANTHIET, South Vietnam, Feb. 10 (AP) American paratroopers fought their way into a Communist jungle prison camp today and rescued 51 emaciated Vietnamese prisoners who cried with joy as the Americans arrived.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 10 (AP) Buckpasser, the horse of the year in 1966, took his first timed workout since Jan. 26 today and his trainer, Eddie Neloy, expressed cautious optimism that the millionaire colt would start in the $145,000 guaranteed Santa Anita Handicap on Feb. 25.

ADELAIDE, Australia Feb. 10 (UPI) Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., proved his defeat of Ken Rosewall of Australia earlier this week was no fluke by beating him again tonight in a professional tennis tournament, 13-11, 6-1.

In the strongest public crackdown by the New York State Harness Racing Commission since Robert A. Glasser has been it's chairman, one man was denied yesterday a license to own, train, drive or have any connection with the sport and five others were labeled as "expelled" patrons at any trotting track in the state.
A batch of city-owned cars were parked illegally on Broadway near City Hall yesterday while Mayor Lindsay was conducting his weekly Cabinet meeting nearby.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 10 Andrew L. Cobb Jr., chairman of the board of the Morristown Erie Railroad Company, died today of a heart ailment in Morristown Memorial Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 50 Noe Avenue, Madison.

ADEN, Feb. 10 The British authorities tonight imposed a general curfew on the state of Aden from midnight tonight until further notice. Nationalist organizations have called for massive demonstrations tomorrow on the eighth anniversary of the formation of the South Arabian Federation.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Feb. 10 (AP) Wes Gallagher, general manager of The Associated Press, said today that "a new sophisticated society," which he described as cynical and critical, could be influenced only by a flow of factual news, not opinion.

Isaac Siegmeister, a retired Brooklyn lawyer who had been impartial chairman for the millinery industry here and in New Jersey, died Thursday in the Beth Israel Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 11 Fifth Avenue.
PHOENIX, Ariz. Feb. 10 (AP) Rod Funseth shot a seven-under-par 64 today and took a four-stroke lead after two rounds of the $70,000 Phoenix open golf tournament.

LONDON, Feb. 10 Dr. Emil Savundra, whose insurance company collapsed shortly after he had sold control of it, was arrested tonight. He was charged with forgery involving the equivalent of about $1.5-million and a false entry in the insurance concern's balance sheet.
GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 10 (UPI) Ion Istad of Norway, the world champion, showed speed and a fair aim with the rifle today as he won the preOlympic biathlon meet.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 10 Nationalist Chinese analysts of affairs on the Communist mainland believe that Mao Tse-tung and his chief collaborator, Defense Minister Lin Piao, command the loyalty of at least 24 of the 36 army corps in the Chinese Communist armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 A photograph map taken from a satellite, showing the nation's cloud cover from coast to coast, will be offered by the Govern ment to newspapers and television networks on a daily basis starting next week.

WAYNE, N.J., Feb. 10 In social-studies classes of the two high schools here and in groups outside the schools, youngsters talked today about the vice president of the local school board who has urged the defeat of two Jewish candidates in a board election next Tuesday.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla. Feb. 10 (AP) Rocket problems have forced the space agency to postpone until about midMarch the launching of a Comsat satellite needed to strengthen commercial communications links across the Atlantic ocean.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The United States is expected to furnish Morocco with about 170,000 tons of wheat, valued of $12-million, over the next six months.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Princess Lalla Aisha of Morocco who discarded her veil 20 years ago is a complete diplomat when it comes to discussing the paradox of the modern Arab woman.
The spot rate on the British pound eased in dull trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.
United Press International's newsfilm division and Independent Television News, which serves Britain's independent TV network, have formed a new newsfilm agency, to be known as U.P.I.T.N.
Mayor Lindsay and civic leaders began a private campaign six months ago to persuade officials of Pepsico, Inc., not to move the company's world headquarters out of New York City.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Feb. 10 Dr. James A. Storing, provost and dean of faculty of Colgate University, collapsed and died of a heart attack last night during a discussion with student leaders. He was 61 years old.
GAINESVILLE, Ala. Robert Williams picked his last crop of cotton months ago, but the empty, wasted plants still hold together in the even rows about his weather-worn tenant house in western Alabama.
The bond market declined sharply yesterday, ending the week with the most notable downturn so far this year.

TOKYO, Feb. 10 Underground in Japan is where the people are. A far cry from the milieu of Andy Warhol or Dostoevsky, the spaces beneath Japan's major cities are brightly lit and steadily crowded with shoppers and stores catering to them.

TRENTON, Feb. 10 A public defender proposed today that subscribers to New Jersey Blue Shield and its participating physicians accept a two-year program of mutual sacrifice for saving the 2.7 million-member medical insurance plan from what he termed financial disaster.
LONDON, Feb. 10 Viktor M. Sukhodrev, the Soviet official who translated for Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin at yesterday's news conference, was chided in the press today for inaccurate work.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 United Nations Under Secretary Ralph J.Bunche, a 1929 graduate of the University of California at Los Angeles, returned to his alma mater today and said he would never have gone to college "if the kind of tuition the Governor [Ronald Reagan] is proposing was in existence."
Two hundred stiff-necked, highly disciplined young men bound for jobs in the merchant marine graduated from the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I. yesterday.
WALPOLE, Mass., Feb. 10 For the first time since the $1million Brink's robbery of 1950 in Boston, one of the men convicted of taking part has admitted his involvement.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 11 All members of the Chinese Communist Army and its supporting agencies who are away from their posts for political activity have been ordered to return to their units by Feb. 20, according to Japanese reports from Peking.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 10 Like victims of a storm at sea, Saigon politicians and generals are gratified at their good fortune in reaching the lifeboats, but Worried that they may not put foot on dry land.
PARIS, Feb. 10 French exports to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union increased by 29 per cent in 1966 over corresponding figures in 1965, it was announced today.
A leading scientist told a Federal task force here yesterday that unless we do something quickly about air pollution we will run the risk of creating a civilization of "respiratory cripples."

Governor Rockefeller's highway safety program is basically sound, but scarcely new. Most of his recommendations have been discussed for years and should have been put into effect long ago. The question now is whether they are strong enough to reduce the shocking carnage on New York's highways, grimmer in 1966 than in any year since 1937.
Two major international unions representing printers and pressmen agreed yesterday on a formula for settling jurisdictional disputes that have long plagued their relationships.

The Humble Oil and Refining Company, domestic affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), announced yesterday that it would purchase from the Standard Oil Company of California the service stations and related properties of California Standard's Signal Oil Company division.
Governor Rockefeller and a representative of President Johnson criticized yesterday Mayor Lindsay's assertion that Federal aid for urban program should be paid directly to the cities.
Savings bankers and mortgage brokers pressed again yesterday for an end to the 6 per cent ceiling that may be charged in New York State on home mortgages.

MINEOLA, L.I. Feb. 10 Nine men were arraigned in Long Beach today in connection with an alleged $100-million-ayear bookmaking operation involving bets on college and professional football and basketball games.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--The national campaign machinery of the Democratic party, rusty from long disuse, was set in motion today and pointed toward the 1968 election.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Feb. 10 (AP) New Jersey's controversial gun-control law, requiring a police-approved identification card for the purchase of firearms, was held constitutional today by Somerset County Superior Court Judge J. Berkeley Leahy.

WARSAW, Feb. 10 The Foreign Ministers of the Warsaw Pact nations ended a threeday meeting today that had been intended to soothe the disquiet of East Germany and Poland over their allies' lively interest in drawing closer to West Germany. The indications are that the seven-nation meeting failed in that purpose.

John Edmond Hewitt, a former professor at New York University's School of Law and a former leader of the National Republican Club, died yesterday at his home at 850 Park Avenue. He was 80 years old and was the last surviving partner in the law firm of Thompson, Koss, Warren Hewitt, 521 Fifth Avenue.
The Continental Insurance Companies of New York reported yesterday operating income of $72.5-million, or $6.27 a share last year, compared with $47-million, or $3.92 a share, in 1965.
BOSTON, Feb. 10 (AP) Dick Barnett's two free throws with three seconds remaining tonight gave the New York Knicks a 122-121 National Basketball Association victory over the stubborn Chicago Bulls.

A study made for the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Advancement of Education says that some day authors of scientific and technical books will sell their works to operators of information systems rather than to publishers.
Shipments of finished steel products by United States producers the key factor controlling revenues dropped nearly 3 per cent last year from record 1965 levels.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The Treasury bill rate edged upward at today's auction for the second consecutive time after its previous dramatic decline, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

The city's Housing and Development Administrator conceded yesterday that New York was not in danger of losing $75-million in Federal housing aid if the City Council and the Legislature did not approve a new housing code by March 2.
MEMPHIS, Feb. 10 (AP) No snow fell in Memphis but they shoveled it anyway. One million pounds of snow arrived in the city yesterday on a freight train from Chicago.

Arthur Clark Farlow, a retired senior vice president of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, died yesterday in Chicago. He was 62 years old.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 10--Princeton University's nationally ranked Ivy League basketball leaders barely escaped Yale's Payne Whitney gymnasium tonight with their league status still intact.
A 10-piece jazz band without precedent in outlook, appearance and performance is playing Monday nights at Slug's, the East Village jazz center at 242 East 3d Street.

Charles G. Moerdler, City Building Commissioner, said yesterday that widespread "substantial safety hazards" had been found during inspections of municipal, voluntary and proprietary hospitals in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The Johnson Administration tightened the definition of its negotiating position on Vietnam this week because it wished to deflect the diplomatic pressures of the Soviet Union, Britain and other potential mediators back toward Hanoi.

National Educational Television will continue its coverage of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearings on "the responsibilities of the United States as a great power" on Monday and Tuesday. Scheduled to testify on those days are Henry Steele Commager, professor of history and American studies at Amherst College, and Gen. James M. Gavin, Ambassador to France during the Kennedy Administration. Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, is chairman of the committee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Retail sales held steady in January at the reduced December level, the Commerce Department reported today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 10 Harvard's basketball team broke an eight-game losing streak tonight as two sophomores, Barth Royer and Eric Gustavsen, led the Crimson to an 82-73 victory over Columbia.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino declared yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's capital budget for 1967-68 contained $162-million in funds unused from previous capital budgets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The State Department said today that the United States was "seriously concerned" over reports that North Vietnam was sending increased supplies to Communist forces during the holiday cease-fire.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 10 Secretary General Thant appealed again tonight for an indefinite extension of the current cease-fire in Vietnam and an end to United States bombing of North Vietnam as the first step toward a conference table to end the war.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The Administration, concerned about the political fallout upon nonnuclear nations, postponed today an experiment in the peaceful uses of atomic explosives.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Feb. 10 Pepsico, Inc., the company that directs the production and distribution of Pepsi-Cola around the world, said today that it would move its corporate headquarters from New York City to the 112 acres of the Blind Brook Polo Club here.
A holdup suspect was shot and killed and a passer-by slightly wounded last night in a running gun battle with the police near Herald Square.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 10 Two student leaders at Vassar College expressed annoyance today at a letter signed by 39 alumnae and former faculty members voicing "disappointment" that Vassar students who were critics of Administration policy in Vietnam had remained silent.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 10--The Government of President Julius K. Nyerere took control of several industries today. Despite some reluctance in the Cabinet to carry on with his program of nationalizing the country's commerce...
NEW DELHI, Feb. 10 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi underwent a minor operation today for her injured nose and a loose tooth.
Mayor Lindsay moved to the podium of Philharmonic Hall yesterday, arched his back and said: "Fellow citizens, we cannot escape history."
PONTIAC, Mich., Feb. 10 More than 26,000 regular-sized 1967 Pontiacs are being recalled because of a possible defect in a power brake unit, the company announced today.

Chanting "We want our checks," 200 nonworking Welfare Department caseworkers and supervisors refused the city's offer yesterday of a loan of 100 each aganst the money they are to receive for work done in the last two weeks.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 10 (Reuters) An Andean village of about 4,000 inhabitants was reported to have been wiped out in a 90-second earthquake that killed 74 people throughout Colombia yesterday.
HIGHWATER, Que., Feb. 10 (Canadian Press) a five-inch space gun launched the first rocket ever fired from a vertical gun in Canada today. The missile reached a height of 47 miles before it fell.

BRYN MAWR., Pa., Feb l0 Mrs. J. Kearsley Mitchell has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ruth Winsor Mitchell, to the Rev. Timothy Bernard Cogan, assistant minister at Grace Episcopal Church in New York. He is the son of Mrs. Lloyd O.V. Mann of New York and the late Bernard S. Cogan.
PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 10 (AP) The long egg-shaped orbit of Lunar Orbiter 3 will be altered, United States scientists say, for a close, clear look at the moon.

President Johnson's proposals to Congress for $250 million in new benefits for veterans include some thoroughly desirable new provisions to bring troops serving in Vietnam into line with veterans of other wars, to extend educational opportunities under the G.I. Bill of Rights, to increase G.I. life insurance and to provide additional aid to widows and dependents of fallen soldiers.
The American Stock Exchange edged ahead yesterday on reduced volume.
WOLFSBURG, Germany Heinz Nordhoff, the chairman of West Germany's Volkswagen company, is somewhat more cautious than his own workers in predicting better times ahead.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. one of the nation's leading securities underwriting concerns disclosed plans yesterday to become a subsidiary of the Chicago Title and Trust Company. It said its directors had agreed with Chicago Title and Trust to sell for $11.5-million cash.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) A three-man committee that runs the 20-by-60-foot swimming pool in the Rayburn House Office Building has yielded the 11 women House members two extra hours of pool time on Mondays for a total allotment of 14 hours every week.
The whipping of Ernie Terrell, decried by some as an immorality play, was shown on video tape yesterday to Cassius Clay. With a few mild reservations, he liked it.
Testimony before the Joint Legislative Committee on Matrimonial Laws demonstrates the need for improvement in the state's new liberalized divorce law before it goes into full effect Sept. 1.
DETROIT, Feb. 10 (UPI) Passenger car production climbed by 17.8 per cent this week despite more winter storms and assembly shutdowns, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
The biggest independent art school in the world got a head start on its 100th birthday last night by giving itself a celebration dinner eight years in advance.
HONG KONG, Feb. 10--China and the Soviet Union have ended agreements permitting their citizens to travel without visas between their two countries.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10 The Pacific Telephone Company asked the California Public Utilities Commission today for annual rate increases totaling $181-million.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 10 Four African states called on the Committee on South-West Africa today to recommend the establishment of an interim government in the territory with an international police force to enforce its decrees pending independence.

GREAT NECK, L.I, Feb. 10 Mrs. Fanny L. Friedman, one of the first lawyers assigned to the Social Security program, died of cancer yesterday in the North Shore Hospital in Manhasset. She lived at 66 Colgate Road.

WASHINGTON, Feb.10 (AP) The Department of Justice announced today a consent judgment aimed at ending a five-year-old antitrust action involving the American Smelting and Refining Company, the General Cable Corporation, and Revere Copper and Brass, Inc. The judgment becomes final in 30 days.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Arthur J. Goldberg called on North Vietnam today to resolve "ambiguity" in its peace proposals to help clear the way for a settlement of the war in Vietnam.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 10 Sydney Archibald Vincent, chief naval architect at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company from 1940 to his retirement in 1959, died here yesterday. He was 72 years old.
The Central Conference of American Rabbis said yesterday that a preoccupation with winning the war in Vietnam had hurt this nation's civil rights movement.

GENEVA, Feb. 10--The Swiss Government ordered today a further 2 per cent reduction in the temporary foreign labor force, which now totals about 600,000. An announcement in Berne said it would be imposed by the end of July. Additional restrictions may be imposed later, it said.

The construction of a professional football team costing $8.5-million took place in a suite on the 38th floor of the Waldorf Astoria Tower between 8:30 A.M. and 11 P.M. Thursday. The suite, as well as the principal part of the football team, belonged to John Mecom Jr., the 28-year-old Texas millionaire who calls almost everybody "sir." He was present to watch Tom Fears and Vic Schwenk spend his money.
ENTERPRISING antiquaries are staking out treasures of the future with turn-ofthe-century oak furniture, which is still offered as often by second-hand furniture dealers as by antique shops.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 A university sophomore of 19 was granted a patent this week for a space-saving carton to hold golf balls, marbles, ball bearings and oth er hard spheres. Douglas J. Sheehan, a student at Washington State University, invented the container when he was a high school senior in Redmond, Wash. The research was part of a mathematics project for a science symposium.

Arrangements to market uranium from two sources, one in Wyoming and one in Utah, have been announced.

Three high-ranking city officials lost all use of city-owned automobiles for two weeks yesterday after Mayor Lindsay learned that their official cars were illegally parked across from City Hall Friday.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Feb. 11 The engagement of Miss Judith Steel Purser to Michael Francis John O'Heney Sibley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Sib ley of London, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Carr R. Purser. A May wedding in London is planned.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb.11 Mr. and Mrs. James T. Burnish have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Elizabeth Burnish, to Richard Standish Gilmore. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Gilmore of Cape Elizabeth, Maine.
SHORT HILLS, N. J., Feb. 11 Miss Phyllis Myra Mueller and Thomas Henry Clynes 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Henry Clynes of Summit and Long Beach Island, plan to marry in August.

Disaster struck the retail trade in many areas along the East Coast last week in the form of a blizzard and low temperatures. Only a very few customers braved the storm on Tuesday and many New York stores closed their doors early in the afternoon.

DETROIT, Feb. 11-Several years ago the New York Rankers gave up on Ted Hampson, a small but sturdy center, because he was unable to score. "He couldn't put the puck in the ocean," the purists said at the time. ATLANTA, Feb. 11 (AP) A serum called antilymphocyte has greatly increased the survival rate of persons receiving a kidney transplant, a leading medical researcher says.

TUNIS, Feb. 11 Ahmed Ben Salah, Tunisian Minister of Planning and National Economy, voiced strong criticism yesterday of the nation's economic program.
ALBANY, Feb. 10 Governor Rockefeller has promised to keep a close watch on a grand jury investigation into alleged vote buying by the Democratic machine in Albany.

King Hassan II of Morocco, accompanied by two of his children and a large retinue of ministers and aides, returned to the Plaza Hotel yesterday after a fruitful two-day visit to Washington.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 11 Dartmouth's ski jumpers staged a tremendous one, two, three finish in the final event of the Big Green's 57th annual winter sports jamboree to take carnival honors by one of the most lopsided margins in years.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 Col. Francis Richard Sullivan, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Sullivan have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Jean Sullivan, to John Robert McCloskey, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Donald McCloskey of Islamabad, Pakistan.

ATLANTA, Feb. 11 (AP) Georgia Tech blew a 14-point lead but then battled back to pin an 82-80 basketball upset on North Carolina tonight. It was only the second loss of the season for the Tar Heels.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 11 (AP) Solo Landing, a 3-year-old roan colt by First Landing, easily won the $21,750 Francis Scott Key stakes at Bowie today.

TOKYO, Feb. 11 Young Japanese are enrolling in higher educational institutions at an age when their elder brothers and sisters went looking for jobs. To meet the labor shortage that has resulted, the Tokyo metropolitan government is inviting married women to take jobs.

NORTH BELLMORE, L.I., Feb. 11 The Mepham High wrestling team, coached by Kenny Hunte, finished its regular season by clinching the Division I South Shore Athletic League championship with a 2611 victory over Calhoun of Merrick today. Calhoun started the neet with a won lost mark of 11-0.

SHAFTSBURY, Vt., Feb. 11 Mr. and Mrs. Floyd N. Holliday have announced the engagement of Mrs. Holliday's daughter, Miss Nancy Van Nostrand Orr, to Ens. Timothy O'Neil Fanning Jr., U.S.N. He is the son of Mr. Fanning of West Hartford, Conn., and the late Mrs. Fanning.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 Pacific Coast Stock Exchange trading is running nearly 25 per cent ahead of last year's volume according to Thomas Phelan, president. Mr. Phelan credits the growth to the vast population expansion on the West Coast with a consequent increase in stockholders and investors.

BANNER ELK, N.C. What is described as the highest ski run in the eastern United States is being built on near by Beech Mountain in the Southern Appalachians. But man-made snow is what will make skiing feasible.

FIGHTEENTH CENTURY England was an age of increasing participation in the arts. Music ceased to be aristocratic, ecclesiastical or private; concerts proliferated, massed choirs came into being, so did music festivals, and music publishers flourished as never before. And so in literature; no publisher could get enough manuscripts, hence the ease with which Goldsmith could raise subscriptions and advances on universal histories that today would never see print.

THE ubiqultcus cent (1909-2...), issued to commemorate the centennial of Lincoln's birth, is in a class by itself as a living memorial. During a conversation between Hubert H. Humphrey and Nikita to Khrushchev in Moscow in 1958 the subject of Mao Tse-tung's experiment with agricultural communes came up. The Soviet Premier said the communes wouldn't work because "you can't get production without incentive." When Senator Humphrey said that sounded capitalistic, Mr. Khrushchev answered, "Call it what you will, it works." Mr. Humphrey later wrote that he. "almost fell off my chair."

New Zealand will join the majority of the countries in the world July 10 by changing to a decimal currency.

The Manhattan Community College of the City University plans a two-year degree course in traffic and shipping for the academic year beginning next September. It will be the College's seventh business career program. The others include accounting, data processing, secretarial science, banking, marketing and advertising.

LAWRENCE, L.I., Feb. 12 --Miss Merrill Ruth Schiller, daughter of Mrs. Barbara N. Schiller of Valley Stream and Lloyd A. Schiller of New York, was married here today to Paul David Rosenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold N. Rosenberg of Englewood, N.J.
Mrs. Andre Malraux, wife of the French Minister of State for Cultural Affairs, will make her American debut as a piano recitalist March 7 at the University of Texas in Austin.

A silver-gray brindle took top honors at the specialty show of the Afghan Hound Club of America yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel. He was Ch. Akaba's Sterling Silver owned jointly by Donna M. Bandy and Lois R. Boardman who handled the 3year-old dog from Calabas, Calif.

SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 11--South Korea's strife-ridden Opposition has surprised almost everyone in this country by uniting its rival factions and agreeing on Posun Yun, a for-, mer President, as its standard bearer in the coming presidential elections.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Feb. 12--Whitney Wilson Merrill, who retired two years ago as trust officer in charge of the personal trust division of the Franklin National Bank, died yesterday in Huntington Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived on Janes Lane, Lloyd Harbor.

BUFFALO, Feb. 12--Sen. Jacob K. Javits called tonight for an "unconditional cessation" of the United States' bombing of North Vietnam and charged that President Johnson had become "locked into the mistakes, illusions, and overoptimistic predictions of his own policies."

Losing altitude at 1,000 feet per minute, it circled tightly into a narrow valley between rocktopped mountain ridges, then flattened into a final brief glide.
A Federal grant of $185,000 has established the Southern New Jersey Council for the Arts and Humanities, to increase appreciation of the arts.

LONDON, Feb. 13--The Soviet Union and Britain pledged today to "make every possible effort" for peace in Vietnam and agreed to "maintain contact to this end."

A black miniature poodle and a pigeon blue Old English sheepdog, each a superb representative of his breed and one, two among the country's show dogs, were the stars of the 91st Westminster Kennel Club show that opened a two-day stand in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

The decision of the company that makes PepsiCola to move its corporate headquarters to Westchester represents a crushing start for Mayor Lindsay's ambitious effort to attract more industry to this city.
The swain interested in buying a Valentine's Day gift for his intended would have had choice a plenty yesterday at the 22d semiannual New York Gift Show.

An Anglo-Soviet agreement to settle long-standing debts on three issues of Baltic bonds of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, states that were taken over by the Soviet Union in 1940, triggered a flurry of speculative activity yesterday in other East European bonds on the London stock market.

Rabbi Lipman Levine, who retired a year ago as spiritual leader of Congregation Agudath Achim Anshe New Lots in Brooklyn, died yesterday at the Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 86 years old and lived at 1425 51st Street in Brooklyn.

In St. James Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Rosalind Valoise Townsend, daughter of Mrs. Philip L.B. Iglehart of Lantana, Fla., and of Edward Townsend of New York, became the bride of C.J. Stuart Allan. His parents are Mrs. C.J. Stuart Allan of New York and the late Mr. Allan.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Feb. 13 (AP) Mrs. Harry S. Truman observed her 82d birthday today, still as shy of personal publicity as when she was the First Lady at the White House.

The assumption that the public interest always requires more and wider roads has been challenged by a bipartisan joint legislative committee, which proposed creation of a State Board of Highway Planning Review to pass on road-building decisions of the Public Works Department and other state agencies.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 13 In the crowded lobbies of this city's myriad banks today, customer after customer walked away from the teller's windows with a bewildered look.

PARIS, Feb. 13 France's Three-week general election campaign officially began today. Most political experts, though not all, predict that the supporters of President de Gaulle will again win a majority in the National Assembly.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 13 (AP) Chubasco, a 66foot sloop, took the lead in the St. Petersburg-to-Fort Lauderdale sailing race today as the 46-boat fleet sailed up the Atlantic homestretch.

ATLANTA, Feb. 13 A move is developing among some Democratic national committeemen to close the doors of the 1968 convention to any delegation from the Deep South that does not have Negro members and does not promise to uphold Federal civil rights laws.

ALBANY, Feb, 13 Governor Rockefeller has appointed State Supreme Court Justice Owen MeGivern to the Appellate Division, First Department, which has jurisdiction over Manhattan and the Bronx. The appointment is effective tomorrow.

GRENADA, Miss., Feb. 13 (UPI) A Negro and a white man were swept into a runoff tonight in a special election for a City Council post.
BOSTON Feb. 13 Approximately 500 students participated in a protest today over the appearance, at Harvard University of Arthur J. Goldberg, chief United States Representative at the United Nations.
The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation announced here yesterday the appointment of Francis A. O'Connell to the new post of vice president for employe relations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson picked Valentine's Day to promote the designing of competitively salable arts and crafts products to be made by the handicapped.

The bond market declined sharply yesterday in response to the resumption of bombing raids in North Vietnam, discouragement in Wall Street with the lack of new Federal Reserve steps to ease credit, and the large volume of new issues for sale.

DETROIT, Feb. 14 (UPI) Dr. Timothy Leary, a leading advocate of the use of LSD, was arrested by United States customs officers today on charges of failing to register as a narcotics violator before leaving the country.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 14 Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president emeritus of Vassar College, charged today that moving Vassar to New Haven, Conn., would be "a wholesale takeover of an independent institution."

ALBANY, Feb. 14 Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz held today that Dean Stephen K. Bailey of Syracuse University, a candidate for the State Board of Regents, could not hold his university post and serve on the state board at the same time.
RIVERBOAT, Empire State Building, Fifth Avenue and 34th Street. Xavier Cugat and his orchestra extended engagement through Feb. 25.

RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 14 (AP) Bob Lewis's 36 points led the No. 40-ranked North Carolina basketball team to a 77-60 victory over North Carolina state tonight.

LONDON, Feb. 14 A British judge asserted today that Walt Disney Productions, Ltd., had fallen "far below the generally accepted standard of commercial propriety" in its efforts to prevent production of a rival to its animated cartoon "Peter Pan."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 North Vietnam appears eager to gain United States political recognition of the Vietcong before the South Vietnamese elections " this summer, American analysts of Southeast Asian affairs said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 The trucking industry appeared headed tonight toward untangling a dispute that has snarled the start of negotiations on a new national trucking contract.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 The Legislature passed and sent to Governor Rockefeller today a bill that would require anyone purchasing a common cough remedy containing codeine or opium to have a prescription. The law now requires a prescription only for persons under 21 years of age.

Theodore W. Kheel promised the Amateur Athletic Union and the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday one more chance to settle their differences before his sports arbitration board rendered a final decision.

Mr. and Mrs. James Johnson Sweeney of 120 East End Avenue and Houston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ciannait Sweeney, to Alan Tait, son of Mr. and Mrs. J.R. Hutton-Tait of Kirkcudbrightshire, Scotland.

SHOE fashion is operating under the reverse of the law of gravity. Now that heels have gone as far down to the ground as possible (thanks to Courreges and Roger Vivier of Paris), they are on the ascent once more. The era of the chunky shoe has not quite ended, but middle-aged adolescents will soon be returning their sandbox sandals to the kiddies.

George Orwell specified in his will that he wanted no biography. Nevertheless, his widow and his publisher are arranging to put out four volumes of his nonfiction writings that they feel will present a sketch of his life and character.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 15--A United States minesweeper was sunk today and two others were damaged severely in two separate guerrilla attacks along the Longtau river, the main shipping channel into Saigon, a United States spokesman announced.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) President Johnson gave his wife a Valentine's Day present today.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Feb. 14--A three-day meeting on security in Central and East Africa closed here today with a declaration by ten participating countries pledging support of the fight against the remnants of Colonialism in Africa.

ALTHOUGH it was not a retirement that had earth-shattering implications, it was not one that should go unnoticed. Ted Lyons has stepped out of baseball after 44 years, most of them with the Chicago White Sox, and he was only a scout when he brought his diamond career to a halt. But it is the man who rates attention, rather than the position.

Minneapolis's Tyrone Guthrie Theater will put on next season's productions at St. Paul's Crawford Livingston Theater, St. Paul's Council of Arts and Sciences raised $100,000 to cover any deficit, and another $100,000 to enlarge the seating capacity of the house from 410 to 661.

A dinner-jacketed judge motioned one of the six dogs before him to the center of a green-matted ring in Madison Square Garden last night and thus made a Scottish Terrier best of the Westminster Kennel Club competition for the second time in three years.

An official of the Soviet state airline, Aeroflot, predicted yesterday that the opening of Moscow-New York air service in May would bring a large increase in American tourists going to Russia.

Volume expanded markedly and prices went up yesterday in a lively session on the American Stock Exchange.

The Humble Oil and Refining Company, the nation's leading producer, refiner and marketer of petroleum products, appeared to hold the key yesterday to efforts of the Federal Government to roll back recent gasoline price increases.

Morton Sobell lost a new bid yesterday for freedom from prison, to which he was sentenced for 30 years in 1951 for conspiracy to spy for the Soviet Union.

The State Education Commissioner yesterday ordered the Board of Education to rezone high school attendance areas in Queens to prevent Andrew Jackson High School from becoming a de facto segregated Negro school.

The British-Soviet communiqu at the end of Premier Kosygin's visit to London suggests that something approaching a detente was agreed to by the Russian leader and Prime Minister Wilson. If the communiqu 's words mature into action, there will be major increases in trade, air services, technological cooperation and cultural and other exchanges between the two countries, as well as the conclusion of a treaty of friendship and peaceful cooperation.

Marion Davies, a cellist who made her debut at Town Hall in 1963, returned last night for her first Carnegie Hall recital. She was principal cellist of the Houston Symphony before beginning her concert career.

Eugene Rodriguez, the first man of Puerto Rican descent to be elected to the New York State Senate, was sentenced yesterday to 18 months to four years in prison for perjury and attempted grand larceny.

In the first case involving "improper" weather reporting to commercial air carriers, the United States Court of Appeals held yesterday that the Government, which supplies the weather service, was liable for the negligence of its employes.

Patricia Neal will speak at a dinner to be given on March 12 at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the New York Association for Brain Injured Children. It will be the actress's first public appearance since she suffered a stroke two years ago.

Mayor Lindsay swore in a new Highway Commissioner yesterday and told him to "go in and give that department the modern budgetary practices, strong leadership and advanced scientific techniques it needs."

There may be some question about the specific excuse for removal of Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal as chairman of the Assembly's Democratic Advisory Committee, but there can be no doubt about the result.

ROME, Feb. 14 The centerleft Government of Premier Aldo Moro, shaken by a Parliamentary defeat last Thursday, won a firm vote of confidence in the Senate tonight.
