The New York Generals of the National Professional Soccer League, characterizing themselves as "the seventh major professional team in the city," disclosed yesterday they would play their 16 home games in the prestigious surroundings of Yankee Stadium.
America's oldest and largest modern dance troupe, the Martha Graham Dance C ompany, and what is one of America's smallest and youngest, the Twyla Tharp Dance Company, have scheduled European trips.
PARIS, Feb. 14 A device permitting the effective dropping of atomic bombs from low altitudes has been perfected by France, it was announced today.
The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation set records in all major phases of its 1966 operations, Leslie H. Warner, president, reported yesterday.

YONKERS, Feb. 14 An accident in which four pacers were involved marred the feature Class A-2 race at Yonkers Raceway tonight. None of the horses or drivers were seriously hurt although they suffered minor bruises.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 14--Secretary of State Dean Rusk was reported to be confident today that Latin-American nations will make sufficient progress on the issue of economic integration in the next few days to justify a conference of Western Hemisphere Presidents by the middle of April.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 14 (AP) The Apollo 1 capsule will be removed from the top of its Saturn 1 rocket late this week, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra gave a concert at Phil harmonic Hall last night that was wrapped in success. Eugene Ormandy conducted, Isaac Stern appeared as soloist and an easy-to-listen-to work by a currently fashionable composer was played first, so that Brahms's Third Symphony and Lalo's "Symphonie Espagnole" could be savored at leisure.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14 A company in which David Rockefeller has a leading role unveiled plans today for a major building complex between the Ferry Building and the financial district here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 The select committee investigating Representative Adam Clayton Powell began today to look into a Bahamian corporation whose shares were held by close friends of Mr. Powell and by the new Prime Minister of the Bahamas.

MIAMI, Feb. 14 Bobby Ussery provided a fine afternoon for his followers in the crowd of 18,316 fans at Hialeah today. When the feature race of seven furlongs was over, the exultant cry rang out through the stands, "Ussery did it again." The reference was to the fact that the strong jockey from Vian, Okla., had won for the third time in the afternoon.
OBERLIN, Ohio., Feb. 14 A demonstration against Air Force recruiters on the campus at Oberlin College took a new tack today.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 14 (AP) Flashy Shot took the lead soon after leaving the starting gate and led the rest of the way to score an upset victory in the feature race at Bowie today.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 14 The turmoil in Communist China has inspired new feelings of optimism in the Chinese Nationalist Government about the prospects of its return to the mainland.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 14 Byron De La Beckwith, the 46year-old former fertilizer salesman who was tried twice without a verdict for the assassination of a Negro leader, became a candidate for Lieutenant Governor of Mississippi today.
QUEBEC, Feb. 14 (AP) Quebec took the lead today in the first Canadian Winter Games, scoring 16 points at speed skating and synchronized swimming.
The New York State Racing Commission, in its annual report to the Governor, said yesterday that a record high of $77,569,039 in state revenue had been produced by thoroughbred racing in 1966.

That a researcher looking for medieval ballads should find 700 lost pages of Leonardo da Vinci's manuscripts and drawings is wildly improbable. Yet it happened in Madrid, and the event is a milestone in the history of science and technology.
Everett B. Morris, yachting editor of The World Journal Tribune, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 16 Monfort Road, Port Washington, L.I. He was 67 years old.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Feb. 14 (UPI) The Green Bay Packers will love Lambeau Field in December as they do in August next season because of a huge electric blanket that will keep it dry and firm rather than slick and frozen.
Two of New York City's largest banks predicted yesterday that interest rates may already have dropped close to their lows for 1967.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14--Samuel H. Daroff, men's clothing manufacturer, philanthropist and civic leader, died today at Einstein Medical Center after a week's illness. He was 66 years old and lived at 226 West Rittenhouse Square.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 A leading savings-and-loan-association official has protested to the Treasury that the Government's planned new savings certificate could thwart attempts to roll back interest rates generally, The Treasury Department disagrees.

WASHINGTON, Feb.14 (AP) The Supreme Court was asked today to reverse lower court rulings and permit 4,100 Japanese-Americans to sue the Federal Government to regain bank savings seized as alien, property at the start of World War II.
The Chrysler Corporation, last of the nation's big three auto producers to announce 1966 results, reported yesterday a 19 per cent drop in earnings for the year.
WASHINGTON, Feb 14 (AP)--The Agriculture Department reported today that state and local taxes levied on farm real estate in 1965 set a record of $1.65-billion.

SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 14 Jose Edison Mandarino, the chief artisan of Brazil's first Davis Cup Victory over the United States last year, was beaten in the second round of the national indoor tennis championship tonight.
LONDON, Feb. 14 The Foreign Office said today that Foreign Secretary Brown's remark on the Oder-Neisse line meant "no change of policy on the attitude toward the East zone of Germany."

DETROIT, Feb.14 Appliance makers and other manufacturers should heed "early warning" signals and offer consumers a better break to avert "the heavy hand of government," an automobile executive warned today.

Paperboard production rose 1.7 per cent with 450,500 tons in the week ended Feb, 11, from 443,000 tons in the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

Robert Malson of White Plains High School took first place in the open shot-put event of New York University's schoolboy track meet yesterday. He made a put of 58 feet inches in the competition at Alumni Gymnasium in the Bronx.

The International Paper Company and its subsidiaries the world's largest paper making organization set new highs last year in production, sales and earnings, Edward B. Hinman, president, reported yesterday. It also benefited from a firmer price structure.

WASHINGTON, Feb.14--A petition calling for an over-all review of United States policy on chemical and biological warfare was turned over to the White House today by four scientists who estimated they had signatures from 5,000 of their peers.
When he sought re-election as President of France in 1965, Charles de Gaulle at first disdained to campaign. He swung into action only after being forced into a humiliating runoff.

Quality or quantity? Ideally we should have both in the arts. If we could wave a wand and make wishes come true, we would ask for a host of excellent theaters, orchestras, operas, dance companies and museums and a great company of fine, creative artists to fill their programs and walls.

Mayor Lindsay last night appointed a New York Board of Trade official to head a task force on noise control. The panel is to set up maximum sound levels to protect New Yorkers in their homes, at work and in public places.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 Governor Rockefeller announced today the signing of a contract to link the state's five independent educational television stations in a statewide hookup to be known as the New York Network.

A video-tape replay of the controversial portion of Sunday's Philadelphia-Boston National Basketball Association game showed yesterday that the Celtics had one too many players on the court for four seconds.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) The Defense Department said today that during 1966 the number of Negroes killed in Vietnam was proportionately larger than that of whites.
TRENTON, Feb. 14 Gov. Richard J. Hughes offered the Legislature today a $1-billion budget temporarily marked down to $999-million.

DEHGAM, India, Feb. 14--On the green benches of the Chetna Restaurant here today, paunchy merchants and lean farmers sprawled in the sun, munching their wheat cakes and curds and casting suspicious glances across the street.
The man who runs Kastor Foote Hilton Atherton announced yesterday that the name had been changed to one of the best-known in the ad game his own, Emerson Foote, with an Inc. at the end.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 14 Hospital administrators and directors of nursing education predicted here today that the critical shortage of nurses in the United States might be more than twice as bad by 1970.

A video-tape replay of the controversial portion of Sunday's Philadelphia-Boston National Basketball Association game showed yesterday that the Celtics had one too many players on the court for four seconds.
In an expansion and relocation move, the International Executive Service Corps has leased about 13,000 square feet of space in the Duras Building at 545 Madison Avenue.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 16 Japanese correspondents in Peking reported yesterday that military forces led by opponents of Chairman Mao Tse-tung had seized control of the capital of Tibet.
All activities, of the Coast Guard involving merchant-marine inspection have been moved to the service's Battery Park Building, Capt. William F. Rea announced yesterday.

PARAMUS, N.J., Feb. 14 A new shopping center for the quality minded, The Fashion Center, will open here to the public tomorrow in a 33-acre hollow scooped out of former celery farms on Route 17 at Ridgewood Avenue.

IN this bullish market traders are moving from one group of stocks to another looking for undervalued ones relative to the market as a whole. Analysts said this factor helped to explain why steel stocks were popular yesterday.
Mrs. Mary Frances Hudson Large, widow of Rex Large, an assistant telegraph editor of The New York Times, died Sunday of a heart attack in her home at 430 West 24th Street. Her age was 76.
ONE day in the late nineteen-twenties, shortly after Mala Rubinstein arrived in Paris from her native Krakow, she and her aunt Helena were sitting in a cafe with a group of artists.

ALBANY, Feb. 14--A getaway driver testifying for the Government in the bank-robbery trial of John (Sonny) Franzese and four others said today that Franzese sent him a death warning in jail, using a prison "chef" as a courier.
A 55-year-old lawyer was shot and critically wounded in his office in the financial district yesterday, according to the police of the Old Slip stationhouse.

WASHINGTON, Feb.14 (AP)--An Air Force reserve colonel says that former Gov. Samuel P. Goddard Jr. of Arizona had played a central role in a stormy seminar at the Air War College in Montgomery, Ala., that led to the reassignment of a top Air Force general.

ONE of the silent movies' more notorious Tiffany lamps, relic of a style of artsy acting and fancy decor that blazes as present-day camp, is being placed on view today at the Gallery of Modern Art as a part of its current exhibition of Aubrey Beardsley drawings and prints.

WESTON, Mass., Feb. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Emmett Sullivan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Andrea Joslyn Sullivan, to Paul Keenan Jr. He is the son of Mrs. Keenan of Chicago and Naples, Fla., and the late Mr. Keenan.
WAYNE, N.J., Feb. 14 Two Jewish candidates for the township Board of Education were badly defeated tonight after an election campaign in which the religion of the two became an issue.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 14 Miss Sheila Mary Dacey and Paul Bransfield Galvani are planning to be married in June.
Korean scholars have found what they believe to be the oldest printed text yet discovered.

Rabbi Julius G. Neumann resigned yesterday from the city's Commission on Human Rights and charged that its chairman was "whipping up animosity among people," ignoring discrimination against Jews and investigating only the complaints of Negroes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 President Johnson, intervening in a controversy over Central Intelligence Agency subsidies to the National Student Association, instructed the C.I.A. today to close out all secret programs of aid to student groups, Government officials said.

TORONTO, Feb. 14 Bernard (Boom Boom) Geoffrion, one of the spirited souls in the revival of the New York Rangers, was suspended tonight for the Blues' next three games by Clarence Campbell, the president of the National Hockey League.

The Appellate Division yesterday began consideration of the criminal contempt of court ruling that makes representative Adam Clayton Powell subject to arrest in the state at any time. In doing so, the five justices sharply questioned the legality of the lower court order.
The marriage of Miss Paige Cary to Wallace Butterworth Jr. took place yesterday morning in the Rutgers Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Cyril Jenkins performed the ceremony.

The youth activities program of Casita Maria will benefit from a children's fashion show and tea, to be held in the Pierre's Grand Ballroom on March 5. Mrs. F. Colman Greene is chairman with Mrs. Charles M. Grace as co-chairman.

One of the principle arguments for the constitutional amendment authorizing New York State to conduct lotteries was that it would provide more funds for education. On the strength of this argument the voters approved the amendment last November.

The Central Intelligence Agency used undercover financing and secret collaborators to turn the National Student Association's international activities into "an arm of United States foreign policy," Ramparts magazine said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 Following is the text of President Johnson's message to Congress today on civil rights:

THE Blackfriars' Guild is a Roman Catholic organiza tion whose general aim is "to restore to the theater the spiritual perspectives which are necessary to the health and vigor of a great popular art."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 W. (for Wayne) Eugene Groves is described by his young friends in Washington as a left-of-center liberal and by his mother back home in Indiana as a Republican.
The spot rate on the British pound eased again slightly yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
The American Stock Exchange started yesterday to query leading brokerage houses about the recent sharp increase in activity in speculative issues.
Thomas P.F. Hoving is planning something of a royal happening for his first exhibition as director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
The Amerada Petroleum Corporation and the Ashland Oil and Refining Company announced yesterday a revised plan for their proposed merger and a slate of officers for the combined company.

SALEM, Mass., Feb: 15 (AP) Mary Ann Eisel of St. Louis upset top-seeded Mrs. Billie Jean Moffitt King of Long Beach, Calif., 6-4, 5-7, 11-9, last night to win the New England women's indoor tennis championship.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 15 (AP) Dizzy Dean, the former baseball pitcher, dropped out of the Mississippi Governor's race today because of his wife's health.
Prices fell yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in the final hour and a half.

Remember Dick Van Dyke? He's the funny fellow who left his TV audience in tears when he decided to quit his popular comedy series at the end of last season. After five years and a dozen Emmy Awards, he explained at the time, he wanted to quit while the show was near the top of the ratings to devote himself to other projects.

Over the protests of some Harlem parent groups, the Board of Education adopted a program last night that would give the controversial Intermediate School 201 additional remedial and tutorial facilities four days a week.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 15 The Jersey City Board of School Estimate adopted today a record budget of $20.6-million for the 1967-68 scholastic year, but did not provide for pay increases for teachers.
The New York City Housing Authority has called on the real estate industry for help in expanding a new program the leasing of private apartments to applicants having low incomes.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15 Mrs. Arnold Schoenberg, widow of the noted composer, died at her home in Branchwood, West Los Angeles, yesterday after a long illness. She was 68 years old.

BONN, Feb. 15 Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger and Prime Minister Wilson agreed today to brush aside a momentary misunderstanding about Germany to concentrate on discussions of Britain's proposed entry into the European Common Market.
The promotion of four executives to the posts of vice presidents of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., has been announced by Leone J. Peters, president of the real estate company.
Harcourt, Brace World, Inc., one of the largest publishers of textbooks, has received a Federal license to construct two commercial television stations and has applications on file for four others.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 15 The Government has severed communication with the General Labor Confederation. The 2.5 million-member confederation is the strongest organized labor group in the country.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 15 (UPI) The Gallup Poll said today that about two of every five Republicans would select Richard M. Nixon as the party's Presidential nominee for 1968 but that a majority of all voters would name Gov. George Romney of Michigan.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 15--Western Hemisphere diplomats who assembled today for the opening of the third special inter-American conference of the Organization of American States agreed unanimously to abandon opening speeches in favor of getting down to business.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 Two former chairmen of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, a Republican and a Democrat, told Congress today that a tax increase would probably be necessary later this year if the economy resumed strong growth, as expected by the Administration.

TORONTO, Feb. 15 In any sport, the essence of a quality team is its ability to perform on a high competitive level when some of its best players are absent. The New York Rangers failed to display that essence tonight. They were routed, 6-0, by the Toronto Maple Leafs. It was their most one-sided defeat in the National Hockey League season.

May potato futures reached another new low in its downhill move yesterday as the New York Mercantile Exchange had its fourth busiest day in history. The new low for the chartists to ink on their charts was $3.20 a hundred pounds, and at day's end the contract was nudged upward to $3.21, down 13 cents a hundred pounds on the day.

Cassius Clay signed yesterday to defend his title at Madison Square Garden on March 22 against Zora Folley. It will be the Eighth Avenue arena's first world heavyweight championship bout in 16 years, and probably its last.

HONG KONG, Feb. 15 Some Western analysts of politics in China said today that increasing concern about the food supply might have forced a slowdown in the Cultural Revolution led by Mao Tse-tung, Communist party chairman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 The seven allied nations that met at Manila in October for a strategy conference on the war in Vietnam are preparing to hold a follow-up meeting here next April, officials disclosed today.
NOW that the stock market has moved into a more optimistic phase, there's a feeling in Wall Street that lots of companies can make merger bids without offering exorbitant prices.
Bernard Godwin, who painted a portrait of Pope John XXIII in Rome, died Tuesday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 115 East Ninth Street.

Philip R. Dunst, Republican leader of the 62d Assembly District, South, and a senior administrator of the Board of Elections, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived at 15 Stuyvesant Oval.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Feb. 15 Companies have been moving from New York City to Westchester County to escape city income and sales taxes, to benefit from available pools of white-collar workers including young housewives with college degrees and to minimize the companies' contacts with unions.
The Port of New York Authority opened a campaign yesterday to obtain Federal funds for two critically needed harbor improvements.
BERGDORF GOODMAN had a fashion show yesterday that made spectators feel a bit un-American if they had ever done business with foreign couturiers.

President Sukarno seems still to believe he can cling to office and some of his old power in Indonesia. He thus has rejected the army-led regime's "final" proposal that he step down gracefully and leave the country.

The chairman of National Student Association chapters on more than 40 campuses in the metropolitan area predicted yesterday that student governments would stay with the organization rather than disaffiliate because of its link with the Central Intelligence Agency.
The Calhoun School and the Barnard School for Boys, both old-established private schools, have entered into negotiations toward a merger.

It would be disingenuous to deny that part of the difficulties confronting the President's civil rights bill stems from a crisis of confidence splitting those who care about human equality and racial harmony.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) Vladimir Kazan-Komarek said today that he had smuggled persons out of Czechoslovakia after the Communist take-over there in 1948.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) About 2,500 women demanding to see "the generals who send our sons to Vietnam" stormed the Pentagon today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, told the Senate today that there could be no defense of the United States without a strong merchant marine.
Bard Browne, retired vice president in charge of sales for the Superheater Company, now the Combustion Engineering Company, died Tuesday at the age of 80. He lived in Ardsley, N.Y.

The impropriety and folly of permitting the Central Intelligence Agency to subsidize the National Student Association cannot be mitigated by post-mortem rationalizing. It is absurd to suggest that, because the student organization was too impoverished to take part in international meetings, the C.I.A. merely assumed the role of a benevolent patron of youth.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 15 Mr. and Mrs. William Devereaux Nolte have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Nolte, to Dr. Robert Montague Wein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gustave Ferdinand Wein of Bronxville, N.Y.
"MY Russian mother once told me," Jennie Tourel said as she put a carving knife to a loaf of pumpernickel, "if you can't slice bread or onions, you never will get married."

The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation made an offer yesterday to acquire the Wilbur B. Driver Company of Newark for about $54.7-million in stock. The New Jersey company makes metallurgical products and materials.

Anthony Newman and the pedal harpsichord arrived last night for a joint local debut at Carnegie Recital Hall and neither is likely to be forgotten soon. Mr. Newman is a mildmannered 25-year-old virtuoso from Boston, who dazzled his audience with a severely difficult Bach program. His pedal harpsichord there are only 10 in the country is a 10 -foot assemblage that looked like a barge about to be launched.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 Two high Administration officials complained today that the antipoverty program was being stalled on Capitol Hill and elsewhere.

An increase of 2,624,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend supplies totaled 215,934,000 barrels, up from 213,310,000 a week earlier and 205,853,000 a year before.
THE HAGUE, Feb. 15 (UPI) The International Student Conference denied today that it had received financial support from the Central Intelligence Agency or any other American governmental body.

LAST night's concert by the Chamber Symphony of Philadelphia in Philharmonic Hall marked the return of the Soviet pianist Yakov Zak for the first time since his debut appearances here two seasons ago. He was heard in Chopin's Piano Concerto No. 2 in F minor. Whether by accident or design, Anshel Brusilow, the conductor, had chosen for the first half of the program two Russian works, Prokofiev's Sinfonietta and Tchaikovsky's "Mozartiana" Suite.

An artful diplomat and a charming man of affairs, William Christian Bullitt was at the center of three great events in this nation's history in the first half of this century. They were the Vetsailles Peace Conference after World War I, United States recognition of the Soviet Union in 1933 and the prologue, in the late nineteenthirties, to American entry into

THE vanishing lady trick, which belongs in the repertoire of the professional conjurer, has an equvivalent in bridge terms. It is the vanishing trump trick, and it is always attractive to watch. The diagramed deal was the occasion for a recent performance of the trick in a rubber bridge game, and the conjurer was Manny Reiss of New York.
Harry Thomas Gamble, Lafayette's new coach, was honored by a group of the college's New York alumni at a luncheon in Rosoff's restaurant, 147 West 53d Street, yesterday.
SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 15 United States players had conspicuous success over the foreign representation today in the national indoor tennis championship.

Martha Raye, who recently returned from Vietnam, where she served as a nurse and an entertainer, will be the new Mrs. Dolly Gallagher Levi in "Hello, Dolly!" She will take the role over from Ginger Rogers on Feb. 27.
Thomas S. Carroll was elected yesterday as president and chief executive officer of the Lever Brothers Company, an American subsidiary of the Unilever organization.

SAN DIEGO, Feb. 15 (AP) Sig Ruman, the Sergeant Schultz of the movie "Stalag 17" and one of the three Soviet envoys in the Greta Garbo film "Ninotchka," died outside his home in nearby Julian yesterday as he returned from a camping trip.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 15 Gov. Ronald Reagan's proposed budget cuts for the University of California could, in the extreme, force a shutdown of three of the institution's nine campuses, university officials reported to the Board of Regents today.
A contest to acquire the controlling stock in the Lunkenheimer Company, a Cincinatti maker of flow control devices and valves for the petroleum industry appeared to be shaping up yesterday.

Judged charitably, the school board election in suburban Wayne, N.J., was a victory for foolishness. The voters defeated two Jewish candidates after an incumbent member of the board warned that "most Jewish people are liberals, especially when it comes to spending for education." In the same election the voters rejected the proposed school budget.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 15 (UPI) Oscar Robertson scored 46 points, two below his season high, and had 14 assists tonight to pace the Cincinnati Royals to a 127-118 victory over the New York Knicks.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb, 16 A South Korean military spokesman reported that two companies of Korean marines, perhaps 300 men, killed 242 North Vietnamese soldiers in fighting yesterday.
DALLAS, Feb. 15 (AP) A controversial Episcopal priest declared today that a religious revolution, largely unknown to organized church leadership, was taking place in the United States.

TORONTO, Feb. 15 The net worth of C. Powell Morgan, former president of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, soared from $162,000 in 1960 to almost $2-million in 1965, only to sink to an apparent deficit of $119,000 three weeks after Atlantic collapsed on June 14, 1965.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 15--Most officials and residents of this wealthy suburban community look upon plans of the American Can Company to build its $15-million headquarters here as an inevitable result of "growing pains."

MADRID, Feb. 15 The Spanish National Library acknowledged today that its index system was antiquated and that it had made some errors in catalogue numbers, but it denied that any rare manuscripts of Leonardo da Vinci had ever been "lost."

State and city officials have agreed in principle to seek state legislation establishing new revenue sources to meet subway and bus operating costs. If the new revenues are not enough, the officials have agreed to allow open subsidizing by the city.

WAYNE, N.J., Feb. 15 The Mayor of this community, where two candidates' religion was introduced in the school board election campaign, issued a proclamation today noting that Brotherhood-Week begins on Sunday.

The only question in the second game of a collegiate basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night was whether or not Mal Graham would score 50 points. He didn't. But his 45 points powered a New York University team that had fallen upon hard times to a 76-63 victory over Manhattan.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 15 Two goals in the final six minutes of play tonight broke a 4-4 tie and gave Clarkson College a 6-4 victory over Princeton at Baker Rink.

Cyrille Adoula, Congolese Ambassador to the United States, said here yesterday that he expected an amicable settlement of the dispute over his Government's seizure of Union Miniere du Haut-katanga, the copper producer.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 15 The Yemeni royalist authorities said here tonight that Egyptian aircraft launched a poison-gas attack last Thursday on the village of Beni Salamah, in southern Yemen, and killed 70 persons.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 15 India began her fourth general elections today in a tense and anxious mood. From the white deserts of Rajasthan to the green rice paddies of Madras, more than 30 million voters went to the polls in an atmosphere of uncertainty unmatched in the country's three previous elections since it obtained independence.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 15 A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that Rye could continue to bar nonresidents from its city-owned Rye Golf Course and swimming pool.

The Kaiser Industries Corporation reported yesterday 1966 earnings of $20,125,000, or 81 cents a share. This was six times the 1965 income of $3.71million, or 9 cents a share, because the company changed its accounting procedure last year.
The B.F. Goodrich Company announced yesterday its entry into the shoe-upper material market with a synthetic leather-like product called Aztran, The new poromeric ma-

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 Frank J. Scholl, who with his brother, Dr. William M. Scholl, built the international foot-treatment empire of the Scholl Manufacturing Company, died Monday in his home. He was 83 years old.

Donald R. Atkin, a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died of a brain tumor Tuesday night in the Neurological Institute of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 42 years old and lived on Pea Pond Road, Katonah, N.Y.
A woman was killed and a man was critically injured yesterday in a flash fire in a photographer's secondstory studio at 144 East 57th Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues.

WASHINGTON, Feb.15 (AP) Home building activity, sparked by an easing in credit conditions, rose 14.6 per cent during January, the third straight month of substantial gain following October's postwar low.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 15 An economist for the Battelle Memorial Institute predicted today that more and more construction work would gravitate from the building site to the factory where components could be prefabricated.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 "A small, low-grade fire" may have preceded the "more intense fire that caused the deaths of the three Apollo astronauts, the space agency said today.
The All-State Credit Corporation, a finance company based on Long Island, has emerged as the most recent concern to encounter difficulties as an aftermath of the tight money market of 1966.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 A new type of compact artificial heart device, with no valves or other interior, moving parts, was described here today.
The Greater New York chapter of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine women's division will give its annual Spirit of Achievement luncheon on April 11 in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom.

"Would it make more sense for me to buy a house or rent an apartment for about $150 a month?" That question was asked by a New York City high-school teacher on Tues- day in the New York Times Auditorium here at the first session of this year's Economics In-Service Course, sponsored by The Times and the New York City Council on Economic Education.

WASHINGTON, Feb.15 (AP) The House Armed Services Committee accused the Johnson Administration today of failure to provide "meaningful and understanding support" of the nation's National Guard and Reserve military forces.
MOSCOW, Feb. 15 (UPI) The publication of a controversial novel that deals favorably with the theme of Christ was completed today.

The National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System have rejected offers to send camera crews to North Vietnam because the networks would have had to contribute money to a group planning a "war crimes trial" of President Johnson.
Forty tenants from all parts of the city yesterday picketed the office of one of the major real estate associations, which has proposed a plan to eliminate rent control in the next five years.
Ronald Searle, the British cartoonist and the man behind the man in the "Acquire Squires" gin ads, is in town for a bit Business, you know.

All three sides of the natural gas industry producers, transmitters and distributors got together yesterday with an idea of producing true figures on gas supplies for the present and needs for the future.

LONDON, Feb. 15 Roman Catholics in Britain, disturbed recently by the decision of a leading theologian, Charles Davis, to leave the priesthood and the church, has been upset anew by the case of the Rev. Herbert McCabe.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) A light plane trying to weave its way through skyscraper apartments wrapped in fog struck one of the buildings at the 16th floor today, then caromed 75 feet into another and plunged into a vacant lot. The two men aboard were killed.

A memorial service for Stephen R. Currier and his wife, Audrey Bruce Currier, the philanthropists who disappeared on a Caribbean flight last month, was held here yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church. Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson, Governor Rockefeller, Senator Robert F. Kennedy and Mayor Lindsay were among the more than 800 persons who attended.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the trucking industry got down to serious bargaining today on a new contract after settling a dispute over the format of the talks.
ITHACA, Feb. 15 A new manifestation of campus criticism of the Vietnam war began at Cornell University tonight with the opening of the first National Student Conference on Vietnam.

The advertising agency that was hired to oppose the civiliandominated police complaint review board last fall has filed a $9-million libel suit against 30 advertising agencies because of their statement that a "deceptive inflammatory" campaign was being waged to kill the board.

If Ron Swoboda starts to show as much maturity in action as he displayed yesterday in words, the 22-year-old slugger may yet make a place for himself in the New York Mets' outfield at present apparently closed to him.

Although the last of the scores of films Mr. Moreno made over a 40-year career included Spanish-language features, his reputation stemmed largely from the Latin lover heroes he portrayed opposite Greta Garbo, Pola Negri and Gloria Swanson, among others.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara made public today a list of 50 cities that might be included in an antimissile defense system if one is ever deployed by the United States.
A school boycott in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn was called again by parents last night after they rejected a Board of Education compromise plan because "we do not trust the board."

JUST when Ralph Townsend, the popular Williams Col- lege ski coach, was convinced that the snow cover for the Purple's annual winter carnival this weekend was going to present no unusual problems, along came yesterday's thaw to complicate matters.

The United Scenic Artists, Local 829, has become the first New York film production union to reject Mayor Lindsay's proposed one-year experiment designed to attract feature film producers to the city.
A student chapter of the Irish Republican Army, which is outlawed in Ireland, was chartered at City College yesterday, according to the organization's president, Fergus Madigan Bordewich.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 The nation's leading airlines have agreed to advance more than $50-million toward development of a supersonic airliner, it was learned today.
A little boy and an Emperor met yesterday on the porch of Gracie Mansion.
Mail orders for some of the events of the Lincoln Center Festival '67 are now being accepted. The box offices at Lincoln Center will open April 9 for all events in the respective theaters.

The Medicaid program of the state, and especially of New York City, was described as "totally unworkable . . . chaotic" and strangled in red tape yesterday by the Medical Society of the State of New York.

WESTON, Ill., Feb. 15 (AP) The trustees of this hamlet, chosen by the Atomic Energy Commission as the site for a $375-million atom smasher, approved last night open-occupancy that covers real estate dealers but not owners.

Bill D. Moyers assumed his new job yesterday as publisher of the Long Island newspaper Newsday, and said he had no plans to run for pubic office in the state or play a direct role in Democratic politics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 The Republican National Chairman, Ray C. Bliss, urged the party's militant youth leaders today to give the 1968 Presidential nominee their full support even if they do not agree with him.
RICHARD VERBER of Chicago and William Martz of Hartland, Wis., topped 137 of the Midwest's best players to tie in a first-place deadheat in the recent North Central Open at Milwaukee.
NO one could argue with the appropriate ness of the mini-fashions shown yesterday at Gimbels. The designs were all for mini-girls, sizes 3 to 6x and 7 to 14.
Samuel Briskman of 880 Fifth Avenue, inventor of the pinking shears and president, since 1953, of the New York Cardiac Center in Yonkers, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Miami Beach.
AMSTERDAM, Feb. 15 A new political party with a widespread youth appeal made a strong showing in the Netherlands' general elections today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (UPI) A blizzard powered by wind gusts of hurricane force moved across the upper Middle West today, disrupting ground and air travel and forcing hundreds of schools to close.

ABOARD S.S. RAFFAEL LO AT SEA, Feb. 15 This giant Italian luxury liner, returning to New York after its first West Indies cruise, diverted from her course early this morning to take an injured seaman aboard from an Italian freighter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 Foundations identified by officers of the National Student Association as channels for money from the Central Intelligence Agency have also been helping to subsidize at least four other youth organizations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 In the first call-up of Reservists for the Vietnam war, the Pentagon intends to summon to active duty up to 31,100 Reservists who have not met their military obligations and 100 Reserve physicians who have not served in uniform at all.

Herbert L. Canty, a 32-yearold suspended patrolman who was convicted in the slaying of a Brooklyn physician, Dr. Milton Lopyan, was sentenced yesterday to life imprisonment by State Supreme Court Justice John R. Starkey.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 15 Commercial television's most sustained venture into education, the pre-midnight weather report, may have been successful with some people, but on the whole it seems only to have proved that the average man finds it hard to broaden his horizon of knowledge at 11:15 P.M. while holding beer in a darkened room.

The election of Lawrence S. Phillips, 39 years old, as president and chief operating officer of the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation was announced yesterday following a meeting of the company's board of directors.

Hart Island will become a major treatment center for narcotics addicts, under a program in which everyone on the island, apart from the professional staff, will either be, an addict or a former addict working with those under treatment.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 15 (AP)--Harry Gilmer, a former head coach of the Detroit Lions, was named an assistant coach today by the St. Louis Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--Differences are developing between the United States and some of its European allies over the safeguards to insure observance of the projected treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.
ATLANTA, Feb, 15 Agnes Scott College has touched off protests from within Atlanta's Jewish and academic communities by reiterating a long-time policy against hiring non-Christians for its faculty.
WASHINGTON Feb. 15 (AP) President Johnson approved today the appointment of Capt. Thomas B. Owen as Chief of Naval Research and nominated him for promotion ceed Rear Adm. John K. Leyden.
One of the city's few remaining eighteenth-century houses was among a number of landmark designations announced yesterday by Geoffrey Platt, chairman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission.
Maria Clodes, the Brazilian pianist who played at Carnegie Hall last night, has musical charm and a lyrical touch.
MOSCOW, Feb. 15 (AP) Izvestia denounced Bob Hope today as "a promoter of aggression" in Vietnam.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 15--United States diplomatic officials confirmed today a statement by an Army spokesman in Washington that the American armed forces rather than the Government of South Vietnam had legal authority over American civilians working here under military auspices.
BEVERLY HILLS, Feb. 15 (AP) Antonio Moreno, one of the suave stars of the silent screen, died at his home today. He had been under nursing care for more than two years. He was 78 years old.

MIAMI, Feb. 15 With the favorite enjoying an apparently insurmountable lead rounding into the stretch, Mac's Sparkler of the Hobeau Farm seemed about to became an also-ran in the $33,700 Columbiana Handicap at Hialeah today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15 Private philanthropy reached a record $13-billion in the United States last year, up a billion dollars over 1965, despite increased Government grants to private institutions.
ABOARD THE ENTERPRISE, off North Vietnam, Feb. 14 The world's largest fighting ship went back to war today, with her crew neither jubilant nor downcast.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 15 Roger Hilsman, a leading State Department official in the Kennedy Administration, asserted today that the United States neglected a real opportunity for peace negotiations in resuming the bombing of North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 President Johnson appealed to Congress today to enact the civil rights proposals that were talked to defeat in the Senate last year and thus to persevere in the drive for social justice for Negro Americans.
Don E. Carter, managing editor of The National Observer, has been appointed executive editor of The Record, a prosperous northern New Jersey afternoon newspaper.

A play was staged a few months ago by a group of Negro and Puerto Rican teenagers in the South Bronx, depicting life as it appears to pupils in the overcrowded schools in their area. It was called "The Cement Rainbow."
SAYBROOK, Conn., Feb. 15 (AP) J. Frank Duryea, who with his brother Charles designed the first successful gasoline-powered automobile built in the United States, died today. He was 97 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 Mrs. Parsons Wainwright of Washington and Stuyvesant Wainwright 2d of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Snowden Wainwright, to Charles Brandon Waring. He is the son of Mrs. Antonio J. Waring Jr. of Savannah, Ga., and the late Dr. Waring.

KATONAH, N.Y., Feb. 15 Mr. and Mrs. Henry Jessup Cochran Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Frew Cochran, to John B. Rusch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rusch of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb.15 Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara said today that the bombing of military targets in North Vietnam, resumed Monday after a pause of nearly six days, was achieving most of its objectives.
PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 15 (AP) Lunar Orbiter 3 televised new pictures from the moon today showing broad level areas pitted with small craters but probably safe for astronaut landings.

In a street-floor window at 260 Park Avenue South, at East 20th Street, a red marker moved back and forth, hard by the sign, "Air Pollution Can Affect Your Health." The readings it showed on a meter were 10, 15, 20, 25 parts per million carbon monoxide assaulting New Yorkers.
The appointment of John C. Franklin as vice president in charge of corporate development was announced here yesterday by the General Dynamics Corporation.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 15 (Reuters) Heavy rains brought floods to South Africa today for the second time this month.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 15 (AP) American Football League owners voted today to contribute $1.25-million to player pensions, putting its plan on a par with that of the National Football League and possibly speeding the merger of the two leagues.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 Mrs. Adam Clayton Powell flew here today from San Juan in response to a subpoena to testify tomorrow before a House select committee investigating her estranged husband's conduct.

In his message on civil rights President Johnson assumes that acceptance of nondiscriminatory practices in the sale and rental of housing is merely a question of time. It is probable that this assumption reflects a prudent judgment of Congress's currently hostile mood rather than an expression of optimism about the nation's eagerness for residential desegregation.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 (AP) Cecil Moore, president of the Philadelphia branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, was sentenced today to six days in jail for failing to pay a $300 fine imposed because he used foul language during a trial in Common Pleas Court.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 The chairman of one of the Assembly's key committees ordered a lobbyist out of his office today when, according to the Assemblyman, the lobbyist forcibly tried to walk off with privileged committee documents.

Record sales and earnings were achieved last year by four diversified chemical and drug producers, with the Allied Chemical Corporation and Merck Co., Inc., also setting highs for the fourth quarter, their reports disclosed yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 15--Representatives of 15 Western nations, including France, tentatively approved today a procedural plan for an ambitious study of the ways in which the Atlantic alliance could be modernized.

HARTFORD, Feb. 15 Gov. John N. Dempsey today proposed a record budget of $1.7-billion for the next two fiscal years and told the General Assembly that it could be balanced "without new or increased taxation."
The American Can Company disclosed yesterday that it would move its international headquarters to Greenwich, Conn., or to some other suburban area before 1970.
The drop in bond prices that has gripped the market since early February continued with increased intensity yesterday.
WASHTNGTON, Feb.15 (AP) The Johnson Administration told Congress today that it needed the interest equalization, tax to help improve an unfavorable balance of payments.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy and the State Democratic Chairman expressed doubt yesterday that Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal's advocacy of a liberalized abortion law was a factor in his replacement as chairman of a Democratic advisory committee. However, Mr. Blumenthal said he believed it was.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 The Justice Department charged today that there are "apparent inconsistencies" between what the International Telephone and Telegraph Company told the Government about its decision to acquire the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., and what is disclosed in the company's own internal documents.

QUEBEC, Feb. 15 (Canadian Press) The Alberta badminton team was beaten for the first time in the Canadian Winter Games today when the Manitoba women's doubles combination of Mrs. Connie Blamey and Judy Borland defeated Mrs. Kena Whitaker and Kay James, 15-10, 15-8. Alberta had won 35 matches.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15 (UPI) Rigid police security measures were ordered today for the marriage tomorrow of Gov. Claude Kirk of Florida and a Brazilian divorcee because of threats on the Governor's life.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15, (UPI) The Defense Department announced today that a United States missiletracking ship was being diverted from a planned stop at Durban, South Africa.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 15 (UPI) Premier Nguyen Cao Ky hinted today that he may be les interested in Peace negotiations with the Communists than his Government's official position would indicate.
DAVID GARNETT blandly sketches things that more excitable novelists attack in blithering rages. He satirizes the human comedy with imperturbable humor.
In spite of a sharp drop in residential building, the dollar value of construction in New York State in 1966 increased 2 per cent from the 1965 level to more than $2.6-billion.
The Metropolitan chapter of the Finlandia Foundation will hold its annual award dinner dance on Feb. 25 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 15 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Maurice Viertel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Susan Viertel, to Dennis Clark Krieger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Krieger of San Francisco.
ANY swingers who have yet to shop in an "electrodelic environment" should race right over to Best's Fifth Avenue while the fuses hold out.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 The Government returned nearly $10,000 in December to the wife of a key witness against John (Sonny) Franzese, although the witness, an admitted holdup man, had told the Federal Bureau of Investigation that the money was stolen from banks.

Joseph Bercovici, a retired journalist, died yesterday in Los Angeles at the home of a son, Leonardo. He was 87 years old and lived at the Capitol Hall Hotel, 166 West 87th Street. The late Konrad Bercovici, author and journalist, was his brother.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 PresidentJohnson directed three high officials in his Administra- tion today to formulate a policy that would prevent the Central Intelligence Agency or any other Government agency from en- dangering the integrity and independence of American educa- tional institutions.

THE experienced eyes that watched the 5 -year-old black Scottish terrier, Ch. Bardene Bingo, become best in show at the 9lst Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison ware Garden Tuesday might included those of two judges who spoke at-the Dog Fanciers Club luncheon
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 15--The Yale University Library added 177,000 volumes in the past year, to bring the collection above the 5-million mark. The total now is 5,013,491 books.

Mr. and Mrs. Halsted Billings Vander Poel of Rome have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Stuart Vander Poel, to Eric Richards Rippel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Alexander Rippel of Madison, N.J.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Feb. 15 A concerted effort to help revive the Power and popular esteem of state governments began here today. The job was described as chancey with uncertain prospects of success.

TEXARKANA, Tex., Thursday, Feb. 16 (AP) A 105-mm. artillery shell exploded on a loading line at the Army ammunition depot near here last night and a military spokesman said that eight to 10 men had been killed.
ALBANY, Feb. 15 The Legislature gave its unanimous approval today to bills that will save nearly 2 million New York City residents and commuters from the chore of filing city income tax returns.

Mrs. Hamilton Eaton of Northampton, Mass., and Joseph O. Eaton of Essex, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Hamilton Eaton, to William Edward Smart 3d. He is the son of Gen. Jacob E. Smart, U.S.A.F., retired, of Washington and Mrs. A.W. Melton of Ann Arbor, Mich.

Michael Rubin, 17-year-old Brooklyn pianist, winner last season of the first annual WQXR Young Artists Competition, started collecting his award this week appearances at the Young People's Concerts of the American Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall.

BONN, Feb. 15 A traveler returning from Asia to his own version of civilization in the West suffers a re-entry problem almost as tangible as the depredations that jet flight across a half-dozen time zones can work upon his appetite, sleeping habits and mental clarity.

The Pacific Northwest Bell Telephone Company announced yesterday that it would offer stockholders 3,466,866 shares of new common stock at $16.50. Holders will be entitled to buy one new share for each 10 held March 2. The American Telephone and Telegraph subsidiary will use the money for new construction.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 16 (UPI) The Hanoi radio reported today that the Vietcong had released two American prisoners of war on Feb. 7 as a lunar new year gesture of goodwill. American officials said, however, that they could not verify the report. They, appealed to the Communists for more information.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Feb. 16 The Soviet Communist party condemned the Peking leadership of Mao Tse-tung today and appealed for his overthrow and the return of China to the "Socialist community."

PARIS, Feb. 15 William C. Bullitt, the first United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union and envoy in France early in World War II, died of leukemia today at the American Hospital of suburban Neuilly. He was 76 years old.
Industrial issues closed mixed and Government bonds declined in a lackluster session yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 15 Barry Liebowitz led Long Island University to a 105-50 victory over Adelphi University here tonight.
YONKERS, Feb. 15 Forrest Gerry Jr. was granted today a temporary license, valid for 30 days, to own, train and drive standard-bred horses in the state.
CAMBRIDGE, England, Feb. 15 (Reuters) The young wits of Cambridge University have decided that the education of the 18-year-old heir to the throne, Prince Charles, is no laughing matter.

An early advance in the stock market faded under persistent profit-taking pressure yesterday.

In another move to revitalize the team, the last-place New York Giants dropped three assistant coaches yesterday and acquired one replacement, Harland Svare, as an aide to Al Sherman, the head coach. Deposed were Frank (Pop) Ivy, Harry Wright and Tom Scott. This brought to nine the number of assistants Sherman has acquired and lost in his six years as the boss.
HONG KONG, Feb. 15 (Reuters) The North Vietnam Foreign Ministry said tonight that Hanoi would never agree to any peace talks under American pressure.

Placement Service, 51 West Fourth Street, but canceled the recruiting session because too many students had signed up.
George Champion, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, attacked the Johnson Administration yesterday for its suspension last fall of tax incentives for business investment.
WASHINGTON, Feb.16 (AP)--A plea to soften President Johnson's proposals for tougher taxing of United States lending and investing abroad was made to the Congress today by the New York Stock Exchange.

The recent flight of several large corporation headquarters to the suburbs is no indication that the city is declining as the corporate capital of the nation, the city's acting Commissioner of Commerce declared yesterday.

The Tele-Med Corporation, which for three years has been offering recorded sponsored telephone-informational messages to physicians, is starting a new service. It's called the F.D.A. Hot Line.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 16 (UPI) Arnold Palmer returned to the pro golf tour with a flourish today, firing a six-under-par 66 to latch onto the first round lead in the 72-hole, $60,000 Tucson open.

Long Island University made known yesterday a 10-year, $138-million development plan that includes the establishment of a law school, a science and engineering complex, a graduate school of social work and a health sciences center.

Mayor Lindsay's appearance before the Legislature dramatically emphasized the hazardous financial plight that continues to grip the city.
The number of mortgage loans in delinquency rose slightly in the quarter ended Dec. 31, a survey by the Mortgage Bankers Association of America has shown.
Jersey City's four public high schools, with a total enrollment of 9,800 were closed again yesterday because 316 of the 458 teachers staged a boycott.
Trading was subdued and prices steady yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
Winners of the 1966 Margo Jones Awards, given to professional producers who do the most to stimulate production of new plays, are Harlan P. Kleiman, Jon Jory and Arthur Ballet.
The New York Stock Exchange confirmed yesterday previous reports that it was planning to enlarge its trading floor by extending it into the adjoining building at 20 Broad Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (UPI)--Mayfield Country Club of Shaker Heights, Ohio, scored the most points and the most decisive victory in early events in the second day of the United States Women's Curling Association bonspiel today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 16 (UPI) Lew Hoad, an Australian professional tennis star, said today he intended to retire from competitive play within two months and settle in the quiet Spanish fishing township of Feungirola.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 16 George Meany announced today that the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations would sponsor rallies in at least 16 major cities to mobilize support for President Johnson's proposal to increase Social Security benefits.

Miss June Ellen Crystal has become engaged to Richard G. Kolombatovich and Miss Sally Jane Nygren to his brother, Specialist 4 George E. Kolombatovich of the Army. The future bridegrooms are the sons of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar F. Kolombatovich of Huntington. L.I.
Oh, the rewards of trying harder! Avis on Monday will announce that it has moved from No. 2 to No.1 in the race against Hertz. And 26 airports, where the research took place, can't be wrong.
Executives of the National Biscuit Company and the Colgate-Palmolive Company have agreed in principle to merge the two companies.
ALBANY, Feb, 16 The Rockefeller administration proposed today that compulsory automobile insurance coverage be more than doubled.
As cold winds whipped the promenade deck of the S.S. Nieuw Amsterdam yesterday, Doug Ford demonstrated how to play golf aboard ship.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 102 on Wednesday from 102.1 on Tuesday.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 16 Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia, the president-designate of the forthcoming state Constitutional Convention, rejected today suggestions that the convention draft a two-part constitution.
Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia stressed yesterday his willingness to take the iniatiative in seeking peace in Vietnam if any of the countries concerned requested that he do so.

MIAMI, Feb. 16 Kar-Stan, a Florida-bred owned by Stanley Hubbard, Minneapolis television executive, gave a splendid account of himself in the feature race at Hialeah today. Competing against 10 others over the distance of l 1/8 miles, KarStan clicked off the excellent time figure of 1:48 4-5 in winning by a smashing nine lengths.
The Civil War ironclad whose sinking is said to have inspired Rear Adm. David G. Farragut to heroic utterance has been found buried in mud and silt at the bottom of the mouth of Mobile Bay.

New York's present noise code, like that of many other American cities, relies on such undefined terms as "loud," "excessive" and "unreasonable" terms so vague that convictions for violating them are rare.

Time, Inc., the world's largest publishing company, had the best year in its 44-year history in 1966, with record revenues and earnings for the seventh consecutive year. The annual report yesterday of James A. Linen, president, and Andrew Heiskell, chairman, said gains were 11 per cent for both profits and revenues over 1965.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 When Yvette Marjorie Diago Flores met Adam Clayton Powell Jr. she was a 27-year-old divorcee working in the front office of a San Juan, P.R., hotel. That was in 1958.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 The 20-story Mark Hopkins Hotel, with its world famous cocktail lounge, Top of the Mark, passed into the operating hands of Loew's Theaters, Inc., in an agreement reached tonight.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 16 The long-sought goal of political union in East Africa is a lost cause, the Government of Kenya indicated today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 President Johnson recommended to Congress today a package of new and revised measures that would give greater protection to shoppers, investors and medical patients and would help guard against fires, electric power failures and natural gas pipeline accidents.

HONG KONG, Feb.18 Opponents of Mao Tse-tung's Cultural Revolution evidently have not found it feasible to attack the Chinese Communist party's chairman openly or have not felt that it is good tactics to do so.
Corporate profits this year are expected to continue higher than they were in 1966 but at a slower rate of growth, according to results of a survey made by McGrawHill, Inc., trade publishers.
Miss Cecile Van den Daele and Axel Tourmente of New York, son of Mrs. Daniel Tourmente of Paris and the late Dr. Tourmente, plan to be married in the spring.

New York State's neighbors, Connecticut and New Jersey both among the few states that levy no personal income taxes are taking record-breaking budgets in stride, with no need at present for new or increased taxes.

ROWS, Mass., Feb. 18 Yuzuru Motoda, a survivor of the Hiroshima atomic bomb, drove up today in a rented car to the gates of the Yankee atomic power plant, seeking to determine if plutonium was being produced for atomic weapons.

With Patricia Brooks the victim of a cold, the New York City Opera had a new Violetta at last night's New York State Theater performance of "La Traviata": Nadja Witkowska, a leading soprano with the company since her debut in 1955.
The men who head the National Biscuit Company and the Colgate-Palmolive Company are both "small-town boys," but their careers in finance have been anything but "small town."
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has regained from the General Motors Corporation the title of top corporate money maker.

LONDON, Feb. 16 The Nazi intelligence branch penetrated the direct radio line between Churchill and Roosevelt by finding the key of the Allied transAtlantic telephone scrambling system, according to David Irving, a specialist on wartime Germany who is writing a book on Hitler.

WINCHESTER, Mass., Feb. 16 (AP) Cecelia Martinez, a 19-year-old college girl from San Francisco, defeated a former champion, Mary Ann Eisel of St. Louis, 6-2, 8-6, today in the only upset of the opening day of the National Women's Indoor tennis championships.
PEKING, Feb. 16 A Red Guard newspaper reports that authorities in Szechwan Province are using the Chinese Army and peasants to harass, beat up, imprison and suppress Maoists.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 A key House committee chairman whose support is crucial to President Johnson's civil rights bill announced today that he planned to delay its consideration until later this year. The delay could diminish the controversial bill's already shaky prospects.

The film version of James Joyce's "Ulysses" was passed uncut through United States Customs here Wednesday after no more than 15 minutes of discussion among Customs officials and representatives of the United States District Attorney's office.

JERUSALEM (Israel), Feb. 16 The faltering Israeli-Syrian border talks appeared today to have broken down as a result of an indefinite postponement of the scheduled fourth meeting since the talks began Jan. 25.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI)--President Johnson was given a routine heart examination today and was reported "doing just fine."

Patty Duke and Barbara Parkins have been signed for featured roles in 20th CenturyFox's film version of "Valley of the Dolls," the long-term best-selling novel by Jacqueline Susann about the romantic and business trials of show-business personalities.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 16 (UPI) The retired California Angel outfielder, Albie Pearson, scored 72 for 145 on the Dunes Country Club course today for a two-stroke lead in the national championship of the Professional Athletes Golf Association.

PARIS At the height of their power the Mongol-Turkic tribes called Tatars overran much of Europe and Asia, including Russia and China. One medieval chronicler wrote: "The rattling of their chariots and the clashing of their, horses' hoofs were like thunder and lightning. With their wrath in full flame, they advanced."

PLEASANTYILLE, N.Y., Feb. 16 The marriage of Mrs. Diane Nolan, daughter of Mrs. E. William Nolan and the late Mr. Nolan, to Walter Jason Hunt, took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Hunt of St. Paul.

MEMPHIS, Feb. 16 (AP) Vance Jackson Alexander, honorary chairman of the board of the Union Planters National Banlk and a former member of the Federal Reserve Board, died in a hospital here yesterday. He was 80 years old.
LONDON, Feb. 16 (Reuters) Nearly 85 years after his death, Karl Marx, founder of Communism, has started a dispute here between two local governing bodies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Following is the text of the message President Johnson sent to Congress today On Consumer protection:

ITHACA, Feb. 16 The National Student Conference on Vietnam, advertised by its sponsors as the first attempt at sober, unemotional campus dialogue on Southeast Asian policy, was under attack today as a tool of antiwar "Vietniks."
Fourteen corporations employing a total of about 11,500 persons are considering moving their headquarters from New York City, an expert in finding new sites for business concerns disclosed yesterday.
Charles Herbert (Red) Ruffing, who acknowledged that he had become "a little bitter" at not being elected to the Baseber Hall of Fame in recent years, mellowed somewhat yesterday.
DAVIDSON, N.C., Feb. 16 (UPI) A freshman basketball player, Mike Maloy, has become a pledgee of Sigma Chi the first Negro to break into Davidson College's all-white fraternity system.

SIMSBURY, Conn., Feb. 16--Edgerton Grant North, chief appraiser of the Williamsburgh Savings Bank, 1 Hanson Place, Brooklyn, from 1946 until 1965, died yesterday at Hartford Hospital. He was 66 years old and had lived here at 85 East Weatogue Street since his retirement.
A special Liberal party committee will submit a recommendation today that the party refuse contributions of more money than one-tenth its budget from any single individual or organization.

The engagement of Miss Isabel Catherine Kauffmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Desire Kauffmann of New York, to Philip Carter Carling Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carling of Fair Haven, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents.
A common diagnosis lies behind two prescriptions unveiled in the last few days for curing some of the major ailments of New York's municipal hospitals.
MADRID, Feb. 16 Hundreds of students demonstrated in Barcelona today in a prelude to a major demonstration against the Spanish Government that students and workers plan to stage tomorrow evening.
Regular helicopter service will begin March 1 between Teterboro Airport in Bergen County, N.J., the Pan Am Building and Kennedy International Airport, New York Airways announced yesterday.
Word of possible drought in the Southwest winter wheat areas inspired a run-up in wheat futures prices yesterday.

The slumping New York Rangers, who have lost three and tied one in their last four games, brought up a right wing, Ken Schinkel, from the Baltimore Clippers, their American Hockey League affiliate, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) Attorneys for James R. Hoffa said today eavesdropping by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on a close associate of the Teamsters union president helped confirm their charges of widespread bugging during Hoffa's jury tampering trial in 1964.

Gladys Rockmore Davis, a painter, died yesterday in the French Hospital after a short illness. She was 65 years old and lived at 1 West 67th Street. Her husband, Floyd M. Davis, painter and magazine illustrator, died in October.

MONTREAL, Feb. 16 (AP) Seven union representing 55,000 nonoperating railroad employes announced today the ratification of an agreement providing a wage increase of 24 per cent in a period of three years.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Feb. 16 A survey of the two high schools in this upper middleclass North Shore community showed today that 8 per cent of the student body had used marijuana. The enrollment of the schools is about 2,800.

Many past and current leaders of the National Student Association feel that the group's attempts in the last two years to end its ties with the Central Intelligence Agency reflect the changing nature of the American student community and the history of the association.
City Council President Frank D. O'Connor charged last night that neither Governor Rockefeller nor Mayor Lindsay had lived up to the promises they made in their last campaigns.
William H. Booth, chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights, denied yesterday that he had been lax in failing to protect the rights of minority groups other than Negroes.

The New York City portion of the Port of New York was described yesterday in a report as desperately needing an agency that would deal specifically with the "new age of world trade" and competition of other ports.
HAVE you ever noticed when you leave a Broad- way theater there are always those people who refuse to rush out like the rest of us lemmings, and just sit there?

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 16 Mr. and Mrs. Dudley H. Dommerich have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Anne Dommerich, to Gary Allen Host of the Navy. He is the son of John Loren Host Jr. of Los Alamitos, Calif., and Mrs. Ellen Corn of Campbell, Calif.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Intercity truck tonnage and revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the week ended Feb. 11 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of 1966. Severe weather in the latest week and a strong upturn in traffic during the comparable 1966 week, following a week of Snowstorms, were major reasons for the declines in Year-to-year volume.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Discovery of an obscure Government employe retirement law has suddenly given President Johnson the opportunity to remake the Federal Reserve Board with a majority of his own appointees within the next 10 weeks.

TOKYO, Feb. 15 Japan has acquired most of the trappings of a television culture except frozen TV dinners. Recently even some of those, imported from the United States, went on sales in a Tokyo supermarket but attracted-few customers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 When President Johnson was told that the Central Intelligence Agency's secret fund for university students was about to be exposed, he asked when the fund started (1952), and he wanted assurance that the fund had stopped.
Robert Schlageter has been elected president of the 34th Street-Midtown Association, Inc. Mr. Schlageter is second vice-president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

Britain's drive for Common Market membership appears to have been slowed down just when it was expected to pick up speed. Prime Minister Wilson has now completed exploratory visits to the three most important Community capitals, and his prospects seem as dim as when he started perhaps dimmer.
AS far as one prejudiced fan is concerned, the two most delightful woodland sounds are those of loons and wolves.

William Schuman, president of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, will receive the 1967 Concert Artists Guild Award at the guild's annual benefit dinner concert in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom on March 12. The award is for "his distinguished achievements in the development of our musical culture and sponsorship of talented young artists."
LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP)--The World Council of Churches called today for a cessation of the bombing of North Vietnam as a means of breaking the current impasse and leading to meaningful negotiation.
Mrs. Ethel Parker Riddick, a city tax assessor, died Wednesday in the Wyckoff Heights Hospital. She was 61 years old and lived at 115-40 174th Street in St. Albans, Queens.
The spot rate on the British pound rose 2 points at the close to $2.7946 after moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. Currency for Monday was quoted at $2.7940.
PARIS, Feb. 16 Spring arrived today at the Big A on the right bank just as the form sheets had promised.
CHAMROUSSE, France, Feb. 16 (UPI) The West German, Austrian and Swiss ski teams walked out on the Olympic trials today because of their cramped living quarters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 President Johnson's request to the Congress today for "careful consideration" of proposals to reduce the charges imposed on purchasers of mutual fund shares appeared to guarantee that the Congress would at least begin to study the controversial legislation this year.
Beckman Instruments, Inc., won over the Automatic Sprinkler Corporation of America in their contest to acquire Interstate Engineering Corporation of Anaheim, Calif.
LONDON, Feb.16 The American musical "Fiddler on the Roof" opened at Her Majesty's Theater tonight to critical acclaim.

Turning boos to cheers by suddenly coming to life with a 13-0 rally in the closing moments, the New York Knickerbockers clung to their twogame hold on third place in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division last night by beating the St. Louis Hawks, 121-120.

A Scandinavian Airlines jet yesterday flew in the first group of European tourists to visit the United States under new, low North Atlantic fares set in December by the International Air Transport Association.

THE first marriage of the attractive Long Island housewife had ended in divorce. Now, she was discussing the problems she had encountered in her second marriage to a divorced man with a 17-year-old son. "I just can't love the boy," she said, her voice breaking in midsentence. "He's so terribly hostile.

ARCADIA, Calif. Feb. 16 (UPI)--Bill Shoemaker escaped serious injury today when Duncan Junction, his mount in the fourth race, stumbled at the finish and threw the jockey over his head at Santa Anita.

Bond prices stopped going down yesterday, cushioned by the reduction in West Germany's central bank rate.
WASHINGTON, Feb.16 (AP) Pentagon sources said today most of the up to 25,000 Army reservists expected to be called to active duty this year would come from control groups.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 16 (AP) Two free throws by a reserve guard, Charlie Provini, provided the margin today as Navy scored a 66-65 basketball's victory over Maryland. It was only the third time the sophomore had seen action this season.
Paul E. Bragdon, executive assistant to Council President Frank D. O'Connor, will resign next month to take the newly created post of director of governmental relations at New York University.

BONN, Feb. 16 Three weeks ago in Strasbourg, when he spoke in glowing terms about Britain's place in Europe, Prime Minister Wilson called for a largeness of spirit on everyone's part as he explored the possibilities of British membership in the Common Market.

Negotiable certificates of deposit outstanding against major New York banks declined in the week ended Wednesday for the first time since Dec. 21, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

SEOUL, South Korea, Friday Feb. 17 (UPI) Eight South Koreans civilians were killed and two others wounded yesterday when they were hit by artillery fire on a practice range manned by American and South Korean troops, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) Sixteen members of the Roman Cathoiic hierarchy in the United States asked the Supreme Court today to strike down state laws that prohibit racial intermarriage.
