HONOLULU, Feb. 16 Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to expand air routes in the Pacific. He made the request at the opening session of the transPacific air route hearings at the Ilikai Hotel.
For a guy who's 6 feet 1 inch tall, Mal Graham can jump pretty high. But he had never jumped as high before as he did the past week in the nation's major college basketball scoring race.
A sudden 24-hour strike of the 700 crew members of the Italian luxury liner Michelangelo yesterday left more than 1,100 cruise passengers with bed but without board until 4 P.M. today.

The Cleveland Orchestra, playing at Carnegie Hall last night in the International Festival of Visiting Orchestras, listed three items. The first two promised to be of special interest the New York premiere of Benjamin Lees's Concerto for String Quartet and Orchestra and Geza Anda's appearance as soloist in Bartok's Piano Concerto ...
Winds full of fury brought deaths, injuries and destruction to the Northeastern states yesterday in a wild prelude to a cold spell.

Council President O'Connor and Mr. Ross, in asserting they wanted to measure the impact of any proposed new tax before supporting it, questioned whether the new liquor tax might not produce a round of bootlegging such as the city has suffered on cigarette sales from outside the state.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 16 (UPI) The Rev. Walter Riess, a Lutheran minister, and Edward Meiners, a Roman Catholic layman, said yesterday that they had asked the Vatican to lift the excommunication placed on Martin Luther.
YONKERS, Feb.16 A 5-yearold pacer perished today at Yonkers Raceway as a result of a freakish accident that occurred while the mare was training over the main track.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 The Republican party has never held a Presidential nominating convention in New York City, and it is not going to break precedent in 1968.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 16 (UPI) Joe Campanella, general manager and vice president of the Baltimore Colts, collapsed and died, apparently of a heart attack, after playing handball yesterday with Don Shula, the football team's coach. He was 36 years old.

DETROIT, Feb. 16 (AP) Phil Esposito's two goals helped Chicago build up a 3-0 lead and the high-flying Black Hawks went on to a 5-1 National Hockey League victory over the slumping Detroit Red Wings tonight.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 Mayor Lindsay urged the Legislature today to provide new sources of revenue, including a 90-cent increase in the tax on every fifth of liquor, to save him from having to run New York City with "piano wire and Scotch tape."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) --Maurice J. Williams, now chief of the United States foreign aid mission in Pakistan, will be nominated to be assistant administrator of the Agency for International Development, the White House announced today.

The Metropolitan Opera's final performance of Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" will be nonsubscription, on Saturday, March 25. In the Met production for the first time will be Francisco Molinari-Pradelli, conductor, George Shirley, tenor, and Shirley Love, soprano.
For six hours yesterday the 1,380 crewmen of the Italian liners Michelangelo and Raffaello were out on strike at the same time as they held separate 24-hour work stoppages.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 17 (UPI) --A three-inch snowfall caused Bowie officials to cancel racing today but the track was ready by midafternoon to reopen tomorrow with the second running of the $25,000 added Native Dancer Handicap as the feature of the program.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17-- Former Senator Barry Goldwater accused President Johnson tonight of creating a "sanity gap" in Vietnam.

COMPREHENSIVE exhibition of the art of Paul Klee (1879-1940), the Swiss artist who was one of the key figures in the history of modern painting, went on view this week at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue at 88th Street. Organized by Thomas M. Messer, the director of the Guggenheim, the exhibition consists of nearly 200 works embracing, the entire course of the artist's development.

WINNIPEG, Man., Feb. 17 (Canadian Press)--Sinclair M. Stevens resigned today as chairman of the Bank of Western Canada and announced that his financial interests were prepared to surrender majority control of the new bank.
MADRID, Feb. 17--A massive display of police power tonight prevented antiregime demonstrations by workers and Students in Barcelona.
A new monthly newspaper supplement devoted wholly to small suburban communities across the country has failed, the victim of advertising competition in the big city.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 17--A 32-year-old former cub reporter was introduced at a luncheon here today as the new publisher of Newsday.
Northwest Airlines reported yesterday a 1966 net profit of 53,135,922, or $5.81 a share, compared with $45,694,024, or $4.99 a share, in 1965.

LONDON, Feb. 17--A measure to provide birth-control information and devices unconditionally to any woman, married or unmarried, who wants them received an unopposed second reading in the House of Commons today. This virtually assured final passage of the bill, which was cheered by the members.

Hearings have been held these last weeks about the proposed liberalization of the New York State Abortion Law in the form of a bill proposed by Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal. The following questions may not be asked, certainly not in this form; yet they go to the heart of the final decision.

Fifteen young women, all descendants of men who served in the American Revolution, made their formal bow to society last night at the Colonial Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. More than 600 guests attended the 32d annual event sponsored by the New York Chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution and the Daughters of the American Revolution in the metropolitan area.
IT is not uncommon for the homes of personalities of the theater, arts, letters or public life to look like an assemblage of trophy rooms, for celebrities are natural collectors of memorabilia.

YONKERS, Feb. 17--From Perth, West Australia, came word today that Eddie Cobb, the well-known American horseman who fared so well with Adios Butler when that champion ruled the pacing world some years back, may drive Robin Dundee, the great Down Under mare, in the $100,000 International pace at Yonkers Raceway on June 1.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 17 --A farm economist told farmers today that their prices and income had climbed too high in the last two years to promote agricultural stability.
A proposal to form a new committee on the Church and Economic Life of the National Council of Churches has been protested by a group of liberal laymen and labor leaders.

An expert on India's food problems warned yesterday that unless Congress quickly approved a $25-million emergency food request from New Delhi, "sufferers from the drought will be numerous and deaths may be expected" in Bihar and Uttar states.

Surrogate Samuel S. Silverman, the Reform Democrat who defeated Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein for the Manhattan post last year in the election, has fulfilled a campaign promise to publicize persons he names as guardians.
COLOGNE, Germany, Feb. 17 (AP)--Josef Cardinal Frings patched up his differences with the Jewish community here today and agreed to give a lecture during Brotherhood Week.
The police used tear gas last night to flush a gunman from the southeast Bronx apartment house where he reportedly wounded two young people with, the shotgun he later turned on the police.
SYOSSET, L.I., Feb. 17-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy told a high school audience here today that "there are obvious changes that have to be made" in the state's abortion law.
WALPOLE, Mass., Feb. 17-- Adolph Maffie, serving a life sentence as a member of the Brink's gang, steadfastly maintained today that he did not take part in the $1,219,000 robbery of 1950.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP)--An Air Force review board reports that improper pre-landing procedures led to the crash of an F-111 fighter near Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., last month.
Dr. Max L. Hammerschlag, a gynecologist and obstetrician at 1020 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, died Thursday in his home at 535 East 86th Street. His age was 54.
DETROIT, Feb. 17 (UPI)--A probate judge said today that a second, unsigned will takes precedence over one handwritten in 1949 by Jack Ruby, killer of Lee Harvey Oswald, assassin of President Kennedy.

The key role played by the American Broadcasting Company as a conveyor of news and opinion to millions of homes makes it desirable that the Federal Communications Commission remove any doubt about the soundness of its decision to approve the company's acquisition by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
DOWNERS GROVE, Ill., Feb. 17 (AP)--Mrs. Lottie Holman O'Neill, the first woman to serve in the Illinois Legislature, died today in her home at the age of 88.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 17 (UPI)--A four-day rescue operation ended today as a wet, mud-caked German Shepherd puppy was pulled from a 28foot well shaft.
CANTON, N.Y., Feb. 17.-- Dave Erickson, a forward, and Rick Smith, a center, each scored three goals tonight as St. Lawrence scored a 12-4 hockey victory Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 17 (Reuters)--Twenty-one persons were killed and nine were injured when an Indonesian airliner exploded yesterday seconds after landing at Menado Airport in Celebes, the Garuda State Airline announced today.
TOKYO, Feb. 17--The Japanese police are moving from judo to karate for the subduing of criminal suspects who resist arrest.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, Feb. 17 --Mr. and Mrs. Clemens Alva Werner have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Stafford Werner, to A. Robert Thoresen, son of Mr. and Mrs. A.M. Thoresen of Claremont, N.H.

City and state housing officials opposed yesterday any across-the-board rent cuts for tenants in public aided middleincome housing developments, where rents have increased by almost 50 per cent in the last five years.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 17--A spring visit to the United States by Premier Nguyen Cao Ky is being discussed by South Vietnamese and American officials.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association assailed yesterday several of the rules proposed to govern the trial of Richard Speck in Peoria, Ill., charging they "are unwarranted and would seriously interfere" with the press.
The Columbia Gas System, reported yesterday new highs in total revenues and net income for 1966.

Technically speaking, there were no novelties on last night's Carnegie Recital Hall program by the American Brass Quintet. But the works they played-- both old and new--are heard so seldom that the entire program could be regarded as an innovation.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 17--Michael A. Stavitsky, a, leader in Jewish philanthropic and civic work, died today at the Westchester division of New York Hospital in White Plains. He was 72 years old and lived at 320 South Harrison Street here.
The London Stock Exchange declined on a broad front yesterday as traders sized up bearishly the prospects for next year's budget.
TOKYO, Feb. 17--Eisaku Sato, leader of the pro-American wing in the Japanese Parliament, formally took charge of the Government today for four more years.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17--The American Ballet Theater's new production of "Swan Lake," given at the Opera House here last night, will enter the record books as one of the significant events in the history of American ballet. It was, after all, the first production by a professional American company of the 1895 classic version of Tchaikovsky's "Swan Lake," choreographed by Lev Ivanov and Marius Petipa. But, even more, it was notably successful.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Feb. 17--The Congo copper crisis was resolved today with an agreement of technical cooperation between Generale Congolaise des Minerais, the new Congo state-owned company that replaced Union Miniere du HautKatanga, and Societe Generale des Minerais, a Union Miniere associate.

KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Feb. 17--Robert Dodge Merrill, former vice president of the American Cable Radio Corporation, died Tuesday of a heart attack at his home. He was 62 years old and had lived here since retiring in 1963.

Only six out of 959 children attended classes at Public School 122 yesterday as parents from the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn continued a boycott for a new building for the school at 68 Harrison Avenue.
HONG KONG, Feb. 17--Reports from Communist China indicated today that the opposition was slowing Mao Tsetung's drive to install a more rigorous system and leadership.

ROME, Feb. 17 (UPI)--And Italian court that is trying 32 men accused as members of an international heroin smuggling conspiracy decided Friday to ask for permission to hold hearings in the United States and France.
THE auction of the Nicholas dinner service at Chris tie's March 21 provides a rare opportunity to acquire fine examples of Russian porcelain, which is otherwise almost unavailable here.
LIMA, Peru, Feb. 17 (Reuters)--Ciro Alegria, a leading South American writer who played a role in Peruvian politics, died of a heart attack today at his home here. He was 70 years old.
UNION, N.J., Feb. 17--Jack Bardy of 2380 Morris Avenue, president of Bardy Farms for 45 years died yesterday at his winter home in North Miami, Fla., after a short illness. His age was 70.

LONDON, Feb. 17--Prime Minister Smith's ideas for separate development of the races broadly along the lines of South Africa's Bantustans were seen here by persons who have recently been in Rhodesia as a first step toward apartheid, the separation of the races.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 17-- Former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama stepped up his unofficial campaign for the Presidency tonight with sharp attacks on a half-dozen Democratic and Republican national leaders.

Seven civilian employes of the Fire Department were dismissed by Commissioner Robert O. Lowery, yesterday for refusing to waive immunity in a grand jury inquiry into payoffs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP)--The Agriculture Department authorized Yugoslavia today to purchase $9,625,000 worth of cottonseed and soybean oil.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb.17--The United States indicated today that it would not make large, long-term financial commitments in support of Latin American economic integration without the approval of Congress.

DETROIT, Feb. 17 (UPI)-- Auto production for 1967 pushed past a million Thursday, eight days behind the 1966 pace, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

"I would say it is a moral duty to confront the audience with its own times," said Rolf Liebermann, the director of the Hamburg Opera, yesterday. Mr. Liebermann is in New York for a week to prepare for the German company's run at the Lincoln Center Festival 67 from June 23 to July 2.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 17 (AP) --The Justice Department announced today the settlement of four antitrust suits whereby four producers of glass fiber industrial products would pay the Government $737,500 damages for alleged price fixing.

Celedonio Romero and his three sons, Celin, Pepe and Angel, played their four guitars in Carnegie Hall last night. Those in the know about guitars and the Romeros will not be surprised to learn that the concert was of high quality from the start to finish.

The arbitration board attempting to settle the power struggle in track and field ordered the warring sides yesterday to end their latest flareup immediately. It told them exactly how to do it. One side refused, so the suspensions of all foreign athletes continued.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The American Newspaper Guild has received nearly $1-million in foundation grants since 1960 to help finance its South American and other overseas activities. The Rev. Dr. Harry Milton Shuman, president of the Christian and Missionary Alliance from 1925 until his retirement in 1954, died yesterday at a hospital in DeLand, Fla. He was 88 years old.

Chairman Fulbright of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has taken to the warpath even before the 1968 foreign-aid bill has started its hazardous journey through Congress. The hour-long color documentary, "Florence: Days of Destruction," has been made available on a free-loan basis for public and private use through Association Films, Inc., at 600 Madison Avenue.

CAPETOWN, Feb. 17-Prime Minister Balthazar J. Vorster expressed regret tonight that the United States had declined South African hospitality for the crews of two warships. PARIS, Feb. 17--The Chinese Ambassador to France, Wang Chen, is to leave soon for a brief visit in Peking, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17-- President Johnson expressed "high" hopes today for agreement on a treaty to bar the spread of nuclear weapons. But he cautioned that the United States and the Soviet Union were being drawn into another "futile escalation" of the atomic arms race.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 17 (AP) --Wally Jones scored 4 points in five seconds in a fourth-quarter rally that carried the Philadelphia 76ers to a 127-118 National Basketball Association victory over the Cincinnati Royals tonight before 11,036 fans. Stocks finished with more declines than advances in relatively slow trading; volume, 8.53 million shares.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 18 (Reuters) The Bermuda Sailboat Club plans to co-sponsor the first official multi-hull yacht race from the United States to Bermuda in June with the Multi-Hull Association of the United States, officials announced today.

Life in the Tombs was pictured last week by three witnesses as so brutally overcrowded, miserable and despairing that some defendants awaiting trial plead guilty to win release to prison and a few, in desperation, commit suicide.
HYDE-PARK, N. Y., Feb. 18 (A.P) Three frame building, one seven-stories tall, stretching for half a block in the center of town, were leveled by fire early today.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 18 The opening of the 14th annual Jersey Coast Boat Show today was in sharp contrast, as far as weather was concerned, to the yachtman's dream of a warming sun and relatively serene waters. The show's home at Convention Hall, which juts 300 feet into the Atlantic, was battered by angry winter waves and lashed by snow-filled winds.

UNTIL he walked by an open window of the St. Regis Hotel by years ago, John Noosel had planned to study for the priesthood. One look in the window, though, and he became devoted to a career at the luxury hotel.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 18 (UPI) Bill Hickey and his Lake Placid Club team zoomed down the Mount van Hoevenberg one-mile ice chute in the four-heat time of 4 minutes 37.94 seconds today to capture the four man National Amateur Athletic Union championship. The event was a trial for next year's Olympic squad.
Mr. and Mrs. James A. Wechs- ler of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Holly Carol Wechsler, to David Alan Karpf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour S. Karpf also of New York.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 18 Army's ability to convert several critical one-and-one foul situations in the closing minutes of the second half tonight carried the cadets to a 68-55 victory over N.Y.U. The victory was the 12th in 20 games for Army.

MADRID, Feb. 18 As riotpolice squads stood guard this week in the streets of Barcelona and Madrid to prevent antiGovernment demonstrations, a parliamentary commission here drafted amendments to the Spanish penal code providing for stiff penalties for political offenses.

MIAMI, Feb. 18 George D. Widener has been in racing virtually all his life, but the 77year-old sportsman said he could hardly remember a greater thrill in thoroughbred racing than the one he experienced today.

CLEWISTON, Fla. Each year, starting in No vember and continuing through March, the air Florida's Lake Okeechobee is redolent with the tang of smoke and the sweet-green smell of sugar. PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 (AP) Cecil B. Moore, head of the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, announced today the formation of an all-Negro political party.

FREDERICKBURG, Va. On the Rappahan nock River here in Fredericksburg is an early ferry site that perhaps has been the scene of as much history as any place in the United States. For a century or more, a bridge spanning the river displaced the ferry, but now there will be water transportation again.
Two footnotes to the history of the New York Knickerbockers, one pleasant and the other perhaps tragic, were furnished last night at Madison Spuare Garden.

This week brings winter's last full moon, which in the old days was sometimes called the Snow Full Moon, sometimes the Hunger Moon. WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Following is the text of a statement issued today by officers of the American Newspaper Guild concerning allegations that Central Intelligence Agency funds helped to finance the guild's activities overseas:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 A wide spectrum of youth, student, academic, research, journalist, business, legal and labor organizations here and abroad have been receiving millions of dollars since the nineteen fifties from foundations identified as conduits of Central Intelligence Agency funds or with agency-connected sources of income.

SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, Feb. 18 Mr. and Mrs. Jack Oettinger have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Dina Oettinger, to John Alan Baeder, son of Julius Baeder and the late Mrs. Baeder of Atlanta.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Miss Ellen Montgomery Lishman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Lishman, was married today to Cpl. George Andrew Robertson, R.A.F. He is the son of Dr. George H. Robertson of Johannesburg, South Africa, and Mrs. Nesta Robertson of St. Andrews, Scotland.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) The President's Crime Commission acknowledged today the crucial importance of newspaper, television and radio reporting to the administration of justice. counsel.

MARGUERITE DURAS is un doubtedly one of the most forceful and interesting novelists to emerge from the nonvelle vague, and this novel, her fifth to be translated and published in the United States, will strengthen her reputation here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AF) A 39-year-old New Jersey machinist was selected today as the 25th million person to have cast a ballot in bargaining elections conducted since 1935 by the National Labor Relations Board.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Feb. 18 Mr. and Mrs. Nathan R. Fine have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gail Leslie Fine, to Frederic Stanlee Gnesin, son of Mrs. Isaac Gnesin of New York and the late Mr. Gnesin.
The appointments of seven new assistant vice presidents for States Marine-Isthmian Agency, Inc. have been announced by A.J. Theis, president.
LISBON, Feb. 18 Portugal is engaged in a cold war with Sweden because of a play by Peter Weiss based on the nationalist uprising in Portuguese Angola.

SANIBEL AND CAPTIVA ISLANDS, Fla. The big event of the year on these two Gulf Coast is lands is the Sanibel-Captiva Shell Fair, an annual show that attracts casual shell gatherers and serious conchologists from all parts of the country. It will be held March 2-4 at the Community House on Sanibel Island, where it was presented first in 1938.
Construction of what will be one of the largest hotels in Latin America, a 24-story beachfront resort, has started on the Bay of Acapulco.
FORT WORTH, Feb. 18 (AP) Charles Beasley's clutch free throws broke a tie in the final seconds today and gave Southern Methodist an 85-83 Southwest Conference basketball victom over Texas Christian.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 18 Mrs. John H. Fulweller and Preston Lea Spruance have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice LEA Spruance, to Richmond dePeyster Talbot Jr. of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Talbot of Front Royal, Va.

North Carolina's industrial development program recorded its largest calendaryear growth ever for new and expanded facilities in 1966. It broke the $500-million mark for the first time since tabulation began in 1937.
An apartment building on a tiny plot but with a high premium for a spacious view of Central Park is nearing completion on Fifth Avenue between 85th and 86th Streets.

The American Newspaper Guild, in statements here and in Washington, denied yesterday that it had knowingly accepted $1,004,000 in grants from foundations that were conduits for Central Intelligence Agency funds.

BONN, Feb. 18 (Reuters) Willy Brandt, West Germany's Foreign Minister, said today that the United States had assured him that the projected treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons would not discriminate against development of the atom for peaceful purposes.

WILTON, Conn., Feb. 18 Mr. and Mrs. J. Stanley Parkin of Wilton and Mattituck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leslie Virginia Parkin, to Benjamin Burroughs Jr. of Upper Montclair, N.J. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burroughs of Myrtle Beach, S. C., and Shelter Island, L.I.

NAMBAC, Laos, Feb. 15, Every morning as the sky clears, leaving wisps of mist around the surrounding mountain tops, two or three green Air America helicopters whir onto a grass airstrip and settle beside stacked bags of rice. The bags are tossed aboard by dusty Laotian troops, and the helicopters take off for mountain strongpoints, usually of few thatched bamboo huts surrounded by shallow foxholes.
Nine police officers from precincts containing large Spanishspeaking populations will attend a one-month community rela tions course at the Catholic University in Ponce, P. R.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska,Feb. 18 Gov. George Romney charged today that the Johnson Administration's prosecution of the war in Vietnam was "clumsy, ill-timed and poorly coordinated."

Brooklyn College announced yesterday's construction program that includes an underground area with classrooms, faculty offices, lecture halls, an art museum, a college bookstore, a dining area and a storage area.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18--The Vietcong fired mortar shells at targets in or near two provincial capitals today, but the surge of heavy fighting subsided for the first time since the lunar new year holiday truce ended Sunday.
FRANCOPHILES, and others, should be pleased to know that Gerard Sonzay has made a new recording called A Century of French Song (Philips PHM 500-132; stereo PHS 900-132).
Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler said yesterday that structural flaws had been found in three middleincome rental projects built with mortgage money supplied by the city.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 18 David L. Hagan, president of the Vernon Pontiac Company here, died yesterday in Mount Vernon Hospital. He lived at 365 New Rochelle Road, Bronxville.

The New York Mets received signed contracts yesterday from Rob Gardner, a left-handed pitcher, and Larry Stahl, an outfielder purchased last fall from the Kansas City Athletics. The signings brought the Mets to within four of completing their player roster for the 1967 season.
Extensive design research undertaken by the architect of an office building recently completed in Melville, L.I., adjoining Huntington in Suf folk County, substantially reduced construction costs.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 18 Mrs. Henry M. Thomas Jr. has announced,the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Whitall Thomas, to William Murrie Clevenger. He is the son of Mrs. James Logan Clevenger Jr. of Plainfield, N.J., and the late Mr. Clevenger. An April wedding is planned.

THE accompanying photographs could be a preview of a trip to the moon, but the "lunar landscape" is actually to be found about 170 miles from the Turkish capital of Ankara. These are the cone-dwellings of Cappadocia, one of the most fascinating sights in the Middle East and yet one that is visited yearly by only a handful of tourists.

BAL HARBOUR., Fla., Feb. 18 Leaders of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations gathering here this weekend appeared to be surprisingly calm in the face of Walter P. Reuther's bitter split with George Meany.

TURIN, Italy With an enthusiasm possibly, similar to the excitement that the Pled Piper must have once generated, youngsters are being drawn to Italy's ski slopes, in rapidly increasing numbers. In short, the piccolo skier is everywhere.

BOSTON, Feb. 18 The Boston University Terriers, paced by Fred Bassi scored an impressive 12-2 victory over Army tonight before 4,000 jubilant fans at Boston Arena. Bill Riley, a nephew of the Army coach, Jack Riley, scored two goals for the victors as did Jim Quinn and Serge Boily. Mike Sobeski, Brian Gilmour and Herb Wakabayashi also scored once, each for the Terriers.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 8 (AP) Bert Weaver of Biloxi, Miss., shot a par 72 today and held a one-stroke lead with a 209 total after three rounds of the 72-hole Los Lagartos international golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 In the strategic world of megatons and megadeaths, appearances can be deceiving. The Johnson Administration, for example, has decided to reduce the total number of intercontinental ballistic missiles by phasing the mammoth Titan 2 missiles out of the strategic force.

DUFTING 1965 and 1966, various articles in British magazines presented London as the new leader of fashion in almost everything from hairstyling to music. London gambling clubs and other phenomena of our supposedly affluent and progressive society were called into the account.

Columbia's basketball fortunes rose and fell last night with the performance of a 6foot-3-inch sophomore named Roger Walaszek. In the end, Walaszek converted two 3point plays and the Lions beat Pennsylvania, 68-60.

MOUNT VERNON, Ill., Feb. 18 A summer wedding is planned by Miss Sandra West Morgan and Arthur Richard Hessel. Their engagement has been made known by Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Morgan, her parents Mr. Hessel is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Hessel of St. Louis.

DOVER, Mass., Feb. 18 Miss Timi Hall Garritt's engagement to Peter Harold Parsons of New York has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hall Garritt Jr. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Norman Parsons of Birmingham, England.

The National Gallery of Art in Washington has agreed to buy A portrait by Leonardo daVinci from Prince Franz Josef II of Liechtenstein for a figure between $5-million and $6-million, the highest price ever paid for a painting.
At least 12 books about Senator Robert F. Kennedy are being written, most of them to be published this year.

GOWER, CHAMPION loped across the living room of his 13-room penthouse that looks like a Sonja Hence set from "Sun Valley Serenade," gazed down through the beaded glass windows overlooking Central Park and said, "I've been lucky." It was the understatement or the year.

GENEVA, Feb. 18-William C. Foster and Aleksei A. Roshchin, the chief United States and Soviet negotiators, held their second meeting today in preparation for the resumption of negotiations Tuesday on a treaty prohibiting the further spread of nuclear weapons.
PARIS, Feb. 18 (Reuters) The Cambodian head of state, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, said in an article today that the Central Intelligence had plotted against him ant tried to assassinate his parents.

WATERTOWN, Conn., Feb. 18 Mr. and Mrs. Heminway Merriman of Satertown and of Wcekapaug, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mallory Betts Merriman, to Richard Wells Constantine of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wells Wadsworth Constantine Jr. of South Orange, N.J. and Weekapaug.

The addition of 26 radio stations in the Pacific highlighted the search and rescue activities of the Coast Guard's Automated Merchant Vessel Report (AMVER) System in 1966, the service noted here last week.

WRITTEN about a quarter century ago, around the time when Pearl Buck's "The Good Earth" was winning a Pulitzer, and, with her other work, a Nobel award, this novel was once set in type, only to have publication canceled with her approval because, supposedly, it was "too personal."

ATLANTA, Feb. 18 Mr. and Mrs. Harry Stevens Baxter have made knovwn the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Julia Baxter, to John Adams Sibley 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Adams Sibley.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 18 (UPI) Ralph Terry rallied today to win the first championship tournament of the Professional Athletes' Golf Association.
WINCHESTER, Mass., Feb. 18 Mrs. Billie Jean King, the defending champion, needed only 34 minutes today to reach the final of the national women's indoor tennis championship.

Do not overwater cacti and succuwhen the outdoor temperatures are frigid lents during their dormant winter months.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 A clearer picture of the Apollo spacecraft fire is beginning to emerge from an exhaustive investigation, though the exact cause may never be known.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 18 Commisioner Robert L.Bennett of the Bureau of Indian Affairs struck a cautious note this week as he opened a twoday conference here on the problem of Indian unemployment.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Feb. 18 Ray Widelski, the Downtown Athletic Club pro, and Allen (Skip) Davidson led the way into the semi-final bracket of the fifteenth annual Harry Geidel pro-am squash racquets benefit tournament at the Nassau Country Club today. The proceeds go to St. Christopher's Home, Sea Cliff.

TEHERAN, Feb. 18 A half century ago, Russian Cossak officers rode the streets of this hilly capital, commanding Persian soldiery during the reign of Shah Naserdin Qajar before being expelled after a coup in 1921.
Dr. Frederick A. Weiss, a psychoanalyst whose home and office were at 11 Riverside Drive, died of a heart allment on Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. His age was 68.

The builders of a community of apartments and individual homes in Rockland County have found a way to forestall the objections often raised by the house-buying members of such planned-unit developments to the apartments that rise in their midst.

SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 18--Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico and Arthur Ashe of Richmond, the finalists at the Richmond and Philadelphia tournaments, gained the title round of the national indoor tennis championship today.

ITALY, to most of its eager visitors is art-frosted dolce far niente in glorious Technicolor. Italian cafes are conveniently arranged for the relaxed, Campari-accompanied enjoyment of the umber-toned beauties of Rome and the Renaissance: churches, palaces, fountains and plazas, gallerias and opera houses, and the Eternal City under an eternal blue sky.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 18 Leaders of Suffolk County's Economic Opportunity Commission have voted to disband and set up a private nonprofit corporation, "free from political control," to run the county's $1.9-million antipoverty program.
EL CENTRO, Calif., Feb. 18 (UPI) A member of the Navy's Blue Angels precision flying team was killed today when his F11A Tiger Jet crashed 250 yards from the site of is similar tragedy two weeks ago.
Employment in 100 large area manufacturing plants dipped slightly in January, although it is still higher than a year ago.

After a year-long dispute with the National Collegiate Athletic Association over eligiblity requirements Ivy League teams apparently will be able to compete again in postseason championships of the N.C.A.A.

The United States Rubber Company announced last week that it was using a computer to design tires. The computer technique can produce drawings for new tires in 18 hours, compared with four to six weeks of drafting time previously required, the company said.

Gossip of the fairway will dominate a gathering at the Hotel Americana on Tuesday, when officials, club members and some of the nation's leading golf professionals assemble for the annual Metropolitan Golf Writers Association awards dinner.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 18 Miss Alice Elizabeth Coughlin and John Pyer Nixon, son of Mrs. John F. Hyland of Pelham and the late Albert Nixon, were married at noon today. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Paul V. Coughlin of Bronxville.

The electronic computer, which can direct a space vehicle, solve a complicated engineering problem and put the right boy with the right girl, now has found additional work in putting the right worker in the right job.
NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 18 Boston College finally did it defeated Providence in a basketball game tonight after losing 12 in a row to the Friars.

MONTREAL, Feb. 18 (UPI) Rogtien Vachon made a successful major league debut as a goalie tonight as he stopped the Detroit Red Wings and led the Montreal Canadiens to a 3-2 victory in a National Hockey League game.

TAKE away the powder and gilt, Marie Antoinette and Du Barry, the silks, laces and puffy brocades; put in creamy carpet ing, an avocado velvet sofa, white an tique phone, view of the Spry sign across the Hudson, a make-up table. But it's still a boudoir, and what is Diahann Carroll, who generally holds court in some of the most sophisticated saloons in the Western world, doing in a boudoir?

PARIS What our Government calls "the intelligence community" is regarded as sordid by some embarrassed Americans who still, to an endearing but impractical degree, continue to cherish the innocence of their forefathers. To them C.I.A. is a dirty word and any organization even tangentially touching it is held thereby to be tarnished.

COMMON vegetables take on an exciting new di mension when children learn to know what the seeds look like and how they grow. Many experiments can be carried out at home.
Liability insurance for owners of tenement property here including high-risk buildings with histories of frequent accidents is being offered on a trial basis by a Bronx insurance company.
Wall Street is pondering a new puzzle: Has the move toward easier money that helped the stock market recoup more than one-third of the ground lost last year come to an end?
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18 The first stock car race run here in 1936 was conducted as a defensive measure.

The suggestion that airports throughout the world should be operated at cost as public utilities and not for profit was made last week by Knut Hammarskjold, Director General of the International Air Transport Association.
Mrs. James Edward Welsh of the Bronx has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Kathryn Edwardine Welsh, to Peter Joseph Morgan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan Jr. of Trenton.

MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (UP) A Soviet newspaper said today that Chinese husbands and wives were being told to abandon love as a "Petit bourgeois prejudice" and build themselves up ideologically by battering one another with criticism.
Detroit, Feb. 18 American cities can increasingly adapt to the motor vehicle and need not ban it from downtown, areas, a study commissioned by the Automobile Manufacturers Association affirms.
One of the most important private collections of rare and preious jewelry, that of the late Mrs. I. W. Killam of Montreal, has been purchased by Harry Winston, the jeweler here.

MODERN University is a glass and concrete tower 50 floors high, in which every student enjoys a private room, and such a choice of shops, restaurants, bars and social facilities that he need never leave his vertical campus. The university has, moreover, a superb faculty, and chooses its boys and girls from the academic cream of all 50 states and many foreign countries.

Mrs. Pearson E. Neaman of 1107 Fifth Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sophia Neaman, to William Hughes Fitshugh, son of Dr. Greene S. Fitzhugh of Boston and Mrs. Pringle Barrett Fitzhugh of Tucson, Ariz. A June wedding is planned.
Ability of the student will be the key to a new type of city high school that will do away with fixed hours, percentage, grades and formal classifications such as freshman and sophomore.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 18 Affiliation between Vassar and Yale would raise the moral quality of campus life, Kingman Brewster Jr., the president of Yale, said today.
HONG KONG, Feb. 18 A rift in the Army in Hupeh Province way hinted in a broadcast from Wuhan tonight.
New York University's national champion fencing team yesterday with a 15-12 victory over the Naval Academy's swordsmen.
EUGENE, Ore:, Feb. 18 (AP) An official of the University of Oregon says the Central Intelligence Agency was the largest single employer of 1966 University of Oregon graduates for 1966.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 18 (UPI) An 800-pound lion bit and mauled a father-and-son lion taming team today in front of 8,000 spectators.

FERNS, one of the oldest forms of plant life, are truly universal. Their natural habitat extends from the Arctic Circle to the Antarotic and they are represented in 15 different plant families which are divided into 175 genera aad some 8,000 species.
LONDON, Feb. 18 (Reuters) Norwich City, a Second Division team, scored the biggest upset of the English Football Association Cup fourth round today by defeating the favorite, Manchester United, 2-1.

IN this novel with an existentialist message, Josephine Carson has matched the excellence of her first book, "Drives My Green Age." "First Man, Last Man" is the story of Tracy Sudlow, who rises, propelled by uncomprehended yearn ings, from poverty to riches and of Pink, his articulate poet-daughter, who tries to understand his blindly forceful life and transmute it into meaning.
HONG KONG, Feb. 18 (Reuters) Supporters of Chairman Mao in the northern port city of Tsingtao were told today to cool off the Cultural Revolution campaign and go to work instead of holding rallies.

Miss Mailyn Irene Burke, daughter of Mrs. Michael Joseph Burke of Elmhurst, Queens, and the late Mr. Burke, was married yesterday to Robert Frank Karsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Karsch of Stewart Manor, L.I.
CAPETOWN, Feb, 18 (Reuters) The South African Government has dropped two bills that would have enforced racial segregation on university campuses, Education Minister Jan de Klerk said tonight.

PARIS, Feb. 18--United States "aggression" in Vietnam, the behavior of Soviet tanks in Budapest in 1956, the Berlin Wall, the European Common Market, and France's nuclear striking force--all these and countless other issues were debated from one end of France to the other this week as the election campaign picked up momentum.
Fifteen barge operators and a motor truck line have filed applications with the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to operate on the unfinished Arkansas-Verdigris Rivers canal system.

The suggestion that airports throughout the world should be operated at cost as public utilities and not for profit was made last week by Knut Hammarskjold, Director General of the International Air Transport Association.

Miss Judith Ann Prenske, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold N. Prenske of Hollis, Queens, and the late Mr. Prenske, was married yesterday afternoon to Bruce Allan Rich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice H. Rich, also of New York, and the late Mr. Rich. Rabbi Ephraim Shimoff performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

NYACK, N.Y., Feb. 19 A car crossed a low median divider on the Tappan Zee Bridge early this morning, skidded several hundred feet and plunged in flames through the railing into the icy Hudson River, killing at least one man.

On Thursday afternoon, for the second time in nine months, Robert H. O'Brien's management as president of MetroGoldwyn-Mayer, Inc., will be formally challenged by its dissident director, Philip J. Levin, New Jersey real estate man.
Mrs. Ella Wise Fisch, a founder of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue on West 68th Street, died yesterday in her home at 28 East 70th Street. She was 90 years old.
The American Assembly of Columbia University announced yesterday the election of three new trustees.

HAMMARSTRAND, Sweden, Feb. 19 (AP) East Germany, led by the 1964 Olympic champion, Thomas Koehler, dominated the one-man event today in the world luge championships, taking three of the first four places.

Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said yesterday that "the real trouble" in the controversy over operations of the Central Intelligence Agency "is that things that should have been open were clandestine."
BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 19 (AP) Butch Baird of San Tee, Calif., won the fourth Largartos international golf tournament today with a 277 total. Bert Weaver of Biloxi, Miss., finished second.

AMARILLO, Tex., Feb. 19 (AP) Cal Farley, a former professional wrestler who devoted the last 30 years of his life to helping wayward youngsters at Boys Ranch, died today of a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

WINCHESTER, Mass., Feb. 19 (AP) Mrs. Billie Jean King of Berkeley, Calif., routed Trudy Groenman of the Netherlands, 6-1, 6-0, today in a successful defense of her national women's indoor tennis championship.
CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 19 The residents of India's biggest city voted today.

Senator Jacob K. Javits called on the Legislature yesterday to pass the controversial Blumenthal bill to liberalize the state's 84-year-old abortion law. "The present law has lost touch with reality," New York's Republican Senator said. "Intelligent reform is long overdue."
BARNSTABLE, Mass., Feb. 19 Henry Crocker Kittredge, rector of St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., from 1947 to 1954, died yesterday at his home on Pine Lane. He was 77 years old.
THE Group for Contemporary Music, whose home is at Columbia University, moved downtown to Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday night with a program of substantial 20th-century works.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) The formation of a subcommittee on Regional Development of the Great Lakes conference of Senators was announced today by Senators William E. Proxmire and Gaylord Nelson, Wisconsin Democrats.

ONLY two of the characters in "Of Love Remembered," which opened without fanfare or intermission at the ANTA Theater on Saturday night, managed to survive the evening without being disinherited, disfigured or otherwise disabled. They are to be congratulated. The place is a deathtrap.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 When the Chicago Black Hawks scored early in the first period tonight, the organist at Chicago Stadium boomed out a few bars of "More."

DANANG, South Vietnam, Feb. 19 (AP)--An American Navy doctor who removed a live mortar round from a South Vietnamese soldier's chest and a United States Marine from Ireland who threw himself on an enemy hand grenade, and lived, were today awarded the Navy Cross, the service's highest award.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 A new study has found that getting a chill does not seem to cause or even worsen the common cold.
Canada's three armed services, rich in history and tradition, are about to enter a new era as a single-service, oneuniform force.

New York City has only "about eight years left" before it uses up all seven present sites for dumping its refuse at the current rate of use, according to Sanitation Commissioner Samuel J. Kearing Jr. The city, he says, "is in a real crisis."
The presidency of the New York Stock Exchange has been offered to Donald C. Cook, a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission and currently president of American Electric Power.
TOKYO, Feb. 19 (UPI) North Vietnam said today that it regarded demonstrations in the United States against American policy in Vietnam as proof that the Communists would win the war.
To meet a growing demand of travelers who would like to visit EXPO '67, Canada's World's Fair at Montreal, two steamship lines have announced additional cruise voyages to Montreal.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 19 (UPI) Arnold Palmer, despite two double bogeys and a oneover-par 73 on the final round, edged Chuck Courtney by one stroke today to win the $60,000 Tucson open with a 72-hole score of 273.

UNTIL last night, everybody thought that either Andrew Wyeth at the Whitney Museum or Paul Klee at the Guggenheim had the biggest one-man show in town, but it turns out to be Marc Chagall at the Metropolitan Opera with an eight-ring circus called "The Magic Flute."

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 19 (AP) A United States Air Force team, headed by Gary Sheffield, raced to victory in the two-man National Amateur Athletic Union bobsled championships today, but a postfinish accident sent Sheffield to a Lake Placid hospital with minor injuries.

The University of Texas defeated the University of Omaha yesterday, 375 to 125, on the National Broadcasting Company's "College Bowl" television series. The winners identified P.T. Barnum, plays by Shakespeare, Oscar Wilde and Tennessee Willlams, and famous Negroes in history.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The Government is urgently considering measures to increase imports of gasoline, thus adding to supply and helping to roll back the recent cent-a-gallon price increase.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 19 Zolton A. Ferency, who ran unsuccessfully against Gov. George Romney in last November's election, won a third term today as Democratic state chairman at his party's convention here.
Herbert Blau, who recently resigned as director with Jules Irving of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center, is returning to the academic world.

Erroll Garner gave his first concert in eight years at Carnegie Hall Saturday night. The capacity audience indicated that he had not been forgotten. He rewarded them with a program full of the traditional Garner hallmarks--rollicking, joyous rhythms, moments of lush romanticism carried on a deliberate, lagging beat, and elfin quirks and twists in his interplay with his accompanists.

DEVENTER, The Netherlands, Feb. 19 (AP) Stien Kaiser of the Netherlands won the over-all women's world speed-skating championships today, while an obscure 15-yearold schoolgirl from Illinois took third place.

WEST ALLIS, Wis., Feb. 19 (UPI) Mike Passarella, Barth Levy and Jeanne Omelenchuk smashed records today in the second and final day of the United States Olympic team trials, and won berths on a national team that will compete against Canadian skaters next weekend at Edmonton.
President Johnson's "credibility gap," according to his former press secretary, "is due primarily to the ambiguity, the dilemma, the difficulty and the complexity of the Vietnam war."

That hardy perennial, "What's Wrong With the State Department?" has been commanding the attention lately of prominent publicists who are providing an unusually wide and contradictory range of answers.

PEKING, Feb. 19 (Agence France-Presse) Thousands of Maoist demonstrators chanting "Free the South!" massed in Peking's Tienanmen Square today for a rally directed against Tao Chu, former head of the propaganda department of the Chinese Communist party.

LONDON, Feb. 19 Ralph Schoenman, general secretary of Bertrand Russell's Peace Foundation, accused the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company today of "impugning the integrity" of the foundation.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 19 Sam Howe 3d, the national champion, won the Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship today by defeating Maurice Heckscher, 15-6, 15-8, 7-15, 15-11, at the ChalfonteHaddon Hall Racquet Club.
NEWARK, Feb. 19 (AP) The State Transportation Department has licensed Newark to operate a small helicopter landing area on a Passaic River dock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) A member of the Warren Commission said today that any new evidence uncovered by the New Orleans district attorney's office into the death of President Kennedy should be "immediately" transmitted to officials in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The Organization of American States and the State Department were concerned today that a small but promising venture in Latin-American self-help might be endangered as a result of last week's revelations that many organizations received funds from the Central Intelligence Agency.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 A Federal commission urged Congress today to enact legislation that would require racial balance in all of the nation's public schools.

A major conflict within baseball's ruling family is brewing over the soccer-in-baseball question, and Commissioner William D. Eckert declared yesterday that he had added the subject to the agenda for various owners' meetings scheduled for Florida next month.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino took issue yesterday with Mayor Lindsay's proposal to have the City University made an "autonomous unit" of the State University.
S. Klein Department Stores, Inc., the highly promotional department store chain, whose main store is at Union Square, will open its first new store in the city in 60 years today.

The United States should not have had to warn its partners in the Kennedy Round of trade negotiations that time is running out on their bargaining sessions. That it did so indicates Washington's concern that it will have nothing to show after five years of discussions to liberalize trade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 An organization headed by Richard M. Hunt, an assistant dean of the Harvard University Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, has received money from a foundation identified as a channel for Central Intelligence Agency funds.
The Latvian Folk Ensemble of New York gave a charming concert of ethnic music at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, which Was attended by about 500 persons.

WASHINGTON, Feb.19 (AP) Dr. James L. Goddard, head of the United States Food and Drug Administration, proposed today a private, nationwide television network to keep doctors posted on new research and advances in treatment including any fresh evidence on effects of drugs.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 19 Buckpasser, the 1966 horse of the year, pulled up short today during a scheduled mile workout that was supposed to determine whether the 4-year-old was fit to start in the $145,000 Santa Anita Handicap next Saturday.
THE much-awaited new production of "Die Zau berfl te" was unveiled last night at the Metropolitan Opera. Mozart's "Magic Flute"? Marc Chagall's "Magic Flute"? It is a legitimate question.

Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, "the father of the atomic bomb," was praised yesterday as a man who not only brought American physics to the front rank but also impressed on people the dangers and benefits the new science could bring.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 19 (AP) Three scientists have discovered a substance they believe can remove the infectious hepatitis virus from water supplies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Apparently without collaboration in advance, three leading economists have presented a surprised Congress with an identical and somewhat disturbing conclusion: Efforts by the Government to "fine tune" the economy with monetary and fiscal policy cause disruptions rather than prevent them.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 19 Kallyur Srinivasachariar, a leading Madras astrologer, has predicted that the Congress party will return to power in both Madras and the nation. However, he warns that the stars do not favor Mrs. Indira Gandhi's return as Prime Minister.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 19 (UPI) An official statement said a two-pound charge of dynamite exploded at Arad at 1 A.M. today. The statement said footprints of two men led northward across the Jordanian border from the pipeline.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 19 The first National Student Conference on Vietnam adopted a stand harshly critical of the United States early today after an angry walkout by nine proAdministration delegates who said the conference had been rigged by extreme leftists.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 20 (UPI) North Vietnam broadcast today the photograph of a captured American pilot and part of what it called his handwritten "avowal" that United States planes were deliberately attacking civillian targets in the North.
QUEBEC, Feb. 19 (AP) Ontario, with 128 points, won the team championship today as the week-long Canadian winter games came to a close.

HAWTHORNE, N.J., Feb. 19 A fourth body was found today in the smoldering rubble of a chemical plant here that was destroyed in a series of explosions on Friday. Seven more workers are believed to be entombed in the debris.
Princess Irene of Greece caught her plane home last night but just barely.

ONE of the best-played deals of 1966 makes an excellent test of technical ability. There is no difficulty on a double-dummy basis, so the reader should cover the East-West hands and put himself in South's position.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) The Empire State District Council of the American Newspaper Guild endorsed today the Guild's international affairs program and the use of foundation funds to support it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) will offer a $250-million bond issue during the week of March 13, it was announced today.
CHAMROUSSE, France, Feb. 19 (UPI) A double French skiing victory rang down the curtain today on France's trouble-plagued rehearsals for next year's Winter Olympic Games at Grenoble.
The Federal Maritime Commission has scored a major victory in the United States Court of Appeals that sustains its much-challenged subpoena powers.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 19--The tourist and political seasons are at their height here. Visitors loll on the beaches as violence increases in the campaign for general elections Tuesday, the first since Jamaica became independent of British rule in 1962.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Feb. 19 Standing at the lectern of a Mormon church, Gov. George Romney called today for a stepped-up citizen campaign to eliminate "Social injustice based on race and color."

The disastrous effects of the systematic penetration of American educational, cultural and labor organizations by the Central Intelligence Agency daily become more apparent. The strength of these organizations, both in the structure of American society and in their relations with their opposite numbers in other nations, always has been their freedom from government domination.
Miss Barbara Ann Brener and Lawrence Blyn Parker were married yesterday afternoon by Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.

Meredith J. Bratton, an assistant vice president in the public relations department of the Security National Bank at Huntington, L.I., died of a heart attack on Friday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived at 3 Peter Cooper Road.

BE it ever so jumbled, there's no place like home to start a business. An everincreasing number of fresh ideas in fashion are being executed throughout the city in premises that double as living quarters.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 19 (UPI) Bill Cunningham's free throw with six seconds left gave the Philadelphia 76ers a 123-122 victory over the St. Louis Hawks in a National Basketball Association game today.
An average of two persons died each day in traffic accidents here last year a total of 727 Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 19 Premier Amir Abbas Hoveida announced in Parliament today that Iran had signed an agreement with the Soviet Union for the purchase of $110-million worth of arms and military equipment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The Central Intelligence Agency said today it was "inconceivable" that members of the National Student Association who disclosed their secret relationship with the C.I.A. would be prosecuted for their unauthorized revelations.

BEDFORD MILLS, N.Y., Feb. 19 Darwin J. Adams, who retired two years ago as assistant to the publisher of The Social Spectator, a resort and travel magazine published seasonally in New York, died today in High Ridge House here. He was 68 years old and lived at 49 Main Street, Newtown, Conn.

TOKYO, Feb. 19 Witold Trampcynski, Poland's Minister of Foreign Trade, arrived here this afternoon for a seven-day visit and for what Tokyo hopes will be the first of several longterm agreements with East European countries for expanded trade.

The Commissioner of Marine and Aviation has unfolded a dream in which long stretches of rotting piers would be transformed into bulkhead areas for restaurants, foreign merchandise marts, "boatels" and permanent dock sites for whalers, clipper ships and other craft of yesteryear.
When Marilyn Horne walks out on a concert stage nowadays, she bears a heavy burden that of being expected to live up to the press notices she has received over the last five years or so.
Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson ended months of speculation by saying yesterday that he would seek re-election to a third term in November.
MOSCOW, Feb. 19 (UPI) A Soviet newspaper criticized today the National Student Association, an American group, for its links with the Central Intelligence Agency.

DETROIT, Feb. 19 (UPI) Leo Boivin scored the winning goal and turned in a flawless defensive performance as the Detroit Red Wings gained a 3-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens in a National Hockey League game today.
HARRIMAN, N.Y., Feb. 19 Differing views of life today one optimistic, one somber were offered at a three-day conference on democracy that ended here today.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 20 Wall posters quoted by Japanese newsmen yesterday said President Liu Shao-chi and his principal aide, Teng Hsiao-ping, had been deprived of their "official duties and powers" in the Chinese Communist party.

A three-year agreement between Children's Dressmakers Local 91 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the Industrial Association of Juvenile Manufacturers was announced yesterday by the union.

Gerard Souzay's recital at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum last night, his only one scheduled for New York this season, was a triumph of personality and artistry, especially during the generous sampling of French songs he offered.
BANGKOK, Thailand-Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn's regime is once more weighing the politically sensitive problem of Thailand's money-losing industries.
WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 19 (AP)--The Paul Revere Company of Worcester announced today it had been offered 9,206,541 shares of Avco Company common stock.
There are so many potential pitfalls to most forms of joint ownership of property, it is a wonder that the devices remain popular.
An aide to Mayor Lindsay helped capture a knife-wielding dishwasher early yesterday, minutes after the man allegedly had stabbed an East Side cafe owner.
HOPEWELL, Va., Feb. 19 (UPI) An officer of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference asked Gov. Mills E. Godwin for help today after three terrorist attacks upon his home.

OWENSBORO, Ky., Feb. 19 (AP) The Rev. Ralph S. Pfau, a Roman Catholic priest who helped alcoholics throughout the world after he had overcome his own alcoholism, died of hepatitis today at Our Lady of Mercy Hospital. He was 62 years old.
RICHARD MAHON of Brooklyn captured first place in a recent "30-30" tournament (30 moves in 30 minutes) at Brady's 42d Street Chess Club.

Sales and earnings of Eastman Kodak Company set records in 1966, William S. Vaughn, chairman, and Louis K. Eilers, president, reported over the weekend. It was the 12th consecutive year of higher sales and the 14th of higher earnings.
The Long Island Rail Road and an independent union representing 137 gang foremen on the railroad announced agreement yesterday on a new contract granting the workers a 5 per cent increase in wages.

JERUSALEM, (Israel), Feb. 19 (AP) The Israel Government confirmed tonight that two magazine editors had been sentenced to one-year prison terms after a secret trial earlier this month involving security matters. The secrecy immediately came under press attack.
Brooklyn's top longshore leader charged yesterday that the Waterfront Commission was trying to acquire "extreme police powers" in a measure now before the Legislature.
Nothing is safe from the boundless influence of the computer not even safes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) President and Mrs. Johnson attended vesper services today at the St. John's Episcopal Church today and surprised a seminarian.
Westchester County wants to be selective but not ultraselective in the industry it attracts, County Executive Edwin Michaelian said yesterday.
The new bureau directors were named yesterday by Austin N. Heller, the city's Air Pollution Control Commissioner, in what he called to total reorganization of his department.

The six agencies who will bepitching for the $2.5-million ad account of the United States Plywood Corporation, besides the incumbent Kenyon Eckhardt, are Grey Advertising; Young Rubicam; Papert, Koenig, Lois; J. Walter Thompson, Fuller Smith Ross, and Foote, Cone Belding.

New York, which has long ranked with Indiana as the only states that make no statutory provision for a direct primary for Governor and United States Senator, may soon lose that dubious distinction. The prospect appears bright for favorable action in Albany on a direct primary bill.

JERUSALEM (Israel), Feb. 19 Israel is taking the first step toward establishing her own "think tank," an Institute for Applied Policy Science. Its proponents say it would be the first devoted entirely to nonmilitary problems.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, which originally supported the ombudsman idea because it didn't single out the police for special attention, now objects because it doesn't single them out for special insulation.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Monday, Feb. 20 (AP) Two apartment buildings and a house collapsed in Rio de Janeiro late last night, burying an unknown number of people.

TORONTO, Feb. 19 The Canadian dollar's sharp recovery in the foreign-exchange market since the first of the year is being interpreted by economists here as reflecting the resumption of heavy Canadian debt financing in United States dollars.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The Central Intelligence Agency was established by Congress in 1947 under the National Security Act for the purpose of operations to other branches of activities of various Government departments and agencies.
The Board of Education announced a plan yesterday that would give district superintendents a voice in appointing principals, selecting curriculums and allocating funds.

NUITRON OUTPOST, South Vietnam, Feb. 19 South Vietnamese paratroops reported a major victory over North Vietnamese regulars today in several hours of fighting in a broad valley about 320 miles northeast of Saigon.
LONDON, Monday, Feb. 20 The celibacy doctrine of the Roman Catholic church has caused another British priest to give up the clergy.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 Ralph Latham of Cincinnati won the fourth annual Automobile Racing Club of America 250-mile late model stock car race on the highbanked 2.5-mile-Daytona, International Speedway today. He drove a 1966 Plymouth. It was an exciting race among 39 starters, slowed down twice by spectacular spins that sent two drivers to the hospital, each with minor injuries.

Bob Seagren and Kipchoge Keino are up to old tricks and Tom Von Ruden has found new ones. They were three of the stars in major indoor track and field meets Saturday night at Cleveland, Louisville and Vancouver, B.C.

Consolidated Edison said yesterday that it would build a 500,000-kilowatt turbine generator at its Arthur Kill plant on Staten Island this year because of delays on its controversial Cornwall, N. Y., hydroelectric proiect.
REDDING RIDGE, Conn., Feb. 19 Dr. Stephen M. Smith, director of Gracie Square Hospital, a private hospital in New York, died yesterday in his home here. He was 68 years old.
A snow happening on Staten Island turned into more of a mud happening yesterday. Most events went on as scheduled; it was just black instead of white.

To start a new series called "Experiment in Televi sion," the National Broadcasting Company presented yesterday afternoon a program that emerged from Budd Schulberg's Writers Workshop in the Watts section of Los Angeles.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 19 A team of Indonesian negotiators will leave tomorrow for a conference in Amsterdam Thursday and Friday of seven major creditors to ask for $160million in new credits and for permission to use the funds at the discretion of Indonesia for a complete overhaul of her economic machinery.

The National Gallery of Art in Washington said yesterday that it could not comment on whether it had agreed to buy a portrait by Leonardo da Vinci from Prince Franz Josef 2d of Liechtenstein for a figure between $5-million and $6-million, the highest price ever paid for a painting.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19--Although most leaders in the segregationist Citizens Councils believe that former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama will run for President on a third-party ticket, they are growing anxious over his failure to announce his candidacy formally.

The Defense Department's proposal to build a fleet of high-speed supply ships to be deployed around the world loaded with military equipment for use in emergencies came under sharp attack yesterday by a top labor leader.
Louis Lamkay, who advised people to belong to long-lived families to attain his age, died yesterday in Long Beach (L.I.) Memorial Hospital. He was 98 years old and lived at 304 West 89th Street.
MIDDLE ISLAND, L.I., Feb. 19 Acks I made his debut in the ring at the Middle Island Horse Show today and to the amazement of his owner won the open hunter championship.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 19 (UPI) The United States and four Latin-American nations agreed tonight on a strategy to break a deadlock over the proposed meeting of Western Hemisphere chiefs of state.
The city's plans for new stables and a new police station in Central Park were supported yesterday by a newly formed Citizens Committee for Stables in Central Park.

In the Cottage of the Hampshire House at noon yesterday, Miss Linda Ruth Berman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Berman of New York and Long Beach, L. I., became the bride of Harvey Weiner. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Weiner of Hyde Park, Mass.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 19 An 80-pound Samoyed, whose profuse white coat made him look like an animated snowbank, became the final major winner tonight of the series of dog shows that started with breed specialities last weekend, continued through two days of Westminster and extended into Hartford and finally this city.

Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert E. Jones of New York and Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Jean Macpherson Jones, to Anson McCook Beard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Beard of West Hill, L.I.
TORONTO, Feb. 15--United States influence in the Canadian labor movement, a perennial source of uneasiness, is drawing renewed attention.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 First nights, like first loves, shouldn't really happen to dogs. At the Chicago Opera House last night, the American Ballet Theater danced David Blair's new staging of the original 1895 Petipa and Ivanov version of "Swan Lake."

SALISBURY, Md., Feb, 19 Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico defeated Arthur Ashe of Richmond in the final of the 64th national indoor tennis championship today and became the first player to win the title in successive years since Gregory Mangin's double triumph in 1935 and 1936.
William Manchester says that Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. began conferring about the replacement of President Johnson as the 1964 Democratic candidate within 24 hours after the Kennedy assassination.
MOSCOW, Feb. 19 (AP) Norway won a five-nation speed-skating meet today with a total of 217.5 points.
PEORIA, Ill., Feb. 19 (UPI) Richard Speck goes on trial tomorrow on charges of having killed eight nurses in their Chicago dormitory last summer.

IF golf were an informal game, the queries that pour into the offices of the United States Golf Association would be ad- dressed "Dear Joe." For Joseph C. Dey Jr. is the executive director of the organization and his duty is to offer advice to the golflorn.

More than a year after the election of John V. Lindsay as the first Republican Mayor of New York in two decades, observers find the Democrats still without a clearly defined, authoritative leader at City Hall.

HOHENAU, Austria, Feb. 19 (AP) A 24-year-old West German and his fianc e from East Germany escaped from Czechoslovakia early yesterday by swimming the March River northeast of here, authorities reported today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 Resplendent in a pink shirt, red suspenders and a deep blue and maroon striped necktie, Warren Hinckle 3d paced between the rolltop desks.
St. Francis College upset a taller Niagara University team, 81-72, yesterday at the Bishop Ford High School court in Brooklyn.
Nina Simone faced an almost impossible situation at Philharmonic Hall at a midnight concert on Saturday. She had to follow Bill Cosby, one of the least followable performers around today.

The New York Athletic Club's A saber team, the national champion, successfully defended its metropolitan title on its home strips yesterday by beating the Fencers Club. Alex Orban of the victors won all three of his final-round bouts.

Pilot films for television series that are never sold usually end up on the video equivalent of the remainder counter that is, as part of a throwaway summer series with a somewhat ambiguous title such as "First-Run Playhouse."

Starting precisely at 5:30 A.M., Mountain War Time, July 16, 1945, J. (for nothing) Robert Oppenheimer lived the remainder of his life in the blinding light and the crepusculine shadow of the world's first event for which he was largely responsible.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 19 (UPI) Jackie Stewart of Scotland, leading from start to finish, broke three records today when he drove his V-8 B.R.M. to a 16-second victory over Jim Clark of Scotland in the 32d Australian Grand Prix.

Ivy League teams and individual athletes are again eligible to compete in National Collegiate Athletic Association championship tournaments, at least for the remainder of the current academic year. An agreement on Ivy League eligibility has been worked out between the league and the president of the N.C.A.A., Marcus L. Plant.

JUST as no amount of empathy can make us truly understand what it is like to live submerged in a world of water only a fish can understand that so Jean Genet's "Miracle of the Rose" makes us realize that we will never understand that part of society whose natural habitat is the prison.
