About 1.8 million books of the 4.5 million in the Central Research Library on Fifth Avenue "are in an advanced state of deterioration," according to Edward G. Freehafer, the director of the New York Public Library.
JERUSALEM (Israel), Feb. 19 An Israeli Army spokesman said today that a border patrol last night shot and killed a Syrian infiltrator near Notera north of the Sea of Galilee.

The Free University of Berlin in the American sector of West Berlin was used both by the Central Intelligence Agency and Army intelligence to recruit American and foreign students for what members of the agencies often called "part-time work."

The Broadway Building, a 20-story office and loft structure at 915 Broadway, southwest corner of 21st Street, has been purchased by Harry B. Helmsley and Irving Schneider for about $1.7-million. The property, fronting 73 feet on Broadway and 129 feet on 21st Street, is assessed at $1,215,000.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 19 Ski jumpers from all over the East and parts of the Far West swarmed into this colorful Connecticut River Valley city for its annual tournament today only to see a familiar figure from downriver emerge as king of the hill.
The formation of a Romney for President Committee was announced yesterday by Leonard W. Hall, former chairman of the Republican National Committee.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 19 Demand for steel remained sluggish last week.

Miss Patricia Ann Vender, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Angelo Vender of Stratford, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon to Michael Forrest of 60 Sutton Place South. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Forrest of New York.

HONG KONG, Monday, Feb. 20 (UPI)--Communist China said today that the main condition for Vietnam peace talks was the withdrawal of American troops from South Vietnam and that a halt in United States bombing of North Vietnam would not be enough.

TOKYO, Feb. 19 (UPI) The Hanoi radio reported today that two American prisoners of war the Vietcong allegedly released in South Vietnam on Feb. 7 were freed with 10 captured South Vietnamese "east of Saigon."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Two front runners have emerged in the race for the soon-to-be-vacant Republican spot on the Securities and Exchange Commission. Informed people here are betting, however, that neither man will wind up with the job.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Under Secretary of State Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, chairman of the President's Commission on Law Enforcement and Administration of Justice, strongly disputed today the idea that court decisions upholding indi vidual rights lead to higher crime rates.

Vladimir Ashkenazy split his recital Saturday night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art between Beethoven and Schumann. Throughout the program the young Soviet virtuoso's playing was never less than the work of a dedicated musician and technical master, but the Schumann half was more persuasive.
ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 19--Sales of goods and orders taken at the 19-day international trade fair that ended here tonight are expected to run into several million dollars.

Twelve graduate students at Columbia University's School of Social Work are earning master's degrees through a project that is pressuring government agencies and merchants groups, organizing sit-ins and preparing what could be the city's lastest rent strike.
JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 19 Thousands of Mississippi Negroes have been eliminated from a Federal food assistance program that has helped sustain more than 400,000 of the state's poor.

The Botticelli Ball, a benefit for Orphans of Italy, will be held on March 29 in the Plaza. Mrs. John G. Phillips Jr. is chairman. The proceeds will help restore the agency's youth assistance center in Florence, Italy, that was destroyed in the flood.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Feb. 19 (AP) Gail Purdy of Saratoga Springs and Al Harding of Paterson, N.J., captured the senior titles today in the International Silver Skates speed skating championships on Lake George.

The nation's principal Jewish, Protestant and Roman Catholic organizations, which until now have restricted their joint activities to secular matters, are preparing to move to a new stage their first discussion of a religious subject.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (Reuters) --A Thai Government official paid 360 ($1,000) today for a series of letters in broken English from the King of Siam, now called Thailand, about Anna, the English governess at his 19th-century court.

"Project 20," the National Broadcasting Company's celebrated documentary unit that has filmed programs on the Nativity and on the Resurrection of Jesus, plans to travel backward in time for a one-hour special on Old Testament prophets.

Pee Wee Russell had been scheduled to play at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. When he was unable to fill the engagement, Pee Wee Erwin was rushed into the breech, thus keeping the changes in the posters to a minimum.
The American Electric Power Company entered 1967 with new highs in earnings for the 12 months ended Jan. 31 and for the month of January.

The loss of one university would hurt a city more than the departure of a series of industrial companies, Charles Abrams, chairman of the Division of Urban Planning at Columbia University, said yesterday.

Jay Lovestone, director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. International Affairs Department, is a former Communist who has swung far to the right since 1929, when he broke with the party after two years as its national head.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--A group of Congressional liberals started a drive today for immediate White House approval of a $25-million allocation for emergency food aid to the Indian states of Bihar and Uttar Pradesh through CARE and other American voluntary agencies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- The temporary repeal of the 7 per cent tax credit for business investment has caused businesses to cut back their capital-spending plans for this year by $2.3-billion, according to a special Government survey made public by the White House today.
PUPPETS are the thing that "People Is the Thing That the World Is Fullest Of" is fullest of.
Nine men have been arrested in an investigation into charges that a truck-loading racket is costing housewives $1-million million more a year for fruits and vegetables than they should be paying.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI)--President Johnson said today he would nominate former Oregon Senator Maurine B. Neuberger as the first woman to serve on the General Advisory Committee of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.

"Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?", with 13 candidates, and "A Man for All Seasons" and "The Sand Pebbles," with eight each, outdistanced the competition in the 39th annual nominations for Academy Awards. The winners and their Oscars presented will be announced in Santa Monica, Calif., on April 10.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- The Supreme Court restricted today "harmless error" procedures by states that allow judges to let convictions stand even though defendants' constitutional rights have been violated.

Wheat futures, which had been dawdling, took off yesterday, reacting to somewhat improved export orders, good volume in the Chicago market and news of little moisture over the weekend in the Southwest.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 20--Vice President Humphrey said today the financing of student groups by the Central Intelligence Agency represented "one of the saddest times, in reference to public policy, our Government has had."
WICHITA, Kan., Feb. 20 (UPI)--The Wichita State basketball coach, Gary Thompson, said tonight he had suspended seven of his top nine players for a training violation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) --The Supreme Court all but Invalidated today a Texas plan for reapportioning its state House of Representatives.

About 100 students, chanting "The C.I.A. must go," disrupted a hearing yesterday at Columbia University to determine the fate of 19 students who staged a sitin Feb. 8 at a C.I.A. recruiting office on campus.
Stocks declined in moderate trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
What's perking between Donald C. Cook, president of the American Electric Power. Company, and the New York Stock Exchange? Will he succeed Keith Funston as president of the Big Board?

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 20--District Attorney James Garrison, who once said he was only weeks away from making arrests in the Kennedy assassination case, revised his esti-- mate upward today to "many months."
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 20--Dr. Ray Laforest Hamon, chief of the School Housing Section of the United States Office of Education from 1943 to 1958, died yesterday. He was 71 years old.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 20--An official of The Public Health Service testified today that the Rand Development Corporation did not give the Government adequate information on its experimental cancer vaccine.

TRENTON, Feb. 20--A state air pollution official reported today that a rural area in southern New Jersey, chosen as an air test station because of the "rural qualities of its air environment," was not measuring up to new Federal clean air standards.

DETROIT, Feb. 20 (UPI)-- The General Motors Corporation said today that a wildcat strike at an Ohio parts factory could "paralyze" its automobile production by Friday, closing 22 plants and forcing the layoffs of 80,000 workers.

MANILA, Feb. 20 (UPI)-- The Mayor of the Philippine city that United States sailors call "Liberty Town," who had twice escaped unharmed from hand-grenade attacks, was fatally shot today by a teen-ager.
Stock prices tumbled in the first three hours of trading yesterday but regained a substantial part of their losses in an afternoon recovery.

BONN--Balanced budgets and tight money may be the foundation stones of Western civilization, as so many members of Congress would have their constituents believe, but it would be hard to prove it in West Germany, where the famous "economic miracle" has disappeared in painful experience.

A new system of reporting crime in New York that the police say is more accurate has resulted in a 72.1 per cent increase in the number of major crimes recorded in 1966. The police reported, however, that the actual rise in crime cases was only 6.5 per cent.

Demand for most major grades of paper and paperboard caught up with supply in 1966, it was reported yesterday by William R. Adams, chairman of the American Paper Institute, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

President Johnson, mixing Humpty Dumpty with Vietnam, is reported to have told a luncheon of farmers yesterday that: "We've reached a point where all the king's horses and all the king's men are not going to move us out of our position."

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 20--John Andrew Conradie, a 29-year-old former history lecturer, was sentenced to 20 years' imprisonment today on charges of conspiracy to commit murder, of illegal possession of Soviet-made grenades and of having taken part in the activities of an outlawed Rhodesian nationalist organization.
A man who admitted slaying his wife and five small children walked out of a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday, free, because the only available evidence against him was his own confession.
STRATTON MOUNTAIN, Vf., Feb. 20--Old Man Winter, who has been throwing curves at New England ski operators since December, finally threw a home run ball today.
ALBANY, Feb. 20--Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia said today that he was opposed to Mayor Lindsay's proposal to have the City University made an independent unit of the State University.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 20--Following is the text of a statement issued today by the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Orgainizations in response to charges or complacency by Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers Union:
The Yale School of Drama is looking for young men and women with a flair for theater.

GENEVA, Feb. 20--The Soviet Union has raised several unexpected objections to the United States draft treaty to bar the spread of nuclear weapons. This ruled out the possibility of prompt acceptance of the proposal by the Geneva disarmament conference.

COLONIA, N.J., Feb. 20-- Leonard Liberman of 52 Leslie Road, sales director for the Chancellor Electronics Company, Newark, died yesterday of a heart attack at Perth Amboy General Hospital. His age was 50.
The spot rate on the British pound declined 2 points to $2.7940 in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. Currency for Thursday was quoted at $2.7933 to $2.7935.

LAST Friday night, during the New York Athletic Club Games, a near-capacity crowd rose and cheered as a 57-year-old man ran a lap of honor around the Madison. Square Garden board track. Ten minutes later, after a sub-four-minute Baxter Mile, the crowd rose and cheered even louder as a young man of 20 took a lap of honor.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20-- Joe Frazier and Doug Jones, two heavyweights said to be going in opposite directions, will test those evaluations here tomorrow night at the Arena.

Norman L. Brickell, Thomas Emma and Michael F. Simcich have been appointed assistant vice presidents of the Cross Brown Co. Mr. Brickell and Mr. Emma are specialists in store leasing, while Mr. Simcich is an industrial sales and leasing broker in the firm's Long Island City office.
FASHIONABLE women may soon be painting their faces to look like Africans, predicts Gil, the 27-year-old European make-up artist who gave the world striped eyebrows.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 20 --Torrential rains have brought death to more than 100 people in this city and its outskirts over the weekend.

HONOLULU, Feb. 20--Civil Aeronautics Board hearings in the trans-Pacific air route case ended today when the examiner, Robert L. Park, ran out of witnesses after four days of testimony. The hearings will resume March 8 in Washington.

A branch of the Whitney Museum of American Art will be opened in late summer. And like the neighborhood libraries that began dotting the city early in the century, it will be financed by Carnegie funds.

Frank J. Ix Jr., a textile executive, died of a heart attack Sunday aboard the HollandAmerica liner Statendam enroute from a Caribbean cruise to Norfolk, Va. He was 69 years old and lived in Charlottesville, Va.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- Henry Steele Commager, the historian, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the United States, because of a "moralistic obsession" with Communism, had overextended itself as a world power.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Feb. 20-- Miss Kerry Regina Belford's en gagement to Harvey Charles Vogel Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. J. Frank Belford Jr., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vogel of St. Paul.
A modification was announced yesterday in the terms by which the American Tobacco Company plans to acquire the Royal Crown Cola Company.

The science of acoustics, applied with care and patience to violin-making, has raised the possibility that stringed instruments almost on a par with those of Stradivari and other great masters can be mass-produced.
A three-year contract worth about $22-million to supply iron ore to a Japanese steel-mill consortium has been won by Mount Goldsworthy Mining Associates in Western Australia.

HONG KONG, Feb. 20--Observers in Hong Kong specu late that the growing hostility between China and the Soviet Union has increased the apprehensions of both powers about renewed trouble along their frontier.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- A member of the Select Committee Investigating Adam Clayton Powell said today that he expected the committee to censure and penalize the Man-- hattan Democrat in humiliating language.

Broadcast Music, Inc., has offered a prize of $1,000 to be divided between the composer and lyricist of the best student musical comedy or revue presented in the United States or Canada during the 1967-68 academic year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- William P. Hobby Jr. said today that the Hobby Foundation of Houston, Tex., had been for many years a conduit for the transfer of funds from the Central Intelligence Agency to various organizations here and abroad.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 20 (UPI)--Enver Hoxha, the Albanian Communist leader, said today that a major shake-up in party and government posts was near.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 20 (UPI)--An officer of the National Student Association said today that the Central Intelligence Agency had intimidated and spied on groups in the association while subsidizing them.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 (AP)--James M. Jenkins, an engineer who worked on projects ranging from the Panama Canal in 1905, to the first atomic submarine, died Saturday in Chestnut Hill Hospital. He was 83 years old.

DURBAN, South Africa, Feb. 20 (Reuters)--The Mayor's office here announced today that it had received a telegram from the officers and most crewmen of the United States Navy satellite-tracking vessel Sword Knot expressing "extreme displeasure" at Washington's decision against letting the ship enter harbor here.
MONTREAL, Feb. 20 (AP) --Most Roman Catholic teachers in Quebec province voted today to end their strike against the Montreal Catholic school commission. There were some holdouts.

Mrs. Jose M. Ferrer, long a leader in Roman Catholic, charitable and civic organizations here, died Sunday in Harkness Pavilion of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 89 years old and lived at 791 Park Avenue.
PARIS, Feb. 20--The fishermen of Lorient put out in the teeth of a storm today, after four weeks of idleness.
LONDON, Feb. 20--"If I had five times as much ability as I have, I would still not want to do anything other than what I do."
SINGAPORE, Tuesday, Feb. 21--Indonesia's Foreign Minister, Adam Malik, said yesterday that President Sukarno would "be brought to trial" in the interest of justice, the Jakarta radio reported today.
The Gambest Corporation of New York, developer of regional shopping centers, will build a store center on a site of about 11 acres on the Boston Post Road, at the Stamford line, in Greenwich, Conn.
WASHINTON, Feb. 20-- Following are excerpts from the text of a statement made today by Prof. Henry Steele Commager before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee:

The Kennecott Copper Corporation and the Govermnent of Chile have reached agreement on a management contract that opens the way for a $200-million investment to expand production of Chile's El Teniente copper mine.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- Scrambled history.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 20-- For want of a tougher hoof, Ogden Phipps's champion, Buckpasser, was withdrawn today from next Saturday's running of the $145,000 Santa Anita Handicap.
HAWTHORNE, N.J., Feb. 20 (UPI)--Workers pulled four bodies from the ruins of a chemical plant today, bringing to eight the known dead in an ex plosion that destroyed a threestory building Friday.
Soviet press and radio reports monitored by Western sources indicate increased emphasis on civil defense measures along the Chinese border in the Soviet Far East.

MISFIT hands often present bidding problems, and the diagramed deal is no exception. When the combined hands have the values for game, three no-trump is often the least evil. It would have been in this case.

Gordie Howe, wearing a prominent bruise over his right eye, a shimmering blue suit and tasseled black shoes, received the second annual Lester Patrick Memorial Trophy last night at a National Hockey League dinner at Toots Shor's.

A battle of the sexes erupted yesterday at a City Council hearing on a Lindsay administration bill that would permit the 342 women on the police force to take examinations for promotion to posts as high as captain.

Robert A. Glasser, the chairman of the New York State Harness Racing Commission, in a joint statement with John B. H. Carter, head of the Pennsylvania commission, said yesterday that twin-double wagering would be banned at harness tracks in both states.

ROME, Feb. 20 (UPI)-- Armed policemen began throwing 57 million postage, stamps worth about $1-million into the furnace of the Bank of Italy today, to the relief of most stamp collectors but to the regret of many.
Plans for the Leasco Data Processing Equipment Corporation to acquire Documentation, Inc., were announced here yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 20--An indication that West Germany may withdraw all offers of offset payments for the British Army of the Rhine brought a bitter reaction in London today.
Cecil H. Underwood, governor of West Virginia from 1957 to 1961, was elected yesterday by the Monsanto Company as regional vice president for governmental and civic affairs.

The Holly Sugar Corporation and Western Nuclear, Inc., announced plans yesterday to consolidate. Holly Sugar ranks second to the Great Western Sugar Company among the nation's processors of beet sugar. Western Nuclear owns uranium properties in the West.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa Feb. 20--Experienced political observers said today there were indications that Prime Minister Balthazar J. Vorster was planning to ease South Africa's apartheid policy in the field of international sport.

Officially assured of a playoff berth and escape from the Eastern Division cellar for the first time in eight years, the New York Knickerbockers worked out at Madison Square Garden yesterday, preparing for another miniscule millenium.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP)--President Johnson said today that the world would miss the genius of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, who died Saturday night at Princeton, N.J., at the age of 62.

Alaska's centennial--the 100th anniversary of Alaska's purchase by the United States from Russia--will be marked by Meredith with publication on March 30 of "An Alaskan Reader," edited by Senator Ernest Gruening. The selections

Edward M. Gilbert's office in Manhattan at the Northerlin Company, a lumber wholesaler that until recently grossed about $10-million a year, is small and cluttered. A built-in table and an outsize metal cabinet take up most of the space, and what appears to be the concern's entire supply of letterheads, envelopes, Invoices and scratch pads is tucked into a set of open shelves above Gilbert's desk.

The Consolidated Edison Company told a public hearing yesterday that even with a $32million-a-year electric rate increase that took effect last November it could not maintain a "just and reasonable" profit margin.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 21-- According to Japanese dispatches from Peking, Chairman Mao Tse-tung has restored power to some officials formerly considered his enemies.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 21 --A group of prominent Americans said in a letter published in The Times of London today that the "special relationship" between the United States and Britain should remain a fundamental part of the two countries' policy even if Britain enters the European Economic Community.
WE applaud when new ground is won for the theater by the avant-garde. Shouldn't we applaud when the ground is held?

Edward M. Gilbert, a onetime wonder of Wall Street who fled to Brazil to avoid prosecution and later returned to face it, pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to charges that he had stolen $1,117,000 from the company he once headed.

MIAMI, Feb. 20--After a furious stretch duel, Phil Godfrey's Biller won the $32,600 Florida Breeders' Handicap today. With Bobby Ussery riding, Biller beat the odds-on choice, In Reality of the Grace A. Gentry Stable, by half a length. A long shot, Crafty Look, was next more than two lengths farther back.
ALWIN NIKOLAIS'S "Imago" is a remarkable work, as much theater as dance and an experience not to be missed by anyone interested in either.

MINHLONG, South Vietnam, Feb. 20--Military commanders from a wide area flew into this hamlet 320 miles northeast of Saigon today to see the results of yesterday's major South Vietnamese victory over North Vietnamese regulars.
ATHENS, Feb. 20--A 60year-old Athenian has threatened to kill himself with dynamite in Parliament to force the Government to build hospitals for the poor.
BERLIN, Feb. 20--East Germany widened the division of Germany today by introducing separate "nationality of the German Democratic Republic" for the 17 million East Germans.

New York's entry, as yet unnamad, in the new America Basketball Association will play its home games in the 69th Regiment Armory on Lexington Avenue and 26th Street, Arthur Brown, principal owner of the club, announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Feb. 20--Egypt agreed today to bring in American capital and technical skill to tap the rich El Alamein oil field which, along with another recent oil strike, in the Gulf of Suez, is expected to bolster her sagging economy and hence her prestige and power in world affairs.
THE weekend crowds at the New York Sport and Camping Show were heavy enough to drive a man right out of the Coliseum to the nearest patch of uninhabited woods. But one little boy solved the problem.

DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 20-- Dr. Frank G. Hall, an acrospace medical expert who contributed to development of the pressure suit worn by high-altitude military flyers in World War II, died of a heart ailment yesterday at Duke Hospital. He was 72 years old.

The Soviet Union has raised several objections to the United States draft of a treaty to bar the spread of nuclear weapons, United States sources disclosed in Geneva yesterday. As a result, it was said, there is no possibility of prompt acceptance of the proposal at the Geneva disarmament conference. [Page 1, Column 8.]
Track and field's bitter feud over eligibility of foreign athletes took a new twist yesterday and set off a tense and emotional shouting match.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feb. 20 --Col. Chester M. Freudendorf, U.S.A., and Mrs. Freudendorf have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Anne Freudendorf, to Roger Hart Kramer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kramer of the Bronx, New York. A wedding is planned for next month.
The election of J.M. Clifford as a director of the First Camden National Bank and Trust Company, Camden, N.J., was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20--The future of the independent men's apparel merchant in an era of big retailing was a subject of much discussion today in corridor conversation at the annual convention of the Menswear Retailers of America.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- Pentagon sources said today that the United States was planning to step up the war against surface-to-air missiles in North Vietnam.

LONDON, Feb. 20--"Gerald Moore at the piano"--and there he usually is by the time the soloist has made her entry, taken a bow, coughed, twiddled with her rings and finally, with a regal nod, graciously indicated her readiness to begin.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 20-- President Joma Kenyatta said today that Kenya was determined to preserve in Africa as wide an area of cooperation as she could.
Deputy Inspector Cyril R. Regan, who has been Sanford D. Garelik's top aide since he took over as chief inspector early last year, has been transferred to the Police Department's narcotics bureau.

ALBANY, Feb. 20--Democratic and Republican leaders appeared today to be lining up against the new taxes sought by Mayor Lindsay, but indicated that they might go along with an expanded state lottery to generate more financial aid for New York City.
The Cruikshank Company, real estate concern established here in 1794, has announced several executive changes.
PEORIA, Ill., Feb. 20--Richard Franklin Speck, charged with murdering eight student nurses in Chicago last July 14, went on trial for his life today.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 20 (AP) --Eleven at-large berths instead of the usual 10 will be at stake when the National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball tournament committee issues its invitations Thursday, the N.C.A.A. announced today.
GENEVA, Feb. 20--Sean MacBride, secretary general of the International Commission of Jurists, denounced the United States Central Intelligence Agency today for its "highly dangerous" activities.

Reform of the state's rigid abortion law has now been urged by both of New York's United States Senators, Robert F. Kennedy and Jacob K. Javits. Their stands range them alongside Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller in favor of liberalization.
William Cunningham, a novelist, died yesterday at Boulevard Hospital in Long Island City, Queens. He was 65 years old and lived at 83-45 Vietor Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens.
PARIS, Feb. 20 (AP)--Frederick D. Griffiths, manager of the American Chamber of Commerce in France since 1963, died yesterday at his home. He was 48 years old.

RICHMOND, Ky., Feb. 20 (AP)--Western Kentucky, the third-ranked college basketball team, rallied in the last half for a 71-62 victory tonight over Eastern Kentucky. The triumph clinched the Ohio Valley Conference title and a place in the National Collegiate tournament for the Hilltoppers.

The New York Yankees and the New York Mets signed Hamiltons right and left yesterday, or at least announced that they had. Steve Hamilton, the Yankee left-hander, and Jack Hamilton, the Met right-hander were among the six players whose signings were reported.
The Nation, the weekly magazine of political commentary, announced yesterday that it had absorbed Frontier, a monthly liberal magazine published in Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- The Administration heard today of a sense of insecurity among farmers despite higher farm income and the disappearance of surpluses in key crops.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--President Johnson reiterated today in strong terms his refusal to stop the bombing of North Vietnam without some reciprocal reduction of mili
SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 20-- Gov. George Romney asked the American people today to judge him as a citizen with individual views rather than as a member of his church.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 21 (AP)--United States Air Force fighter-bombers attacked a motor convoy in North Vietnam yesterday and destroyed or damaged 62 vehicles in l0 hours of bombing and strafing, the United States command said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- Consumer prices, taken as a whole, remained stable for the first time in a year last month, the Labor Department reported today.
Most of Buddy Gilmour's troubles--his application for an owner-trainer-driver license has been denied by the New York State Harness Racing Commission--were traced yesterday to a punch on the chin.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 20-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk is scheduled to fly back to Washington tomorrow to report to President Johnson that progress has been made on planning for Latin-American economic integration with long-term United States help.
Directors of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., voted yesterday in Wilmington, Del., to maintain the quarterly dividend rate at $1.25 a share despite a five per cent decline in earnings last year.
The Green Bay Packers hit the jackpot with a total individual payoff of $24,813 for taking the National Football League title and Super Bowl games.

VALDOSTA, Ga., Feb. 20 (AP) --All aircraft at Moody Air Force Base were ordered grounded today after it was discovered that 12 jets used in pilot training had been tampered with, the Air Force announced.
The National Gallery of Art confirmed yesterday that it had become the owner of the only generally acknowledged painting by Leonardo da Vinci outside Europe.

A New York freelance writer disclosed yesterday that the Central Intelligence Agency had supported a foundation that sent hundreds of Americans to World Youth Festivals in Vienna in 1959 and Helsinki, Finland, in 1962.
A six-month-old court order enjoining several milk dealers in the metropolitan area from controlling milk prices was rescinded yesterday by State Supreme, Court Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff.
Time magazine said yesterday that photographs published in its current issue show that five aides of President Kennedy were present during the swearing in of President Johnson on Nov. 22, 1963.

MADRID, Feb. 20--Plans of the University of Massachusetts to publish two volumes of Leonardo da Vinci's manuscripts belonging to the National Library here appeared tonight to be threatened with collapse.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. ENTERPRISE, off North Vietnam, Feb. 17--When targets are assigned to the pilots of Attack Squadron 35 aboard this carrier, it is usually done on a random basis--but not when the target is Namdinh.
Multimillion-dollar mergers involving companies in aerospace, materials handling, chemicals, building materials and textiles were proposed yesterday.

The president of the Association of American Railroads says his industry "is more than willing to cooperate" with the Government to stem the losses of long-haul passenger service in the United States, Travel Weekly reported.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20-- The top-ranking representative body of the University of California's 8,500 full-time faculty members voted today against the introduction of tuition at the institution. The group urged that admissions be limited if necessary to maintain educational quality in the face of a tightened budget.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 20--F. Skiddy von Stade Sr., one of the country's best-known horsemen and a polo player of distinction in that sport's golden era in the nineteen-twenties, died here yesterday at his home in Powell's Lane. Death was attributed to a heart attack. He was 82 years old.
Directors of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation proposed yesterday in Bethpage, N.Y., a three-for-two split of the common shares.
The Johnson Administration opened yesterday a small, but significant, loophole in the coverage of the interest-equalization tax.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--The State Department emphasized today that neither a treaty to bar the spread of nuclear weapons nor international inspection would interfere with the peaceful development of atomic energy by nonnurlear countries.

Come to us, say the ads from states, counties, cities, utilities and railroads. Come to us, call the wooers of industry through their ad agencies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- Walter P. Reuther said today "we're going to abolish" hourly wages in the automobile industry in 1967 and substitute an annual salary.

The Boston Symphony has announced that New York auditions for fellowships to the Berkshire Music Center at Tanglewood, Lenox, Mass., will be held from March 1 to 4 and from April 12 to 15 in Room 856 of Carnegie Hall.

The United States Commission on Civil Rights, in lashing out at the "racial isolation" caused by de facto school segregation, reiterates what virtually all educators and sociologists recognize--that schools in which disadvantaged Negro children predominate operate under severe handicaps.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)--The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the Procter Gamble Company of Cincinnati to sell within five years the Houston plant it obtained by acquiring J.A. Folger Co., a coffee company.

"Benefits are an absolutely dead way to raise money," said Mrs. John Barry Ryan 3d, an exotic-looking brunette who was co-chairman of a $100 a person gourmet dinner held last night. The dinner was a benefit that celebrated the reopening of Le Pavillon, restaurant and raised money for the United Nations Children's Fund.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 20 (AP)--Cassius Clay, the heavyweight boxing champion, has lost his appeal that he be deferred from the draft by a unanimous vote, but his attorney said today the fight was far from over.

The 1967 Canadian-American Challenge Cup, a fall series of six road races for international sports cars, will present total awards estimated at $500,000, a 40 per cent increase over last year's value.

Industrial issues led declines along a broad front yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, The dominant factor was increased fears among traders and investors of a tax rise in the annual budget message scheduled for April. These reservations surfaced in Friday's session and were still much alive in yesterday's trading.
SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP)--Dr. Carl Coppolino filed a $1,275,000 suit for damages today against Marjorie C. Farber, widow of the man Dr. Coppolino was found not guilty of murdering.

Twenty-seven foreign-trained nurse are about to be licensed by New York State despite their failure to take or pass qualifying examinations. The move was hailed as helping to ease the nurse shortage here.
Ernie Terrell clamped a brawny arm around Sam Solomon's neck here yesterday and poked his free right thumb at the eyes of his chubby 5-foot-7-inch trainer.

The news magazine Time denied yesterday that it had approached Bertrand Pusell's Peace Foundation for help in obtaining visas for North Vietnam for its newsmen. A spokesman for Newsweek said that magazine had made inquiries to the organization.

MIAMI, Feb. 20--Premier Fidel Castro delivered a strong attack today on Cuban bureaucracy and said that hundreds of administrators would be dis-- missed and some of them jailed for disobeying orders to reduce office personnel.
Held, 6 to 3, that the 1966 law that apportioned the Texas Legislature was defective in that it allowed too much deviation in population between various districts (No. 235, Kilgarlin V. Hill).
Edward J. Power, chairman and president of the Nassau Savings and Loan Association, was elected yesterday to the board of the Savings and Loan Bank of the State of New York.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20-- University of Pennsylvania faculty members who oppose secret germ warfare research threatened today to wear gas masks at the May commencement exercises.
Brooklyn residents were warned by the police yesterday that a hatbox-size drum containing a highly poisonous, corrosive and flammable chemical was missing from a truck.
THE soaring airline stocks have hit some turbulence of late and yesterday a leading brokerage house set out to explain why.

SANFRANCISCO, Feb. 20 --Paul Freeman, a winner in the Dmitri Mitropoulos International Music Competition in New York last month, was named today as a guest conductor for three concerts of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra next week.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 20--Two leaders of the American Federation of Teachers were sentenced to jail today for criminal contempt of court growing out of last month's teachers' strike in Woodbridge.

A $500,000 musical version of "Casablanca," the Academyaward winning film of 1943, is being prepared for a Broadway premiere on Oct. 23. Arthur Schwartz, who will do the score, and Julius J. Epstein, the adapter, will be the sponsors. Lyrics will be by Leo Robin.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI)--President Johnson announced today that he would renominate Rutherford M. Poats to be Deputy Administrator of the Agency for International Development.

Clifford Curzon appears too seldom in New York, a fact emphasized by his playing as soloist in Beethoven's "Emperor" Concerto with the Cleveland Orchestra in Carnegie Hall last night. It was the English pianist's only orchestral appearance here of the season.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 20--Reports that Indian student and youth groups have received funds from foundations connected with the Central Intelligence Agency have shocked and dismayed leaders of Indian youth movements.
CHICAGO, Feb. 20--The directors of the Monon Railroad today elected Samuel T. Brown as chairman, president and chief executive officer.
A Brooklyn man returned from work yesterday afternoon and found his wife, his sister-in-law and his 5-year-old son shot dead in their Crown Heights apartment.
DETROIT, Feb. 20 (AP)-- Bad weather, labor troubles and lagging sales continue to cut into automobile production.
A NEW catering service, Call Cuisine, which specializes in French dishes, operates from a tiny store at 1073 First Avenue (at 58th Street).

BERCHTESGADEN, Germany, Feb. 20 (AP)--Norwegian skiers took the first three places today in the men's 15-kilometer (9.3-mile) crosscountry race, the opening event of the International Winter Games for the Deaf.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- John H. Glenn Jr., the first American to orbit the earth, said today the the deaths of three Apollo astronauts were a part of the price man must pay in his quest for knowledge.
A slight increase in dock hiring in the port last month was reported yesterday by the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- The Supreme Court declined today to rehear the appeal of Z.T. Osborn Jr., a Nashville, Tenn., lawyer, who was convicted of attempting to corrupt a jury in a trial involving James R. Hoffa, the teamsters union president.

NORWOOD; Mass., Feb. 20-- The Rev. and Mrs. Walton Denson Moffitt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Perry-Lynn Moffitt, to Robert L. Henn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Henn of Pittsford, N.Y.

The F.D.R.-Woodrow Wilson Reform Democratic club on the upper West Side, one of the city's largest, expressed sharp reservations last night about President Johnson's policies in Vietnam and warned that unless he changed them he would lose the support of Democrats in 1968.

JERUSALEM (Israel), Feb. 20--An influential Israeli newspaper said today that the Government had tried to keep the trial and conviction of two editors secret "not as a result of security considerations but out of political considerations."

The Crystal Room, a bar that is under court stricture because its topless waitresses revealed too much, was accused yesterday by the State Liquor Authortty of having covered up the fact that its director of entertainment was an ex-convict.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--The Treasury bill rate continued its upward movement at today's action, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI)--General Dynamics Corporation said tonight that the Soviet Union was interested in buying an advanced two-man research submarine.
Five members of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center will offer a 45-minute program called "Repertory in Action" to more than 50,000 metropolitan area high school students over the next months.

About 300 freshmen at the City University's five temporary centers picketed the headquarters of the Board of Higher Education yesterday, charging that they were being denied the opportunity to switch to fouryear courses.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 20--George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., spoke out strongly today against any effort by the Central Intelligence Agency to use or subsidize the labor movement.

A NORELL dress is something to grow up to. The women who have acquired enough social security and affluence to wear clothes by the dean of American designers are not likely to forget their first Norell dress.

ROCHESTER, Feb. 20 (AP) --A nun was killed and a priest was severely burned today as they tried to save chalices and consecrated holy communion wafers from a fire that swept through St. Philip Neri Roman Catholic Church.
For the second time during the current winter cruise season, several hundred passengers were up against the bar yesterday--sandbar that is.
MOSCOW, Feb. 20 (AP)--Soviet military leaders asserted today that the Soviet Union had developed an antiballistic missile system that would protect it from attack.

Nathaniel C. Tuxbury, a retired automotive executive who helped set up General Motors plants in many parts of the world, died Sunday in Doctors Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 535 Park Avenue.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday in Burbank, Calif., that earnings last year rose 9.5 per cent to a new high on a 15 per cent increase in sales.

Twelve handicapped Harlem children, whose classroom display on Negro History Week was motly ignored last week by the community, will be "special guest lecturers" at Cornell University's week-long commemoration of contemporary Negro life next week.
A conflict has arisen among city departments over implementing the stringent new airpollution controls on apartmenthouse incinerators.

BONN, Feb. 20--Against a background of rising public opposition to a nonproliferation treaty, the West German Government insisted today that the pact provide guarantees for national security and scientific development.

ALBANY, Feb. 20--Two men involved in the long battle over legislative reapportionment last year recommended today that the forthcoming state Constitutional Convention turn the job over to a nonpartisan commission.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 20-- Frank J.V. Gimino, an assistant Hudson County prosecutor for 15 years until his retirement five years ago, died last night at his home, 545 Pavonia Avenue here. He was 76 years old.

John A. McCollum, a former civll engineer, who retired as chief of the franchise bureau of the Board of Estimate in 1934, died Saturday in his home, 14918 Bayside Avenue, Flushing, Queens. He was 93 years old.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20--How far can a late model stock-racing car go on 22 gallons of gas at 175 to 180 miles an hour? In practice over the last two weeks, the maximum distance has been 88.5 miles. That's only a fraction better than four miles to a gallon.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 (AP)--William C. Bullitt, first United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, was buried today after a funeral service in Holy Trinity Episcopal Church. Mr. Bullitt died of leukemia Wednesday in Paris at the age of 74.
Long-term interest rates continued to move higher yesterday, but some short-term rates, assisted by the Federal Reserve, declined slightly in the day.

A drawing by an Indian in a newly completed hall at the American Museum of Natural History shows five cavalrymen fleeing from a single pursuing Dakota. Anothex shows a lone brave galloping, fearlessly into, the midst of a troop of 20 soldiers.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 20--Organized labor's high command told Walter P. Reuther today that it would consider his complaints only if he expressed them through the machinery of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial organizations.
BAY SHORE, L.I., Feb. 20-- The summer people are planning to return in anger to Fire Island next Thursday night to fight a plan for a $300,000 addition to the schoolhouse.

Former officials of the National Student Association said yesterday that the Central Intelligence Agency had helped subsidize students who had been exiled from their homelands for fighting colonial regimes supported by official United States policy.
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 20--A local law to permit Nassau County to acquire the 17 private bus companies that serve Nassau residents was introduced to the Board of Supervisors today.

Outstanding bankers' dollar acceptances in the United States on Jan. 31 totaled $3,601,000,000, or $2-million below the record registered on Dec. 31, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The January level was $269-million above the level a year earlier.

MOUNTAINSIDE, N.J., Feb. 20--Ronald L. Farrell of 298 Timberline Road, treasurer of the Beneficial Management Corporation of Morristown and a former member of the Borough Council here, died Saturday of a heart attack. He was 49 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) --The Supreme Court refused today to review rulings by Illinois courts that the Illinois Central Railroad, rather than the state or city, owns certain filled lands along Chicago's Lake Michigan waterfront.

QUONSET POINT, R.I, Feb. 20--Mr. and Mrs. Paul Donnelly have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia A. Donnelly, to David L. Gilpatric. He is the son of Mrs. Corbett Gilpatric of New York and Mount Desert, Me., and of Chadbourne Gilpatric of New Delhi, N.Y., and Mount Desert. The wedding is planned for June 17.

After failing in its verbal appeal for a rollback in gasoline price increases, the Interior Department is getting tough with the oil industry. Its officials have threatened to raise the quotas on imports of cheap foreign oil; they talk ominously of other measures to boost oil supplies to force a cut in gasoline prices.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP)-- Frank Sinatra's wife, Mia Farrow, and the Italian actresses Gina Lollobrigida and Virna Lisi have been chosen to be presented to Britain's Princess Margaret at next Monday's Royal Film Show.

Ernest R. Bauer, president of B.N.S. International Sales Corporation, 52 Broadway, world traders in food products and agricultural commodies, died Sunday of a heart ailment in his home, 785 Fifth Avenue. He was 45 years old.
Marine engineers can turn down job opportunities with the Military Sea Transportation Service and still qualify for unemployment insurance, according to the New York State Insurance Appeal Board.

I. MILLER, has remodeled its shoe store at 450 Fifth Avenue (40th Street), renamed it Galleria, and ex panded its coverage. Starting today it will sell not only shoes but also clothes that are color-coordinated to shoes and othor accessories. Store executives call this "The Total Look." ...
Benedict T. Harter and Henry A. Supplee have been elected vice presidents of Becton, Dickinson Co.

NEWARK, Feb, 20--Eric M. Mann, a husky 24-year-old white teacher in a "98 per cent" Negro elementary school, said today that he would fight his suspension as an eighth-grade teacher "not with a lawyer but with the parents of my students."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI)--Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, asked Interior Secretary Stewart L. Udall today to prevent construction of a high-rise motel unit with neon signs near the Virginia end of Key Bridge.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 21-- Confusion and controversy deepened today over allegations that the Central Intelligence Agency had pressured a Japanese interpreter here into softening political statements by Joan Baez, pacifist American folk singer, during her Tokyo television appearance Jan. 27.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 (UPI)--Abe Woodson, a defensive back with the St. Louis Cardinals, traded in his football uniform for green stamps today.
JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 20-- The Department of Justice went before a newly convened Federal grand jury today to seek new indictments in two civil rights murder cases.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange in the month ended on Feb. 15 rose to 13,399,913 shares, from 12,531,230 shares in the month ended Jan. 13.

MOSCOW, Feb. 20 (Reuters) --The Soviet Union today accused Mao Tse-tung, chaiaman of the Chinese Communist party, of casting aside the party and attempting to set up a one-man dictatorship based on the army, the secret police and groups such as the Red Guards.
DALLAS, Feb. 20 (AP)-- Curtis Cokes, the world welterweight champion, knocked out young Ted Whitfield with a right uppercut in the third round of a scheduled 10-round nontitle fight tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--If the 1968 Republican National Convention is held in Houston delegates will have the run of 326 private clubs where liquor is said to be served in more ways than in legal bars. Furthermore, the Houston Astrodome has many rooms that are guaranteed never to become smoke-filled, even if the ladies puff cigars.

ELIA KAZAN, the movie director, published his first work of fiction. "America America," in 1962. It was, in fact, an autobiograhically inspired screenplay though without technical directions; it told the story of an energetic Armenian's escape from Turkey to America in the early years of the century, and it enjoyed a considerable sales success. DETROIT, Feb. 20--The auto industry asked for "realistic" motor vehicle standards to reduce air pollution and enough time to meet them, in a hearing today before a Senate subcommittee here.
MIAMI, Feb. 20 (AP)--Sam Ellis, a Cincinnati Reds pitcher, shot a 75 today to take the lead at the halfway mark of the Baseball Players golf tournament with a 36-hole score of 150.

HONG KONG, Feb. 20--Communist China declared today that the situation in Vietnam was "in a crucial stage, with "imperialism, modern revisionism and reaction" exerting military and political pressure on North Vietnam "more flagrantly than ever before."
Mr. and Mrs. Milton Fried of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Fried, to Michael David Wolin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene R. Wolin of New York.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 21 Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that the whites of Rhodesia were as much entitled as Africans to have their rights guaranteed by law.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 21 A Senator from the Government party resigned today because of his opposition to Australia's involvement in the Vietnam war, leaving the administration without a working majority in the Senate.

HONOLULU, Feb. 21 (AP) The National Football League changed its fair-catch rule today, adopted a new single-standard slingshot-type goalpost and set the dates and sites for its two divisional playoff games.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 21 Chuck McKinley of Port Washington, L.I., was beaten by Torben Ulrich of Denmark after having stood within a stroke of victory in the international invitation indoor tennis tournament at the Concord Hotel today. The scores were 6-4, 0-6, 7-5.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin urged today an immediate and unconditional halt of American bombing of North Vietnam as the first step toward a political settlement of the war.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Feb. 21 (UPI) A Navy jet from an aircraft carrier just returned from Vietnam crashed into a home near this resort today, injuring five persons, two of them critically.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 21 (AP) Villanova held Jim Walker to 5 points tonight and upset Providence, 55-52. Walker, who had averaged nearly 30 points a game, made only two of 20 field-goal attempts against a zone defense.

TO Howie Young, the ice in the arenas of the National Hockey League once was incidental to his existence. The ice in his drinks was much more important.
A spirited and hardy group of athletes from 10 metropolitan colleges battled 30-mile winds, freezing temperatures and competition yesterday at New York University's Ohio Field in the Bronx.
Directors of the KimberlyClark Corporation voted here yesterday to raise the company's quarterly dividend to 55 cents a common share from 50 cents in previous quarters.

U.S. Industries, Inc., a diversified company, offered yesterday to buy substantially all of the assets of the Lunkenheimer Company for $19-million in stock. The offer outbid the recent tender of the Condec Corporation for 51 per cent of Lunkenheimer stock.

Indian Head, Inc., has announced the election of James W. Morrison as a group vice president. He was formerly managing director of Aba Textile Mills, Ltd., a Nigerian subsidiary.
Continued talk of good export sales as well as dry weather over Southwest winter wheat areas lifted wheat futures prices again yesterday. At day's end gains ranged from 3 to 4 1/8 cents a bushel.

ONE of the more popular exhibits at the New York Sport and Camping Show, which will run through Sunday at the Coliseum, is the New York State Conservation Department's display.

James E. Gellert, executive director of the former Home for Aged Sons Daughters of Israel at 232 East 12th Street from 1947 to 1962, died in Phoenix Ariz., Monday while on vacation. He lived at 170 Second Avenue.

Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, who was as closely associated with the American thoroughbred scene as the horse itself in the minds of so many track enthusiasts, will have his memory perpetuated at Hialeah Park. NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 21 (AP) Boston College scored its 16th victory in 18 basketball starts as it defeated Boston University tonight, 74-46.

William D. Eckert, Commissioner of Baseball, said yesterday that the major league executive council would meet on March 1 and March 31 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

WHILE yesterday was a dull day in Wall Street, broadly speaking, there was still room for talk. And talk people did. JAKARTA, Indonesia, Wednesday, Feb. 22 (UPI)--The Indonesian Army newspaper War News said today that President Sukarno was reported to have resigned unconditionally. It said an official announcement might be made later today or tomorrow.

Max O. Urbahn, architect, was elected yesterday as president of the New York Board of Trade. As president, he succeeds James T. Gill, vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, who becomes chairman.

The 18-nation disarmament committee reconvenes today in a time of renewed hope. Conclusion of a treaty banning weapons of mass destruction in outer space, and a treaty for a Latin-American nuclear-free zone, give new impetus to the effort to bring the arms race under control.

Sydney O. Crystal, an early real estate developer on the East Side, including the Sutton Place area, and in the Bronx, died yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 78 years old and lived at 190 Meadow View Avenue, Hewlett, L.I.
