A skating and buffet supper party, to be held from 6 to 8 P.M. on March 10 at the Riverdale Ice Skating Rink, will aid the James Weldon Johnson Community Center's teen-age program. Invitations have been sent to private school students in grades 7 through 12.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 21 State Senator Robert O. Tiernan of Warwick defeated former Governor John A. Notte Jr., of North Providence today in a special primary to choose a Democratic candidate for the late John E. Fogarty's seat in the U.S. House of Representatives.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 21 Jamaica kept to a moderate center course today with an electral victory for the incumbent Jamaica Labor party.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino said yesterday that salary raises of $500 to $4,000 given to 67 senior staff members in his office were "based on merit and will not cost the taxpayers a penny."

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 21 For the first time, an anti discrimination clause was written into contracts between the Town of North Hempstead and eight volunteer fire departments signed today. The contracts total $295,331.
DETROIT, Feb. 21. (AP) The General Motors Corporation announced tonight that at least 80,000 of its workers would be laid off this week as a result of a strike at Mansfield, Ohio.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 21 Nineteen persons, including three clergymen, were arrested here today on disorderly conduct charges for blocking trucks at the $25-million construction of The Mall, a downtown shopping center.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) A first sergeant from Florida was named today to the Air Force's top enlisted post, Chief Master Sergeant of the Air Force.
Willlam Richmond, a retired banker and former executive manager of the War Finance Committee for New York, died on Monday at Doctors Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 245 East 21st Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 Wilson Co. told shareholders at their annual meeting today that the company was proceeding with its regular business on assurance from its new major partner, Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., of Dallas, that it would not interfere with Wilson's management or operations.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Feb. 21 Troops occupied the campus of the University of Lovanium today after a riot last night by 2,000 students. The students, who included 25 girls, were suspended and the university closed.
ALBANY, Feb. 21--The Assembly, in its longest debate of the session, defeated legislation tonight that would have prohibited all forms of electronic eavesdropping.
WASHINGTON, Feb, 21 Following are excerpts from the text of a statement today by Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin, retried, before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee:
OXFORD, Miss., Feb. 21 (AP) Phil Stone, a lawyer who was a close friend of the late William Faulkner, died Monday in a Jackson hospital at the age of 74.
MOSCOW, Feb. 21 A Soviet order has prohibited Chinese newsmen from taking photogarphs in the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, Feb. 21--A plump, middle-aged bookkeeper disputed today a key allegation of the Government in the trial of John (Sonny) Franzese and four others charged with arranging a series of nationwide bank robberies in 1965.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 New Government figures disclosed today a sudden upsurge of consumer saving in the final quarter of last year, a counterpart of the puzzling slowdown in retail sales, including automobile purchases.
TRENTON, Feb. 21 (AP) The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad has agreed to restore 18 passenger trains on its main and Bergen lines, State Transportation Commissioner David J. Goldberg disclosed today.

GENEVA, Feb. 21 President Johnson assured the nonnuclear powers today that if they accepted a treaty prohibiting the spread of nuclear weapons, it would not hinder their development of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes.

MIAMI, Feb. 21 Aided by Nassau County District Attorney William Cahn from New York State, Florida officials raided a private house with 12 phones here and arrested a man for running a gambling establishment.
Irving Brodsky, a lawyer and realty investor here, has contracted to buy 26 industrial buildings of one and two stories within a one-mile radius in the heart of downtown Houston.
The Union Carbide Corporation has reorganized the management of the billion-dollar-ayear, chemicals and plastics portion of its business, the company announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 An 80-pound, two-volume, 350page scrapbook that cost $18 to send air express to Washington won the Cleanest Town grand prize today for San Antonio, Tex.
A call for a new approach to forest management was sounded yesterday by Karl R. Bendetsen, chairman and president of Champion Papers, Inc.

Norman Thomas, the former Socialist Party leader, defended yesterday a program under which Latin-American politicians of the democratic left were trained largely at the expense of the Central Intelligence Agency.

The American Electric Power Company filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 1.2 million shares of common stock to be offered at competitive bidding. Based on yesterday's closing price of 40 5/8, the offering would be worth more than $48.6-million.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 Miss Patricia Sue Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Smith of Dougherty, Iowa, was married today to Eric R. Fox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Fox of New York.

Winners of the Tony Awards, emblematic of the best that arrived on Broadway between May 25, 1966, and Feb. 18 of this year, will be selected from 64 nominees in 16 categories. The ballots are now in the mail to the 500 persons, affiliated with every branch of Broadway's theater industry, who will do the voting.

The quiet man who came to the city "as a stranger" just a year ago to take over the police force, and whose coming threatened to touch off a departmental revolt, looked back yesterday and found that it had been a good year.
A Bronx synagogue caretaker gave himself up to police yesterday in connection with the rape and assault of a 19-yearold girl in the synagogue last Thursday.

The series of eight New York concerts celebrating the centenary of the Oberlin Colleeg Conservatory of Music, reached its halfway point last night at Town Hall. The event was a piano recital by Emil Danenberg.

The Administration is maintaining a restrictive policy on prices while seeking little restraint on future inflationary wage demands, M. A. Wright, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said here yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 Doug Jones took the bigger slice of the purse, but that's about all he won tonight at the Arena in his heavyweight bout with undefeated Joe Frazier.
"MacBird!" flies tonight, at long last, and there is reason to believe that it will be in the air for a while no matter what potshots the critics may take at it.

Top officials of the predominantly Protestant Masons and the Roman Catholic Knights of Columbus, organizations whose hostility has roots in the 18th century, announced yesterday they would form joint national programs in the "moral, civic and social action fields."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 A select committee examining the right of Representative Adam Clayton Powell to keep his House seat struggled without success for six hours today to reach unanimous agreement.
AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 21 Dr. Edward C. Moore, dean of the University of Massachusetts Graduate School, said today:
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 Men's wear retailers were urged today by a leading manufacturer to increase their mark-ups in order to end up with a fair profit on the bottom line of the ledger.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 American officials denied today Soviet charges that the United States was seeking a political alliance with Communist China against Moscow.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 Men's wear retailers were urged today by a leading manufacturer to increase their mark-ups in order to end up with a fair profit on the bottom line of the ledger.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 American officials denied today Soviet charges that the United States was seeking a political alliance with Communist China against Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 After all the mysterious disclosures about the Central Intelligence Agency's secret operations among the students and foundations of America, one mystery remains: Why did all the intelligent people around the President not intervene to change the policy before it became a public scandal?

Malcolm Mackenzie, formerly a real estate man who took part in major construction projects in London, including Berkeley Square House, a huge office building, died here Thursday. He was 72 years old and lived at 485 Park Avenue.
SACRAMENTO, Calif. Feb. 21 (UPI) Gov. Ronald Reagan said today that he was planning to be a "favorite son" can didate in California's Rebublican Presidential primary in 1968.

MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 21 (AP) A state court was asked today to enjoin the Smithsonian Institution from raising and taking possession of the Union ironclad Tecumseh, sunk in the battle of Mobile Bay more than a century ago.
A team of biochemists at the National Institutes of Health has demonstrated that various organisms use the same genetic language, but that they may to speak in different dialects.

Mayor Lindsay signed a local law yesterday permitting homeowners to pay local assessments for sewer improvements predating Jan. 1, 1963, over a fiveyear period. Such assessments became citywide after that date.

Many Americans are incredulous today when reminded how their country's Government herded 110,000 persons into concentration camps during World War II without legal process and kept them behind barbed wire for up to four years. About 70,000 of them were American citizens by birth: Their only crime was their Japanese ancestry. Their suffering was great, their economic loss incalculable.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 (AP) The Rev. Marshall L. Shepard, a councilman at large on Philadelphia's City Council since 1955, died today at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 67 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP)--President Johnson announced today that he would nominate Richard H. Nolte to be Ambas- sador to the United Arab Republic.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 21 Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Adler of Shaker Heights have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss June Adler, to David J. Vail, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah H. Vail of Upper St. Clair, Pa.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--A new type of Government savings bond, to be called a "freedom share" and to bear a higher rate of interest than traditional savings bonds, will go on sale May 1.
Earnings of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., fell 18 per cent last year despite a rise in sales, the company reported yesterday.
PEORIA, Ill., Feb. 21 The second day of jury selection in the Richard F. Speck murder trial ended today with the first juror yet to be empaneled.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 The annual battle over where adoption cases should be handled was fought again today in the senate. After a thirty-minute debate, the upper house passed, 45-11, a measure extending concurrent jurisdiction over adoptions in the Surrogates' and Family Courts.

FLEETWOOD, Pa., Feb. 21 Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Zakrison have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen L. Zakrison, to Roger A. Whyman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin N. Whyman of Woodmere, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) Miami Beach made an $800,000 bid to the Republicans today to hold their Presidential nominating convention of 1968 in the Florida resort city. Of the total, $650,000 would be in cash and $150,000 in services.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 Richard Helms, director of the Central Intelligence Agency told a Senate watchdog committee today that the agency would withdraw financial assistance from a number of non-Government organiza tions.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21 The innovators are the boys responsible for the 75 sportsman and modified cars entered in Saturday's 300-mile Permatex Trophy race here.
The Greek Line yesterday terminated the current 12-day Caribbean cruise of its flagship Queen Anna Maria at Kingston, Jamaica, where the vessel ran aground Sunday morning while entering port.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 21 (AP) The official death toll in Rio de Janeiro and its sister city of Niteroi rose to 119 today after two days of floods and landslides.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 The Johnson Administration made it clear today that it had neither hardened nor softened its position on talking peace with North Vietnam.
Agreement was reached yesterday between the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and the Long Island Rail Road on new contract terms providing a 16 per cent wage increase over the next 20 months.

The Budget Finance Plan announced yesterday it would offer its shareholders of record Feb. 28 the right to purchase 498,220 shares of 6 per cent referred stock and warrants, to buy 99,644 common shares.

Mrs. Molly Howe Lynn of New York and Madison, Wis., and Myron Lynn of Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kate Howe Lynn, to Michael S. Levy of Washington. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip K. Levy of Yonkers.
Spectators attending the 1967 United States Open golf championship will be advised of the progress of play by a new electronic information service.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21 (AP) The newly-formed National Professional Soccer League awarded a franchise to Boston today.
A 21-year-old youth shot and wounded himself in Brooklyn yesterday the police said, when detectives tried to capture him on charges of killing his mother, aunt and 5-year-old half brother.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lauder's vast white mansion was the setting last night for another of the little extravaganzas Palm Beach does so well, and despite a rainstorm that played havoc with what was supposed to have been dancing under the stars, everything went pretty much as planned.

PARIS--Mai Van Bo is a rather jovial North Vietnamese who puffs a pipe professorially, serves a pungent brand of tea, and receives visitors at No. 2 rue le Verrier near Montparnasse in a sitting room dominated by a large photograph of Ho Chi Minh.
MOSCOW, Feb. 22--Two Soviet military leaders conceded tonight that antimissile defense systems could not prevent all enemy rockets from reaching their targets.
WARSAW, Feb. 22--A conference of European Communist parties opened here today, but not all seats were occupied.
Manhattan took first, second and fourth in the pole vault yesterday to move ahead of St. John's for team honors in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate track and field championships.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Feb. 22--Gov. George Romney got an encouraging political assist today as he moved into the fourth state of his Western campaign tour.
Alexander Brailowsky returned to Carnegie Hall last night for a typical bravura program, and the pianist's familiar style seemed to please his audience.
BERCHTESGADEN, Germany, Feb. 22(AP)--Tamara Marcinuk of Fitchburg, Mass., won the women'S giant slalom ski race today at the International Winter Games for the Deaf.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 22 (AP)--Rising Market won the $62,550 San Felipe Handicap in a rousing finish of 3-year-old Derby hopefuls that was decided by a nose, a neck and a nose before a crowd of 46,679.

Not all the action in the city's art auction market takes place in Manhattan. In Forest Hills yesterday, there was standing room only and an overflow crowd on the sidewalk at Haber's, which has become sort of a Parke-Bernet of Queens. Two-hundred people jammed into the 20-by-100-foot store at 116-49 Queens Boulevard.

IT is, reputation and bill boards assure me, a Mr. Howard Johnson who comes in 28 flavors. True artists better him. Martha Graham comes in so many flavors that the taste buds all but rebel, yet gratefully.
The appointment of Gibson F. Dailey as president and chief administrative officer of Brown Matthews, Inc., an engineering and construction concern of Union, N.J., has been announced.

The General Electric Company had record sales last year, but its profits were depressed by a strike, shortage of skilled labor, heavy costs in developing its computer and nuclearpower business, and too much business in certain other areas.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 22 (UPI)--Second-ranked Louisville, paced by Westley Unseld and Jerry King with 20 points apiece, routed Drake tonight, 86-63, and won the Missouri Valley Conference title.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Feb. 22 (AP)--County Solicitor Carl Harper began an investigation today of the death of a man who left Dallas after President Kennedy's assassination because, his brother contends, he was being constantly questioned by "agents" or "plotters."

BARBARA GARSON, the author of "MacBird!" is like someone who has suddenly thought of something funny to say at a party, who has blurted out the beginning of the joke only to realize that it is hurtling her headlong toward embarrassing consequences, and who has then plunged on anyway--hurriedly, boldly, wistfully, boorishly --hoping against hope that something, anything, would turn up to save the day.
Paperboard production rose 2.9 per cent to 459,000 tons in the week ended Feb. 19 from 445,900 tons in the corresponding week last year, the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

Dr. Frederick H. Frost, vice president in charge of research for the S.D. Warren Company, Cumberland Mills, Me., was honored yesterday by the Technical Association of the Pulp and Paper Industry for his pioneering work in the field of coatings for paper.
The city was urged by engineering consultants yesterday to plan and build the proposed Cross Brooklyn Expressway without delay.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 22--The engagement of Miss Patricia Ann D'Alvia to Patrick F. Foley, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Foley of Woodside, Queens, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Carl R. D'Alvia.

Frank Wille, the youthful New York State Superintendent of Banks, recommended yesterday legislation that would force some 350 trustees and directors of savings banks and savings and loan associations who were over 75 years old to retire by Dec. 31, 1970.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22--A 500-mile public road trip in the family car is seldom completed in fewer than l0 hours. Even that time requires an average of 50 miles an hour, a rather difficult feat considering that stops at red lights and gas stations must be made.
SAN DIEGO, Feb. 22 (AP) --A $30,000 insurance award has been made to a widow who contends that her husband died of lung cancer because the pressures of his job caused him to smoke excessively.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 22 (UPI)--Harmon Killebrew, one of the lading sluggers in baseball, has agreed to a 1967 contract for a salary estimated at $65,000, the Minnesota Twins said today.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 22-- Plans have been approved for a subway system here that will cost nearly $200-million, the Mayor of Mexico City said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)--A group of prominent citizens announced today a $5million fund raising campaign to build a cathedral tower as a memorial to Sir Winston Churchill.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 22-- The Minnesota-Dakotas Regional Conference of the National Student Association has adopted a resolution deploring "the covert and clandestine relationship that has existed between N.S.A. officers and the Central Intelligence Agency."

LAST spring a 16-man round robin zonal tournament was played in Buenos Aires to determine three South American qualifiers for the interzonal. The six highest scorers in the interzonal-- which is to be played in Tunis in August--become candidates for the right to challenge the world chess champion.

The Crucible Steel Company of America registered yesterday its objection to a report by the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday that trading volume in the company's shares on Jan. 5 had been incorrectly computed.

BONN, Feb. 22--Fritz Erler, deputy chairman of West Germany's Social Democratic party and one of the most influential men in the country's postwar politics, died today at his home in Pforzheim in southern Germany. He was 53 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--A select committee of the House was reported today to have agreed to recommend the seating of Adam Clayton Powell with censure and salary deductions for unauthorized spending of public funds.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 22 (AP) --Gala Performance, twice runner-up to Misty Cloud in previous Maryland-bred stakes races at Bowie, turned the tables today and won the $24,300 Prince Georges Stakes by a neck.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12--The University of Chicago ended today its practice of ranking male students in a separate category for use in determining draft deferments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--The key factor in the decision to call off plans to eliminate gradually free burial sites for veterans was that some national cemeteries, filled to capacity, were turning away persons killed in Vietnam.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 22--James S. Bixby, district engineer for the State Department of Public Works for 32 years, died today at his home here. He was 80 years old.

Mrs. Vera Goldman, a victim of a fire, died at Bellevue Hospital yesterday 26 hours after she had been sent there by ambulance from Lenox Hill Hospital. The transfer of the critically injured patient while she was in a state of shock was characterized Wednesday by Bellevue Hospital's administrator, Dr. Randolfp A. Wyman, as "not very food medicine."

ROME, Feb. 22--Pope Paul VI invited all Christians today to join in the celebration of "a year of faith" to honor SS. Peter and Paul, whose martyrdom 19 centures ago the Roman Catholic Church is celebrating this year.

A bill was introduced yesterday in the Legislature to appropriate $180,000 for the New York State Council on the Arts, to support summer festivals in for the arts. The bipartisan bill calls for hiring professional people in the arts, both performers and personnel, to set up new fesctivals and revitalize existing ones.

LONDON, Feb. 22--A group of four of Britain's leading shipping companies announced today that it would spend more than $117-million for container ships that would revolutionize cargo transport between Britain and Australia.
LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP)-- The executive committee of the giant Trades Union Congress rejected tonight the Labor Government's proposals to continue a freeze on wages and prices for another year.
The appointment of William T. Marx and Frank J. Pizzitola as executive vice presidents was announced here yesterday by the Celanese Corporation, a producer of chemicals and fibers.
Dr. Giuseppe Tomasulo, a retired general practitioner, died yesterday in his home at 21-25 34th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens. He was 89 years old.
CHICAGO, Feb. 22--A top executive of the National Council of Churches charged today that Representative Adam Clayton Powell had been stripped of his rights without due process of law.

The New York Stock Exchange yesterday characterized 1966 as "the year of the institutions," and then went on to give a slap on the wrist to one of its best customers, the performance-oriented mutual funds.
Herb Lubalin likes type, knows type and admires ad men who show they can use type creatively.
Two Queens patrolmen reported yesterday that they had to force a couple to leave a burning house at 40-12 20th Avenue, Astoria.

PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 22 (UPI)--Lunar Orbiter 3 finished its successful moon-photographing mission tonight earlier than planned because of renewed trouble with its film advance mechanism, scientists reported.
F. Lee Bailey has received hundreds of thousands of dollars in book and movie rights as his payment for representing celebrated defendants in nationally publicized trials during the last year.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 22 --Cornell's hockey team made Harvard its ninth consecutive victim as the Big Red scored a 4-1 victory in Watson Rink, tonight.
LANSING, Mich., Feb. 22 (UPI)--A Negro state legislator urged Governor Romney today to resign from the Mormon church, which he compared to the Black Muslims.

WOODLAND HILLS, Calif., Feb. 22 (AP)--Charles Beaumont, author of many television shows and motion pictures, died yesterday at the Motion Picture Country Home and Hospital after a three-year illness. He was 38 years old.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 22--Arthur Ashe of Richmond defeated Torben Ulrich of Denmark and Thomas Koch of Brazil in succession today and won the first international invitation indoor tennis tournament at the Concord Hotel.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 22 --Civil rights demonstrators carried a flower-decked mock casket to the City Hall today to protest the slaying of 10 Negroes by the authorities in less than 14 months.

Conservative politicians and youth leaders have been puzzled and outraged by the disclosures that the National Student Association received about $3-million from the Central Intelligence Agency in the last 15 years.
Marshal Matt Dillon has been shot down by that potent adversary--old age.

The Rev. Dr. Leslie E. Cooke, associate general secretary of the World Council of Churches, died yesterday at the Neurological Institute of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center of complications following surgery for a brain tumor. He was 58 years old and a British subject.
The election of Ian Willis as a vice president of the TransLux Corporation was announced yesterday by Richard Brandt, president.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 22--The winter meetings here of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations have become almost as much of a focal point for bankers, Government officials, labor consultants and hangers-on as for union leaders.
BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 22 (UPI)--Mario Savio abandoned plans today to seek readmission to the University of California, where he led student demonstrations that rocked political and academic careers.

Mal Graham was munching on a cheeseburger and sipping a strawberry malted between classes. He had emerged from "Advertising Research" and in a few minutes would be on his way across New York University's downtown conCrete campus to "Sociology of Religion."

YONKERS, Feb. 22--Residents blocked the entrance to the state's projected treatment center for narcotics addicts on Sprain Ridge here today with automobiles, baby carriages, leashed dogs and picket lines in another attempt to dissuade the state from opening the center.

CAIRO, Feb. 22--President Gamal Abdel Nasser declared tonight that his country would not pay debts to anyone "who exerts economic pressure on us." His threat, in a speech marking the ninth anniversary of Egypt's shot-lived merger with Syria, was apparently directed principally at the United States. Cairo economists said that $150-million was owed to the United States Government. The country's total foreign debt is more than $1-billion.

PARIS, Feb. 22--A spokesman for Hanoi reaffirmed today its offer to enter into talks with the United States if American bombing attacks against North Vietnam were unconditionally and permanently halted.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 22 (AP) --The Chicago Bulls outscored the New York Knickerbockers, 20-6, in the final seven minutes of the third quarter tonight and went on to record a 117-103 National Basketball Association victory.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22-- Tonight's TV listings on the Washington network are as follows:
PEORIA, Ill., Feb. 22--Judge Herbert C. Paschen issued two written modifications today of his controversial restrictions on news media in the Richard F. Speck murder trial.
AMES, Iowa, Feb. 22--Iowa State University, a hotbed of moderacy for generations, has elected to its surprise a bearded disciple of the New Left as president of the student body.

Representatives of the Roman Catholic Church and the Young Men's Christian Associations announced yesterday that they had held recent meetings to explore the possibility of improved relationships between the two organizations.
GENEVA, Feb. 22--The United States has suggested a compromise for policing in five of the six Euratom nations the proposed treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 22--Sanford Silver, a trial lawyer in Elizabeth, died today in St. Mary's Hospital, Orange, after a short illness. He was 48 years old and lived at 320 South Harrison Street.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 22 --Churchbells clanged across the chill darkness before dawn today and the townsfolk of Donmatias were told that the Vatican had ruled the Rev. Abelardo Arias Arbelaez must obey his bishop and leave Donmatias.
A "good many" Americans are almost untouched by the benefits and extraordinary achievements of modern medicine, John W. Gardner, secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said here yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 22--A central figure in District Attorney Jim Garrison's investigation into the assassination of President Kennedy was found dead in bed today.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., Feb. 22 (AP)--Joseph H. Durrell, a retired banker and big game hunter, died Monday in Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 87 years old.
MACAO, Feb. 22--The most important escape route for refugees from Communist China is apparently being sealed by the Portuguese administrators here.

A drama by Eugene O'Neill may receive its American premiere next season in Los Angeles. The project is being discussed for a six-week presentation in the new 2,000-seat Ahmanson Theater there and a later run in New York.

PARIS, Feb. 22--Premier Georges Pompidou and the leader of the non-Communist left, Francois Mitterrand, met tonight in a heated, sometimes sarcastic, face-to-face debate at a Gaullist rally in central France.

MIAMI, Feb. 22--Bobby Ussery got the mud and the money with Reflected Glory in the $34,050 Everglades Stakes today. The strong-armed jockey from Vian, Okla., urged Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's brown colt from last place through the slop to win the 1 1/8-mile race for 3year-olds, He had a length over Michael Phipps's Gentleman James, with the Holiday Stable's Ask the Fare next in the 15-horse field.

Industrial issues closed with narrow gains on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, stemming a three-day decline.
ALBANY, Feb. 22--Governor Rockefeller and legislative leaders proposed today that the state enact the nation's first compulsory health insurance law.

BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 22 --Cosmic ray detection equip ment, designed at the University of California will be shipped to the United Arab Republic next month to search for hidden burial chambers of the pharaohs in the pyramids at Giza.
MOSCOW, Feb. 22 (UPI)-- A Soviet scientist said today that fluoridation of water could counteract adverse effects in bone tissues of strontium 90, a component of radioactive nuclear fallout.
The appointment of Gerrit Hagenzieker as manager of the Holland-America Line's operating department here was announced yesterday by Albert A. van L. Maas, the line's general North American manager.
Haryou-Act, the controversial agency responsible for Harlem's antipoverty program, announced yesterday the appointment of Charies H. King as its new executive director.
The chairman of the Brockton Taunton Gas Company charged yesterday that Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates was attempting to acquire Brockton illegally.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP)-- Six Protestant monks and two Roman Catholic priests have begun a common life together in a rented home because "it is not possible to preach love for others and be divided yourself."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI)--As a result of the controversy over Central Intelligence Agency use of private channels to funnel money to various groups, a Congressional committee will reopen an investigation of operations of tax-exempt foundations, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--W. Averell Harriman, Ambassador at Large, said tonight that he saw some indications that peace in Vietnam was getting closer. Mr. Harriman, named by President Johnson to serve as a filtering point in the State Department for potential peace leads, said there were signs that the North Vietnamese leaders were "coming around to the point where they may be willing to talk" about a settlement of the war in Vietnam.

If room can be found in April, freshmen with superior grades in the City University's five temporary centers will be admitted directly to senior colleges regardless of their high school averages, Dr. Albert H. Bowker, chancellor of the university, announced yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 22--The chancellor of Syracuse University, William P. Tolley, said today the school would revise its bylaws as a result of the controversy over the eligibility of Dr. Stephen K. Bailey to serve on the state Board of Regents.

OTTAWA, Feb. 22--Ambassador Goldberg conferred on Vietnam with Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson and Paul Martin, Secretary of State for External Affairs, on a visit to Ottawa last Thursday. They discussed Mr. Goldberg's imminent trip to South Vietnam.

ALBANY, Feb. 2--A Protestant legislator made an impassioned attack on the floor of the Senate today against the current bill to liberalize the state's abortion law. He said all abortions were immoral and pledged to do everything in his power to insure that the bill "never sees the light of day."

AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 22--Gov. John B. Connally Jr. of Texas took issue today with a proposal by the Secretary of the Interior, Stewart Udall, for the assumption by the United States of conservation regulation of oil and gas production on the Continental Shelf in the Gulf of Mexico.

Tne Johnson Administration acknowledged last December that American pilots had accidentally struck civilian areas in North Vietnam while hitting at military targets, but the Defense Department, in a formal statement, re-emphasized that it was United States policy to attack only military targets.

Malcolm John MacKenzie Hartsell, a lawyer specializing in insurance negligence cases, died of a heart attack Monday in Patchogue, L.I. He was 56 years old and lived at 154-27 11th Avenue, Beechhurst, Queens.
COLONIA, N.J., Feb. 22-- Christian L. Knudsen, a dog fancier and dog-show judge in the East, died yesterday at his home. He was 66 years old and lived at 263 Pierce Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI)--Gen. Nathan F. Twining of the Air Force, retired, former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that an "antinuclear clique" of scientists had influenced the Government to slow weapons development and thus weaken the United States deterrent to nuclear war.

Increased surcharges, ranging between 133 and 400 per cent, will be applied by London marine underwriters effective next Wednesday on Liberty ships and certain other vessels built during World War II.
BONN, Feb. 22--The West German Government sought today to allay British fears that Bonn plans to withdraw all financial support for the British Army of the Rhine.

THE George Washington Birthday tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association began last night at the New York Hilton. It continues tonight, when the Master Pairs (in two flights, above and below 200 master points) is scheduled at 8 o'clock.
MADISON, Wis., Feb. 22 (UPI)--The chancellor of the University of Wisconsin, Robben Fleming, put up bail money tonight for 18 demonstrators arrested earlier in the day.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP)-- Big Ten athletic directors called today for the University of Illinois to dismiss its football coach, Pete Elliott, its basketball coach, Harry Combes, and an assistant basketball coach, Howard Braun, or show cause why the school's membership in the conference should not be suspended or terminated. The vote was unanimous.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 23 --Units of the Communist Chinese Army have turned on followers of Chairman Mao Tsetung, killing 2 and arresting nearly 1,000 in Honan Province, Japanese reports from Peking said today.

LONDON, Feb. 22--Laurence Daly, general secretary of the Scottish area of the National Union of Mineworkers, declared today on his return from North Vietnam that he was "deeply shocked" by evidence of "deliberate concentration by the United States Air Force on destruction of the civilian population."

AN unusual insight into the realities of the world of commercial television--the agonies of being canceled, the fabulous profit that attends success and the religious considerations that may bear on popular entertainment--was presented in the early hours of yesterday morning by Allen Funt, creator of "Candid Camera."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22--Behind the wheel of his plum-colored Impala, a 1967 stick job with bucket seats, Joe Frazier reverts to type: wide-open extrovert. Friends call his new car "The Jet," and his wife, Florence, sometimes worries more about her husband's fast driving than about his fighting.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 22--President Sukarno has turned over all governmental authority to General Suharto but has retained the title he has held since 1949.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22-- The world's first known white gorilla has been discovered in Africa, the National Geographic Society announced today.

The nation's electric power production rose 6.8 per cent in the week ended Feb. 18, from the level in the corresponding 1966 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

Fifes and drums, bugles and cymbals sounded on Fifth Avenue yesterday, honoring the nation's first President and its war dead.
NEW DELHI, Thursday, Feb. 23--India's Congress party suffered serious new setbacks this morning as opposition parties continued to show unexpected strength in many parts of the country.
A dog was an accomplice yesterday in robbing a 22-yearold nurse of $45.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 22-- An Argentine proposal to create a permanent defense advisory committee in the Organization of American States was defeated today, 11 to 6, at the hemisphere conference of foreign ministers.

The question for the past year in Indonesia was not whether President Sukarno would be removed but when, and whether it could be done without a civil war. The answer to the "when?" came yesterday in his surrender of executive powers to General Suharto. The switch may bring some trouble in Sukarno's stronghold of central and eastern Java, but the probability is that there will be nothing of the magnitude of a civil war.

The 1966 fiscal year was one of unusual prosperity for the airline industry as well as of explosive growth and expansion of every aspect of civil aviation, the Civil Aeronautics Board has told Congress in its annual report made available here yesterday.

The Congress party in India suffered a stunning defeat in the general elections. Prime Minister Gandhi won her own seat easily, but the results as a whole, she conceded, were "very bad." In what appeared to be the largest offensive operation of the Vietnam war, more than 25,000 American troops drove through swamps and jungle near the Cambodian border in search of the secret headquarters of the Vietcong. Directors of the Anaconda Company, the world's largest copper producer, recommended yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock.

MANILA, Feb. 24 (UPI) Chen Ching Po of Taiwan carded a three-under-par 69 for 140 today and moved into a first-place tie with Celestino Tugot of the Philippines in the $39,000 Philippine open golf tournament. Tugot had a 73.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Congressional leaders said today that there would be no special investigation of the Central Intelligence Agency by the legislative branch.

Legislative representatives of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut announced yesterday that they would press for identical bills in the three states to combat air pollution.

The National Theater of the Deaf, which has been in the planning stage since last spring, has received a three-year $331,000 Federal grant to establish a professional acting company under the wing of the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Foundation.

City College overcame a slow start last night to defeat Queens College, 76-50, in the opening round of the City University of New York basketball tournament at Queens College before a capacity crowd of 2,200.
Several decades of dreaming, talking and planning for a place where North and South America can meet are beginning to take shape.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 24 Of 75 states that have replied to an inquiry from Secretary General Thant, all but three have reported that they are applying the economic sanctions imposed on Rhodesia by the Security Council Dec. 16. However, 47 countries have not replied.
A group of professional engineers complained yesterday that Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler was practicing their craft without a license.

The N.A.A.C.P. said yesterday it would file a brief with the Court of Appeals on a $135,000 judgment against Representative Adam Clayton Powell for the alleged transfer of property in Puerto Rico to relatives of his estranged wife.

Coffee drinkers will get a price reduction of 2 to 6 cents a pound on all popular brands of ground coffee Monday morning home mortgages since Ocductions announced by major packers and retailers yesterday. Instant coffees are not affected.

Willard Schilff, a 26-year-old horseman from Kenmore, N.Y., denied yesterday at a New York State Harness Racing Commission hearing that he had punched and knocked out Bud Gilmour at the Island Inn, Westbury, L.I., Jan. 23, 1966.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla. Feb. 24 George Meany said today that he would look into the allegations that some A.F.LC.I.O. unions received financial support from the Central Intelligence Agency.
LONDON, Feb. 24 The Government today barred George Raft from Britain and was reported considering barring another American gambling figure, Dino Cellini.

A Federal judge yesterday ordered the city's Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Milton Helpern, not to interfere with an examination of the findings or an autopsy on Dr. Carl A. Coppolino's first wife, Carmela.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 24 (AP) Secretary General Thant of the United Nations arrived here today amid rising speculation that he might have direct contacts with North Vietnamese representatives in Rangoon.

PARIS, Feb. 23--Senator Jean Lecanuet, the politician who became prominent by campaigning on television for the presidency in 1965, returned to television tonight with an offer to support the Gaullists in the National Assembly if they would adopt policies "to construct a modern France."
Intelligence estimates on the Battle of the Boston Run indicated yesterday that the opposition was capturing a sizable number of Boston-New York air commuters.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Feb. 24 Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Flanner Patterson Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla White Patterson, to John Norman Anderson Wylie, son of Mrs. Amos Kelso Wylie of Rye, N.Y., and the late Lieut. A committed of Lutheran Churches has submitted proposals to the National Conference of Catholic Bishops to extend and amplify recent theological discussions as part of the 450th Reformation Anniversary this year.

PARIS, Feb. 24 Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's Chief of State, said today that the United States would gain prestige and not lose face if it withdrew from Vietnam. He said that even President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam would ask for American aid following such a withdrawal.

CAIRO, Feb. 24 American companies have provided about a quarter of the equipment used in the United Arab Republic's program to build a supersonic jet interceptor for use against Israel, informed sources said yesterday.
BERCHTESGADEN, Germany, Feb. 24 (UPI) Italy's Vittorio Palatinin won the men's downhill race in 2 minutes 38.5 seconds today on the final day of the international deaf athletes ski games.
PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 24 (AP) The plywood market showed a sharp drop this week after six consecutive weeks of advance, the American Plywood Association reported today.
A section of the fuselage of an airliner was blasted out by an "explosive decompression" early yesterday as the craft soared 15,500 feet over New Jersey with nine passengers and a crew of five.
The London Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday in light trading.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 (AP) Cornell overwhelmed Penn, 101-81, tonight in what turned out to be a warm-up for its showdown contest against Princeton tomorrow night for the Ivy League title and the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament bid that goes with it.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 24 'No one ever goes to sleep in New York," Bobby Murcer was saying yesterday.

John W. Lengemann, a civil engineer, who retired in 1951 as head of the design division of the topographical bureau of the Queens Borough President, died Wednesday at his home, 84-33 165th Street, Jamaica, Queens. His age was 88.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 24--Twenty-four cadets have resigned and 24 others are under investigation in a new cheating scandal at the Air Force Academy, the Academy disclosed today.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 24 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress party lost control of a third state today in returns from the nationwide elections. The partys position continued to deteriorate in elections for the national Parliament as well.
DETROIT, Feb. 24 (AP) General Motors has begun calling back thousands of production workers laid off after an Ohio parts plant wildcat strike.

MANILA, Feb. 24 (AP) Speaker Jose B. Laurel Jr. of the House of Representatives said tonight he believed the United States Ambassador to the Philippines, William McCormick Blair Jr. should be declared "persona non grata" or be recalled by the State Department.
The stock market held on to a narrow gain yesterday after an afternoon retreat trimmed advances made in early trading.
Victor Borge, the pianist and humorist, will be honored Wednesday at a luncheon to be given by the Women's Division of the United Jewish Appeal.
A.L. Alexander, moderator of radio's "Good Will Court" in the nineteen-thirties, died Thursday night in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 127 West 79th Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) President Johnson announced today that Vice Adm. John S. McCain Jr. would relieve Adm. John S. Thach as commander of United States Naval Forces in Europe.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 24 The Rand Development Corporation expected to realize an annual income of $50-million, based on the sale of its cancer vaccine, a New York securities analyst for D.H. Blair Co., testified here today.
Orville S. Carpenter, trustee in reorganization for the Westec Corporation, has retained Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co. to make a study for prospective buyers of Westec's subsidiaries.

The State Senate's rush passage this week of a bill prohibiting defamatory religious and ethnic remarks in public was more an expression of legislative mindlessness than of meaningful concern for brotherhood.
Prices moved irregularly yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, winding up the day with an almost even mixture of gains and losses.

Mr. and Mrs. Max Edmund Poritz have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Freddagayle Poritz, to Steven Harris Levenherz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Levenherz. Both families are Brooklyn residents.
Marc Chagall went to City Hall to get his medal yesterday.

Hildarene Harris walked quietly along the linoleum in the darkened hallway of her fourth-floor walk-up apartment in Brooklyn yesterday, turned into a tiny bedroom and placed a 5-pound 5-ounce baby in a crib.

OTTAWA, Feb. 24 (AP) A Royal commission gave the House of Commons today recommendations for a major revision of Canadian tax laws designed to spread the tax burden, eliminate inequities and spur investment.

DETROIT, Feb. 24 (UPI) A wildcat strike, which crippled most of General Motors' car production and production cutbacks by other automobile makers, sliced production this week to its lowest level of the year, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
Three high school seniors said they rode the subways for 23 hours on Thursday, passing through every station in the system, to break the record set by three Princeton students by 28 minutes.

DENVER, Feb. 24 (AP) The Denver Post Said in a copyrighted article today that the Central Intelligence Agency used a Denver-based labor organization "to pump hundreds of thousands of dollars into undercover activities in Latin America and the Middle East."
TORONTO, Feb. 24 (AP) Bob Seagren won the pole vault at the Maple Leaf Games tonight with a leap of 16 feet 8 inches, but failed to break his own indoor record of 17-3.
MADRID, Feb. 24 Spain and the Soviet Union signed a general shipping agreement in Paris Feb. 17, it was announced here today.

BALTIMORE, Saturday, Feb. 25 (AP) At least eight persons, including seven children, died late last night in a fire at a two-story brick row house in the suburban Eastpoint section, hospital authorities said.
BRIDGEWATER, Mass., Saturday, Feb. 25--The man who says he is the "Boston Strangler" escaped with two other inmates yesterday from the Massachusetts Correctional Institution here.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24 A group of at least 50 New Orleans businessmen each pledged $100 a month today to District Attorney Jim Garrison's investigation into an alleged conspiracy that culminated in the assassination of President Kennedy.
GROSSE POINTE FARMS, Mich., Feb. 24 Miss Carol Ann Cawthra was married this evening to John Stuart Wood. The Rev. George Kurz performed the 7:30 ceremony at the St. James Lutheran Church.
One of those things that machines can do to men a machine did yesterday to 28year-old Don Gaon, of Forest Hills, Queens.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 24 (UPI) A 22-year-old blonde married her childhood sweetheart tonight although he was half a world away and the honeymoon will have to wait.

A two-year-old middle-income housing project administered by the city has wide cracks running from floor to ceiling, falling plaster and loose ceramic tiles, and blasts of hot air coming from cracks near incinerators.
RESIDENTS of low-income public housing or ancient railroad flats do not usually call in a decorator when they have home furnishings problems.

LOS ANGELS, Feb. 24 (UPI) Lew Alcindor, who came close to not playing because of an upset stomach, led topranked University California, Los Angeles, to its 22d straight victory tonight as the Bruins defeated Washington, 71-43.
MAIMI, Feb. 24 A buoy broke loose in 20-knot winds on Biscayne Bay today and forced shortening of the annual Comet Class mid-winter sailing championships from five races to three.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 24 Record sales of ready-towear apparel were recorded at Israel's third Fashion Week, which closed here yesterday.

In the national stocktaking that is going on in no very amiable way in Britain today, two issues are coming to the surface: the position of "the public schools," i.e., private prep schools; and the related problem of "Oxbridge."
The stockholders of the Continental Telephone Corporation and the Superior Cable Corporation approved at separate meetings yesterday a merger of Superior into Continental.
The tempo of baggage handling by longshoremen on Pier 88 on the Hudson River was adagio yesterday, rather than the customary presto.

JACKSONVILLE, N.C., Feb. 24 (UPI) The 17-year-old daughter of a retired Marine Corps major was found beaten and stabbed to death on a wooded path today and the son of the deputy sheriff who discovered her body was charged with rape and murder.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The Federal Government moved its campaign against protein malnutrition out of the laboratory for the first time today.

Botswana, the poor southern African nation known as Bechuanaland until it became independent Sept. 30, learned yesterday it has copper one of the most sought-after base metals of the industrialized world.
DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 24 (AP) A practical device can be built to prevent aerial collisions, a national meeting on the problem of such crashes was assured.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 24 The Indonesian Government won agreement in principle today on a long-term, low-interest loan of $200-million to tide it over a projected foreign exchange deficit this year.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24 Jim Garrison's style is the "big splash, "that of the big man who does things in a big way.
Sir John Gielgud has been signed for Paramount's romantic comedy, "Mr. Sebastian," to be shot in England. Dirk Bogarde and Susannah York will co-star.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 The president of the General Motors Corporation predicted here today that car sales in the United States would be between 8.3 million and 8.6 million units in the 1967 model year somewhat below earlier estimates.
A fire destroyed the Tremont Methodist Church at Washington Avenue and 178th Street, the Bronx, early this morning.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Feb. 24 Mr, and Mrs. Robert Rimsky have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rena Lynn Rimsky, to Edward Joseph Wing. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice John Wing of Port Washington. An August wedding is planned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) Fred B. Black Jr., a business associate of Robert G. Baker, brought a $5-million suit today against the Government and a Washington hotel because his suite had been bugged by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Renata Scotto will sing her first Violetta here in the Metropolitan Opera performance of Verdi's "La Traviata" on Thursday, March 30. In Ponchielli's "La Gioconda" on Monday, March 27, Ruza Pospinov will sing her first La Cieca at the Met.
Color television made a major contribution to the record sales and second highest annual earnings of the Admiral Corporation last year, the report disclosed yesterday.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 23 A visitor to Jamaica this week could step on to a beach in Montego Bay and get a smile, a daiquiri, a beach chair and a feeling that he was wanted.
MIAMI, Feb. 24 A field of 12 horses has been named for the Hialeah Turf Cup, the main attraction on the program for tomorrow, the final Saturday card of the Hialeah meeting.
IN Bangkok, few young Thai women take the time to wrap the chakri any more. In Karachi, many women no longer wear the traditional Pakistani kameez that gave the western chemise its name.
Braulio Baeza, feeling "like brand new," returned to Florida yesterday to resume the chauffeur's job that last year earned him more than $300,000.
SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 24 Theodore E. Obrig, an early developer of contact lenses, died at the Sarasota Memorial Hospital yesterday. He was 72 years old.
THE National Antiques Show that opened at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday is reminiscent of the Paris Flea Market before that treasure trove became fashionable.
The first case of paralytic polio contracted in the city since 1964 has been reported to the Department of Health.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 24 Mrs. Dorothy Crane Marston, widow of Russel Marston, who had been president of the Lawyers Mortgage Corporation of New York, died today at Nassau Hospital in Mineola. She was 71 years old and lived at 9 Franklin Court West.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 Mrs. Frederic C. Bold Jr. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Meredith Myers Higley to Capt. John W. Lyon of the Marine Corps. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Jefferson Lyon of Glen Ridge, N.J., and Lake Gerard, N.J. Miss Higley is the daughter also of Lorenzo S. Higley Jr. of Balboa Island, Calif.
Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli repeated his Philharmonic Hall concert of Nov. 2 last night at Carnegie Hall with much the same effect.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 24 (AP) Ernesto Miranda, whose original conviction was overturned by the United States Supreme Court in a historic opinion, was found guilty of kidnapping and rape for the second time today.
VANCOUVER, B.C. The mood of British Columbia's volatile lumber industry has shifted from uneasiness to modest optimism in view of the pickup in housing starts in the United States and Canada.

At Lincoln Center today: New York Philharmonic Young People's Concerts, Philharmonic Hall, noon and 2:30 P.M.; "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, 2; "Carmen," New York City Opera, State Theater, 2:15; "Peter Grimes," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "Tosca," New York City Opera, State Theater, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Revenue freight generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the week ended February 18 was an estimated 14.1 billion ton-miles a 2.8 per cent increase over the corresponding 1966 week.

PENNSBORO, W. Va., Feb. 24 (AP) The Baltimore Ohio Railroad's crack National Limited jumped the tracks in a rural area of north-central West Virginia today, killing four persons and injuring 78 others.
The spot rate on the British pound closed 4 points lower yesterday, at $2.7925, after moderate trading on foreignexchange markets here. Sterling for Tuesday was quoted at about $2.7923.
Dr. HOLLIS S. INGRAHAM likes apple pie. And his wife likes to cook what he likes. So she has baked him 8,000 apple pies in the 36 years they have been married.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 24 (UPI) Federal District Judge James F. Gordon dismissed today a $2-million libel suit filed against The Courier-Journal, the Louisville Times Company, Inc., and WHAS, Inc., by former Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker of Dallas.

BONN, Feb. 24 Three former Hitlerite officials were sentenced in Munich today to prison terms ranging from 5 to 15 years for complicity in the murder of more than 90,000 Dutch Jews during World War II.

Mrs. Mabel Limburg Rossbach, for many years a leader in charitable, educational and hospital activities, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in her apartment at the Ritz Tower Hotel, Park Avenue and 57th Street.
TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) The road to the Tampa Dixie international tennis championship continued to be a rocky one today.

Treasury securities prices advanced yesterday for the first time in a week, bolstered by purchases made by Federal agencies in an effort to keep the national debt below the $330-billion ceiling imposed by Congress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Wholesale prices declined twotenths of 1 per cent this month, a preliminary report by the Labor Department disclosed today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 (UPI) Dan Colchico was signed as a defensive coach for the 49ers today after he failed to obtain medical clearance to play again for San Francisco.
The stockholders of Universal Controls, Inc., failed yesterday at a special meeting in Towson, Md., to approve a onefor-three reverse split of the common shares.
An argument involving two girls in a Yorkville discotheque early yesterday led to a gun battle in which a man was killed and two others critically injured.
Mayor Lindsay was startled yesterday when he opened his weekly news conference for questions and heard a reporter say, "Thank you, Mr. Mayor," the traditional signal for the end of the conference.

The Gulf Oil Corporation said yesterday it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed secondary offering of 1,518,800 capital shares a block valued at $93.4-Million.

While President Johnson's efforts to build bridges to the East are frustrated by Congressional resistance, Moscow continues to score successes in its simultaneous program of building bridges to the West, East and South.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 24 (AP) Wilt Chamberlain recorded a perfect field-goal percentage and poured in 42 points tonight as the Philadelphia 76ers crushed the Baltimore Bullets, 149-118, in a National Basketball Association game.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 24 The local Snow Bowl's maintenance crew dug out of yesterday's blustery 12-inch snowstorm just in time to permit the 36th annual Middlebury College Winter Carnival to start on schedule this morning.
Mrs. Cristina Chace Capehart, widow of Capt. Everett Dole Capehart, U.S.N., died Thursday at her home, 135 East 54th Street. Her age was 70.

MADRID, Feb. 24 The Spanish Government was reported tonight to be studying legal means for canceling a contract with the University of Massachusetts for the publication of manuscripts of Leonardo da Vinci housed in the Madrid National Library.

As a newspaperman for nearly half a century Otto Tolischus had a commitment to the search for truth that was complete and unremitting. Whether as reporter or news executive, or in the foreign correspondence and editorial writing to which he devoted his later years, he was never content until he had nailed down the last fact.
CANTON, N.Y., Feb. 24 Capt. Gary Croteau and Don D'Angelo each scored three goals tonight to lead St. Lawrence to a 10-1 hockey victory over Merrimack.

Returning to competition after undergoing an operation on his injured ankle, Manuel Santana of Spain will compete in the Vanderbilt international indoor tennis tournament here next week in the Grand Central Terminal Building.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 24 (AP) About 800 students demonstrated today in support of a warning by the University of Wisconsin's chancellor that he would seek police help to control further disorderly antiwar demonstrations.
THE dance series of the Brooklyn Academy of Music continued last night with a concert by Norman Walker and his Dance Company, when Mr. Walker gave the premiere of a new work, "Eloges."
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 24 A best-selling book, "How to Avoid Probate!" by Norman F. Dacey was attacked in a pamphlet published today by the Connecticut Bar Association.

A LITTLE-PUBLICIZED change in policy at Amer ican Telephone and Telegraph seems to have caught at least part of the investment community by surprise and may have made the shares of the world's largest private corporation a bit more appealing.
BONN, Feb. 24 Violent winds swept northern Europe last night and early today, killing more than 40 people. The toll may rise as strong winds continue to pound coastal areas.

MADRID, Feb. 24 Eleven coal miners ended this afternoon their five-and-a-half-day protest sit-in at the bottom of a 1,000-foot mine shaft in Asturias Province in northern Spain and were immediately placed under detention at a hospital.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)--The Shipbuilders Council of America has complained that the Navy ignored United States builders in purchasing 15 steel barges for use in Vietnam.
Arcadia, Calif. Feb. 24 (AP) The strong combination of Pretense and Bill Shoemaker was installed today as the 9-5 favorite in tomorrow's $145,000 Santa Anita Handicap.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Feb. 24 Trustees of the Pennsylvania State University tonight formally authorized university officials to continue participation in the National Defense Student Loan Program.

A CONVENTION that has grown in popularity among tournament players is the Jacoby Transfer Bid. A response of two diamonds to one no-trump indicates a long heart suit, and a response of two hearts similarly shows spades.
The election of Hendon Chubb 2d as a director was announced here yesterday by the Vigilant Insurance Company.

LUCAYA-FREEPORT, Gran Bahama, Feb. 24 Chubasco, a powerful 66-foot sloop improving with age, continued her boat-for-boat domination of the 1967 Southern Ocean Racing Conference tonight by being first to finish in the MiamiLucaya yach race.

PANAMA, Feb. 24 (AP) Bert Weaver of Broadwater Beach, Miss., fired an eagle and six birdies today and catapulted into a four-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the 72-hole Panama open gulf championship.
In dull trading, early selling dropped wheat prices about 3 cents a bushel yesterday. However, a late rally took prices above the previous day's levels at the close.
The Air Transport Association has reported a 20.4 per cent increase in domestic airline traffic last month over January.

HARRISON, N.Y., Feb. 24 Miss Patricia Adelaar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Adelaar, was married this afternoon to Roger Wolfe Norian of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Norian of Chicabo. Rabbi Lawrence Schwartz performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.
ATLANTA, Feb. 24 (AP) Joe Torre signed his 1967 contract with the Atlanta Braves today for a salary reported at $65,000, making him the highest paid catcher in the National League.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)--The Air Force Chief of Staff says he removed Maj. Gen. Jerry D. Page from command of the Air War College because he showed a "lack of sound judgment" in that post.

Borough President Abe Stark filed suit yesterday in State Supreme Court seeking to block the establishment of a state narcotics treatment center in the Central Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, in downtown Brooklyn.
AUCKLAND, N.Z., Feb. 24 (AP) Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., is bowling them over on the professional tennis tour.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24 The New York Mets lost a pitcher and gained a pitcher today, even before a player had arrived for spring training or a baseball had been thrown.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) President Johnson paid tribute today to Roy A. Roberts, former president of the Kansas City Star Company, who died on Thursday at the age of 79.

The District Attorney of Queens said yesterday that the high incidence of violent crime was linked to the failure of Congress and the Legislature to provide adequate control over the sale of firearms.
PEKING, Feb. 24 (Agence France-Press) The formation of a national political party made up of opponents of the Communist party chairman, Mao Tse-tung, was reported today by wall posters here.

Manhattan College, with Joe Kearney, Brian Kivlan and Del Benjamin playing heroic roles, unexpectedly won the team title last night in the 25th annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track and field championships.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 24--Brown led all the way tonight in defeating Dartmouth, 70-63, in an Ivy League game.

Governor Rockefeller's proposal to put most New York wage-earners under a compulsory hospital insurance program seems to have undergone a strange transformation on its way to the Legislature.

The Group of Ancient Drama's production of Euripides's "The Bacchants" at the Library and Museum of Performing Arts, Lincoln Center, is not the overwhelming experience that a higher-powered, better-financed production might have been.
ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 24 Ghanaians last night celebrated what seemed to be Christmas, New Year's and the anniversary of Kwame Nkrumah's overthrow rolled into one.
The New York International Sport and Camping Show closes a nine-day run at the Coliseum tonight. Dates and floor space have already been allotted to the producer, Paul Rimmeir, for a 1968 encore.
NEWARK, Del, Feb. 25 (AP)-- Terry Donnelly, running the mile, led a powerful William and Mary team that dominated the first annual Delaware Eastern invitation track meet here today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Feb. 26--American warships have begun shelling North Vietnamese rail yards, ammunition storage areas and other links in the supply trail leading toward South Vietnam, the United States command reported today.

TOKYO, Feb. 25 (AP)-- Wall posters in Peking quoted by Japanese correspondents, suggest that China appears to be suffering from a shortage of red cloth as a result of heavy demand for arm hands, ribbons and flags since the Cultural Revolution began last August.

THE career of Paul Klee was in some respects a paradoxical one. Miss Jane Elizabeth Baird of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Allen Baird of Menasha, Wis., was married yesterday afternoon to Alan Resnick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Edwin Resnick of Brooklyn.

The private house may be coming back on Manhattan's East Side, reversing a trend of three decades in which large numbers of town houses were converted to use by more than a single family.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 25--Three American civilians, convicted last summer of South Vietnamese currency-law violations, were released from a Saigon prison today, the United States Embassy said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) --The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that an electrical malfunction was the "most likely source" of the fire that killed three astronauts in the Apollo I space capsule during a ground test last month.

THE quest for the perfeet "Swan Lake" has become, in dance circles, something like the quest for the Holy Grail. LAGOS, Nigeria--Island-hopping vacationists have led the tourist invasion of West Africa. Indeed, the Canary Islands and Madeira have served as stepping-stones to the beach resorts on the mainland hereabouts.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 25 --Four goals and two assists by Wayne Small, a wing, sparked Brown to an 8-6 victory over Princeton today at Baker Rink.
The Taconic Foundation, through which the late Mr. and Mrs. Stephen P. Carrier carried out many of their philanthropies, is expected to elect a new president within three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25-- There has been too much emphasis on the military value of the merchant marine and not enough on its economic value, James W. Gulick, Acting Ma- rine Administrator told a group, of maritime labor men this week.

SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 25 --Although there has been an upsurge recently in North Korean raids on American and South Korean troops across the Korean Demilitarized Zone, no one in military circles here seems to think that the increased Communist attacks are indicative of any major attempt to disrupt the 14-year-old Korean armistice.
At 12:30 P.M. last Tuesday, Thomas L. Stix kissed his secretary good-by and left his office for good, ending an 36-year career as an agent for people who appear on radio or television.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Wagner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Wagner of Jackson Heights, Queens was married yesterday noon to Francis C. Dougherty, son of Mrs. Frank J. Dougherty of Newtonville, Mass., and the late Mr. Dougherty.

Horace Mann won the wrestling championship of the Ivy Preparatory School League yesterday at the Riverdale school with 61 points. Poly Prep took second place with 42 points and Stony Brook was third with 39 points.

IN all the lofty and stimulating concern over the future of non-commercial television, there has been a persistent and ill-considered disregard of an older and equally deserving medium: non-commercial radio.

A new East German play based on Mark Twain's "A Connecticut Yankee at King Arthur's Court" is being used by the East German Communist party to warn followers of a Western type of socialism that their beliefs are "unreal and impossible."

PARIS Feb. 25--The French Academy has barred from its dictionary the words "score," "goal," "indoor," "doping" and "shoot" in its first skirmish of a war against the invasion of French by foreign words. It reluctantly endorsed "set" and "crack" as words so entrenched in French sportsmen's parlance as to be impossible to purge.
GENEVA--Swiss tourist officials are proclaiming this year their conviction that all travel and no vacation is no life, even for the most determined globe-trotter.
DETROIT, Feb. 25--Senator Charles H. Percy today advocated ratification of the United States-Soviet consular treaty.

PUNTA LAS TUNAS, P.R.--Ninety minutes by car from San Juan, after a drive that skirts picturesque seashore and spreading cane fields, is one of Puerto Rico's little-known prehistoric relics, La Cueva del Indio--the Indian Cave.

Leonard Bernstein brought the 10th season of children's concerts by the New York Philharmonic to a close yesterday with two programs at Philharmonic Hall. He called them "Alumni Reunion" because the three young soloists had gone places since the initial exposure on a former children's concert. A composite of the two programs will be televised by Channel 2 on April 19.

WOODMERE, L.I., Feb. 25-- Mrs. Leonard J. Oppenheimer has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joan L. Oppenheimer, to Mitchell Samuelson of Arlington, Va., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Samuelson of Sherman Oaks, Calif.
Two libraries that frankly expose structural materials in wall, floor and coiling, surfaces will rise soon above small parks in Woodbridge, N.J.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 25 --The marriage of Miss Virginia Arlene VanEss to Airman 3d/CI. Richard Gerard McDermott Jr. took place this morning at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.
VADUZ, Liechtenstein, Feb. 25--This picturebook country has just lost its most famous picture, but very few Liechten- steiners seem upset.

With their eyes on the strong demand these days for longerfibered, high-quality cotton, the members of the New York Cotton Exchange will vote March 6 on a new cotton contract There is little doubt about approval, perhaps even unanimous, since the exchange hopes to revive interest in futures trading in cotton, now dormant.
CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP)--A biting blast of Arctic air sent temperature records tumbling in 15 states from the Canadian border to the Gulf of Mexico today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia-Americans visiting this country are usually surprised, to find that Yugoslavia does not conform to their expectations of a typical Eastern European nation. Frontiers are open without restriction, visas are not required, Customs officials are well-disposed and the people are friendly and helpful.

Gerald Whitmore, whose brother George Whitmore Jr. confessed to three murders three years ago and was freed after repudiating the admissions, was arrested and charged with stabbing a man to death yesterday in a Brooklyn street brawl.

SOFIA, Bulgaria--Until very recently, taking a car through Yugoslavia and Bulgaria to the Middle East was a rugged business for both driver and automobile. The tallest structure believed ever to be constructed of poured-in-place exposedaggregate concrete is being built in Rochester. When completed, it will be the new would headquarters of the Xerox Corporation, manufacturer of duplicating machines, which was established in Rochester.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Feb. 25--An unusual state-supported school has been set up here to counter criticism by many in state and local government that key officials, because of lack of training and education, are incompetent to deal with the complexities of modern public administration.

MOSCOW, Feb. 25--The mood in Moscow toward relations with the united States at the moment is reminiscent of a lull after a long and bitter battle. The hope in Soviet circles is that the lull will turn into a sort of permanent, undeclared cease-fire. But a tense concern lingers Lhat the lull may end abruptly and cold war skirmishing and conflict resume.

THERE is much to commend in Kenneth Eble's critique of contemporary American education and in his suggestions for improving it. His book is a pleasure to read in the way a well designed parkway is a pleasure to drive on: it is smooth, flows easily, and the viewpoints, though never arresting, are pleasing and always in perfect taste. Mr. Eble's writing is skillful, humane and wellmannered.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 25-- The unbeaten Lehigh University wrestlers routed Rutgers 36-7, tonight before a capacity crowd of 3,800 spectators. It was the Engineers' 14th victory in a row, 10 of them this season.

PARIS--The tall, distinguished figure in the black chesterfield moved warily among the cut flowers and greenery and the voluble customers of the Parisian florist shop. A Tony Lema Memorial golf tourney will be held tomorrow at the Marco Island Country Club, Marco Island, Fla. Sam Snead, Jimmy Demaret, Gene Sarazen and Ken Venturi are among the 30 professionals who will join with 90 amateurs in this special one-day event.

BASSETERRE, St. Kitts --A new terminal building at Golden Rock Airport here is the first major step in a program designed to attract Caribbean travelers to this lush British island. THE MARK Hopkins Hotel, since 1926 a land mark on San Francisco's Nob Hill, has been purchased by Loew's Hotels.
