PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 25--George Howe, a real-estate developer in Westchester County for more than 50 years, died yesterday in the United Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at the Westchester Country Club in Rye.

PARIS. CLAUDE LELOUGH is the French cinema's new wonder boy. His Film, "Un Homme et Une Femme," after sharing the divided grand prize at the Cannes Festival last spring, has proved as astonishing hit both at home and abroad.

MIAMI, Feb. 25--War Censor of the Fourth Estate Stable came along at the final jump to nip the North Star Ranch's Greek Jab in the $96,750 Hialeah Turf Cup handicap today. The finish was a sizzler that made the crowd of 25,773 forget the cool, windy 59-degree weather, as three horses in the field of a dozen finished a head and two noses apart.

BEIRUT, Lebanon--On New Year's Eve, 14 Americans and their children arrived at Palmyra, in the Syrian desert, and took over the modest Zenobia Hotel. This establishment lies in the midst of this ancient caravan city, a place once ruled by the queen for whom the hotel is named.

The winner of the new Westchester Golf Classic will receive $50,000, the largest first prize ever awarded in a regulation 72-hole tournament. William H. Jennings, the general chairman, said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP)-- Three groups backed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association lost another round today in an effort to gain membership on the United States Olympic Committee.
Dr. Samuel Soloveichik, associate professor of chemistry at Yeshiva University, died Saturday at Montefiore Hospital the Bronx. He was 58 years old and lived at 480 West 187th Street.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Feb. 26-- Miss Susan Gould Rose and Bruce Arnold Ackerman plan to be married in the spring.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)--Seismic signals similar to those from an atomic blast were detected last night coming from a test range in the Soviet Union, the United States Atomic Energy Commission said today.
Two brothers who had been turned in to the police by their parents pleaded not guilty in Queens Criminal Court yesterday to charges of possession of marijuana, a misdemeanor.

MAURIAC, France, Feb. 26 --Premier Georges Pompidou came home to this spectacularly scenic and spectacularly poor mountain region in south-central France this weekend to tell the voters why they should elect him their deputy to the National Assembly in balloting next Sunday.

NATURE'S Own Fruits has put out a new line of bottled fruits processed without added sugar. The dried fruits--Turkish Smyrna figs, Haitian mango slices, California prunes and a compote-- are packed in water, which draws the natural sugar from the fruits to make a light syrup.
MOLINE, Ill.--Here, where there are five city halls to fight in a metropolitan area of 320,000 residents, a businessman is providing the leadership toward improving local government.

LONDON, Feb. 26--Anthony Crosland, Britain's Minister of Education, said at a Labor party meeting today that "brains move from every country of the world to America" because "America is the richest country in the world and can pay much more for the brains."
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP)--Vice President Humphrey commissioned into service today a $130-million undersea test center that he predicted might become the Cape Kennedy of oceanography.
WASHINGTON, Feb 26-- The deadliest vehicle on the nation's highways is the motorcycle, according to a University of Iowa professor who has made an extensive study of two-wheel machines.
A Gallup poll published yesterday in The World Journal Tribune said that more than two-thirds of the people in the United States favored the continued bombing of North Vietnam.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (AP)--Cliff Anderson scored 32 points and took 32 rebounds in leading St. Joseph's to a 96-83 victory over La Salle today in a Middle Atlantic Con ference game at the Palestra.

Not long ago, the Smith College Art Museum in Northampton, Mass., a neo-Georgian brick building that houses 6,000 objects, including five Courbets, three Monets and three Cezannes, bought an important sculpture by Rodin.

Investors in bonds have a wide selection of new offerings to choose from this week. More than $280-million worth of corporate issues is expected in the market. The Bond Buyer, a trade publication, reports that tax-exempt bonds up for bidding total $238,412,225, up sharply from last week's $130,454,364.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb.26 (UPI) --Frenchmen were one, two in ski jumping at the GarmiscbPartenkirchen Nordic championships today, but Austria won the team title.

ABOARD MINESWEEPING BOAT 16, on the Longtao River, in South Vietnam, Feb. 26 --The six crewmen of this proud little vessel write often to their wives and sweethearts but they seldom mention their work.

"THE Medium Is the Massage"--that's right, "massage"--is an adroit and entertaining effort to massage into our awareness the basic implications of Marshall McLuhan's famous dictum, "the medium is the message."
A report by the Presbytery ofNew York charging that Congress had denied Adam Clayton Powell due process of law because of his race has divided local Presbyterians.
ROME, Feb. 26 (AP)--Giuseppe Paratore, President of the Italian Senate in 1952-53, died at his home here today at the age of 91.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 26--On a gray and chilly day in the winter of his career. Elston Howard ended his mild four-day rebellion against a cut in salary and began his 13th year as a Yankee catcher.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26-- The Defense Department is scheduling production and inventory of military items in a manner designed to prevent a sharp drop in production when the war in Vietnam ends.

A FRIEND of mine once suggested that the most sophisticated symbol in New York was a billboard outside a 42d Street movie house quoting, with calm pride: "Sordid ...Seamy ... Disgusting ....N.Y. Times." Therefore when I suggest that the Martha Graham Dance Company is the most erotic thing in the American theater today, let me make it clear that any voyeurs among you would not find it worth the admission price purely for titillation.
HOUSTON, Feb. 22 (UPI)-- Cassius Clay, heavyweight boxing champion, says he plans to buy real estate in Chicago, Houston and southern Georgia.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26--Like dragon seed, men in baseball uniforms sprouted in the fields of Florida today as spring training camps bustled from Miami to Tampa. And in St. Petersburg, the haven of the aging, the lettering on 30 new uniforms read "New York Mets."
John Griggs, an actor, died Saturday after a long illness. He was 58 years old.

STRATTON MOUNTAIN, Vt., Feb. 26--The Middlebury College Winter Carnival's concluding jumping event was canceled this morning because of high winds. As a result, New England's competitive skiing focus swung to this popular resort for the ninth annual New England Kandahar.
DETROIT, Feb. 26 (UPI)-- Ron Stewart's goal with nine seconds left to play gave the Boston Bruins a 3-3 tie with the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game today.

Freight service in the United States--measured in intercity ton-miles--rose 7.2 per cent for all modes of transportation in 1965, as compared with the 1964 figure, according to the 80th annual report of the Interstate Commerce Committee.
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina warned yesterday that "there are a lot of judges just itching" to impose rules on how much news the police can give to the press in criminal cases.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 26-- Nearly eight months ago, in one of his first moves after the military coup that put him in power. President Juan Carlos Ongania named his brother-inlaw, Enrique Green, as chief of police in Buenos Aires.

TOKYO. Feb. 26 (AP)--Shingoro Takaishi, former president of the large-circulation newspaper Mainichi Shimbun and a member of the International Olympic Committee, died of lung cancer in a hospital here. He was 88 years old.

MISSOULA, Mont., Feb. 26 (UPI)--Karen Budge of Jackson. Wyo., won the women's combined title and Jumeng, Giovanoli of Switzerland took the men's honors today in the United State Alpine ski championships at the Snow Bowl.

THE two-session Open Pair event at the George Washington Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association on Saturday resulted in a triumph for two young players, James Becker of Gloversville, N.Y., and William Esberg of Elberon. N.J. Runners-up were Victor Mitchell and Lloyd Ribner of New York.
Barbra Streisand, who has become one of television's hottest properties, will do her third hour-long color special next fall.
DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 26-- Pat Heuckeroth, a 22-year-old daughter of the club professional, piloted April Showers to the green working hunter championship today at the Ox Ridge horse show.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 26-- S.K. Patil, the tough Congress party leader of Bombay, did some unusually tough talking yesterday.
COLOR television imaginatively used proved a happy complement yesterday to the unpredictable poems of Lawrence Ferlinghetti.
BIMINI, the Bahamas, Feb. 26--Representative Adam Clayton Powell has been told by his lawyers to be quiet for a while.

HINGHAM, Mass., Feb. 26-- Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Tilghman Earle have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Campbell Earle, to Gordon McKay Stevenson Jr., son of Mrs. Stevenson of Summit and Beach Haven, N.J., and the late Dr. Stevenson.

UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 26 (AP) --Mark Sullivan of Buffalo, and Gail Purdy of Saratoga Springs won the titles in the senior men's and women's divisions, respectively, today in the Eastern Seaboard indoor ice skating championship.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 26--Maneuvering began today in the badly weakened Congress party to decide whether Mrs. Indira Gandhi will still be Prime Minister when the new Parliament convenes in April.
HOUSTON, Feb. 26 (AP)-- Joe weingarten, a Polish immigrant who built a $300 investment into a multimillion-dollar grocery chain, died today in a hospital. He was 82 years old.
BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 26 (AP)--A University of California coed plunged to her death from her third-floor apartment last night, shattering her closed window.
Maurice Samuel, author and lecturer, yesterday received the second annual B'nai B'rith Jewish Heritage Award for "excellence in Jewish literature."
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 --Rural electric cooperatives, a key element in the agricultural production revolution of the last three decades, are in a fight for their lives.

There are five women's roles in Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro," and, at yesterday's matinee in the New York State Theater, four of them were taken for the first time by gifted members of the New York City Opera Company.
HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 26--A woman injured in a gas explosion and fire here last night died in Dobbs Ferry Hospital this morning of burns.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP)-- Istvan Gulyas of Hungary defeated Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, the defending champion, in the final of the Dixie International tennis tournament today. A pulled stomach muscle forced Drysdale to quit in the fifth set, with the score 3-6, 6-1, 2-6, 7-5, 2-0.

Women of the ghetto arrive daily in the emergency rooms of the 21 municipal hospitals, often in critical condition, the victims of incomplete abortions induced by crude home remedies and bungling abortionists.

The New York Telephone Company, subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, reported over the weekend gains in 1966 operating revenues and net income. The report also showed a net gain of about 300,000 telephones during the year. The year end total was 10,066,000, against 9,734,000 at the end of 1965. Operating revenues rose ...
The sixth annual Peppermint Ball, a benefit for the Finch College development fund, will be held on March 10 in the Waldorf-Astoria Sert Room.

The American Stock Exchange announced over the weekend the development of a computer-based data retrieval system to provide a broader flow of information on price ranges and volume, as well as to expand its stock-watching activities.

Plans for a $4.5-million reconstruction of the Howard Laboratory, the original research facility of the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research, were announced yesterday by Richard D. Vanderwarker, presdent.

TOKYO, Monaday, Feb. 27-- Mao Tse-tung, Chariman of the Chinese Communist party, and Premier Chou En-lai have accused Maoist groups of having carried out the Cultural Revolution in "bad taste," according to a Japanese report from Peking.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (UPI)-- Henri Richard scored with less than five minutes to play tonight to give the Montreal Canadiens their fifth tie of the season in 11 games with the Chicago Black Hawks, 2-2.
SAIGO, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 27--The United States has begun dropping mines into rivers in North Vietnam, the American command disclosed this morning.

DEERE CO., the farmequipment manufacturer, reported yesterday a rise in its net income for the three months ended Jan. 31 to $15,267,520, or $1.03 a share, compared with $12,803,164, or 92 cents a share, a year earlier.

The city's rent control chief reported yesterday that only 1 per cent of the 1.3 million rent-controlled apartments here have been shown to be legally entitled to an increase. But he added that the city planned a long-range study of the economics of rental housing.

The Inter-American System is taking on a new form, more suited to the late 1960's than the Charter of Bogota of 1948. This is the chief significance of the meetings which have been going on in Buenos Aires. The great question now is whether the substance of hemispheric life can keep pace with the change in form. It is not yet "One Hemisphere."

BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 26-- The Rev. Marvin Pierce Halverson, former executive director of the department of worship and the arts of the National Council of Churches, died Friday at Oakland Hospital. He was 54 years old.
A proposal that fleets of state and Federal motor vehicles be used to test the development of electric cars was voiced yesterday by State Senator Ned J. Parsekian of New Jersey.

Miss Stephanie Adams Wilson, daughter of Mrs. George Homer Wilson of Elmhurst. Queens, and the late Mr. Wilson, was married yesterday to Perry Underhill, son of Mrs. Charles H. Campbell of Forest Hills, Queens, and Cataumet Mass.
CRISP, crunchy, homemade cookies appeal to both young and old. The recipes here are of this type and may be served as a snack with a beverage or as an accompaniment to fruit compote or sherbet.

WASHINGOTN, Feb. 26 (AP) --Barry Goldwater said today that there were six or seven leading candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination and "if front-runners don't win in an early ballot, there may be a dark-horse winner."
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said yesterday that the city was getting ready to add enough new parking meters to collect an additional $2.5million a year from drivers.
A policy-making body of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People proposed yesterday that radical changes be made in the Selective Service apparatus.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) --Senator Joseph S. Clark, Democrat of Pennsylvania, said tonight that his Senate labor subcommittee would open on March 13, "an objective, thorough and bipartisan analysis" of the antipoverty program.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 26--On an evening or a Sunday the elevators leading to the Air Force Academy's faculty offices are blocked by heavy chain gates that roll down from the ceiling six inches in front of the doors.

The American Cyanamid Company announced over the weekend the election of Nolan B. Sommer, former president and general manager of its subsidiary, the Formica Corporation, as a vice president and director of the parent company. Also announced was his appointment to the management and finance committee.

TWIGGY, the 17-year-old British mannequin who measures 31 inches around when she throws out her boyish chest, is coming to New York next month. She has straightened out her difficulty with the British passport office, and the model agency that is booking her appointments with fashion photographers has set her fee at $120 an hour. But by the time Twiggy gets here, she may be obsolete.
DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Feb. 26 (AP)--Harold T. Green, who helped set up the stuffed-animal exhibit at the Philadelphia Museum of Natural Sciences, died today at Doylestown Hospital. He was 70 years old.
A group of three elevator apartment houses on West 12th Street in Greenwich Village, built in 1911 and held in continuous family ownership since then, has been sold to an investor.
LONDON, Feb. 26--Rootes Motors, Ltd., disclosed over the weekend plans to stop indefinitely production of three of its biggest, most expensive cars within four weeks.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 26--A. Philip Randolph has begun to press for the selection of a second Negro to the A.F.L.C.I.O. executive council.
Neal Boenzi, a photographer for The New York Times, was awarded four first prizes last night at the 52d annual awards dinner of the New york Press Photographers Association.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26 --Westfield High School of New Jersey successfully defended its Eastern interscholastic swimming championship last night with a score of 42 points. The runner-up was St. Joseph's of Pennsylvania, with 35.

Net new orders for machine tools--the machines that make machines and, in effect, production lines for all sorts of goods--turned sharply downward in January. In December there was a modest rise in foreign business and the third decline in a row in domestic volume.
MSTISLAV ROSTROPOVICH's second concert in his series of eight at Carnegie Hall last night was a dashing adventure, and it was not only the cellist's playing that made it so.

The Coast Guard was accused yesterday of having employed "unconstitutionally vague" regulations in prohibiting former members of the Communist party from getting credentials that would permit them employment in the merchant marine.

DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 26-- Gordon Gray and Mrs. William G. Symmers, the top-seeded team representing the Greenwich Field Club, successfully defended their American Platform Paddle Tennis Association national mixed-doubles championship today at the Wee Burn Country Club.

The Borough Presidents of the Bronx and Queens proposed additional public works for their home communities yesterday that would swell the projected $1-billion capital budget for the coming year by 15 to 20 per cent.

INZELL, Germany, Feb. 26 (AP)--Cees Verkerk of the Netherlands, the world speedskating champion broke two world records today in winning the 1,500-meter race and the grueling 5,000-meter event at an invitation speed-skating meet.
LANDING ZONE MUSTANG. South Vietnam, Feb. 26 An American patrol probing to the Cambodian border has reported that it watched a squad of armed Vietcong cross from Cambodia into Vietnam.
The American Export Isbrandtsen Company announces the election to its board of T. Keith Glennan, president of Associated Universities, Inc., Washington.

Fifty thousand Americans a year now die as a result of traffic accidents. It took sixteen years for the death toll to rise from 30,000 to 40,000, but only four years for it to reach 50,000. The upward curve must be stopped.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 26-- Striking teachers voted today to return to work tomorrow pending a progress report on negotiations aimed at ending their 12-day walkout.
The American Chicle Company said last night that elements of its office operations would be shifted this spring from Queens to Morris Plains, N.J.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 26-- A meeting of American chiefs of state is to take place from April 12 to 14 in the Uruguayan seaside resort of Punta del Este, it was announced officially today, but there were indications that two of the Presidents would not attend.
THE man at the piano smiled amiably at his guest, who was removing her snow-covered boots just inside the entrance to the living room.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 26--Miss Joann Osborn of Washington and Frederick J. Willman of New York were married this afternoon at the home of the bridegroom's parents. Mr. and Mrs. Elias C. Willman. Essex County Court Judge Leon W. Kapp of East Orange, performed the ceremony.
New charges were hurled at the Waterfront Commission by longshore leaders yesterday in a growing dispute over the allocation of their respective powers.
